headline: The Bartender Appears to Be Shaken Up
text: “WHEN we first started Varnish, we began sustaining a bunch of injuries,” Marcos Tello said. “I had a huge, constant knot in my forearm. Chris Ojeda developed tennis elbow. Matty Eggleston popped a tendon in his hand. We were all sidelined with all these injuries.”

headline: Port Is a Welcome Guest at Cocktail Parties
text: ASK me about port and I’ll tell you I love it. I have fond memories of the sumptuous flavors of a well-aged vintage port, and, even more so, the delicate, subtle pleasures of a 20-year-old tawny. Alas, these delights reside mostly in the past. I almost never drink port anymore.

headline: The Bartender Played With Fire
text: THE whole aesthetic  some might say shtick  of Apothéke, the haute bar sequestered in a mysterious time warp of Chinatown, was pharmaceutical from the moment it opened. Bartender-slash-alchemists in white lab coats decocted botanical-and-herb-infused libations from great laboratory beakers. On certain evenings, the main medicine man himself, Albert Trummer, stood in the back bar lined with classic Latin-labeled druggist vials and soothed grateful patrons with curative elixirs and stress-relievers, even as he mesmerized them with his mixological rituals.

headline: Beers From Near and Far in New East Village Store
text: David Cichowicz, left, is pursuing his passion for beer in an East Village storefront with more than 400 labels, from Germany, Belgium, Britain and the United States. His domestic selections emphasize craft beers, especially from the Northeast. Unlike a wine shop, which cannot run a bar on the premises, or a wine bar, which cannot sell bottles to go, Mr. Cichowicz’s Good Beer Store is legally allowed to do both — and it does. Amid the shelves and refrigerated cases, he has a small bar area, with tables, where he dispenses a rotating inventory of 12 beers on tap, and serves plates of meats, sausages and cheeses.

headline: Polish Vodka Arrives With a Wisp of Grass
text: To those who know their vodka, zubrowka (pronounced zu-BROV-ka) is legendary. It’s a Polish vodka, said to have been made since the Middle Ages, seasoned with bison grass, or zubrowka, a plant that grows in a northern region of Poland where the now-endangered European bison graze. But the federal Food and Drug Administration does not allow authentic zubrowka to be imported because bison grass contains a blood thinner.

Not really, because he was a quick study and he learned from the best in the business, Monet.

headline: The Pentagon, Pursuing Justice
text: After nine months of study and regular leaks, the Pentagon’s report on repealing the “don’t ask, don’t tell” law was hardly a surprise. Most soldiers long ago came to terms with the thorough and frank report’s conclusion that allowing gay men and lesbians to serve openly poses little risk. Only 30 percent of the serving military believes that open service would be harmful, and even most naysayers agree that they have long served with gay and lesbian colleagues to no ill effect.

It’s about time.

headline: Travel Gifts From $10 to $60
text: SHOPPING for travel gifts after being on the road for five months brings on an acute state of something that is best described as the opposite of buyer’s remorse. It turns out that products abound that could have made many moments of my trip more pleasant and, in some cases, more frugal, too. Those icky sheets in a Guatemalan hotel room? Turns out that I didn’t have to touch them. That bottle of Argentine red that I delicately wrapped in a sweater? There was something better I could have put it in. And the cellphone that took a split-second dip in Brazilian waters? Well, a device could have sucked the moisture right out of it.

headline: Dodging Those Pesky Airline Fees

For most, I used a simple criterion: would they have been useful to me in the six months that I have been the Frugal Traveler?

headline: Wisconsin: Young Gunman Is Dead After Standoff at High School
text: A student who held his social studies class hostage for several hours died at a hospital on Tuesday, the result of a self-inflicted gunshot wound that ended the standoff, the authorities said. The student, Samuel O. Hengel, 15, entered his classroom at Marinette High School in northeastern Wisconsin on Monday with two handguns and ammunition, trapping 25 other students and a teacher inside. After hours of waiting  and what turned into a conversation about hunting and fishing, students said  several students were allowed to leave the room. Law enforcement officials were entering the room when the student shot himself, they said. No one else was injured. The teenager was described as a good student who said little during the standoff about what was troubling him.

headline: Dueling Beauty Pageants Put Income Gap on View

Women in miniskirts and men in pressed guayaberas danced at Jet-Set magazine’s fete in this city’s Naval Museum, as the candidates for Miss Colombia sashayed about, flashing perfect smiles and impossibly high cheekbones.

headline: Israel: Easing of Gaza Blockade Did Little, Report Says
text: A group of 22 international human-rights and aid groups issued a report on Tuesday asserting that Israel’s easing of its blockade of Gaza five months ago had made little difference to the people living there. The groups, including Amnesty International and Save the Children, said that construction material was still trickling in and that exports remained banned, meaning that the Palestinian coastal strip could not recover from Israel’s three-week war there two years ago. Israel responded that the report was distorted. It said that nearly twice the amount of goods were going into Gaza compared with earlier this year.

headline: China: U.S. Embassy Blocked From Geologist’s Hearing
text: The United States Embassy was denied access to an appeal hearing for an American geologist sentenced in July to eight years in prison for buying a database on China’s oil industry, an American official said in Beijing on Tuesday. The official, Robert Goldberg, the embassy’s deputy chief of mission, said that the embassy had made a formal request to attend the hearing of the geologist, Xue Feng. The request was denied, he said, even though Dr. Xue is entitled to consular representation. Mr. Goldberg said the embassy had filed a formal protest. Asked about the complaint at a news conference, an official, Hong Lei, said, “The Chinese judicial authorities will handle the case according to law and continue to fulfill our obligations according to the China-U.S. treaty on consular affairs.”

headline: Brazil: Extended Troop Presence Sought for Rio Slums
text: The governor of Rio said he asked Brazil’s Defense Ministry to maintain about 2,000 troops until next October in two slum areas that were cleared of drug traffickers by the police and the military over the last week. The governor, Sérgio Cabral, had asked for troops to continue patrolling Complexo do Alemão and Vila Cruzeiro for the next seven months, but he said on Brazilian radio that he revised his request to give more time for the military police to form a new community policing unit. Cmdr. Carlos Chagas, a spokesman for the Brazilian Marines, said Tuesday that the marines had still not received a request for an extended troop presence.

headline: Phys Ed: Why Wii Fit Is Best for Grandparents
text: With the Christmas video-game-buying season in full swing, now seems the right time to ask, Are active video games being aimed, at least in part, at the wrong audience? Active video games refer, of course, to games that require you to be active. Often also called exergames, they include the Wii Fit, Dance Dance Revolution from Konami and the new Microsoft Xbox Kinect and Sony PlayStation Move systems, among others. Depending on the game, they exhort players to hop, wriggle, serve and volley, left-hook a virtual boxing opponent or, in some other fashion, move. The underlying premise of these games is that, unlike Madden NFL 11 or Super Street Fighter IV, playing them should improve people’s fitness and health.

headline: So, Do You Like Owning a Restaurant?

headline: Seeing the Light
text: For those of you who have considered hoarding incandescent light bulbs before they’re phased out for good in 2014, you might want to hold off on renting that storage space. General Electric’s Energy Smart LED bulb goes on sale on Wednesday on the company’s Web site. The nine-watt bulb is not only energy-efficient — it produces the same amount of light as a 40-watt incandescent bulb (higher-wattage models are in the works) with 77 percent less power — but is also omnidirectional, unlike earlier generations of LED bulbs, which shed light in one direction only. Its 22,500-hour life span is twice that of a compact fluorescent bulb, and it contains no mercury. GE claims that one bulb will last 22.8 years, and GE’s  Energy Smart microsite, designed by the New York firm Doyle Partners, makes the point by following a girl from infancy to her wedding day, with the same light illuminating each scene. The bulb’s $50 price tag may give sticker shock to all but early adopters. But considering its long life and its incandescent-quality white light — not to mention GE’s assertion that if every American household bought just one, we’d save almost $400 million in energy costs and prevent five billion pounds of greenhouse gas emissions in one year — the bulb could turn out to be a good investment in more ways than one.

headline: Behind Serbia’s Rise in Tennis, a Star and His Family

headline: Hydraulic Fracturing in the Spotlight

headline: Jamie Dimon: America’s Least-Hated Banker
text: Back in 2004, way before the mortgage bust and before Americans thought of banks as four-letter words, Jamie Dimon took charge of JPMorgan Chase & Company. Known as a tough, hands-on manager, Dimon was supposed to avert the sort of foolish risks that tempted so many of his peers. And sure enough, he was different.Instead of reviewing brief summaries of the bank’s operations, as his predecessor had, Dimon demanded to see the raw data — hundreds of pages detailing J. P. Morgan’s businesses every month. Instead of simply trusting his traders, Dimon put himself through a tutorial, so that he would understand the complex trades the bank was exposed to. And rather than run its mortgage machine at full throttle for as long as possible, Dimon reined in lending earlier than did others and warned his shareholders of looming trouble.

headline: Police in Spain and Thailand Arrest 10 in Qaeda-Linked Ring
text: MADRID  The police in Spain and Thailand arrested 10 people suspected of operating a counterfeiting network that provided fake European passports to terrorist groups linked to Al Qaeda in order to smooth their entry into Western countries, the Spanish Interior Ministry said Wednesday.

headline: The Shrill Has Moved To Europe
text: I’ve been reading Kevin O’Rourke at the Irish Economy blog, watching with astonishment and admiration as the mild-mannered economic historian becomes Isaiah, righteously denouncing what has been passing for responsible policy. Now the even more usually mild-mannered Barry Eichengreen weighs in, calling it what it is: reparations imposed on an innocent public.

headline: Reign Of Error
text: Oh, well. Sewell Chan has an article about the rising influence of conservative economists; what he doesn’t point out is so far that these guys have been wrong about everything. They’re prospering because their political faction is prospering, not because their economic doctrines have proved correct or even plausible.

headline: The Biggest Boat
text: Royal Caribbean’s newest cruise ship, the Allure of the Seas, is not just big. It is the biggest cruise ship in the world, and as such it crashes magnificently against the tide of the zeitgeist: There is very little sustainable, small-batch, or boutique about it. The ship weighs 225,000 gross tons, consumes 4.7 million pounds of fresh water per day, and enjoys 1.6 million square feet of air conditioned space. At 1,187 feet long, the Allure of the Seas is precisely five centimeters longer than its sister ship, launched in 2009, the paradoxically-named Oasis of the Seas.

headline: Dancing All the Way to the Ziegfeld, and Maybe Oscar
text: “Freaking Ziegfeld!” Darren Aronofsky, Coney Island boy made good, shouted at the premiere of his film “Black Swan” on Tuesday night, although he used a more Brooklyn-y word. Mr. Aronofsky could be forgiven for crowing. “Black Swan,” the dark, fantastical story of a perfectionist ballerina, was, by his own admission, a difficult film to make, and his first to have its premiere at the Ziegfeld, the grand movie palace in Midtown Manahattan which he frequented while growing up. (“Mom, I have a confession – I cut out of high school to see ‘Raiders of the Lost Ark’ in this theater,” he said from the front, and later confided to the Bagger that it wasn’t a one-time thing.) “Black Swan” felt and played big to its hometown crowd, who could be heard shrieking and shuddering at the more macabre moments. “The Red Shoes” it’s not.

They’ll be in stores in mid-December, perfect timing for the annual holiday cavalcade of cinema. headline: World Cup 2022: A View From Long Island
text: Which nation will be selected on Thursday by FIFA to host the 2022 World Cup? You have read all the oh-so-serious analyses, so here is a different take.Australia … Great place, very lovely kangaroos, nice people with weird accents, sports enthusiasts, socceroos and the oh-so-lovely Matilda calendar girls, but it’s Down Under and halfway around the world. That makes for a difficult TV viewing schedule for those in Europe and elsewhere, and FIFA wants the big-time TV revenues. If they should get selected, don’t schlep there just to see some soccer games, you can buy their steaks at Outback, Uggs at Zappos and save on the air fare.

headline: Parity for Women in Theater Is Focus of Symposium
text: When the playwrights Julia Jordan and Sarah Schulman discovered a couple of years ago that New York’s nonprofit subscription theaters were producing plays by men more than five times as frequently as ones by women, they organized a meeting for women playwrights to air their grievances. A year later, four members of the Dramatists Guild of America – Barbara Masry, Cynthia Cooper, Catherine Gropper and Andy Landis – formed the Women’s Initiative. On Saturday afternoon the group is holding a symposium, “Women in Theater: Achieving Gender Parity,” at the Players Club in Manhattan.

headline: All I Want for Christmas: Muggs
text: Last night, my favorite sports commentators, Tony Kornheiser and Michael Wilbon, on “Pardon the Interruption,” tussled over the merits of men in Uggs, now that Tom Brady, quarterback of the New England Patriots and husband of Gisele, has endorsed a man pair of the boots. Wilbon tried to sound positive, citing an obscure tradition of “house shoes” for men. Kornheiser winced: “House shoes?” I sense that Kornheiser saw a man in a different end zone. As it is, Brady’s wife won’t let him cut his hair. So Brady keeps saying. I just want to see the cameras pan from Coach Bill Belichick’s frowning face down to his Muggs.

headline: Year of the Couturière
text: With the Chinese buying cars by the tens of thousands every week — big cars, too — and throwing up new buildings, driving in Beijing is no lark. It was an hour before Guo Pei and her husband, Cao Bao Jie, reached the headquarters of Rose Studio, their fashion company, on the city’s north side. The October sun was blazing pale when their Mercedes pulled up to a low-rise office complex, its white brick rendered shabby by newer developments. Cao, a stocky, good-looking Taiwanese man who goes by the name Jack, had been kneeling the whole time next to the driver; facing his wife, who sat in the back; and translating from Chinese into English. Now he sort of backed out of the car. Guo Pei, whose career as a fashion designer began when there was no fashion in her country, remained a study in Asian poise and etiquette. In addition to large eyes and delicate features, enhanced by careful makeup, she has a gentleness unmarred by circumstance. These circumstances include wealth and a list of clients in Beijing’s highest political, media and social circles. But as Jack said proudly, ‘‘Guo Pei is a very traditional lady — a wonderful wife and daughter and mother who always cares more about her family than the attention she receives.’’

headline: Formal Talks Start, at Last, on Tax Cuts

The film, about a lesbian couple and their family from Lisa Cholodenko, received five Independent Spirit Award nominations to go with its two Gotham Independent Film Award nods. A strategic holiday DVD release date of Nov. 16 has been beneficial, but the months-long publicity campaign to keep the movie in the public eye has also helped.

headline: Last Time New York Had Just 27 House Seats? The City Was on the Rise

The present tempestuous state of the world does not encourage us to expect a long season of uninterrupted fair weather.”

headline: Do You Do Background Checks on Job Candidates?
text: In a case study we’ve just published, Dalia Fahmy writes about OfficeDrop, a two-year-old document-scanning company based in Boston. Prasad Thammineni, chief executive, knew he would have to check employee backgrounds before giving them access to sensitive client documents, but it took him a while to find the right solution. He eventually settled on a customized bundle offered by Kroll Background Screening, which reviews a variety of federal and local criminal records, as well driving histories and credit reports (Mr. Thammineni decided against requiring drug tests). Now, every new employee undergoes a background check after accepting a conditional job offer.

headline: Have We Learned Anything From the Leaked Cables?
text: David Brooks: Gail, I’ve begun to worry about what you might call the Caligula Gap. When you look around the world, or at least around the leaked State Department cables, you see world leaders living full, decadent lives. Muammar el-Qaddafi has his voluptuous Ukrainian nurse.  Vladimir Putin has his power and his muscles. Silvio Berlusconi has everything. Even aging Saudi princes go around talking about cutting the heads off snakes, like Clint Eastwood movie characters.

headline: Graphic Content | Marian Bantjes, Illuminated
text: This is what the graphic designer Marian Bantjes’s  first book, “I Wonder,” published by the Monacelli Press, is not: It is not a conventional graphic design monograph that presents all the work that’s fit to print; nor is it reductively minimalist in the modernist tradition, which is so common in today’s design publishing. It is not without a surfeit of excesses that would drive a modernist insane, nor is it modest in word or image. What it is not could fill volumes.

headline: Fresh Sparkle | Sotheby’s Diamonds Collection
text: Sotheby’s is no stranger to diamonds. Last month they sold the world’s largest “fancy intense pink diamond” in Geneva for a record $46 million. If that level of stone is too aspirational, the auction house is offering an alternative. Sotheby’s Diamonds, which was established in 2005, and Steinmetz Diamond Group are combining their expertise to provide exquisite jewels and gems directly to consumers. Patti Wong, the chairwoman of Sotheby’s China and Southeast Asia, developed the retail division as a means for clients to acquire new diamonds like investments.

headline: A New Crop of Sundance Films, Light on Stars
text: LOS ANGELES— The competitive line-up for the 2011 Sundance Film Festival is heavy on off-the-wall stories, light on war documentaries and — for better or worse — nearly devoid of one of the festival’s signature ingredients: stars. As both a showcase for American cinema and a free-wheeling bazaar for movie executives, Sundance is carefully scrutinized for signals about where independent movies are headed. If these filmmakers represent the future, what’s on their minds?

headline: David Diehl Returns to Practice With Giants
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — For weeks, left tackle David Diehl expressed hope that his return to the Giants was imminent, but he has been absent from practice. On Wednesday, however, he participated mostly in individual drills.

headline: Worries About Italy and Belgium in Euro Zone
text: Throughout Europe’s financial crisis, Italy and Belgium have managed to avoid being one of the countries that keep people awake at night.

headline: Beauty Spots
text: SPICY BODY WASHES Not everyone requires body wash to be vegan, as Pattern’s are, but many can appreciate that they don’t strip skin of its oils. It doesn’t hurt that Pattern’s washes have distinctive scents  their latest are nutmeg and sage created with natural oils and plant extracts for perfume-like depth. An 8-ounce bottle is $20; a little goes a long way. Sold at patternbodywash.com.

headline: Raising Awareness: Developing Social Media Campaigns About H.I.V. and AIDS
text: Overview  | In this lesson, students consider how celebrities are using social media to build awareness about H.I.V. and AIDS. They then research the basic biology and epidemiology of H.I.V. and AIDS, and develop their own social media campaigns to educate people about the virus and to generate support for H.I.V. and AIDS advocacy.

headline: Ginobili: The Spurs’ Man for All Paces
text: The San Antonio Spurs, in both success and failure, have long been a balancing act. On one end, we have an establishment. Tim Duncan is one of the best to ever lace up, and his style -– deliberate, dominant, calculated -– is perfectly in line with the philosophy of Coach Gregg Popovich. The two have functioned as the heart of the Spurs for more than a decade, and their track record speaks for itself.

headline: Dressing Up | Keegan Singh and Graeme Armour
text: It’s Friday night and the workweek might be over, but the night is still young. “When it comes down to fashion, we need to all look different,” says the stylist Keegan Singh, who shares a Chelsea apartment with the jeweler Eddie Borgo. Singh swaps an oversized Brooks Brothers blazer for a Graeme Armour cropped motorcycle jacket. “There are few girls that know how to do that.” Singh and the model Harley Viera-Newton playfully sift through the dark, directional and chic spring 2011 collection of Armour, the former Alexander McQueen intern and up-and-coming designer. “He has that oomph I want to explore,” gushes Singh. Paired with a simple sleeveless Calvin Klein undershirt or a preppy St. James top, “my girl is someone with her own taste and thought on dressing,” says Armour. “Someone like Harley ticks all the boxes and makes it cool in her own way.”

headline: Oprah Network Denies Talks with Outgoing CBS Exec
text: Oprah Winfrey’s cable venture denied a report on Wednesday that it was in talks to hire Terry Wood, a television guru who groomed Phil McGraw, Rachael Ray and other stars of syndication.

headline: U.S. Emphasizes Diversity in World Cup Bid
text: Former President Bill Clinton and the actor Morgan Freeman joined the star soccer player Landon Donovan on Wednesday to try to convince FIFA officials that the United States deserves to host the 2022 World Cup.

headline: Once an Editor, Now the Subject
text: IT doesn’t really matter whether Serendipity, the restaurant on East 60th Street in Manhattan, was already serving footlong hot dogs in 1975, or its frozen hot chocolate. Neither Nan Talese nor Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis would have ordered them anyway.

headline: Rangel Asks Supporters to Make a Call on His Behalf
text: With the hour of his reckoning drawing near, Representative Charles B. Rangel on Wednesday morning asked thousands of his supporters to call the Capitol switchboard and ask their congressmen to vote against a measure that would censure him for an assortment of ethical violations.

headline: Unsinkable Captain of Spoofs
text: “SURELY you can’t be serious.” That line, said not by Leslie Nielsen but to him (by Robert Hays, the ostensible male lead of “Airplane!,” the movie in question), might be taken to sum up Mr. Nielsen’s career, or at least the part of it that people are most likely to remember. Of course Mr. Nielsen could be serious. “I’m serious! And don’t call me Shirley.” And that’s what was so funny. He had also, up until “Airplane!,” been a sober and solid character actor, mostly on television, sometimes playing heavies, sometimes figures of bland authority. And if not for “Airplane!” and the spoofs that followed, he would be recalled now as one of those “hey, it’s that guy” guys of an earlier era, lingering in the memory banks of baby boomers and Gen-Xers who watched way too much TV when they were kids.

headline: The UnMuseum
text: EVEN if it were just another glimmering new Lower East Side tower full of multimillion-dollar condos, the sleek, eight-story glass tower at 257 Bowery would qualify as a statement building, with its room-size red elevator visible through the building’s corrugated-glass facade and its sensuously undulating balustrade, perched high above the 29-foot-tall ground-floor exhibition space.

headline: Macquarie Hires Ex-Bear Stearns Energy Banker
text: The Macquarie Group, the Australian investment bank, said on Wednesday that it had hired a former senior energy banker from Bear Stearns to lead its oil and gas team.

text: In San Francisco, visitors will find a living, historically rooted literary scene.

headline: When a Child Pushes You Away
text: This time of year means parties. And, for parents of fall athletes, awards banquets. Sometimes those are bonding times for families, but in the context of an already stressful time (a senior who is in the throes of college applications, for instance) and a difficult age (a senior who has lost a parent recently, and seems to be processing her grief by lashing out at her surviving parent) what should be simple and joyful can become a minefield.

headline: Nuclear Lab Directors ‘Pleased’ With Modernization Plan
text: 4:57 p.m. | Updated The directors of the nation’s three nuclear laboratories said Wednesday that they were satisfied with the Obama administration’s 10-year plan to modernize their facilities, a declaration Democrats hope will clear Republican obstacles to a new arms control treaty with Russia.

headline: A Book Lover’s San Francisco
text: ON a balmy fall evening in the Mission District of San Francisco, hundreds of people spilled onto Valencia Street, where they chatted happily for a few minutes before pouring back into bookstores, cafes and theaters. It was a giddy, animated crowd, but most of all bookish — a collection of fans and believers, here to listen to the written word.

headline: Cutting Right to the Oscar Chase
text: “All right, bag me,” Lisa Cholodenko said, standing outside the party for her film “Kids Are All Right” on Tuesday, smoking. The Bagger turned up to chat briefly – it was a two-party night – and, to our delight, Ms. Cholodenko cut right to the chase.

headline: Theater Talkback: Speaking the Same Language
text: Watching the Atlantic Theater Company’s exquisite productions of “The Collection” and “A Kind of Alaska,” two short plays by Harold Pinter, I almost forgot that the cast was speaking in a foreign language. Technically, of course, Pinter wrote in English. But as is true of most great dramatists, his syntax, locutions, rhythms and silences make up a sui generis grammar. To navigate the treacherous, autonomous nation that is Pinterland requires a thorough command of this exotic tongue.

headline: Embracing Georgia, U.S. Misread Signs of Rifts
text: Throughout the cold war and often in the years since, Western diplomats covering the Kremlin routinely relied on indirect and secondhand or thirdhand sources. Their cables were frequently laden with skepticism, reflecting the authors’ understanding of the limits of their knowledge and suspicion of official Russian statements.

headline: Below Surface, U.S. Has Dim View of Putin and Russia
text: Early in 2009, as recession rippled around the world, the United States Embassy in Moscow sent to Washington a cable summarizing whispers within Russia’s political class. Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putin, the rumors said, often did not show up at his office.

headline: Cheshire Appeal Will Point to Twitter
text: NEW HAVEN  There were half a dozen of them typing away in the courtroom rows. Minute by minute, they sent out reports of gruesome testimony via Twitter. In the end, the defense says, there were more than 140,000 Twitter messages about the trial that dealt with rape and children tied to their beds in a house that was set ablaze.

headline: Hamas Leader in Gaza Softens on Vote
text: GAZA  The leader of the Hamas government in Gaza, Ismail Haniya, said Wednesday for the first time that any resolution of the Palestinian dispute with Israel should be put to a referendum of all Palestinians around the world, and that if one were held, Hamas would accept the results no matter what they were.

headline: Asked & Answered | Matthew Stone
text: The British artist Matthew Stone uses the rather Obama-esque slogan “Optimism As Cultural Rebellion” to describe his performance and photographic art. For Stone, the proto-manifesto suggests idealistic activism that he would like to inspire through his art. More practically, it has lead the former collaborator with outré designer Gareth Pugh to organize a series of large-scale performances that combine Greco-Roman bacchanalia, Joseph Bueys-inspired performance art and the more ecstatic moments of rave culture. We spoke with him following the November 26 performance of “Anatomy of Immaterial Worlds,” his first “shamanic opera” at London’s ICA.

headline: No Criminal Charges Against Ensign
text: Justice Department prosecutors have cleared Senator John Ensign of criminal allegations arising from his affair with an ex-aide and his effort to secure lobbying work for the ex-aide’s husband, the senator’s lawyers announced Wednesday.

headline: Surgery for Yankees’ Gardner and Aceves
text: Brett Gardner is scheduled to have surgery Tuesday to treat the tendinitis in his right wrist that hampered him over the final four months of the season.

text: Damascus loves to flaunt its age, but has never looked so fresh.

text: Ron Reinfeld and Idit Barak turned their dark and boxy apartment into a bright, loftlike space.

headline: The Wall of Junk Bonds Grows Taller
text: The Federal Reserve’s data dump of more than 21,000 loan documents from the financial crisis provides a vivid reminder of how ugly it can get when the credit markets freeze up. In order to get crucial overnight loans, hundreds of banks had nothing else to give the Fed as collateral except junk-rated loans and bonds — valued at $1.3 trillion.

Jones/Arnie Zane Dance Company voted unanimously Wednesday to merge their organizations, forming a combination producing and presenting entity to be called New York Live Arts.

headline: The Cheat: Dark Arts
text: This week’s recipe is a raggedy Christmas number out of Venezuela called asado negro. It requires a fat roast of beef that is simmered for a long time in dark caramel, its sweetness tempered by vinegar. The result is sticky and unctuous beneath a cloak of peppers, onions and leeks. It looks mysterious and bold on the plate and at the start of a New York winter can conjure some degree of Latin American humidity and joy.

headline: Enforcement Takes On a Softer Side in China
text: CHENGDU, China  Like an urban drill sergeant, Tang Shenbin paced on a city square, sternly inspecting his nervous charges, issuing sotto voce commands with military authority. He wanted the female members of chengguan  China’s burly enforcers of urban order, feared and despised for their capricious crackdowns and penchant for violence  to convey a certain impression to a clutch of onlookers.

headline: Spain Reveals Plan to Reduce Its Giant Debt
text: MADRID  The Spanish prime minister, José Luis Rodríguez Zapatero, introduced measures Wednesday intended to distance Spain from Ireland and other ailing European countries.

headline: In Ibsen, Discontent and Desires Unspoken
text: It’s not surprising that “Rosmersholm” was one of Freud’s favorite plays. There’s so much roiling under its surface  deep desire, silent guilt  that he even used it to illustrate psychoanalytic theory. As presented by the Pearl Theater Company, this Ibsen drama is compelling to watch as its characters grapple with those unvoiced emotions. Yet when their internal struggles turn into external battles, the production sometimes suffers.

headline: Carpetbagger: The Gotham Awards
text: Bill Murray, Patricia Clarkson, Anne Hathaway and more turn out for the first movie awards of the season. Melena Ryzik reports (and tries to calm Jesse Eisenberg's nerves.)

headline: 36 Hours in Damascus
text: DAMASCUS loves to flaunt its age. It claims to be the world’s oldest inhabited city — replete with biblical and Koranic lore, Roman ruins, ancient Islamic edifices and Ottoman-era palaces. But that’s not to say the Syrian capital is stuck in time. Dozens of centuries-old mansions have been reborn as Mideast-chic hotels, and fashionable shops and restaurants have arisen in the ancient lanes of the Old City. Throw in a fledgling generation of bars and clubs, and the age-old metropolis has never looked so fresh.

headline: Carpetbagger Video: The Gotham Awards
text: Bill Murray, Patricia Clarkson, Anne Hathaway and more turn out for the first movie awards of the season. Melena Ryzik reports (and tries to calm Jesse Eisenberg’s nerves.)

headline: Some Time at the Races, With Luck and Change
text: When Jaimy Gordon won the National Book Award for fiction last month, she prompted a profligate outburst of metaphors about dark horses. After all, her winning book, “Lord of Misrule,” is set at a low-stakes, down-at-the-hoofs racetrack. And Lord of Misrule is the name of “a shiny black beetle of a horse” who arrives in this book’s last lap, just in time to serve as deus ex machina for a dramatic finale.

headline: Searching for Clues in History’s Nooks
text: To call someone a conspiracy theorist is, in truth, to say something insultingly vague, because as we all know conspiracy theorists come in degrees. On the one hand are the elite squad of paranoids who keep 10 years’ worth of kidney beans in their basements, bite their nails and believe that the North Koreans are lacing our club soda with something dangerously nonnutritive. On the other hand are the languorous crackpots who wonder if codes are embedded in their Home Depot receipts, or if George Washington’s wooden leg hid an alternate Constitution. It is for this group that the series “Brad Meltzer’s Decoded” has been conceived.

headline: First the Bonbon, Then the Main Course: Camp
text: “Contemporary ballet” is a murky category; like “postmodern,” it is much easier to use than identify. But here’s one hint: If the dancers are wearing knee socks instead of point shoes, undulating their torsos and lashing their limbs hither and yon in unremarkably virtuosic phrases, chances are there’s contemporary ballet afoot.

headline: Just a Voice, a Piano and Mahler Lieder
text: Given Mahler’s concentration on rich-hued, broad-boned symphonic works, the celebration of the 150th anniversary of his birth this year and the centenary of his death in 2011 are boons mainly to conductors and orchestras, and their audiences. But the Austrian baritone Wolfgang Holzmair was determined to join the party, and he has been touring with a program of Mahler songs that he and his pianist, Russell Ryan, plan to record in January. (Mr. Holzmair was to have made his Metropolitan Opera debut in the current run of “Così Fan Tutte,” but withdrew because of illness.)

headline: Conspicuously Sparse in Sundance Competition Lineup: Movie Stars
text: LOS ANGELES — The lineup of films competing in the 2011 Sundance Film Festival is heavy on off-the-wall stories, light on war documentaries and — for better or worse — nearly devoid of one of the festival’s signature ingredients of late: stars.

headline: Video Deemed Offensive Pulled by Portrait Gallery
text: The National Portrait Gallery in Washington has removed a video from an exhibition and apologized for its contents after the video was criticized by the Catholic League and members of the House of Representatives for being offensive to Christians.

headline: Revealed: Where Chancellor Spent the Rainy Day
text: If you guessed that Cathleen P. Black spent the day visiting two schools in Queens — Public School 111 in Astoria, and P.S. 78 in Long Island City — give yourself two points.

headline: A Song Cycle by Schubert Mirrors an Artist’s Journey
text: The story of “Die Schöne Müllerin,” Schubert’s song cycle about a miller lad suffering in unrequited love, has been interpreted many ways. The talented young tenor Paul Appleby sees the boy as an artist finding his voice.

text: As if in direct response to its overscaled, canon-cementing Abstract Expressionism display, the Museum of Modern Art is also giving us something quirky, speculative, physically light, a show called “On Line: Drawing Through the Twentieth Century.”

headline: Store Review: TSC Signature, in Beirut
text: Food itineraries in far-flung locations tend to feature colorful public markets. But in the newly revived downtown area of Beirut, where slick corridors of high-end, marble-faced shops have replaced the souks that were destroyed in the civil war, there is a dazzling new food hall, TSC Signature, which opened in April.

headline: Glimmers of Hope for Small Films During Glittery Oscar Promotions
text: “Brooklyn, Brooklyn in the house!” Darren Aronofsky shouted from the front of the Ziegfeld Theater on Tuesday night. Mr. Aronofsky, the director and Coney Island native, was living out a childhood fantasy when his film “Black Swan” had its New York premiere at that Midtown Manhattan movie palace, which he frequented while growing up. “Mom, I have a confession: I cut out of high school to see ‘Raiders of the Lost Ark’ in this theater,” he said, later admitting it wasn’t a one-time thing.

headline: Outcome Uncertain in Ivory Coast Election
text: ABIDJAN, Ivory Coast  Three days after a landmark election meant to bring peace here in West Africa’s former economic leader, an old fear hung over this tattered ex-boomtown: a president who refuses to give up power.

headline: Tech Toys to Keep Your Gift Budget in Balance
text: While the leading candidate for this year’s most marvelous toy is the iPad, followed by, perhaps, a Microsoft Kinect video game system, both can put a significant dent in your gift budget. Consider that for the price of one iPad, you can buy five $99 BMX bicycles, and that one Kinect game costs the same as 10 classic beaded jump ropes, or about 48 cans of Play-Doh.

headline: Kiteboarding in the Dominican Republic
text: FROM shore, David flashed a thumbs up: the signal for me to go ahead. I pulled down on the control bar attached to the harness on my waist, and the 20-foot-wide kite emblazoned with a dragon arced across the sky. Instantly, a jolt was transmitted through the lines that connected the kite to the harness, and I shot across the water.

headline: A Single Deal Proves Crucial as a Title Is Defended
text: ORLANDO, Fla.  The Marsha May Sternberg Women’s Board-a-Match Teams title was successfully defended on Monday evening here by Joyce Hampton of Blythewood, S.C.; Jenny Wolpert of Jupiter, Fla.; Daniela von Arnim from Germany; Sabine Auken from Denmark; and Bénédicte Cronier and Sylvie Willard from France. They finished a quarter of a board ahead of Geeske Joel of Palo Alto, Calif.; Tobi Sokolow of Austin, Tex.; Jill Meyers of Santa Monica, Calif.; Jill Levin of Lake Ariel, Pa.; Debbie Rosenberg of New Rochelle, N.Y.; and Janice Seamon-Molson of Hollywood, Fla.

headline: Top 10 Android Apps
text: A few weeks ago, I compiled a list of essential iPhone apps for people who are too busy to sift through the roughly 300,000 titles in the App Store.

headline: Viewers Like Christmas
text: NBC’s annual special “Christmas in Rockefeller Center” attracted its most viewers in seven years as 11.3 million tuned in to the tree-lighting ceremony at 8 p.m., according to Nielsen’s estimates. The show easily outperformed the combination of ABC’s holiday specials “How the Grinch Stole Christmas” (6.9 million) and “Shrek the Halls” (7.4 million) in the time slot but lagged behind Fox’s “Glee” (11.6 million) and CBS’s “Rudolph the Red-Nosed Reindeer” (12 million), which led at 8. NBC finished in second place for the night over all, averaging 8.3 million for “The Biggest Loser” from 9 to 11. CBS won the night, earning 15.1 million viewers at 8 for a rerun of “NCIS” and 9 million at 10 for its annual “Victoria’s Secret Fashion Show.” Fox was third with new episodes of its comedies “Raising Hope” (6.9 million) and “Running Wilde” (3.4 million) at 9 and 9:30. ABC ranked fourth.

headline: Harry Smith, Proud of ‘Early Show’ Years, Looks Ahead

headline: A ‘True Grit’ Round-Up
text: In the awards game, the Bagger is certain of one thing; don’t discount the Coen Brothers. (Don’t mess with them either; they have kind of a reputation.)

headline: In Asheville, N.C., the River Arts District Blooms
text: ON a recent autumn afternoon, a rusty cargo train lumbered past a rundown, three-story brick warehouse in Asheville, N.C., as a pack of dogs chased one another around a dusty dirt lot. Inside the dilapidated building, though, once-grimy rooms are now paint-flecked, clay-crusted artist studios. And on the lower level, a former storage space for slaughtered hogs is now home to the Wedge Brewing Company (125 B Roberts Street; 828-505-2792; wedgebrewing.com), a microbrewery that opened in 2008 with a variety of beers on tap and a sun-splashed patio.

headline: Hotel Review: Hotel Indigo, Asheville, N.C.
text: BASICS

headline: Letters: Looted Art
text: To the Editor: Regarding “In Paris, on the Trail of Art Looted by Nazis” (Nov. 21): As lawyers who have spent more than 10 years assisting the families of Holocaust victims in recovering Nazi-looted art, we welcome this article.

headline: Letters: Cambridge Cemetery
text: To the Editor: In “36 Hours in Cambridge, England” (Nov. 21), there was no mention of the Cambridge American Cemetery and Memorial, which is the only American cemetery from World War II in Britain. The graves (including that of my cousin) are of American airmen stationed in Britain who made raids on continental Europe and did not return. The memorial for those unknown include the names of Glenn Miller and Joseph Kennedy Jr. There is a lovely nonsectarian chapel on the grounds as well.

headline: Trading Up: Men’s Sweaters Borrow From Folk Patterns
text: At the hands of today’s designers, the Fair Isle sweater has manned up and trimmed down, newly invigorated with the youthful spirit that brought it fame 85 years ago.

headline: The Pedigree, Knitted In
text: IT’S too bad that the previous Prince of Wales, the great-uncle of the current titleholder, is known to history for his dubious decisions: namely, spending barely a year as Edward VIII before abdicating the throne, and picking the wrong horse in World War II. Before he became the black sheep of the House of Windsor, the fair-haired Prince of Wales was known for woolens of a different color, his clothes slavishly imitated in the ’20s and early ’30s. In 1924, Men’s Wear magazine put it bluntly: “The average young man in America is more interested in the clothes of the Prince of Wales than in the clothes of any other individual on earth.”

headline: Fill-In | What an ‘A’ Means
text: Fill in the blanks in this article about schools revamping grading so that it reflects only the mastery of material–not good behavior. Use your own words and phrases, or click “read more” to choose from a scrambled list of the words or phrases that were removed.

headline: Best Media Apps for the iPad
text: The historical media verticals of radio, television, print and Web evaporate inside the frame of an iPad—it’s all just content, backlighted and inviting, waiting for the swipe of a finger. Long-form narrative and news has found a reliable wing man in the iPad.

headline: A Look That’s Worth a Million Hits
text: ON the afternoon of what has come to be known as Cyber Monday, Alissandre Martines, 23, a French Polynesian with high-arched eyebrows, was making a color-blocked scarf by Me & Kashmere look like a must-have.

headline: Tech Talk Podcast: Best Camera Gifts
text: Finding just the right gift for the technology lover on your list might take a little research. Bettina Edelstein gets the low-down on this season’s popular camera trends from Rik Fairlie, a frequent contributor on the subject to the Gadgetwise blog and the Personal Tech pages of the New York Times.

headline: Will the Big East and T.C.U. Live Happily Ever After?
text: On Monday, the Big East Conference and Texas Christian University entered into a shotgun wedding. Beginning with the 2012 season, T.C.U. will join the conference in all sports, including football, where their team has just completed an undefeated regular season.

headline: Candidates for R.N.C. Chair Make Their Pitches
text: Four candidates seeking to lead the Republican National Committee delivered their pitches at an open forum on Wednesday, arguing that the party needs new direction and an aggressive focus on rebuilding a tattered fund-raising network if Republicans hope to mount a credible challenge to President Obama.

headline: EBay Shows Where Mobile Shopping Is Hot
text: Using a cellphone to shop on eBay is big in San Francisco, along with most metropolitan areas. But mobile commerce has yet to catch on in the West Texas desert, most of South Dakota and rural Illinois.

text: Tel Aviv

headline: Shopping Snapshots for Dec. 2
text: Chanel at Jeffrey New York; fingerless gloves; Mackage opens a store in SoHo; and more.

headline: Designers Honor the Endangered Christmas Card
text: The digital age may someday mean the demise of the paper Christmas card. That is one reason Stefan Nilsson, the creative director of Designgalleriet, a gallery in Stockholm, chose to make holiday cards the focus of his year-end exhibition, which runs through Dec. 22.

headline: The Air Stool
text: Hector Serrano wanted the Air stool he designed for Gandia Blasco, a Spanish manufacturer, to look good, but not so good that it competed with its surroundings: “The idea was to create a stool that was understated and visually light enough to complement any setting,” he said.

headline: Small Shops, Big Wonders
text: RAYMAN BOOZER is a survivor, a member of that hardy (dare one say quixotic?) tribe known as independent retailers. Sixteen years ago, Mr. Boozer, an Indiana-born interior designer, opened Apartment 48 on West 17th Street. He had worked at Bloomingdale’s, Saks Fifth Avenue and Conran’s and was eager to create his own retail magic.

headline: Frazzled Moms Push Back Against Volunteering
text: IT was last spring, somewhere between overseeing Teacher Appreciation Week and planning the fifth-grade graduation party, when Jamie Lentzner, mother of two in Foster City, Calif., reached her breaking point.

headline: Furniture, Lighting and Tableware on Sale
text: Frances Palmer is offering 20 percent off White Pearl ceramic tableware online, through Sunday (a scalloped cereal bowl, originally $35, is $28; a fluted vase, regularly $75, is $60); francespalmerpottery.com.

headline: Asia Captures Lion’s Share of Big I.P.O.’s
text: HONG KONG — A bank whose customer base is larger than the population of the United States, a French cosmetics maker, a microlender and a Chinese pharmaceutical company that makes an anticoagulant derived from pigs’ guts: Asian stock exchanges have seen it all this year.

headline: House Ethics Committee Suspends Two Lawyers
text: The House ethics committee placed two of its attorneys on paid administrative leave last month for reported problems with their handling of the committee’s investigation of Representative Maxine Waters, a California Democrat accused of helping steer bailout money to a bank in which her husband owned shares.

headline: Konstantin Grcic on Being Designer of the Year at Design Miami
text: Design Miami, the annual design-art fair being held in Miami Beach through Dec. 5, has named the German industrial designer Konstantin Grcic designer of the year. The selection of Mr. Grcic (pronounced GER-chich) was a surprise to many. While previously winners — including Zaha Hadid, Fernando and Humberto Campana, and Maarten Baas — have created sculptural objects that make provocative statements and veer closer to art, Mr. Grcic is known for his rigorous focus on logic, utility and simplicity.

headline: More Accolades in the Year of the Saint
text: DREW BREES, the quarterback of the New Orleans Saints, was in New York on Tuesday to be honored as Sports Illustrated’s Sportsman of the Year. There was a red-carpet party on his behalf, but he couldn’t drink.

headline: Cheney Hoping for R.N.C. Shakeup
text: Dick Cheney is sponsoring a shakeup attempt at the Republican National Committee.

headline: Some Promising Ideas That Didn’t Quite Work
text: Why do some toys become classics and others fade before their first set of batteries? Here’s a closer look at some of the more highly marketed toys that didn’t work, according to my testers, along with some alternatives that did. Barbie Video Girl Doll (Mattel, $45 at Toys “R” Us, ages 3 and up) seems like clever idea  put a video camera inside a doll  until you try to find the tiny Phillips screwdriver needed to fit the AAA batteries into Barbie’s legs. Your child soon will discover that Barbie has no speakers, so all the videos are silent until the doll is tethered to the computer.

headline: Chávez Opens His Palace to Flood Victims
text: CARACAS, Venezuela  Miraflores Palace, designed in the 1880s by an Italian count for one of Venezuela’s 19th-century dictators, has been home to presidents here for more than a century. In recent years, it has welcomed a lively medley of foreign leaders, including Presidents Mahmoud Ahmadinejad of Iran and Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva of Brazil.

headline: Inside North Korea, ‘Business as Usual’
text: SEOUL, South Korea  While North Korea’s state-run media continued to rage over the military exercises being held off the North’s coastline, saying the four days of drills that ended Wednesday afternoon had brought the Korean Peninsula to “the brink of war,” much of daily life in the secretive North appeared remarkably normal, or at least what passes for normal.

headline: Too Big to Succeed
text: Kansas City, Mo.

headline: Prosecutors Won’t Charge Ensign
text: WASHINGTON Justice Department prosecutors have cleared Senator John Ensign of criminal allegations arising from his affair with a former campaign aide and his efforts to secure lobbying work for the woman’s husband, the senator’s lawyers announced Wednesday.

headline: Contrary to Hopes, Afghan Vote Disappoints
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Afghanistan’s Western backers put up $150 million this year for parliamentary elections, hoping that a credible vote would demonstrate progress in the war, help stabilize the country and encourage efforts toward peace.

headline: House to Add One Important Room
text: A lady may no longer rule the House, but the ladies will be more comfortable while there.

headline: Scans Could Aid Diagnosis of Brain Trauma in Living
text: In a finding that could eventually lead to ways to identify and perhaps treat athletes who have chronic traumatic encephalopathy, Boston-based researchers announced on Wednesday that a new imaging technique found chemical changes in the brains of living athletes with a history of head trauma.

headline: Putin Sees Conspiracy in Criticism of FIFA
text: MOSCOW  Russia’s prime minister, Vladimir V. Putin, responded angrily to allegations of corruption in world soccer’s governing body on Wednesday, suggesting that some members of the body were being “smeared” in an effort to undermine his country’s bid to host the World Cup in 2018.

headline: Civil Unions Advance in Illinois
text: CHICAGO  Illinois lawmakers on Wednesday approved legislation allowing civil unions in this state, and the governor has indicated he will sign it, making Illinois one of only a handful of states to grant to same-sex couples a broad array of legal rights and responsibilities similar to those of marriage.

headline: More Evidence of Strong Retail Sales
text: All signs continue to point to a strong holiday shopping season for online retailers, according to two surveys issued on Wednesday. Consumers are in a buying mood – as long as the price is right and ordering requires no more than a few clicks of a computer mouse.

headline: New Ways to Prevent Hospital Errors
text: To the Editor:

headline: Mixed Reaction to F.C.C. Internet Plan
text: WASHINGTON — The plan from the chairman of the Federal Communications Commission to ensure an open and neutral Internet drew mixed reviews on Wednesday from consumer advocates and Internet service providers, presenting the agency with an uncertain way forward as it considers new broadband regulation.

headline: A Brash Bettor Stumbles
text: Shortly after noon on Nov. 14, a Russian-made rocket blasted off from Baikonur Cosmodrome, the Soviet-era launch site that catapulted Sputnik 1 into orbit.

headline: Comedian Conversation Falls Flat at 92nd Street Y
text: In the history of intellectual chatter, the events of Nov. 29, 2010, at the 92nd Street Y will be archived under disaster. Or comedy.

headline: Google’s Bid for Groupon Portrayed as a Bargain
text: As investors fret that Google’s $6 billion bid for Groupon is too high a price to pay, new details about the company’s sales and growth suggest that it might be more like one of Groupon’s cut-rate deals.

headline: Fisk University Plans to Appeal Ruling on Stieglitz Art Sale
text: Fisk University in Nashville, which wants to sell a $30 million ownership stake in its Stieglitz art collection to raise money, plans to appeal a court decision that set limits on the sale, the university announced on Wednesday.

headline: A Mission to Transform Baltimore’s Beaten Schools
text: BALTIMORE  For years, this city had one of the worst school systems in the country. Fewer than half its students graduated, enrollment had fallen precipitously and proficiency levels were far below the national average.

headline: Survivor of African Rebel Raids Struggles in New Life
text: “The rebels came in one night at 2 a.m.; they started shooting and killing people,” said Michael Kallon, 55, a survivor of rebel raids in Liberia in 1986. “There were hordes of them, and I fled to Guinea.”

headline: L.P.G.A. Will Allow Transgender Players to Compete
text: L.P.G.A. players have voted to eliminate the tour’s requirement that players be “female at birth” and to allow transgender athletes to compete, less than two months after a transgender woman sued the tour in federal court, arguing that the rule violated California civil rights law.

headline: Bankrupt St. Vincent’s Moves Toward Selling Hospital Site
text: The prime Greenwich Village real estate that once housed St. Vincent’s Hospital Manhattan is likely to go on the market soon, if a bankruptcy judge allows the move.

headline: No Last Push by Paterson to Legalize Gay Marriage
text: Gov. David A. Paterson, still unhappy about the defeat last year of a bill that would have legalized same-sex marriage, reached out to lawmakers recently to see if they would approve it during the lame-duck session this year.

headline: N.C.A.A. Declines to Punish Newton
text: The N.C.A.A. ruled on Wednesday that the Auburn star quarterback Cam Newton is eligible to play in the Southeastern Conference championship game despite his father’s using a third party to solicit money from Mississippi State “as part of a pay-for-play scenario.”

headline: Eight Nights: The Joy and Meaning of Hanukkah
text: To the Editor:

headline: ESPN Names ‘Sunday Night’ Team
text: ESPN finally named Dan Shulman, Bobby Valentine and Orel Hershiser as its new “Sunday Night Baseball” announcing team Wednesday, three weeks after declining to renew the contracts of Jon Miller and Joe Morgan. Hershiser joined Miller and Morgan last season.

headline: Ward Calls League Hypocritical on Safety
text: Pittsburgh Steelers wide receiver Hines Ward criticized the N.F.L. for what he called its hypocritical stance on player safety, arguing that the league recently toughened its stance only because it wanted to expand to an 18-game season.

headline: Council Considers Rules on Phone Antennas
text: Most of the battles over the placement of cellular telephone antennas are fought locally, generally pitting a landlord and a cellphone carrier against the residents of a particular building where the antennas are planned.

headline: Fears of Regression as Newark Police Force Is Cut
text: NEWARK  For Ramon Tabera, the news that this city was laying off 163 police officers brought back memories of the pain in his left knee and right ankle, where he was shot five years ago during a nighttime robbery at a grocery store where he works.

headline: Runner Crawls to Finish as Team Wins Title for Ailing Coach
text: SAN FRANCISCO — A top runner who hits the wall. A coach with a cruel illness. A state championship at stake.

headline: 3-Strikes Challenger Is Charged With 4 Murders
text: LOS ANGELES  A multiple felon who campaigned against California’s three-strikes law and was free after managing four times to escape its harsh sentencing guidelines has been charged with murdering four people in home-invasion robberies here this year.

headline: Jets and Patriots Wage War of Praise
text: Despite a Monday night matchup between the Jets and New England that Coach Rex Ryan labeled the marquee game of the N.F.L. regular season, a relatively quiet week continued Wednesday. Both teams, it seemed, were guided by the Patriot way, presenting, at least publicly, nothing beyond their mutual respect.

headline: Google Acts to Demote Distasteful Web Sellers
text: Google announced on Wednesday that it had changed the way it ranks search results so that unscrupulous merchants would find it harder to appear prominently in searches.

headline: Charity, Citing Village Wealth, May Close School
text: Gentrification usually attracts good schools. Rarely does it close one.

headline: Obama Rallying Support for Pact With Russia
text: WASHINGTON  President Obama appears to be building momentum for Senate approval of a new arms control treaty with Russia by the end of the year, but it may have to come at the expense of other legislative priorities with far greater support among his liberal base.

headline: Speaking in Tongues
text: In Hong Kong, where I lived until I was 14, most expat kids had more than one passport; spoke English, Cantonese (curse words were the gateway) and at least one romance language; and we could emulate several accents convincingly. We were well-designed for espionage.

headline: Senate Republicans Threaten Tax Dispute Blockade
text: WASHINGTON  Not even 24 hours after President Obama met with senior Republican Congressional leaders and expressed hopes for a “new dialogue,” renewed partisan fury engulfed the Senate on Wednesday, as Republicans threatened to block any legislation until a deal is reached to extend the expiring Bush-era tax cuts, potentially derailing the Democrats’ busy end-of-year agenda.

headline: Greeting James: Jeers and ... Laughter?
text: Given the anger that LeBron James inspired by moving to Miami this summer, there has been no shortage of ideas on how spurned and snakebitten fans should react to his return to Cleveland on Thursday.

headline: Senators Push NASA to Carry Out Revamping
text: Concerned that the National Aeronautics and Space Administration is dragging its feet in revamping its space program, a Senate panel sought assurances from Obama administration officials on Wednesday that NASA would carry out the orders it had been given for the next three years.

headline: Benefits of Career Colleges
text: To the Editor:

headline: Weather’s Perils, Fiscally Considered
text: For Megan E. Linkin, meteorology is not about storm chasing or forecasting the weather on camera. Ms. Linkin, 28, whose meteorology-related degrees include a 2008 Ph.D. in atmospheric and oceanic science from the University of Maryland, is an atmospheric perils specialist for Swiss Reinsurance America Corporation in Armonk and New York City. Her job is to assess the future insurance risk posed by tornadoes, hurricanes and other natural catastrophes. She lives in Stuyvesant Town “because it’s safe.”

headline: $30 Million Is Awarded Over Abuse by Priest
text: A jury in Delaware on Wednesday awarded $30 million in compensatory damages to a man who said he was sexually abused more than 100 times by a Roman Catholic priest  the largest such award granted to a single victim in a clergy abuse case, victims’ advocates said.

headline: Lame Ducks Gone Mad
text: Strange signs and portents abound in the land.

headline: Avery Gets Chance on Line With Gaborik
text: Sean Avery will get a rare chance to skate alongside Marian Gaborik, the Rangers’ top sniper, on Thursday in the opener of back-to-back games against the Islanders.

headline: Storm Snarls Commutes and Topples Big Christmas Tree
text: Gusting wind and rain knocked out power, soaked pedestrians, delayed travelers and felled a 50-foot fully decorated Christmas tree at the South Street Seaport on Wednesday.

headline: Photo Replay: Dec. 1
text: A view of the day in sports, from a World Cup biathlon race to snowy soccer fields.

headline: Fresh Details on the Fed Rescue of A.I.G.’s Insurance Units
text: The documents released by the Federal Reserve on Wednesday provide new details of how close to the precipice some insurance subsidiaries of the American International Group came in 2008.

headline: Thursday: Thursday
text: There’s a neat trick at work in Joe Krozel’s puzzle: using the same clues for consecutive entries. He does this three times at the top, in the middle and at the bottom.

headline: The Cultural Roots of Disunion
text: The traditional take on how the Union came apart after Abraham Lincoln’s election rests on the irreconcilable political and economic differences between North and South over slavery. Yet the secession crisis didn’t emerge overnight, and the long build-up to it also involved concerted efforts on both sides to construct self-serving pseudo-ethnic and civic identities. These identities consciously exaggerated the cultural antipathy between the two sections — and contributed greatly to their eventual split.

headline: F.D.A. Panel Rejects Expanded Use of Prostate Drug
text: The question before the Food and Drug Administration advisory committee on Tuesday was path-breaking: Would it recommend that the labels of two drugs be changed to say that they can reduce a man’s risk of getting prostate cancer?

headline: Obesity Surgery May Become Option for Many More
text: Weight-loss surgery, once a last resort for extremely overweight people, may soon become an option for those who are less heavy.

headline: Growth in Virtual Gatherings Offers Marketing Opportunities
text: MIKE LESTER, chief executive of a transportation software company on the outskirts of Minneapolis, mingles with the best in his industry  virtually, that is.

headline: Teammate Turns to Texting to Lure Lee Back
text: It was just a little bantering between friends, but the text messages Cliff Lee exchanged Tuesday with Ian Kinsler provided a glimpse into the bidding for his services, which are set to intensify next week at baseball’s winter meetings.

headline: Opponents Take Aim at Limited Health Plans
text: Maybe something isn’t always better than nothing.

headline: Small-City Congregations Try to Preserve Rituals of Jewish Life
text: Although Irving Greenblum, an 81-year-old investor and retired furniture store owner, has four grown sons, he says he is “the last Greenblum who lives in Laredo,” a city on Texas’ border with Mexico.

headline: The Cholera Outbreak in Haiti
text: The Pan American Health Organization has estimated that 400,000 Haitians will get cholera over the next year. Nicholas D. Kristof visited a center treating those with the disease.

headline: Wild Cards Are in Play for 2022 Cup
text: London

headline: L.P.G.A. Tour Accepts Transgender Players
text: L.P.G.A. players have voted to eliminate the tour’s requirement that players be “female at birth” and to allow transgender athletes to compete, less than two months after a transgender woman sued the tour in federal court, arguing that the rule violated California civil rights law. The L.P.G.A. was sued in October by Lana Lawless, a retired police officer who had sex reassignment surgery in 2005 and who won the 2008 women’s world championship in long-drive golf. Lawless sought to play in L.P.G.A. qualifying tournaments after Long Drivers of America changed its rules to match the L.P.G.A.’s. More at nytimes.com/sports.

headline: Pope Sought in Past to Punish Errant Priests, Report Says
text: ROME  Pope Benedict XVI pushed for “more rapid and simplified” procedures to punish errant priests as far back as 1988, when he was the Vatican’s chief doctrinal officer, but his request was not met, according to documents released by the Vatican on Wednesday.

headline: Working to Ease Tensions in the Jeter Talks
text: Tuesday’s meeting in Tampa, Fla., between the Yankees, Derek Jeter and his agent was set in motion when the agent, Casey Close, called Hal Steinbrenner, the team’s managing partner, and suggested that the sides get together in an attempt to break Jeter’s contract stalemate.

headline: The Miracle Toilet
text: Nicholas D. Kristof reports from Haiti about toilets that aim to address the sanitation problems that lead to cholera, while also providing fertilizer to help farmers.

headline: A Treatable Disaster
text: Nicholas D. Kristof visits a Haitian cholera treatment center.

headline: Haiti, Nearly a Year Later
text: MIREBALAIS, Haiti

headline: Polygamist Sect Leader Extradited to Texas for Trial
text: HOUSTON  Warren S. Jeffs, the jailed leader of a polygamous sect of Mormons, was transferred Tuesday to West Texas to stand trial on charges of bigamy and sexual assault after fighting extradition from Utah for two years.

headline: Tests for H.I.V. Reach a Record
text: The number of American adults tested for H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS, reached a record high in 2009, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said Tuesday.

headline: Holiday Shopping for Investors
text: Befitting the season, two large buyout targets — the food producer Del Monte and the clothing purveyor J. Crew — are trying to reel in shoppers. But their investment bankers, like so many retail clerks, may get a reply of “No thanks, just looking.”

headline: The Un-Sensible Common Ground
text: The odds of a calm and reasoned deficit debate have never been good. Politicians from both parties favor deficit reduction until it comes to raising taxes on the rich or making actual cuts in the big-dollar programs, like Social Security and defense. The events of this week, however, have been truly absurd. Deficit talk reached new decibel levels, as lawmakers and administration officials huddled over extending budget-busting, Bush-era tax cuts.

headline: Ethics Plan Is Offered by Governor in Alabama
text: Less than two months after a federal corruption investigation led to the arrest of four state senators, Gov. Bob Riley of Alabama announced Wednesday that he was calling a special session of the Legislature this month and urged lawmakers to pass an aggressive ethics overhaul package.

headline: Leaving It for the Next Guy
text: Andrew Cuomo, the governor-elect of New York who is fresh from a peacekeeping lunch with Democratic legislators on Tuesday, could not resist a complaint. Lawmakers had just failed to cut state spending by at least $315 million so that Mr. Cuomo would have a balanced ledger when he arrives in January. “Very disappointing,” he said, adding that “denial is not a life strategy” because the budget hole will only grow by the day.

headline: Google and Europe
text: The European Commission did the right thing on Tuesday when it opened a formal antitrust investigation into allegations that Google abused its dominant position in online search to help its other businesses at the expense of rivals.

headline: Eminem Leads Grammy Nominations
text: With 10 nods for his comeback album, “Recovery,” Eminem led the nominations for the 53rd annual Grammy Awards, which were announced on Wednesday night in a televised ceremony from Los Angeles.

headline: Republicans Killing Climate Committee
text: Republicans plan to eliminate the House Select Committee on Energy Independence and Global Warming, which was created in 2007 by the current speaker, Nancy Pelosi, to examine climate change and press for possible caps on carbon dioxide emissions. Climate change matters are overseen by the House Energy and Commerce Committee, as well as the Natural Resources Committee; the select committee did not pass legislation but did hold hearings, which will cease in the new Congress. Michael Steel, a spokesman for Representative John A. Boehner of Ohio, who will become speaker in January, said the select committee was unnecessary. “The Select Committee on Global Warming was created by Democrats simply to provide political cover to pass their job-killing national energy tax,” he said.

headline: O’Malley to Lead Democratic Governors
text: Gov. Martin O’Malley of Maryland was elected chairman of the Democratic Governors Association on Wednesday. He will preside over the next campaign cycle as Democrats seek to rebuild from their widespread losses in the 2010 midterm elections. Mr. O’Malley succeeds Gov. Jack Markell of Delaware, who has served two terms as chairman. Gov. Bev Perdue of North Carolina was elected as vice chairwoman. The class of newly elected Republican and Democratic governors is spending a few days in Washington this week, holding meetings with Congressional leaders, members of the cabinet and administration officials.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Corrections
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: A Few Cheers for the Sun in Suffolk
text: The atmospherics have been a little fuzzy during Long Island’s big solar moment, which includes the groundbreaking scheduled for Thursday that is part of the biggest solar project in state history.

headline: U.S. Weighs Prosecution of WikiLeaks Founder, but Legal Scholars Warn of Steep Hurdles
text: WASHINGTON  Calls to prosecute the founder of WikiLeaks, Julian Assange, mounted this week as his organization began releasing documents from a cache of 250,000 State Department cables  its third major disclosure of United States government secrets this year.

headline: Sudan: Bashir Forced to Skip 2 International Events
text: President Omar al-Bashir, who is wanted on charges of genocide, was forced to stay away from two high-profile international events this week after diplomatic pressure. On Wednesday, judges at the International Criminal Court, who had issued a warrant for Mr. Bashir’s arrest, warned the Central African Republic that it was obliged by treaty to arrest him should he arrive on its territory. Mr. Bashir, left, abruptly canceled his planned trip to attend the Central African Republic’s independence celebrations on Wednesday. He was also forced to stay away from the 80-nation African-European summit meeting in Libya, which ended Tuesday, after a number of European nations had informed the Libyan government that they would not attend the meeting if Mr. Bashir were present.

headline: Iran: Woman Convicted of Murder Is Hanged
text: A woman convicted of murdering the wife of a former soccer star was hanged in Evin Prison in Tehran on Wednesday, according to the official IRNA news agency. The woman, Shahla Jahed, was hanged in the presence of the family of the victim, Laleh Sahrkhizan, and Ms. Jahed’s former lover, Naser Mohammadkhani, who was a soccer star in the 1980s. Rights groups had campaigned for her release during her eight-year imprisonment after doubts were raised over a confession she later retracted.

headline: West Bank: Western Wall Article Pulled From Web Site
text: An article by a Palestinian Authority official denying any Jewish connection to the Western Wall appeared to have been removed from the Web site of the authority’s Information Ministry on Wednesday after provoking sharp Israeli and American condemnation. The article, posted on Nov. 22, described the wall as the western wall of Al Aksa Mosque.

headline: Exploring the Meaning of ‘Constitutional Conservatism’
text: John Boehner, the next House speaker, expresses the message of constitutional conservatism in calling for every bill to identify the part of the Constitution it rests on. Sarah Palin used the phrase to campaign for limited government. Tea Party members call themselves constitutional conservatives. It is the new mantle in which Republican politicians are wrapping themselves.

headline: Al Masini, ‘Entertainment Tonight’ Creator, Dies at 80
text: Al Masini, a creator of hit television shows that often focused on glamour and fame, among them “Lifestyles of the Rich and Famous” and “Entertainment Tonight,” the breezy show business news program that has run for 29 years, died on Monday in Honolulu. He was 80.

text: Daniel Drezner, left, of Tufts University and Eli Lake of The Washington Times debate the motivations behind the leaking of diplomatic cables.

headline: After Killing of Publicist, a Suicide
text: LOS ANGELES — A man apparently linked to the killing of Ronni Chasen, the Hollywood publicist gunned down after midnight in Beverly Hills two weeks ago, killed himself on Wednesday evening as the police tried to carry out a search at the apartment building where he was staying, the authorities said.

headline: News Quiz | December 2, 2010
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper.

headline: Amazon Removes WikiLeaks From Servers
text: Under pressure from federal lawmakers, Amazon.com on Wednesday booted WikiLeaks, the whistle-blowing Web site, from its computer servers, three days after the group released a trove of embarrassing State Department cables and documents.

headline: 48 Years Up (and Down) at the Geographic
text: “William Albert Allard: Five Decades,” showcasing the work of a pioneering contributor to National Geographic — 4.8 decades actually, but why quibble at this point? — is to open Thursday at the Steven Kasher Gallery in Manhattan. A retrospective monograph has also been published, written by Mr. Allard, under the same title. On this occasion, he was interviewed for Lens by David Alan Harvey, a Magnum photographer who worked with him at National Geographic. Their conversation has been condensed.

headline: What Do You Want to Give and Get for the Holidays?
text: Hanukkah has just begun, and Christmas and Kwanzaa are on the way. What gifts would you like to receive this holiday season? What would you like to give your loved ones?

headline: A London Show Looks at Britons Living in New York
text: At first glance, the title “An Englishman in New York,” an exhibition of photographs at the National Portrait Gallery (Room 38a, St Martin’s Place; 44-207-306-0055; www.npg.org.uk), running through April 17, may seem like a reference to the hit song by Sting — who, indeed, is featured in the show. But the real Englishman of the title is Jason Bell, a British photographer living in New York, who has shot a wide range of Britons — both celebrities and everyday folk — who also have chosen to make New York their home.

text: Luis DeLoureiro operates NFLStatAnalysis.net and is a contributor to the Cold Hard Football Facts.

headline: Swedish Court Confirms Arrest Warrant for WikiLeaks Founder
text: LONDON — Sweden’s highest court refused on Thursday to allow Julian Assange, the founder of the WikiLeaks whistle-blowing organization, to appeal a court order seeking his arrest to face questioning over alleged sex crimes, his lawyer said.

headline: Pepsi to Buy Russian Juice Maker for $3.8 Billion
text: 7:45 p.m. | Updated  PepsiCo said Thursday that it had agreed to pay $3.8 billion for a two-thirds stake in the Russian dairy and juice maker Wimm-Bill-Dann Foods, giving the country a vote of confidence.

headline: The Nutcracker Chronicles: Following the Dancers From Room to Room
text: As a European tourist living in America, I couldn’t resist the invitation to see a “Nutcracker” in one of the most spectacular mansions in Newport, R.I. Rosecliff, built in 1902, is where parts of the 1974 “Great Gatsby” were filmed.

headline: N.F.L. Week 13 Game Probabilities: Patriots Over Jets
text: Brian Burke, a former Navy pilot who has taken up the less dangerous hobby of N.F.L. statistical analysis, operates Advanced NFL Stats, a blog about football, math and human behavior.

headline: Japanese Regulator Approves a Search Partnership of Google and Yahoo
text: TOKYO  Japanese regulators on Thursday approved a partnership between Google and Yahoo Japan for local Web search, clearing the way for an alliance that would control almost all of the country’s search market.

headline: Europe Bank Extends Emergency Support
text: FRANKFURT  The European Central Bank on Thursday continued its emergency support to weak countries within Europe but stopped short of more aggressive action to contain the debt crisis that has already engulfed Greece and Ireland.

headline: A Design Competition Yields Three New Apartments
text: Three designers had a month and $5,000 to design a studio or one-bedroom apartment in 99 John Deco Lofts, a 442-unit condo built in 1933 as the Insurance Company of North America Building. The competition was sponsored by TF Cornerstone, the condominium’s developer.

headline: Early Oscar Talk, Non-‘True Grit’ Edition
text: While “True Grit” reviews seemed to be lighting up most Oscar Twitter feeds Wednesday, here’s a look at few other items being discussed in the awards season blogosphere.

headline: Hill Democrats Fear Quick Tax Deal
text: Some Congressional Democrats are growing increasingly nervous that the White House will give in to Republican demands for a temporary extension of all of the Bush-era tax cuts without getting enough in return.

headline: Ex-R.B.S. Chief Is Cleared in Bank’s Stumble
text: 7:03 p.m. | Updated  LONDON — Frederick A. Goodwin, the former chief executive of Royal Bank of Scotland, who was widely blamed for the bank’s demise, has been cleared by Britain’s financial regulator of any major wrongdoings.

headline: The Satirical Spider-Man: The Web Zings Broadway’s Web-Slinger
text: Whether it makes back its $65 million budget, gets it audience to stop shouting out inappropriate remarks or even opens on Broadway, the musical “Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark” is already a success in one regard: it has reached that ineffable zeitgeist-y moment where it is now inspiring its own parody Web videos. Can “Mrs. Warren’s Profession” or “Women on the Verge of a Nervous Breakdown” make the same boast?

headline: Russia and Qatar Win World Cup Bids
text: The world’s biggest sporting event continued its spread to new corners of the globe Thursday as Russia and Qatar were named as hosts of the 2018 and 2022 World Cup soccer tournaments.
