text: Barbra Streisand’s favorite architects are dead. Charles Rennie Mackintosh, Charles and Henry Greene.

headline: Smartphones and Tablets to Take Over in 2011, Researchers Say
text: The research firm IDC predicts that in 2011, computing’s third major technology wave will become mainstream, when computers held in one’s hand — smartphones and tablets — really take over and start putting personal computers in the rearview mirror.

text: The presidential panel investigating the BP Deepwater Horizon accident opened two days of public deliberations on Thursday as it begins to piece together its findings and recommendations. The hearings can be seen here, along with the staff reports on which their findings will be based.

headline: Double Trouble | Harmony Korine and Rita Ackermann at the Swiss Institute
text: When the young artists and old friends Rita Ackermann and Harmony Korine joined forces to create the work that would become “Shadow Fux,” the show currently at the Swiss Institute, their concept was simple “Let’s make something that has never been seen before.”

headline: McCain on ‘Don’t Ask, Don’t Tell': Don’t Rush
text: In his opening remarks at a hearing on the military’s “don’t ask, don’t tell” policy on Thursday, Senator John McCain of Arizona, the senior Republican on the Armed Services Committee, reiterated his strong concerns about ending the ban on gays serving openly in the military.

headline: Poetry Pairing | Dec. 2, 2010
text: In our weekly “Poetry Pairing” series, we collaborate with the Poetry Foundation to feature a work from its American Life in Poetry project alongside content from The Times that somehow echoes, extends or challenges the poem’s themes. Each poem is introduced briefly by Ted Kooser, a former United States poet laureate.

headline: A Star-Filled Party for One Heavy Movie
text: “Biutiful,” written and directed by Alejandro González Iñárritu (“Babel”), is the dark story of a struggling father of two, played by Javier Bardem, who is barely getting by in Barcelona, hustling even more struggling people – illegal Chinese and African immigrants – while dealing with a troubled ex-wife and his own life-threatening health problems. Mr. Bardem’s character lives on the margins in a world that rarely has time for pleasure and seems encircled by death. He won a best actor prize at the Cannes Film Festival for his performance in the movie, which opens on Dec. 29.

headline: Thursday Reading: The Bush-Era Tax Cuts
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: JPMorgan Hires Ex-Goldman Deal Maker (and Art History Student)
text: JPMorgan Chase said Thursday that it had hired Robert Cummings Jr., a former senior deal maker at Goldman Sachs, as vice chairman of its investment banking group.

headline: Lethal Fire Rages Through Forest in Northern Israel
text: JERUSALEM  A fire raging in a rain-starved forest in northern Israel on Thursday has left at least 40 people dead, caused the evacuation of thousands of people, burned some kibbutz houses to the ground and prompted the government to call for urgent international aid in fighting the blaze.

headline: At Art Basel Miami Beach, Less Heat
text: MIAMI BEACH – The crowds that used to form more than an hour before the opening of the “First Choice” portion of Art Basel Miami Beach—the four-hour window between 11 a.m. and 3 p.m. when only elite collectors can enter and browse the fair—are gone. Gone too are the speculators who before the financial crisis used to race down the aisles as soon as the doors opened in order to snag a work that they thought they could flip at a profit a few months later. Indeed, on Wednesday during “First Choice” things seemed sedate compared to the years before 2008. Some described the giant convention hall as “empty.”

headline: Omega’s Cooperman Bullish on Stocks
text: Economic growth in the United States, intervention by the European Central Bank and a toning down of antiwealth sentiment from President Obama will help pave the way for a bullish market, Leon Cooperman of Omega Advisors told an audience at a hedge fund conference on Thursday.

headline: A Hedge Fund Charity for Up-And-Comers
text: Hedge fund up-and-comers that want to give back — but not as much as the industry titans — will have their chance Thursday night at the fifth annual London gala for Hedge Funds Care.

headline: Election Results Challenged in Ivory Coast
text: ABIDJAN, Ivory Coast  A historic presidential election intended to unify this long-divided nation slipped further into uncertainty on Thursday, as a heated tug of war emerged over who had the power to proclaim a winner.

headline: How Much Untapped Oil Is There? Answers Vary
text: As John Broder and I report in Thursday’s Times, the Obama administration has reversed itself on opening vast acreage along the Atlantic coast and in the eastern Gulf of Mexico to new oil and gas drilling.

headline: Diller Steps Down as C.E.O. of IAC
text: For Barry Diller, an end to a “great, and occasionally, wild ride.”

headline: No Flipping: IFC Adds Classic 1990s Comedies to Its Lineup
text: While the IFC cable channel stakes its future on a slate of original comedies aimed at young male viewers who like to stay up until the wee hours, it is also looking to the recent past to help build its library. On Thursday IFC said it had acquired the rights to four breakthrough comedy shows from the 1990s, a not-too-long-ago era when David Cross and Bob Odenkirk were wide-eyed newcomers looking for things to be cynical about, and Judd Apatow produced everything but nobody realized it yet.

headline: A Scene From 'Black Swan'
text: Natalie Portman and Vincent Cassel in a scene from "Black Swan."

headline: For the N.Y.P.D., an Award From PETA
text: The suspects were small and furry and elusive, as mice tend to be. They were scurrying around Police Headquarters in Lower Manhattan. Janitors were put on the case. Traps were set — glue traps, to be exact. We wrote about them. But not everyone was happy: someone complained to People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals.

headline: Should Tax Rates Be More Gradual?
text: Think your annual income tax return is complicated now? Imagine if you had to calculate a new tax rate for each additional $2,000 of income you earned.

headline: McCain Questions Pentagon on Repeal of Gay Ban
text: WASHINGTON  Senator John McCain, the Arizona Republican and Vietnam-era war hero, took on the nation’s top defense and military officials Thursday when he repeatedly challenged the Pentagon’s position that gay men and women should be allowed to serve openly in the armed forces.

headline: Now Reading | ‘Designers Against AIDS: The First Decade’
text: Ninette Murk is a woman with a mission. It has been 10 years since she founded Designers Against AIDS, an international organization that enlists popular culture to raise awareness of the disease and keep discussions about it alive in the media.

headline: Two Charged in Bronx Antigay Attacks Were Victims, Indictment Says
text: Two of the young men initially charged in the October antigay attacks in the Bronx were actually among its victims, according to a 75-count indictment unsealed on Wednesday. Prosecutors had already dropped charges against the two teenagers in the weeks after their arrest.

text: Darren Aronofsky discusses an audition scene from “Black Swan,” featuring Natalie Portman, Vincent Cassel and Mila Kunis.

headline: Jolie Film About Bosnian War Continues to Stoke Controversy
text: Angelina Jolie defended a film she is directing about a love story set during the 1990s Bosnian war from a fresh round of criticism, saying she did not intend to cause controversy and that most Bosnians supported the project, Reuters reported.

headline: Attention-Grabber for Sudan’s Cause
text: “I do human rights the way I played basketball,” John Prendergast said. We were sitting in the outdoor restaurant of an unfinished hotel in Juba, a boomtown of mud and shanties beside the White Nile in southern Sudan. It’s a restaurant where the South’s liberation leaders tend to gather, and these days they are in a buoyant mood. They have traded their fatigues for dress shirts and suits. A half-century of civil war seems to be culminating in independence. If a referendum on Jan. 9 goes as expected, the map of Africa will be redrawn — with a new nation around the size of Texas. But for the moment, Prendergast, who is America’s most influential activist in Africa’s most troubled regions and who huddled on a White House patio with President Barack Obama a few days earlier, talked about basketball guards.

headline: Company of We
text: Christopher Crawford and Jayzel Samonte discuss how their company came together while inside their pop-up shop in the West Village.

headline: Officials Detail Terrorist Ties to Passport Ring
text: BANGKOK  Investigators in Thailand and Spain were scrutinizing the operations of a suspected counterfeiting network on Thursday, a day after 10 people were arrested in Barcelona and Thailand on suspicion of providing stolen, doctored European passports to terrorists entering Western countries.

headline: Two More G.O.P. Senators Back Deficit Plan

text: Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer neared an exit from bankruptcy protection on Thursday after a federal judge approved its reorganization plan, less than a month after it filed for Chapter 11.

headline: Microbe Finds Arsenic Tasty; Redefines Life
text: Scientists said Thursday that they had trained a bacterium to eat and grow on a diet of arsenic, in place of phosphorus  one of six elements considered essential for life  opening up the possibility that organisms could exist elsewhere in the universe or even here on Earth using biochemical powers we have not yet dared to dream about.

headline: Pepsi’s Russian Play: A Big Deal in Deals

headline: Q&A: 3 Generations to Rome for the Holidays
text: Seven people, from a 16-year-old grandson to 79-year-old Grandpa, will be in Rome over the holidays. Will we starve on Christmas Eve and Christmas Day, or be forced to eat in an expensive hotel? It is also Grandpa’s big birthday the day after Christmas. Where to celebrate?

headline: An Airport Program That Makes Traveling (Gasp!) Easier
text: With Transportation Security Administration screening techniques getting extra personal of late, it’s tempting to think that the airport experience only goes from bad to worse. But Global Entry, the latest “trusted traveler” program from the Customs and Border Protection agency, is that rare beast: a government initiative that is making international travel more convenient.

headline: TimesCast | December 2, 2010
text: Don't ask don't tell hearings; World Cup announcements and AMC scores another hit with "The Walking Dead."

headline: In Malaysia, Tourists Are Lured by George Town’s Colorful Past
text: BEHIND the Goddess of Mercy Temple in George Town, the capital of the Malaysian state of Penang, a rebirth is under way. For as long as anyone can remember, the eastern end of Stewart Lane, which runs behind the temple, has been marred by the blackened shells of seven historic terrace houses. Several years ago a suspicious fire left the houses roofless. But inside, allusions to a grand past remained: skeletons of timber staircases, bits of terra-cotta tile, indigo patches of lime wash on walls rising 25 feet.

headline: The Life Aquatic
text: O.K., Peru’s Ica River is going dry, thanks to global asparagus. The Colorado River is already spoken for, every acre-foot of it —totally oversubscribed. Lake Mead may soon be merely a spit in the bucket. You could cross through many parts of the Rio Grande on your hands and knees without drowning. And all over the globe, tourists are making pilgrimages to say goodbye to the glaciers.

headline: Banning Circumcision?
text: Lloyd Schofield, a retired hotel credit manager in San Francisco, is determined to protect all infants and children in that city from “forced genital cutting” and he is gathering signatures on a petition to bring the question to the city’s voters next November.

headline: The Smartphone Race Heats Up
text: According to a report released Wednesday by the Nielsen Company, a market research firm, 30 percent of all mobile phones in the United States are smartphones as customers move away from standard-issue mobile devices. The trend is expected to continue as consumers jump to the Apple iPhone, Google Android platform and the new Windows Phone 7 devices.

headline: F.C.C. Commissioner Proposes ‘Public Values Test’

headline: Art Basel Miami Beach | The Art of Parties, Day Two
text: Surrealism is having another moment in the sun, but not necessarily at the A.B.M.B. fair. How else to describe the weird scenes taking place at parties all over town last night? At the A-list majora dinner at Mr. Chow hosted by Larry Gagosian, Dasha Zhukova and Wendi Murdoch, Daphne Guinness arrived in head to toe couture accessorized with red headphones and a plastic Walgreen’s bag. Equally unreal was Alex Rodriguez, Julian Lennon and Linda Evangelista rubbing shoulder pads with the likes of Aby Rosen and the Russian artists Ilya and Emilia Kabakov. (Speaking of Rodriguez, what to make of the rumor that Madonna is also said to be in town?)

headline: A Visit From an Acting Deity
text: “I saw God today,” Javier Bardem said Wednesday night, having a smoke outside the party for “Biutiful,” the Alejandro González Iñárritu movie in which he stars. “I saw God and God talked to me, and I’m actually amazed by his grace.” God, for Mr. Bardem, is Al Pacino, who made a surprise visit to the celeb-stocked party, after his performance in “The Merchant of Venice” on Broadway. Mr. Pacino, his hair in a messy little ponytail, chatted with Mr. Bardem, who eagerly introduced him to Penélope Cruz, his very pregnant wife. Mr. Pacino promptly touched her belly. (“He touched the baby!” Mr. Bardem gushed later.) They all talked and laughed in a tight circle for a few moments.

headline: Ireland Agonistes
text: Kevin O’Rourke has put out a beautifully written, heartfelt piece on Ireland’s woes. Read it and weep.

headline: ‘I Destroyed Innocent Lives,’ Cheshire Killer Says
text: NEW HAVEN  On the day he was formally sentenced to die, Steven J. Hayes stood in a baggy orange prison jumpsuit in a crowded courtroom on Thursday and said he took responsibility for the crime that ended with the deaths of a Cheshire, Conn., woman and her two daughters.

headline: Katie Couric to Fox? Yes, for an Episode of ‘Glee’

text: While the Environmental Protection Agency, General Motors and others differ on what the proper fuel economy rating for the Chevy Volt plug-in hybrid is, one customer is delighted to say that he has driven more than 1,100 miles on less than a quarter-tank of gas. headline: AMP Signs Deal to Deliver Electric S.U.V.’s to Iceland
text: Iceland, geologically blessed with an abundance of renewable energy resources like hydropower and geothermal, is hoping to use some of that energy to run the country’s automobiles. On Monday, Cincinnati-based AMP Holding announced it had signed a letter of intent to deliver 1,000 electric sport utility vehicles over five years to Northern Lights Energy, a company that is constructing a network of electric vehicle charging points throughout Iceland.

headline: Market Watch | Lashfully
text: Last year, the eyelash industry generated roughly $1 billion. Despite the apparent popularity, it is still one of the beauty industry’s best kept secrets — people do not want to divulge about enhancements to their lashes. With “lash boutiques” popping up across the country, T caught up with Lashfully, a start-up lash salon to get under the lid of this latest beauty phenomenon.

headline: Syracuse to Play in Pinstripe Bowl

headline: Selections Challenge Soccer’s Past and Future
text: The World Cup in Russia in 2018 will be spread across by far the biggest country in Europe. Then, four years later, the tournament in Qatar, an oil-rich land of only 1.7 million people, will be the most compact ever.

headline: For the Jets, Brady Is All Smiles
text: FOXBOROUGH, Mass. — If there was any doubt that the New England Patriots are muzzling themselves this week, Tom Brady cleared it up.

headline: The Big Names Return for Sundance’s Unofficial Section
text: LOS ANGELES— Here come the stars: the Sundance Film Festival announced its roster of films playing out of competition on Thursday and the selections – unlike those in the competitive slate – include marquee names on both sides of the camera.

headline: On Point, on Top, in Pain
text: A witchy brew of madness and cunning, “Black Swan” tells the story of a ballerina who aches, with battered feet and an increasingly crowded head, to break out of the corps. Played by Natalie Portman in a smashing, bruising, wholly committed performance, the young dancer, Nina, looks more like a child than a woman, her flesh as undernourished as her mind. When she goes to bed at night, a nearby jewelry box tinkling “Swan Lake,” a crowd of stuffed animals watches over her, longtime companions that — as Nina and this dementedly entertaining film grow more unhinged — begin to look more like jailers than friends.

headline: World Cup Announcements
text: FIFA announces Russia will host the 2018 soccer World Cup and Qatar in 2022.  The Times's Tom Jolly and Tom Connelly report.

headline: Pulled from National Portrait Gallery, Video Emerges Elsewhere in Washington
text: Visitors to the National Portrait Gallery in Washington will no longer be able to find the David Wojnarowicz video “A Fire in My Belly” there, but they will not have to travel far to see it. Transformer, a Washington-based arts organization, has been playing it in the front window of its gallery on P Street NW, near Logan Circle, and says it will continue to do so on a 24-hour loop until the National Portrait Gallery reinstates it.

headline: Suicide at Center of Publicist Mystery
text: LOS ANGELES  His name was Harold, according to neighbors at the Harvey Apartments, though he offered different last names in various conversations, which was not particularly unusual at this way station for transients in a run-down corner of Hollywood. He had spoken of serving time in prison, of having a gun, of various exploits.

headline: Leek Croquettes: Perfect With a Drink
text: In restaurants it’s impossible to pass on certain things: fish and chips; fritto misto; tempura; croquettes. How can a plate of raw fluke with red peppercorns and yuzu juice compete? Sometimes my wife, Jackie, and I try to pretend they’re an afterthought: “Oh — and a little plate of those fried whitebait … for the table.” (Always a “little” plate — like “just a drop” of wine.)

headline: Creative State of Mind: Focusing on the Writing Process
text: Overview | How can using writer’s notebooks and practicing the use of literary elements help writers develop ideas? In this lesson, students examine the lyrics of rap artist Jay-Z for literary elements including rhyme, metaphor, puns and allusions, then consider what he says about his own writing process. Finally, they analyze additional lyrics and apply lessons from Jay-Z’s process to their own reading and writing.

headline: U.S. Should Know There’s No Sulking in Soccer
text: Soccer is, after all, the world’s game. It belongs to the 203 nations that play the sport, from Spain all the way to Papua New Guinea, neither of which will be hosting the 2018 or the 2022 World Cup.

headline: G.O.P. Proposes Rule Changes for House
text: It’s nothing personal, Chi Chi Rodriguez.

headline: Deforestation Slows as Brazil Chugs Toward a Goal
text: While many countries are somewhat stalled in their efforts to reduce greenhouse gas emissions, Brazil has been making progress, in large part by combating deforestation of the Amazon. President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva has helped Brazil show itself as one of the greener large developing countries.

headline: The Real Mother of Invention
text: Wilmot McCutcheon, from Orinda, Calif., offered the following reaction to my piece on new ways to shift education to stimulate innovation and to seek innovations that spread the gifts of education. His view is valuable and well worth highlighting here as a “Your Dot” contribution:

headline: In Good Company
text: Christopher Crawford and Jayzel Samonte started Company of We a little over a year ago from their downtown Manhattan apartment. Launched initially as an online-only boutique, the boys, 30 and 28 respectively, watched as their playful toggle coats and double-breasted captain’s jackets gained a virtual following, only to be later snatched up by the likes of Saks Fifth Avenue. This month, the designers opened up a pop-up shop in the West Village, where they are manning the registers, meeting their customers face to face for the first time. “It breathes life into our digital roots,” Crawford said of the earthy, masculine space. The shop also serves as a platform to introduce the Company of We’s women’s capsule collection, featuring easy, ladylike confections like an elongated dinner jacket with metallic detailing and a pastel pleated skirt. The couple’s first foray into women’s wear channels both the interior designer Kelly Wearstler (“She was a Playboy Playmate, has impeccable taste and is now filthy rich,” says Samonte) as well as friend and fashion journalist, Meenal Mistry, (“Stylish, slightly mysterious, intelligent and aspirational,” says Crawford). And as for sharing a life as well as a business? “The New Yorker and Bravo’s ‘Real Housewives’ can be the perfect high-low distraction,” Samonte says with a laugh.

headline: Will Today’s Unemployed Become Tomorrow’s Unemployable?
text: Lots of smart economists and policy makers have been debating whether the problems in the job market are primarily cyclical (that is, temporary, and related to slack demand) or primarily structural (that is, reflecting a deeper problem in the economy, such as a tougher mismatch between the skills employers want and the skills workers have).

text: Talks between the Yankees and Derek Jeter appear to be slowly moving forward, and the team now appears willing to offer its captain and shortstop a contract of three or four years at $16 million to $18 million a year, according to two people in baseball briefed on the status of the negotiations.

The new program, also offered online by many other news organizations, was introduced to improve and widen Times readers’ sharing experience.

headline: Art Basel Miami Beach | Ruba Katrib
text: Ruba Katrib has been organizing some of the freshest and smartest museum shows anywhere — in Miami. As the associate curator at the Museum of Contemporary Art (MOCA) in North Miami, Katrib — a West Virginia native with a master’s degree from Bard College’s renowned Center for Curatorial Studies — has been responsible for recent surveys of Cory Arcangel and Claire Fontaine, and sprawling, international concept shows like last year’s “The Reach of Realism.” The Moment caught up with the creative force who helps to keep the city on the map all those other 51 weeks of the year.

headline: Cables Offer Shifting Portrait of Karzai
text: WASHINGTON  Oman’s foreign minister says that he is “losing confidence” in him. A British diplomat says Britain feels “deep frustration” with him, while an Australian official complains that he “ignores reality.” A diplomat from the United Arab Emirates says Afghanistan would be better off without him. NATO’s secretary general speculates that he has a split personality.

headline: Cables Depict Afghan Graft, Starting at Top
text: This article is by Scott Shane, Mark Mazzetti and Dexter Filkins.

headline: Co-op in the Platt-Designed ‘Studio Building’ Is for Sale
text: IN 1904, when Charles A. Platt was commissioned to design an artists’ co-op studio building on 66th Street and Lexington Avenue, he was known as the country’s foremost architect of country houses, all heavily influenced by the style of the Italian Renaissance. The 11-story building was not only Mr. Platt’s first large-scale urban commission; it would also become his New York City home.

headline: Congress Approves Child Nutrition Bill
text: WASHINGTON  Congress gave final approval on Thursday to a child nutrition bill that expands the school lunch program and sets new standards to improve the quality of school meals, with more fruits and vegetables.

headline: Night of Tributes and Performance, Too
text: Alvin Ailey died 21 years ago, on Dec. 1, the very date that his namesake company opened its annual season at City Center this year. He would surely have been astounded and delighted to see the by-now ritualized Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater opening night: the red carpet, the photographers, the stars, the speeches, the money.

headline: Creating Primal Wilderness With Lunges and Antlers
text: Among the many marvelous aspects of the Chocolate Factory is the way in which this most specific of theaters is utterly transformed by each new occupant. Something about the rough little industrial space makes imaginations grow big. (I suspect that it’s an artist-run organization has something to do with it.)

text: TIVO started the modern home entertainment revolution with DVR technology, allowing consumers to watch the shows they wanted, when they wanted. Appointment television  shows worth building a schedule around  was obliterated.

headline: Obama Seeking Aid for Jobless in Deal on Tax Cuts
text: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration is holding out for an extension of unemployment assistance and of a variety of expiring tax breaks for low-wage and middle-income workers as part of a deal with Congressional Republicans to extend all the Bush-era tax cuts.

headline: Fun by the Barrel (Wine, Too)
text: BEADS of sweat covered Lorraine Nedell’s forehead as she bent over a cluster of merlot grapes one sunny fall morning at Sannino’s Bella Vita Vineyard in Peconic, N.Y., on Long Island. Inching along the row of vines, she grabbed the purple berries, snipped them with a clipper and dropped them, over and over, into a plastic bin.

headline: Survival Proves Popular
text: “Survivor: Nicaragua” topped the ratings on Wednesday night as 12.2 million viewers tuned in to that CBS reality show, according to Nielsen’s estimates. That put the program easily ahead of its 8 p.m. rivals, including NBC’s “Undercovers” (4.8 million), Fox’s “Human Target” (5.8 million) and the season finale of CW’s “America’s Next Top Model” (3.4 million). CBS led the night over all despite a meager audience for its live 10 p.m. Grammy nominations concert special (5.1 million). NBC was second, earning solid results for “Law & Order: SVU” (9.2 million) and “Law & Order: Los Angeles” (9.1 million) at 9 and 10. Fox was third and ABC was fourth.

headline: Honey, Let’s Get a Little Divorced
text: MY husband and I recently celebrated a milestone. It was the day we’d been married for 13 years, 2 months and about a week: the day our marriage outlasted my parents’ marriage.

headline: T Exclusive Video | Julian Assange
text: T’s forthcoming Holiday issue includes a feature on Julian Assange, the controversial founder of WikiLeaks. In this exclusive behind-the-scenes video, filmed during the last week of September, our features and entertainment director Jacob Brown and the photographer Max Vadukul track the elusive Assange to London.

headline: Taking Square Aim at Critics, E.P.A. Marks Its 40th
text: In the summer of 1970, President Richard M. Nixon consolidated the anti-pollution enforcement powers of 15 federal departments into a single new entity, the Environmental Protection Agency. “We’re going after the polluters,” William D. Ruckelshaus, the agency’s first director, said after his nomination to the post. “All of them.”

headline: Celebrating New Music, Just Off the Beaten Path
text: Calling your new-music festival Darmstadt Essential Repertoire is a conscious provocation on multiple levels, as the New York composers Zach Layton and Nick Hallett surely realized when they chose the name. It alludes to the Darmstadt International Summer Courses for New Music, a venerable and formidable German laboratory for avant-garde innovation, known for dogmatic (and sometimes rancorous) adherence to modernist severity.

headline: Retail Without a Safety Net
text: When Nina Garduno opened Free City Supershop in 2005, in a strip mall in Malibu, Calif., it was hard to describe the place. It wasn’t a boutique, exactly, though she sold clothes and jewelry. It wasn’t a “concept store,” though it offered a genuine sense of discovery rare in the world of retail. And you hesitated to lump it with the deadly term “lifestyle,” though she sold refurbished bicycles, custom turntables and teepees.

headline: Adding Green Space to MoMA With Tropical Terrariums
text: The Museum of Modern Art lobby — that awkward space designed by the Japanese architect Yoshio Taniguchi — spans a city block, making it as much a thoroughfare as a museum entrance. People flood the place throughout the day, ducking in from the cold, avoiding street traffic or simply using it as a meeting spot.

headline: ‘Social Network’ Nabs Season’s First Big Award
text: “The Social Network” was a big hit with the National Board of Review, which on Thursday awarded it several top prizes, including best feature, best director (David Fincher), best actor (Jesse Eisenberg) and best adapted screenplay (Aaron Sorkin). The group’s president, Annie Schulhof, lauded the truthy drama for being a timeless story that will “appeal to many generations,” especially if or when Facebook takes over the world.

text: Mr. Kaufman, 51, is the founder of Gene Kaufman Architect, a New York firm that specializes in hotels and multifamily housing.

text: If you’re in the market for certain energy-efficient home improvements, you may want to act quickly.

headline: Back When Theater Was Simply Unrolled
text: Victorian theatergoers packed halls to watch canvases roll past. Entrepreneurs would ship paintings of exotic scenery hundreds of feet long to theaters nationwide, and stagehands, as if anticipating animated movies, would slowly reveal section after section of the “moving panoramas.” Pianists supplied uplifting music, and actors’ voice-overs explained the plot.

headline: BlackBerry Aims for a Better Look
text: Research In Motion, which gave us the BlackBerry, was once considered the leader in mobile phone technology, creating mobile devices that changed the business world and rapidly propelled the adoption of instant communication.

headline: Canal Street, Is That Really You?
text: IF ever a street seemed to embody the cacophony of New York City, Canal Street would be it. Tourists throng Canal’s sidewalks in search of bargains on copycat designer goods; commuters surge in and out of a maze of subway stops; and in the evening cars and trucks jostle to enter the Holland Tunnel amid a sea of brake lights and a jangle of horns.

text: A look at some of the selections from the Fifth Romanian Film Festival in NYC.

headline: British Tell How Rescue by G.I.’s Broke Down
text: LONDON  The British government revealed details on Thursday of a harrowing attempt by American Special Forces troops to mount a nighttime rescue of a British aid worker kidnapped by the Taliban in the highlands of eastern Afghanistan, and of the woman’s death when an American soldier threw a hand grenade into a gully where she was being held.

headline: Jazz Listings for Dec. 3-9
text: Jazz

headline: Maybe a Dinosaur, Just Not Purple
text: Barney Panofsky, a Montreal policeman’s son, meets his third wife at his second wedding, a gilded gala that he stumbles into halfway between his wayward bohemian youth and his distempered dotage. Barney, played with shambling energy and vulgar elegance by Paul Giamatti, catches a sudden, breathtaking glimpse of Miriam (Rosamund Pike) and pretty much forgets about the unnamed ninny he has just married (even though she is played by the lovely Minnie Driver).

headline: ‘Last Supper’ for the Laptop Generation
text: IF you had tied on a blindfold, suspended disbelief and allowed yourself to be carried last week to a particular location just off Park Avenue near 66th Street, your reopened eyes would have had trouble telling that they were not inside the Santa Maria delle Grazie monastery in Milan, looking at a sight everyone knows and few have actually seen: a magisterial painting of 13 enrobed men seated oddly on one side of a long dinner table.

headline: Museum and Gallery Listings for Dec. 3-9
text: Art

headline: Baucus to Vote Against Debt Plan
text: Senator Max Baucus said on Thursday that he will vote against the debt-reduction plan before President Obama’s bipartisan commission when it votes on Friday, dealing a blow to the effort given his role as chairman of the Senate committee that would deal with the sort of tax changes and spending cuts the plan proposes.

headline: A Spitfire Onstage, Singing of Young Love and Achy Hearts
text: A little over two years ago Lykke Li played a show at Le Poisson Rouge to celebrate the release of her debut album, “Youth Novels.” Wednesday night she was back on the circular stage there, introducing songs from her coming second album, “Wounded Rhymes.” Certain things hadn’t changed.

headline: Pellegrini Reflects on His Decision to Leave
text: Paolo Pellegrini, best known for helping the hedge fund manager John A. Paulson earn billions in a bet against subprime mortgages, has a lot of time to think about the market these days.

headline: A Pianist Explores the Smoother Side of an Often-Aggressive Sound
text: It was not so long ago that when the Russian piano style was mentioned, what came to mind was a huge, steely, aggressive sound with a dynamic range that ran from fortissimo to quadruple fortissimo. Things are different now. Power remains a hallmark of Russian pianism, but young players like Olga Kern and Kirill Gerstein have made gracefulness, precision and subtlety parts of the equation too.

headline: Cracking Open a Holiday Classic
text: STROLL down Fifth Avenue this month, or along an aisle at Target, or through any other shopping establishment for that matter, and you will inevitably hear Tchaikovsky’s “Nutcracker.” The music is so ingrained in the Christmas routine that it can be hard to hear it amid the holiday hubbub. But that is what Mark Morris wants audiences to do with his creation, “The Hard Nut.”

headline: Weekend Miser
text: The 19th annual Double Dutch Holiday Classic is a competition that goes beyond anything you saw as a kid at your neighborhood playground. On Sunday students from around the world compete for spots on national and international double dutch teams, using, well, themselves and jump ropes, along with music, dance and gymnastics. The festivities begin at 1 p.m. at the Apollo Theater. Tickets can be bought online at Ticketmaster.com, by phone at (800) 745-3000, or at the Apollo box office. (253 West 125th Street, Harlem; 212-531-5305; apollotheater.org; $20-$22.)

headline: A Deal on the Tax Dispute? Not So Fast
text: The White House may be compromising with Republicans on the Bush-era tax cuts, but it moved on Thursday to dispel reports that a deal (read: capitulation) is at hand.

headline: Getting Small: A Man’s World, in Miniature
text: If Charles LeDray does not have little, nimble-fingered elves working in platoons around the clock under his direction, then I don’t know how he does it. His magical retrospective “workworkworkworkwork”  consisting mainly of thousands of miniature pieces of clothing, tiny ceramic vessels and dollhouse-scale furniture at the Whitney Museum of American Art  is dumbfounding. That one man could have singlehandedly created all these things defies credibility. (The exhibition was organized by Randi Hopkins, an associate curator at the Institute of Contemporary Art, Boston, where it first appeared this year.)

headline: Discounts Abound for Popular Hybrid Cameras
text: FOR several years, camera makers have trained their engineering expertise on the sweet spot between compact point-and-shoot cameras and chunky (yet capable) D.S.L.R.’s. An ideal combination would involve a small chassis, a big image sensor, the ability to swap out interchangeable lenses and snap-simple ease of use.

headline: Movies Listings for Dec. 3-9
text: Movies

headline: Ghost Town Where the Koreas Clashed
text: YEONPYEONG ISLAND, South Korea — Besides the military forces on the hill, Yeonpyeong Island has only about 1,400 residents in normal times. When North Korea shelled the village on Nov. 23, nearly every civilian was evacuated or fled to the mainland.

headline: The Flesh and Blood Behind the AK-47
text: It is no accident that C. J. Chivers opens “The Gun,” his bold history of the AK-47, not with the loud crack that is the report of the rifle but with the monstrous bang of the first detonation of a Soviet nuclear bomb. As Mr. Chivers’s detailed history then skirts as far back as the United States Civil War and brings us right up to the current conflict in Afghanistan, the message of his prologue is clear: For all that the escalating cold war shaped the last 60 years, no one was ever killed in conflict by a Russian nuke. By contrast untold millions have been wounded and killed by the AK-47 and related weapons, as they have proliferated and mutated from tools of engineering ingenuity, honestly wrought in defense of the socialist motherland, to the firearm of choice for both oppressor and oppressed.

headline: Digital Devices Can Become Objects of Affection
text: I GAVE up my Palm Treo smartphone last year for an iPhone. It had been my companion for nearly five years, a long time for a cellphone. At the end people laughed at it, and by extension, at me. But I liked the feel of the thing. I liked what it, one of the first smartphones, could do.

headline: Assorted Acts of Betrayal Among the Moneyed and Dysfunctional
text: There are various bad things in “All Good Things,” principally a dictatorial father, a submissive son and the tragic fates of the two unfortunate women who married them. These bad things are part of a strange case named David Marks, a fictional character based on Robert A. Durst, the true-life son of a New York real estate developer, Seymour Durst. Among the weirder bad things: in 1982 the younger Mr. Durst’s wife, Kathie, disappeared. In 2000 his friend Susan Berman was murdered. (Both cases remain open.) A year later, while living as a mute woman in Texas, he killed (and chopped up) a neighbor in self-defense. Well, the jury called it self-defense before sending him to jail. The film takes a somewhat different view.

headline: Gift Choices for Lovers of the Next Big Thing
text: TO be any kind of enthusiast, techies included, requires a modicum of snobbery. So if you are pondering a gift for your gadget lover, it had better be the Next Big Thing, otherwise you risk (at best) tepid thanks before your costly gizmo goes to the back of a drawer.

headline: Country Dancing in the Big City
text: THE sound of fiddles and foot stomping may be the last thing you expect to hear at the Chinatown Y.M.C.A. Nevertheless, every weekend Country Dance New York turns the basketball courts into a country dance hall, filled with jigs, reels and plenty of swinging your partner.

headline: Clinton Moves to Ease Tensions on Kyrgyz Base
text: BISHKEK, Kyrgyzstan  Hoping to defuse the latest round of tensions over a strategically important American air base, Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton said Thursday that the United States would steer part of a lucrative Pentagon jet fuel contract to a newly created Kyrgyz state-owned corporation.

headline: House Votes to Censure Rangel
text: The House of Representatives voted to censure Representative Charles B. Rangel, Democrat of New York, for a host of ethics violations. Read City Room’s live blog of the proceedings.

headline: A TV That Sounds Great Right Out of the Box
text: MOST solutions to mediocre television sound involve external devices like sound bars and surround-sound systems. Bose, maker of speakers, headphones and other audio equipment, took another approach: a TV that sounds good to begin with.

headline: Time Inc. Names No. 2 Editor, Signaling Possible Succession Plan
text: Time Inc. has revived its long-vacant No. 2 editorial position in a major management reorganization that centralizes a far-flung media empire stretching from Menlo Park, Calif., to Birmingham, Ala.

headline: Rangel Censured Over Violations of Ethics Rules
text: WASHINGTON  Representative Charles B. Rangel, his gaze steady and his hands clasped before him, stood silently in the well of the House of Representatives on Thursday as Speaker Nancy Pelosi somberly read a resolution censuring him for bringing discredit to the House.

headline: Shopping for a Smartphone, With a Focus on Features
text: WHEN shopping for a smartphone, it is common to be drawn to the coolest design. But a phone is basically a collection of features wrapped in a case. Too often that case is a distraction from what is more important: whether the phone has the right features for its prospective user and how well those features work.

headline: Obama Promises to Work With Governors on Education, Economy
text: President Obama hosted a luncheon on Thursday for newly elected governors across the street from the White House at Blair House, where he promised to work closely with them to fix the economy and improve education over the next two years.

text: THE sound bar, a single box that can replace a set of surround-sound speakers, can be a great gift idea for anyone who wants better sound out of a television but does not have the space or budget to set up a full-blown home theater.

headline: Design Miami | Q&A With Aranda\Lasch
text: Whether it’s designing the Design Miami exhibition tent (in 2008, 2009, and 2010), showing their work at the Johnson Trading Gallery booth, or conceiving the fair’s floor plan (2010), Ben Aranda and Chris Lasch of the New York architecture firm Aranda\Lasch have been a consistent presence at the fair. This year, they added another arrow to their quiver: a Fendi-sponsored booth that showcases Modern Primitives, a collection of objects that are the product of the firm’s research into developing crystalline shapes into building systems. Despite the name, the concept behind their latest venture is anything but primitive, including references to the revolutionary 17th-century mathematician Johannes Kepler and a special app the duo devised to generate different formations. But the end results are beautiful sculptural pieces that fulfill both a function (in this case, mostly seating) and offer the possibility of being developed into a full-fledged architectural system. The Moment sat down with Ben and Chris to discuss the process behind the project, and how the storied Roman luxury house became part of the equation.

headline: Where Alcoholism Drinks in the Laughs
text: Television has a drinking problem.

headline: A Big Box for an Overlooked R&B Career
text: FOUR years ago Syl Johnson, a Chicago soul singer beloved by R&B purists but otherwise not well known today, was approached by the Numero Group, a small record label that wanted to reissue some of his music from the 1960s and ’70s. Mr. Johnson said bluntly that he was not interested.

headline: Lots of Wine, but None to Drink

headline: House Tour: Saugerties, N.Y.

headline: As Biodiversity Declines, Disease Flourishes
text: A study by a group of biologists, ecologists and medical researchers casts new light on a phenomenon farmers have known for years: the less the genetic variety in a crop or a herd, the greater the risk that disease will decimate it. The presence of many species in ecosystems, the scientists report in  Thursday’s issue of the journal Nature, damps a pathogen’s ability to spread among humans.

headline: Guilt, Anxiety, Obstacles: Adultery Is Hard Work
text: Except during its three heated sex scenes, “Come Undone,” a sober exploration of the disruptive effects of adultery on family life, portrays infidelity, despite its thrills, as almost more trouble than it’s worth. At the same time those sex scenes (nude but not anatomically explicit) show the power of unleashed passion to make the rest of life feel like a laborious, frustrating slog. Directed by Silvio Soldini from a screenplay he wrote with Doriana Leondeff and Angelo Carbone, this movie is set in and around Milan, which is filmed without a smidgen of glamour.

headline: Excerpt: 'The Sing-Off'
text: The NBC singing competition returns for another season.

headline: Vengeful? Combative? There’s a Game for You
text: In 2010, makers served up a bounty of engrossing choices for adults who enjoy violent, intense video games.

headline: 'Metamorphosis'
text: Photos from the show at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

headline: Napolitano Backs Immigration Bill
text: The secretary of homeland security, Janet Napolitano, called on Congress to pass a bill granting legal status to many thousands of illegal immigrant students, saying it would help immigration authorities focus their resources on deporting dangerous criminals.

headline: Canada: ‘Pigeon King’ Arrested in Alleged Squab Scam
text: THE AMERICAS

headline: Amid the Ailing and Uninsured, Hospital Chaplain Finds New Faith
text: Standing in a hallway at Stroger Hospital on Wednesday morning, Dr. Stathis Poulakidas began a weekly status report on the mostly horrific cases in the burn unit he runs.

headline: A Winning Smile Makes the Scamming a Breeze
text: Jim Carrey’s portrayal of Steven Russell, a notorious real-life con man now serving a 144-year sentence in a Texas prison, hot-wires “I Love You Phillip Morris,” a nervy comedy that bills itself as an “improbable but true story.”

headline: Art Basel Miami Beach | Deal Or No Deal?
text: Yesterday’s four consecutive openings of Art Basel Miami Beach — a ten-hour delight for jet-lagged, untanned dealers minding their booths — yielded an overall quiet turnout. On Thursday the fair opened to the public, and beyond the bottleneck at the gates things were … even quieter. Which is not to say dead, or even grim; the mood at Art Basel this year so far has merely been sober. The work is selling. The $20 Champagne is selling. You might say things have been laid back … is that OK? Why not. I even saw an errant Eames chair extrude beyond the limits of a booth, and it was not instantly destroyed by Swiss authorities.

headline: Visual Culture Out of Africa
text: Africa is everywhere, so pervasive in our lives that we barely see it. Since it is in all likelihood the continent where human evolution began, it is literally in the bloodstream of everyone. DNA aside, huge portions of everyday life and cultural achievement are unthinkable without Africa.

headline: Indian State Empowers Poor to Fight Corruption
text: NAGARKURNOOL, India  The village bureaucrat shifted from foot to foot, hands clasped behind his back, beads of sweat forming on his balding head. The eyes of hundreds of wiry village laborers, clad in dusty lungis, were fixed upon him.

headline: Competition Wasn’t Part of CTA’s Apple Deal
text: The Chicago Transit Authority announced last month that it is looking for a consulting firm to help develop a “revenue-generating corporate sponsorship program”  a plan to sell private companies the naming rights to CTA train lines, train stations and bus routes.

headline: An Interview With Stephen A. Schwarzman
text: Stephen A. Schwarzman, the chairman, chief executive and co-founder of the Blackstone Group, talks to Maria Bartiromo of CNBC about the future of private equity.

headline: Africa and Its Legacy
text: Images from “The Global Africa Project” at the Museum of Arts & Design.

headline: Commercial for Oprah Winfrey Network
text: A new commercial being shown in movie theaters features Oprah Winfrey discussing the launch of the Oprah Winfrey Network.

headline: ‘How Wine Became Modern’
text: Images from a new exhibition at the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art.

headline: Some Blustery Gospel, Some Blaring Metal
text: The Rev. Johnny L. Jones

headline: From Women’s College to Football Powerhouse
text: Steve Murphy was surrounded by women while serving as vice president for student affairs at St. Xavier University in Chicago some 20 years ago. Not that he minded, but as a pragmatic, professional educator, he believed a better gender balance within the student body was essential to the university’s long-term health.

headline: Stage Scenes: Lily Rabe
text: Photos of the actress’s past performances in New York.

headline: Living In | Cypress Hills, Brooklyn
text: Cypress Hills, a part of East New York just south of Queens, is a neighborhood on the upswing.

headline: Radical Actions of the ’60s, Reverberating in the Reflective ’70s
text: Although “Night Catches Us,” written and directed by Tanya Hamilton, is haunted by the threat and the memory of violence, its tone is sober and calm, almost serene. Staking out volatile, myth-enshrouded historical territory — Black Panther militancy, police brutality, the ebbing of the revolutionary intensity of the ’60s — Ms. Hamilton tells a modest, complex story with admirable clarity and nuance. That her film is so quiet, so evidently invested in contemplation rather than confrontation, gives it power as well as insight. The large dramatic gestures and sweeping implications are off-screen, between the lines, discernible as a kind of negative afterimage of what is actually seen.

headline: Poles Seek to Overcome Gap in Math and Sciences
text: WARSAW  The newly opened science and technology center here was conceived not only as a place to excite young minds about science and discovery, but also as a chance for Poland to overcome at least one piece of its tragic past, to set aside one legacy of war and occupation  the decline of math and science education.

headline: Chris Paul Sets Standard for N.B.A. Point Guards
text: One of the highlights of the first full month of the N.B.A. season was the outstanding play of the league’s top point guards. This seems to be a golden age for the position, with young stars like the Spurs’ Tony Parker, the Hornets’ Chris Paul, the Celtics’ Rajon Rondo, the Bulls’ Derrick Rose, the Thunder’s Russell Westbrook and the Jazz’s Deron Williams mixed in with veterans like the Mavericks’ Jason Kidd and the Suns’ Steve Nash. This has sparked an age-old debate: Who is the best point guard in the N.B.A.?

headline: After 30 Years, Preserving Nuns’ Legacy
text: There is no way that Flor Lazo could have memories of the unspeakable crime that rocked her homeland, El Salvador, on a distant Dec. 2. That monstrous deed  the torture, rape and murder of four American churchwomen by a military death squad  took place in 1980, a brutal time in El Salvador. Ms. Lazo was not born until five years later.

headline: An Animated Space Odyssey
text: Beginning with accidentally sprayed Russian mucus and ending with deliberately deployed American urine, the plot of “Mars” owes at least as much to bodily fluids as it does to science fiction. Low key, low budget and low energy, this animated space odyssey from the writer and director Geoff Marslett accompanies three mismatched astronauts to the red planet and the search for new life forms.

headline: Discovering a Sinister Santa in Finland
text: The Santa at the center of “Rare Exports: A Christmas Tale” is not the sort Mommy is likely to be kissing beneath the mistletoe (or anywhere else) this year. Rather, the focus of this bizarre Finnish fairy tale — as black as anything the Brothers Grimm could have dreamed up — is a sinister old codger who chews off ears and whose demon minion kidnaps innocent children. Ho ho no!

headline: Managing Risk for JPMorgan, and Blindness
text: LONDON — As a trader at JPMorganChase in London, Ashish Goyal helps manage billions of dollars of the bank’s exposure to risks like foreign exchange fluctuations. In his spare time, he takes tango lessons, plays cricket and goes clubbing with friends. Mr. Goyal is also blind.

headline: Where Prices Are Practical, and Cuisines Colorful
text: IN August, Debra Kayman bought her first home, a two-family on Ashford Street in Cypress Hills, in the East New York section of Brooklyn. She came to the United States from Trinidad and Tobago in 1985, living in East Flatbush with family until her move to Cypress Hills in 1988. There she rented a succession of apartments, including one on Arlington Avenue near the stately Arlington branch of the Brooklyn Public Library, built a century ago by the steel magnate Andrew Carnegie.

headline: Remaking a School Lunch
text: How the nutrition bill would change a meal.

headline: Inside the Life of a Leader
text: “Bhutto,” a documentary about Benazir Bhutto, the two-time prime minister of Pakistan who was killed while campaigning in 2007, packs an impressive amount of information about Bhutto, her family and Pakistani history into its 111 minutes. If nothing else, the directors, Duane Baughman and Johnny O’Hara, deserve praise for devoting this kind of attention to a foreign leader and to the internal politics of another country (as opposed to how those politics affect the United States).

headline: A New Test Is Proposed in Licensing Radio and TV
text: Michael J. Copps, one of the five commissioners on the Federal Communications Commission, said Thursday that a “public value test” should replace the current licensing system for television and radio stations.

headline: Nonprofits Fear Losing Tax Benefit
text: With the federal government struggling to regain control over the nation’s deficit, a debate is emerging over the charitable deduction and other tax policies that support nonprofit groups.

headline: Iran: Arrests in Attacks on Nuclear Scientists
text: Some perpetrators of the recent bomb attacks on two of the country’s top nuclear scientists have been arrested, Iranian news media reported Thursday. Intelligence Minister Heidar Moslehi said the spy agencies of Israel, the United States and Britain played roles in the attack on Monday, which left one scientist dead and the other wounded, according to Iran’s state-run Press TV.

headline: A Tale of Fevered Ambition
text: There is something cozy and a little claustrophobic about Henry Jaglom’s indulgent Hollywood satires, their characters adrift in a sea of self-involvement. Never mean-spirited or malicious, his tales of striving starlets and broken moguls are designed to amuse rather than mock, and “Queen of the Lot” (a sequel to his 2006 film, “Hollywood Dreams”) is no exception. Filling the roles with friends and family and delivering a few sharp jabs to the industry’s solar plexus, he mixes an exceedingly dry cocktail of fevered ambition and congealed disappointment.

headline: Gaza: Israelis Kill 2 Palestinian Militants
text: The Israeli military said Thursday that it killed two armed Palestinian militants who had approached the Israeli border from Gaza overnight. A spokesman for the militant group Islamic Jihad said that the two men had gone to plant explosives by the border fence “to counter any future Israeli incursion into Gaza.”

headline: A Tough History Begets Unsentimental Films
text: Romania is a small country on the edge of Europe, with a tiny film industry  it’s more like a passionate, fractious, underfinanced social network  and a very large footprint in the world of cinema. Perhaps no nation has more Cannes prizes per capita, or a better streak at that festival, where Romanian films have been one of the big stories of the past decade.

headline: Small, Hot and Loaded With Cash
text: SANA, Yemen  Qatar, winner of the bid for the 2022 World Cup, has undertaken a number of ambitious building projects in recent years, earning a global reputation despite its tiny size.

headline: Oprah Winfrey Channel Gears Up for Its Debut
text: IN a one-minute ad that starts Friday in movie theaters across the country, the voice of the Black Eyed Peas frontman will.i.am calls out to dreamers, believers and “tomorrow leaders.”

headline: Restraint Layered Over Scales of Expression
text: “We’re shy people,” Johan Duncanson of the Radio Dept. told a sold-out Bowery Ballroom audience on Wednesday night, in one of his few moments of stage patter beyond song titles and thank yous. That would account for his vocals, subdued and submerged in the mix, and for the melancholy and reticence in the Radio Dept.’s lyrics: “Words fail me all the time,” he sang as the band’s set began. Behind that reserve, however, is studious craftsmanship and the determination to pinpoint what would otherwise go unsaid.

headline: Euro Zone Is Imperiled by North-South Divide
text: LISBON  Sara Vale Lima, sales manager at Eical, a Portuguese textile company, feels suffocated by the euro. The common currency once meant flush banks and easy credit, but these days it has laid bare a cold reality: Portugal shares the high wages and prices of richer northern European neighbors, but not their competitiveness.

headline: A Novel Way to Sidestep Investor Suits
text: One of the great legal fictions of Wall Street is that mutual funds are independent of the companies that create and run them.

headline: The Sound of Two Hands Texting
text: I ride a shuttle bus every day. This morning, a young woman sat down beside me and started texting: click, click, click. I said gently: “I find that disturbing. Could you possibly save it for later?” She put her phone away, and I thanked her. Then she thought a moment, and said — politely: “Everyone does it. You might just have to deal with it.” What do you make of this?

headline: Qatar a Questionable World Cup Host
text: This year’s soccer World Cup in South Africa, in the end, yielded relatively few surprises. Seven of the eight quarterfinalists hailed from either Europe or South America, soccer’s traditional power continents. The tournament was won by Spain, which was ranked as one of the two strongest teams heading into the competition. Sure, the 2006 finalists, Italy and France, performed poorly. But that should not have shocked anyone who watched these countries’ tepid performances in the qualifying stages.

headline: Amazon Cites Terms of Use in Expulsion of WikiLeaks
text: WASHINGTON  Amazon on Thursday defended its decision to expel WikiLeaks from its Web site hosting service this week after an aide to Senator Joseph I. Lieberman called the company and asked about the relationship.

headline: Caustic U.S. Views of Berlusconi Churn Italy’s Politics
text: ROME  In his dealings with American diplomats, Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi of Italy has often said that he wants his country to be “the best friend of the United States.” In cables to Washington, American diplomats added a few caveats.

headline: Arizona Cuts Financing for Transplant Patients
text: PHOENIX  Even physicians with decades of experience telling patients that their lives are nearing an end are having difficulty discussing a potentially fatal condition that has arisen in Arizona: Death by budget cut.

headline: Analysis of James’s Return to Cleveland
text: The minutes before the tip-off of the Heat-Cavaliers game on TNT were focused entirely on LeBron James and his return to Cleveland. TNT showed James’s 7:52 p.m. Eastern entrance on tape, having not broken into the last minutes of a “Bones” rerun.

headline: N.Y.C. Misdemeanor Defendants Lack Bail Money
text: Thousands of people arrested on low-level crimes in New York City spend days languishing in jail, not because they have been found guilty but because they are too poor to post bail, according to a report to be released on Friday.

headline: Ecuador Tries to Lure Emigrants Home
text: From a spare, second-floor office in Queens, an outpost of the Ecuadorean government offers English classes, computer training and after-school programs to immigrants building new lives in New York City. But these days, the office’s busiest program works in the opposite direction  helping Ecuadoreans go home.

headline: A Killing (a First) in a Town Produced by Disney
text: CELEBRATION, Fla. — As if the Thanksgiving murder were not enough to ruin things in this subdivision that Disney designed. Now, tanks and SWAT teams?

headline: Fiscal Plan Is Expected to Fall Short of Votes
text: WASHINGTON  The ambitious debt-reduction plan before President Obama’s bipartisan commission is likely to get support from a majority of the members on Friday but fall short of the votes needed to send it to Congress for a vote.

text: Great Neck, N.Y.

headline: The Secret Lives of Nations

headline: Curtis Martin Used Football to Find Some Real Work
text: Inside Trinity Boxing Club in Lower Manhattan, Curtis Martin looked more like an active running back than a retired one. He pounded the heavy bag with the biceps of a bodybuilder, his body absent fat, still thick, solid, imposing, perhaps more sculptured than when he left professional football after the 2005 season.

text: This is the final installment of this series.

headline: Vick’s Runs and Passes Rally Eagles Past Texans
text: Michael Vick threw for 302 yards and accounted for 3 touchdowns, rallying the Philadelphia Eagles to a 34-24 victory over the Houston Texans on Thursday night.

headline: Some Democrats Count on ‘Millionaires’ Strategy on Tax Cuts
text: WASHINGTON  The chances of Congress allowing income tax rates to go up only for millionaires: slim. The chances of Democrats using “tax cuts for millionaires” as a political bludgeon against Republican lawmakers: game on.

headline: Freezing Out Hope
text: After the Democratic “shellacking” in the midterm elections, everyone wondered how President Obama would respond. Would he show what he was made of? Would he stand firm for the values he believes in, even in the face of political adversity?

headline: Recount Finds 195,000 Votes Were Missed on Election Night
text: Everybody has misplaced something of value: a set of keys, eyeglasses, a cellphone. The New York City Board of Elections also misplaced something important last month  about 200,000 votes.

headline: Lottery Numbers
After the Decision, the Drubbing
text: CLEVELAND  Six months after the jerseys burned and the fury raged, after “The Decision” and the betrayal, LeBron James returned home and indulged the hatred.

headline: Texas Proposal Spurs Race to Dispose of Nuclear Waste
text: WASHINGTON — Aged nuclear plants in Vermont and Illinois may be playing the equivalent of musical chairs in a graveyard, vying for space at a dump in Texas whose owner hopes to accept radioactive waste from many other states.

headline: A Tax Reform Vision
text: I have a vision.

headline: Groupon’s Biggest Deal Could Transform City’s Tech Start-Ups
text: Chicago has been home to far bigger transactions than the one being discussed between Google and Groupon. But few, if any, have had as much riding on it for the city as this $6 billion deal does.

headline: China, the Enabler
text: What is China thinking? Its client and neighbor North Korea is becoming more belligerent by the week, and Beijing is still playing cynical diplomacy-as-usual.

headline: When Leaders Pass, Like Ships in the Night
text: Democrats and Republicans on Capitol Hill are known for occasionally talking past each other.

headline: Napolitano Drums for Dream Act
text: Homeland Security Secretary Janet Napolitano called on Congress on Thursday to pass a bill granting legal status to thousands of illegal immigrant students, saying it would help immigration authorities focus their resources on deporting dangerous criminals. In a telephone call organized by the White House, Ms. Napolitano told reporters that the students who would benefit “have no fault for being here in the United States” because they were brought here as children. “No one who poses a threat to public safety will be able to adjust their immigration status,” she said, under a revised version of the bill, known as the Dream Act, which was introduced Tuesday. Senator Jeff Sessions of Alabama, a Republican who is a leading opponent, said he would resist it “with every strength and every ability that I have.”

headline: After Daughter’s Death, Helping Others Cope With Dying
text: There is an armchair in the living room of Fran Sax’s apartment covered with the stuffed toys that her patients have asked her to care for: Minnie Mouse sits next to a baby doll, bobbing on a sea of teddy bears.

headline: Amid Routine Business, History and Humiliation
text: WASHINGTON  All week the issue hung around, nagging for attention like a churlish relative, while the House of Representatives considered measures that would rename post offices, lower the volume level of TV commercials and salute the golfer Chi Chi Rodriguez.

headline: Ruling on Newton Is Drawing Criticism
text: Two of the most powerful people in college sports, Big Ten Commissioner Jim Delany and Pacific-10 Commissioner Larry Scott, expressed concerns Thursday about the N.C.A.A.’s decision to declare Auburn quarterback Cam Newton eligible for Saturday’s Southeastern Conference championship game. The N.C.A.A. had acknowledged that Newton’s father used a third party to shop his son in a “pay-for-play” scheme.

headline: Progressives Keep Pressure on Obama
text: Another day, another progressive group hitting President Obama from the left on the Bush-era tax cuts.

headline: Justice Unbound
text: Watching the post-retirement emergence of Justice John Paul Stevens is almost enough to make me a fan of term limits for Supreme Court justices.

headline: Playing Like His Old Self, Woods Grabs the Lead
text: THOUSAND OAKS, Calif.  Not to suggest expectations were lowered for Tiger Woods on Thursday at the Chevron World Challenge, but when he made his third birdie on the front nine, the standard-bearer for Woods’s group reached for a red 3 and found none.

headline: Safety Commission to Push Stronger Helmet Standards
text: WASHINGTON  The self-regulated world of football helmets collided with the federal government Thursday, as the chairwoman of the Consumer Products Safety Commission told a Senate subcommittee that the agency would “monitor and accelerate” the development of stronger standards for headgear, particularly among children.

headline: French Captain Still Wowed by Cup
text: PARIS  It has been a season of Davis Cup flashbacks for Guy Forget, none brighter than the semifinals in September when he returned to Lyon, where he and his French team celebrated victory to the tune of Yannick Noah’s hit single “Saga Africa” with nearly the same enthusiasm that he and Noah had displayed in the same arena way back in 1991.

headline: Advances on the AIDS Front
text: Promising scientific developments to prevent AIDS, not just treat its victims, have sparked hope among health officials, researchers and advocacy groups struggling to control the epidemic. Unfortunately, the global recession and soaring deficits in advanced nations have made it unlikely that sufficient money will be available to fully seize the new opportunities. Some agonizing choices will have to be made.

headline: Photo Replay: Dec. 2
text: A view of the day in sports, including highs and lows at the World Cup announcement.

headline: The House Rebukes Mr. Rangel
text: The tragic tale of Representative Charles Rangel’s ethics violations has ended with a deserved vote of censure by his peers in the House, despite the once powerful lawmaker’s pleas for a less humiliating reprimand.

headline: Homeless, Mentally Ill and, Soon, Short a Lifeline
text: Scott James writes a column for The Bay Citizen.

headline: From Copenhagen to Cancún
text: A year ago, delegates from 193 countries went to Copenhagen with hopes of signing a treaty limiting emissions of greenhouse gases and committing each country to hard targets. What emerged was an interim “statement of intention” full of nonbinding pledges that mean nothing if governments choose not to honor them.

headline: Fans React to LeBron’s Return to Cleveland
text: Miami Heats’ LeBron James played his first game against the Cavaliers since he left Cleveland for Miami back in July.

headline: Friday: Cabbageheads
text: Matt Ginsberg, who consistently puts together tight and clever puzzles, does so again today. My solve started off with uncharacteristic speed in the upper left and then continued downward with barely a hiccup. However, the east side quickly … er, slowly made up for that.

headline: Google Signs Deal to Buy Manhattan Office Building
text: In the biggest real estate deal of the year, Google signed a contract on Thursday to buy one of the largest office buildings in Manhattan for more than $1.8 billion, according to two real estate executives who have been briefed on the deal.

headline: Restaurant Bets on Future of Nascent Neighborhood
text: In Manhattan’s midsection, just a short stroll from Times Square and Pennsylvania Station, lies a no man’s land of unrealized potential.

headline: Government Money Woes Hit the Local Museums
text: When the Oakland Museum of California was founded in 1969 as a “museum for the people,” there was no question about who would pay for it. The museum’s land was owned by the city, its building was operated by the city and its collection belonged to the city. Admission, now $12, was free.

headline: Labor Fight Stops Work to Install Solar Panels
text: A bitter dispute over who can work on solar power projects has brought to a halt San Francisco’s efforts to install solar panels at City Hall, Davies Symphony Hall and other prominent buildings.

headline: A Power in Emeryville Slides Quickly, Politically and Personally
text: Four years ago, Ken Bukowski, the five-time mayor of Emeryville, refinanced his house to buy new teeth.

headline: Applesauce, Sour Cream or Soy Sauce?
text: Ah, the traditional joys of Hanukkah — the flickering candles, the crisply fried latkes, the sushi….

headline: Insider to Fill No. 2. Job in Editorial at Time Inc.
text: Time Inc. has filled its long-vacant No. 2 editorial position in a major reorganization that centralizes the management of a far-flung media empire.

headline: Charter Schools and Public Ones Align in Valley
text: It was almost lunch time on the day before Thanksgiving break, but Gustavo Corrales, a math teacher, was not ready to let his students out the door at the San Juan campus of IDEA Public Schools, a network of charter schools in the Rio Grande Valley.

headline: Cross Section of Rich Invested With the Fed
text: WASHINGTON  One investor, Kenneth H. Dahlberg, is a World War II flying ace who, as a volunteer in President Richard M. Nixon’s re-election campaign, was a minor figure in the Watergate scandal.

headline: Rangers Hold On Against Islanders
text: UNIONDALE, N.Y.  The rivalry may not be quite what it was a generation ago, and the arena on Long Island may now have its share of empty seats, even for games against the team from Manhattan.

headline: PepsiCo’s Big Bet on Changing Russian Tastes
text: At last, some refreshing news about the movement of overseas capital to Russia. PepsiCo has agreed to buy a two-thirds stake in the juice and dairy group Wimm-Bill-Dann and is making an offer for the rest, valuing the enterprise at $5.4 billion. It’s one of the largest ever foreign investments in Russia. Despite the country’s notoriously tricky climate for outsiders — consider the private equity firm TPG’s travails with its investment in Lenta supermarkets — Russia’s nascent consumer market still holds attractions for acquisitive global companies.

headline: Legislators Support Internet Privacy, but Question How to Achieve It
text: WASHINGTON  Lawmakers examining the Federal Trade Commission’s recommendation for a “do not track” mechanism to restrict the monitoring of Internet users said that they supported stricter safeguards for consumer privacy, but raised questions on how the system would work.

headline: Reform Comes Knocking at Railroad Commission
text: Texas has three railroad commissioners, who are elected statewide. They regulate oil and gas, which you’d never know from their title. But that’s not the only reason there’s a serious effort afoot to change the agency’s name and replace those officeholders with part-time gubernatorial appointees, as there are at most of the state’s other regulatory agencies.

text: To the Editor:

headline: That Panda in the Legislature? White Democratic Women
text: After an election cycle in which the Republicans picked up nearly two-dozen additional seats in the State Legislature, a new endangered political species has been identified at the Capitol: the white Democratic woman.

headline: Duel Over Sugar Beet Seeds Could Create Shortage
text: Court decisions that have suspended the planting of genetically modified sugar beets could result in a sharp decline in American sugar production in the next two years, leading to possible price increases for consumers and food processors, according to experts and farmers.

headline: Straight Outta Wesleyan
text: Your indie-rap group, Das Racist, is known for songs that wittily riff on Taco Bell, Google and the general limitations of American consumerism. Rap is a black art form that originated in the Bronx, so why, as two Wesleyan graduates who met in college, would you think you could rap?  Himanshu Suri (top): Would you prefer your rappers to be uneducated? Victor Vazquez: And would we even be on the page of this publication if we had not gone to Wesleyan?

headline: Speed-Freak Football
text: EARLY IN A GAME last month against Washington, a running back for the University of Oregon’s powerhouse football team darted through a small opening on the right side of the line, then cut smartly upfield for a seven-yard gain and a first down. A typical-enough play, and good for the home team. But seconds after it was over, the Oregon fans at Autzen Stadium in Eugene let out an enormous boo. I turned to the man next to me in the press box, who happened to be the associate director of Oregon’s bands, for an explanation. “The officials aren’t moving the chains fast enough,” he explained. “It’s slowing us down.” Oregon made another first down, and the crowd booed more loudly. I wondered: What do these people want, sprinters imported from Jamaica to move the chains? Next, a Washington defensive player limped to the sideline with an apparent knee injury, and the boos came cascading down again inside Oregon’s concrete bowl of a stadium. “They think he’s faking it so the defense can get rest,” my friend from the bands explained. “That’s been happening to us a lot.”

headline: Statement from JPMorgan Chase

headline: Voice Mails Cost Deadspin $12,000
text: Deadspin paid $12,000 for voice mails and photos that it said were sent by Brett Favre to Jenn Sterger, a former Jets game-day employee, said Nick Denton, the owner of Gawker Media, which owns the Web site. Deadspin says the photos are of Favre’s genitals. The N.F.L. is investigating Favre’s actions, which occurred in 2008 when he was a Jet. Fox Sports reported that Favre had admitted to sending the voice mails but not the pictures. Although Sterger spoke to Deadspin about the voice mails and photographs, she never authorized it to use them or her name. Deadspin used them anyway.

headline: Sri Daya Mata, Guiding Light for U.S. Hindus, Dies at 96
text: Sri Daya Mata, who for more than five decades was the leader of one of the most influential Hindu groups in the United States and an ardent advocate of the healing power of meditation, died on Tuesday at the group’s retreat for nuns in Los Angeles. She was 96.

headline: Frank W. Lewis, Master of the Cryptic Crossword, Dies at 98
text: For more than six decades, Frank W. Lewis mesmerized, mystified and miffed a circle of obsessed people by writing a devilishly quirky cryptic crossword puzzle for The Nation. But there were some bridges even he would not cross.

text: Research In Motion, which gave us the BlackBerry, was once considered the leader in mobile phone technology, creating mobile devices that changed the business world and rapidly propelled the adoption of instant communication, Nick Bilton writes at Bits.

headline: ‘Scratch Paper’ or ‘Scrap Paper’?
text: Andrew Marc Greene e-mails: "My son's fourth-grade class was debating whether paper on which one scribbles offhand notes is scrap paper or scratch paper. Scrap paper describes where it comes from, and scratch paper defines what it's used for. We were wondering if the phonetic similarity is just coincidence, or if one term was derived from the other."

headline: AdWords and Me: Exploring the Mystery

headline: Complaint Box | Shadowy Boutiques
text: For years, it seemed as if precision lighting was a fundamental element of retail design. Stores had the perfect amount of soft, incandescent light with a touch of track lighting to highlight a featured ensemble, akin to the way museums focus light on fabulous works of art. Unfortunately, those days are over. A new and incredibly irritating trend has sprung up in retail design: dark, darker and nocturnal.

headline: From Jalopnik Joke to 24 Hours of LeMons
text: By now, many people with even a casual interest in automobiles have heard of Jay Lamm’s hoopty racing fever-dream, the 24 Hours of LeMons. The fun-first race series for $500 cars has made real road racing more accessible than perhaps ever before. To quote Mr. Lamm, “At LeMons, racing isn’t just for rich idiots, it’s for all idiots.” LeMons is, and always has been, about fielding a more terrible and ridiculous car than the team in the next pit. As I am one to revel in the irrational and idiotic aspects of car culture, I had to have a truly hateful car.

headline: The Nutcracker Chronicles: The One Where Mom Is the Sugar Plum Fairy
