text: BING CROSBY was a gorgeous singer and so was Karen Carpenter and also Nat King Cole  as is his daughter, too  and let’s not forget Chrissie Hynde or, for that matter, Alvin and the Chipmunks. Yet regardless of how much one admires fine vocal styling, this time of year tests the patience of the most devoted pop fan. I refer, of course, to the curse of holiday music.

headline: Winter Holiday Behind Glass
text: The Times’s Ariel Kaminer on New York department store holiday window displays.

headline: T’s the Season
text: Having a gang of style-centric girlfriends to shop for means gifts have to be three things: penny-wise, clever and no-fuss cool. Chloë Sevigny for Opening Ceremony’s capsule T-shirt collection (openingceremony.us), screen printed with Robert Mapplethorpe photographs and available next month (preorder and give an I.O.U.), manages to be both street savvy and seasonal — no easy feat. ‘‘There are so many to choose from,’’ Sevigny says.‘‘I think they all hold a bit of his magic.’’ For your other eclectic pals, here are some other suggestions:

headline: Lotus Hires Former BMW and Ferrari Executives
text: Lotus Cars announced two new high-level executive hirings. The news confirms a widespread impression that the sports car company is making an aggressive effort to expand sales — an effort signaled by the hiring of a new design chief, Donato Coco, roughly a year ago and the unveiling of multiple new models — Elise, Elan, Esprit, Elite, and Eterne — at the Paris auto show in September.

headline: Buffett Helps Create Nuclear Fuel Bank
text: Spurred by a pledge of $50 million from Warren E. Buffett, the billionaire investor and philanthropist, the board of the International Atomic Energy Agency voted Friday to set up a global nuclear fuel bank that aspiring nations can turn to for reactor fuel instead of making it themselves.

headline: Sunday Preview
text: @import url("http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/css/multimedia/bundles/SlidingGallery.css");

headline: A ‘Spider-Man’ Actress Is Injured Backstage
text: A lead actress in the new Broadway musical “Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark” suffered a concussion at the first preview performance on Sunday night when, standing offstage, she was struck in the head by a rope holding a piece of equipment, a spokesman for the actress said on Friday.

headline: Holiday Windows Can Be a Harsh Mirror
text: Silver-clad galaxy hoppers gaze idly through telescopes or space visors amid a Jules Verne fantasy world in which nothing is as it seems: The gears on a wheel are the teeth of a sawfish, hanging crystals of ice are glittering jewels and the spines of an alligator are polished white shells, which in turn resemble the skyline of a futuristic city. Bergdorf Goodman credits the fashion to Marc Jacobs, Isaac Mizrahi and CD Greene. The drugs used to achieve the psychedelic effect however go unnamed — sadly, as that is one product that no store would have trouble moving.

headline: Blue Skies and Blue-Chip Sales at Art Basel Miami
text: MIAMI BEACH — Wind, rain and even snow left some collectors making the pilgrimage to Art Basel Miami Beach stranded for hours at airports in New York and Europe. But here, except for a few showers on Wednesday afternoon, the sun shone brightly, as if to demonstrate how much the little strip of South Beach, which each December becomes the setting for an art-world bacchanalia of buying, selling and socializing, is a place apart from the rest of the country, where unemployment and financial anxiety linger.

headline: Jennifer Barton, William Packer
text: Jennifer Nerissa Barton and William Henry Packer were married Saturday afternoon at the Parish Church of St. Michael’s Cornhill in London. The Rev. Dr. Peter Mullen, an Anglican priest and the church’s rector, performed the ceremony.

headline: Kristin Dwyer, Michael Galkoski
text: Kristin Marie Dwyer and Michael Galkoski were married Saturday at Fordham University Church in the Bronx. Msgr. Robert S. Meyer, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

headline: Rachel Laitala, Colin Greenspon
text: Rachel Anne Laitala and Colin Haynes Greenspon were married Saturday at St. James’ Episcopal Church in New York. The Rev. Brenda G. Husson, the church’s rector, performed the ceremony, with the Rev. Dr. Arthur A. Rouner Jr., a Congregational minister, taking part.

headline: Pnina Grauman, Aaron Safier
text: Pnina Ayala Chana Grauman, the daughter of Judith I. Grauman and Robert A. Grauman of Manhattan, is to be married Sunday afternoon to Aaron Benjamin Safier, a son of Phyllis Safier and I. Jay Safier of Fair Lawn, N.J. Rabbi Ariel Rackovsky is to officiate at the Rockleigh Country Club in Rockleigh, N.J.

headline: Alyson Warshaw, Jason Stein
text: Alyson Warshaw and Jason Stein were married Saturday evening at Capitale, an event space in Manhattan. Rabbi Marc Gellman officiated.

headline: Amanda Pullins, Nathan Fend
text: Amanda Caroline Pullins, a daughter of Nancy Sanford Pullins and Jerald L. Pullins of New Canaan, Conn., was married Saturday evening to Nathan Thomas Fend, a son of Dawn Schmeckpeper Fend and Thomas J. Fend of Naperville, Ill. The Rev. Edward Mulligan IV, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony in the chapel at St. George’s School in Middletown, R.I.

headline: Traci Kampel, Keith Di Fiore
text: Traci Melissa Kampel, a daughter of Janice Kampel and Dr. Lewis J. Kampel of New York, was married Thursday evening in Great Bay on St. Thomas in the Virgin Islands to Keith Michael Di Fiore, a son of Judith Di Fiore and David Di Fiore of Scotch Plains, N.J. Stuart Scott, a Universal Life minister, officiated at the Ritz-Carlton.

headline: Elizabeth Levy, Brennan Veys
text: Elizabeth Sara Levy and Brennan Richard Veys were married Saturday evening at the New York Palace hotel. Loretta A. Preska, the chief judge of the Federal District Court for the Southern District of New York, officiated.

headline: Laura Brown and Adam Singh
text: Laura Darby Brown and Adam Jasbir Singh were married Saturday at the Harvard Club in New York. The Rev. April Beer, an interfaith minister, officiated.

headline: Nola Weinstein, Bradley Glodny
text: Nola Beth Weinstein, the daughter of Lois Weinstein and Ira Weinstein of Atlantic Beach, N.Y., was married Saturday evening to Dr. Bradley Scott Glodny, the son of Jane Glodny and Shimon Glodny of Lawrence, N.Y. Rabbi E. Samuel Klibanoff performed the ceremony at Temple Israel in Lawrence.

headline: Cary Gunther, James Miller
text: Dr. Cary Sidlett Gunther and James Lawrence Miller were married Saturday at the St. Regis Hotel in New York. Rabbi Allan Schranz officiated.

headline: Lisa Neumann, Ian Weston
text: Lisa Anne Neumann, the daughter of Susan Neumann and Edward H. Neumann of North Potomac, Md., was married Saturday evening to Ian Philip Weston, the son of Joyce S. Weston and Burton S. Weston of Great Neck, N.Y. Rabbi Marim D. Charry officiated at the Marriott Wardman Park hotel in Washington. Cantor Henrique Ozur Bass took part in the ceremony.

headline: Marie Wilson, Jorge Espinel
text: Marie Helen Wilson and Jorge Espinel were married Friday at the Municipal Marriage Bureau in New York. Blanca Martinez, an employee of the City Clerk’s office, officiated.

headline: Kathleen Morris, Robert Kraus
text: Kathleen M. Morris and Robert D. Kraus were married Saturday at the Williams College Faculty Club in Williamstown, Mass. Rabbi Jeffrey W. Goldwasser officiated.

headline: Jana Singer and Larry Sidman
text: Jana Beth Singer and Larry Richard Sidman were married Saturday evening at the Ritz-Carlton hotel in Washington. Rabbi William D. Rudolph officiated, with the assistance of Cantor Abraham Lubin.

headline: Ellen Tobin and Todd Kaminsky
text: Ellen Betsy Tobin and Todd David Kaminsky were married Saturday evening at the Fresh Meadow Country Club in Lake Success, N.Y. Rabbi Moshe Schwartz performed the ceremony, with Cantor Bette Cohen taking part.

headline: Gina Miller, James Neale
text: Gina Miller and James Wyatt Neale were married Monday in Flippen Park in Highland Park, Tex. Judge John Peyton, of the Probate Court of Dallas County, officiated. On Saturday, the Rev. S. M. Wright II, a Baptist minister, performed a ceremony that included Jewish traditions at Casa de Mita, a hotel in Punta Mita, Mexico.

headline: Hannah Gaw, Andrew Richardson
text: Hannah Elizabeth Gaw and Andrew Garmory Richardson were married Saturday evening at St. Mary of the Assumption Roman Catholic Church in Brookline, Mass. The Rev. Brian M. Clary, the church’s pastor, performed the ceremony.

headline: Catherine O’Connor and Michael Devine
text: Catherine Ryan O’Connor and Michael Gerald Devine were married Saturday at St. Joan of Arc Church in Orleans, Mass. The Rev. Robert J. Powell, a Roman Catholic priest and the church’s pastor, performed the ceremony, with Msgr. Richard Malone, the great-uncle of the bridegroom, taking part.

headline: Judging The Bodies In Ballet
text: Go to any gallery and you see how painters and sculptors for centuries have made fat an issue. The nudes of Titian, Rubens, Rembrandt and Renoir show women with curves that are no longer part of any fashionable idea of beauty. Venus or Diana had a belly like that? I love most of them myself, but I have friends who object. Either way, all of us acknowledge that weight plays a part in our response.

headline: (Non)Rumors Over ‘Non-Papers’ at Climate Talks
text: Dec. 4, 7:34 p.m. | Updated CANCÚN, Mexico — At almost every negotiation in recent years aimed at building a new international climate agreement, a batch of delegates and United Nations officials huddle at the end of the first week to start framing some kind of text. The diplomatic term of art for such documents is “non-paper.” The idea is to have something ready for high-level officials to firm up before the meeting ends a week later.

headline: Budget-Cutting Colleges Bid Some Languages Adieu
text: Albany

headline: Scott Brown Was an Outlier After All
text: A new poll from Public Policy Polling in Massachusetts suggests that Republican Senator Scott Brown — who represents one of the Democrats’ few opportunities to play offense in a cycle in which they hold more than two-thirds of the Senate seats that will be contested in 2012 — is in relatively good shape for re-election. Against a series of potential Democratic opponents, he holds leads by margins ranging between 7 and 19 points, according to the survey.

headline: The Hunt for Julian Assange
text: One big lesson from the WikiLeaks dump  of state department documents:  Weddings in Dagestan are insanely awesome.

headline: Chronicle of a Changing City
text: THE PARK AVENUE CHRISTMAS LIGHTS are a tradition that goes back to 1945, when a group of neighborhood families arranged to put up majestic fir trees on the avenue’s central malls to honor soldiers who died in World War II. The group turns on the lights on the first Sunday of December, after a festive ceremony outside the Brick Presbyterian Church at 91st Street. Early on, the cost was paid by the founding families. Nowadays, the $10,000 tab is picked up by the Fund for Park Avenue, which also maintains the mall plantings, and whose lighting committee includes Muffie Potter, David Rockefeller and Joanne Woodward, said the fund’s president, Barbara McLaughlin.

headline: A Puppeteer and His Stick Friend
text: Basil Twist, 41, is a third-generation puppeteer who spends roughly half the year on the road and the other half in Greenwich Village, where he lives and works. He runs the Dream Music Puppetry Program at the Here Arts Center downtown, which presents his work and that of others. On Broadway, some of his most recent creations include puppets for “The Pee-wee Herman Show” and for the musical   For Mr. Twist, Sunday is often a work day, or a day to unpack. —ISOLDE RAFTERY

headline: China: 2 Intellectuals Barred From Leaving the Country
text: In two separate incidents on Thursday, Ai Weiwei, a prominent Chinese artist and frequent critic of the Chinese Communist Party, and Mao Yushi, an 80-year-old economist, were prevented from flying out of Beijing to cities in Asia, presumably because Chinese authorities are trying to keep Chinese intellectuals from attending the Nobel Peace Prize ceremony in Norway next Friday. The prize was awarded to a Chinese dissident, Liu Xiaobo, in early October. China is also preventing Mr. Liu’s wife, Liu Xia, from leaving the country to collect the prize. On Thursday, Mr. Ai was catching a flight to Seoul, South Korea, and Mr. Mao was going to Singapore. Both were stopped in the Beijing airport and told by the authorities that they could not travel because they might “endanger state security.” Mr. Ai said in a Twitter message that he had not intended to go to the Nobel ceremony but that he was instead traveling on a matter related to his art.

headline: Jets’ Leonhard Breaks Leg in Collision at Practice
text: Jets safety Jim Leonhard broke his right leg in practice Friday, and it looks almost certain that he will miss the remainder of the season.

headline: European Union Members Reach Deal to Enforce Driving Laws
text: The days of Europe’s motoring law free-for-all appear to be numbered. Under a deal reached on Thursday, the 27 nations of the European Union plan to step up cooperation in enforcing penalties levied for speeding or offenses like drunken driving and failing to wear seat belts. The agreement has been in the making for many years and is subject to approval by the European Parliament before becoming law. The new system  expected to come into force by 2013  would apply all over the bloc, except for Denmark, which has the ability to opt out on justice cooperation. Britain and Ireland, which also have special  though different  provisions, will decide whether to take part.

headline: U.S. Aided Mexican Drug War, With Frustration
text: MEXICO CITY  More than a year ago  before drug cartels killed a gubernatorial candidate and began murdering mayors, before shootings and kidnappings in Mexico’s industrial capital, Monterrey, surged to the point that the State Department ordered children of American diplomats there to leave the country  a Mexican official admitted that the government feared it could lose control of parts of the nation.

headline: When Love Is in Transit
text: Buses — whether local or inter-city — seem to rank somewhere between the dentist’s office and the laundromat as likely backdrops for powerful emotion. Who falls in love, erupts in rage, experiences an epiphany on a bus? More people than you might think, at least according to the following poems “found” last week in the Missed Connections section of newyork.craigslist.org. They are printed verbatim, with only line and stanza breaks added. The titles are the subject headings. ALAN FEUER

headline: Weekly Pick ‘Em: Championship Saturday
text: In the current college football era, where strength of schedule is just one of the factors determining where a team stands in the Bowl Championship Series rankings, those at the top can often find themselves rooting for already defeated opponents, hoping a win here or there will convince the computers’ metrics that their schedule is indeed stout. Well, on Saturday, none of that will matter. The equation will be much simpler for most teams: win a game and win a title. Oregon is an exception. If the Ducks beat Oregon State in the rivalry known as the Civil War, then they will merely secure a chance to win a title. Of course, it will be the B.C.S. championship. Auburn is hoping to join Oregon in that game, but first the Tigers will have to beat South Carolina and win the Southeastern Conference. Florida State and Virginia Tech, two teams that have improved as the season has gone on, will fight it out for the A.C.C. title, while the old foes Oklahoma and Nebraska will meet for one last time as members of the same conference, a fitting end to the Cornhuskers’ time in the Big 12. Connecticut will be looking to wrap up the most improbable B.C.S. berth in the country. If the Huskies beat South Florida, they will be Big East champions. Even without mathematical formulas, there is plenty at stake on Saturday.

headline: A Happy Ending to a Raw, but Common, Tale
text: Lilla Roberts is a 73-year-old retired physical therapist, a pleasant, engaging woman who moved to this country from Jamaica 46 years ago. In 1988, she bought a small house in Jamaica, Queens, putting down $25,000, and taking out a mortgage for around $120,000. For many years, she religiously made her mortgage payments.

headline: Video Eye Aimed at Teachers in 7 School Systems
text: As part of the project to develop new ways to evaluate teachers, researchers have recruited 3,000 teachers in seven school systems  Dallas; Denver; Charlotte, N.C.; Hillsborough County, Fla.; Memphis; New York; and Pittsburgh  who allowed themselves to be videotaped in their classrooms. (As part of the agreement, only researchers can view the tapes, not school administrators).

headline: Teacher Ratings Get New Look, Pushed by a Rich Watcher
text: PRINCETON, N.J.  In most American schools, teachers are evaluated by principals or other administrators who drop in for occasional classroom visits and fill out forms to rate their performance.

headline: Under Fire Since Explosion, Mining C.E.O. Quits
text: Don L. Blankenship, the embattled chief executive of Massey Energy, resigned Friday in a move that might enable the company to improve relations with federal regulators but might also hasten a takeover.

headline: Panel Votes to Expand Surgery for Less Obese
text: A federal advisory panel Friday endorsed an expansion of the use of Allergan’s Lap-Band stomach-restricting device to patients who are less than severely obese.

headline: Groupon Said to Reject Google’s Offer
text: 11:37 p.m. | Updated  Groupon has walked away from Google’s $6 billion takeover offer, according to a person close to Groupon. The rejection at least temporarily thwarts Google’s efforts to buy the social buying site, which would have been its largest acquisition to date.

headline: Football Coaches Say Don’t Overlook Small-Town Players
text: ST. PAUL  In his three years on the University of St. Thomas football team, quarterback Dakota Tracy has heard all kinds of remarks about his tiny hometown, Geneva, Minn., which has a population of 449. Because he shares a house with three teammates, all from Twin Cities suburbs, the ribbing can be relentless.

headline: Two Communiqués, and a Commander’s Dilemma
text: Charleston Harbor, S.C., Dec. 4, 1860

headline: Once in Glare of the Media, Club Owner Is Now a Critic
text: BOSTON  The former owner of a nightclub in Rhode Island who drew news media scrutiny when 100 people died at the club in a 2003 fire has quietly re-emerged as a media critic.

headline: The Transformation of 42nd Street
text: A 30 year plan to make over 42nd St. is completed

headline: New Subject of Debate on Mideast: Hummus
text: Forget Hezbollah and Hamas. The latest chapter in the Israeli-Arab conflict is all about hummus, the chickpea dip that is a staple of American college cafeterias.

headline: 8 Urns in ‘Unknown’ Grave at Arlington Spur Inquiry
text: WASHINGTON  The Army has opened a criminal investigation after the discovery of eight urns of cremated remains of soldiers in a grave marked “unknown” in Arlington National Cemetery, an Army official said this week.

headline: Pfizer Plans $75 Million Fund to Address Shareholder Suits
text: Pfizer has agreed to set up a $75 million fund and to create a new compliance committee to settle shareholders’ lawsuits accusing the board and top officials of failing to stop illegal marketing of its drugs, according to a settlement agreement filed in United States District Court on Friday.

headline: One Borough, Five Generations
text: Melanie Lefkowitz’s family has had an enduring presence in Brooklyn since the early 20th century. She chronicles their lives in words and pictures.

headline: Jokes and Secret Hopes for Lieutenant Governors
text: OMAHA  They have been disparaged as spare-tire politicians, kept in the dark and used only in emergencies. They have been dismissed as ribbon-cutting versions of the appendix, prominently situated but without any discernible function. And the office itself has been likened to a form of political purgatory, with occupants passing time hoping for some outside force to elevate them.

headline: BP Is Planning to Challenge Estimates of Oil Spill
text: BP intends to challenge official government estimates of how much oil leaked from its runaway well in the Gulf of Mexico, a move that could reduce its legal liability by billions of dollars, according to documents the company filed with the presidential commission investigating the spill.

headline: Hermès Falls as Holders Discuss Takeover Defense
text: Shares of Hermès International fell 9.3 percent in Paris on Friday as members of the company’s controlling family met to discuss their strategy for fending off the unwelcome interest of Bernard Arnault, the chief of LVMH Moët Hennessy Louis Vuitton. Hermès’s limited-partnership structure and the combined 73 percent stake held by the Puech, Guerrand and Dumas families make it impossible for an outsider to gain control against their wishes. But the families are considering ways to ensure that they can sell shares as needed without allowing Mr. Arnault to increase his stake. Mr. Arnault has made a career of acquiring family-owned businesses on his way to creating the world’s biggest luxury group. He surprised the company in late October with the disclosure that he had acquired 17.1 percent of its shares. A spokeswoman for Hermès declined to comment on the meeting Friday.

headline: Surviving a Job Loss, and a Family’s Devastation
text: Sitting in her living room in Ocean Hill, Brooklyn, Aldine Francois, 27, peeled layers of silk cloth away from a white book with golden pages. It was a photo album holding the most recent pictures she had of her mother, from a wedding in July 2009.

headline: How Iran Derailed a Health Crisis
text: So how did Iran do it?   How did a conservative theocracy decide to deal with its drug addicts as if it were Canada?  In Tuesday’s column, I wrote that Iran is treating its massive epidemic of injecting drug use mainly as a health problem.  With this strategy, it has effectively managed to lower H.I.V. rates among drug users and keep the disease from spreading.  It has taken an approach to drugs known as harm reduction, which includes the provision of methadone maintenance therapy and clean needles to drug users.

headline: Walter Energy Will Buy Rival
text: Walter Energy, a coal producer, said on Friday that it had agreed to buy Western Coal of Canada in a deal that values the company at 3.3 billion Canadian dollars ($3.26 billion).

headline: On Eve of Butler-Duke II, Passions Still Run Deep
text: There are few do-overs in sports, and Saturday’s basketball game between Duke and Butler is not one, no matter how many times it is referred to as a rematch of April’s national championship contest.

headline: Tax-Cut Debate Turns to Millionaires
text: WASHINGTON  Senate Democrats on Friday denounced Republicans for insisting on continued tax breaks for “millionaires and billionaires,” even as they braced for the White House to make concessions that would allow an extension of the Bush-era tax cuts at all income levels.

headline: A View of the Bronx, of the Past and of a Dream Reconsidered
text: A former colleague of my brother’s recently called him to ask if he was, by any chance, related to someone by my name. My brother informed him (nervously, I am sure) that that person was his sister. “Well, tell her I have some of her mail,” came the reply.

headline: From a Ski Resort, Djokovic Emerges as a Serbian Tennis Groundbreaker
text: KOPAONIK, Serbia  To begin to understand how a small, struggling nation like Serbia managed to reach its first Davis Cup final this weekend, you could interview Slobodan Zivojinovic, a big-serving Serbian trailblazer at Wimbledon and elsewhere before he became a portly tennis administrator and car salesman.

text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around Nassau and Suffolk Counties this week. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com, or by mail to Long Island Weekly, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in Connecticut this week. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com, or by mail to the Connecticut Calendar, Metropolitan, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

headline: Events in Westchester
text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around the Hudson Valley. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com, or by mail to Westchester Calendar, Metropolitan, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

headline: Millions Bracing for Cutoff of Unemployment Checks
text: More than two million jobless Americans are entering the holiday season seized with varying levels of foreboding, worry or even panic over what lies ahead as they cope with the expected cutoff of their unemployment benefits.

headline: If It’s So Easy, Why Don’t You Try It
text: POSTHUMOUS fame and high auction prices notwithstanding, the painter Jackson Pollock was not an uncontested genius during his lifetime. The critic Robert Coates once derided a number of Pollock’s works as “mere unorganized explosions of random energy, and therefore meaningless.”

headline: In a First for Obama, Nine Pardons Are Granted
text: WASHINGTON  For the first time since taking office nearly two years ago, President Obama exercised his clemency powers on Friday by granting pardons to nine people.

headline: The Show Must Go On
text: IN September, officials at the 61-year-old Surflight Theater in Beach Haven announced that they needed $500,000 by Oct. 31 to keep it from closing. Fund-raising efforts came up short — some $300,000 has been raised to date — but the theater’s annual “Holiday Spectacular” is going on anyway.

headline: Singing His Way Toward the Big Break
text: Before the advent of reality TV, YouTube and “American Idol”  the distant early 1980s  practically the only route for a show-business hopeful to stardom in New York was by pounding the pavement with a handful of 8 x 10 head shots and a heart full of dreams. And that’s the time, place and essential story of “...And Then I Wrote a Song About It.”

headline: A Silicon Bubble Shows Signs of Reinflating
text: In a memorable scene in the “The Social Network,” the actor Justin Timberlake, who portrays the Silicon Valley investor Sean Parker in the movie, leans over the table and tells the founders of Facebook in a conspiratorial tone: “A million dollars isn’t cool. You know what’s cool? A billion dollars.”

headline: Back to the Barricades: ‘Les Miz’ Reworked at 25
text: Susan Boyle has ruined it for all future Fantines. When Betsy Morgan, for instance, a mere wisp of a young woman, opens her mouth to sing the character Fantine’s solo, “I Dreamed a Dream,” in “Les Misérables,” at the Paper Mill Playhouse, at least half the audience has to be thinking about Ms. Boyle’s stunning 2009 performance of that song on “Britain’s Got Talent” (78 million YouTube views so far). And wondering why this actress is so vocally demure in comparison.

headline: Washington: Court-Martial for Soldier
text: A second of five soldiers accused in the killings of three Afghan civilians has been referred to an Army court-martial. The soldier, Specialist Adam C. Winfield, is accused of shooting an unarmed man after his unit leader, who is also accused in the killings, reportedly detonated a grenade to fake a combat situation. The other three cases are pending. The killing happened months after Specialist Winfield’s parents have said they tried to warn military officials that their son was concerned about unjustified killings by his unit.

headline: Trying Not to Let the Color Show
text: Normally it’s a touching Hallmark-card kind of scene. A glamorous mother at her dressing table, doing her hair and makeup for a dinner party, while her daughter looks on.

headline: A Diner That Was the Special of Every Day

headline: New Jersey Closer to Sales of Medical Marijuana
text: A standoff between Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey and advocates for medical marijuana has ended in a compromise that could put marijuana on the market for seriously ill patients by next summer.

headline: Parent Sues to Block Schools Chief
text: The father of two Brooklyn public school children filed a lawsuit against state education officials on Friday to stop Cathleen P. Black, a publishing executive, from becoming the next New York City schools chancellor.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Former Yeshiva Principal Sought on Abuse Charges
text: A former Brooklyn yeshiva principal and three of his sons sexually abused four of the principal’s other children, molesting one of the victims over 15 years, the authorities said Friday.

headline: Hanging Out at Elaine’s

headline: Saturday: Red Flag’s Purpose
text: If such a thing were possible, it would be nice to have red flags warning us of the difficulties lurking in a puzzle. Today, I ran into trouble in the lower right, then upper right, middle, lower left and finally in the red-flag-worthiest upper left.

headline: ‘Messiah,’ Modest or Mighty
text: SINCE its premiere in 1742, Handel’s “Messiah” has been interpreted, reinterpreted and, some say, misinterpreted so many times that its identity has become muddled. But that is not stopping two of Connecticut’s major orchestras, joined by leading choirs, from weighing in with their own versions of the piece  versions that contrast markedly in scale and style.

headline: Detective Faces Charges of False Drug Arrests
text: An undercover New York City police detective assigned to an embattled narcotics unit in Queens has been charged with falsely accusing five men of selling drugs to him, according to a 48-count indictment unsealed last month in Queens.

headline: Maps for Navigating to a New Perspective
text: What are maps for? Of course, you think you know, and so did I  until I found my way to “Mapping: Memory and Motion in Contemporary Art,” at the Katonah Museum of Art. The works in this terrific exhibition offer so many takes on the subject that you feel your personal definition of cartography exploding as you walk  with no map to guide you  through the galleries.

headline: A Tale That Rings With a Familiar Sound
text: “The Sound of Music” made the news in October, when the core cast members of the movie version visited “The Oprah Winfrey Show” for a 45th-anniversary reunion, during which Christopher Plummer, who played the role of Capt. Georg von Trapp, admitted that, yes, he had called the musical the name long attributed to him, “The Sound of Mucus.”

headline: The Junkie and the Atheist
text: As an Irish-American, I don’t usually trumpet the work of a nation that kept my ancestors under its boot heel for nearly 300 years. But having just finished the memoirs of two great exports of Britain, I rise to praise a pair of Brits in the season of book-buying.

headline: Shop, Shop, Shop, Then Eat, or Even Dine
text: AT Fratelli Trattoria, an 18-month-old Italian restaurant in the Tanger Outlets at the Arches in Deer Park, diners are presented with a choice. As they enter the spacious foyer, they can turn right to order pizza by the slice at the counter, with catch-as-catch-can seating at five tables in front. Or they can turn left, to be seated by a hostess in a full-service restaurant with a menu featuring entrees like chicken mezzaluna with asparagus in white wine sauce.

headline: The First Lady of First Editions
text: Greg Lawrence’s ‘‘Jackie as Editor’’ (St. Martin’s/Thomas Dunne Books, $26) is the first biography of Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis dedicated to her 19-year publishing career, which began in 1975 with a $200-a-week editorial job at Viking. (A head honcho at Random House had politely turned her down.) Lawrence credits Kennedy with publishing 97 books, including many on dance — memoirs by Martha Graham and Gelsey Kirkland, and a collection of Pushkin fairy tales prefaced by Rudolf Nureyev. ‘‘If you produce one book,’’ she said, ‘‘you will have done something wonderful in your life.’’

headline: It’s a Small Town After All
text: RARELY has a town been conceived and constructed in the glare of publicity and aura of hope that greeted Disney’s master-planned, picture-perfect village of Celebration in central Florida. Expectations were so high that, in November 1995, 4,000 people entered into a lottery for the chance to win the right to pay 25 percent over the market price to move into one of the first 500 or so homes.

text: We know politics is never pretty. But this horse-trading is disgraceful: nuclear weapons cuts versus tax cuts for the rich.

headline: Inside the Beltway: A Deficit of Purpose
text: A sense of resolve and a clear purpose should not be partisan commodities, yet, in Washington, only the Republicans seem to have them. They know exactly what they want and pursue it with ruthless efficiency: preserve all the Bush-era tax cuts, no matter the cost, and make sure President Obama gets nothing done.

text: With almost no payroll flexibility and most of the starting positions already accounted for, the Mets are not going to be big players in the free-agent market. But they do have needs, especially in the areas of pitching depth and backup position players.

text: Allison Moultry needed many things in November 2009: surgery to treat a pulmonary artery aneurysm; a doctor to diagnose the lump in her breast; and help paying bills after her heart condition meant she could not do her job as a day care provider. She did not need bedbugs.

Last month, they struck a deal with growers to raise workers’ pay and to create an industry code of conduct, a health and safety program and a system to resolve worker complaints.

Until then, I will no longer take part in the left’s obsessive-compulsive fascination with her, which is both unhealthy and counterproductive.

headline: Mick Without Moss
text: On the top floor of a photography studio somewhere in Chelsea, Mick Jagger is capering about to a sleepy reggae cover of “Eleanor Rigby.” The photographer has requested “mischief,” and Jagger is gamely attempting to provide some  pouting, smirking, stomping his feet and shrugging his shoulders in a style that is part hipster frug, part Rumpelstiltskin tantrum. He is wearing clumpy black Nikes, electric green and black socks and drainpipe jeans in a Prince of Wales plaid. (Earlier, when he arrived at the studio, he had on a shiny, aubergine-colored John Pearse jacket with camouflage lining, but this, sadly, has now been replaced by a rather more subdued Alexander McQueen drape coat.)

headline: Sam Wyche Recalls a Frantic No-Huddle Moment
text: With college teams faking injuries to stop Oregon’s no-huddle spread offense, the former Cincinnati Bengals coach Sam Wyche can understand how the Ducks must feel. In the N.F.L. playoffs after the 1988 season, Wyche recalled how Seattle Seahawks nose tackle Joe Nash repeatedly fell to the ground on second down to slow Cincinnati’s no-huddle spread.

headline: Photo Replay: Dec. 3
text: A view of the day in sports, including highlights from the Davis Cup.

headline: Orender Will Resign W.N.B.A. Post
text: Donna Orender announced she was stepping down as president of the W.N.B.A. after six seasons. She will continue to work for the league as a consultant as she begins a marketing and strategy company. Orender presided over six years of modest growth for the W.N.B.A., with increases in attendance and sponsorship.

headline: In Good Paste
text: It was too early in the day for a drink, which was a shame, because the image of Lauren Santo Domingo tending a Lalanne hippo bar would have been amazing. Instead, Santo Domingo and I got drunk on her mountain of scrapbooks -- visual cocktails spilling over with inspiration, literally. "I'm working on a rooftop garden in Paris, so I sent this topiary picture to Madison" -- that would be Madison Cox -- "who's designing it," Santo Domingo narrated, flipping through the sketchbooks she jams with magazine clippings. Crudely cropped and pasted down, the tear sheets are arranged with an art director's eye for winking juxtapositions, making Santo Domingo a kind of Alexey Brodovitch, if Alexey Brodovitch had been an "It" girl.

headline: Full House
text: Down by the Hudson in an old Manhattan pickle factory lives a widow surrounded by a tyrant’s ransom in broken violins. Armand Fernandez, known as Arman since the day a printer left the “D” off his name in a catalog, was a founding member of the midcentury French New Realists and one of the giants of 20th-century art. His medium was objects and his process a focused attack that he called “the pinnacle of a catharsis.” His friend, the painter Yves Klein, told him when they were young, “I’ll take what’s organic, you take what’s manufactured.” Klein invented his iconic International Klein Blue and died young; Arman squared off in violent yet precise acts against violins and guitars, shower hoses, sofas, paint tubes, bicycles, motorcycles, cars and statues, which he smashed, flattened, burned, sawed in half, cast in bronze and sliced, or sank into Perspex or concrete. His 1961 manifesto was titled “The Realism of Accumulations,” and when he wasn’t destroying to create, he made harmonic sequences, set on wooden panels, of musical instruments (whole or chopped), watch faces, trumpets, ladles, gas masks, typewriters, saws and paintbrushes. An Arman retrospective, at the Pompidou Center in Paris through Jan. 10, gives some idea of his range, output and influence on artists as diverse as Jeff Koons and Damien Hirst, but it cannot, for practical reasons, include his 106-foot-high “Hope for Peace,” a concrete tower in Beirut, Lebanon, in which he buried 78 tanks, jeeps and various pieces of artillery.

headline: PayPal Suspends WikiLeaks Account
text: Updated | Saturday | 3:33 p.m. As the release of hundreds of thousands of United States diplomatic cables brings more attention to WikiLeaks, commercial entities on the Internet have come under increased scrutiny for their business relationships with the organization.

headline: 7 Blasts Hit Baghdad, With Mostly Shiite Targets
text: BAGHDAD  A string of bomb attacks, two of them aimed at Iranian pilgrims, rippled through Iraq’s capital on Saturday morning, breaking a stretch of relative calm as the country’s new government slowly takes shape.

headline: Can You Go Home Again?
text: About a year after I moved to the suburbs, the previous owners of our home stopped by unannounced: They had been in the neighborhood — did I mind terribly? They wanted a look around.

headline: A Very Heston Holiday
text: Heston Blumenthal is one of the most forward-thinking chefs in the world. But his new restaurant, Dinner by Heston Blumenthal, is firmly rooted in the past — circa 1558. The London restaurant, which opens next month in the Mandarin Oriental overlooking Hyde Park, will champion British food from Tudor times up through that 20th-century invention, the ploughman’s lunch. ‘‘I was fascinated because I thought I knew quite a lot about cooking, and here I was, finding things I never knew existed,’’ he said of his extensive historical research. ‘‘There’s a sense of pride of introducing this stuff to people today.’’

headline: The Nutcracker Chronicles: Clues to the Original Production
text: BOSTON — Some of the Russians who fled after the 1917 Revolution took little more than the clothes on their back. But a few took treasures to the West that Russia was loath to lose.

Well, I’m in the middle of a meeting with the Multilateral Men (and a few women); I somewhat suspect that I’m an MM myself. So, limited posting.

headline: Air Traffic Controller Strike Disrupts Holiday Travel in Spain

The controllers began returning to work for their afternoon shifts, but air travel in and out of Spain was likely to be disrupted for the next day or two, officials said.

text: The TrendThe male twin set: not just for men who lunch but for those who would do that — and other things — in Prada and Gucci.

text: The Jets’ defensive coordinator, Mike Pettine, spoke Friday about the impact of safety Jim Leonhard’s injury. headline: The Gift of Information
text: Julian Assange and WikiLeaks have been jettisoned to fame or notoriety (choose your noun, please) not because of a passing political battle but for reasons much deeper: the desire to possess, distribute and devour information. Ever since the release in July this year of some 92,000 documents relating to America’s involvement in Afghanistan, an old joke from Communist times keeps spinning around my head. ‘‘We cannot predict the future,’’ announces the newsreader of Soviet radio reporting on the Politburo’s deliberations, ‘‘but the past is changing before our very eyes.’’ Now our understanding of the nature of the intervention in Iraq has also changed radically with the publication of a still more astonishing collection of 391,832 secret United States military field reports from the kaleidoscopic theaters of battle.

headline: Class And Social Security
text: Digby  sounds the warning: a fair number of “centrist” Democrats – probably including the Incredible Shrinking President — seem willing, even eager, to join up with Republicans in cutting Social Security benefits and raising the retirement age. As she says, this is idiotic even in narrow political terms: in the very next election, Republicans will run ads in which they pose as the defenders of Social Security, while Democrats are the meanies who want to take away your retirement.

headline: Novel Lives
text: A nurse who became a philosopher. An art historian who washed dishes. A prep-schooled runaway who touched down in Bollywood. They’re first-time novelists whose facts are as rich as their fictions.

headline: Cables Depict Range of Obama Diplomacy
text: BEIJING — Barack Obama came to office vowing to restore “engagement” — talking and listening to America’s most troubling adversaries and reluctant partners — as a central feature of American foreign policy. But engagement can take many forms, from friendly to wary, naïve to cunning, and it was never quite clear how the term would translate from a campaign sound-bite to a practical approach to the world.

Exhausted firefighters, aided by airplanes and helicopters from around the world, meanwhile worked to contain the fire, which has killed 41 people and destroyed 12,500 acres of forest.

headline: The Gift of Time
text: Complete the following sentence by the photographer Walker Evans: ‘‘All my life I’ve wanted nothing so much as. . . .’’ Freedom to pursue my work? The respect of my peers? A retrospective at MoMA? It’s actually none of the above (all of which he either already had or would eventually have). No, what Evans wanted was leisure. And he had it — this was in 1947 — in the form of an unbelievably cushy job at Fortune magazine. We often hear of artists going into decline, but by the 1960s, Evans seemed to have fallen into terminal recline.

headline: Acrostic: Odditorium Entrepreneur

I quickly dismissed it as trash and continued my walk across a large swath of damp mulch woodchips under the cover of old trees.

headline: Along Came a Spider-man

headline: Of Debts and Doubts: Reading the Deficit Panel’s Report

headline: In Ireland, There’s an All-Too-Familiar Gloom

headline: If Only Laws Were Like Sausages

headline: After a Rough Night, Hotel Investors Are Waking Up

Now as private equity giants like the Blackstone Group and entrepreneurs like Richard Branson are diving into the sector, others are starting to think it has finally hit bottom and may be bouncing back.

headline: The Gift of Reconciliation
text: As the ocean liner steamed in from the open sea and approached the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge, the boy worried that the ship’s superstructure would not clear. ‘‘It was a cold, sunny winter day, Wednesday, the 22nd of December, 1965,’’ he said. ‘‘There are certain dates etched in your memory.’’ His journey to America had begun in Egypt, where his father was a leading religious figure. ‘‘The image of the Statue of Liberty came into view slowly . . . such majesty and beauty. It was a life-changing moment in my life. I was 17 years old.’’ That Feisal Abdul Rauf’s American story began off the southern tip of Manhattan can seem foreordained, in light of the controversy that consumed him 45 years later. At his first glimpse of his new world, he told me, ‘‘I had an intuition that my work would involve introducing Islam to America.’’ Yet at that point, young Rauf was himself in the throes of typical adolescent questioning. ‘‘In such a free society — it was the ’60s! — religion had become a matter of choice.’’ Not so in Kuwait, where he was born, and where religion was inherited. In America, ‘‘religion was passé. I was bewildered by all that. I was asking, ‘Does God exist? What is the meaning of life?’ And I found the answers to my religious questions as a matter of choice. I could choose to embrace my Muslim faith — and I did.’’ That simply, Feisal Abdul Rauf glimpsed the meaning of the nation’s defining freedom. ‘‘America made it possible for me to freely and deliberately choose to be religious and Muslim.’’ Rauf would become an American citizen in 1979.

headline: Political Books Best-Seller List
text: “Decision Points” by George W. Bush makes it debut on top of the best-seller list for political books, while “Spoken From the Heart” by his wife, Laura, is at No. 11.

headline: Holograms Deliver 3-D, Without the Goofy Glasses
text: WHEN the famous hologram of Princess Leia says, “Help me, Obi-Wan Kenobi,” in “Star Wars,” it’s science fiction. Now you can watch actual moving holograms that are filmed in one spot and then projected in another spot.

headline: It’s the Big Questions That Slow Growth
text: UNCERTAINTY is frequently blamed for the sorry state of the economy — for why businesses are not investing strongly in new equipment or hiring more workers, and for why consumers are not spending freely. On Wall Street, it’s even said that government meddling is the main culprit and that political gridlock is the cure.

headline: The Bond Vigilantes Have Moved to Dublin

text: AT its best, an overseas job offers rich cultural experiences and professional advancement — along with a whiff of glamour. But international work is not for everyone, and those considering it need to be realistic and strategic.

text: Banking expert: “What happened was that tri-party repo, which used to be all government securities, came to include all these cats and dogs, and then these cats and dogs ended up facing haircuts. …”

headline: What Else Would $60 Billion Buy?
text: $60 Billion: The approximate amount that extending the Bush tax cuts on income above $250,000 a year — which Congress seems on the verge of doing — will cost a year, in inflation-adjusted terms. On average, the affluent households that benefit from these cuts will save $25,000 annually. What else might that $60 billion a year buy?

headline: Scout’s Heart Still Beats in Gillick
text: A star pitcher wins half his games, a productive hitter reaches base 4 of 10 times, a skilled manager guides his team mostly to victories. For the best scouts, the success rate is lower. Their job is a test of persistence against near certain failure.

text: Bill Cosby dreamed about football for most of his life  often playing better than he had at Temple University decades earlier.

headline: Surprising Star Turn for Role Player
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  On most days, Kevin Boss strolls around the Giants’ practice center wearing a plain blue sweatshirt that has frayed from frequent use, a dependable, indispensable part of his wardrobe. It could be a metaphor.

headline: Gifted | Matthew Williams
text: Remember that flamethrower bra? Williams was the art director on Lady Gaga’s design team and one of the creative forces behind her ascent to pop music’s heights. Now he is also taking on other similarly visually inclined artists, including Kanye West.

headline: Don’t Mention the Cables, Future Diplomats
text: Columbia University’s School of International and Public Affairs, which grooms future diplomats, has confirmed to The Lede that it did send an e-mail to students this week warning them to avoid posting comments online about the leaked diplomatic cables, if they ever hope to work for the State Department.

headline: End of Discussion: Jeter’s a Yankee
text: This past month has been by far the most tumultuous period of the Yankees’ otherwise cozy 18-year relationship with Derek Jeter, and it left an uneasy feeling across their empire. Even with his eventual return considered a certainty, the public dispute over the terms of his new contract was unsettling, evocative of parents quarreling: Jeter and the Yankees were never headed for a divorce, but the innocence had faded.

headline: Quarterly Report on the Knicks: Stock Is Rising
text: The hour was late, and the visitors’ locker room at New Orleans Arena was nearly empty Friday night when two deep voices called across the room to each other.

headline: One Man’s Trash Is Grist for Another Man’s Blog
text: ON THE SCREEN Blogs about trash have a wide-ranging, if filthy, pedigree. At one end are the fun and highly focused sites like Street Mattress (founded in 2001 and still posting pictures of discarded Posturepedics). At the other are more academically minded ruminations on refuse, like Discard Studies, started in August. Last Night’s Garbage occupies a space between these two poles. Photographs of trash dominate the blog and provide its author, Jed Tamarkin, with inspiration for writing short bits of fiction.

headline: The McNabb Conundrum
text: As a 40-year-old Upper East Sider originally from Philadelphia, I can’t wait to see Donovan McNabb, wearing his horrid maroon-and-gold Washington Redskins uniform, bring his trademark smirk to New Meadowlands Stadium on Sunday.

headline: Taking Sides in a Divorce, Chasing Profit
text: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif.  Michelle Pont and her husband amassed millions of dollars in properties and investments from a freight-hauling business that they started with a single stake-bed truck in 1991. They bought a four-bedroom home, then a second home, a vacation home, a motor home and half a dozen cars.

headline: Styled to a T | Tamaryn
text: The TrendIndecisive hemlines. On the streets of New York and London, and in resort offerings from Jean Paul Gaultier and Richard Chai Love, lengths are long and short all at the same time.

headline: In Sports, Wahlberg Finds Stories That Inspire
text: Before Mark Wahlberg modeled underwear, before he became a rapper (Marky Mark and the Funky Bunch), an actor (“Boogie Nights,” “The Departed”) and a producer (“Entourage,” “Boardwalk Empire”), he grew up a boxing fan in Massachusetts. And one of his favorite fighters was Micky Ward. In his new movie, “The Fighter,” Wahlberg portrays Ward, a junior welterweight champion. The film opens Friday in New York, Boston and Los Angeles, and Dec. 17 nationwide. Wahlberg, 39, trained on and off for more than four years, and all the punches in his fight scenes are real.

headline: Cleopatra’s Guide to Good Governance
text: LET’S say you can’t readily lay your hands on “Leadership Secrets of Attila the Hun” or those of Winnie the Pooh. And let’s say the political mood around you is bleak; gridlock is the order of the day. Why not turn to a different management guru, a woman who left some 2,000-year-old teachable moments, each of them enduring and essential?

headline: Gifted | Curren Caples
text: This 14-year-old West Coaster finished fourth in the skateboard park event at this year’s X Games, making him the sought-after young star of the circuit — Bieber on wheels, in a cool way.

headline: Republicans Lay Claim to New York State Senate
text: Republicans claimed they had retaken the New York State Senate on Saturday after a State Supreme Court justice rejected a hand recount of a pivotal race in Nassau County. But Democrats said they planned to appeal the decision this week, leaving the balance of power in the chamber still in some doubt.

headline: The New Wave
text: Naomi Campbell’s been accused of many things, but crimes against hair? The beehive she sported on the stand at the United Nations war-crimes trial of Charles Taylor at The Hague last summer garnered a lot of buzz, but the buzz was tinged with ridicule — a clear indication that while the style possessed a lot of pins, it didn’t have real legs. The staid, sculptured bumps of hair looked painfully anachronistic, and just like that, a trend that seemed fresh on Prada’s fall runway came tumbling down. ‘‘For all the talk of the beehive this fall, no one’s really wearing it,’’ says Orlando Pita, who created the edgy style on the previous page. ‘‘The big editorial up-do doesn’t translate into real life.’’ Accordingly, at the spring shows, hair started to come undone. There were long, partial plaits at Givenchy, sex-kitten tousles at Isabel Marant and half-up-half-down dos at Miu Miu and Christopher Kane, while the rocker chicks at Balmain looked like they had just rolled out of bed. For Pita, the new down-do is all about texture. ‘‘We’ve seen perfectly blown out, silicone-sleek hair for so long,’’ he says. ‘‘The new texture doesn’t look so worked on. It’s all in the brushing and the products you use.’’ Pita sprays Elevate, a texturizer from his own line, into wet hair and dries it using his fingers to encourage the natural wave. (Everyone has one.) Next, he sprays dry shampoo (his version is called Refresh) onto the roots (avoiding the top of the head) in one-inch sections. Finally, he gently brushes it out with a Mason Pearson brush, fluffing the hair so ‘‘it feels soft, not tacky with product. I call it the anti-blow dry.’’

headline: All the President’s Captors
text: THOSE desperate to decipher the baffling Obama presidency could do worse than consult an article titled “Understanding Stockholm Syndrome” in the online archive of The F.B.I. Law Enforcement Bulletin. It explains that hostage takers are most successful at winning a victim’s loyalty if they temper their brutality with a bogus show of kindness. Soon enough, the hostage will start concentrating on his captors’ “good side” and develop psychological characteristics to please them  “dependency; lack of initiative; and an inability to act, decide or think.”

headline: The Big American Leak
text: O.K. I admit it. I enjoy reading other people’s mail as much as the next guy, so going through the WikiLeaks cables has made for some fascinating reading. What’s between the lines in those cables, though, is another matter. It is a rather sobering message. America is leaking power.

headline: The Utah Compact
text: Not all the political news this year involves the rise of partisan extremism and government by rage. There has been lots of that. But maybe there is a limit, a point when people of good sense and good will band together to say no. As they have just done in Utah.

headline: New Meningitis Vaccine Brings Hope of Taming a Ravaging Illness in Africa
text: JOHANNESBURG  For over a century, epidemics of bacterial meningitis have swept across Africa, arriving with the dry harmattan winds to kill with terrifying speed. But on Monday, a drive starts to inoculate tens of millions of West Africans with a new vaccine in what scientists hope will be the beginning of the end of ravaging meningitis epidemics.

text: The forecast for spring calls for dark red lips, brightly colored ‘‘hair makeup’’ and intense blue eye shadow.

headline: Don’t Look, Don’t Read: Government Warns Its Workers Away From WikiLeaks Documents
text: WASHINGTON — In a classic case of shutting the barn door after the horse has left, the Obama administration and the Department of Defense have ordered the hundreds of thousands of federal employees and contractors not to view the secret cables and other classified documents published by Wikileaks and news organizations around the world unless the workers have the required security clearance or authorization.

headline: The Art of Interruption
text: LAST Monday, at the 92nd Street Y in New York, I took part in a conversation about a novel I had written. The book is set in the art world, and my conversation partner was Deborah Solomon, an art scholar and a writer for this newspaper, as well as a friend. Some years ago, she and I had conducted a similar conversation in Washington to discuss my art collection. It was lively and entertaining, and I couldn’t think of a reason that this evening would not go as well. Because it’s an honor to speak at the Y, we agreed to do the event for free.

headline: New Obstacles for WikiLeaks and Founder
text: LONDON — As the political storm over their release of 250,000 secret American diplomatic cables continues, the WikiLeaks Web site and its founder, Julian Assange, are facing new legal and operational challenges from Swedish prosecutors and from one of the online payment services that have been used to channel donations to the whistle-blowing organization.

headline: Editor’s Letter
text: Last July, I rode my bicycle down to the Bowery to be photographed sitting on a paper moon. The photographer was Alice O’Malley, whose pictures of downtown personalities hung recently at MoMA P.S. 1, and her price for a Polaroid was $20. I felt as though I had been given the perfect gift — a sentimental miniature by a great artist for a song — and one that I will pass on to my sons. I thought about Alice and her moon when we began planning this holiday issue; I wanted to convey that magical sense of being in the presence of someone who is truly gifted, and being allowed to walk away from the experience with something very special. She was one of the first people I called; the result is a breathtaking portfolio of intriguing and talented beauties in wistful resort frocks, which Alice produced with the fashion editor Susan Winget.

headline: Gifted | Lindsey Wixson, Mathieu Lehanneur and Gaspar Noé

headline: Haunted by Attack, Few Return to Island
text: YEONPYEONG ISLAND, South Korea  Sitting in front of his home, Chang Woon-il looked almost out of place, a lonely human figure on a street where stray dogs wandered among the abandoned and broken houses. Nor was he intending to stay very long. Wielding a stubby knife, Mr. Chang, a 64-year-old fisherman, quickly shucked oysters as he hurried to gather as much food as he could before catching the next ferry out.

headline: Why Iran Loves WikiLeaks
text: THE editor of WikiLeaks, Julian Assange, has much in common with the anarchists of the early 20th century: he aims to disrupt the established order by impairing its alliances and violating its proprieties. With the release of a quarter-million documents written by American diplomats at home and abroad, many of them shockingly candid, he has gone some distance toward accomplishing this. Take the Middle East, for example.

headline: For Pentagon Lawyer Who Co-Wrote Report on Gays, Military Bias Hits Home
text: WASHINGTON  Few officials have had to handle more legal mayhem and institutional queasiness at the Pentagon this year than Jeh C. Johnson, the Defense Department’s general counsel and a co-author of an intensely debated new report on the effects of allowing openly gay men and women to serve in the United States military.

headline: Senator at the Luau
text: The emblematic dish of Hawaii is kalua pig, baked whole in a pit with ti leaves and lava rocks. It is perfect both as party food and political metaphor, for a state that has been living for 50 years on heaping helpings of federal largess. The people of Hawaii are the No. 1 per-capita recipients of Congressional earmarks, thanks largely to their beloved senior senator, Daniel Inouye.

headline: Mother’s Call Led to Rescue of 10 Children From Smugglers in Phoenix, Officials Say
text: PHOENIX  It could have been mistaken for a day care center, with so many children of all ages inside. But the authorities said that the crowded house in a working-class neighborhood here was really a drop point for a human-smuggling operation and that the 10 children, ages 2 to 17, were illegal immigrants being held for ransom.

headline: Buying Rice — With Your Cell Phone
text: My Sunday column is about the use of cell phones to fight poverty by bringing banking services to the unbanked. I’ve long been fascinated the the power of microsavings and financial services for the poor, but the problem has always been what platform to use. Most microfinance institutions aren’t even allowed to accept savings deposits, because for that they would need a banking license.

headline: Critics Accuse Group of a Serious Texas Sin: Forgetting the Alamo
text: SAN ANTONIO  For 105 years, a private organization of women descended from Texas pioneers has been taking care of the Alamo with very little oversight by the state.

headline: James P. Simpson Dies at 87; Cleaned Up Galveston
text: Something of a relic of the speakeasy era, Galveston County, Tex., was dotted with gambling dens, prostitution parlors and illegal nightclubs well into the 1950s  a time when it was still against state law to sell liquor by the drink. (You could buy a bottle, brown-bag it into a club and order ice.)

headline: Richard N. Goldman, Civic Leader and Patron, Dies at 90
text: Richard N. Goldman, a San Francisco civic leader and philanthropist best known for co-founding the Goldman Environmental Prize, which is given to six grass-roots environmental activists every year, died Monday at his home in San Francisco. He was 90.

text: Handball is New York City’s quintessential street game, and for nearly a century, the city has produced many of the best players in the world.

headline: State Cuts Put Officers on Front Lines of Mental Care
text: PORTLAND, Me.  As community mental health systems fray under the strain of state budget cuts and a weak economy, law enforcement officers across the nation are increasingly having to step in to provide the emergency services that clinics have typically offered the mentally ill.

headline: Neediest | Bridging a Community
text: With help from The Neediest Cases Fund, a Yiddish language group for fixed income seniors at The Edith and Carl Marks Jewish Community House in Brooklyn was able to continue weekly meetings.

headline: Truth and Plea Bargains
text: The value of DNA testing to clear the unjustly convicted is well known. That did not stop the Bush administration from bullying defendants who pleaded guilty to waive their right to seek such testing. Attorney General Eric Holder made the right choice last week, ordering the Justice Department to drop this policy.

text: Labor and business leaders are busy sifting through questionnaire responses from the record crop of would-be aldermen to determine which of the challengers might be friendly to their agendas and could mount viable campaigns.

text: San Francisco school officials, including Superintendent Carlos A. Garcia, received warnings that a group of administrators in charge of after-school programs used questionable accounting practices while handling millions of dollars in district money, according to senior executives with community organizations.

text: Driving his mud-spattered Suburban through a wood storage yard, Danny Vines gestured out the window at piles of lopped-off logs and bushy materials.

headline: The Texas Shuffle
text: We’ve all walked into a record store looking for one thing and left with another. As quaint as that may seem in the digital age, record store clerks are the original purveyors of “If you like ...” They get to know your tastes and revel in suggesting albums they think you will enjoy. At the few surviving mom-and-pops, where the owners and employees are typically the best authorities on their local music scene, those referrals are often for albums made by musicians down the block or around the corner — although you may never have heard of them.

headline: Crabbers
text: Crab season is here and Spud Point Crab Company, based in Bodega Bay, is enjoying its best run in more than seven years. Fishing offshore for up to 36 hours at a time, its five boats set traps and collect up to 8,000 pounds of Dungeness crabs before returning to their dock.

headline: For the Ultimate, Intimate Concert, Host It Yourself
text: As the time comes to gather with friends and family around a warm hearth, consider this: home holds the heart, but it may also hold your next concert.

headline: Trying to Ignite Spark of Revival in a Grim Gary
text: Anthony Broadnax clambered up the stairs of a vacant brick building in Gary, Ind., on Thursday, stepping through rubble left by thieves who had ransacked the structure for copper. The thick burgundy carpet was littered with trophies, microwave popcorn and plastic flowers.

headline: As Bullies Go Digital, Parents Play Catch-Up
text: Ninth grade was supposed to be a fresh start for Marie’s son: new school, new children. Yet by last October, he had become withdrawn. Marie prodded. And prodded again. Finally, he told her.

headline: Mounting Debts by States Stoke Fears of Crisis
text: The State of Illinois is still paying off billions in bills that it got from schools and social service providers last year. Arizona recently stopped paying for certain organ transplants for people in its Medicaid program. States are releasing prisoners early, more to cut expenses than to reward good behavior. And in Newark, the city laid off 13 percent of its police officers last week.

headline: Pushing a Right to Bear Arms, the Sharp Kind
text: PHOENIX — Arizona used to be a knife carrier’s nightmare, with a patchwork of local laws that forced those inclined to strap Buck knives or other sharp objects to their belts to tread carefully as they moved from Phoenix (no knives except pocketknives) to Tempe (no knives at all) to Tucson (no knives on library grounds).

headline: A Range of Options for a Victim’s Parents
text: When a child becomes entangled in an online conflict, parents understandably feel stricken. But they do not need to panic, experts say. Increasingly, parents have options, ranging from giving their child emotional support to contacting schools and the police, as well as Web sites and service providers, most of whom are tightening their processes to handle complaints.

headline: For 2nd Year, Younger Women Beat Older Men at Czech Event
text: In chess, men almost always outperform women, and younger players often beat older ones. But which group  women or older players  has the advantage when they face each other?

headline: Helen Boatwright, Celebrated Soprano, Dies at 94
text: Helen Boatwright, an American soprano renowned for her interpretations of Charles Ives, died on Wednesday in Jamesville, N.Y., outside Syracuse. She was 94 and had lived nearby in Fayetteville, N.Y.

headline: College Football Replay, Dec. 4
text: A look at the day’s action in regular-season finales, conference championship games and the Football Championship Subdivision playoffs.

headline: In a Hometown Parade, Posey Trumps Even Santa
text: LEESBURG, Ga.  The last float in Leesburg’s 22nd Spirit of Christmas Parade, as always, was occupied Saturday by Santa Claus. It is the law, the mayor said jokingly.

headline: Vows: Rachel and Ryan
text: It was a setup. A mutual  friend conspired for Rachel and Ryan to meet at a bridal shower. Despite rumors, he was not shy. They danced and talked until 3 a.m. and a fun romance was to follow.

headline: Jeter Deal Done; Now Comes Hard Part
text: Derek Jeter’s signing with the Yankees is a reminder of what the pilot sometimes says over the intercom after he has landed the plane: the safest part of your day is now over.

headline: A ‘Shared Vision’ on Climate, With a Glitch
