headline: Gates Arrives in Oman
text: MUSCAT, Oman — Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates arrived in Oman on Sunday as a jumping off point for a trip to the U.S.S. Abraham Lincoln, an aircraft carrier in the Arabian Sea used to launch air missions into Afghanistan.

headline: Rhapsody in Green
text: Sharon Wauchob just presented her first collection as creative director for Edun, the socially conscious line founded by Bono and Ali Hewson and now partially owned by LVMH. The Madagascar-made organic poplin cotton dresses and Kenyan beadwork found in a number of her clothes made us think: who better to advise on greening up holiday packaging supplies? Wauchob suggests recycled tissues from Calligrane ($14 per sheet, 6 Rue du Pont Louis Philippe) and, for ribbons, old ripped T-shirts strung with locally produced African beads (beadsofparadisenyc.com). ‘‘Recycling should be impulsive,’’ she says, ‘‘an intimate way to give a little bit more.’’

headline: Fancy Free
text: This holiday season, designers are trading vertiginous heels for vamp-heavy embossed leather and flouncy Lurex flats. Prepare to be comfortably seduced.

headline: The Democrats’ Tax Cut Dilemma
text: Saturday afternoon, the Senate failed to achieve cloture on a proposal to extend the Bush-era tax cuts for family incomes below $250,000 but end them for incomes above this threshold.

headline: Historic Hong Kong Building Hosts Photo Festival
text: The imposing 19th-century Central Police Station is one of the few historic buildings of note left near SoHo, a Hong Kong quarter stuffed with bars, restaurants, galleries and boutiques. For years, it has been mostly left unused, despite various plans to turn it into a cultural center.

headline: Wax Works
text: Isabel Toledo, long New York’s most singular designer, makes magic with a Mizensir candle. ‘‘I really wanted to tap the secret garden of my memories,’’ says Toledo, recalling days spent in the Caribbean, where lemon trees and rosebushes are often in bloom together. The pairing ‘‘never fails to lift my spirit.’’

headline: Cash Flow to Terrorists Evades U.S. Efforts
text: WASHINGTON  Nine years after the United States vowed to shut down the money pipeline that finances terrorism, senior Obama administration officials say they believe that many millions of dollars are flowing largely unimpeded to extremist groups worldwide, and they have grown frustrated by frequent resistance from allies in the Middle East, according to secret diplomatic dispatches.

headline: Europe Wary of U.S. Bank Monitors
text: WASHINGTON  When the European Parliament ordered a halt in February to an American government program to monitor international banking transactions for terrorist activity, the Obama administration was blindsided by the rebuke.

headline: Meddling Neighbors Undercut Iraq Stability
text: WASHINGTON  Saddam Hussein’s Iraq was a regional menace that sent shudders through its neighbors. Today’s Iraqi leaders are struggling to restrain the ambitions of the countries that share Iraq’s porous borders, eye the country’s rich resources and vie for influence.

headline: Straphangers
text: Whether your wheels are on a bike, car or train, you need the right bag for how you roll.

headline: Watch Out for Online Scams This Holiday Season
text: The Internet security firm McAfee recently released a list of the online scams that consumers should be aware of this holiday season.

headline: Ink: The New Accessory
text: Diamonds are forever — but so is pigment etched into skin. Once the province of sailors and bikers, the tattoo has recently been elevated to the runway (Louis Vuitton and Yves Saint Laurent) and to the day’s supermodels, like Catherine McNeil. Here, four artists suggest a few indelible additions to your jewelry box.

headline: Shaping the Way
text: Suddenly everyone is talking about Thomas Tait, 23, the London-based Central Saint Martins graduate who in October, with barely two collections to his name, won the first-ever Dorchester Collection Fashion Prize. The Montreal-born Tait has yet to sell a single dress outside of private orders (some accessories are available through a project with Asos.com), but he says the prize money will enable him to begin proper production and retail sales. However, it’s his new friends, famous for their taste, who are likely to move his business along the most. Giles Deacon, Daphne Guinness, Stephen Jones and others selected him for the award; another judge, Manolo Blahnik, has been widely quoted gushing over Tait’s ‘‘incredible couture mind.’’

headline: From Boos to Boss as Giants Face Redskins
text: A pause in our coverage of the Northeast mini-Super Bowl — Jets-Patriots — to bring you a few recommended links on the Giants:

headline: Capitalist Crusaders
text: Eleven years ago, Donna and Philip Berber had a Texas-size life — a booming tech company in Austin (Cybercorp), three sons and, “you know, flowers in my garden,” says Donna, who started A Glimmer of Hope, a foundation to help the rural poor in Ethiopia. Then, after seeing a video of his wife handing out bread to the hungry in Addis Ababa, Philip made a trip there himself and decided to “turn my back on my commercial career.” With $60 million from the recent sale of Cybercorp to Charles Schwab (for $488 million), he joined the foundation full time, and the couple (he’s Irish, she’s English) became pioneers of philanthro-capitalism. The Berbers’ endowment covers all of Glimmer’s operating costs, which has allowed the foundation to spend $40 million and counting to help alleviate poverty in Ethiopia. “One hundred percent of the money, not 50 or 80 percent, needed to get to the people,” says Philip, comparing Glimmer’s business model with that of other charities. “We had to start with a clean piece of paper.”

headline: Laura & Adam
text: Adam Singh and Laura Darby Brown fell in love over a game of Dungeons and Dragons.  They continued their adventures in the Democratic Republic of Congo, studying chimpanzees.

headline: What Does $60 Billion Buy?
text: In today’s Week in Review section, I look at how else Congress could spend $60 billion a year — the annual cost of extending the Bush tax cuts on income above $250,000 a year. This post provides details on the calculations.

headline: Gaylord Opryland Reopens
text: The Gaylord Opryland hotel in Nashville celebrated its reopening recently with three days of events that included country music concerts, a Christmas tree lighting and indoor fireworks at its Delta Atrium.

headline: With Great Satire Comes Great Publicity: ‘S.N.L.’ Sends Up the ‘Spider-Man’ Musical
text: 11:38 a.m. | Updated

headline: T Holiday Issue
text: The latest holiday issue of T makes its debut this weekend with Mick Jagger on the cover. At 67, Jagger, the iconic rocker/style-setter/knight of the cultural realm, shows no interest in raking over the past — a fitting idea for a newly redesigned T. Along with several retooled features, you’ll see plenty of fresh faces, among them Nicki Minaj, Reeve Carney, Sasha Pivovarova, Todd Selby and a full cast of up-and-comers in music, fashion, film and art. They’re all gifted in some way, and they’re our holiday gifts, along with other offerings both ruminative — the Icelandic volcano’s surprise gift of time, Wikilieak’s not-always-welcome gift of information — and retail: There’s an eye-popping preview of the spring collection’s boldest moments; a portfolio of languid, ladylike dresses worn by fierce modern beauties like Maggie Gyllenhaal and Mila Kunis; and a guide to gifts so good you can’t give just one.

headline: An Endangered Butcher Gets His Groove Back
text: Updated, Tuesday, Dec. 7 | Six months or so ago, Jeffrey Ruhalter was a butcher in a deep funk, grappling with a sinking family business that dated back to his German great-great-grandfather in 1870. Jeffrey’s Meat Market is, he says, the last original tenant at the Essex Street Market on the Lower East Side, opened by his grandfather in 1940. The dynamics of change, along with the global economic downturn, had blindsided him.

headline: Bookshelf
text: Jessica Kerwin Jenkins’s ‘‘Encyclopedia of the Exquisite’” (Doubleday, $28) collects history’s most reverie-inducing marginalia — on subjects like milk baths, italic typefaces and blancmange, a silky almond pudding name-dropped by Chaucer. The same sun-baked optimism that sent ‘‘The Girl From Ipanema’’into the stratosphere also spawned some of the best album art ever, now compiled in ‘‘Bossa Nova and the Rise of Brazilian Music in the 1960s’’ (Soul Jazz Books, $40). Punta Arenas, Abomey, Alice Springs: the postmarks in ‘‘Under the Sun: The Letters of Bruce Chatwin’’ (Viking, $35) betray an epic case of wanderlust. When good triumphs over evil, the comic-book heroes of Marc Guggenheim and Tara Butters’s ‘‘Halcyon’’ (Image Comics, $3.50) face an uncommon enemy: ennui. A monograph on the man who made Marilyn’s skirt billow: ‘‘Sam Shaw’’ (Hatje Cantz, $75). ‘‘The Victorian hoop skirt, the Gibson Girl coif, the plume hat slouching over one winking eye’’ — these and every other part of Gypsy Rose Lee are examined afresh by Karen Abbott in ‘‘American Rose: A Nation Laid Bare’’ (Random House, $26). And in ‘‘We Have Met the Enemy: Self-Control in an Age of Excess’’ (The Penguin Press, $27), Daniel Akst explains why there’s a glut of everything these days — except willpower.

headline: Disinflation Confirmed
text: One of the things you often hear is the claim that statistics showing falling inflation are just about housing. Via Mark Thoma, the San Francisco Fed has done the homework: the same downward trend is there if you purge housing from the core index:

headline: King of the Jungle
text: A dark and stormy night: the cliché has come to life, zombielike, and is clutching the party island of Bali in an intense and unseasonable monsoon. I’ve had to bribe my cabby to get him to take me to a spooky gate on a lonely country road. ‘‘You can’t miss it,’’ Bickerton, a reclusive artist, had assured me. I don’t. Set into twin niches chiseled into the stelae that serve as gateposts are two severed heads. Gene Simmons-caliber tongues writhe from mouths agape in midscream, and only their neon complexions give them away as sculptures.

headline: Not Crass, Class
text: Karl Smith sort of takes issue with my point about how Social Security is a favorite target of the Beltway crowd, because it’s not important to anyone they know. “I doubt anyone thinks about it in such crass terms,” he writes.

headline: Final: Giants 31, Redskins 7
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — The Giants’ 31-7 win over the Washington Redskins on Sunday was a showcase of dominating defense and a thundering rushing offense. But the victory was important because of what it signified for the Giants.

headline: Undercut by Microsoft, Russia Drops Piracy Case
text: MOSCOW  The authorities have dismissed software piracy charges against one of Russia’s most well-known environmental groups after Microsoft indicated that it would no longer support the case.

headline: G.O.P. Leader Sees Outline of Tax Deal
text: After thwarting efforts to raise taxes on America’s top earners, Sen. Mitch McConnell, the Republican leader, predicted Sunday that Congress would retain the expiring Bush-era tax cuts for a limited number of years and might also extend unemployment benefits as part of a compromise with the White House.

headline: Another Look at the 2010 World Cup
text: The awarding of the 2018 and 2022 World Cups to Russia and Qatar is certain to change the way the world views the sport of soccer. These days, that metamorphosis is not limited to play on the field. In today’s graphical world, computers and the human imagination have added a new dimension to objects as prosaic as the plain-vanilla tournament draw sheet.

headline: Web Site for Teenagers With Literary Leanings
text: When Jacob Lewis helped create the beta version of the Web site Figment with Dana Goodyear, a staff writer at The New Yorker, Mr. Lewis envisioned it as a sort of literary Facebook for the teenage set.

headline: Israel Credits Outside Help as Deadly Fire Is Contained
text: JERUSALEM — A deadly forest fire that had raged for four days in the parched north of Israel has been brought “more or less under control,” an Israeli police official said Sunday evening, crediting assistance from an international fleet of more than 30 firefighting aircraft and the so-called Supertanker, the world’s largest fire-extinguishing plane.

headline: Ailey Continues to Build on Its Proud Tradition
text: Why does almost everyone who choreographs for Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater create work that looks as if it’s made for Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater: The Brand?

headline: Pressure Rises to Bolster European Bailout Fund
text: European finance ministers are under mounting pressure to significantly increase the 750 billion-euro rescue fund for the currency union when they meet Monday.

headline: Downsizing: When a Heavenly Body Got the Boot
text: The Caltech astronomy professor Mike Brown is not the first person to write about the rise of the planet Pluto (discovered in 1930 by Clyde Tombaugh) or its recent demotion (in 2006) to second-class citizenry in a newly reduced, eight-planet solar system. He may not even be the best, coming on the heels of Neil deGrasse Tyson’s breezy “Pluto Files,” the novel “Percival’s Planet” and at least one other nonfiction book on the cosmic Pluto flap.

headline: For One Team, a Pairs Title; For Another, an Early Exit
text: ORLANDO, Fla.  The Nick Nickell team did not “threepeat” in the Reisinger Board-a-Match Teams here on Sunday because it failed to qualify on Saturday. Leading the 10 teams that advanced to Sunday’s two sessions were Kevin Bathurst of New York; Daniel Zagorin of Skokie, Ill.; Bart Bramley of Dallas; Nikolay Demirev of Arlington Heights, Ill.; and Peter Bertheau and Fredrik Nystrom from Sweden.

headline: On the Express Train to Hell and Other Sonic Journeys
text: The American Composers Orchestra has had to scale back its operations in recent seasons. This essential freelance ensemble, which has championed American music for 34 years, used to present up to five concerts a season at Carnegie Hall. Like many arts institutions facing economic hard times, it has adjusted. These days it offers a playfully billed series called Orchestra Underground at Zankel Hall, downstairs from Carnegie’s main hall.

headline: A Trove of Ancient Silver Said to Be Stolen Returns to Its Home in Sicily
text: AIDONE, Italy — They came in throngs. On Friday afternoon hundreds of residents from this tiny hilltop town in eastern Sicily excitedly trekked up the steep slope to the town’s archaeology museum to celebrate the return to Aidone of a treasure trove that was buried nearby some 2,200 years ago and illegally whisked away in more recent times.

headline: The Click Fix
text: It was a dark December, decades ago, a beastly night of sleet and hail, a night to ruin your favorite boots. Needing gifts and needing them in a hurry, I dashed from drugstore to thrift shop to the fresh hell that is Macy’s at holiday time, in search of something that might slake the peculiar appetites of my peculiar circle. How pleasant to remember those desperate hours as I sit under an afghan, laptop on my knees! A few clicks are all it takes to find that for $150 bottegaveneta.com offers a woven-leather money clip, usa.hermes.com a ladybug key ring. What’s that — you hate obvious labels? Perhaps an exception can be made for a Lanvin Cabas tote that resembles a laundry bag, if that item were made of marine blue nylon and cost $840 at barneys.com? Or even a graffiti-bespeckled motorcycle helmet by Martin Margiela at aloharag.com? If you insist that your gang’s predilections swerve away from capitalist exccess, send Walter Benjamin’s ‘‘Arcades Project,’’ 1,088 pages for $31 at www.hup.harvard.edu. But Americans defy categorization, and that same person enjoying Benjamin may be a defender of the Second Amendment, pouring port from a crystal decanter decorated with a shotgun-toting hunter from the old Park Avenue emporium scullyandscully.com. Or, if your posse prefers ‘‘The Simpsons’’ to Schopenhauer, try a pair of Bécassine plastic servant-girl earrings, invariably available on ebay.com. Don’t think you know anyone who wants a pair of ear bobs based on a circa-1905 French comic-book scullery maid? Guess you haven’t peeked inside my jewelry box lately.

headline: Soloists Take or Share the Spotlight as Needed
text: After two nights in the relatively intimate Zankel Hall, the musicians of the Risor Chamber Music Festival from Norway moved to the considerably larger Stern Auditorium on Friday night for the third of four concerts in its Carnegie Hall residency. The first half of the concert featured two world-class soloists in superb form; the second half, remarkably, was better still.

headline: It’s a Jungle Out There: Big Cats, Big Body Counts
text: Attention all water buffalo, impalas, zebras, ostriches, elephants and lizards: Run for your lives. It’s Big Cat Week.

headline: Fake Writer, Real Books? That’s ‘Castle’
text: On a recent episode of “Castle,” the cutesy ABC police procedural that is more gumdrop than gumshoe, a male stripper turns up dead after a night of carousing with some bachelorettes who are still drunk and memory-impaired from cheap tequila. Before long it is revealed that the stripper — who liked to dress up as a cop, carry a toy gun and call himself Officer McNaughty — was also involved in a real estate con. And this is where, from a critical perspective, things get problematic.

headline: Navigating Past Nihilism
text: “Nihilism stands at the door,” wrote Nietzsche.  “Whence comes this uncanniest of all guests?”  The year was 1885 or 1886, and Nietzsche was writing in a notebook whose contents were not intended for publication.  The discussion of nihilism ─ the sense that it is no longer obvious what our most fundamental commitments are, or what matters in a life of distinction and worth, the sense that the world is an abyss of meaning rather than its God-given preserve ─ finds no sustained treatment in the works that Nietzsche prepared for publication during his lifetime.  But a few years earlier, in 1882, the German philosopher had already published a possible answer to the question of nihilism’s ultimate source.  “God is dead,” Nietzsche wrote in a famous passage from “The Gay Science.”  “God remains dead.  And we have killed him.”

headline: Aquatic and Narcotic, Propelled by the Drummer
text: It’s easy to be a great drummer by being loud, but Stella Mozgawa finds all the other ways. She’s dense, leaving little air in her patterns. She’s not overly forceful, sometimes sounding as if she were nudging the rhythm out. And she’s reliably in the pocket, the steady force that sets the mood and pace for the rest of the band.

headline: A Slow Weekend at the Box Office
text: The weekend after Thanksgiving is typically one of the slowest of the year at the North American box office, and the last three days proved no exception. The only sizable new release, “The Warrior’s Way,” a Relativity Media western designed as a vehicle for the South Korean superstar Jang Dong-gun, flopped badly with just $3 million in ticket sales. Most notable for the weekend was a film that opened in only 18 theaters: Darren Aronofsky’s “Black Swan,” a dark portrait of a ballet dancer (Natalie Portman), grossed $1.4 million for a per-theater average of $77,459  one of the best art-house results for the year and a record for the studio behind the film, Fox Searchlight. Over all “Tangled” (Walt Disney Studios), above, was No. 1 in its second weekend in theaters, selling $21.5 million for a new total of $96.5 million, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles box office statistics. “Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 1” (Warner Brothers) was second with $16.7 million for a three-week total of more than $244 million. The runaway-train thriller “Unstoppable” (20th Century Fox) lived up to its title, tying for third in its fourth week with about $6.1 million for a new total of $69 million. The musical “Burlesque” (Sony Pictures Entertainment) shared third-place ranking with $6.1 million of its own for a two-week total of $29 million. “Love and Other Drugs” (Fox) rounded out the top five with $5.7 million for a two-week total of $22.6 million.

headline: Gala for Billy Crystal Will Benefit a Childhood Haunt
text: The Tisch School of the Arts will hold a benefit gala on Monday honoring Billy Crystal, the actor, writer and, apparently, amateur tap dancer. Proceeds from the performance will go toward renovating the school’s original building at 111 Second Avenue, near Seventh Street in the East Village, also known as Central Plaza. It was there that Mr. Crystal’s father, Jack, produced “The Sessions” jazz concerts on Friday and Saturday nights from the late 1940s through the early ’60s. In a telephone interview on Sunday, Mr. Crystal, right, emphasized the legacy of jazz, particularly Dixieland, that his father helped preserve there at a time when rock ’n’ roll was beginning to permeate the music scene. He also talked about his own ties to the building, referring to a “world of these amazing musicians, their spirit, their sense of humor” that, he said, first inspired him as a child to take the stage to tap-dance. But it was watching his father as the master of ceremonies that had the most profound effect on him. “He was up onstage with a microphone, and I guess I wanted to do what he did,” he said.  Whoopi Goldberg and Robin Williams will be among those paying tribute to Mr. Crystal at the gala, at Jazz at Lincoln Center’s Frederick P. Rose Hall. They will be joined by several Tisch alumni, including James Franco, Marcia Gay Harden and Jesse L. Martin.

headline: Stolen Russian Documents Are Recovered by the U.S.
text: Historic documents stolen from the national archives in Moscow and St. Petersburg between 1994 and 2002 were returned to Russia at a ceremony on Friday in Washington, the United States Immigration and Customs Enforcement Agency said in a statement on its Web site, www.ice.gov. The documents include a decree made by Catherine the Great in 1792 and a report, marked “Top Secret,” that was written by Gen. Vasily Blyukher in 1932 outlining the reconstruction of airfields. The documents were found for sale or loan for $300 to $15,000 each on five American Web sites. An investigation continues into several other stolen documents believed to have been smuggled into the United States.

headline: Knicks’ Road Remains Smooth in Rout of the Raptors
text: TORONTO  The boos arrived at intervals at Air Canada Centre, finally and most forcefully as the Knicks smiled and slapped hands. The Knicks, the old Knicks, are used to vocal disapproval because of their play at Madison Square Garden.

headline: Fantastical Thrust (and Hair Color)
text: What’s the quickest way out of New Jersey? Judging by the new My Chemical Romance album, it might be a spaceship. “Danger Days: The True Lives of the Fabulous Killjoys,” the group’s fourth album and its first in four years, is a shameless, grand and sometimes goofy work that sounds destined for ComicCon.

headline: A Spoonful of Exotica Makes the Geography Go Down
text: MTV doesn’t get out much.

headline: Adding Bells and Whistles to Leonardo
text: The British filmmaker Peter Greenaway began his career as a painter and, by aspiration, still is one. He speaks of his films  “The Cook, the Thief, His Wife and Her Lover” from 1989 is the best known  as painterly. And a few years ago he announced a long-term project called 10 Classic Paintings Revisited, in which, through a fusion of film, digital wizardry and installation, he planned to remake some textbook masterpieces.

headline: Once on This Island, a D.I.Y. Art Show
text: MIAMI BEACH  Flagler Memorial Island, a tiny oval of sand and coconut palms in Biscayne Bay, is a strange appendage to the city of Miami Beach. It is a municipal park with no means of access unless you own a boat or have friends who do. It is artificial, like the overdeveloped Venetian Islands nearby, but remains uninhabited and a little wild, with no electricity or facilities. It is home to a big white obelisk, but almost no one here seems to know what the monument honors or goes to visit it.

headline: Monday: Pinnacles
text: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — Almost everyone adores alliteration. Richard Chisholm likes it so much that, sure as shootin’, he built a Monday theme around it. Along the way, and probably without even trying, he manages to include 16 H’s, which ties the record for the most in a 15×15 grid.

headline: Immaculate Perception
text: At a time when the weight of scientific evidence would seem to call into question the Bible’s account of history and the God who set it in motion, the Virgin Mary enjoys a kind of free pass. As the third-century Christian theologian Tertullian wrote of the Resurrection, “It is certain because it is impossible” — a notion that might well apply to the virgin birth; such a conundrum that it elevates Mary to a safe place, beyond logic.

headline: The Night New Orleans Came to Brooklyn
text: Starting with a parade (down an opera-house aisle) and ending nearly three hours later with a jam session, Red Hot + New Orleans brought a generous Crescent City spirit to the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Friday night to kick off a two-night stand.

headline: 'Anointed'
text: Images of a new work by Christopher Huggins.

headline: Nursing Grudges With Acid
text: “I would have won a Tony if there had been a category called Hating Other People’s Careers While Combining Maker’s Mark, Ambien and Pinkberry,” Jackie Hoffman announced during “Jackie Five-Oh!,” her latest caustic cabaret show.

headline: Photo Replay: Dec. 5
text: A view of the day in sports, with fights, spills and unlikely championships.

headline: Madoff Suit Cites HSBC as a Helper
text: The trustee seeking assets for victims of Bernard L. Madoff’s global Ponzi scheme filed a lawsuit on Sunday seeking $9 billion from a roster of defendants headed by HSBC, the London-based financial giant with hedge fund clients that fed piles of cash into the enormous fraud.

headline: Low Interest in Egyptian Runoff That Favors Ruling Party
text: CAIRO  Runoffs in Egypt’s parliamentary elections were held on Sunday amid a general mood of public disinterest and quiet resignation after it became clear from the first round that the ruling party was determined to eliminate any meaningful opposition.

headline: Aide to British Lawmaker Arrested Over Spying Claims
text: LONDON  A Russian aide to a House of Commons member of the Defense Select Committee has been detained by the security services on suspicion of espionage and faces deportation, the lawmaker said Sunday.

headline: The Biggest ‘Mo’ on Embassy Row
text: Last year, Martin Longden, the press secretary for the British Embassy in Washington, was the clear winner for his “John Bolton,” a dense mustache that dominated his upper lip in the fashion of President Bush’s former ambassador to the United Nations. This year, his “imperial Germany” look drooped into second place. A colleague called it “a 19th-century colonial administrator’s Mo.”

headline: Forecasts for Ad Spending Turn Upward
text: Forecasters whose predictions for advertising spending are closely watched are projecting better results for 2010 than initially expected. And they are mostly seeing better days ahead, spending-wise, for next year as well.

headline: Light Asylum | Looking Bright
text: In some underground New York, Tokyo or London club, Shannon Funchess’s powerful contralto punches through the fog-filled stage — as does the spread of green laser light emanating from behind her. Funchess, the Light Asylum frontwoman, drums and sings, pogoing around in a mix of black leather and new-wave neon, like a punker, harder-edged Grace Jones possessed by the sensibilities of Ian Curtis. Her voice has appeared on tracks by bands like Telepathe and TV on the Radio, but it’s with this latest project (a duo, with Bruno Coviello on synth) that she has come into her own. Light Asylum is catchy but raw, music you can lose yourself in.

headline: In Interview, Bernanke Backs Tax Code Shift
text: WASHINGTON  The Federal Reserve chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, said in an interview broadcast on Sunday evening that rising inequality was eroding social cohesion and that Congress could help economic growth by making the tax code more efficient.

headline: Iran Claims Advance With Uranium From Its Own Mine
text: Iran on Sunday claimed for the first time to have used domestically mined uranium ore to make the material needed for uranium enrichment. It called the step a major advance in its atomic program, sending a defiant message before a new round of talks on Iran’s suspect nuclear activities.

headline: Police Say 6 Arrests Foiled Attack
text: ATHENS  Greek police officials said Sunday that they had averted an imminent terrorist attack by arresting six people believed to be linked to domestic terrorist activities, including two suspected members of a group that had claimed responsibility for letter bombs sent to embassies in Athens and foreign leaders last month.

headline: Drew Brees Suckers a Bengal
text: Drew Brees is a great quarterback and the Cincinnati Bengals are a bad football team. Those two N.F.L. truths came together on one play in the final minute Sunday.

headline: ‘Give Me a Chance,’ Black Says in a TV Interview
text: Cathleen P. Black, the chancellor-designate of the New York City schools, defended herself in an interview broadcast on Sunday against the considerable criticism of her surprise appointment, asking the city to get to know her before deeming her unqualified because she lacks experience in education.

headline: Elaine’s Without Elaine? Regulars Wonder
text: In the last couple of years, as Elaine Kaufman faced on-and-off health problems, some of the regulars at her restaurant played a particularly morose kind of parlor game.

headline: For Federal Employees, a Feeling of Being Targets in the Budget Wars
text: WASHINGTON  Iyauta Moore may be many things  a single mother raised by a single mother in the South Bronx, a 34-year-old woman with a master’s degree in public administration from American University, a top-level government employee who makes a little over $100,000 a year  but she bristles at the notion that she is just another overpaid, underworked, cosseted bureaucrat.

headline: Same-Sex Initiative Reaches Next Hurdle
text: SAN FRANCISCO  It has been more than two years since voters outlawed same-sex marriage with a ballot initiative in California, and it may be two more before the legality of that measure  Proposition 8  is finally decided, most likely by the Supreme Court.

headline: Team Sales Top Board of Governors’ Agenda
text: The potential sale of at least three teams and the increasing disparity in value between rich and poor franchises stand atop a busy agenda for the N.H.L. board of governors meeting Monday and Tuesday in Palm Beach, Fla.

headline: Afghanistan Government Arrests 4 on Election Panel
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  Four officials of an Afghan election commission were arrested on Sunday by President Hamid Karzai’s government, which has been deeply critical of the panel’s handling of disputed parliamentary elections.

headline: Nationals Sign Werth on Eve of Winter Meetings
text: The winter meetings officially begin Monday in Orlando, Fla. But for shock value, it will be hard to top the announcement made there Sunday.

headline: Buchanan: Too Little, Too Late
Dan Abrams Plans 3 Web Sites
text: After a successful run with his Web sites that cover media, sports, gossip and technology, Dan Abrams, perhaps best known not as an Internet entrepreneur but as an MSNBC personality, is expanding.

headline: Extreme Makeover: Criminal Court Edition
text: CLEARWATER, Fla.  When John Ditullio goes on trial on Monday, jurors will not see the large swastika tattooed on his neck. Or the crude insult tattooed on the other side of his neck. Or any of the other markings he has acquired since being jailed on charges related to a double stabbing that wounded a woman and killed a teenager in 2006.

headline: Jets and Patriots Are More Alike Than Portrayed
text: From inside the conference room at his Rockefeller Center office last week, Woody Johnson projected confidence and calm. On Monday night, his Jets play the Patriots in Foxborough, Mass., and with both teams boasting identical and league-leading 9-2 records, this marked perhaps the most important regular-season game in Johnson’s tenure as the team’s owner.

headline: Cosmo Sets Sights on Mongolia
text: Coming to a newsstand most likely not near you: Cosmo Mongolia.

headline: In Bitter Weather, Giants Get Comfortable
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  A veteran Giants crowd filled the parking lots Sunday, a collection of fans comfortable on their turf. Against the cold and high wind, they wore old woolen caps and weathered team jackets, symbolic choices outside a stadium that is new and shiny.

headline: Loss Binds the Mortals of a Village
text: SCARSDALE, N.Y.

headline: In Kentucky, Noah’s Ark Theme Park Is Planned
text: Facing a rising tide of joblessness, the governor of Kentucky has found one solution: build an ark.

headline: Peep Show Back in Times Sq., in a Tamer Guise
text: When it was finally shuttered eight years ago, Peep-O-Rama achieved a public cachet that it had never gained in its five decades: the garish pornography emporium was the last peep show palace on “the Deuce.”

headline: Web Anonymity: Double-Edged Sword
text: To the Editor:

headline: Pfizer Loses Man Behind Wyeth Deal
text: Jeffrey B. Kindler announcing Pfizer’s $68 billion deal for Wyeth in January 2009.

headline: Yemen Loses in Soccer, but Scores a P.R. Victory
text: ADEN, Yemen  This decaying port city, near the heart of Yemen’s deadly Qaeda insurgency, may seem an odd place to host an international soccer tournament.

headline: At Barclays, a Pay System That May Please
text: Investment bankers don’t come up with a lot of financial innovations that regulators and politicians tend to like. But Barclays Capital is working on one that just might please everyone.

headline: A Government Forms in Ivory Coast
text: ABIDJAN, Ivory Coast — The winner of last week’s presidential election set up a parallel government on Sunday while the incumbent refused to give up power, raising the stakes in a political standoff that threatens to tip this nation back into civil war.

headline: Stride Rite Ad Tries to Lure New Mothers
text: This season, Stride Rite is hoping new mothers will be watching one of the most popular holiday cartoons of the year, “A Charlie Brown Christmas.” That is when the company’s first national brand television commercial in 20 years will be shown.

headline: Tax Fear May Move Bonuses Earlier
text: Congress is debating tax rates, and that has Wall Street nervously eyeing the calendar.

headline: Guilty of Violating Dress Code, in Any Case
text: Lawyers say that getting their clients ready for trial can often involve a bit of an image upgrade. The clients, however, don’t always help matters.

headline: To Beat ‘Today,’ Look to Tomorrow
text: When a sports team loses long enough, fans get restless and soon enough, the coach ends up getting the gate. After all, you can’t fire the whole team, right?

headline: B.C.S. Title Game Promises to Be Sprint to the Finish
text: Gus Malzahn, the coordinator of top-ranked Auburn’s prolific offense, is not a joking kind of guy. That does not mean others will not have fun at his expense.

headline: WikiLeaks and the Perils of Oversharing
text: THE recent release of internal State Department cables by WikiLeaks, assisted by a coalition of news outlets in the United States and Europe, has been viewed as a national security matter  have confidential sources been compromised? Could relations between the United States and Russia (or Italy or France or Pakistan) be permanently damaged?

headline: Congressional Oversight
text: To the Editor:

headline: Bush Tax-Cut Deal With Jobless Aid Said to Be Near
text: WASHINGTON  White House officials and Congressional Republicans said Sunday they were closing in on a deal to temporarily continue the Bush-era tax cuts at all income levels, while bitterly frustrated Democratic Congressional leaders began exploring whether they would have the votes for such a package.

headline: ESPN Says Study Shows Little Effort to Cut Cable
text: Seeking to understand the cutting of cable cords, ESPN has waded into the Nielsen Company’s audience sample and concluded that the cancellations are currently a “very minor” phenomenon.

headline: In Spain, Gypsies Find Easier Path to Integration
text: MADRID  Encarnación Rómero Bastante, a manicurist, was not sure what to expect when she was hired by a government-financed program to train a 33-year-old Gypsy woman.

headline: Speaking Out About AIDS

headline: Tiger Woods Is Upstaged in Last Shot of Year
text: THOUSAND OAKS, Calif.  If further proof was needed that the tectonic shift in men’s golf had reshaped the landscape, Graeme McDowell provided it with a short Twitter message Saturday night and two long putts Sunday.

headline: Jurors in ’01 Bombings Case Sympathize With Pressures on Recent Panel
text: Few people really know what went on during deliberations in the trial of Ahmed Khalfan Ghailani, or what led the jury to acquit him of hundreds of murder and conspiracy counts and to convict him of only one: conspiring to destroy government buildings and property.

headline: MetroCard Blazes Mother’s Path to a Job
text: When Jessica Torres is nervous, words flutter from her mouth like butterflies in springtime, flitting in every direction. As she giggles, short phrases fly from her lips, colliding with each other, trailing off or suddenly reappearing.

headline: In Online Privacy Plan, the Opt-Out Question Looms
text: The Federal Trade Commission’s proposed privacy mechanism could cause a major shift in the online advertising industry, as companies that have relied on consumers’ browsing history try to make up for what could be billions in lost revenue.

headline: G.E. and JPMorgan Got Lots of Fed Help in ’08
text: Newly disclosed records show that during the 2008 financial crisis, the Federal Reserve essentially lent $16.1 billion to General Electric by buying short-term corporate i.o.u.’s from the company at a time when the public market for such debt had nearly frozen.

headline: A Bleak Budget Outlook for Public Broadcasters
text: In less than four weeks, NJN, the public radio and television network owned by New Jersey, will run out of state money to operate. Without a last-minute intervention, its outlets will go off the air on Dec. 31, and NJN’s 130 employees have already received layoff notices.

headline: Economic Reports for the Week of Dec. 6
text: ECONOMIC REPORTS Data this week will include consumer credit for October (Tuesday); weekly jobless claims and wholesale trade for October (Thursday); trade deficit for October, import prices for November, and Thomson Reuters/University of Michigan consumer confidence index for December (Friday).

headline: An Old-Fashioned Drubbing in December
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.

headline: With Republicans Running State Senate, Cuomo’s Job May Be Easier
text: Andrew M. Cuomo may not say this out loud, but his new job may have gotten a bit easier over the weekend.

headline: Pfizer’s Chairman and Chief Retires Unexpectedly
text: Jeffrey B. Kindler is retiring as chief executive and chairman of Pfizer, the world’s largest pharmaceutical firm, the company said on Sunday evening in an unexpected announcement.

headline: Topsy-Turvy Feel to N.F.L.’s Playoff Chases
text: When the N.F.L. backloaded its schedule to ensure that even the most dominant teams would play meaningful games in December, it had weekends like this one in its sights. With nine games between division opponents, including Monday night’s showdown between the Jets and the New England Patriots, and with no division led by more than one game entering Sunday, the N.F.L. had the late-season tension it craved.

headline: Waning Support for College Radio Sets Off a Debate
text: Like many college radio stations across the country, Rice University’s KTRU and Vanderbilt University’s WRVU play a broad swath of music  from undiscovered indie bands and obscure blues acts to ’60s garage rock and ’80s postpunk. It’s a mix largely absent from commercial broadcasts, and students active in radio say their stations add distinct voices to their cities’ broadcast landscape.

headline: Studios Battle to Save Narnia (From Grip of Sequel Fatigue)
text: LOS ANGELES  With the opening this Friday of “The Chronicles of Narnia: The Voyage of the Dawn Treader,” comes a study in one of the most difficult challenges a studio can face: fixing a broken movie series.

headline: As U.S. Leaves, Iraqis Suffer Economic Toll
text: TIKRIT, Iraq  Qahtan Kareem is a businessman whose main business  the United States  is leaving town. He made his fortune buying and reselling scrap and surplus from military bases. Now, as the American Army withdraws from Iraq, he is grim about the future of his company and its 430 employees.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Rabbit Ears Perk Up for Free HDTV
text: Julie and Anthony Bayerl of St. Paul, Minn., love watching prime-time shows on the sleek 50-inch television in their bedroom. They also love that they pay nothing for the programming.

headline: Hundreds of WikiLeaks Mirror Sites Appear
text: LONDON — The battle lines between supporters of the whistle-blowing Web site WikiLeaks and its detractors began to form on Sunday, as supporters erected numerous copies of the site on the Internet and the United States put pressure on Switzerland not to offer a haven to the site’s founder, Julian Assange.

headline: Helping Ingredients Step Out of Their Comfort Zone
text: AS recently as the early 1980s, olive oil was something of rarity in the United States, used mostly by gourmets who sought it out in specialty stores. Then, because of claims that the oil is heart-healthy, sales began to sizzle. And today, olive oil commands over a third of the market for oils.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: Athletes’ Soul-Searching Begets Spoofs
text: After abandoning Cleveland for Miami, the basketball star LeBron James tried to rehabilitate his image in October with a 90-second Nike commercial in which he rhetorically asks, “What should I do?” The campaign generated significant interest online, but after 13 days, derivative parodies  coming from political candidates sports personalities and even “South Park”  eclipsed its viewership, according to data from Visible Measures, an online video measurement company.

headline: W.N.B.A. Internships Put Players to Work
text: Dressed stylishly in a white blouse, dark purple blazer and designer blue jeans, Nicole Powell sat at a back corner of a conference table, five floors above the midday Manhattan bustle on Avenue of the Americas. She looked and sounded the part of a young public-relations whiz.

headline: Glittering Tributes for Winners of Kennedy Center Honors
text: WASHINGTON  Oprah Winfrey and Paul McCartney were among the five cultural luminaries whose lives and work were celebrated this weekend at the White House and the State Department as recipients of the Kennedy Center Honors.

headline: News From the Advertising Industry
text: Accounts

headline: Sleepy-Headed Rangers Allow Hat Trick
text: Until Sunday, the Rangers had a 12-2-1 record against teams well below them in the standings. But they came out sleepwalking against the Ottawa Senators at Madison Square Garden, then surrendered the decisive goal with 2 minutes 24 seconds remaining in a 3-1 loss.

headline: Mets Have Specific Wish List and Limited Budget
text: LAKE BUENA VISTA, Fla. — Word of Jayson Werth’s seven-year, $126 million contract percolated up to the Mets hotel suite here and it seemed to make General Manager Sandy Alderson almost giddy with relief that he was not in the market for any big-ticket free agents this off-season.

headline: Senate Vote Is Scheduled for Bailout of City OTB
text: With its parlors yet again on the verge of turning off the lights for good, the New York City Off-Track Betting Corporation has one corner of its operation that remains attractive to the outside world.

headline: Madoff Case Lingers as Menace to Mets
text: As the Mets head into this week’s winter meetings in Orlando, Fla., they are dealing with an issue that would seem to overshadow whatever modest moves they may make in the days ahead to fill out the 2011 roster.

headline: Museum Sells Pieces of Its Past, Reviving a Debate
text: PHILADELPHIA — A galloping horse weather vane sold for about $20,000, and the cigar store Indians brought in more than $1 million. A Thomas Sully oil painting of Andrew Jackson netted $80,500, and a still life by Raphaelle Peale, part of the family that put portraiture in this city on the map, was auctioned at Christie’s for $842,500.

headline: Corrections
text: The Times welcomes comments and suggestions, or complaints about errors that warrant correction. Messages on news coverage can be e-mailed to nytnews@nytimes.com or left toll-free at 1-888-NYT-NEWS (1-888-698-6397). Comments on editorials may be e-mailed to letters@nytimes.com or faxed to (212) 556-3622.

headline: Cathedral With a Past; Basilica With a Future
text: New York City’s first Roman Catholic cathedral, a landmark Gothic Revival church built in downtown Manhattan two centuries ago, when sailing ships crowded the harbor and DeWitt Clinton was mayor, was elevated to the status of a basilica on Sunday, honoring a rich history of succor to waves of immigrants.

headline: Redskins, Under Shanahan, Struggle to Turn Things Around
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Along with the gold and white tape that littered the carpet in their locker room, the Washington Redskins were left to sift the debris of another lost season after their 31-7 defeat to the Giants on Sunday.

headline: Palle Huld, Danish Actor Said to Be Model for Tintin, Dies at 98
text: Palle Huld, a Danish actor whose fleet, youthful and highly public circumnavigation of the globe as a cowlicked teenager is believed to have inspired the popular comic-book character Tintin, died on Nov. 26 in Copenhagen. He was 98.

headline: At the Scene of Danroy Henry Jr.’s Shooting
text: Videos from the scene of the shooting of a Pace University student in October.

headline: After Police Shots, Grief and Conflicting Stories
text: The 33-year-old police officer, Aaron Hess, was a former Marine who for seven years had served on the tiny police force in Pleasantville, N.Y., the village where he had grown up. He had never fired his gun at anyone in the line of duty.

headline: Hollywood Goes to Havana
text: “No route found.”

headline: A Building Conquered, Cashman Returns to Building Up the Yankees
text: STAMFORD, Conn. – Most of the time, highly anticipated off-season signings are followed by stage-managed stadium news briefings or conference calls with reporters.

headline: The Long-Distance Climate Campaigner
text: CANCÚN, Mexico — Over the weekend, I caught up with Bill McKibben, whose approach to environmental campaigning seems drawn from the “year of living strenuously” he endured training to reach peak performance as a long-distance skier.

headline: S. Korea Starts Naval Firing Drills Amid Tension
text: SEOUL, South Korea  Brushing aside North Korean warnings of war, South Korea began live-fire artillery drills near their disputed maritime border on Monday, less than two weeks after the North’s surprise shelling of a South Korea-held island sharply escalated tensions between them.

headline: Europe’s Piecemeal Failure

headline: Doctor Faces Suits Over Cardiac Stents
text: Word quickly reached top executives at Abbott Laboratories that a Baltimore cardiologist, Dr. Mark Midei, had inserted 30 of the company’s cardiac stents in a single day in August 2008, “which is the biggest day I remember hearing about,” an executive wrote in a celebratory e-mail.

headline: Let’s Not Make a Deal
text: Back in 2001, former President George W. Bush pulled a fast one. He wanted to enact an irresponsible tax cut, largely for the benefit of the wealthiest Americans. But there were Senate rules in place designed to prevent that kind of irresponsibility. So Mr. Bush evaded the rules by making the tax cut temporary, with the whole thing scheduled to expire on the last day of 2010.

headline: ‘Long Story Short’ Extends
text: “Long Story Short,” the comedian Colin Quinn’s satirical history of the world, directed by Jerry Seinfeld, has been extended. The show began previews on Oct. 22, opened on Nov. 9, and was originally scheduled to close on Jan. 8. It will now run at the Helen Hayes Theater through Feb. 5.

headline: Giants Replay: Week 13
text: Images from the Giants’ 31-7 victory over the Redskins.

headline: The Changing Culture War
text: For a long time, the contours of America’s culture war seemed relatively straightforward. On one side was the country’s growing educated class, who tended to be secular, permissive and favorably disposed to the sexual revolution. On the other side were the social conservatives of middle America — benighted yahoos or virtuous yeomen, depending on your point of view, but either way a less-educated and more pious demographic, with more traditional attitudes on sexuality and family.

headline: The Crime of Punishment
text: In 2005, when a federal court took a snapshot of California’s prisons, one inmate was dying each week because the state failed to provide adequate health care. Adequate does not mean state-of-the-art, or even tolerable. It means care meeting “the minimal civilized measure of life’s necessities,” in the Supreme Court’s words, so inmates do not die from rampant staph infections or commit suicide at nearly twice the national average.

headline: Comcast and NBC
text: Television is undergoing a wrenching change. Companies like Netflix and Google TV are lining up to offer movies and TV online. Cable systems are developing online bundles as they add broadband customers but lose TV subscribers. Broadcast networks are still figuring out how to sell their shows online, and charging cable systems more as ad money moves to the Internet.

headline: A Sordid, Unethical Tale
text: The Department of Justice has ended a criminal investigation without making charges in the case of Senator John Ensign, his mistress and the conveniently doled out political favors.

headline: The Country Can Learn a Lesson From These Students
text: Twenty-one-year old Zakiya Qualls seemed almost too shy to speak at the start of our telephone conversation. But her tone was lively and her voice forceful when she talked about her senior-year science research at Howard University and her dream of finding a cure for Parkinson’s disease.

headline: Rights Group Says Caning in Malaysia Is Torture
text: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia  Amnesty International is calling on Malaysia to halt the practice of judicial caning, a punishment the rights group says amounts to torture and violates international law.

headline: John Diebboll, Who Designed Offbeat Pianos, Is Dead at 54
text: John Diebboll, an architect who discovered a second career as an artist when he began designing fantasy pianos that resembled the Brooklyn Bridge, a diner or a Murphy bed, died on Nov. 23 at his home in Beacon, N.Y. He was 54.

headline: Test Yourself | Math, Dec. 6, 2010
text: Test your math skills with today’s question, created by Bobson Wong at Math for America from the Times article “E.P.A. Finds Gas Mileage Improved in ’09 Fleet.”

headline: How Much Do Your Parents Know About Your Life Online?
text: An article this week about Internet bullying describes the difficulties parents face in keeping their children safe online. Not only are they often scrambling to catch up with the technological sophistication of the next generation, but parents today must also wrestle with issues of how much online privacy is appropriate. What do you think? How aware are your parents or guardians of what you do online or via your cellphone? How much should parents in general know about their teenagers’ life online? Why?

headline: Nations Start Talks With Iran on Its Nuclear Program
text: GENEVA  The United States and other world powers pressed Iran on Monday to assuage international fears that it intended to build a nuclear bomb, meeting here in the first direct talks since October 2009 on the country’s nuclear program and its failure to obey United Nations Security Council resolutions to stop enriching uranium.

headline: North Korea Is Sign of Chilled U.S.-China Relations
text: BEIJING President Obama and President Hu Jintao of China talked by telephone on Monday about North Korea, culminating 13 days of effort by the White House to persuade China’s leaders to discuss a crisis that many experts fear could escalate into military action.

headline: Ackman Offers to Finance a Borders Bid for Barnes & Noble
text: 8:42 p.m. | Updated William A. Ackman has never been shy about swooping into situations others would shy away from. But on Monday, his hedge fund proposed one of its boldest offers, homing in on the besieged bookselling industry.

headline: 14-Year-Old’s Water Pipe Blamed for Israeli Fire
text: JERUSALEM  A 14-year-old boy was arrested Monday as the prime suspect in the largest fire in Israel’s history, a four-day inferno that left 42 people dead, devoured 10,000 acres of forest and forced Israel to request international assistance.

headline: John Skelton and Fordham’s Moment in the N.F.L.
text: It has  become so dire, so grim, for the Arizona Cardinals that they are considering starting the rookie John Skelton at quarterback. He came on in relief Sunday in another Arizona loss and was 3 for 6 for 45 yards.

headline: Families Controlling Hermès Move to Fight Off a Takeover
text: PARIS  Hermès International, the French luxury company, is building a defense it says will ensure that Bernard Arnault, the head of LVMH Moët Hennessy Louis Vuitton, cannot take it over.

headline: Matt Ryan: The Comeback Kid for M.V.P.
text: Matt Ryan of the Falcons might not be the best quarterback in the N.F.L. Or the biggest, or the fastest or the strongest. But he might just be the most valuable.

headline: Suicide Blasts Strike Tribal Pakistan
text: PESHAWAR, Pakistan  Two suicide bombers dressed as police officers detontated explosive vests at a meeting of hundreds of people with the top civilian official in the tribal agency of Mohmand, killing more than 40 and wounding at least 100, government officials said.

headline: After HSBC, Madoff Trustee May Pursue Mets’ Owners
text: With just six days left to file suit, Irving H. Picard, the court-appointed trustee seeking assets for victims of Bernard L. Madoff’s global Ponzi scheme, continues to bring legal action against financial firms and other big investors he thinks profited from the fraud.

headline: No Fast Start for Lame Ducks This Week
text: As they await a possible agreement on extending Bush era income tax rates, members of Congress will try to dispose of a few other items this week to clear the lame-duck decks for a tax vote as well as consideration of a spending package and nuclear treaty.

headline: A Crystal Ball for Electricity
text: The major factors dominating the national electricity market are the recession, which has caused the biggest reduction in demand in 60 years, and the low price of natural gas, which has made every other energy source look pricey by comparison.

headline: Bond Prices Rise; Wall Street Ends Mixed
text: Bond prices rose and stock indexes ended flat on Monday after remarks by the Federal Reserve chairman broadcast over the weekend that left open the possibility of expanding the central bank’s bond purchases.

text: The first-round selection of defensive end Jason Pierre-Paul was not a terribly popular pick among Giants fans. For one thing, it was thought, the Giants needed a linebacker.

headline: ‘Social Network’ Makes a Few More Friends
text: On the heels of a “60 Minutes” profile of Mark Zuckerberg, the unblinking C.E.O. of Facebook, “The Social Network” swept the top prizes at the Washington, D.C. Area Film Critics Association awards on Monday. It won best feature, best director (David Fincher) and best adapted screenplay (Aaron Sorkin). “Inception” also scored with four awards, including best original screenplay for Christopher Nolan and the cinematography and best score prizes.

headline: Yassky (It’s Him, Again!) Finally Fades to Black
text: The back seat of a New York City yellow cab may be one of the city’s final redoubts of solitude, but anyone who took a taxi in the last two weeks of November found himself or herself joined by an uninvited guest: David Yassky, the city’s newly installed taxi and limousine commissioner.

headline: A Few Essays That Worked (And a Few That Didn’t)
text: In preparation for a segment on NBC’s “Today” show this morning, I reached out to the admissions offices at the University of Virginia and Occidental College in California for examples of essays that they considered memorable — for good, or ill.

headline: Eric Dinallo Joins Debevoise & Plimpton
text: Eric R. Dinallo, a former New York insurance superintendent who played a role in the rescue of the American International Group, has landed a job in private practice.

headline: E.D.F. Sells Stake in German Utility for $6.2 Billion
text: Baden-Württemberg, the southwestern German state, said on Monday that it would pay 4.67 billion euros ($6.2 billion) for Électricité de France’s 45 percent stake in the local power producer EnBW Energie Baden-Württemberg, with a view to listing the company on the Frankfurt stock exchange.

headline: Updates on Leak of U.S. Cables, Day 9
text: On Monday, The Lede continued to update readers on the leak of American diplomatic cables obtained by WikiLeaks, the whistle-blowers’ Web site. (For an overview of the revelations and reactions so far, see our previous live-blog posts.)

headline: Trade Does Not Equal Jobs
text: One thing I’m hearing, now that all hope of useful fiscal policy is gone, is the idea that trade can be a driver of recovery — that stuff like the South Korea trade agreement can serve as a form of macro policy.

headline: Gay Teenagers Face Harsher Punishments
text: 5:58 p.m. | Updated

headline: ‘Waste Land’ Finds Some Gold
text: Some lingering awards news to start your week. Late on Friday the International Documentary Association gave “Waste Land” its top honors of the year. The film, Lucy Walker’s documentary about how a group of trash pickers in Brazil are transformed by working with the Brazilian artist Vik Muniz, won the best feature award as well as the Pare Lorentz Award. The International Documentary Association, a Los Angeles-based group, last year picked “Anvil! The Story of Anvil,” which was snubbed by the Academy, for its highest prize. “Waste Land” did make the Academy’s short list of documentary contenders, where it will compete with frontrunners like “Waiting for Superman.”

headline: George Clooney in Sudan
text: In just over a month, South Sudan is scheduled to vote on whether to become an independent nation. But it’s no clearer now than it was three years ago that the North will actually allow the referendum to go ahead. There’s still considerable anxiety that the North, determined not to lose the three-quarters of the country’s oil that lies in the South, will find one means or another to block the vote or deny its legitimacy — and that the result will be the world’s worst war in 2011.

headline: The Jets’ Danny Woodhead Problem
text: Would anyone be shocked if Bill Belichick used Danny Woodhead a little more than usual against the Jets?

headline: Google Opens Doors to E-Bookstore
text: The Google e-bookstore is finally open.

headline: Supreme Court Agrees to Hear Wal-Mart Appeal
text: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court on Monday agreed to hear an appeal in the biggest employment discrimination case in the nation’s history, one claiming that Wal-Mart Stores had discriminated against hundreds of thousands of women in pay and promotion. The lawsuit seeks back pay that could amount to billions of dollars.

headline: Porsche: ‘Spectacular’ New Car Planned for Detroit Show Return
text: Porsche has begun the Detroit auto show teasing game early. In an interview with Bloomberg, Hans-Gerd Bode, a Porsche spokesman, said recently, “We’ll have something spectacular to show there. You’ll have to wait and be surprised.”

headline: Steinbrenner and Miller Fall Short of Hall
text: ORLANDO, Fla.  When Pat Gillick left the Yankees’ front office in 1976 to build the expansion Toronto Blue Jays, George Steinbrenner was upset. He did not like a new American League East rival poaching his scouting director.

headline: On Our Radar: Republicans Urge Opening of Arctic Refuge to Drilling
text: In an essay co-authored with Spencer Abraham, energy secretary under President George W. Bush, Fred Upton of Michigan, the leading Republican candidate for chairman of the House Energy and Commerce Committee in next year’s Congress, calls for opening the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge in Alaska to oil drilling, a massive increase in domestic deepwater oil production and a rapid expansion of nuclear power. Yet “oil and nuclear are not the only energy sources we need more of,” the two write. “The current situation demands an ‘all of the above’ strategy — diversifying our energy portfolio and pushing development of our own natural resources. That means not just more oil and nuclear, but more coal, natural gas and renewables. Sooner rather than later.” [Politico]

headline: Overmatched
text: Wolfgang Munchau suggests that we need a German word — ueberfordert — to describe the condition of Europe right now. I think he’s wrong about the lack of an English equivalent; “overmatched” seems fairly close. European leaders, and the European system, just seem not up to dealing with the crisis.

headline: Police Release Video of Queens Livery-Cab Gunman
text: The police released a video Sunday showing the suspect in Friday’s shooting of a livery-cab driver in South Ozone Park, Queens, pulling a gun moments before shooting the driver in an attempted robbery. The one-minute video shows the suspect, a bearded young man in a white hoodie who sat in the passenger seat, appearing to argue with the driver before pulling the gun.

headline: Monday Reading: How to Avoid Airline Fees
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: Quick and Easy Pastas
text: Years ago, I stayed with an Italian friend in Bologna who worked long hours at his job. By the time he got home, he was hungry, so he’d start water boiling and cast about his tiny kitchen to see what he could use for dinner.

headline: ‘Dexter’ Watch: Love Blooms and Blood Spills
text: Before we get to the grisly conclusion of Sunday night’s episode of “Dexter,” a few words on some of the lighter moments. What is more romantic than mapping out your next murder plan with your new girlfriend on the floor of your apartment? Oh, I know, going to an open-air market and picking out a pocketknife for her.

headline: Spaghetti With Walnuts and Anchovies
text: This is a pared-down version of a recipe that I came across in Nancy Jenkins’s informative book on Southern Italian food, “Cucina del Sole.” The dish is traditionally part of a meatless Christmas Eve dinner. If you can find freshly harvested walnuts, they’ll make this pasta even better.

headline: Pasta With Fresh Herbs, Lemon and Peas
text: If you don’t grow your own herbs, I suggest that you buy a bunch of parsley along with basil or chives to keep on hand in your refrigerator. The herbs will keep for a week if properly stored.

headline: Pasta With Tomatoes and Beans
text: This pasta is one reason I always keep a few cans of tomatoes and cannellinis in my pantry. Beans contribute protein to this pasta, which makes a great vegan dish if you serve it without the cheese.

headline: Beijing: Resized Museum Breaks Ground
text: BEIJING  Construction began last Thursday on a museum that has been the centerpiece of a controversial plan to raze and rebuild a large swath of ancient alleyways in the heart of Beijing, according to a report on Monday in China Daily, an English-language newspaper.

headline: Throwing It (Away) Like Never Before
text: For the first time in his N.F.L. career, Peyton Manning has thrown 11 interceptions in a three-game span. He has thrown four interceptions in back-to-back games, another first.

headline: Look Who Wants to Cap Hedge Fund Pay
text: Add a new, and unexpected, voice to the chorus of those calling for more moderate compensation for hedge funds: the chairman of a hedge fund industry group.

headline: Pasta With Tomatoes, Capers, Olives and Breadcrumbs
text: Bread crumbs, crisped in olive oil with garlic, make a flavorful addition to just about any pasta. Make your own bread crumbs if you’ve got bread that’s drying out, and keep them in the freezer.

headline: The Peninsula’s New Fleet: the Mini Cooper
text: The Peninsula Hotels are known for their upscale perks, like the fleet of Rolls-Royces that its Hong Kong flagship uses to ferry its guests to meetings and to the airport. In New York and Chicago, however, the hotel has opted for an amenity that’s more sporty than glam: chauffeur-driven Mini Coopers.

headline: Vain Glorious | Bond No. 9’s Dreamy New Bottle
text: What: Bond No. 9’s Chandelier Dreaming

headline: Meta Alert: Cartoon Comments on Cartoon Feud Between ‘Simpsons’ and Fox News
text: Though ArtsBeat has previously devoted bandwidth to the friendly-ish sibling rivalry between “The Simpsons” and Fox News, no story is truly complete until it’s been commented on by Next Media, the Hong Kong- and Taiwan-based media company that brings to life American pop-culture and celebrity stories in comical (and occasionally baffling) computer-generated cartoons. In this latest effort, Next Media recaps the recent feud between the two warring arms of the News Corporation empire, using 3-D renderings of Bill O’Reilly, Rupert Murdoch and what it thinks the “Simpsons” writers look like. (Watch for the subtle metaphor as one of them jumps over a shark.)

headline: For Once, a Bipartisan Boost for Obama
text: 1:52 p.m. | Updated In an era of deep partisan polarization, President Obama will open his mailbox on Monday to find at least one letter offering bipartisan support — and bipartisan advice. The letter is from six senators, three from each caucus; they praise Mr. Obama for his tough stance on Iran and urge him not to let up.

headline: Quadrangle Looks to Life After Rattner
text: 2:34 p.m. | Updated Quadrangle Group, the embattled private equity firm co-founded by the financier Steven L. Rattner, on Monday announced new leadership and said it would remain independent.

headline: The Week Ahead in Drug Industry News
text: Speculation about the real reasons behind the unexpected resignation Sunday of Pfizer’s chief executive and chairman, Jeffrey B. Kindler, is sure to fuel water-cooler conversations across the drug industry this week.

headline: After Werth Deal, How Much Will It Take to Sign Crawford or Lee?
text: ORLANDO, Fla. — Now that Brian Cashman has rappelled down a 21-floor building and lived to talk about it, a dangerous precedent has been set. Imagine him descending the exterior of the Walt Disney World Dolphin Hotel — a mere 17 stories — and swooping into the room of Darek Braunecker, the agent for Cliff Lee, to discuss a contract. Of course, such unconventional (and fanciful) tactics will not lure Lee to the Bronx – and away from the hovering Texas Rangers; money, and lots of it, will.

headline: ‘Tummy Time’ for Babies
text: When my first son was born in 1991, the rule was that he should never, ever sleep on his back. Babies aspirate that way, the pediatrician warned.

headline: The Case of the Contagious Stuttering
text: To the surprise of absolutely no one, “The King’s Speech,” an early Oscar favorite, swept the British Independent Film Awards last night, winning best film, best screenplay and a host of acting awards (honors went to Colin Firth, Helena Bonham Carter and Geoffrey Rush). A film about a monarch who has trouble communicating, “The King’s Speech” may be the most British movie ever made. And Mr. Firth, who plays the titular character, a king overcoming a stutter, may be the most British performer.

headline: Sharing the Dakota With John Lennon
text: Long before its history was marked by the sound of bullets, thousands of fragrant flowers and crowds grievously singing “Imagine,” the Dakota was just another historic Manhattan co-op where among its famous inhabitants lived a musician named John Lennon.

headline: Off the Couch, Into the Multiplexes: Irrfan Khan on His New Big-Screen Roles
text: Viewers going through withdrawal as time runs out on Sunil, the patient on HBO’s “In Treatment” played by the Indian actor Irrfan Khan, can breathe easier knowing there will eventually be an end to their pain. (Sunil’s final session will be shown on Monday night at 9:30.) Mr. Khan, whose interpretation of a grieving Bengali widower won critical accolades, has just been cast in two high-profile film projects: Marc Webb’s reboot of the “Spider-Man” franchise and Ang Lee’s adaptation of “Life of Pi.” Both films are to be released in 2012.

headline: Booksellers’ Shares Jump on Ackman Deal Overture
text: Normally, when one company offers to buy another, shares in the would-be acquirer fall while those in its target rise. That was not the case with the Borders Group and Barnes & Noble on Monday.

headline: Asked & Answered | Hany Armanious
text: The sculptor Hany Armanious will represent Australia at next year’s Venice Biennale. A native Egyptian who lives and works in Sydney, Armanious is known for his methodically messy installations that game the eye as well as the mind with circular materialities and metaphors. His work (shown above) at the Foxy Production booth was one of the standouts in the Art Positions section of the Art Basel Miami Beach fair, for which galleries present a statement exhibition made by one artist.

headline: Icahn Takes to Web in Hostile Bid for Lions Gate
text: Carl C. Icahn has a new forum for his activism: the Web.

headline: Broken Nose Enters Steelers-Ravens Rivalry
text: Pretty much everything you need to know about the N.F.L. this season can be summed up by looking at Ben Roethlisberger’s nose.

headline: Justices to Hear Appeal in Power Plant Emissions Case
text: WASHINGTON (Reuters)  The Supreme Court said on Monday that it would hear an appeal by four big coal-burning utilities of a ruling that a group of states and New York City could proceed with a lawsuit seeking to reduce the carbon dioxide emissions of the power companies.

headline: Numberplay: How Does Newton’s Cradle Work?
text: Adam Bowman How does a Newton’s Cradle work?

headline: Would Your Business Use Groupon Again?
text: As you may have noticed, we’ve been writing about Groupon a lot lately. MP Mueller did a post on the experiences of a high-end restaurant in Austin, Tex., and offered some tips. I suggested how you might do the math to assess your Groupon deal (and a smart reader pointed out that I did not fully account for the loss of revenue if your regular customers buy Groupon coupons). In fact, we got lots of smart comments (especially here and here). We also ran several articles when it looked as if Google was going to buy Groupon and another reporting that the founders and owners of Groupon had decided to turn down Google’s $6 billion offer.

headline:
Japan Wars on U.S. and Britain; Makes
Sudden Attack On Hawaii; Heavy Fighting
At Sea Reported
text: Washington, Monday, Dec. 8.--Sudden and unexpected attacks on Pearl Harbor, Honolulu, and other United States possessions in the Pacific early yesterday by the Japanese air force and navy plunged the United States and Japan into active war.

headline: Author of 'Lost Lady' Won the Pulitzer Prize in 1922 for Writing 'One of Ours'
text: Willa Sibert Cather, noted American novelist, died at 4:30 P.M. yesterday in her home at 570 Park Avenue. After Miss Cather's death a secretary, who was with her at the time, was too upset to talk about it. It was reported that death was due to a cerebral hemorrhage. The author was 70 years old in December.

headline: Sammy Davis Jr. Dies at 64; Top Showman Broke Barriers
text: Sammy Davis Jr., a versatile and dynamic singer, dancer and actor who overcame extraordinary obstacles to become a leading American entertainer, died of throat cancer yesterday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 64 years old and had been in deteriorating health since his release from Cedar-Sinai Medical Center on March 13.

headline:
U.S. DECLARES WAR, PACIFIC BATTLE
WIDENS
text: Washington, Dec. 8.--The United States today formally declared war on Japan. Congress, with only one dissenting vote, approved the resolution in the record time of 33 minutes after President Roosevelt denounced Japanese aggression in ringing tones. He personally delivered his message to a joint session of the Senate and House. At 4:10 P. M. he affixed his signature to the resolution.

headline: Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., a Democratic Power in the House for Decades, Dies at 81
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 6  Democrats and Republicans today bade a warm farewell to Thomas P. (Tip) O'Neill Jr., the gregarious and irrepressibly liberal Bostonian who symbolized the Democratic Party through much of the 1980's as Speaker of the House.

headline:
Charles and Diana Are Separating
'Amicably'
text: LONDON, Dec. 9 -- Buckingham Palace wrote the unhappy ending today to a storybook marriage gone badly wrong, a seven-sentence-long announcement that Charles, the Prince of Wales and heir to the British throne, and Diana, the Princess of Wales, had agreed to separate after 11 years as husband and wife.

headline:
Human Rights Declaration Adopted by U. N.
Assembly
text: Paris, Dec, 10--A universal Declaration on Human Rights nearly three years in preparation, was adopted late tonight by the United Nations General Assembly. The vote was 48 to 0 with the Soviet bloc, Saudi Arabia and the Union of South Africa abstaining.

headline: Dr. Melvil Dewey Dead In Florida
text: LAKE PLACID, Fla., Dec. 26 (AP)--Dr. Melvil Dewey, internationally known educator, inventor of the decimal classification system used in libraries, and spelling reform advocate, died here today of a cerebral hemorrhage. He celebrated his eightieth birthday on Dec. 10.

headline:
U.S. NOW AT WAR WITH GERMANY AND
ITALY; JAPANESE CHECKED IN ALL
LAND FIGHTING; 3 OF THEIR SHIPS
SUNK, 2D BATTLESHIP HIT
text: Washington, Dec. 11 --The United States declared war today on Germany and Italy, Japan's Axis partners. This nation acted swiftly after Germany formally declared war on us and Italy followed the German lead. Thus, President Roosevelt told Congress in his message, the long-known and the long-expected has taken place.

headline: La Guardia Is Dead; City Pays Homage To 3-Time Mayor
text: Fiorello H. La Guardia died in his sleep at 7:22 A.M. yesterday. He was 64 years old. At the bedside were his wife, the former Marie Fisher, who had been his secretary while he was in Congress; their adopted children, Jean, 18 years old, and Eric, 15, and Mrs. La Guardia's sister, Miss Helen Fisher.

headline: Prokhorov as Ivan Drago
text: The same guys who brought you “Like a Bosh” have struck again, this time pitting James L. Dolan, the chairman of Madison Square Garden, which owns the Knicks, against Mikhail D. Prokhorov, the owner of the Nets, in “Battle of the Boroughs.”

headline: Formula One May Switch to Turbo 4-Cylinder for 2013, Says Report
text: The chatter over the possibility that Formula One would adopt turbocharged 4-cylinder engines for 2013 reached its height Monday, when BBC Sport reported that a Ferrari spokesman said he would be “surprised” if the switch from 2.4-liter V-8s was not announced at a meeting of the sport’s governing body on Friday.

headline: Banks May Face Rating Cuts, Analyst Says
text: One of Wall Street’s most influential securities analysts is telling investors to brace themselves: some of the nation’s biggest banks could be on the cusp of a credit rating downgrade.

headline: How They Got Neil Patrick Harris to Host the Video Game Awards: We Have No Idea
text: As Neil Patrick Harris told The New York Times in a 2009 interview, ”You go from the Tonys to the Emmys, and there’s only one big one left. The Telemundo awards.”

headline: A Subway Trip Back in Time
text: Passengers waiting on the downtown F train platform at the Broadway-Lafayette station on Sunday were stunned when the train approached. Instead of the silver bullet that they expected, an ancient-looking, olive-drab metal box lumbered into the station. When it ground to a halt and the doors opened, men dressed in orange reflective vests hopped out to announce that this was the F train, making all local stops.

text: Among highly educated women who take time off from their careers to raise their children, women with M.B.A.’s suffer the largest percentage “mommy penalty,” while those with medical degrees suffer the lowest proportionate loss, with female Ph.D.’s and lawyers falling somewhere in between.

headline: Marco Brambilla’s ‘Evolution (Megaplex)’
text: Anyone who’s ever taken the elevator at the Standard Hotel in New York will be familiar with the work of the artist Marco Brambilla. His kaleidoscopic video piece “Civilization” — a film collage loosely depicting the journey from purgatory to celestial heights — has been wowing hotel guests since 2009. Following a recent collaboration with Kanye West for his video “Power,” Brambilla has now taken his manic motion picture collageing to a new level and has produced arguably the first 3D video art piece ever. “Evolution (Megaplex)” is a three-minute-long three-dimensional firework of images, scenes, and clips culled from an archive of over a thousand movies, ranging from Hollywood blockbusters (“E.T.”, “Mad Max”, “Star Wars”) to cult classics (“Idiocracy,” “Zardoz,” “Salo”) — all set to a score of a bombastic rendition of Prokofiev’s “Romeo and Juliet.” During the poolside screening at the Standard Spa Hotel in Miami last Friday, guests including Jeffrey Deitch, Bob Colacello, Jefferson Hack, Michael Stipe and Cecilia Dean sported especially designed Armani Exchange 3-D glasses and turned the event into a quiz of sorts, trying to identify different bits and pieces. (“Was that Klaus Kinski in a loincloth, or a nubile Sting? And what movie was the woman riding a giant phallus taken from?”)
