text: Q: (Reader)

headline: Accounts and People of Note in the Ad Industry
text: Sandra Alfaro joined Kirshenbaum Bond Senecal & Partners, New York, part of MDC Partners, in a new post, general manager for multicultural.

headline: Cabrito to Close, as a New Fatty Looms
text: Cabrito, the pink-goat-decorated Mexican outlier in Zakary Pelaccio’s Fatty Crew family of vaguely southeast Asian restaurants, which opened on Carmine Street in 2008 and received one star from Frank Bruni of The New York Times in 2009, is to close by Dec. 31.

headline: Hey, Syrah Sister: Rock Band Offers Wine Club to Fans
text: Remember how Orson Welles, hawking for Paul Masson, would solemnly intone, “We will sell no wine before its time”? Now, the “we” selling wine extends from vintners to clubs, bearing brand names like USA Today, Sunset magazine, The New York Times, Zagat, The Wall Street Journal and Harry & David.

headline: Sad Day for ‘Terriers,’ but ‘Dexter’ Lives On to Kill Again
text: It’s either a terrible day or a great day to be the creator of a cult cable-television series. FX announced on Monday that it would not be ordering a second season of “Terriers,” its series about a former detective (played by Donal Logue) and an ex-burglar (Michael Raymond-James) trying to make it as private investigators in San Diego. The show, created by Ted Griffin, the “Ocean’s Eleven” screenwriter, and whose producers included Shawn Ryan, the creator of “The Shield,” was well reviewed at its debut in September. Ginia Bellafante in The New York Times  called it “a welcome love child, one we are eager to embrace rather than put up for adoption.” But it never seemed to reach a critical mass of viewers, and while we don’t want to say its title was to blame, we will point out that Mr. Ryan recently renamed another new cop drama he is preparing, changing its title from “Ride-Along” to “The Chicago Code.”

headline: In Their 30s, in the Throes of a ‘Big Chill’
text: Stop me if you’ve heard this one: a group of college friends in New York, now in their 30s but still best buddies and confidants. ... What’s that you say? Stop?

headline: Gates Skeptical of ‘Don’t Ask , Don’t Tell’ Repeal This Year
text: MUSCAT, Oman  Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates cast doubt Monday that the Senate would vote before the end of the year to allow gay men and women to serve openly in the armed forces.

headline: Remembering the Night John Lennon Was Shot
text: We filed out of the Spectrum in Philadelphia that warm December night, my high school buddies Jim, John, Glenn and I, exhausted and exhilarated, echoes of “Santa Claus is Coming to Town” ringing in our heads. Bruce Springsteen had rocked us righteously, and all was right with the world.

headline: WikiLeaks Founder Warns About More Dispatches
text: WASHINGTON  Julian Assange, the beleaguered founder of the anti-secrecy group WikiLeaks, has threatened to release many more confidential diplomatic cables if legal action is taken against him or his organization. Mr. Assange’s threat poses a problem for the Obama administration as it explores ways to prosecute Mr. Assange or the group.

headline: In the N.F.C. West, the Race Is as Ugly as It Is Close
text: The N.F.L. showcased the best side of parity this weekend. Ravens-Steelers? Jets-Patriots? Those are probably the best four teams in football now. But in the last two weeks of the season, the N.F.L. will avert its eyes from the flip side: consecutive division games for the Rams, including the season finale with the Seahawks, to be played, just like those others this weekend, with the division title hanging in the balance.

headline: Leaked Cable Lists Sensitive Sites
text: WASHINGTON  A State Department cable released by WikiLeaks provides a compendium of sites around the world  from hydroelectric dams in Canada to vaccine producers in Denmark  that, if lost, might “critically impact” public health or the national security of the United States.

headline: Afghanistan Softens Ban on Private Security Firms
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  The Afghan government appeared Monday to edge away from plans to ban all private security companies, announcing modifications that would allow most licensed firms to continue their work, but leaving important details in doubt, company representatives and Western officials said.

headline: Market Watch | Bidding on Luxury
text: Heritage Auctions, better known for selling collectible coins and vintage comic books, is exploring new and perhaps more feminine ground. This month the company introduces its latest category: luxury accessories.

headline: ‘Boardwalk Empire’ Builds on Strong Performances
text: If you missed the season finale of “Boardwalk Empire” on Sunday night, chances are you missed the whole season, in which case you are hereby advised to sequester yourself for part of the holiday season and catch up via HBO on Demand. The visual splendors of “Boardwalk Empire” have been exhaustively noted — the cinematography; the grand and meticulously constructed sets; the detailed Prohibition-era suits made by Martin Greenfield Clothiers, the renowned Brooklyn tailoring outfit; and so on — but the series has also easily delivered the best television performances of the year. Steve Buscemi (as the Republican Party boss Nucky Thompson), Kelly Macdonald (as a young Irish widow, Margaret Schroeder, whose moral relativism is leaning in a Carmela Soprano direction) and Michael Pitt (as the Oedipally afflicted young gangster Jimmy Darmody) all merit recognition beyond what the devalued Emmys have to offer.

headline: Grisly Hand Injury Interrupts Modano’s Season
text: It’s good that veteran Detroit Red Wings forward Mike Modano wasn’t considering a post-hockey career as a concert pianist. Or as a thumb-wrestler.

headline: Spenders Become Savers in Race for Key House Post
text: WASHINGTON  The thick binder is dominated by a drawing of a chubby Uncle Sam, shirt buttons straining against his girth, with a fleshy hand open and outstretched.

headline: Spousal Chatter and Bankruptcy Terror
text: Carl Richards is a certified financial planner in Park City, Utah. His sketches are archived here on the Bucks blog, and other drawings are available on his personal Web site, BehaviorGap.com.

headline: Obama Calls for New ‘Sputnik Moment’
text: WINSTON-SALEM, N.C. – President Obama called for another “Sputnik moment” on Monday by having the nation invest more in education and science, previewing a theme that is likely to be part of his agenda and his budget for the second half of his term.

text: Deborah Voigt and Marcello Giordani in an excerpt from the production at the Metropolitan Opera. (Video courtesy of the Met)

headline: The Yeltsin Effect
text: Term used to liken the increasing power of Taiwan’s provincial leaders to that of Boris Yeltsin in 1991.

text: Links from around the Web.

headline: Winfrey Chooses Two Dickens Novels for Book Club
text: For her latest book club selection Oprah Winfrey decided to go “old school,” she said on Monday. Ms. Winfrey has selected two Charles Dickens novels, “A Tale of Two Cities” and “Great Expectations,” both announced on her show on Monday, both books that she had never read before. They could be two of the last selected for the Oprah Book Club before her show goes off the air next year.

headline: D.N.R. by Another Name
text: Let’s imagine an end-of-life scenario. Your ailing and elderly parent has been admitted to the hospital yet again with a condition she’s not going to recover from. The medical team asks what they should do if her heart stops. She’s always said she didn’t want to die “hooked up to a bunch of machines,” but you’ve never really explored the details. Besides, though she has a terminal illness, no one has yet mentioned the d-word.

headline: Miller Says Hall Is ‘Trying to Rewrite History’
text: Marvin Miller fell one vote short of election to the National Baseball Hall of Fame on Sunday  the closest of five losing votes that began in 2003  and he still believes he will never be enshrined.

headline: Germany Reluctant to Expand European Bailout Fund
text: BRUSSELS  Despite rising pressure for new measures to draw a line under the debt crisis, Germany moved Monday to close off debate on an increase to a 750-billion-euro bailout fund, or the more radical step of issuing common euro zone bonds.

headline: Two Broadway Shows On the Move
text: In a confluence of financial interests and theater availability on Broadway, two commercially popular rock ‘n roll musicals — the metal/hair band love story “Rock of Ages” and the Beatles tribute show “Rain” — will change theaters in early 2011 to continue their runs, the producers of both shows said on Monday. The moves, which are relatively rare for Broadway, will allow “Rain” to stay open, while “Rock of Ages” will be able to lower its weekly running costs (and potentially increase its profit margin) by running in a smaller Broadway house.

headline: Animation Domination Contest Narrows
text: The Oscars for the world of animation, the Annies, announced the nominees for this year’s top prize on Monday, and there were no surprises to be had. “Toy Story 3,” “How to Train Your Dragon,” “Tangled,” “The Illusionist,” and “Despicable Me” received nods for best animated feature. The list of finalists, from the International Animated Film Society, is sure to have some overlap with the little gold man race, especially this year, when the Academy can nominate only three films (out of 15 submitted for eligibility). “Toy Story 3″ is a lock, of course, but may also wind up in the best picture category, as “Up” did last year. “Tangled” performed well at the box office against stiff competition, which could help its chances. “How to Train Your Dragon” might be a good bet for the final spot, but don’t double-down yet. Last year, Annie voters gave a nomination to the little-seen Irish film “The Secret of Kells,” and it went on to secure an Oscar slot. Can the same happen for the “Despicable Me” or “The Illusionist” this year? The Bagger will pay close attention to the cartoon winnings to find out.

headline: Tivoli Audio Goes Bricks and Mortar
text: Steve Jobs started with one Apple Store in California, which became a chain that grew to hundreds of shops worldwide. Tom DeVesto says he has no such intention.

text: Yasmine Mousa is an Iraqi-Canadian journalist who works for The New York Times in Baghdad.

headline: Netflix Streaming: Convenience or Quality?

headline: Big, Bold Snapshots of New York
text: Just when you thought you’d seen enough purportedly iconic photos of New York City, our pals at Lens took a stroll this morning through the pages of a new coffee-table book whose editor said he aimed to “unveil hidden gems that would excite even the most jaded New Yorkers and then print them big and bold.” The editor, Reuel Golden, succeeded, David Dunlap writes on Lens in the introduction to an interview with Mr. Golden. The book, “New York, Portrait of a City,” Mr. Dunlap found, “seems to burst with fresh imagery” and little-known masterpieces. Check it out on Lens. »

headline: Red Sox Finally Get the First Baseman on Their List
text: ORLANDO, Fla. — Two years ago, when San Diego Padres General Manager Jed Hoyer was an assistant to Theo Epstein, the general manager of the Red Sox, he experienced visceral disappointment when Mark Teixeira, then a free agent, spurned Boston’s offer at the last moment and instead signed with the Yankees, a defining moment in the recent histories of both teams.

headline: The Saturday Crossword Puzzle
text: From Monday to Saturday, crossword puzzles in The New York Times get harder as the week progresses. Daniel Feyer, a crossword puzzle champion, sets pencil to paper on a recent Saturday puzzle.

headline: Uncertainty Rules in the N.B.A. Player Market
text: Next week, players who signed contracts this summer will turn trade eligible, bringing in a number of new candidates for teams to chat about and yes, more names and numbers to be used by any team trying to pry Carmelo Anthony away from the Denver Nuggets.

headline: We Made It Ourselves | Volunteer Park Cafe Sundries
text: When her friend Josh‘s bacon jam started appearing on grocery shelves in Seattle, Ericka Burke thought, “That’s not fair. What can I make?” And then it came to her: “Mac-n-cheese. I’ve never seen a nice, glass-bottled sauce.” The resulting sauce puts anything in a box to shame — most homemade varieties, too. But that isn’t the only good to come out of the kitchen at the city’s Volunteer Park Cafe. If you’re going to place an order, a care package is the move here.

headline: Jacques Steinberg on Today
text: Jacques Steinberg, education correspondent for the Times, appears on the Today show to discuss what works in a college essay.

headline: Bondurant Driving School Opens Track to Paralyzed Drivers
text: CHANDLER, Ariz. – As a professional motorcycle racer and then as a police officer, Rob Martin knew life and limb were in jeopardy every day — and they were. Martin crashed at 150 miles an hour on the track and was shot at while on duty.

headline: ‘The Life and Opinions of Maf the Dog and of His Friend Marilyn Monroe’
text: My story really begins at Charleston, a perfect haunt of light and invention that stands in the English countryside. It was warm that summer and the mornings went far into the afternoon, when the best of the garden would come into the house, the flowers arranged in pots and given new life by Vanessa in her fertile hours. She was always there with her oils and her eyes, the light falling through the glass ceiling to inflame the possibility of something new. She had good days and bad days. On good days she set out her brushes and knew the time was right for work when all her memories became like an aspect of sleep.

headline: Marilyn, Dostoyevsky and Me, Her Pup
text: Brian the dog here. You know, the talking dog from “Family Guy”: best-selling author, actor, television writer, movie director, song-and-dance ace, civil rights crusader and, yes, animal companion. Because of my sterling literary credentials, I’ve been asked to review this British pooch’s new memoir: “The Life and Opinions of Maf the Dog and of His Friend Marilyn Monroe,” ghosted by this novelist guy Andrew O’Hagan.

headline: Analysts Question Whether E.C.B. Efforts Will Succeed in Keeping Bond Market in Line

But the intervention was smaller than expected and analysts were questioning whether it would be enough to stop investors from widespread selling of the government debt of Ireland and other members of the euro zone.

headline: The Inspiration Found in Silence and Brando
text: Twice a year, Movement Research  an organization integral to the development of experimental dance in New York City and beyond  hosts a festival programmed by guest artists. For the fall installment, masterminded by John Jesurun, a playwright, director and designer, and Jon Kinzel, a choreographer, performer and visual artist, the idea is to explore an increasingly multidisciplinary landscape. Their name for such a place is “Truly Madly Deeply,” though not for the Anthony Minghella film; instead, as they explain in a statement, they are drawn to a “deep group of truly mad artists.”

headline: Voyage Across Centuries, With Bach as Anchor

But he had thorough conservatory training and won prizes in major international competitions. He has explored world music, arranging and composing some 40 genre-blending works for the Kronos Quartet. His song cycle “Piano Lessons” was given its American premiere this season by Dawn Upshaw and Emanuel Ax at Carnegie Hall.

headline: Just Looking | ‘Aware: Art Fashion Identity’
text: When is a dress not just a dress? Certainly when it’s part of “Aware: Art Fashion Identity,” currently on view at London’s Royal Academy. The third in a series of rapidly organized exhibitions on contemporary culture, “Aware” takes as its subject the mutable nature of sartorial identity. “It’s really about how we use clothing to say who we are, what tribe we belong to and what we believe in,” says Kathleen Soriano, the museum’s director of exhibitions, who was considering the proposal for the show, put forward by the artist Lucy Orta and the independent curator Gabi Scardi, when news reached her of the death of Alexander McQueen. “When he died, it brought into focus the enormous contribution that he’d made, not just to fashion but also to art, and how close the two can be,” Soriano explained.

headline: A Hanukkah Miracle, Set to Music

headline: Service Members Face New Threat: Identity Theft
text: The government warns Americans to closely guard their Social Security numbers. But it has done a poor job of protecting those same numbers for millions of people: the nation’s soldiers, sailors, airmen and Marines.

headline: On a Hunt for What Makes Gamers Keep Gaming
text: By the age of 21, the typical American has spent 10,000 hours playing computer games, and endured a smaller but much drearier chunk of time listening to sermons about this sinful habit. Why, the experts wail, are so many people wasting their lives solving meaningless puzzles in virtual worlds?

headline: Adventurously Bashing Borgias Amid the Clamor of Old Rome
text: Perched like a ballet dancer atop the giant, majestic flagpole rising from the pinnacle of Castel Sant’ Angelo, I survey the seven hills of the ancient city rolling to the horizon before me. In the distance below, beyond streets teeming with merchants and thieves, beggars and courtesans, I spy the Colosseum and the Pantheon. Directly beneath me, in the dungeons of the debased Rodrigo Borgia (also known as Pope Alexander VI), the Countess of Forli, Caterina Sforza, languishes as I plot her rescue.

headline: 21 Bodies Found in Colombia Mudslide

headline: Business Travelers Adapt to Airline Fees and Perks
text: AT the airline departure lounge, I sometimes feel as if I’m some rube from the sticks, lined up with the hopeless mob outside a hot Hollywood nightclub. The red rope does not open for me or any of the others. I am not on the List because, like many business travelers, I have let my elite status lapse on various airlines since it is no longer worth the effort.

text: 5:41 p.m. | Updated  Elizabeth Edwards’s long battle with cancer has intensified, with the disease spreading to her liver and doctors advising against additional medical treatment, two family friends said Monday.

headline: Nurture, After Nature Turns Ugly
text: In “Baby Universe: A Puppet Odyssey,” Earth is a beat-up old floozy who wistfully recalls her more verdant, hydrated days: “So much life. I was pretty then.” Mostly, however, she’s just tired and jaded: “I don’t care about my people. I’ve been trying to kill them for years.”

headline: Flower Power | Liya Kebede as Waris Dirie
text: In “Desert Flower,” the catwalk fixture and “Gifted” subject Liya Kebede stands in for the Somali-born model Waris Dirie. A victim of female genital mutilation, the 13-year-old Dirie escaped an arranged marriage in Somalia and made it to London in the 1980s, where she worked at McDonald’s before being discovered by Terence Donovan. Kebede, 32, grew up in Ethiopia and was discovered by a filmmaker at the French lycée in Addis Ababa. In a recent interview, she was quick to draw a distinction between her own life story and Dirie’s. “On the surface we have parallels,” she said, before explaining how different life seemed in Djibouti, a neighboring country to Somalia, where parts of the film were shot. “This is where she came from. There’s nothing there, there’s no water, there’s nothing. And being in that environment was a new thing for me, and then trying to understand how you go from that to become this incredible woman — [Dirie] was never really a victim of her circumstances.”

headline: Maker of ‘Shoah’ Stresses Its Lasting Value
text: Even at 85, Claude Lanzmann is not one to rest on his laurels or shirk a controversy. A quarter of a century after his documentary “Shoah” transformed the way the world regarded the Holocaust, the film is about to be re-released in the United States — an event he welcomes as long overdue.

headline: Scottish Artist Wins Turner Prize for a Recording
text: Susan Philipsz, a 45-year-old Scottish artist, has won this year’s Turner Prize, The Guardian reported. She is the first artist to win for a sound work: she recorded herself singing a 16th-century Scottish lament under three bridges in Glasgow. The prize, established in 1984 by the Tate in London, goes to a British artist under age 50 and comes with about $39,000. Ms. Philipsz beat out Dexter Dalwood, known for his contemporary take on traditional history paintings; Angela de la Cruz, a painter and sculptor nominated for her installation “After,” at the Camden Arts Center in London; and the Otolith Group, consisting of the London artists Anjalika Sagar and Kodwo Eshun, who make documentary films for a series of exhibitions called “A Long Time Between Suns.” (Finalists each receive about $7,800.) Ms. Philipsz is only the fourth woman to win the award, after Rachel Whiteread, Gillian Wearing and Tomma Abts. In a statement the judges said they “admired the way in which her work provokes both intellectual and instinctive responses and reflects a series of decisions about the relationship between sound and sight” and that she “draws on the immersive properties of sound and uses her own voice to create powerful sculptural experiences.”

headline: New Director for State Theater in New Brunswick

Jones, the former executive director of the Paper Mill Playhouse in Millburn, N.J., has been appointed president and chief executive of the State Theater in New Brunswick, N.J., the theater announced last week.“It’s the first job I’ve had in 20 years where I haven’t had to do a financial rescue,” Mr. Jones said in an interview. “I can go in and focus on building the programs.”

headline: Holiday Wish List | Bruce Pask
text: T’s men’s fashion director, Bruce Pask, is craving the finer things in life this holiday season. Never mind dapper suits and polished loafers — it’s all about cozying around a Roy Hardin-designed fire pit with a cheeky bottle of Charles Smith wine and the new volume of Christopher Isherwood’s diaries, “The Sixties.” “If we’re dreaming here, I would really love to hopscotch from one Aman resort to another in the Far East,” Pask says. “I would start at Amansara in Cambodia, then head to Amanpuri in Thailand, then the Amandari in Indonesia. Three are fine, I don’t want to be too greedy.”

headline: City Opera to Perform Rufus Wainwright Work
text: An opera by the singer-songwriter Rufus Wainwright is coming to Lincoln Center  just not the Metropolitan Opera, for which it was originally conceived. Instead New York City Opera said on Monday that the company would produce it sometime next season. The Met and Lincoln Center Theater originally commissioned the work, “Prima Donna.” But the Met declined to present it because Mr. Wainwright insisted on keeping the libretto in French. The opera is about a retired soprano dealing with her past. It had its first performance in July 2009 at the Manchester International Festival in England and was also put on at Sadler’s Wells in London and the Luminato Festival in Toronto. Janis Kelly, above, will sing the main role, and Tim Albery will direct, a publicist for Mr. Wainwright said.

headline: Brewers Send Message by Acquiring Marcum
text: ORLANDO, Fla. – I went to Milwaukee for two nights this past season, midweek games in May against the Astros. I hadn’t been there in nine years, and what struck me was how much the fans cared about a team that was not very good. They just really seemed to love their guys, and they proved it at the gate: the small-market Brewers drew 2.77 million fans, after topping three million in 2008 and 2009.

headline: Renewable Fuels
text: To the Editor:

headline: Still Counting on the Power of Television
text: TV or not TV? On Madison Avenue next year, leading forecasters say, that is not likely to be the question.

headline: A Blessing of the Burger to End a Restaurant Jinx
text: The three holy men made their pilgrimages to Chelsea, braving snow and frigid winds, from as far away as New Jersey and the Bronx.

headline: Obama Urges China to Check North Koreans
text: WASHINGTON  In a sign of mounting tension between the United States and China over North Korea, President Obama telephoned President Hu Jintao and warned that China was emboldening its unruly neighbor by not publicly challenging its behavior, a senior administration official said Monday.

headline: How Campaigns Should Be Financed
text: To the Editor:

headline: Lottery Numbers
U.S. Arrests Online Seller Who Scared Customers
text: Federal law enforcement agents on Monday arrested a Brooklyn Internet merchant who mistreated customers because he thought their online complaints raised the profile of his business in Google searches.

headline: Don Meredith, Cowboys Quarterback and Cosell’s Broadcast Foil, Dies at 72
text: Don Meredith, a former star quarterback for the Dallas Cowboys who helped change the perception of professional football with the easy Texas charm and provocative wit he brought to its first prime-time telecasts on Monday nights, died on Sunday in Santa Fe, N.M. He was 72.

headline: Charter School Is Among 12 Chosen to Close
text: The Ross Global Academy opened five years ago on a raft of promises, like an innovative curriculum that would spiral through different historical eras, small class sizes, yoga, Mandarin lessons, an extended day and organic food prepared by a chef.

headline: Ireland Financial Crisis Wounds Country’s Psyche
text: DUBLIN  The pained debate over a $112 billion international rescue package for Ireland will come to a crunch on Tuesday when a politically weakened Prime Minister Brian Cowen goes to Parliament seeking approval for the harshest austerity program of any government in Europe. But beyond the financial pain, the bitterest pill for the Irish may be the dawning realization that the country’s finances could fall under a foreign yoke for the next 20 or 30 years.

headline: Tracing the Spark of Creative Problem-Solving
text: The puzzles look easy, and mostly they are. Given three words  “trip,” “house” and “goal,” for example  find a fourth that will complete a compound word with each. A minute or so of mental trolling (housekeeper, goalkeeper, trip?) is all it usually takes.

headline: Minnesota Says Discover Cardholders Were Deceived on Financial Products
text: The Minnesota attorney general filed a lawsuit on Monday accusing Discover Financial Services of tricking consumers into buying optional products that would protect them from fraud and financial hardship.

headline: Bombers in Pakistan Strike Anti-Taliban Conference
text: PESHAWAR, Pakistan  Two suicide bombers dressed as police officers detonated explosive vests at a meeting of hundreds of people with the top civilian official in the tribal agency of Mohmand, killing more than 40 and wounding at least 100, government officials said.

headline: Iran’s Divorce Rate Stirs Fears of Society in Crisis
text: TEHRAN  The wedding nearly 1,400 years ago of Imam Ali, Shiite Islam’s most revered figure, and Fatemeh al-Zahra, the daughter of the Prophet Muhammad, is commemorated in Iran’s packed political calendar as a day to celebrate family values.

headline: Leader From Different World Visits Classrooms
text: Cathleen P. Black, the schools chancellor designee, is not a gusher. She is not an over-talker. She is a firm shaker of hands, a professional-grade eye-contact-maker and active listener. During an hourlong visit to Public School 33 in Chelsea on Monday morning, Ms. Black missed no opportunity to smile and say hello to school employees, from the office assistants to the person she later called the safety adviser (safety officer, but O.K., she is still new). Making the classroom rounds, she chatted with the children about pyramids and pets and greeted, but did not exactly bowl over, the teachers.

headline: Debt Escalating, Hornets Are Purchased by N.B.A.
text: The N.B.A. took the extraordinary step Monday of buying the New Orleans Hornets, one of the league’s most financially troubled franchises, after a deal for the sale of the club fell apart.

headline: In Queens Neighborhood, a Dispute Divides Business Owners and Leaves a Festival Dark
text: Diwali, the Hindu festival of lights, was dark this year in Jackson Heights, Queens.

headline: Bombs Away
text: WHILE most Americans were horrified and angered by the attacks on the morning of Sept. 11, 2001, few probably felt the same level of frustration as one of us, Brian Weeden. He was serving on nuclear alert at a Minuteman missile bunker deep under the Great Plains. Despite having the most destructive weapons ever invented at its hands, our military was powerless to deter, disrupt, punish or destroy this new type of adversary.

headline: Brady’s Stats, and Hair, Are Getting Attention
text: FOXBOROUGH, Mass.  For all the accomplishments of Tom Brady  the three Super Bowl rings, the supermodel wife, the contract with all those zeroes, the rock-star hair  he entered Monday night’s game against the Jets on perhaps the most productive stretch of his career.

headline: Do Not Go Directly to Jail
text: PRISON crowding has reached crisis proportions: California’s prisons, the largest state system in the country, operate at almost double their maximum capacity. The conditions there  the legacy of the war on drugs and long, mandatory sentences  are so bad that a federal court has found that they deny inmates constitutional rights to adequate health care and other basic services; the Supreme Court heard arguments in the case last week.

headline: U.S. Counts Big Results in Fighting Fraud Cases
text: WASHINGTON  Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. announced the results on Monday of a crackdown on financial fraud that he said resulted in more than 100 criminal convictions of people whose schemes cost about 120,000 victims more than $8 billion in losses.

headline: Foxwoods to Sponsor Games’ Last 5 Minutes
text: The last five minutes of basketball or hockey games is often the most valuable time for any advertiser to get its message to viewers, who are most likely to stay glued to their seats in the arena or on sofas at home while the game is on the line.

headline: Sidewalk Meeting for State Senator and Lawyer Leads to Guilty Plea
text: In June, after Vincent L. Leibell III, then a powerful Republican New York State senator, learned that federal authorities were investigating him because they suspected he was shaking down lawyers in his district, he pursued a strategy that by many accounts has served some of his colleagues well.

headline: Foreclosure Is Not an Option
text: Given the grim news in lending and home financing in recent months, it would appear that little can be done to stem the tide of foreclosures sweeping the nation.

headline: Mets Plan to Sit Back at Winter Meetings
text: ORLANDO, Fla. — General Manager Sandy Alderson continued to temper expectations of Mets activity at the winter meetings, reiterating Monday that it is unlikely he will sign a high-profile free agent or make a big trade. That is in line with what he has been saying since he was hired during the World Series.

headline: China: Resized Beijing Museum Breaks Ground
text: Construction began last Thursday on a museum that has been the centerpiece of a contentious plan to raze and rebuild a large section of ancient alleyways in the heart of Beijing, according to a report on Monday in China Daily, an English-language newspaper. But the scale of the original plan has been changed, and alleyways and courtyard homes will no longer be destroyed in the project, the report said. The museum, called the Beijing Time Museum, is being built on a site southeast of the Drum Tower, a 13th-century landmark. The original plan encompassed an area 20 times larger than the current project and ignited criticism from people concerned about the relentless destruction of historic areas in Beijing, China Daily reported. That plan was put on hiatus in September after the wave of criticism and a bureaucratic reshuffling of neighborhood governments.

headline: Previewing the G.O.P.’s 2012 Argument on Tax Cuts
text: The White House and Congressional Republicans reached a tentative deal in which all of the Bush-era tax cuts — including those on the highest incomes — would be extended for two years. In exchange, Democrats will receive an extension of unemployment benefits, and a one-year cut in the payroll tax, which — because it is capped at $106,800 — has its largest impact on middle-income workers.

headline: Tuesday: TV Scheduling
text: All the world’s a stage,And all the men and women merely players;They have their exits and their entrances;And one man in his time plays many parts.

headline: Mortgage Aid Restores Family’s Brooklyn Refuge
text: In 2004, when Cynthia Turay was deciding what to call her beauty-supply shop in Mill Basin, Brooklyn, she wanted the name to reflect her bumpy journey. She settled on God’s Time Beauty Supply.

headline: Hulsizer’s Bid for N.H.L.’s Coyotes Gains Committee Approval
text: PALM BEACH, Fla.  Conceding that his bid to buy the financially troubled Phoenix Coyotes is “not going to look smart for a long time,” the Chicago businessman Matthew Hulsizer won unanimous approval for the bid Monday from a committee of the N.H.L. board of governors.

headline: In Deal With G.O.P., Portent for Next 2 Years
text: WASHINGTON  For President Obama, this is what bipartisanship looks like in the new era: messy, combustible and painful, brought on under the threat of even more unpalatable consequences and yet still deferring the ultimate resolution for another day.

headline: A Big Idea
text: Grow a spine. Flex some muscle. Man up!

headline: Mets’ Collins Traded the Links for a Diamond
text: ORLANDO, Fla.

headline: France: L’Oréal Heiress and Daughter Reach a Truce
text: Liliane Bettencourt, the heiress of L’Oréal, has reconciled with her daughter after a three-year legal battle that divided the family and sparked scandals that ensnared top French politicians. The agreement, announced Monday by a lawyer for the daughter, Françoise Bettencourt-Meyers, ended a fierce legal clash between Mrs. Bettencourt-Meyers and the celebrity photographer François-Marie Banier, whom she had accused of exploiting her 88-year-old mother to reap more than $1 billion in cash and presents. Mrs. Bettencourt-Meyers’s husband, Jean-Pierre Meyers, is expected to take charge of the family’s holding company, Téthys, at the end of the month.

headline: Malaysia: Rights Group Says Caning Is Torture
text: Amnesty International is calling on Malaysia to halt the practice of judicial caning, a punishment the organization said amounts to torture and violates international law. In a report released on Monday, Amnesty International said that the number of offenses subject to caning under Malaysian criminal law had increased to more than 60 in recent years and that as many as 10,000 people were caned annually. Based on interviews with 57 people, the report found that some inmates had been left with permanent scars and physical disabilities after being hit with the 3-foot-long cane used in Malaysian prisons. A statement issued by the prime minister’s office said that the government could not comment on the accuracy of the report because it had not had adequate time to review its findings.

headline: Cashman, Ever Busy, Renews Push to Sign Lee
text: ORLANDO, Fla.  One day, Brian Cashman is rappelling as an elf down the side of a building, inviting all to watch. The next, he does not leave his hotel suite, accepting agents and executives while wearing sandals, a navy blue hoodie and a Yankees T-shirt.

headline: Poland: Medvedev Promises to Forge Better Relations
text: Polish and Russian leaders vowed Monday to open a new chapter in their relations, a move that could eventually end centuries of enmity and distrust. The pledge came after talks in Warsaw between President Dmitri A. Medvedev of Russia and his Polish counterpart, Bronislaw Komorowski. It was the first official visit to Poland in nine years by a Russian president. With Poland now having increasing influence in NATO, which it joined in 1999, and the European Union, which it joined in 2004, Mr. Medvedev said that if Moscow wanted better ties with both organizations, it needed to forge better relations with Poland.

headline: María Ester Gatti, Uruguayan Activist, Dies at 92
text: BUENOS AIRES  María Ester Gatti de Islas, a Uruguayan teacher who became a human rights activist while helping to find people lost to political repression in South America, died Sunday in Montevideo. She was 92.

headline: Bloomberg Seeking Election Law Changes to Increase Voter Turnout
text: This has not been a good year for elections in New York State, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said Monday. The state recorded one of the lowest turnouts in the midterm elections of any state. And over the last three federal elections, New York has averaged 47th among the 50 states in voter turnout.

headline: Behind Stoudemire, Knicks Gain Some Revenge
text: Amar’e Stoudemire took turns clapping his hands, pointing skyward, and curling his fingers into fists and pumping them. The moves usually followed a made jump shot, a bank shot or a forceful dunk.

headline: Google Maps for Android Gets New Features
text: At his presentation Monday night at the D: Dive Into Mobile Conference in San Francisco, Andy Rubin, Google‘s Android chief, revealed some new features to Google Maps that will be coming to Android users.

headline: The J. Crew Deal That Almost Wasn’t
text: Putting together a leveraged buyout is never an easy task, and a multibillion-dollar deal like that for J. Crew is especially difficult.

headline: Social Science Palooza
text: Every day, hundreds of thousands of scholars study human behavior. Every day, a few of their studies are bundled and distributed via e-mail by Kevin Lewis, who covers the social sciences for The Boston Globe and National Affairs. And every day, I file away these studies because I find them bizarrely interesting.

headline: For the First Time, Yale Is No. 1
text: Yale’s men’s team is ranked No. 1 for the first time after victories over No. 13 Union College and No. 15 Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute over the weekend. The USA Today/USA Hockey Magazine poll ranked the Bulldogs (10-1) ahead of Minnesota-Duluth (12-2-2), New Hampshire (9-2-4) and Boston College (11-5). Yale is the first East Coast Athletic Association team to be ranked No. 1 since Cornell entered the 2003 N.C.A.A. tournament as the top seed. 8.

headline: Android’s Architect Talks Profitability and Success
text: The secret to the success of Android, Google’s mobile operating system? Its newness, said Andy Rubin, vice president of engineering at Google and the chief architect behind Android.

headline: The Tax Cut Endgame
text: President Obama’s deal with the Republicans to extend all the Bush-era income tax cuts is a win for the Republicans and their strategy of obstructionism and a disappointing retreat by the White House.

headline: Test Your Insight
text: Does your mood affect how quickly you intuit answers? Play this game to find out.

headline: Freshman Party
text: Adam Kinzinger of Illinois is one of the new Republican lawmakers swept into office last month on a promise to change the ways of Washington. “If we look like we’re doing business as usual,” the congressman-elect told a reporter last month, “then obviously the American people will say, ‘Well, what was that all about?’ ”

headline: Final: Patriots 45, Jets 3
text: A lot of N.F.L. games are said to be crucial or must-win, but many of them do not live up to the hype. In the end, they sometimes are not even as important as once thought.

headline: Rules for Gainful Education
text: The Obama administration has already adopted several new rules that will give the Department of Education more authority to rein in corrupt practices by for-profit universities. But the most crucial rule, the “gainful employment” provision, is still awaiting approval, and the industry is pushing back hard.

headline: Bullying and Censorship
text: In an appalling act of political cowardice, the Smithsonian Institution last week removed “A Fire in My Belly,” a four-minute video clip, from an exhibit called “Hide/Seek” at the National Portrait Gallery. The privately financed show explores identity, gender and homosexuality in American portraiture.

text: grudging •\ˈgrəj iN\• adjective

text: Josh Bernstein, left, of the Service Employees International Union and Mark Krikorian of the Center for Immigration Studies debate the Dream Act.

headline: Big Game Turns Out to Be No Contest
text: FOXBOROUGH, Mass.  The Jets strutted into Gillette Stadium with heightened hubris, primed to wrestle control of their division and the A.F.C. from New England. All those years in the shadow of the Patriots, all those seasons of expectations unfulfilled, all that was supposed to end on Monday night.

headline: Seven Years for Cliff Lee?
text: ORLANDO, Fla. – According to Ken Rosenthal at Foxsports.com, the market for Cliff Lee is moving toward C.C. Sabathia territory: a seven-year contract. If some team does, in fact, make Lee that kind of offer, it almost certainly would not be the Yankees – or the Rangers.

headline: Jets Replay, Dec. 6
text: The Jets fell hard against the Patriots, losing a shot at first place in the A.F.C. East.

headline: News Quiz | December 7, 2010
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper.

headline: Soccer Powerhouse Emerges From Pennsylvania Hills
text: Messiah College (enrollment 2,900) has quietly built a Division III soccer dynasty in Grantham, Pa., about 10 miles southwest of Harrisburg.

headline: Hillard Elkins, Producer, Is Dead at 81
text: Hillard Elkins, a producer who broke down sexual barriers and created one of the biggest hits in Broadway history when he brought the erotic revue “Oh! Calcutta!” to the stage, died on Wednesday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 81.

headline: Garry Gross Is Dead at 73; Photographer of Clothes and Their Absence
text: Garry Gross, a fashion photographer for 30 years who was best known for controversial photos of an unclothed 10-year-old Brooke Shields, died on Nov. 30 at his home in Manhattan. Mr. Gross, who in recent years had focused his cameras on dogs, was 73.

headline: 2 Russian Grocers Move to Thwart Wal-Mart
text: Two of Russia’s largest grocery store chains, Pyaterochka and Kopeika, said on Monday that they would merge their operations in a move that would better position them to compete with Wal-Mart, which is expected to enter the Russian market, Andrew E. Kramer reports in The New York Times.

headline: Test Yourself | English, Dec. 7, 2010
text: Test your reading skills with today’s question, created by Danielle Hoagland and Judith McCaffrey at Grammarlogues from the article “Expansion of Bike Lanes in City Brings Backlash.”

headline: Gates Arrives in Afghanistan
text: BAGRAM AIR BASE, Afghanistan  Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates landed here Tuesday morning for an unannounced visit to meet with American commanders and President Hamid Karzai.

headline: What Are Your Favorite Children’s Books?
text: We’re not talking about young adult fiction here. We’re asking you to remember back to when you were 8 or younger to answer this question. You might consider books read to you by relatives, friends or teachers, or the first books you read on your own. What made them so special? What do you remember about reading or having them read to you?

headline: British Court Denies Bail to Assange
text: LONDON — After months of posting troves of classified American documents on the Internet, Julian Assange, founder of the WikiLeaks Web site, surrendered to British authorities and was jailed on Tuesday after a judge reviewing a Swedish extradition request found him to be a flight risk and denied him bail.

headline: Top Test Scores From Shanghai Stun Educators
text: With China’s debut in international standardized testing, students in Shanghai have surprised experts by outscoring their counterparts in dozens of other countries, in reading as well as in math and science, according to the results of a respected exam.

headline: Official in Pakistan Escapes Assassination Bid
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  The chief minister of Pakistan’s southwestern Baluchistan region escaped an assassination attempt early Tuesday in the provincial capital of Quetta, when an explosion set off by a suicide bomber rocked his convoy, according to Abid Notkani, the Quetta police chief. There was no immediate claim of responsibility.

headline: The Genesis of a Theme Park
text: WHO plans to create a theme park based on a replica of Noah’s ark?

headline: 19 Countries to Skip Nobel Ceremony, While China Offers Its Own Prize
text: LONDON — Nineteen governments have said their ambassadors will not attend a ceremony this week awarding the Nobel Peace Prize to the imprisoned Chinese dissident Liu Xiaobo, the Norwegian prize committee said Tuesday, more than tripling the number of rejections and reflecting the strong pressure exerted by Beijing to boycott the event.

headline: Eyes Open, Back Into the Afghan Crucible
text: On my way to Afghanistan, I stop in Paris to pick up my gear. I need cold-weather clothes and I spend hours trying to find wool and cotton. A friend who worked at Walter Reed hospital told me about polyester melting into the soldiers’ wounds from the explosions. They take it out with some sort of cheese grater, he said.

headline: More Nuclear Talks With Iran Are Set
text: GENEVA  Tense talks between Iran, the United States and other world powers ended Tuesday with an agreement to hold another meeting toward the end of January in Istanbul.

headline: Cherry Creek High: Six Seniors Blog About Their College Quest
text: Beginning today, The Choice takes flight from its perch here in New York City, arguably the epicenter of the college-admissions-pressure-cooker in the Northeast, and travels across the country to Denver for a much-needed change of scenery.

headline: Thinking of College as a Tattoo, a Decision Not Easily Erased
text: Choosing a college is like choosing a tattoo. As with body art, you want an institution that is authentically you and, at the same time, one that allows you to flaunt all of your best attributes to the world.

text: Andy Barall writes about pro football history for the Fifth Down.  Don Meredith died Sunday at age 72.

headline: Somehow, the Age on My Driver’s License Says It’s Time for College
text: It’s absolutely bizarre to be applying to college. If it weren’t for the birth date on my driver’s license, I’d be thoroughly convinced that the time for these mind-bogglingly enormous decisions was still years away, a vague speck on my life’s horizon.

headline: A Chef Adds Spice to the Paris Food Scene
text: Parisian gourmands rejoiced when the acclaimed chef Olivier Roellinger recently opened Epices Roellinger, his version of an old-fashioned spice shop, a treasure trove of inspiration for cooks and foodies.

headline: Axiom Telecom Cancels I.P.O. in Dubai
text: The first initial public offering in the United Arab Emirates in nearly two years has been canceled, as the company set to go public — the cellphone retailer Axiom Telecom — got cold feet.

headline: Bonds Fall on Fear That Tax Cut Deal Will Add to Deficit, but Stocks Are Steady
text: The bond market on Tuesday had one of its worst days this year as it sold off over concerns that President Obama’s tax deal would add to the nation’s budget deficit.

headline: AGL Resources to Buy Nicor for $2.4 Billion
text: 7:18 p.m. | Updated  AGL Resources agreed on Tuesday to buy a fellow power company, Nicor, for $2.4 billion in cash and stock, in a bid to create a big new natural gas distributor.

headline: The Nutcracker Chronicles: Shh, the Puppets Are About to Dance
text: GLEN ECHO, Md. — Across a footbridge, over a rushing stream, past a carousel … this is the way to the Puppet Co.’s version of “The Nutcracker.”

headline: Mastering Google AdWords
text: Six years ago, after leaving a high-powered career in fashion sales to become a stay-at-home mother of very young children, Amy Gottesman found herself missing her income — and looking for something to do when her kids were napping. So Ms. Gottesman, who lives on Long Island, put up a Web site under the name of Smash Party Entertainment, offering entertainment for parties, ranging from casinos to living Roman “statues” to murder mysteries.

headline: Updates on Leak of U.S. Cables, Day 10
text: On Tuesday, The Lede continued to follow the fallout from the publication of American diplomatic cables obtained by the WikiLeaks Web site, and the legal problems of its founder, Julian Assange. (The final installment in a 9-day New York Times series on the cables concluded on Monday night, but documents continue to be published by WikiLeaks and other news organizations. For an overview of the revelations and reactions so far, see our previous live-blog posts.)

headline: There Are No Deficit Hawks In Congress
text: It’s a point barely worth making, but the tax cut deal demonstrates, for the umpteenth time, that self-proclaimed deficit hawks are frauds. We can’t afford unemployment benefits or public investment, the fake hawks say — but when it come to cutting taxes on the rich, money is literally no object.

headline: Cacao Prieto to Debut with Pop-Up Store
text: The Brooklyn Ice Cream Factory in Dumbo gets an infusion of chocolate this winter.

headline: For Artists’ Fund-Raising, a Social Network Site
text: United States Artists, a nonprofit group founded by foundations and wealthy art donors to broaden support for working artists, will unveil a new Web site on Tuesday that solicits small donations from regular people to help underwrite specific artworks.

headline: The Problem With Front-Loading
text: A further thought on the tax deal: didn’t the administration repeat exactly the same mistake it made on the original stimulus? The stimulus was too small; but it also too short-lived, with the maximum impact on growth coming in the winter of 2009-2010, then turning negative just in time for the midterm election.

headline: What the Tax Deal Means for You
text: Updated at 2:45 p.m. to add more details about payroll taxes and tax credits.

headline: Morning Take-Out
text: –A man was arrested for parking a crane outside the Irish Parliament building on the day of its vote on the budget. That austerity package will be posted here, as soon as it is presented to the Dail. Elsewhere, Angry Bear wonders if that infamous Celtic Tiger was anything more than a mirage.

headline: Gates Calls Assange Arrest ‘Good News’
text: FORWARD OPERATING BASE, CONNOLLY, Afghanistan  Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates on Tuesday applauded the arrest of Julian Assange, the founder of WikiLeaks, whose Web site has released hundreds of thousands of classified military and diplomatic documents and become a scourge of the Pentagon.

headline: Wall Street’s Advantage in Russia
text: When PepsiCo swooped in last week to buy a stake in the Russian dairy and juice maker Wimm-Bill-Dann Foods for $3.8 billion, Champagne corks were not exactly popping at Russia’s biggest investment banks.

headline: Clubs Covet Last Four Spots in Champions League Knockout Stage
text: The last four spots in the 16-team first knockout stage of the European Champions League will be determined after the final games of the group stage Tuesday and Wednesday.

headline: Ozawa to Limit His Role in Carnegie’s Japan Festival
text: Seiji Ozawa’s cancellation of performances at the Saito Kinen Festival Matsumoto, in Japan, in September because of back problems heightened concern at Carnegie Hall, since the programs in question were also scheduled for Carnegie next week. The programs are still coming, Carnegie announced on Tuesday, and so is Mr. Ozawa, though in a reduced capacity.

headline: T Exclusive Video | ‘Dorothea’
text: Barnaby Roper, the innovative New York filmmaker and photographer, has created a short film exclusively for The Moment starring the model Dorothea Barth Jorgensen. In this captivating short, Roper combines powerful lighting and exquisitely timed edits — along with more than a little wax — to transform Dorothea into a three-dimensional otherworldly beauty. When not appearing in T films or posing for the pages of Italian Vogue or Love, the Swedish-born Jorgensen can often be found at Surf Café in Brooklyn, reading her beloved Anaïs Nin, or, you know, analyzing dreams. She also has a wicked blog called Displaced Bones, where you can see Jorgensen’s beautiful friends captured through her own lens and read her poetry and various musings.

headline: The Dancers Weigh In on ‘Black Swan’
text: Tis the season when the Bagger has to go to other people’s holiday parties. On Monday night, we stopped by the Fox Searchlight party at the Hudson Hotel, where Sam Rockwell, Juliette Lewis and Darren Aronofsky mingled among hordes of Oscar bloggers and other media people out for the free drinks and trays of cheese. (Sidenote: the Bagger has already seen what seems like a larger-than-usual number of cheese trays at these fancy soirees. Cost-cutting measure, or hardcore dairy board lobbying?)

headline: TKTS Gets an iPhone App, and Some Extra Human Help, Too
text: The Theater Development Fund, the nonprofit organization behind the TKTS theater discount service, on Tuesday announced two new additions, one for iPhone users and one for theatergoers who prefer human interaction.

headline: With McDaniels Out, What About Tebow?
text: With Josh McDaniels out as coach at Denver, Tim Tebow has lost his N.F.L. patron.

headline: L.B.O.’s: Don’t Call It a Comeback
text: The buyouts last month of the big consumer names J. Crew and Del Monte were two promising signs that private equity firms were ready to come out and play again.

headline: Morning Buzz | Mayor Moves to Make Voting Easier
text: Tuesday will be chilly with highs in the upper 30s and a 20 percent chance of snow showers.

headline: Hertz Puts Electric Cars on the Fast Track, Starting in New York
text: Early adopters unwilling to drop around $32,000 on a new Nissan Leaf will be able to rent that and several other electric cars from Hertz as soon as next week. On Monday, Hertz announced it would be adding electric cars and plug-in hybrids to its urban and college fleets worldwide, starting with New York City, where they’ll be available in Connect at Hertz car-sharing locations beginning Dec. 15.

headline: Wrong Sanchez Shows Up for the Jets
text: FOXBOROUGH, Mass. — Shortly after the Jets’ Monday night drubbing at the hands of the Patriots, quarterback Mark Sanchez had a hard time recalling the last time he was on the wrong end of such a lopsided game.

headline: U.S. and China Narrow Differences at Climate Talks in Cancún
text: CANCÚN, Mexico  The United States and China have significantly narrowed their differences on the verification of reductions in greenhouse gas emissions, officials said, providing hope that a United Nations conference here on climate change can achieve some modest success.

headline: Tuesday Reading: The Mommy Penalty
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: Dismantling Shows Jets Don’t Yet Measure Up
text: A month ago, Robert K. Kraft, the owner of the New England Patriots, sat in his office and extolled the value of a team that has one superstar in Tom Brady, a magnificent coach in Bill Belichick and “a lot of guys.”

headline: Waters Calls for Investigation of House Ethics Committee
text: Representative Maxine Waters, who has been under investigation by the House ethics committee for allegations that she helped steer government money to a bank in which her husband owned shares, is asking for an investigation into the committee that has been investigating her.

headline: Revival Set for ‘Einstein on the Beach’
text: The Philip Glass opera “Einstein on the Beach” will be revived in 2012  by the production company Pomegranate Arts,  the company said on Tuesday. The 1976 work will go on tour starting in Montpellier, France, in March of that year and travel to London, Toronto, Brooklyn and Berkeley, Calif., before closing in Amsterdam in January 2013. Mr. Glass and his collaborator, the director Robert Wilson, will be involved in the restaging, the producers said. Starting in January 2012, the company will rehearse and give previews at the University of Michigan in Ann Arbor.

headline: Puzzles to Stretch Your Mind
text: Today’s Science Times offers a special issue on puzzles that will either stretch your mind or fray your nerves.

headline: Tea Party Nation Makes Pick for Republican Chairman
text: One day after former Gov. Sarah Palin of Alaska declined to throw her hat into the ring to become the Tea Party movement’s choice to lead the Republican National Committee, a leading Tea Party group threw its support behind Saul Anuzis of Michigan.

headline: Poparazzi | A History of Gossip
text: Trying to track down a half-remembered nugget of trivia, I recently entered the words “history of gossip” into a search engine. The top result — generated by one of those online content companies journalists hate so much — had all the flaws of its subject (speculation, lack of facts) but none of its virtues (pizazz, celebrity names).

headline: Gisele’s Eco-Friendly Cartoon Hopes to Teach Some Model Behavior
text: If you’re trying to raise awareness about the environment there are a number of different avenues open to you. You could start a petition drive, hold a demonstration or write an Op-Ed article. Or you could just get a supermodel to do it for you.

headline: A Child Wanders, Neighbors Whisper
text: My memory is of a lovely summer day, visiting the country home of friends, an idyllic place, right on a lake. We were all munching bagels around the table, two couples and four young children, when I noticed my youngest son simply wasn’t there. He was in his chair a moment earlier, but now he just…wasn’t.

headline: Obama Defends Tax Deal, but His Party Stays Hostile
text: WASHINGTON  President Obama on Tuesday strongly defended his tax cut deal with Congressional Republicans against intense criticism from his own party, insisting it was “a good deal for the American people.”

headline: For Wildlife Rangers, a Human Menace
text: In the West, built-up regions of the cities don’t gently fade into countryside the way you might find, in say, New England or parts of the South. National forests and other federally owned lands, abundant west of Kansas, create boundaries of use and history that have long formed powerful psychological checkpoints. Going into the woods means departing from the cities or suburbs in more than just terrain.

headline: Hawks Fail to Embrace Undervalued Horford
text: Let’s make this simple and direct: Al Horford is the Atlanta Hawks’ best player. Joe Johnson may make more money and Josh Smith may be a SportsCenter staple, but Horford is Atlanta’s most prolific scorer (he leads the team in points per minute), their top rebounder (he also leads in rebounds per minute and rebounding rate), a willing and productive passer, and the team’s most versatile and effective defender.

headline: Holiday Windows Dress Up a Romance
text: Joseph isn’t sure he buys this whole virgin-birth story. The Little Match Girl uses some of her dwindling supply on a cigarette. The fellow from “The Gift of the Magi” gets a perverse kick out of his wife’s newly androgynous hairdo.

headline: The Tax Cut Deal
text: As policy, the bargain Barack Obama just struck with Congressional Republicans is a classic “it makes sense, but only if …” situation. Given the parlous state of the economy, it makes sense to maintain the low Bush-era tax rates, it makes sense to extend unemployment benefits, and it makes sense to temporarily drop the payroll tax rate … if, that is, our leaders use the time between today and 2012, when this bargain comes up for renegotiation, to make real progress on a strategy for long-term deficit reduction, joined to a base-broadening, rate-lowering tax reform package that renders the debates over the Bush tax cuts obsolete.

headline: Nazi Is Exposed, but Did He Have Anything to Hide?
text: BERLIN  Please do not call Mark Gould a Nazi hunter.

headline: Grand Tribute to the Heritage of Italians
text: Anybody who attends the Metropolitan Opera or Fashion Week or shops at Eataly, the new temple of pasta and prosciutto near Madison Square, may think that all due respect is being paid to Italians and their contributions. But he or she has not met Joseph J. Grano Jr.

headline: Five Columbia Students Arrested on Drug Charges
text: Five Columbia University students — including a member of the student council — were arrested on campus early on Tuesday and charged with running a ring that sold drugs to students at fraternity houses and in residence halls, the police said.

headline: When the Assisted-Living Bill Balloons
text: This fall, my father sat down for a semi-annual assessment with staff members at his assisted living facility in Tinton Falls, N.J. They decided his condition — at 72, he has advancing Parkinson’s disease — necessitated an upgrade to the next level of care.

headline: Chinese Tycoon Focuses on Green Construction
text: CHANGSHA, China  Zhang Yue has grounded his three private jets and personal helicopter. He has stored the midnight blue Rolls-Royce stretch limousine and canary-yellow Ferrari behind the conference center he built here as a reproduction of a French palace. This past summer, he kept the thermostat in his office at a steamy 81 degrees.

headline: Puccini’s Western, in Search of Lyrical Gold
text: One hundred years ago this Friday, Puccini’s “Fanciulla del West,” adapted from David Belasco’s play “The Girl of the Golden West” and set in a California mining camp during the gold rush, had its glittery premiere production at the old Metropolitan Opera. Toscanini was in the pit; Enrico Caruso, Emmy Destinn and Pasquale Amato sang the leads; and Puccini, alone in his box, surveyed the scene. That is, until the end of Act I, when the composer and cast appeared on stage for 14 curtain calls. Similar pandemonium broke out at the end of the other two acts.

headline: A Roundup of Novel Gift Ideas
text: You may be looking for something different to give this holiday season.

headline: In Europe, No Action to Expand Bailout Aid
text: BRUSSELS  Fighting to support the euro amid continuing market uncertainty, European finance ministers played for time on Tuesday, making no pledge to increase their backstop fund for the currency and hinting that Portugal might need to take additional measures to fend off speculative attacks.

headline: Under the Hoodie, the Patriots Hum
text: It certainly did seem on Monday that the universe conspired to burnish the legend of Patriots Coach Bill Belichick. The events rolled together so nicely  New England’s complete thrashing of the Jets combined with the latest flaming demise of another supposedly Belichick-spawned miniature genius in Josh McDaniels  that it almost makes you want to start shopping for hoodies at the local thrift store and living your public life with all the apparent joy of having your car repossessed.

headline: Maybach Signs Deal With Artist and Filmmaker Julian Schnabel
text: Mercedes and the artist and film director Julian Schnabel announced a partnership at the recent Art Basel Miami Beach art fair. The deal involves Maybach, the  company’s high-end brand, and a piece by Mr. Schnabel named “Queequeg — The Maybach Sculpture.”

headline: On Our Radar: Negotiations on Wolf Protections Fail
text: Negotiations to remove gray wolves from the endangered species list in three states break down after Wyoming and Idaho decline to endorse a compromise proposal from the federal government. Several states have been pushing to strip protections from the estimated 1,700 wolves now believed to inhabit the Northern Rockies; the Interior Department has reportedly agreed to allow some hunting of wolves, but with restrictions that have so far met with resistance from some state leaders. [Associated Press]

headline: Piquet Wins Case Against Renault
text: The Renault affair has finally, apparently, come to an end. The team last year was accused of cheating at the Singapore Grand Prix of 2008 when Nelson Piquet Jr. was asked by team directors to stage a crash in order to help Fernando Alonso win the race. Piquet kept this secret for a year before revealing the scandal in the summer of last year when he lost his job at the team.

text: KABUL, Afghanistan — When Bibi Aisha’s nose and ears were cut off by her husband and her in-laws, no one ever expected much to be done about it, especially because it happened in a remote area under Taliban control.

headline: The Nutcracker Chronicles: Cue the (Taped) Music for Red Coat Rats and Davy Crockettes
text: WASHINGTON  — Outside the Warner Theater here, there’s the most friendly and seasonal kind of picketing I’ve ever encountered: Members of the Washington Ballet orchestra, unhappy that the troupe is performing “The Nutcracker” to taped music, are playing Christmas carols. “We’d Rather Be Playing Inside” say their fliers, which note that live orchestral accompaniment was integral to the company’s “Nutcracker” for more than 30 years and that their stated hope last year of restoring live accompaniment in 2010 has not been fulfilled.

headline: Performance Artist Returns to His Old Stomping Grounds
text: Is anyone a performance artist anymore? Tim Miller might be one of the last working theater artists to embrace fully the term, already vague to the point of meaninglessness when Eric Bogosian made fun of it in his 1994 slacker drama, “Suburbia.”

headline: Survey Finds Support, but a Bike-Lane Debate Continues

headline: What Would Cleopatra Do? Drawing Lessons From History or Literature
text: Overview | What can history and literature teach us? How are the lives of historical leaders and literary characters relevant and applicable to our own lives and times? In this lesson, students consider the lessons that can be learned from Cleopatra’s reign and then analyze historical or literary figures to develop lessons from their lives that might be useful in the modern world.

headline: State Senator Guilty in Dispute With Photographer
text: State Senator Kevin S. Parker, a Brooklyn Democrat, was convicted of misdemeanor criminal mischief charges on Tuesday stemming from a confrontation with a photographer for The New York Post, but he was cleared of more serious felony assault charges.

headline: Feuding in Cartoon Land
text: Think cartoons are all sweetness and fluff? That’s not all, folks. In the wake of the Annie nominations on Monday, animators and Oscar watchers are talking about some studio drama behind the scenes. This past summer, the Walt Disney Company and Pixar Animation announced they were withdrawing from the Annies, the cartoon world’s equivalent of the Oscars, presented by the Hollywood branch of the International Animated Film Society, because of a dispute with the way the group chooses its winners. “Among Disney’s complaints: that the guild allows anyone to buy a membership (in contrast to most awards-bestowing organizations) and that rival DreamWorks Animation has too much power because it gives all of its employees complimentary membership to the guild,” Brooks Barnes wrote in August.

headline: Designing Election Results on the iPad
text: Election results have been a staple of The Times’s web offerings for years, with the presentation growing in sophistication year by year.

headline: Georgia Arrests Six People in Bombings
text: MOSCOW  Georgia on Tuesday announced it had arrested six people suspected of carrying out a series of mysterious bombings. It said they got their orders from a Russian Army officer based in the breakaway territory of Abkhazia.

headline: Citi Could Get Another Boost
text: Shares of Citigroup, which is nearly free from Uncle Sam, are up — and index fund managers may push them even higher.

headline: Irish Lawmakers Hear Budget Plan, and Protesters, Too

headline: On Climate Treaties and Christmas Trees
text: 3:32 p.m. | Updated CANCÚN, Mexico – On Monday night, Michael Zammit Cutajar, one of the most important figures in two decades of negotiations aimed at a global agreement to avoid dangerous climate change, issued a gentle warning to delegates, officials and others attending a discussion I moderated on social impacts of climate change: Keep track of the difference between a climate treaty and a Christmas tree.

headline: India on Alert as Bomb Hits Hindu Holy City
text: NEW DELHI  Indian authorities issued security alerts in several major cities on Tuesday evening after a bomb detonated in the Hindu holy city of Varanasi. The police said the explosion and ensuing panic of pilgrims left a toddler dead and at least 20 other people injured.

headline: Deconstructing Chicken Soup
text: I really had a great weekend of cooking; winter takes the pressure off of shopping for “the best possible ingredients” and just lets you hunker down and play with what’s around. I baked bread, twice; I made fruit compote; I produced a decent vegetable soup (disregarding, I’m sorry to report, my own advice about putting turnips in soup, thus allowing me to reiterate: do not put turnips in soup); and I ate leftovers.

headline: Cast Set for Opera Based on 9/11 Hero
text: The San Francisco Opera on Tuesday disclosed details of a new opera by Christopher Theofanidis based on a book about Rick Rescorla, the head of security for Morgan Stanley who died shepherding people to safety during the Sept. 11 attack on the World Trade Center. The opera, “Heart of a Soldier,” will star the baritone Thomas Hampson, the tenor William Burden and the soprano Melody Moore. Francesca Zambello will direct and Patrick Summers will conduct. It will have its first performance on Sept. 10, the eve of the 10th anniversary of the attack.

headline: Asked and Answered | Justin Bond
text: Since captivating the downtown performance scene of the 1990s as Kiki, the singing, boozing, yarn-spinning half of the drag cabaret duo Kiki and Herb, the Maryland native Justin Bond has become a witty, kitten-heeled fixture of the New York avant-garde. Bond, who is in his 40s and identifies as transgender, was the mistress of ceremonies in John Cameron Mitchell’s 2006 indie film “Shortbus,” and in October he performed at the Kitchen with his House of Whimsy Players in “Re:Galli Blond (A Sissy Fix),” a self-penned musical spectacle of transgender oppression and uplift. From the phone in his East Village loft, he chatted about his latest project, “Justin Bond: Christmas Spells,” opening Dec. 9 at Abrons Arts Center.

headline: WikiLeaks Founder Arrested

headline: Legions Descend on New World of Warcraft

You may have even stood in line at midnight to buy a Harry Potter book. But have you ever stayed up all night with hundreds of thousands, perhaps millions, of other people for a chance to be among the first to save the universe from destruction?

headline: Suit Over Targeted Killings Is Thrown Out

headline: Rich Getting Richer: Penske Racing Signs Shell and Izod
text: For more than 20 years, most of the Indy racecars fielded by Roger Penske and his formidable team were painted Day-Glo orange and white and carried the Marlboro logo, a brand made by the team’s primary sponsor, Phillip Morris USA. The cars were one of the most easily recognizable in motorsports, in part because Team Penske drivers won the Indianapolis 500 several times in Marlboro colors.

headline: A Navel-Gazing Oscar Countdown
text: We know you’ve marked your calendar: there are now 83 days until the 83rd Academy Awards (Feb. 27, 2011). To celebrate this red-letter date, the Academy itself is starting a countdown, revisiting each and every Oscar event by year. The first one, held in 1929, gave the top prize to “Wings,” the only silent film ever to win an Academy Award; it was also the only time individual prizes were given for dramatic and comedic direction. (They went to “7th Heaven” and the laff-riot “Two Arabian Knights,” respectively.) There wasn’t much room for industry speculation or public betting, though, because the ceremony, in the Blossom Room of the Hollywood Roosevelt Hotel, was held three months after the winners were announced. Two hundred and seventy people attended, and the Academy president, Douglas Fairbanks, was the host. Plus-ones were welcome, as long as they paid $5 for their seat. In this photo, the guests look mostly well-behaved, but the Bagger bets it won’t be long until a close inspection reveals early celebrity misbehavior. Follow along!

headline: Clean Energy Sector Scrambles to Save Incentives
text: Representatives of the renewable energy industries are scrambling to salvage what they say is a crucial federal incentive that has helped keep them afloat during the worst of the recession.

headline: Finding Meaning in the Marketing of the New Windows Phone
text: I got all twitchy (it’s a good thing) when I saw the new “Really?” ad campaign for Windows Phone 7. It features people carrying on life’s routines — walking, running, playing with children, preparing for bed — absorbed in their smartphones and missing life as it is happening around them. “It’s time for our phone,” a narrator intones, “to save us from our phones.” The new Windows Phone 7, we are told, is “designed to get you in and out and back to life” — something many small-business owners long for.

headline: Holiday Wish List | Michelle Kessler-Sanders
text: Forget stockings hanging above an open fire, unless they’re Wolford of course. T’s fashion director, Michelle Kessler-Sanders, is making a list — Balmain, Rick Owens and McQueen — checking it twice and going to get herself something nice.

headline: Informed Dissent: One Blogger’s Critique of the Afghan War

headline: And Over in the Senate, an Impeachment Trial for a Judge

Thomas Porteous Jr. of Federal District Court in Louisiana, whom the House of Representatives impeached in March on four articles of “high crimes and misdemeanors” stemming from charges that he received cash and favors from those with business in his court.

headline: Google Updates Priority Inbox
text: It’s no secret to the creators of Google’s Gmail service that e-mail isn’t the most practical and concise form of communication mostly because of the constant deluge of messages that can clog up even the most organized inbox. To try and combat this, Google introduced Priority Inbox over the summer, a service that it hoped would organize e-mail messages based on importance.

headline: Public Sniping in Talks Left Jeter Feeling Angry

Derek Jeter still lingered behind a podium, where Jennifer Steinbrenner Swindal, a general partner of the Yankees, wrapped him in a lengthy embrace. Her brother Hal, the team’s managing general partner, came over and extended his hand. As they shook, photographers clicked and snapped.

headline: Showing the Adults How It’s Done
text: If young musicians and listeners have no interest in classical music, how is it that organizations like the New York Youth Symphony continue to thrive? Founded in 1963, it has grown from a youth orchestra into a large, streamlined program with chamber groups, jazz ensembles and classes in conducting and composition. And its players, ages 12 to 21, are sufficiently devoted to the music that when they perform at Carnegie Hall, as they did on Sunday afternoon, they produce a sound that would do an adult orchestra proud, in programs built largely of cornerstones of the standard canon.

headline: Translation as Literary Ambassador

But for work from other regions, in other genres, winning the interest of big publishing houses and readers in the United States remains a steep uphill struggle.

headline: A Bypassed Small Town Makes a Visual Statement: Here We Are
text: HOOPER, Neb.  A few years ago, the Nebraska Department of Roads rolled out a highway bypass to hasten the already-hurried everyday pace. Motorists rushing north to Norfolk, or south to Omaha, no longer had to slow to 40 miles an hour through a blink-and-miss-it place called Hooper.

headline: Nebraska Town Refuses to Be Bypassed

headline: Closing the Deal: How Qatar Won the World Cup

headline: Tentative Signs of Life for Greenhouse Gas Controls
text: For a patient suffering from paralysis, the movement of a single finger is momentous. So, in the face of a threatened hiatus in government-led action on climate change, what the Environmental Improvement Board of New Mexico has done in the last month or so is worthy of note. It has twice approved plans to cap and/or reduce greenhouse gas emissions, most recently on Monday evening, when a plan for annual 3 percent reductions beginning in 2013 won approval in a 4-to-1 vote.

Programs focusing on the American colonial and 19th-century eras, like the one Early Music offered on Saturday evening at the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine, are more unusual.

But the Barnard Project, a pairing of the Barnard College dance department and Dance Theater Workshop, gives choreographers a chance to work with their pick of students. In turn, the young dancers acquire some experience of creative collaboration and performance in a professional setting.

headline: Laughing Matters: Discuss
text: In the 1940s, long before the unlovely abbreviations LOL and ROTFL became standard usage, the great film critic James Agee broke the four main kinds of laughter inspired by silent-film comedians into four more intricate categories: “the titter, the yowl, the belly laugh and the boffo.”

text: The brothers Sablich are here to help with fantasy football analysis for Week 14. Check back on Thursday for their weekly matchup analysis and their reader Q. & A. and follow them on Twitter for more advice leading up to game time on Sunday.
