text: Hertz plans to add electric cars and plug-in hybrids to its urban and college fleets, starting with New York City next week, the Wheels blog reports.

headline: The Dark Lady and Judy Garland Play the Muses
text: Rufus Wainwright knows how to make an entrance. Wearing a black floor-length gown with a matching fur collar and dark eye makeup, he was every inch the tragic diva as he gravely crossed the stage of Carnegie Hall on Monday evening. A prima donna and a sad clown rolled into one, this grand, androgynous mourner embodied the grieving central figure of Mr. Wainwright’s sixth studio album, “All Days Are Nights: Songs for Lulu,” released last spring.

headline: For ‘The Hobbit,’ Peter Jackson Signs Up an Old Friend and a Former ‘Doctor Who’
text: With the start of production drawing closer on his cinematic adaptations of “The Hobbit,” Peter Jackson has begun reuniting his old gang from his Academy Award-winning “Lord of the Rings” movies. On Tuesday, Mr. Jackson announced that Cate Blanchett, who played the elf Galadriel in his film versions of J. R. R. Tolkien‘s “Fellowship of the Ring,” “The Two Towers” and “The Return of the King,” will reprise that role in his two-part “Hobbit” series. In a statement reported at comingsoon.net, Mr. Jackson said Ms. Blanchett was “one of my favorite actors to work with and I couldn’t be more thrilled to have her reprise the role she so beautifully brought to life in the earlier films.” Also joining the “Hobbit” movies are Sylvester McCoy, a star of the British fantasy series “Doctor Who,” as the wizard Radagast the Brown, and Ken Stott (“Charlie Wilson’s War”) as Balin, a dwarf leader.

headline: The Most Dangerous Beat: Juárez, Mexico
text: Reporters in Juárez not only cover drug cartel violence but are often targets themselves.

headline: Just One Look | Jason Wu’s Pre-Fall Collection
text: Forget The Sartorialist. Jason Wu has been getting inspiration from the street fashion photos of the Séeberger Brothers, who captured Paris society of the 1930s. Back then, crazy hats, feathers and fur were the stuff of everyday wear. We particularly like how Wu jazzed up this otherwise simple trench with a mantle of lace and paired it with easy yet “elevated” sweat pants.

headline: A Political Life Filled With Cruel Reversals
text: Elizabeth Edwards, who as the wife of former Senator John Edwards gave America an intimate look at a candidate’s marriage by sharing his quest for the 2008 presidential nomination as she struggled with incurable cancer and, secretly, with his infidelity, died Tuesday morning at her home in Chapel Hill, N.C. She was 61.

headline: Choir Academy of Harlem Takes Advantage of Reprieve
text: Last year, city education officials issued the Choir Academy of Harlem a death sentence. Unable to find its footing after a 2001 scandal that led to the demise of its founding organization, the famed Harlem Boys Choir, the school, along with 18 others, “lacked the capacity to improve student performance,” and would be closed, the city said.

headline: At La Scala, Budget-Cut Protests, Inside and Out
text: Tear gas canisters and smoke bombs were lobbed outside the Teatro alla Scala in Milan on Tuesday as the police battled protesters who denounced cuts in funding to cultural institutions. Inside, the conductor Daniel Barenboim lobbed a brickbat of his own. Before conducting “Die Wälkure” in La Scala’s season-opening gala performance, Mr. Barenboim spoke from the pit and urged Italy’s president, Giorgio Napolitano, who was present, to protect the arts, The Associated Press reported. “We are deeply worried for the future of culture in the country and in Europe,” the conductor was quoted as saying. The government is expected to soon announce decreases in spending on culture, including subsidies to La Scala and other opera houses in Italy.

headline: Class and the Culture War
text: My column yesterday plucked out one thread from the National Marriage Project’s depressing new report, “The Retreat from Marriage in Middle America,” and looked at the ways in which its findings complicate some of our stereotypes about the American culture war — in particular, the widespread understanding (one that I’ve perpetuated in my own writings) that less-educated Americans tend to be more religious and socially conservative than well-educated Americans. The “Retreat from Marriage” report suggests that this frame held up more strongly in the 1970s than it does today. On some questions (the morality of premarital sex, whether a divorce should become harder to obtain) well-educated and less-educated Americans seem to have converged over the last few decades, or else the less-educated have become more permissive than college graduates. At the same time, rates of churchgoing have fallen much faster among less-educated Americans than they have among college graduates, to the point where there’s now a strongly positive correlation between education and church attendance — one that didn’t exist in the ’70s. (The recent trend toward secularization, it turns out, may have been driven more by community college dropouts than by Richard Dawkins-reading Ph.Ds.)

headline: The Hurley Family Business
text: Basketball is in the blood of Danny Hurley, the first-year men’s coach at Wagner; his assistant Bobby Hurley, his brother; and their father, Bob Sr., the longtime coach at St. Anthony of Jersey City.

headline: Three Years After Private Equity Boom, an Exit Strategy
text: Private equity firms may finally have an exit strategy for deals made at the height of the buyout boom.

headline: Hey, Laddies
text: In case you hadn’t heard, the hipster is dead. But who will replace their enigmatic omnipresence? Matt Fox, proprietor of the Web store Fine and Dandy Shop, just may hold the answer. As a response to the sartorial disarray that has become au courant of late, Fox started his e-commerce site two years ago to peddle comely accessories to dandies and Beau Brummels alike. He’s shrewdly fixed his attentions on one-size-fits-all trimmings like bow ties, ascots and tie bars (a best seller) perfect for the rakish fop, and found an untapped market of eager fashionistos.

headline: The Ice Man Warneth
text: .CANCÚN, Mexico –- As the main plenary session at climate talks here was getting under way on Tuesday, I received word that Lonnie Thompson, a longtime student of ice and climate at Ohio State University, has a paper coming out in a behavior journal, The Behavior Analyst, concluding with unusual bluntness that humanity is in deep trouble. Thompson is an extraordinary scientist focused for decades (along with his equally remarkable wife, Ellen Mosley-Thompson) on direct observations of climate as well as evidence derived from ice cores extracted from glaciers around the world. He appears to have spent more time on ice fields above 18,000 feet than any human being in history. (The connection between glaciology and behavior will become clear below.)

headline: Nuclear ‘Renaissance’ Is Short on Largess
text: The federal aid now in place for new nuclear plants is far from sufficient for the so-called “nuclear renaissance” that backers are seeking, a panel made up of members of Congress, high-ranking federal officials and leaders of major nuclear companies agreed on Tuesday.

headline: Food, Recalled
text: Surveys show that Americans are concerned about food contamination, but experts say that recalls have only a short-term effect on consumers.

headline: Google Raises Curtain on Chrome OS Notebooks
text: Taking aim at Microsoft, Google on Tuesday showcased a test version of Chrome OS, its Internet-centric operating system, and began distributing a limited number of prototype PCs running the software.

headline: The Hippie Serving Peace and Breakfast
text: Yes, Virginia, there is a Santa Claus. A portly, bearded, 74-year-old hippie clown, born Hugh Nanton Romney but better known as Wavy Gravy, he has been sending ripples of good will that have gently lapped around the fringes of American culture for more than 50 years. The subject of Michelle Esrick’s doting documentary portrait, “Saint Misbehavin’: The Wavy Gravy Movie,” he is first seen practicing his morning prayers at his home in the Berkeley branch of the rural California commune known as the Hog Farm.

headline: Out of Paradise and Into the Pot: A Post-Communism Parable
text: Part nature study, part cold war allegory, “Rabbit à la Berlin” examines the human consequences of the Berlin Wall through the startled eyes of the wild rabbits that once flourished in the no man’s land on its eastern side. For almost 30 years the animals’ home — a 90-mile strip of succulent grass — was an oasis between Communism and capitalism, a verdant meadow ringed by barbed-wire fences and antitank barriers.

headline: Can Playing Chess Prevent Alzheimer’s Disease?
text: Chess can be diverting, amusing, engrossing, perplexing, exasperating, infuriating, and a few other things. But is it good for your mental health?

text: Apple has trained customers, investors, bloggers and technology pundits to expect its products to be revamped on a yearly basis. The iPhone, for example, first went on sale late in June 2007. The iPhone 3G followed in July 2008, and the iPhone 3GS in June 2009. The iPhone 4 arrived in June 2010.

headline: Dark Chocolate but Still Dulce de Leche

Now, also from Argentina, is dark chocolate dulce de leche, thick and not too sweet. Spread it on a peanut butter sandwich or on toast with sea salt and you might retire that jar of Nutella.

headline: Restaurant Owners Who Rule the Dining Room
text: THE death last week of the restaurateur Elaine Kaufman, who ruled Elaine’s on upper Second Avenue for the better part of five decades, was a blow for a struggling population in the ecosystem of Manhattan restaurants: the owner who is also a host. Restaurateurs of Ms. Kaufman’s ilk — men and women who begin and end their days in their dining rooms — were once the norm in a certain kind of Manhattan restaurant. They were invested both in the pleasure of their customers and in the business that brought it. They were curators, working as the help.

text: Harney & Sons has opened its first retail store in Manhattan (below). Over 200 loose teas are sold by the ounce, or prepacked in tins, and in whole-leaf mesh bags for convenient brewing. headline: When News Events Are Retold Onstage
text: The artists of the theater company the Civilians began “In the Footprint: The Battle Over Atlantic Yards,” an acclaimed new show about the controversial development project in Brooklyn, the same way a reporter approaches an article. They researched and conducted interviews, transcribing, condensing and ordering the material into a coherent narrative. The result resembles a staged work of the kind of passionate long-form journalism that has become too rare. With songs.

text: In search of slivers of optimism the day after he suffered the worst loss of his coaching career, Rex Ryan reached deep into his memory. What surfaced was a lopsided football game played on Dec. 2, 1985.

text: WASHINGTON  About one in four former detainees who have been transferred out of the Guantánamo Bay military prison are confirmed or suspected by American intelligence agencies of having engaged in terrorist activities after their release, the Obama administration said Tuesday.

headline: In Sweden, Sex Assault Gets Little Tolerance
text: When Julian Assange, the founder of WikiLeaks, asked two Swedish women out on dates in August, he may not have known that Swedish laws protecting women in their sexual encounters include wide-ranging definitions of sexual assault and rape.

headline: Is Julian Assange Helping the Neocons?
text: It turns out our government has been lying to us about whether we have troops in Pakistan engaging in combat operations. The Pentagon has said the mission of American soldiers is confined to “training Pakistani forces so that they can in turn train other Pakistani military,” but in fact our forces have been embedded in Pakistani fighting units, giving them electronic data and other support as they kill the enemy.

headline: A Gentlemen’s Agreement at the White House
text: Washington, Dec. 8, 1860

headline: Still Digging
text: Given where we are, this tax-cut deal with the Republicans is the best President Obama could do since raising taxes in a recession would not have been a good idea and the Republicans had the votes to prevent it. But given where we need to go, this deal is just another shot of morphine to a country that needs to do things that are big and hard and still only wants to do things that are easy and small. It still feels to me as though we’re splitting the difference between the two parties, not making a difference for the country as a whole.

headline: Icahn-Lions Gate Epic: No Hollywood Ending
text: The battle between Carl C. Icahn and Lions Gate Entertainment invites comparison with the studio’s movies. Is it a slasher movie akin to “Saw”? An action film along the lines of “Kick-Ass”? Or perhaps it is something new, a cold and calculating thriller showing the perils of shareholder activism.

headline: New York Teachers Still in Idle Limbo
text: For her first assignment of the school year, Verona Gill, a $100,000-a-year special education teacher whom the city is trying to fire, sat around education offices in Lower Manhattan for two weeks, waiting to be told what to do.

headline: Out of Prison, and Suited Up for a Future
text: By the time Trumont Williams was 12, he was pocketing $30 to $50 a day as a lookout for crack dealers. This was in the late 1980s, when the drug was ravaging the South Bronx.

headline: Time Served for Woman Once Called ‘No. 1 Escort’
text: Before there was Anna or Ashley, the pinup crime figures of the moment, there was Natalie  or Natalia, as she was known in the trade. Five years after her 15 minutes of fame, Natalie McLennan was sentenced to time served on Tuesday after pleading guilty to a charge of attempted money laundering in connection with her involvement in an upscale prostitution ring.

headline: As Hotel of Stars and Grit Faces Uncertain Future, the City Shrugs
text: The Chelsea Hotel seems like the last place that would go quietly into the night. After all, some of the last century’s most notorious deaths took place within its walls. It was where Sid Vicious’s girlfriend, Nancy Spungen, was stabbed to death. Where Dylan Thomas stayed during his last drinking spree. On the flip side were the boldface lives lived there: Arthur Miller, Marilyn Monroe, Bob Dylan, Patti Smith, Mark Twain, Jean-Paul Sartre, Frida Kahlo and Tennessee Williams were among the dozens of illuminati who once called the Chelsea home.

headline: Biden and G.O.P. Leader Helped Hammer Out Bipartisan Tax Accord
text: WASHINGTON  As a bipartisan group of Congressional tax writers opened widely watched negotiations last Wednesday over what to do about expiring tax cuts, a secret set of tax talks was taking place just steps off the Senate floor.

headline: Cuomo Pension Inquiry on Financier Grows Nasty
text: In conversations with people in her social circle these days, Maureen White, the wife of the financier Steven L. Rattner, shares a dark prediction: embarrassing information will soon surface about how Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo has handled an investigation involving her husband.

headline: Pakistan: Provincial Minister Escapes Assassination
text: The chief minister of Baluchistan Province escaped an assassination attempt early Tuesday in the provincial capital of Quetta, when an explosion set off by a suicide bomber rocked his convoy, said Abid Notkani, the Quetta police chief. There was no immediate claim of responsibility. The chief minister, Mohammad Aslam Khan Raisani, was unhurt; his chief security officer and several policemen were wounded. Baluchistan Province borders Iran and Afghanistan and makes up one-third of Pakistan’s territory.

headline: Canada: Report Criticizes Police Crackdown
text: A report released Tuesday by the ombudsman for the province of Ontario found that a secret regulation used to detain protesters at the June meeting of the leaders of the Group of 20 in Toronto had “dubious legality” and probably violated the Canadian Constitution by creating “extravagant police authority.” The report is one of a series of inquires into actions by the police during the meeting. About 1,100 people were arrested, including many bystanders; only 278 were ultimately charged. André Marin, the ombudsman, said that regulations enacted under a World War II-vintage law on sabotage had given the police “ ‘go directly to jail’ cards,” and that the police had exceeded even those exceptional powers.

headline: Lottery Numbers

During the resulting media coverage, surprisingly little attention was focused on a corollary topic. What about nonalcoholic energy drinks, which will remain on sale? Are they safe? Effective? Who should be drinking them? Who shouldn’t?

headline: Unguarded Moments: John Lennon in the Studio

The sessions lasted just over a month: Lennon’s idea, at that time, was that recordings should be a form of journalism — that once he had an idea, he should pop into the studio, record it quickly and with few production flourishes, and get it out.

headline: Now Sparkling | Alexis Bittar Heads West
text: West Coast fans of the jewelry designer Alexis Bittar now have three stores where they can view his creations. Last week, the Brooklyn-based jeweler opened a shop on Abbot Kinney in Venice, Calif., another on West Third Street in Los Angeles, and next week he’ll open on Filmore Street in Pacific Heights in San Francisco. Expanding at a time when many other designers are just staying above water may be a bold move. But Bittar believes “it’s a great time to come into new cities with a force.” He chose Los Angeles, in particular, because he feels the city, along with New York, “shapes the country in terms of trends.” San Francisco, on the other hand, is a revenue leader for the company; the new shop will cater to a woman Bittar describes as being more “artistic, with a personality more like New York City women.” The boutiques’ décor incorporates 1930s wallpaper that’s been sprayed with graffiti, along with a smattering of the taxidermy groupings that have become a Bittar design statement. “We’re creating animal hybrids with these, like putting swan wings on a gazelle,” he says. “On a theatric level, having a store is great. And I think it makes shopping fun.”

headline: Shoe In | Pierre Hardy’s New Digs
text: The artist Dan Graham has not gone into retail design as far as we know, but you could easily mistake Pierre Hardy’s first United States boutique, in the West Village, for one of Graham’s installations. His glass and mirror pavilions, which are often plunked down into incongruous environments (say, a forest or the roof of the former DIA building in Chelsea), play tricks on the eye, integrating the spectator into the structure’s reflected surfaces. “He’s my dream artist,” Hardy said earlier this week, acknowledging the homage. His shop, at 30 Jane Street, which was designed by David Mann of MR. Architecture + Decor is a little jewel box — all smokey brown glass and mirrors; its situation, ensconced within the rough and crudely patched walls of a historic carriage house, feels both serene and strangely precarious. “It’s exactly the opposite of Paris,” Hardy explained. “There you have historical places you can’t touch and you have to work with it. Here we had to destroy and rebuild everything because what was here was unusable. We tried to do something more precious in the middle of something more raw.” A particularly Grahamesque touch comes in the form of two large plates of interlocking glass that section off the 1,400-square-foot space into semi-private cubbies so you can catch furtive glimpses of the woman trying on Hardy’s special New York “Skyline” shoes next to you (Um, excuse me, do those come in my size?), and still maintain the illusion that you have the place all to yourself.

headline: The Scarlet “U” of Unemployment

headline: Who Wants to Be Pat Buchanan?
text: Matt Bai’s piece on the possibility of a primary challenger to Obama reminds me of this exchange between Ed Kilgore and Jay Cost, which took place just before the great tax cut bargain/sell-out sent the American left into a tailspin. Kilgore argued that Obama was secure from the risk of a primary challenge, because there’s no sign that “a coherent bloc of Democratic voters—whether liberal or moderate” have soured on the president. Even when Democrats tell pollsters that they’d like another option in 2012, they can’t agree on what kind of option it should be: “Given a choice of hypothetical challenges, 39 percent of Democrats and leaners preferred a candidate from the left of the president, and 40 percent a candidate from the right.”

headline: Parents Embrace Documentary on Pressures of School
text: It isn’t often that a third of a movie audience sticks around to discuss its message, but that is the effect of “Race to Nowhere,” a look at the downside of childhoods spent on résumé-building.

headline: Republicans Name Leaders of House Committees
text: House Republicans have chosen the members who will lead each of the chamber’s 17 committees when the new Congress convenes in January.

headline: Parsons Says Citi Too ‘Interwoven’ to Fail
text: Richard D. Parsons, the chairman of Citigroup, says his bank and other major financial institutions are part of the fabric of the economy and integral to the United States’ global power.

headline: Seattle Police Using Twitter to Recover Stolen Cars
text: Car thefts are on the rise in Seattle — nearly 10 a day, and up from 8.46 a day — and the Seattle Police Department is turning to social media to help nab the criminals and recover the stolen cars.

headline: What We’re Reading: Abolishing the Death Penalty to Save Money
text: Links from around the Web.

headline: Top Lobbyist Ensnared in Pension Fund Scandal
text: One of Albany’s most prominent lobbyists reached a settlement with Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo after being accused of dangling offers to win business as part of Mr. Cuomo’s investigation of the state pension fund, his office announced on Wednesday.

headline: Celebrating 'Revelations' at 50
text: A film produced and directed by Judy Kinberg, will be shown prior to Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater performances of the work at New York City Center through January 2nd.  For more information visit www.alvinailey.org (Photo of Alvin Ailey and Judith Jamison by Jack Mitchell).

headline: Bond Vigilantes, Still Invisible
text: US long-term interest rates have risen somewhat in the wake of the debt deal — and sure enough, we’re hearing warnings about “bond vigilantes” again.

headline: Hellos and Goodbyes
text: After defensive lineman Albert Haynesworth spent most of the N.F.L. season inventing ways to be named the year’s worst employee, the Redskins finally banished him on Tuesday, which means he can now not try to contribute to his team’s efforts from the comfort of his own home for the final four games. Soon, Haynesworth will likely take to the airwaves, his preferred method of self-expression, to try again to explain his complete disdain for actually tackling anyone. And we have come up with an excuse for him: he expended all his energy last week figuring out if the Nationals could pony up enough money to join the Cliff Lee sweepstakes.

headline: Climate Science Survives Climate Diplomacy
text: CANCÚN, Mexico — There’s evidence here that science can survive the intense tussles over information that can occur when big policy decisions are shaped by a body of research.

headline: Senate Removes Louisiana Judge
text: The Senate on Wednesday found Judge G. Thomas Porteous Jr. of Federal District Court in Louisiana guilty on four articles of impeachment, the first time the Senate has removed a federal judge from the bench in more than two decades.

headline: 10 Apps That Make Magic on Your iPad
text: When Steve Jobs introduced the iPad and referred to it as a magical device, lots of people snickered.

headline: Walker, Troubled in Retirement, Wants a Comeback

headline: Democrat Wins Minnesota Governor’s Race
text: Tom Emmer, the Republican candidate for governor of Minnesota, conceded the race to the Democrat Mark Dayton on Wednesday morning, ending the last undecided governor’s race from the 2010 midterm elections.

headline: Education Spending and Those International Test Scores
text: As my colleague Sam Dillon reported on Tuesday, China gave the rest of the world a run for its money in the Program for International Student Assessment, a test administered to 15-year-olds around the world. But how might money actually have affected these test scores?

headline: Now Shaking | Savory Cocktails
text: So this mushroom walks into a bar. Yes, I thought I’d heard this one before as well (and really, it never gets old), but it turns out that fungi are no joking matter at the Library Bar tucked inside the Hollywood Roosevelt Hotel. On a recent Wednesday night, I asked the bartender Matthew Biancaniello what he was aging in a mini oak barrel on the counter behind him. “I’m infusing bourbon with candy cap mushrooms,” he said.

headline: Union Plan Shows Gulf in N.B.A. Labor Talks
text: The standoff between owners and players in the N.B.A. is measured mostly in dollars and rhetoric. But the divide runs deeper, with competing goals and divergent visions of what a healthy league should look like.

headline: Off the Menu: Elsewhere

headline: In the Next Broadway Development, Jeffrey Tambor Joins ‘La Cage aux Folles’
text: With Kelsey Grammer preparing to depart the Broadway production of “La Cage aux Folles” in February, is there another television star who can bring to the role of Georges an equal level of erudition and dignity that’s begging to be chipped away? Hey now! It turns out there is.

headline: Blatter Calls English ‘Bad Losers’

headline: Remembering Senator Edward M. Kennedy
text: Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts, the last surviving brother of a generation of Kennedys that dominated American politics in the 1960s, has died. He was 77.

headline: Man Arrested in Bomb Plot in Maryland
text: WASHINGTON  A 21-year-old recent convert to Islam tried to blow up a military recruiting station in a Baltimore suburb on Wednesday, ensnaring himself in a sting operation orchestrated by the Federal Bureau of Investigation, law enforcement officials said.

headline: Report Finds Problems in Housing Repair Program
text: A program aimed at forcing errant landlords to repair the city’s worst buildings has not yielded the results that local officials hoped for: only about a quarter of the $17 million the city has spent on repairs has been paid back, according to an article in The Times on Wednesday.

headline: Market Watch | Savant’s Scanty Side
text: “It’s a small collection,” says Feng-Feng Yeh, the designer and founder of Savant, her very first lingerie line, “but this collection is so Feng-Feng!” (Pronounced Fun-Fun.) The lingerie market may be new territory for the ready-to-wear designer, but Savant already has its own identity. “You see the high-waisted short shorts and the caged bralette? That’s Savant,” says Yeh.

headline: Intellectual Ventures Goes to Court
text: Intellectual Ventures, the big investment firm that has bought up 30,000 patents, has long held out the threat of patent litigation against companies that do not agree to licensing agreements.

headline: After Dispute Over Video, Curators to Discuss Smithsonian Show

But those not on the royal guest list can always tackle urban reality in his fur vest and leather leggings.

headline: Any Kardashians in Your Closet?
text: WE started trading e-mails the night before under the subject line “Which Kardashian are you?” Fleur was “a Khloé with a strong undercurrent of Kourtney”; Bolt, “a Khloé with Kim rising.” Ace pleaded ignorance, though she’s a Kim, through and through. Me, probably more Kourtney than I’d care to admit, so let’s say mostly Kim and call it a day.

headline: On Our Radar: Ethanol Subsidies in Tax Deal, Group Says
text: A measure to extend tax credits for domestic ethanol production, set to expire at year’s end, is “part of the deal” in negotiations over a sweeping tax bill in the Senate, according to a statement by the Renewable Fuel Association, an industry group. “The final details — the length of the extension and the value of the credit –are still being discussed,” the association says. [Reuters]

headline: Designing Against the Odds
text: THE market for young designers, we are often reminded, is both booming and brutal. Stores and magazines have become increasingly receptive to new faces in the last decade; and yet the rush of new talent has made fashion all the more competitive.

headline: How Stimulating Is the Tax Cut-Jobless Benefit Deal? Part II
text: Yesterday we posted some forecasts from the Center for American Progress, a liberal research organization, on the stimulative effects of the new Bush tax cuts/jobless benefits compromise. The center’s estimates were largely based on models created by Mark Zandi, the chief economist at Moody’s Analytics; today, Mr. Zandi himself is weighing in.

headline: Keeping It Local
text: IF a person’s happiness is inversely proportional to the length of his commute, then John McDonald might be the most contented guy in his downtown Manhattan neighborhood. The buttery-smooth scene-maker’s kingdom includes two restaurants, a style magazine and a celebrity-filled bar  all based on the same street where he lives. “It’s one block, one street: Mercer between Houston and Prince,” Mr. McDonald said proudly.

headline: 81 Die in Chilean Prison Fire
text: SANTIAGO, Chile  At least 81 inmates were killed after a fire broke out during a fight in an overcrowded prison here in the Chilean capital, in what officials described as the worst disaster in the history of the country’s troubled prison system. Many of the prisoners in the stricken wing were first-time offenders.

headline: German Director Plunges Beyond His Comfort Zone
text: After his very first feature film, the small-budget political thriller “The Lives of Others,” won the 2007 Academy Award for best foreign-language film, the German director Florian Henckel von Donnersmarck was besieged with offers of work. A new talent had announced itself, and there was much curiosity about what he would choose to follow his bleak examination of betrayal and moral corruption in East Germany.

headline: The Feds Stage a Sideshow, While the Big Tent Sits Empty
text: Jesse Eisinger is a reporter for ProPublica, an independent, nonprofit newsroom that produces investigative journalism in the public interest.

headline: Meyer Steps Down as Coach at Florida
text: One year ago, Florida Coach Urban Meyer was so gaunt from stress-related health problems that he lost 25 pounds and his shorts sagged far below his waist. When he announced he was resigning, few who spent time around him every day were surprised.

headline: Blue-Eyed Soul Veterans Play for Themselves
text: There they stand, three stone-cold killers. That guy McDonald, he’s a worker. He means every note, every howl, slaughtering so effortlessly you hardly notice the blood. Scaggs looks as if he’s at the tail end of one very, very unhappy bender, his chill utterly frightening. And Fagen, behind the sunglasses, head jerking at odd angles? He’ll cut you as soon as look at you, that one.

headline: The Long Distances Between Co-Workers
text: Rachel Bonds seems to know something about loss. Her play “Anniversary,” about a woman trying to find herself again after the death of a loved one, was a standout of the Ensemble Studio Theater’s one-act festival last June, and now “Michael & Edie” is proving that Ms. Bonds can sustain the sublime tone of the earlier play in a full-length piece.

headline: Got Game? Learning With Puzzles
text: Overview  | What skills are involved in both solving and creating puzzles? What kinds of thinking do puzzles engage? In this lesson, students solve word puzzles and learn about how master solvers approach and develop them. They develop their own problem-solving skills by composing word puzzles or games of their own and come away with a perspective on the cognitive and learning benefits of games.

headline: Girardi Says Lee Is ‘Important to Us’
text: ORLANDO, Fla. – Manager Joe Girardi is usually coy about the Yankees’ intentions. Not so with Cliff Lee, whom he twice called “the complete package” on Wednesday. Asked whether he viewed Lee as a want or a need, Girardi was direct in saying that Lee is “important to us.”

headline: The Chain Purse Leaves Hands Free
text: NAVIGATING the holiday party season is a whole lot easier when you ditch the cumbersome clutch for a swingy little purse hanging from a chic chain you can sling across your chest.

headline: Oedipus’ Mom Explains It All to You

headline: No Black Tie, No Problem at a Benefit at Bellevue
text: Dr. Jeffrey Manko was having one of those wardrobe anxiety moments Tuesday night as he prepared to go to the V.I.P. cocktail party at Bellevue Hospital Center. There he was in the bloody, hectic emergency room, while not far away, in the tranquility of the Bellevue atrium, designed by I. M. Pei, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg was standing below a 20-foot Christmas tree delivering ceremonial remarks about the good cause of public hospitals to a politely inattentive, wine-sipping audience of City Health and Hospitals Corporation administrators and supporters.How to dress for what Dr. Manko assumed to be a black-tie event when he did not even have a blue blazer handy? Being professionally trained in the art of improvisation, Dr. Manko threw his doctor’s coat with the royal purple Bellevue emblem on it over his blue oxford shirt, khakis and sneakers and strolled out to the party, resplendent in his antiseptic whiteness among the women in cocktail dresses and sparkly necklaces and the men in dark suits.

headline: Former N.B.A. Center Plays to a Different Crowd
text: MIAMI BEACH — When Rony Seikaly was a young teenager in Athens, long before he grew into a 6-foot-11 all-American basketball player at Syracuse and a productive N.B.A. center, he built a small disco at home.

headline: Tech Jobs Took Hit in 2009, Report Says

headline: Play With Smoke, Not Fire
text: WOMEN seeking to amp up their look for holiday parties can look to some of the recent runway shows for an updated and user-friendly smoky eye, which many (especially those with natural shadows) avoid for fear of looking like a raccoon or a wounded prizefighter. Models at Valentino, Ruffian, Vena Cava and Blumarine all sported softer versions that blended dark and shimmery eye shadows.

headline: Rare Brough Superior Motorcycle for Sale at Phillips de Pury
text: The black motorcycle sits in a show window on Park Avenue in Manhattan, sharing shopping attention with an auction of jewelry at Phillips de Pury.

headline: Global Puck: Team USA’s Amazing Road to 2004 Bronze
text: USA Hockey had an extraordinary season in 2009-10, quite possibly the finest in the nation’s international hockey history. Consider: The United States won silver at the Olympics in both the men’s and women’s events, gold at the U20, gold at the U18 for men, and silver at the U18 for women. The only blemish was a disappointing 13th-place finish at the I.I.H.F. World Championship in Germany at season’s end.

headline: How I Saved My Company: CompletePT
text: In 2009, CompletePT Pool and Land Physical Therapy had its best year ever, with revenue of more than $3 million. But then, starting in January 2010, the company had to confront a series of setbacks that included insurance reimbursement issues, unexpected delays in a pool-remodeling project and an employee who was engaging in unauthorized borrowing.

headline: ‘Operation Payback’ Attacks Fell Visa.com
text: Last Updated | 6:54 p.m. A group of Internet activists took credit for crashing the Visa.com Web site on Wednesday afternoon, hours after they launched a similar attack on MasterCard. The cyber attacks, by activists who call themselves Anonymous, are aimed at punishing companies that have acted to stop the flow of donations to WikiLeaks in recent days.

headline: Vain Glorious | Zirh’s New Serum for Men
text: What: Restore, Zirh’s new anti-aging serum.

headline: ‘Blue Valentine’ Sheds NC-17 Rating
text: Ending weeks of artistic protests and online hand wringing, the Motion Picture Association of America has reversed its decision to award “Blue Valentine,” the marital drama starring Ryan Gosling and Michelle Williams, an NC-17 rating. After a final appeal by Harvey Weinstein and Co. today, the film, which has earned attention as much for its finely tuned performances as for any explicit content, will now be rated R, which should help its awards chances. (Ms. Williams and Mr. Gosling are both indie darlings and previous Oscar nominees.) The vote by the board was apparently unanimous.

headline: Hitting Home: How Is Your Community Dealing With Budget Woes?
text: Police officers are being laid off. Firehouses are going dark. Several states have released prisoners early, more to save money than for good behavior. And Arizona will no longer pay for certain organ transplants for people in its Medicaid program. The Great Recession has taken a big toll on the finances of state and local governments, and with federal stimulus money running out many governments will continue to have to scramble to make ends meet. Join Times correspondents Thursday in a conversation about how state and local governments are dealing with budget woes. Ask a question or share your story about what is happening in your town or state. Use the comments area below or respond via Twitter using the hashtag #nytchat. Be as specific as possible.

headline: Bettman Says Head Shot Rules to Remain; LaFontaine Urges Zero Tolerance
text: N.H.L. Commissioner Gary Bettman said the league’s legislation against hits to the head would remain in place for the foreseeable future.

headline: Bold Crossings of the Gender Line
text: IT’S certainly a statement on our times that, in the same month, James Franco graces the covers of GQ and Candy. In GQ, he appears in a moody head shot. In Candy, a style magazine dedicated to what it calls the “transversal”  that is, transsexuality, transvestism, cross-dressing, androgyny and any combination thereof  Mr. Franco, shot by Terry Richardson, vamps in trowel-applied makeup, heavy jewelry and a woman’s dominatrix-style power suit.

headline: Florida Officials Expected to Grant Jim Morrison a Pardon

Charlie Crist to hand out a posthumous pardon for Jim Morrison, the lead singer for the Doors. The pardon would come 40 years after Morrison was convicted of indecent exposure after a rowdy profanity-laced concert at the Dinner Key Auditorium in Miami.

headline: The Selling of a Long Shot

Over Elk bourguignon and pepper-smoked Spanish mackerel, the gregarious Ms. Steen beguiled a room full of journalists and industry players with her stories and banter, which of course was the whole idea, even if a few of the attendees were a little fuzzy about exactly which northern European country she actually came from.

text: 1. President Obama extends tax cuts and includes those making more than $250,000 a year. Super-rich spared introduction to crude form of pâté called meatloaf.

headline: Contador Doping Decision Expected to Come Soon
text: Alberto Contador’s doping case may progress more quickly than expected, his lawyer Andy Ramos said Tuesday.

headline: Salesforce.com Offers $212 Million for Heroku
text: It is not the blockbuster deal the technology sector was hoping for this month, but Heroku’s investors should be pleased.

headline: Verdict Against J.&J. in Levaquin Case
text: In a closely watched case, a federal jury on Wednesday awarded a Minnesota resident $1.82 million after finding that Johnson & Johnson had failed to adequately warn patients that its antibiotic Levaquin may cause tendon damage.

headline: Just One Look | Calvin Klein Pre-Fall Collection
text: The Pre-Fall Collections, being shown in New York over the next several weeks, arrive in stores in May to fill the gap between bikinis and furs.

headline: Turning Off Autocorrect on the iPad
Charity Guessing Game: Who Will Join Gates and Buffett?
text: The word in the philanthropic world is that Bill Gates and Warren E. Buffett are planning to announce 15 more signatories to the Giving Pledge they started last summer, bringing the total number of billionaires and multimillionaires committed to giving away at least half their wealth to 65.

headline: The S.E.C. Goes Global With Insider Trading, Again
text: The international flair of the Securities and Exchange Commission continued on Wednesday when it filed suit against unnamed investors who bought Wimm-Bill-Dann Foods shares in the days before the PepsiCo agreed to buy the Russian beverage company.

headline: George H.W. Bush Endorses Arms Treaty
text: 5:51 p.m. | Updated Former President George H.W. Bush, who signed and won Senate approval of the original Start arms control treaty with the Soviet Union in 1991, endorsed the proposed follow-up treaty with Russia on Wednesday, lending another well-known Republican voice to the White House campaign for approval.

headline: Inside the Decorated Diplomatic Reception Rooms
text: David Stark, the event planner, brought holiday chic to rooms at the State Department.

headline: Afghan War Officer-Training Program Lags, but Makes Progress
text: WASHINGTON  A high-priority Pentagon program to train a cadre of officers with special skills for the Afghan war has recovered from a number of start-up stumbles, but is still less than halfway to its numerical goal at the one-year mark, according to senior Pentagon officials.

headline: Former Environmental Commissioner to Run Prospect Park
text: Prospect Park has a new leader with a long history of helping keep the city green. Emily Lloyd, a former commissioner of the city Department of Environmental Protection and the Department of Sanitation, has been chosen to replace the park’s longtime administrator, Tupper Thomas.

headline: 8 Charged in Sewage Dumping in Brooklyn Creek
text: Four people and four businesses at a Brooklyn shopping center face criminal charges over the dumping of raw sewage and restaurant grease into Shell Bank Creek in Sheepshead Bay, home to bluefish, crab, striped bass and other fish, in addition to a marina.

headline: Radiation Rules Differ for Humans and Pets
text: WASHINGTON  One group receiving treatment for a thyroid disorder is given a radioactive drug that makes the patients a potential hazard to children or pregnant women for several days. Still, doctors usually send them home immediately after treatment.

headline: Behind Camera, Checking the Ego
text: David O. Russell does not have the reputation of an evenhanded filmmaker. Depending on whom you talk to, Mr. Russell, whose work includes the Persian Gulf war satire “Three Kings” and the existential corporate comedy “I Heart Huckabees,” is quixotic, combative and occasionally brilliant.

headline: The Wolfe Building
text: To the Editor:

headline: Onstage in Milan, Shadowy Giants Visible in New York
text: Say this for Robert Lepage’s unfolding production of Wagner’s “Ring” cycle at the Metropolitan Opera: the concept is likely to have a certain unity and consistency. There is, after all, only so much you can do to distract from the workings of the giant mechanism that dominates the stage.

headline: An Eye for Detail, and Plenty of Pop
text: “STYLE is, like, the wrapping paper of my life.”

headline: Backers Rev Up Oil Sands Campaign
text: Haven’t heard of the Keystone XL pipeline project yet? That’s about to change.

headline: Misbehaving, but Plenty of Regrets
text: The first song T. I. performs on “VH1 Storytellers: T. I.,” which will have its premiere on Friday night, is “Still Ain’t Forgave Myself,” a catalog of his misdeeds going back to childhood: “Started interacting with fiends at the age of 13/Now my mama finding rocks in my socks/Glocks in my toy box.”

headline: Folky Strokes, With Dabs of News, Video and Static
text: For a composer generally described as contemporary classical, Minimalist or avant-garde, Mikel Rouse has recently been getting almost folky.

headline: Does Music Trump Story? More Answers to Your Broadway Questions
text: Yesterday, Larry Stempel, the author of the new book “Showtime: A History of the Broadway Musical Theater,” answered readers’ questions about lyric writing, guilty pleasures and other topics. Today Mr. Stempel takes a look at the music vs. lyrics debate, short runs and more. His final set of answers will be posted tomorrow.

headline: Gift Ideas for Photo Hobbyists? It’s a Snap
text: IF self-respecting photography lovers haven’t received a digital single-lens reflex camera as a gift by now, they have probably broken down and bought one for themselves. You might think that leaves the camera buff’s loved ones plaintively wailing, “Now what do we get him? He already has a camera.”

headline: Filling First Base in Chicago
text: Within hours of each other on Wednesday, the Cubs and White Sox came to terms with free-agent power-hitting first basemen.

headline: Exploring Variations in a Christmastime Favorite
text: The predictable charms of the annual performances of Handel’s “Messiah” at St. Thomas Church on Fifth Avenue, invariably among the best in New York, have mainly to do with the St. Thomas Choir of Men and Boys, directed by John Scott, and Concert Royal, the period-instrument orchestra directed by James Richman. They do not necessarily involve the guest vocal soloists, who, though sometimes excellent, can be uneven.

headline: 8 Charged With Polluting Brooklyn Creek
text: Four people and four businesses in a Brooklyn shopping center — including a T.G.I. Friday’s and a movie theater — face criminal charges that they dumped raw sewage and restaurant grease into Shell Bank Creek, the short body of water that separates the oceanside neighborhoods of Sheepshead Bay and Gerritsen Beach. The creek is home to bluefish, crab, striped bass and other fish, in addition to a marina. Read about the charges on the Green blog. »

headline: CBS Wins Again
text: Crime shows lifted CBS to No. 1 on Tuesday as a rerun of “NCIS” led the night with 11.8 million viewers at 8 p.m. and “NCIS: Los Angeles” drew 10.4 million at 9. A Christmas-theme episode of Fox’s “Glee” led in the important demographic of viewers 18 to 49 as the episode (11 million) easily outperformed its other 8 p.m. competitors: ABC’s special “A Charlie Brown Christmas” (8 million) and NBC’s game show “Minute to Win It” (7 million). Fox ranked second for the night in total viewers, NBC was third and ABC fourth.

headline: An Abandoned Men’s Club Is Now a Home
text: SELMA, Ala.

headline: A Renovation That Preserves the Decay
text: An industrial designer from Atlanta took an abandoned 20,000-square-foot building on the waterfront in Selma, Ala., and made into a home.

headline: Shopping With Harry Heissmann
text: An interior designer shopped for Christmas tree trimmings that look handmade or vintage.

headline: The Beekeeper Next Door
text: MIKE BARRETT does not have much of a yard at his two-story row house in Astoria, Queens. But that fact has not kept him from his new hobby of beekeeping  he put the hive on his roof. When it was harvest time this fall, he just tied ropes around each of the two honey-filled boxes in the hive, and lowered them to the ground.

headline: Orfeo Quagliata’s Sculptural Glass Cups
text: Orfeo Quagliata, a Mexico City glass artist, started working in the medium as a child, grinding and polishing as an apprentice to his father, Narcissus Quagliata. In the years since, he has produced glass jewelry and sculpture, as well as functional objects for the home.

headline: Forced From Home Yet Never Free of It
text: WITH each year, my childhood house grows bigger in my mind, each nook and corridor casting a longer shadow. The stone steps, about a hundred in total, appear elongated, as if they might reach the sky rather than the front gate. The pomegranate trees and forsythia that had once filled the garden have overgrown into a tropic wilderness, a meteorological miracle for South Korea. The pond, where I looked for the koi with their multiple colors, has turned into a reservoir as deep as the one in Central Park. Rising beyond it all are the peacocks from my father’s menagerie, and I wait, as I have always, for the magical fanning of their tails.

headline: Christmas Tree Trimmings
text: HARRY Heissmann, an interior designer who worked for Juan Pablo Molyneux and Albert Hadley before opening his own office last year, is passionate about Christmas. True, he sold his collection of antique cast-iron Christmas tree stands to help finance his move from Germany in 1995, but that only speaks to how much he wanted to live in New York.

headline: Sales From Judy Ross Textiles, Klein Reid and Others
text: Judy Ross Textiles will offer deep discounts on hand-embroidered stockings, pillows, hand-knotted rugs and runners at its holiday sample sale, through Saturday (an 18-inch chain-stitch pillow, below, originally $195 to $225, is $80; 3-by-6 runners, originally $1,620 to $2,070, are $750 to $800); 41 Union Square West (17th Street), Room 526, (212) 842-1705, judyrosstextiles.com.

headline: Brooklyn’s Seaport Flowers Expands Into Home Décor
text: For years, discerning flower buyers throughout New York City have turned to Amy Gardella at Seaport Flowers in Brooklyn Heights for her sophisticated, modern arrangements. Now that she has moved into a larger space off Atlantic Avenue, Ms. Gardella has expanded her offerings to include an array of home décor, including porcelain vases, lamps, botanic prints and vintage furniture.

headline: Care for a Bronze Cherry?
text: Malia Jensen, a 44-year-old artist in Brooklyn, considers her life-size painted bronze cherries and stainless steel bird feet to be small sculptures. But whether they are art, functional objects (paperweights?) or simply decorative, they are certainly tactile.

headline: A Restaurant Where the Ambience Is Jewel-Like
text: Beauty & Essex, a restaurant opening on Saturday on the Lower East Side, was designed by the Manhattan firm AvroKO to resemble a jewelry store that would sell “pieces kind of reminiscent of what my sophisticated grandmother had,” said Peter Kane, who owns this restaurant, and Stanton Social, with Richard Wolf and Chris Santos. “But with a Lower East Side sensibility.”

headline: David Stark on Washington Chic
text: Tucked away inside the sprawling Foggy Bottom complex in Washington that is the State Department are the Diplomatic Reception Rooms — 42 rooms, used daily by everyone from Secretary of State Hillary Clinton and President Obama to cabinet officials. This year, to celebrate the rooms’ 50th anniversary, the State Department teamed up with Time Inc. and InStyle. Ariel Foxman, the editor of InStyle, brought in David Stark, a New York event producer, to decorate a few of the rooms on the eighth floor of the department — those most frequently used for receptions and diplomacy, and the only ones open to the public — for the holidays.

headline: Voodoo, Vivid Colors and Strange Visions
text: Watching “Celebrating ‘Revelations’ at 50,” the film tribute by Judy Kinberg that precedes the piece during the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater’s current season, it’s notable how rough hewn  and powerful  the dancing looks in the historical footage of Ailey and others performing in that work. Today the Ailey dancers are sleek, athletic masters of the universe, and the pieces routinely draw midmovement applause and cheers for moments of virtuosity.

headline: Azzedine Alaïa’s Mark on Fashion
text: In a way, Mr. Alaïa’s place in the fashion world has remained constant.

headline: Azzedine Alaïa: The Master of the Female Form
text: ON the second floor of a former warehouse in the Marais quarter of Paris, the little man in the faded Chinese pajamas picked up the phone on the second ring. It was after 1 a.m., but few people who dialed his number at that hour expected to get a machine or a sleepy voice. They expected to get Azzedine Alaïa, the designer, and like an Arab grocery, he was open late.

headline: There’s a Nap for That
text: All due credit to Benjamin Stein for that headline, which accompanies his son’s handmade iPhone blanket.

headline: Behind the Camera, Checking the Ego
text: David O. Russell does not have the reputation of an evenhanded filmmaker. Depending on whom you talk to, Mr. Russell, whose work includes the Persian Gulf war satire “Three Kings” and the existential corporate comedy “I ♥ Huckabees,” is quixotic, combative and occasionally brilliant. For his latest film, “The Fighter,” a passion project brought to him by his frequent star Mark Wahlberg, Mr. Russell takes on the true story of Micky Ward and Dicky Eklund, brothers and struggling boxers from Lowell, Mass., near where Mr. Wahlberg grew up. He plays Micky, the quieter but more successful of the two, and Christian Bale , in an outsize, twitchy performance that is generating Oscar talk, plays Dicky, a recovering drug addict and a wiry charmer.

headline: Dumplings With the Kitchen God
text: In the historical novel “Under Fishbone Clouds” one character pauses to contemplate the failure of Chairman Mao’s Cultural Revolution and its grandiose plans to change the world. This character, a woman named Yuying, has grown old enough to smile wryly at those objectives.

headline: Iran Security Officials Arrest Four at Newspaper
text: TEHRAN — Security officials have raided one of Iran’s few remaining independent newspapers, arresting three journalists and a managing director, web sites associated with the political opposition reported Wednesday.

headline: A Melting Pot of ‘Nutcrackers’
text: A look at the holiday classic from the Lower East Side of Manhattan to Houston.

headline: ‘Nutcracker’ Nation: Yes We Can!
text: Snow lay in piles on the sidewalks in Salt Lake City, where I saw “The Nutcracker” danced in a theater that was two years old when Diaghilev’s Ballets Russes appeared there in 1917 and that was once a vaudeville house. In Houston the next day the temperature was around 65, and “The Nutcracker” was being staged in a grand 1980s opera house next to a bayou.

headline: Revisiting a Mellowed Pierre Boulez
text: Pierre Boulez celebrated his 85th birthday in March, and in keeping with the classical music world’s customarily expansive treatment of composers’ birthdays, the festivities have run through the year. The latest installment was a sold-out Composer Portraits concert at the Miller Theater on Monday evening. The virtuosic Talea Ensemble performed, and Mr. Boulez was on hand for a lively onstage interview with Ara Guzelimian, dean of the Juilliard School.

headline: Browsing: Shopping Snapshots for Dec. 9
text: New Gucci collection for children; Pierre Hardy opens his first U.S. store; sales, openings and events of the week.

headline: After West Starts With an Ace, Declarer Ponders the Meaning
text: At the Fall North American Championships in Orlando, Fla., on Sunday, the Reisinger Board-a-Match Teams was won by James Cayne of New York; Michael Seamon of Dania Beach, Fla.; and Giorgio Duboin, Antonio Sementa, Lorenzo Lauria and Alfredo Versace from Italy. They finished 0.38 points in front of Christal Welland-Henner and Roy Welland of New York, Steve Garner of Chicago, Howard Weinstein of San Diego, and Josef Piekarek and Alexander Smirnov from Germany.

headline: ‘Scared Straight’ Comes to Wall Street
text: The White Collar Watch columnist, Peter J. Henning, speaks to Amy Walsh, a former prosecutor, about the recent insider trading inquiry into hedge funds. Is the government’s extraordinary use of manpower and technology an effort to keep financial professionals looking over their shoulders?

headline: Providing Security in Juárez, Mexico
text: Miguel Macias runs the fastest-growing security firm in Juárez, where drug violence has spiked.

headline: Nightlife in New York, Dec. 9 to 14
text: A PREVIEW of the must-attend parties, talked-about openings and fashionable night spots for the week ahead.

headline: Facebook Welcome Groups for Freshmen Now Appear Less Official
text: More than 150 Facebook groups that appeared to be official welcome sites for the prospective freshman classes at colleges and universities were altered Wednesday, to make clear that they exist partly as a marketing tool for a commercial, roommate-matching service known as Roomsurf.

headline: Lucy Sykes Rellie’s Birthday Dinner
text: AS guests filtered in for her 41st birthday party, Lucy Sykes Rellie, the British-born socialite and fashion designer, was instructing the owners of the Park Avenue Tavern to turn the lights down and the music up.

headline: 'Scared Straight' Comes to Wall Street
text: White Collar Watch columnist Peter J. Henning speaks to Amy Walsh, a former prosecutor, about the recent insider-trading inquiry into hedge funds. Is the government’s extraordinary use of manpower and technology an effort to keep financial professionals looking over their shoulders?

headline: For First-Timer, an Icy Challenge
text: Jeff Vervoort, left, an associate professor in radiogenic isotope geochemistry at Washington State University, and John Goodge, a professor of geological sciences at the University of Minnesota-Duluth, will be writing occasional posts from their research expedition in Antarctica.

headline: Champions League: See You in February
text: The group stage of the UEFA Champions League concluded on Wednesday with Arsenal, Shakhtar Donetsk and Roma claiming the final three berths in the 16-team first knockout stage, which begins in February.

headline: Summerall Reflects on the Mesmerizing Lombardi and the Analytical Landry
text: Pat Summerall is best known as the former lead voice of N.F.L. games for CBS and Fox, not as a kicker and occasional tight end and defensive end for the Chicago Cardinals and the Giants. His new book, “Giants: What I Learned About Life From Vince Lombardi and Tom Landry,” recalls the influence exerted by Lombardi, who coached the Giants’ offense, and Landry, who coached their defense, on him and the team. Once Summerall became a Giant in 1958, he sat in on the offensive and defensive meetings. It was the season when the Giants lost to the Baltimore Colts, 23-17, in overtime, in the N.F.L. championship game.

headline: A Poison Pill Cure at Fortune Brands
text: Fortune Brands has found an antidote for its poison pill. The odd combination of liquor, golf clubs and faucets never made sense. The conglomerate structure also dissuaded specialist rivals from making takeover bids. Carving up the company should solve the problem.

headline: An Insider Case of Life Borrowing From Art
text: A bit of unsolicited advice for any DealBook readers thinking about evading the law: when engaging in insider trading from your online brokerage account, don’t borrow code names from the most famous, albeit fictional, insider trade of all time.

headline: From Retired Brands, Dollars and Memories
text: THERE are auctions of old paintings, old books and even old bottles of wine. Now, old brand names can be added to the list.

headline: Sex Offender Is Indicted in Killing Two Years Ago
text: Two years after a 25-year-old woman vanished after leaving a nightclub in Manhattan, the man who has long been considered by investigators to be the main suspect in the case has been indicted on murder charges, the authorities announced on Wednesday.

headline: Hackers Give Web Companies a Test of Free Speech
text: A hacking free-for-all has exploded on the Web, and Facebook and Twitter are stuck in the middle.

headline: Yahoo Revamps Local Pages
text: Yahoo is giving its local listings — a strictly functional service akin to the Yellow Pages — a makeover.

headline: N.F.L. Invites Helmet Safety Ideas
text: With the federal government, state legislatures and football helmets’ regulatory body already focusing on concussions and head protection, perhaps the most influential group of all  the N.F.L.  convened its own summit of experts Wednesday to discuss possible reforms.

headline: Washington Rule Makers Out of the Shadows
text: WASHINGTON  Federal rule makers, long the neglected stepchildren of Washington bureaucrats, suddenly find themselves at the center of power as they scramble to work out details of hundreds of sweeping financial and health care regulations that will ultimately affect most Americans.

headline: Tech Talk Podcast: Tracking and Privacy
text: Concerns about commercial tracking of Web users — and how consumer data is used — have led the Federal Trade Commission to call for action, including a way to opt out. On this week’s Tech Talk podcast, Bettina Edelstein speaks with Tanzina Vega, a New York Times media reporter who has been covering online privacy. Ms. Vega says that some in the advertising industry are raising alarms about the F.T.C.’s proposal for a simple tool to opt out of tracking.

headline: A New Phono Preamp From Parasound. Wait … What?
text: Of all the news releases inundating my in-box in the weeks before the annual Consumer Electronics Show — new cameras, new computer chips, a ton of gadgets for the iPhone and iPad — the one least likely to catch the attention of any au courant reviewer was about a new phonograph preamplifier.

headline: Pirates’ Catch Exposed Route of Arms in Sudan
text: KHARTOUM, Sudan — It was September 2008 and a band of Somali pirates made a startling discovery.

headline: F.C.C. Ponders Ways to Avoid Cable Blackouts
text: WASHINGTON  Seeking to end the brinksmanship that left many cable television customers in the Northeast without access to the first two games of the World Series this year, the Federal Communications Commission will consider changes to the rules governing negotiations between cable providers and broadcast networks, an agency official said Wednesday.

headline: As Windows Slide Shut, a Trade Moves On
text: Jesus Leonardo’s usual place of business felt more like a funeral parlor than a betting parlor on Wednesday.

headline: Twins that Look Alike, and Work Alike
text: Arlene Sloan is not sure which of her twin sons, Brett or Michael, helped sell some sports-themed wallpaper to a startled customer at her interior design shop. It was nearly four decades ago, when the boys were just 8 or 9 years old, and they were  and still are  so much alike that either could have been the precocious salesman.

headline: Yankees Offer Cliff Lee $140 Million
text: ORLANDO, Fla.  Armed with a lucrative contract proposal from the Yankees, Cliff Lee’s agent left the winter meetings Wednesday afternoon to fly back to Arkansas to consult with his most coveted client. In related news, Brian Cashman, the team’s general manager, said he felt like “Hannibal Lecter in a straitjacket” while he waited for a decision.

headline: O’Donnell’s Magic Turns Loss Into Gain
text: Christine O’Donnell‘s failed bid for a Delaware Senate seat could turn out to be her big win.

headline: Cold Leaves Detroit Unfazed
text: DETROIT — This is what a 20-something-degree day means around here: Most of the smokers huddling outside businesses wear gloves. Taking indoor tunnels between buildings is acceptable. It is time to start searching closets for the ankle-length parkas and enormous boots, giving up any semblance of fashion.

headline: Miamians Bundle Up; Tourists Insist It’s Fine
text: MIAMI  Cold weather does many things to this paradise of palm trees and pink. It empties Biscayne Bay of boats, it leads parents to dig winter hats from storage. But above all else, it sharpens the divide between residents and visitors.

headline: Uncommon Cold Strikes in Georgia
text: ATLANTA  What people in the South don’t know about cold is a lot.

headline: Bridge and Tunnel Types
text: Take a date to the Brooklyn Bridge for spectacular views and a romantic stroll. Take a drive in the Lincoln Tunnel and prepare for a cramped, crawling trip to New Jersey.

headline: Power Shift: Red Sox Sign Crawford
text: ORLANDO, Fla.

headline: U.S. Union Backing Boosts Korea Trade Pact
text: An unusual split in the labor movement has developed over President Obama’s proposed free-trade pact with South Korea, with two powerful unions backing the deal — a development that experts say will make Congressional ratification far more likely.

headline: In Tax Deal, Many Public Employees Will Pay More
text: More bad news for government workers.

headline: Bond Yields Continue Their Climb
text: Investors sold Treasuries for a second consecutive day on Wednesday, sending interest rates higher in response to the tentative deal to extend Bush-era tax cuts even as the Federal Reserve was trying aggressively to keep borrowing costs low.

headline: More Antarctic Cruise Ship Peril
text: .Dec. 9, 9:12 a.m. | Updated My friend Jon Bowermaster, a peripatetic kayaking filmmaker and travel writer, alerted me overnight to a post he wrote on an unfolding maritime emergency as the cruise ship Clelia II struggled* with limited power in extraordinarily violent seas halfway between the Antarctic Peninsula and Cape Horn.

headline: On Beltran, Mets Are All Ears
text: ORLANDO, Fla.  Whenever one team inquires about a player on another team who does not figure into that club’s plans, it is an intriguing conversation. Such was the case, if only for a brief moment, when the Boston Red Sox asked the Mets about Carlos Beltran on Tuesday night.

headline: Another Politician Falls, and Earth Barely Shakes
text: CARMEL, N.Y.

headline: Love the Name, if Not the E.R.A.
text: The Mets once had a Buzz (as in Capra). So why not a Boof?

headline: Surviving Hitler and Stalin to Fight Poverty and Cancer
text: For Larisa Shchetinina, now 72, the decision to leave Ukraine  though not the act itself  came suddenly. In 1992, she went to Kiev to say goodbye to her brother, who was moving to Israel. In the center of the country’s capital she saw graffiti on a wall that read, in large letters: “Let’s drown Russians in Jewish blood.”

headline: New York Betting Parlors Close Doors
text: After more threats of extinction than anyone could remember, the New York City Off-Track Betting Corporation unexpectedly made good on a threat of its own and closed the doors to its parlors on Tuesday night.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Louisiana Blue Crab and Blood-Orange Salad
text: For the crab:

headline: Satsuma Mojito
text: 2 limes, halved

headline: Field Report: The Accidental Farmer
text: If you’re supposed to make lemonade when life hands you lemons, what do you do when your divorce, following on the heels of breast cancer and Hurricane Katrina, leaves you with hundreds of your ex’s citrus trees in full fruit?

headline: At Ease With a Straight Razor
text: At last count, there were 8,598 licensed barbers in New York City. You won’t find too many with more hands-on experience than Rafael Cruz, 68, who’s been cutting hair in Manhattan regularly since he came here from the Dominican Republic in 1962. Mr. Cruz has worked for 29 years at the charmingly fusty Mayfair Barber Shop on West 39th Street, east of Eighth Avenue. He lives in Washington Heights with his wife, Rosa.

headline: Jets’ Rival Given Access To the Giants’ Facilities
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  A non-controversy unfolded on Wednesday when it was revealed that the Miami Dolphins would practice at the Giants’ indoor training facility on Friday in preparation for Sunday’s game against the Jets. That the Giants would welcome the Jets’ division rival is unusual, but not worth arguing about, according to the partners who share New Meadowlands Stadium.

headline: Despite the Mayor’s Homeless Program, Many Return to Shelters, Critics Say
text: One of the Bloomberg administration’s signature antipoverty initiatives has come under fire from advocates for the homeless, who say the city has exaggerated its success and ignored data showing that a substantial number of families who enroll in the program end up back in shelters.

headline: To Test Housing Program, Some Are Denied Aid
text: It has long been the standard practice in medical testing: Give drug treatment to one group while another, the control group, goes without.

headline: Profits and Scrutiny for Colleges Courting Veterans
text: WASHINGTON  When Congress moved in 2008 to sweeten tuition payments for veterans, it was celebrated as a way to ensure that military personnel returning from Iraq and Afghanistan could go to college at no cost and to replicate the historic benefits society gained from the G.I. Bill after World War II.

headline: The Worst Bathroom in New York
text: I pulled out my crumpled Google Map printout to make sure I had the right address: 2356 Lorillard Place, a beige-colored, brick building on a sliver of a street wedged between the Bronx’s Little Italy and Third Avenue, one of those wide and unforgivably windy boulevards where everyone seems to be waiting for the bus. A teenage boy stood in the doorway, a cigarette pressed like a joint between his thumb and index finger.

headline: Morgan Stanley Aims to Rein In Executive Pay
text: Even as Wall Street prepares to hand out rich year-end bonuses, one firm, Morgan Stanley, is mapping out a plan to reduce the pay of some of its senior executives, according to people with knowledge of the plan.

headline: Kung Fu for Philosophers
text: In a 2005 news report about the Shaolin Temple, the Buddhist monastery in China well-known for its martial arts, a monk addressed a common misunderstanding: “Many people have a misconception that martial arts is about fighting and killing,” the monk was quoted as saying, “It is actually about improving your wisdom and intelligence.”[1]

headline: Publicist’s Death Could Be Random
text: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif.  The gun used to kill the Hollywood publicist Ronni Chasen appears to match the gun a man used to kill himself when police officers approached him for questioning at an apartment building last week, according to preliminary ballistics tests, police officials said on Wednesday.

headline: Justices, Minus One, Hear Challenge to Arizona Law on Hiring Immigrants
text: WASHINGTON  An Arizona law that imposes harsh penalties on businesses that hire illegal immigrants seemed likely to be sustained after Supreme Court arguments on Wednesday, if only because of judicial arithmetic.

headline: Oyster Creek Reactor to Close by 2019
text: The Oyster Creek nuclear reactor in New Jersey will be shut down by 2019, at least 10 years before its license expires, in a deal with state environmental regulators that will allow it to operate until then without building costly cooling towers, its owner said on Wednesday.

headline: 4 Charged With Stealing $8 Million in Food Stamp Scam
text: Four people, including current and former New York City employees, have been charged in a scheme in which they lined their pockets with $8 million from the federal food stamp program, prosecutors said Wednesday.

headline: Brooklyn Bakery Owner Mourned After Fatal Shooting
text: There were times when the line of customers extended out the door onto Nostrand Avenue in Brooklyn, in anticipation of not only the sweet breads and pastries inside but also the mix of humor, conversation and commentary that flowed from behind the bakery counter.

headline: Albany Inquiry Ends in Penalty for a Lobbyist
text: One of the most influential lobbyists in Albany has been implicated in Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo’s wide-ranging investigation of the New York state pension fund and has agreed to pay a $500,000 fine.

headline: Thursday: They’re Shown in a Beauty Pageant
text: THURSDAY’S PUZZLE — As crosswords continue to evolve, certain themes that used to be common have gone out of fashion. We don’t see so many quote (or step quote) puzzles anymore, word ladders are now rare, and the formerly popular “word that can precede the beginning of each theme answer” form is nearly extinct. It’s not so much that it ran its course but the infinite variations lost their novelty long ago.

headline: A Longtime Marriage, Threatened Inside and Out
text: “In marriage all is perceived, but much withheld,” says Jack Berry, one-half of the fractiously loving couple in “Haunted,” a slight but well-acted new play by Edna O’Brien at the 59E59 Theaters as part of the Brits Off Broadway festival. “Infinite, the book of secrets,” Jack continues, lost in his musings on the troublesome past in the play’s opening monologue.

headline: Nets Owner Sees Upside In Down Year

headline: Ivory Coast: U.N. Affirms Vote Results
text: The incumbent president, Laurent Gbagbo, had no grounds to dispute the results of the Nov. 28 presidential election that gave the victory to his rival, the United Nations said Wednesday after reviewing the vote. Mr. Gbagbo has defied international calls to step down, despite provisional results giving his opponent, Alassane Ouattara, a near 10-point margin. The United Nations mission chief, Y. J. Choi, left, said the decision of the Constitutional Council to overturn the election was “not based on facts.” He also denied accusations from the Gbagbo camp that he had meddled in internal affairs by declaring Mr. Ouattara the winner. “I remain absolutely certain that I have found the truth concerning the will of the Ivorian people,” he said, adding that Mr. Ouattara won “with an irrefutable margin.”

headline: Seven Pay-Per-Click Mistakes to Avoid
text: A few days ago, I described how a stay-at-home mom named Amy Gottesman built a six-figure party-entertainment business largely via the effective use of Google AdWords and other pay-per-click advertising services. These services allow a company to bid on certain keywords and phrases, and if the bid is high enough a short ad from the company will appear alongside the search results of anyone typing those words into a search engine and on some other Web sites. The business then pays the bid price — it can be anywhere from pennies to more than a thousand dollars depending on the competition for those words — every time someone clicks on the ad.

headline: Block That Metaphor

headline: Class and the Culture War (II)
text: One final point on the National Marriage Project report. I’ve been emphasizing the bad news, but I do think it’s genuinely good news that well-educated opinion — as opposed to just well-educated behavior — has been moving in a more conservative direction on divorce. (48 percent of college-educated Americans now agree that “divorce should be more difficult to obtain,” up from just 36 percent in the 1970s.) When social conservatives try to envision public policy responses to the crisis of the American family, they’re almost inevitably stymied by the fact that our upper class (which is, by extension, our policymaking class), while increasingly conservative in the way its members arrange their own private lives, remains intensely allergic to the kind of legal and cultural paternalism that certain earlier elites practiced as a matter of course. I’ve suggested before that America would benefit if its upper class showed “a willingness to translate some of the more conservative habits they’ve embraced (or partially embraced) in their personal lives into law and public policy,” but I’ve never seen much reason for optimism that our elite might actually move in this direction. So the fact that there’s been an uptick in college-educated support for reforming divorce laws is better news than I expected — and a sign, perhaps, that the educated class’s present mix of private conservatism and public permissiveness isn’t set in stone.

headline: Seeing Things | Decolonizing Architecture
text: In a new exhibition at the Gallery at REDCAT in Los Angeles, the Decolonizing Architecture Art Residency (DAAR) looks at ways to use architecture to investigate and speculate about the future of sites that have been evacuated, or decolonized, by Israel in Palestine’s West Bank. DAAR — a Bethlehem-based research studio and residency program led by Alessandro Petti, Sandi Hillal and Eyal Weizman — envisions a “detoured world,” in which political, legal and architectural approaches can be employed to reuse both physical and organizational structures in new, and often unorthodox, ways.

headline: After Death, the Remix
text: ONE telling moment on “Michael,” the first full album of posthumous Michael Jackson songs, is a snippet that might never have appeared during his life: a backstage glimpse of a performer who always strove to appear perfectly polished.

headline: House Democrats Oppose Tax Cut Deal
text: In a closed-door caucus meeting on Thursday morning, House Democrats voted to reject the tax cut deal between the White House and Congressional Republicans “as currently written.”

headline: In Europe, Bank Losses Stabilize, Report Says
text: European banks have stopped bleeding money, but they remain vulnerable to the effects of the sovereign debt crisis or a slowdown in the economy, and a small number still depend on low-cost loans from the European Central Bank, a report from the bank said on Thursday.

headline: YouTube Lifts Time Limit for Some Videos

headline: K.K.R.’s Kravis on Why He’s Optimistic

headline: Dutch Panel Found 2,000 Church Abuse Claims
text: BRUSSELS  The Roman Catholic Church, battered by sexual abuse scandals from the United States to Belgium, is facing a new set of damaging allegations in the Netherlands. Figures released Thursday by an investigative commission showed that almost 2,000 people had made complaints of sexual or physical abuse against the church, in a country with only four million Catholics.

headline: Cuomo Announces Top Aides
text: Governor-elect Andrew M. Cuomo announced on Thursday the first senior appointments in his incoming administration, drawing largely on a mix of trusted old hands from the attorney general’s office and alumni of his father’s administration, along with a few new faces, to assemble his administration.

text: In recent years, Sun Valley has been looking forward, and a proposed master plan will take things even further.

headline: Guilty Verdict for White Plains Mayor in Domestic Violence Case
text: WHITE PLAINS  The domestic violence trial of this city’s mayor ended on Thursday with a guilty verdict in five of nine charges, yet little about the case or his political future seemed settled.

headline: Following Up: When A Crew Chief Fights With His Rifle
text: Racing low over the fields, just above the occasional treetops, the Black Hawk helicopter banked left, turning toward the landing zone. Listening on a headset in the back, I could hear the radio chatter between the two Army pilots up front as they relayed to their crew the update from the infantry patrol below. The pilots summarized what to expect: the firefight had erupted again.

headline: Republicans Block U.S. Health Aid for 9/11 Workers
