headline: Franco Checks Back In to ‘General Hospital’
text: James Franco cannot stop with the multitasking. On the days before and after his Oscar hosting gig, he will once again appear on “General Hospital,” where he plays a menacing performance artiste named Franco. “We just haven’t seen or heard from him, because he’s been terribly busy,” Jill Farren Phelps, an executive producer of the show, explained of the character. As for the real Franco, “He’s also expressed an interest in directing at ‘G.H.,’ ” she told TV Guide.

headline: Senate Democrats Put ‘Dream Act’ on Hold

headline: More U.S. Rail Funds for 13 States as 2 Reject Aid

headline: Wesley Snipes Surrenders to Begin Sentence on Tax Convictions

headline: The Day the Yankees (Yawn) Acquired Enos Slaughter
text: A recent study by experts who fed 300 million facts into a new computer search engine has determined that April 11, 1954, has been identified as the most boring day of the 20th century, a day in which there were no key news events or births or deaths of famous people. The experts clearly did not check the sports pages.

headline: TimesCast | December 9, 2010

headline: ‘Time Stands Still’ to Close

headline: Theater Talkback: The Exploding Art of Set Design
text: Conversation turned to taxidermy as a couple of friends and I awaited the start of “Bloody Bloody Andrew Jackson” the other night. This is not a favorite topic, needless to say, but it sprang naturally to mind because our seats at the Bernard B. Jacobs Theater were directly underneath a stuffed horse suspended upside-down from the ceiling of the theater.

headline: Air Products Raises Airgas Bid to $70 a Share

headline: Europeans Criticize Fierce U.S. Response to Leaks
text: PARIS — For many Europeans, Washington’s fierce reaction to the flood of secret diplomatic cables released by WikiLeaks displays imperial arrogance and hypocrisy, indicating a post-9/11 obsession with secrecy that contradicts American principles.

headline: Debt-Reduction Advocates Offer New Year’s Resolution
text: President Obama’s Treasury secretary and budget director met at the White House with members of his bipartisan debt-reduction commission Thursday morning and agreed that the administration should lead an effort in the coming year to press for the sort of long-term spending cuts and revenue increases that a commission majority recommended last week.

text: The best present you can give a coffee lover is coffee beans. Sometimes the holidays are simple like that.

headline: From N.B.A. To D.J.
text: After Rony Seikaly's professional basketball career was up, he started to seriously pursue his passion of music. Now, the former N.B.A. center is an up-and-coming D.J. working the mixer at dance clubs around the world.

headline: The Tipsy Diaries: Eggnog With a Twist
text: In Frank Bruni’s latest Tipsy Diaries column, he challenges three bartenders to create an alternative to traditional eggnog, that calorie extravaganza and cholesterol jubilee. Below is a guide to their takes on the holiday drink. Do you love eggnog? Share your thoughts and own versions.

headline: Video: Celebrating ‘Revelations’ at 50
text: After seeing “Celebrating ‘Revelations’ at 50,” the film tribute by Judy Kinberg that precedes the piece this season at Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, Roslyn Sulcas wrote:  “It’s notable how rough hewn — and powerful — the dancing looks in the historical footage of Ailey and others performing in that work. Today the Ailey dancers are sleek, athletic masters of the universe, and the pieces routinely draw midmovement applause and cheers for moments of virtuosity.” The film, which was created especially for the 50th anniversary of the work, features Alvin Ailey and Judith Jamison discussing the history of the seminal piece and its influence on American dance. It will be shown before all performances of the work at New York City Center through Jan. 2. Have you seen “Revelations”? Share your memories about the dance.

headline: Terrorism Fighter Now Battles the School Next Door
text: For most of the past four years, Richard A. Falkenrath’s job was helping to protect New York City against possible terror strikes. Now, he is defending his block in Riverdale in the Bronx against the Jewish academy next door, making his case at the local community board — and invoking his terror-fighting past in the process.

headline: Haitian Vote Results to Be Reviewed
text: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  Seeking to defuse the violent protests that have shut down this country for two days, Haiti’s electoral council promised Thursday to rapidly review the widely mistrusted preliminary results from the presidential election last month.

headline: Stronger Secondary Market in Private Equity
text: As private equity firms slowly get back to deal-making, the secondary market for their funds is starting to perk up, too.

headline: What Makes an N.B.A. All-Star?
text: The All-Star Game is, in many respects, quite odd. It’s part coach-determined meritocracy and part popularity contest. It’s a game that means absolutely nothing, and yet the players are supposed to treat it as genuine competition. The honor of being selected has meaning to younger players but is an inconvenience to many veterans. It’s more celebration than exhibition, which makes it hard to draw a line between basketball and frivolity because there really isn’t one.

headline: A Less Costly Reverse Mortgage
text: OLDER homeowners who have spent years building up equity may be tempted to cash out through a reverse mortgage. But high fees can make these loans pricey.

headline: Remembering Josh Levine
text: You meet a lot of people when you own a business. You may not count them as friends, but they are more than acquaintances. You belong to a fraternity, you are members of an unnamed club, you share a certain attitude toward life and life’s cycles. You meet them around town, at functions, at bars, ball games.

headline: Another Nuclear Pact With Russia Close to Approval
text: WASHINGTON  While President Obama focuses his energy on pressing the Senate to sign off on a new arms control treaty with Russia, another nuclear pact with Moscow is securing final approval after more than four years with virtually no notice but potentially significant impact.

headline: Be on the Lookout for a Frugally Attired Thief
text: You might think that when people steal your credit card, they use it to stock up on gold teeth and beluga caviar. Sometimes, to be sure, they do. But sometimes credit-card thieves plow their ill-gotten gains into value that lasts. Like reasonably priced menswear.

headline: President’s Club Meets Friday: Obama, Clinton at the White House
text: Former President Bill Clinton is to meet on Friday with President Obama at the White House for a postelection conversation about moving the agenda forward in a new political environment, according to a senior Democrat told of the meeting.

headline: Critic’s Notebook: David Wojnarowicz’s ‘A Fire in My Belly’
text: In 1989, a Methodist minister named Donald Wildmon, founder of the American Family Association, mailed a pamphlet reproducing details from collages by the New York artist David Wojnarowicz (1954-1992) to every member of Congress, to various media outlets, and to religious leaders across the country.

headline: For Women’s Health, a Poor Report Card
text: What is the state of women’s health? A new report gives women failing grades in key areas.

headline: Shipping News | Bota Bota
text: A new creature has docked in Montreal’s Old Port, nestling among the industrial silos and across the river from Moshe Safdie’s Habitat 67 cuboid apartment block. Bota Bota, a massive 1950s steel liner redesigned by architects from Sid Lee — the Montreal-based creative agency — is the world’s first spa-on-a-boat, a 25,000-square-foot urban fantasy of a Scandinavian-style bath with more than 20 treatment rooms. Aboard the vessel, guests can indulge in all sorts of treatments, like a Honey Ocean massage and a Cocoa Wave body wrap, or work the hot and cold water pool circuit on the ship’s upper decks. After all the steaming and stretching, you can visit the cafe, which serves sophisticated takes on health cuisine, including scallop ceviche with strawberries, foie gras and chocolate-caramel cake — this is French Canada, after all.

headline: German Government Bonds May Carry a Little Risk After All
text: FRANKFURT — German government bonds, seen as practically the closest thing in the universe to a risk-free European investment, may carry a little risk after all.

headline: A Relevant Bowl Game and 34 Others
text: The preholiday blues are striking college football fans who have felt shut out of the national championship since the first loss of the season.

headline: Accounting for Public Pensions
text: A generation ago, when Ronald Reagan was president, the accounting rule makers forced American companies to come clean on the cost of the pension plans they were promising to employees. That decision, perhaps more than any other, heralded the eventual demise of defined-benefit pensions for employees of American companies.

headline: Teaching Twain and ‘Huckleberry Finn’ With The New York Times
text: “[Mark Twain] is surprisingly relevant right now. When you look at how much he wrote and the breadth of the subjects he wrote about, you know that if he were alive today, he would totally be a blogger.” — Rebecca Fitting, an owner of the Greenlight Bookstore in Fort Greene, Brooklyn, quoted in the 2010 article “Mark Twain’s Autobiography Flying Off the Shelves.”

headline: Anthropology a Science? Statement Deepens a Rift
text: Anthropologists have been thrown into turmoil about the nature and future of their profession after a decision by the American Anthropological Association at its recent annual meeting to strip the word “science” from a statement of its long-range plan.

Share your story about what is happening in your town or state. Use the comments area below or respond via Twitter using the hashtag #nytchat.

headline: 8 Percent of American Internet Users Go to Twitter, Report Says
text: A new study released Thursday by the Pew Research Center found that 8 percent of Americans who are active on the Internet are enthusiastic users of the social networking service Twitter.

text: While the N.F.L. universe is focused on Brett Favre’s shoulder and whether it will allow him to continue his consecutive starts streak, the Giants, who were battered by injuries only a few weeks ago, now appear to be the healthiest they have been all season.

headline: Other People’s Kids
text: The boundaries between us and the children of others has been a topic here on Motherlode this week. Laura Shumaker raised it in her essay about how quickly gossip spreads when a mother might possibly have done wrong. A reader touched on it when asking how to integrate sharply different parenting styles when siblings come together for the holidays. And in a guest post today Nicole Blades (who blogs at MsMaryMack.com), continues the conversation, wondering what are the rules when disciplining someone else’s child.

headline: Mayors All, but None With Their Names Enshrined
text: Pity Abraham D. Beame and Vincent R. Impellitteri. To say nothing of John P. O’Brien, Joseph V. McKee, Ardolph Kline, William J. Gaynor and George B. McClellan Jr. They appear to be the only 20th-century dead mayors of New York City whose legacy has not been officially enshrined as the name of a street, bridge, school, park, housing project, college or some other edifice.

headline: Spain to Seek Prison Time for Striking Air Controllers
text: MADRID — Spain’s attorney general said Thursday that he would recommend prison sentences of as long as eight years for air traffic controllers found guilty of staging an illegal strike that shut down airports around the country last weekend.

headline: What Makes an Employee Proud
text: There are plenty of reasons I’m proud to work at the Times — the brilliant reporting, the numerous prizes — and also reasons why I’m occasionally embarrassed. But I’ve never been prouder of this newspaper than over something that doesn’t have to do with its coverage or mission, but with a hiring decision.

headline: Fishing Is Restricted to Help Sea Lions
text: To protect the declining population of the western Steller sea lion, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration will restrict commercial fishing for Atka mackerel and Pacific cod, the animal’s main source of food, off parts of the Alaska’s western Aleutian Islands.

headline: ‘Gran Turismo 5’: Worth the Wait
text: After its much-anticipated — and delayed — arrival, “Gran Turismo 5,” the racing simulation series for the Sony PlayStation 3, hit the streets in late November. Over the next week or so, Sam Schembari — our resident racing game aficionado, and a son of James Schembari, an editor for the Automobiles section — will unravel the layers of the game.

headline: Luke’s Lobster, Part Three
text: Luke’s Lobster is set to open its third location, on the Upper West Side, by the end of the month. The new place, at 426 Amsterdam Avenue (West 80th Street), will have the same lobster shack feel as the ones at 93 East Seventh Street in the East Village and 242 East 81st Street on the Upper East Side. What will be new? A spicy crab and sweet potato bisque and a hearty fish chowder.

text: Five of the six Russians, including the third-highest ranked player, and all of the players from the Republic of Georgia are out, while five Chinese players are among the final 16.

text: The brothers Sablich are here to help with fantasy football analysis for Week 14. They also answered reader questions earlier in the week. Read their answers below and follow them on Twitter for more advice leading up to game time on Sunday.

headline: Blatter, Soccer’s Newest Evangelist
text: Barely a week after FIFA awarded the 2022 World Cup to Qatar, Sepp Blatter said he would be keen to take some of the games elsewhere. The FIFA president told the French sports daily L’Equipe that neighboring countries could host some World Cup games.

headline: Move Over, Alfred Kazin: That’s Kitty Kelley Writing in The American Scholar
text: Kitty Kelley’s celebrity biographies of such figures as Frank Sinatra, Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis, Elizabeth Taylor, Nancy Reagan, the British royals, the Bush family and most recently Oprah Winfrey are known for their juicy and often embarrassing details. Her sensational accounts have frequently landed her on the best-seller list, in the tabloid columns, and occasionally in a law office for allegedly dealing carelessly with facts.

headline: Shift Dressing | Veronica Beard Spring 2011
text: Versatility might as well be their middle name. For fall 2010, the sisters-in-law Veronica Miele Beard and Veronica Swanson Beard, who design under the name Veronica Beard (natch), introduced “the Jacket.” The feminine cut and interchangeable dickey insert have already made it a wildly popular wardrobe staple.

headline: U.S.A.! U.S.A.! U.S.A.!
text: Sometimes you don’t know whether to laugh or cry. Consider, for a moment, the Clicker. It’s a $24 universal remote that can control up to eight devices. Oh, and it has a bottle opener built in.

headline: Crosby, Penguins Look Unstoppable
text: It seems so automatic that it’s starting to seem unremarkable: Penguins star Sidney Crosby is on another major scoring run.

headline: Gallivanting Across Europe in High Heels and High Dudgeon
text: It takes a big man to hold the screen level when Angelina Jolie is around — usually the whole thing just tilts in her direction as soon as she struts into the frame. Her partner in crazy-time fame, Brad Pitt, helped keep the balance in “Mr. and Mrs. Smith,” their only film together. And now Johnny Depp tries to do much the same in “The Tourist.” Going for muted, eyeliner- and nearly irony-free, he plays an ordinary American who bumbles into a Continental intrigue, which looks like a film you’ve seen before, because you have.

headline: Oyster Creek Nuclear Deal Draws Some Fire
text: Some people were deeply disappointed by the deal cut by Exelon and Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey to let the Oyster Creek nuclear plant run without a cooling tower but then cease operations by 2019, 10 years early. But they dislike it for very different reasons.

headline: Big Push in South Sudan Before Vote
text: JUBA, Sudan  For the last half-year or so, people in this fast-growing capital of southern Sudan have gathered on the ninth day of each month to march through the city. It is a countdown to Jan. 9, the day a referendum is scheduled to decide whether the southern part of this country secedes from the north and becomes its own nation.

headline: Pictures of the Day: London and Elsewhere
text: Pictures from England, Germany and Australia

headline: Campaign Finance Reform: C.F.T.C. Style
text: The Commodities Futures Trading Commission wants to limit banks’ campaign donations — but similar rules already exist.

headline: Fair Trade | Art Barter Comes to New York
text: Maybe that Jeff Koons on display at the Gagosian booth at Art Basel Miami Beach last week was a little out of your price range. At Art Barter, opening tonight at NP Contemporary Art Center on Chrystie Street, your money is no good anyway. Instead you can offer up your personal goods or services in exchange for a work by, say, Tom Sachs or Terence Koh. The idea for Art Barter, which made its debut last year in London, came from Lauren Jones and Alix Janta, who were inspired by the free-thinking ways of Burning Man, the RCA Postcard Auction and Freecycle. If you’re stuck for ideas, here are some things that have changed hands in the past: a Tracey Emin piece for 30 hours of French tutoring; a Jason Dodge work for a week in a Scottish castle. Other offers have included Web site design, three months of psychotherapy and a gallop on a white horse. But keep in mind the contract is legally binding so don’t promise something you can’t deliver.

headline: Pictures of the Day: London and Elsewhere
text: Pictures from England, Germany and Australia.

headline: City Council Hears Sides of Bike Lane Battle
text: The Brooklyn borough president, Marty Markowitz, sang a self-written song about bicycle lanes to the tune of a popular selection from “The Sound of Music”: “These are a few of my favorite lanes.” A 40-year resident of Park Slope, Brooklyn, testified that an influx of cyclists had made her afraid to cross the street in front of her house. A group of cycling advocates wondered why the city would reject a nimble, environmentally friendly mode of transportation in favor of bulky, polluting automobiles.

headline: Skyfire Brings Flash to the iPhone, Usually
text: About a year and a half ago, I gave an unreserved rave to the Skyfire browser. I did the same about a year ago when the browser was made available for Android, with speedy downloads and the ability to show Adobe Flash animation on phones that didn’t support it.

headline: Row Houses Gone Wild
text: THEY say free-range chicken is better  how about free-range blocks? Seventy-First Street from West End to Broadway rises steeply midblock and then, like a roller coaster  wheeee!  hurtles downhill. The architecture has a certain giddy touch, joyously untempered by the good taste of contextualism so often claimed as an urban ideal.

headline: Visiting an Ordinarily Unique Artist
text: Here is a description of some of the most innovative and important American theater of the last quarter of the 20th century. A man sits at a table and starts talking. If he has props, they are minimal — a spiral notebook, a record player, a box of pictures — and his costume is correspondingly modest, consisting usually of a flannel shirt, blue jeans or chinos, and sneakers. He speaks mostly about himself, digressing from anecdotes about his childhood and professional life into more serious confessional territory, though always with reserve and good humor.

headline: Medical Illustrations as Art

headline: A Lingerie Shop for All Sizes and Situations
text: THE wallpaper is a nameless color, somewhere between gray and green. The floors are linoleum; the lights fluorescent. Behind the swinging louvered doors of the dressing room, a saleswoman’s eyes are critical, but her hands are warm.

headline: Bystanders to China’s Transition
text: The Beijing-born, New York-based filmmaker Miao Wang follows three cabbies around her old hometown in the picturesque documentary “Beijing Taxi,” filmed over several years leading up to the 2008 Beijing Olympics. The cabbies have interesting and poignant things to say about being left behind in China’s rush to modernize, and Ms. Wang; her directors of photography, Ian Vollmer and Sean Price Williams; and her editor, Sikay Tang, have produced an attractive and seamless set of images of working-class Chinese life. (The chronology gets a little herky-jerky, with major changes in the drivers’ lives happening entirely off screen.)

headline: In Rare Bow to Public, Russian Tower to be Moved
text: MOSCOW  The city authorities in St. Petersburg intend to relocate a planned 1,299-foot glass-and-steel tower for the state energy company Gazprom, saying it has caused too much dissension among architects and residents for it to be built at the chosen site in the city’s historic center.

headline: Fleming Adds New Role, Helping Guide Opera Troupe
text: LET’S say a Major League cleanup hitter wants to help run the front office. Or a celebrity novelist is trying her hand at editing other people’s books. Or the top circus clown has ideas for planning animal acts.

headline: Broadway Cast Is Set for ‘Bengal Tiger’
text: All of the actors who starred in west coast productions of “Bengal Tiger at the Baghdad Zoo” will be going with the show to New York, except for the tiger himself, who will be played by Robin Williams in his Broadway acting debut.

headline: The Retro Experience
text: A retro look is the prevailing wind on the slopes and in the lodge this season.

headline: Friends Who Didn’t Mince Words
text: The story of Julia Child’s life  how a gawky and outgoing diplomat’s wife from Pasadena, Calif., came to write the classic “Mastering the Art of French Cooking” (1961)  has been told so many times and in so many ways (biographies, memoirs, histories of American eating, movies, PBS documentaries, blogs) that it’s not clear there’s more worth knowing. This potato has been peeled.

headline: ‘As Always, Julia’

headline: F.B.I. Asks Panel to Delay Report on Anthrax Inquiry
text: WASHINGTON  The Federal Bureau of Investigation has requested a last-minute delay in the release of a report on the bureau’s anthrax investigation by the National Academy of Sciences, prompting a congressman to say that the bureau “may be seeking to try to steer or otherwise pressure” the academy’s scientific panel “to reach a conclusion desired by the bureau.”

headline: In Zurich, A District Cleans Up
text: Gentrification is cleaning up the vibrant Aussersihl district of Zurich, where restaurants and galleries are edging out the questionable characters.

headline: An Era’s Injustices Fuel an Artist’s Activist Works
text: PURCHASE, N.Y.  The American artist Faith Ringgold, who turned 80 this year, is best known for the vivacious story quilts about African-American life that she’s made over the past three decades. But if all that survived from her career were her paintings and prints from the 1960s and early ’70s, she’d still be in the history books. An inspired and incisive exhibition at the Neuberger Museum of Art here shows why.

headline: Neighborhood Joint: Olga’s Corset and Specialty Shop
text: Customers looking for custom bra fittings, on-site alteration and hard-to-find sizes have relied on the shop for more than three decades.

headline: Metropolitan to Host Cézanne’s ‘Card Players’
text: In the 1890s, when Cézanne was depicting nude figures in his series of “Bathers” and experimenting with landscapes in his canvases of Mont Sainte-Victoire, he was also painting several of the workers on his family farm near Aix-en-Provence. What he captured in paintings and drawings were the figures of stocky, pipe-smoking men, their expressions dour, their dress drab. Some he painted by themselves, others in twos or threes sitting around a table absorbed in a game of cards. This later group — “Card Players,” as the series is known — was a 19th-century take on the so-called genre painting made famous by 17th-century Dutch masters.

headline: Make ’Em Laugh With Tales of Tears
text: “If my life wasn’t funny, it would just be true, and that is completely unacceptable” is how Carrie Fisher rationalizes rehashing the more sordid details in books, screenplays, blogs, a Broadway show called “Wishful Drinking” and now an HBO film version of that stage performance.

headline: Pfizer to Pay Its Ex-Chief $4.5 Million in Severance
text: Pfizer, the world’s largest pharmaceutical company, said in a regulatory filing on Thursday that it had agreed to give Jeffrey B. Kindler a $4.5 million severance payment after his sudden retirement on Sunday as chairman and chief executive.

headline: A Lingerie Shop for All Sizes and Situations
text: The wallpaper is a nameless color, somewhere between gray and green. The floors are linoleum; the lights fluorescent. Behind the swinging louvered doors of the dressing room, a saleswoman’s eyes are critical, but her hands are warm.

headline: Community Health Unveils $3.3 Billion Bid for Tenet
text: 10:25 p.m. | Updated

headline: Perils of the Corporate Ladder: It Hurts When You Fall
text: “The Company Men” puts us down on the ground after having been up in the air. The movie powerfully revisits a theme touched on last year in the bitter comic drama “Up in the Air”: the devastating impact of sudden downsizing on corporate executives who have lived by the treacherous adage “You are what you do.” Instead of regarding these unfortunate men from the lofty perspective of a charming, cynical hatchet man logging frequent-flier miles — George Clooney’s character in “Up in the Air” — “The Company Men” looks them straight in the eye from inside the trenches.

headline: How Much Instability Is Too Much?
text: Will Oldham, performing as Bonnie Prince Billy at Town Hall on Wednesday night, spent a lot of time standing on one foot: hopping, swinging his left leg, tucking it up under him like a stork. Perhaps, as he does in his songs, he was testing just how much instability he could get away with. He never toppled.

headline: His Path From Shutter to Paintbrush
text: If you think you know all you need to know about Norman Rockwell, think again. “Norman Rockwell: Behind the Camera” at the Brooklyn Museum is a revelation. It is no secret that Rockwell relied on photographs to achieve the seeming naturalism of his paintings. But the extent and sophistication of his use of photography from the late 1930s on will come as a surprise to many of his fans and detractors.

headline: Chic Peek | Dior Store Reopens
text: To celebrate the reopening tomorrow of Christian Dior’s sprawling 57th Street flagship, the house’s creative director of accessories, Camille Miceli, designed a clutch of one-of-a-kind jewels, including this $3,500 metal and crackled ceramic necklace. The two-level boutique, which has been given a glamorous face-lift by Peter Marino, also features several chic art commissions, including mirrored glass installations by Rob Wynne, a Oyoram video piece and a stunning ceiling relief by David Wiseman. 21 East 57th Street; (212) 931-2950.

headline: N.Y. Objects to Release of Multistate Fracking Rules
text: A regional regulatory agency that oversees the Delaware River watershed issued proposed regulations on Thursday for natural gas drilling that are intended to bring some uniformity to various rules governing the controversial type of gas extraction that combines horizontal drilling with hydraulic fracturing.

headline: When Youthful Desire Grows Into Regret
text: When Lee Hoiby’s opera “Summer and Smoke,” adapted from the Tennessee Williams play, had its premiere in 1971, it was criticized by some for its conservative music, awash in the harmonic language of Menotti (Mr. Hoiby’s mentor), Barber and Mahler, and its unabashedly lyrical vocal writing. But the work, with an effective and delicately poetic libretto by the playwright Lanford Wilson, also won deserved praise for doing what an opera is supposed to do: telling the story with sure dramatic pacing and understated expressivity, in music admirable for its directness and melodic grace.

headline: A Golden Age in Science, Full of Light and Shadow
text: “Take a look,” Ben Kingsley says, dropping an ancient tome before three British students as if he were teaching the Dark Arts at Hogwarts. “Take a look,” he tells them, “if you dare.”

headline: Guys, Kiss Mom and Come Out Fighting
text: With the possible exception of the romantic comedy, no film genre is more strictly governed by conventions — or enslaved by clichés, if you prefer — than the boxing picture. Something similar might be said about reviews of boxing pictures, so here goes:

headline: O Tidings of Comfort and Joy, Comfort and Joy
text: A sampling of noteworthy musical presentations for the holiday season at churches, synagogues and concert halls in New York City, compiled by Anne Mancuso. All are free unless otherwise noted. (Houses of worship accept donations.) Unless noted, church choirs are featured in church concerts.

headline: Radical Turn for the Trocks’ Youngest Sylph
text: It’s a classic tale of struggle and determination, of hard work and enterprise, of the journey from a small town to the big city. It’s the tale of the passage from the East to the West, and of the transformation of a young Chinese boy into, well, a ballerina. More precisely (say it slowly), into Nina Enimenimynimova. Now say it faster: EE-nee-MEE-nee-MIN-i-MOH-va.

headline: Sports Stars Seek Profit in Catchphrases
text: Jets cornerback Darrelle Revis shut down so many receivers last season that teammates started calling his turf Revis Island, where opposing players were inevitably marooned.

headline: Keeping Score: Why the Knicks Are Winning
text: Justin Kubatko is the creator of Basketball-Reference.com, an online basketball encyclopedia. He is also a statistical consultant for the Trail Blazers.

headline: Snowy Jingles and a Sinatra ‘Dreidel’
text: Genial holiday spirits suffuse Michael Feinstein’s annual end-of-the year shows at Feinstein’s at Loews Regency, the Park Avenue club that bears his name and musically conservative imprint. But for all the shows’ seasonal trimmings, the religious aspect of Christmas is conspicuously absent. Santa Claus, mistletoe, snowy wonderlands and hopes for peace on earth proliferate, but the Nativity remains backstage.

headline: BMW Reveals 1 Series M Coupe
text: BMW announced details Thursday of its coming 1 Series M Coupe. The car will make its United States debut at the Detroit auto show in January.

text: I see that Ryan Avent is confused either about what I’m saying or about what the political science literature on economic determinants of elections says. So let me try to say it more clearly.

headline: A Map of American Slavery
text: One of the most important maps of the Civil War was also one of the most visually striking: the United States Coast Survey’s map of the slaveholding states, which clearly illustrates the varying concentrations of slaves across the South.

headline: Protesters Attack Car Carrying Prince Charles
text: LONDON — Britain’s coalition government survived the most serious challenge yet to its austerity plans on Thursday when Parliament narrowly approved a sharp increase in college fees. But violent student protests in central London, including an attack on a car carrying Prince Charles and his wife, Camilla, to the theater, provided a stark measure of growing public resistance.

And maybe you’ve seen him creating a serious artistic persona in a downtown gallery and poking fun at it on “General Hospital.” ABC is hoping you’ll want to see him do a little shtick on the Academy Awards telecast, and Fox Searchlight is really hoping you’ve seen him cutting off his own arm, playing the hiker Aron Ralston in “127 Hours.” The Awards Tracker blog takes a look at how that film’s box office fortunes may affect its awards standing, drawing unfavorable comparisons with the director Danny Boyle’s previous winner, “Slumdog Millionaire.”

headline: Making a List: Naughty and Naughtier
text: If Scrooge and Tiny Tim are making nice and the Rockettes are wearing out their tap shoes, it must mean that the holiday theater season is here. Whether Christmas makes you want to twirl in the snow or hurl on Santa’s lap, there are plenty of shows — from the cheery to the blasphemous — to keep the winter blahs at bay. Reviewers for The New York Times have weighed in on “Looking at Christmas” and “Elf,” but here are a few more ideas, with suggestions for who might most appreciate a seat. (Tickets can be purchased at theatermania.com unless otherwise indicated.)

headline: Playwright Clears His Stage and Bookcases
text: TWO years ago Ed Schmidt, a New York playwright, got word that his father was near death in upstate New York. He bundled his family into the car and drove north, explaining to his young children on the way the sad fact that Grandpa might not recognize them when they got there. As it happened, they arrived minutes too late; Willie Schmidt, a former history teacher and camp director, had died, probably as they were parking the car.

headline: Obama Is Winning One Big Battle
text: President Obama may be succeeding in at least one area: his battle to stop smoking.

headline: Dread Rattling Thunder! Yes, It’s Shakespeare
text: Messing around with Shakespeare is the bedeviling vice of directors. Saving him from their excesses is the great and noble duty of actors.

headline: A Roomful of Yearning and Regret
text: NOT long ago, the friend of a friend spent the night in a hotel room, which is sometimes what you do when you find out your spouse has been having a yearlong affair. His flight was sadly predictable  it’s all many of us are capable of after discovering such a betrayal  though I am sure he now realizes that mere movement is not a fix for that kind of agony.

headline: Singing Helps NBC
text: Episode 2 of NBC’s a cappella series “The Sing-Off” helped lift the network into second place in the ratings on Wednesday. According to Nielsen’s estimates, 7.6 million viewers tuned in to the series from 8 to 10 p.m., down slightly from the 8.6 million who tuned in to the “Sing-Off” premiere on Monday but still just enough to give NBC an edge over ABC for the night. CBS easily led the night over all, earning 12.2 million at 8 for “Survivor: Nicaragua” and 14.2 million at 9 for “Criminal Minds.” ABC garnered its best ratings with “Modern Family” at 9 (11 million) and “The Middle” at 8 (8.8 million). Fox was fourth.

headline: ‘1001 Inventions’
text: Photos from the new exhibition at the New York Hall of Science.

headline: In the South of France, a 1927 Ménage à Trois Takes an Incendiary Turn
text: The life and work of Ernest Hemingway have been notoriously difficult to translate comfortably onto the screen. For one thing, his signature spare sentences, when spoken by actors, often sound as affected as the most rococo effusions of Oscar Wilde. Beyond that, Hemingway’s chest-beating, rifle-bearing Papa Bear explorer persona seems overbearingly pompous if not creepily antediluvian in these postfeminist times.

headline: Eat Free? I Do!
text: My fiancé and I are researching venues for our wedding rehearsal dinner. We found an Italian restaurant that seemed perfect. We sat with the manager and came up with menu ideas, and told him we would come back that night to try the food. We returned with a couple of friends and spoke with the night manager, who knew about us and promised to “take care of us.” The meal was multicoursed and delicious, but we were shocked by a $300 tab. Were we wrong to take the manager at his word and assume the meal would be free?

headline: Comment Troubles

headline: I Just Popped Out to Play Beethoven
text: If you question whether the Museum of Modern Art should be collecting works of performance art, your doubts may be assuaged by the sight and sound of “Stop, Repair, Prepare: Variations on ‘Ode to Joy’ for a Prepared Piano,” a trenchant, newly acquired work by Allora & Calzadilla, the artist team that will represent the United States at the next Venice Biennale. Created in 2008 and first exhibited at the Haus der Kunst in Munich that year, this performance-sculpture-recital-dance piece was an instant hit when it was at the Gladstone Gallery in Chelsea in January 2009.

headline: Let a Hail of Bullets Be Your Umbrella
text: As far as movie meet-cutes go it’s hard to beat the one in “Vengeance,” when the mystery man played by the French chanteur Johnny Hallyday runs into three Hong Kong assassins in a Macau hotel. The three have just finished a job and slipped into the hall when they’re surprised by Costello (Mr. Hallyday), who’s headed toward his room. He gives them and their weapons the once over and strolls away, just another visiting Frenchman taking in the existential view. One beat later and they’re the best of friends.

headline: ‘Norman Rockwell: Behind the Camera’
text: Images from the new exhibition at the Brooklyn Museum.

headline: Chanel’s Métiers D’Arts Collection
text: The collection was created in 2002 to showcase the work of the small Paris ateliers.

headline: More Than Santa
text: A look at some of this year's holiday-themed shows.

headline: Chanel’s Byzantine Express
text: I always love Chanel’s Métiers d’Arts collection, created in 2002 to showcase the work of the small Paris ateliers, like Lesage, that the company bought. The clothes are quietly evocative of a place and usually a little more down-to-earth than couture. And, as we know, Karl Lagerfeld never minds extra work. I’ve seen two of the shows (in Paris and Tokyo); the latest one I had to catch online. It was held in the house, on the Rue Cambon. Called Paris-Byzance, the collection didn’t quite soar off to Byzantium — too somber in color and shape, I suppose — but I liked the use of square shapes (jeweled buttons especially), the straight-line long dresses, many of the murky carpet-colored tweeds, the flat sandals and Freja’s slouchy pants.

headline: Educator Is Said to Have Rejected Chancellor Job
text: In defending his selection for schools chancellor, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has called Cathleen P. Black, a publishing executive with no education experience, “exactly the right person for the job” and suggested that her skills as a manager were unrivaled.

headline: Exploring the Art of Louisiana Furniture
text: Louisiana cabinetmakers under Napoleonic rule earned job titles as elite as ébéniste and doreur, building and gilding furniture for plantation owners. The artisans’ ranks included slaves, free men of color and immigrants from Germany and the Caribbean. But they developed a signature Louisiana style.

headline: J.&J. Unit Issues Recall of Rolaids
text: A unit of Johnson & Johnson announced a nationwide recall on Thursday of all lots  more than 13 million packages  of the soft chewable versions of Rolaids, its popular antacid drug, after reports of consumers finding metal and wood particles in the products.

headline: Misfit’s Life of Exaggeration
text: The introspective ramblings of a young, underemployed actress get a thorough airing in “You Wont Miss Me,” an experimental portrait of a New York misfit for whom sex and the city are no longer enough.

headline: Warsaw Makes a Bid to Be Central Europe’s Financial Hub
text: WARSAW — It may come as a surprise to some people that the upstart Warsaw Stock Exchange has surpassed the venerable Vienna exchange in trading volume, but to Ludwik Sobolewski, president of the Polish bourse, this is old news indeed.

headline: Modern Treasure Hunts for the Whole Family
text: NOT long after Morgan Lawless, now 13, took up geocaching last year, he asked his mother, Lisa, if she could drive him to a cache near their home in Mamaroneck, N.Y., and let him seek hidden treasure by following Google maps on his iPad Touch.

headline: Movies in a Tunnel; Words and Photos in Harlem
text: This weekend Rooftop Films goes underground for two afternoons to show movies in the Atlantic Avenue tunnel in Brooklyn. On Saturday the event is Trapped in the Tunnel, a program of short films about people who venture into unknown territory, like an insurgent’s cave in the Iraqi desert, an abandoned coal mine in Pennsylvania and, in “Covered Tracks,” a film by Nathan Kensinger and Meghan O’Hara, a train tunnel under Manhattan that is 50 blocks long and has served as a makeshift town for the homeless. On Sunday a second series of shorts, Tunnel of Love, about ill-fated romance, will be shown. On both days the door, or rather the manhole on Atlantic Avenue and Court Street through which the audience will enter (down a 10-foot ladder), opens at 1 p.m. A tour of the tunnel begins at 1:45, with the screening at 2:15. A party at Last Exit bar (136 Atlantic Avenue, near Clinton Street) starts at around 4:15; drinks are compliments of Sailor Jerry rum. (Cobble Hill, Brooklyn; 718-417-7362, rooftopfilms.com; $20.)

headline: Step Hits Its Stride Again
text: FOR many, the very mention of step aerobics evokes images of exercisers in leg warmers and leotards, even though other classes have come to dominate group schedules at gyms today. In New York City, however, this seemingly faded fad from the 1990s is far from dead.

headline: Laura Halzack and Eric Naison-Phillips
text: LAURA HALZACK began studying ballet before she started school, and after graduating from the University of New Hampshire, dedicated herself to a career in dance. She left her hometown, Suffield, Conn., for Astoria, Queens, and filled hard years working odd jobs at night so she could take dance classes during the day. She joined the Paul Taylor Dance Company in 2006 and, as her star ascended, she learned to live a nomadic life on the road, touring for weeks on end.

headline: Unlicensed Drivers and Fatal Crashes
text: States have enacted measures to prevent illegal immigrants from having driver’s licenses and increased enforcement of laws against unlicensed driving. About 80 percent of illegal immigrants are Hispanic. According to federal crash data, Hispanic drivers killed in crashes are disproportionately unlicensed, particularly in Southern states where illegal immigration surged in the last decade.

headline: House Tour: Bridgeport, Conn.
Grey New York to Be Led by Its Chief Creative Officer
text: GREY, long dismissed as being as creative as its name, is giving a creative executive the job of leading its New York office, the agency’s largest, which produces campaigns for marketers like Canon, DirecTV, E*Trade, GlaxoSmithKline, Pfizer and Procter & Gamble.

headline: Aby J. Rosen
text: Mr. Rosen, 50, whose given name is pronounced ABE-ee, is a principal of RFR Holding, a development and property management company with offices in Frankfurt and New York.

headline: South Koreans Guess at the North’s Next Target
text: YEONPYEONG ISLAND, South Korea  Choi Cheol-yeong vividly recalls the shock and fear that he felt during North Korea’s lethal bombardment of this small island, and says his nerves remain on edge because he thinks another attack will come, possibly during South Korean artillery drills this week.

headline: Bernanke Interview an ‘Infomercial,’ Loeb Says
text: In his Third Point investor letter, the hedge fund manager Daniel S. Loeb ruminates on the art and purpose of a story, focusing specifically on the “60 Minutes” interview with Ben S. Bernanke, the Federal Reserve chairman, which he calls “a staged infomercial rather than a serious interview.”

text: Students resisted parliament’s decision to sharply increase college fees by protesting in central London and attacking a car carrying Prince Charles and his wife.

headline: After Operation, Rio’s Forces Greeted by Wariness
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — Flanked by officers holding assault rifles, José Mariano Beltrame, Rio’s security chief, strolled through the streets of Complexo do Alemão, just days after the police and military had stormed the notoriously dangerous slum and retaken it by force.

headline: Royals Hear Shouts of ‘Off With Their Heads’ in London
text: Updated | Friday | 9:08 a.m. As my colleague John Burns reports, the enduring image of Thursday’s protests in London may well be the stunned looks on the faces of Prince Charles and his wife Camilla, as they were subjected to a barrage of abuse while driving past protesters on London’s Regent Street.

headline: John E. du Pont, Heir Who Killed an Olympian, Dies at 72
text: John E. du Pont, an heir to the du Pont chemical fortune whose benevolent support of Olympic athletes deteriorated into delusion and ended in the shooting death of a champion wrestler, died Thursday in a western Pennsylvania prison. He was 72.

headline: After Aetna, Pondering Health Care
text: When tensions between the Obama administration and the nation’s health insurers were at their highest earlier this year, Ronald A. Williams, the chief executive of Aetna, stood out as one of the few industry voices that still resonated within the White House.

headline: A Bankrupt Bargain on Taxes
text: While Wall Street’s moguls and whiz kids might not want to admit it, the best way to figure out what’s really happening in the economy is to read the daily newspapers. You’ll learn all you need to know there. And the zeitgeist is fairly bubbling these days with an array of stories that seem to be pointing to serious economic trouble ahead. We can no longer ignore the message that is being broadcast loud and clear: We must get our fiscal house in order and take meaningful — exceedingly painful, yes — steps to close the $1.3 trillion federal budget deficit. You can be the most zealous Keynesian economist on the planet and still know that at some point we cannot continue to have both guns and butter without serious repercussions. And we have clearly reached that point.

headline: New York City Sues State Over the Cost of Housing Juveniles in Prisons
text: Taking a contentious step intended to shake up the state’s troubled juvenile prison system, New York City is suing the state, claiming it overcharged tens of millions of dollars a year for housing many of the city’s young offenders in upstate jails.

headline: Putting Rumors to Rest, Howard Stern Renews His Sirius XM Contract
text: Howard Stern is staying on satellite radio for another five years.

headline: A Love Tormented but Triumphant
text: If you’re going to read more than 700 pages of someone’s diary covering just a decade, you want him to be a good writer, to know interesting people, to be intensely self-aware and above all to be a fascinating companion. Christopher Isherwood ranks high on every count. He was 56 years old when he began these diaries in 1960, an Englishman who’d lived in the States since 1939, mostly in Los Angeles. In his youth he was best known for his Berlin novels, “Mr. Norris ­Changes Trains” and “Goodbye to Berlin,” on which much later the musical “Cabaret” was based.

headline: A Volleyball Contender Built on Family
text: The University of Northern Iowa’s McLeod Center in Cedar Falls has a sort of bandbox quality. Three thousand fans can sound like 10,000.

headline: Visualizing Slavery
text: The 1860 Census was the last time the federal government took a count of the South’s vast slave population. Several months later, the United States Coast Survey—arguably the most important scientific agency in the nation at the time—issued two maps of slavery that drew on the Census data, the first of Virginia and the second of Southern states as a whole. Though many Americans knew that dependence on slave labor varied throughout the South, these maps uniquely captured the complexity of the institution and struck a chord with a public hungry for information about the rebellion.

headline: Interim Coach Leads Vikings Out of Storm
text: EDEN PRAIRIE, Minn.  Three weeks into his tenure as interim coach of the Minnesota Vikings, Leslie Frazier still has not moved all his belongings from his defensive coordinator’s office at the Winter Park complex into the head coach’s suite, which overlooks snow-covered practice fields.

headline: Pact Lifts Limits on Civilian Nuclear Projects With Russia
text: WASHINGTON  While President Obama presses the Senate to embrace a new arms control treaty with Russia, another nuclear pact with Moscow cleared its final hurdle on Thursday after more than four years with virtually no notice but potentially significant impact.

headline: Beckman Coulter Puts Itself Up for Sale
text: 9:50 p.m. | Updated Beckman Coulter, a maker of diagnostic research equipment for biomedical companies, has put itself up for auction after receiving expressions of takeover interest, people briefed on the matter said Thursday.

headline: Clinic Serving Performers in Pornography Is Closed
text: LOS ANGELES — State health officials ordered a clinic that serves the pornography industry to close Thursday and denied its application for an operating license.

headline: Mexican City Is Blockaded by Gunmen
text: MEXICO CITY  Gunmen blockaded President Felipe Calderón’s hometown on Thursday, forcing drivers from their cars, trucks and buses, then setting the vehicles ablaze in the middle of major intersections.

headline: E.P.A. Delays Tougher Rules on Emissions
text: The Obama administration is retreating on long-delayed environmental regulations  new rules governing smog and toxic emissions from industrial boilers  as it adjusts to a changed political dynamic in Washington with a more muscular Republican opposition.

headline: Smaller Teams Feed Green Monsters
text: ORLANDO, Fla.

headline: Obama’s Hostage Deal
text: I’ve spent the past couple of days trying to make my peace with the Obama-McConnell tax-cut deal. President Obama did, after all, extract more concessions than most of us expected.

headline: San Diego House Is Burned Down, for Safety’s Sake
text: The authorities in San Diego County burned down a house filled with explosives on Thursday after determining that removal of the volatile clutter of chemicals, detonators and grenades would be too dangerous.

headline: Russia: Georgian Allegations Dismissed
text: Russia on Thursday dismissed Georgian charges that one of its servicemen was behind five mysterious explosions that unsettled Georgia this fall. A Foreign Ministry spokesman called the charge “the usual show put on by the authorities in Tbilisi.” He said the accusations were a transparent attempt on the part of President Mikheil Saakashvili to discredit Russia in the eyes of the international community. On Tuesday, Georgian authorities said they had arrested six Georgians who planted bombs on the orders of a Russian Army officer.

headline: Iran: Blogger Reported Freed on Bail
text: An Iranian-Canadian blogger imprisoned for more than two years has been released on furlough, according to a Web site close to President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad. The site reported that Hossein Derakhshan, 35, was temporarily freed on bail. Mr. Derakhshan was arrested in 2008 and sentenced to 19 ½ years in prison in September for offenses including propaganda against the government.

headline: Bronx Teacher Has Miscarriage After Trying to Stop Fight
text: A teacher had a miscarriage after trying to break up a fight between two students this week at her Bronx high school, school officials said Thursday.

headline: On Christmas Shopping Lists, No Credit Slips
text: Christmas will no longer be on credit for many shoppers, despite tempting offers from retailers and credit card companies trying to coax the plastic out of consumers’ wallets.

headline: Saying Goodbye to the Senate
text: On his way out, Senator Jim Bunning threw something akin to a brush-back pitch at some of his colleagues. Senator Robert F. Bennett, on the other hand, used his farewell address to give a gentler appraisal of his tenure in Washington.

headline: Paper Maker Emerges From Bankruptcy
text: OTTAWA  AbitibiBowater, the large newsprint maker formed through a merger three years ago, announced it had emerged from bankruptcy protection on Thursday.

headline: Making Disability Work
text: I will begin a new job for Citigroup in January, so this is my last article as a contributing columnist for The Times. I hope to see you again from time to time on the Op-Ed page.

headline: White House Chat for Bill Clinton
text: WASHINGTON  Former President Bill Clinton is to meet on Friday with President Obama at the White House for a post-election conversation about moving the agenda forward in a new political environment, a senior Democrat told of the meeting said.

headline: Progressives Keeping Heat on Obama
text: One progressive group sure doesn’t mind using President Obama’s words against him.

headline: Sudan: International Prosecutor Says Darfur Violence Has Continued
text: Hundreds of civilians have been killed and thousands displaced in Darfur in the past six months as violence has continued there, Luis Moreno-Ocampo, the prosecutor of the International Criminal Court, told the United Nations Security Council on Thursday. The government of Sudan was neither cooperating with the court in pursuing the perpetrators nor taking action on its own, he said. President Omar Hassan al-Bashir had ordered the attacks against civilians, the prosecutor said. The court has charged Mr. Bashir with crimes against humanity and genocide, but he has not been arrested. Sudan’s United Nations ambassador, Daffa-Alla Elhag Ali Osman, accused the prosecutor of recycling unconfirmed allegations.

headline: In Lee Sweepstakes, Yanks Make Bid Count
text: ORLANDO, Fla.  Brian Cashman spoke over the phone Thursday morning with Hal Steinbrenner, the Yankees’ managing general partner, and made a promise.

headline: The Senate Stands for Injustice
text: On one of the most shameful days in the modern history of the Senate, the Republican minority on Thursday prevented a vote to allow gay and lesbian soldiers to serve openly in the military of the United States. They chose to filibuster a vital defense bill because it also banned discrimination in the military ranks. And in an unrelated but no less callous move, they blocked consideration of help for tens of thousands of emergency workers and volunteers who became ill from the ground zero cleanup after the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001.

headline: House Passes Bill Averting Cut in Medicare Reimbursements
text: WASHINGTON — The House gave final approval on Thursday to a bill that would avert a 25 percent cut in Medicare payments to doctors by freezing reimbursement rates at current levels until the end of next year.

headline: Haiti’s Clouded Election
text: The furious protests paralyzing Haiti were provoked by the widespread suspicion that a botched presidential election is now being stolen. Haiti, with all of its many problems, desperately needs a credible, legitimately elected government. Haitian electoral officials need to scrupulously recheck vote totals under the close watch of outside observers.

headline: Revised Fed Data Raises Doubt on Foreign Appetite for Build America Bonds
text: Amid growing worries about state budget deficits and pension burdens, one bright spot in the municipal bond market has been data showing that foreign investment had climbed to record-setting levels.

headline: Tata’s Nano, the Car That Few Want to Buy
text: MUMBAI, India  When it was introduced in early 2009, the egg-shaped Tata Nano was billed as a modern-day people’s car, an ultracheap vehicle that would bring greater mobility to the masses of India and, eventually, the world. But those ambitions have stalled  for now, at least.

headline: Wal-Mart v. Class Action
text: Wal-Mart Stores is the largest private employer in the United States, with more than a million people on its payroll. It’s no wonder that a class-action lawsuit against the company would be major news when the suit alleges sex discrimination in pay and promotion against hundreds of thousands of female employees and could lead to back pay of billions of dollars.

headline: In Trying Times, Sympathy Is a Tough Sell
text: When the N.B.A. players union’s proposed changes to the labor agreement that is scheduled to expire after the season became public on Wednesday, the news was met with the studied response reserved for an accountant’s financial report.

headline: Dire Headlines Unsettle Muni Bond Investors
text: Armageddon makes for a sexy story. Volatility in the $2.8 trillion United States municipal bond market is real, but the scary tale being spun out of budget-busting states like California involves a lot of literary license.

headline: Senate Stalls Bill to Repeal Gay Policy in Military
text: WASHINGTON — In a blaze of unusual bipartisan fury, a military policy bill that would repeal the ban on gay and lesbian soldiers serving openly in the military stalled in the Senate on Thursday, severely diminishing the chances of ending the Clinton-era policy this year.

headline: Lobbying for Gold in Albany
text: Patricia Lynch, one of the most influential lobbyists in New York State, has agreed to pay a $500,000 fine and will be prohibited from doing any business with the state pension fund for five years. When one considers the sleazy way she maneuvered to get lucrative pension investments for her clients, that is only a slap on the wrist.

headline: Cuomo Gains an Ally for a Looming Fight With the Public-Employee Unions
text: Business and real estate executives intend to raise $10 million in the coming weeks in support of Governor-elect Andrew M. Cuomo’s looming showdown with government employees’ unions over wages and pensions.

headline: Obama Weighs a Broad Tax Overhaul
text: WASHINGTON  President Obama is considering whether to push early next year for an overhaul of the income tax code to lower rates and raise revenues in what would be his first major effort to begin addressing the long-term growth of the national debt.

headline: From Queens, Support for a Dissident
text: It took Sharon K. Hom two and a half hours on Wednesday evening to get by hired car from her home in Bayside, Queens, to Newark Liberty International Airport, a distance of about 22 miles. Much of the time was spent crawling, and barely at that, through the Lincoln Tunnel. Ms. Hom began to worry that she might miss her flight to Oslo.

headline: Hate Charges for 2 Accused of Attacking an Imam
text: Two men were charged with hate crimes on Thursday after they attacked a Muslim religious leader on a New York City subway train, the authorities said.

headline: Martin Russ, a Marine Who Wrote About Combat, Dies at 79
text: Sheets of enemy gunfire and a hail of mortar shells pinned down Sgt. Martin Russ and his platoon of Marines when they ventured into the no man’s land between North and South Korea in the summer of 1953 — the last days of the Korean War.

headline: Mixed Result for Bone Drug in Cancer Study
text: The results of a new study are tempering hopes that a drug used to treat bone loss might also help stave off relapses of breast cancer, especially for younger women, researchers said Thursday.

headline: Holder Denounces a Bill to Ban Detainee Transfers
text: WASHINGTON  Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. on Thursday denounced a Congressional proposal to block the transfer of any Guantánamo detainee into the United States, calling it “an extreme and risky encroachment on the authority of the executive branch to determine when and where to prosecute terrorist suspects.”

headline: Designer Found Dead in Bathtub at Hotel
text: They arrived together early Thursday, the fashion designer and her boyfriend, checking into the exclusive Soho House, where the woman’s membership privileges afforded them access to one of the club’s 24 hotel rooms.

headline: Payroll Advantages Give Red Sox Edge in Making Deals
text: For the past decade, the Yankees and the Boston Red Sox have been rivals not just on the field during the season, but also in the off-season while trying to sign big-name stars. One year, the Yankees sign C. C. Sabathia and A. J. Burnett. The next year the Red Sox add John Lackey and Adrian Beltre.

headline: Lottery Numbers
On Cuomo’s Taxes, a Home Away From Home
text: Andrew M. Cuomo lives much of the time in Mount Kisco, in suburban Westchester County, sharing a house with his companion, the cooking celebrity Sandra Lee, and voting there on Election Day.

headline: Rio’s Police Viewed With Uncertainty
text: After a police and military operation to reclaim the dangerous Complexo do Alemão slum in Rio de Janeiro from drug gangs, residents are viewing the security presence through cautious eyes.

headline: Fighting Pain and Paperwork, and Regaining a Home
text: Diana Brown has been sickly since childhood, suffering a variety of mysterious and disabling problems that often kept her home from school. She remembers a doctor telling her mother not to get too attached to her, because she would not be around very long.

headline: Quebec Fans Take Quest for a Team to Long Island
text: An estimated 1,100 fans from Quebec are piling into chartered buses and heading to Nassau Coliseum for Saturday night’s game between the Islanders and the Atlanta Thrashers, intent on sending a message to N.H.L. Commissioner Gary Bettman: We want a team of our own.

headline: Obama’s Very Good Week
text: Over the past week we’ve seen the big differences between cluster liberals and network liberals. Cluster liberals (like cluster conservatives) view politics as a battle between implacable opponents. As a result, they believe victory is achieved through maximum unity. Psychologically, they tend to value loyalty and solidarity. They tend to angle toward situations in which philosophical lines are clearly drawn and partisan might can be bluntly applied.

headline: About This Article
text: There are no precise statistics on illegal immigrants. For this article, The New York Times estimated the number of illegal immigrants who drive by analyzing data from the Census Bureau’s 2006-8 American Community Survey, which includes all United States residents regardless of immigration status as well as information about commuting to work.

headline: Some Unlicensed Drivers Risk More Than a Fine
text: LAWRENCEVILLE, Ga. — It was just another suburban fender-bender. A car zoomed into an intersection and braked too late to stop at a red light. The Georgia woman driving it, an American citizen, left with a wrecked auto, a sore neck and a traffic fine.

headline: Governor-Elect Turns to Longtime Aides as He Fills Top Jobs in His Administration

headline: Benefits of Estrogen Are Debated
text: Certain women who take estrogen to relieve menopausal symptoms may be protected from breast cancer, according to data released Thursday at the San Antonio Breast Cancer Symposium.

headline: Newton Denies Knowing About Father’s Scheme
text: Auburn’s star quarterback, Cam Newton, whose father solicited money from Mississippi State in a pay-for-play scheme, said Thursday in an interview with ESPN that he never discussed payments with the university and that he told N.C.A.A. investigators he had done nothing wrong.

headline: Jury Convicts 3 Officers in Post-Katrina Death
text: NEW ORLEANS  More than five years after a man named Henry Glover was shot and his body burned here by police officers in the days after Hurricane Katrina, a jury has weighed in on the circumstances of his death. Three police officers were found guilty Thursday night on nine federal counts in an emotionally charged case that painted a grim portrait of the city’s troubled Police Department.

headline: With Pitchers’ Contracts, 7 Is Unlucky Number
text: Seven years. Those two simple words are enough to send a shiver of fear through almost any general manager contemplating signing a free-agent pitcher to a contract of that length.

headline: Friday: Babes in Arms
text: FRIDAY’S PUZZLE — When I told today’s constructor, Elizabeth C. Gorski, that I could tell this puzzle was by her as soon as I saw the grid, her winking response was, “I hope I’m not becoming a predictable Johnny One-Note constructor.” Of course not, but few in the business have as distinctive a voice. Ms. Gorski is a musician and often includes unusual visual elements in her grids. She’s also a veteran constructor who can handle the wide open designs like today’s 63-worder. That single musical eighth note in a sea of white squares points directly at her.

text: Need another clue that the last two years on Capitol Hill were marked by acrimony and a lack of consensus?

headline: Obamas Light National Christmas Tree
text: President Obama, with help from his wife and daughters, flipped a switch to light the National Christmas Tree on the ellipse south of the White House and sent special holiday wishes to the unemployed and troops serving abroad.

headline: Auburn’s Newton Insists That He Did Nothing Wrong
text: Auburn’s star quarterback Cam Newton, whose father solicited money from Mississippi State in a pay-for-play scheme, said Thursday in an interview with ESPN that he never discussed payments with the university and that he told N.C.A.A. investigators that he had done nothing wrong.

headline: Senate Leaders Unveil Package of Tax Cuts
text: WASHINGTON  Senate leaders on Thursday evening formally unveiled the huge tax cut package worked out between the White House and Republicans and immediately began debating it, while House Democrats rebelled against President Obama and threatened to keep the measure from ever reaching the floor.

headline: Trade Growth Accelerated in China
text: HONG KONG  China’s exports and imports grew much more firmly than expected last month, figures showed Friday, fanning expectations that Beijing will soon raise interest rates further to fight rising inflation.

text: Bryan Curtis, left, of The Daily Beast and Conn Carroll of the Heritage Foundation debate the college football Bowl Championship Series.

headline: The Final Farewell at Cabrini-Green
text: The last tenant moved out of the last high-rise at the Cabrini-Green public housing development on Thursday, marking the end of a long and sad era in which the poor were stacked on top of one another in concrete towers that seemed as isolated and forgotten as prisons.

headline: String Quartets Thriving on Bay Area Arts Scene
text: String quartets are proliferating in Bay Area art spaces almost as fast as upscale food carts on street corners.

headline: Souvenirs of War and Hazards in the Attic
text: As World War II veterans pass away  the youngest soldiers who served are now in their 80s  they leave legacies of valor and sacrifice. Many are also leaving something else: explosives and weapons collected as battlefield souvenirs.

headline: Possible Candidate for District Attorney Carries a Powerful Name: Feinstein
text: For three decades, Katherine Feinstein, the only child of Senator Dianne Feinstein, quietly observed the milestones in her mother’s struggle to reach the top of national politics: Two failed San Francisco mayoral campaigns before the assassination of George Moscone elevated her to mayor; a bitter and unsuccessful race for governor; and, finally, a triumphant Senate bid in 1992.

headline: Fighting Prostitution One Motel at a Time
text: Around midnight on a recent Friday, a dreadlocked man wearing diamond earrings and a blue tie walked up to the National Lodge, a motel in East Oakland, and inquired through a bulletproof window about a room.

headline: Brokers Prepare for Wall Street’s Bonus Season
text: In real estate, this is the season to obsess about the bonus season. Wall Street bonuses, in the pre-housing-crash years, were a major economic engine driving sales in the city from January through the spring. They can be a broker’s bread and butter — brioche with brie, really, when you’re talking about multimillion-dollar bonuses and multimillion-dollar apartments.

headline: Dandy Don, Always on My Mind
text: Gary Cartwright wrote this column for the Texas Report

headline: Hispanic Farmers Feel Shortchanged by Settlement Offer
text: Modesta Salazar remembers playing baseball with her 12 brothers and sisters on the family farm outside the South Texas town of Pearsall, where her father and brothers grew cotton, corn and maize. “All this was beautiful,” she said wistfully, looking out over more than 500 acres of once-lush fields that are now scrubland, overtaken by mesquite trees and cactus. “Now it’s just stories.”

headline: How Real Does It Feel?
text: “Is it a documentary?” “Is it like a documentary?” I find myself hearing (and asking) these questions so often that I have started to wonder what they mean. It’s not just that the definition of “documentary” itself is mutable: unlike other journalistic and quasi-journalistic forms, no code of ethics has ever been agreed upon by practitioners of the art, and what rules of thumb there are tend to be temporary, controversial and broken as soon as they are made. To take examples only from this calendar year, a single generic rubric covers a muckraking, talking-head essay on Wall Street like Charles Ferguson’s “Inside Job,” a ruminative memoir on parenthood like “The Kids Grow Up,” by Doug Block, and an exercise in intensive fly-on-the-wall objectivity like Frederick Wiseman’s aptly titled “Boxing Gym.” And those are just the easy cases — the nonfiction films that the academy might agree to consider for its award in the always-crowded and controversial feature-documentary category.

headline: Will Losing Season Be a Financial Loss for Longhorns?
text: Since the Longhorns won college football’s 2005 national championship, the University of Texas at Austin has topped the Collegiate Licensing Company’s annual ranking of schools making the most off merchandise sales.

headline: GTT: Interesting Things in Texas This Week
text: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week.

headline: Cubs’ Off-Season Moves Generate Little Excitement
text: Carlos Peña is the Cubs’ choice to play first base in 2011, over Adam LaRoche. The Cubs had hoped to leave baseball’s winter meetings this week with one of the two left-handed hitters under contract and got a one-year, $10 million deal done with Peña early Wednesday. Be still my heart.

headline: China Tightens Bank Lending Rules
text: HONG KONG  For the third time in a month, China ordered banks on Friday to increase their reserve requirement, fanning expectations that Beijing would soon raise interest rates as it tries to control inflation and surging growth.

headline: Enchanted Realm, Aquatic View
text: Not long before the children’s movie “The Chronicles of Narnia: The Voyage of the Dawn Treader” sets sail, you might find yourself hoping for a nor’easter to come and blow this latest and perhaps last installment in the screen version of C.S. Lewis’s series, far, far away. But where would it go? Both Never Land and Wonderland are occupied, courtesy of the Walt Disney Company, which helped produce the first “Narnia” movies, the fairly diverting “Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe” and the disappointing “Prince Caspian.” Now 20th Century Fox has taken up the franchise with largely dreary results.

headline: Thunder and Lightning
text: A  century after Jim Thorpe first found athletic fame at the Carlisle Indian Industrial School in Pennsylvania, his sporting career is preserved primarily by witnesses’ words rather than by objective measurement. When he was at his peak, in the early 1900s, his best sport, football, was in its infancy, a rough game undergoing basic rule changes and largely devoid of statistics. What made him exceptional in any case was the unquantifiable combination of power and speed, only hinted at in yardage totals or points. Florid descriptions by the sportswriters of the day and recollections by those who played with him and against him make up a majority of the record. One reporter described his broken-field running as demonstrating “amazing intelligence,” as he evaded tacklers “by an easy lope that carries him over the ground at remarkable speed without betraying any undue haste.” His famed coach at Carlisle, Pop Warner, taught his player the technique of “unexpected contact,” which Thorpe mastered, where you sometimes fake the defensive player to make him stop moving, “then, wham, you hit him with the hip or stiff arm,” in the words of a teammate.

headline: How Do You Feel About Winter?
text: It’s cold out there. In Georgia, where this week news anchors reminded viewers to wear warm coats, and Miami, where at least one person sat on the beach while wearing gloves, many of us are dealing with cold — and the reality that winter is almost here. What’s it like where you live? How are you adjusting to the change of seasons? What are your favorite, and least favorite, things about winter in general?

text: Uwe E. Reinhardt is an economics professor at Princeton. He has some financial interests in the health care field.

headline: Roman Gallery Revisits Cranach the Bold
text: In the early 16th century, as Italian Renaissance masters worked for their Papal patrons in Rome, Lucas Cranach the Elder was honing a bold and innovative style of his own in Wittenburg, Germany, birthplace of the Protestant Reformation. His close personal and professional relationship with Martin Luther placed him firmly at odds with the politics and theology of Italy, and his work was divorced from the classicism of the Italian Renaissance. Embracing a unique blend of Flemish and German iconography — though one not completely devoid of Italian influence — Lucas Cranach the Elder pioneered his own Renaissance aesthetic.

headline: Tip of the Week: Customizing Safari’s Toolbar
text: Apple’s Safari Web browser includes a standard set of toolbar buttons for things like navigating through recently loaded Web pages, but you can also add buttons for popular actions like pasting a page link into a new e-mail message. To add new toolbar buttons, right-click (control-click on a trackpad or single-button mouse) in the gray area at the top of the Safari window. The Customize Toolbar menu should appear.

headline: Chad Pennington Describes How His Shoulder ‘Fell Out’
text: Dolphins quarterback Chad Pennington spoke with reporters Wednesday about how he’s handling his latest injury. He hurt his throwing shoulder Nov. 14, on his first play against Tennessee, in his first start of the season. He stayed in for one more play and completed a pass (naturally) — his 66 percent career completion percentage is the highest for an N.F.L quarterback. Pennington seemed to relish telling the story about how his shoulder “fell out.”

text: Bank of America said on Thursday that it would restart foreclosures on 16,000 properties this month, after suspending them in October because of the robo-signing scandal.

headline: Christopher Isherwood’s Mick Jagger
text: As everyone knows by now, Mick Jagger’s foibles and flaws are on display in Keith Richards’s autobiography, “Life.” (Mick’s harp playing receives the highest marks from Keith, but that’s pretty much it as far as unqualified praise goes.) Jagger comes off considerably better in “The Sixties,” the second volume of Christopher Isherwood’s diaries. Isherwood describes meeting Jagger in the Australian outback, where he was filming “Ned Kelly”: “Mick Jagger, very pale, quiet, good-tempered, full of fun, ugly-beautiful, a bit like Beatrix Lehmann; he has the air of a castaway, someone saved from a wreck, but not in the least dismayed by it.”

headline: Why Cash Is NOT King
text: “Cash is king” is a well-worn phrase that has been used quite a bit over the last few years. I hate to burst the bubble, but it is not true. Cash can be king for a day, a month or maybe even a year, but eventually it will be unseated by the real king: profit.

headline: Speaking Volumes | Birch Books
text: For those on your list who like to linger in the 20th century, to wallow in the cultural riptides of a predigital age, the holiday catalog for Birch Books (212-787-2844) is manna from heaven. Choose from well-priced first editions of still glossy coffee-table books, with titles like “Picasso’s Picassos (1961)” and Julian Schnabel’s “CVJ: Nicknames of Maitre d’s and Other Excerpts From Life (1987).” The pages from Robert Mapplethorpe’s “Certain People: A Book of Portraits (1985),” above, demonstrate what the photographer meant when he said, “I’m not interested in those plain … people.”

headline: Down the ‘Rabbit Hole,’ Together
text: In “Rabbit Hole,” Nicole Kidman and Aaron Eckhart play grieving parents dealing with the accidental death of their four-year-old son. The film, adapted by David Lindsey-Abaire from his Pulitzer Prize-winning play, was “a passion project for Nicole,” Mr. Eckhart said last year, when they were filming in Douglaston, Queens. It was the first movie from her production company, Blossom Films, and, as a producer, Ms. Kidman made an unorthodox choice for director in John Cameron Mitchell (“Hedwig and the Angry Inch”), who had never before directed a movie he didn’t write. “Rabbit Hole” was made for about $4 million, and eventually bought for distribution by Lionsgate. It opens Dec. 17 in limited release. In a wide-ranging interview in a SoHo hotel room recently, Ms. Kidman and Mr. Mitchell spoke about the constraints of indie filmmaking, their childhood and adult inspirations. This is an edited version of their conversation.

headline: Climate Talks Reach Final Day With No Deal
text: CANCÚN, Mexico — Negotiators blew past a self-imposed deadline for reaching an agreement at the United Nations conference on climate change here on Friday, working into the night to try to piece together a package acceptable to the nearly 200 participating countries.
