This year there will be the cringe-inducing giggles of “Little Fockers,” the sci-fi splendors of the “Narnia” franchise, an animated picnic with “Yogi Bear” and “True Grit,” a western from those nice Coen boys, Joel and Ethan.

headline: Snoring: What to Do When a Punch in the Shoulder Fails
text: DR. ELIZABETH WALTON, a 43-year-old internist in Atlanta and the mother of twin 4-year-old boys, has a common, if sometimes embarrassing, health problem. She snores  loudly. And she has tried to fix it with a variety of things, including a machine that blows air down her throat and an oral appliance that looks something like a mouthguard worn by a hockey player.

headline: The King’s Tongue Twisters
text: “My Fair Lady” had “The rain in Spain stays mainly in the plain.” “Singin’ in the Rain” had “Moses supposes his toeses are roses.” To cinema’s pantheon of tricky diction, we can now add, “I have a sieve full of sifted thistles and a sieve full of unsifted thistles, because I am a thistle sifter.” Audiences for “The King’s Speech” can hear Colin Firth as Prince Albert, Duke of York (later King George VI), practice this tongue twister as part of the speech therapy conducted by Lionel Logue, played by Geoffrey Rush.

headline: F.C.C. to Hold Forum on Teenagers and Technology
text: Parents, researchers and educators have been asking whether the spread of mobile devices and Internet access, for all their benefits, can have negative side effects for young people, interfering with homework or leading to cyberbullying. Now the government is asking the same question.

headline: Looking for the Real Mark Zuckerberg
text: When my grandmother was old and frail, my job was to run movies between her apartment and the corner video store. It wasn’t easy to choose movies for her. She was close to death, and she didn’t want a film that might upset her. That ruled out drama. But even comedies have conflicts. Eventually she settled on a single type of conflict she could tolerate: mild-to-moderate mistaken identity. In her last weeks, I brought her “My Favorite Spy,” “Some Like It Hot” and “To Be or Not to Be.”

headline: True to ‘True Grit’
text: Charles Portis, a novelist from Arkansas who politely declines to promote himself or his work, is best known as the author of “True Grit.” That’s mostly because John Wayne starred in the film adaptation, winning his only best actor Oscar for it in 1969. But there are passionate readers, among them the literary maestro Jonathan Lethem, the crime writer George Pelecanos and Ron Rosenbaum, that obsessive reporter on our obsessions, who regard Portis as a major figure in his own right: possessor of an original American literary voice comparable to Mark Twain’s.

headline: The Career Builder
text: The number of wide-release films made this year fell over 30 percent from 2007. As one of Hollywood’s best-known agents and the co-chief executive of William Morris Endeavor, do you see wide-release movies going the way of the dinosaur?  I think there were too many in the marketplace. I think that’s a correction to where it should be. About 1.3 billion people went to movies 10 years ago and about 1.3 billion go today. That has not changed.

headline: Tots on Bikes
text: My wife and I frequently transport our 4-year-old and 1-year-old by bicycle. They wear helmets and ride in a trailer or bike-mounted seats. People sometimes challenge us, asking if this is safe. The chances of our being hit by a car are low, but the consequences could be catastrophic. Is it O.K. to take the kids by bike when our admittedly safer, albeit not risk-free, car is available? DEREK PELLETIER,PORTLAND, ME.

headline: C’mon, Touch Me Babe
text: Dresses that fit like an embrace are nothing new. Dresses that show the imprint of every embrace, however, are far more unusual. We know of only one — this liquid blue “Science of Sequin” frock from the spring collection of Boudicca, the London-based label designed by Zowie Broach and Brian Kirkby. Run a hand over the sequins and they flip over, revealing a paler underside; if the path of the caress is retraced, they return to their original position. The idea of making a garment that recorded touch was, says Broach, “seductive as soon we came across the fabric. It immediately inspired your sense of imagination and play.” Only six dresses were made, and they arrive in stores this week, just in time for the holiday cocktail circuit. “What would be amazing,” Kirkby says, “would be to know where they finally end up. But something as unique as this is possibly best a secret that takes its own time to tell.”

headline: Theatrical Stumbles of Historic Proportions
text: HISTORY is being quickly shuttled off Broadway stages and back into the library stacks this fall, as three new high-aiming, talent-rich shows that delve into the American past for subject matter are playing to sparse audiences. The musicals “The Scottsboro Boys” and “Bloody Bloody Andrew Jackson” are closing with unhappy dispatch, despite reviews that range from respectful to ecstatic. And the new John Guare play about the Louisiana Purchase, “A Free Man of Color,” looks likely to eke out its limited run playing to strictly limited houses after sharply dividing the critics. Staged history lessons, it would appear, are about as appealing to Broadway audiences these days as Shakespeare without celebrities.

Companies like Tanztheater Wuppertal Pina Bausch regularly invite her over; she is currently in Germany on one of several European trips she makes each year for guest stints at influential festivals like ImPulsTanz in Vienna.

headline: Climate and Energy Beyond Cancún

headline: Accept It: Dylan’s Lyrics Are Sold at Auction
text: The ownership of Bob Dylan‘s handwritten lyrics to “The Times They Are a-Changin'” will soon be a-changin’ hands: on Friday, a weathered sheet of ruled paper on which Mr. Dylan scrawled most of the verses to that classic protest song were sold at an auction for $422,500, a representative for Sotheby’s said. The auction house said the winning bid, which includes the house’s commission, was made by Adam Sender, whom it identified as an American collector; he is also a hedge fund trader whose office is home to works by Ed Ruscha, Kara Walker and John Currin, according to a recent report by Bloomberg News. Mr. Sender took part in the auction by phone and outbid three other contenders to claim his trophy, which Sotheby’s expected to fetch $200,000 to $300,000. With this lot Mr. Sender does not receive the verse that begins, “Come writers and critics who prophesize with your pen,” which Mr. Dylan apparently added later, nor does he own the 1960s, which belong to everyone, man.

headline: American Girl
text: Many readers of “Little Women” have fantasized about being Jo; a few about being Meg, Beth or Amy. After reading Susan Cheever’s biography of Louisa May Alcott, even fewer would want to change places with the novel’s author. Like her heroine, Alcott was a bookish tomboy with three sisters, a writer who churned out pseudonymous melodramas before finding fame as a domestic novelist. Unlike Jo, Alcott never married, concluding that “liberty is a better husband than love.” Where Jo romps with her own children as well as a houseful of her husband’s students, Alcott declared that she “never liked girls” and stayed clear of children until adopting a niece at 48. A third difference is that “Little Women” portrays a matriarchal household made up of a mother, her daughters and their cook. Adding a servant spared her characters some of the domestic work that ate up Alcott’s own time. An even greater wish-fulfillment, however, lay in subtracting the man of the house. The March girls spend much of the novel waiting for their father to return from the Civil War, but in real life Alcott was the one who left Concord, Mass., in 1861 to nurse wounded soldiers.

headline: How One Dry Cleaner Competes With Tide
text: Joe Runyan, the founder of Hangers Cleaners in Kansas City, Mo., an environmentally safe dry cleaner, was concerned when, in 2008, Procter & Gamble opened its first franchised Tide-branded dry-cleaning facility 1.5 miles from the Hangers headquarters. As we discussed in a case study published in April, Mr. Runyan feared Tide would undercut his prices and outspend him on promotional material to gain market share.

headline: Childhood: Sick in Day Care May Mean Healthier in School
text: Young children in day care get more ear and respiratory tract infections than other children their age, a new study reports. But once they reach elementary school, they are sick less often.

headline: Risks: Hospital Admissions for Dog Bites Are on the Rise
text: The number of Americans hospitalized for dog bites almost doubled over a 15-year-period, increasing to 9,500 in 2008 from 5,100 in 1993, a new government study reports.

headline: The Shores of Tripoli
text: In the early 19th century, the United States Navy and Marines played a small but significant part in the demise of the Barbary corsairs, the pirates who terrorized the Mediterranean from their bases in Algiers, Tunis, Tripoli and Morocco. As a result, we Americans have tended to view this history through the lens of our own past. Adrian Tinniswood’s dramatic narrative, “Pirates of Barbary,” reminds us that the corsairs had preyed on Europeans long before the United States arrived on the scene. Indeed, they reached the height of their power in the 17th century, not long after the pilgrims landed on Plymouth Rock.

headline: The Kitchen God Dreams of Love
text: China, 1946: the Japanese occupation is over, and the people of Fushun are wondering when prosperity will return. But 16-year-old Yuying is anticipating the answer to her own big question — what her new husband will be like. Her father, the owner of three of the best restaurants in the city, has chosen a young man named Jinyi because he has agreed to take their family name, to live in their house and to let Yuying continue her studies. What Yuying doesn’t know is that her future husband is illiterate and of peasant stock. Although only a few years older than she, he has led a life of extraordinary hardship. He is, however, a good and loyal person and a fine cook. And the one thing he has never had — and really wants — is a family.

headline: 57th and St.-Honoré
text: The Dior store on East 57th Street is reopening on Saturday after a retouch by Peter Marino, and if you need a new dress or just want to pretend you do, it’s worth a visit. Mr. Marino, the architect of choice for many retailers (LVMH, Barneys, Armani), said he thought that the look of stores in general was becoming too international and what Dior’s New York flagship needed was a frank hint of Paris elegance.

headline: TimesCast | December 10, 2010
text: Chinese government censors news of the Noble Peace Prize; U.N. representatives meet in Cancun to negotiate climate change policy; and a contender for the Heisman Trophy is surrounded by scandal.

headline: Should You Google at Dinner?
text: WHEN I was growing up, we used to play a game that went something like this: If you could invite any five people from history to dinner, who would it be? That game seems to have lost popularity of late, and I’m beginning to think I know why. These days, everybody I know invites the same guest to dinner. Who’s this ubiquitous invitee? The answer is sitting in your pocket.

headline: Graphic Books Best Sellers: Fearless ‘Ex Machina’
text: Starting with the last page of its very first issue, “Ex Machina” boldly announced its willingness to go beyond your typical funny book fare. The final panel (six-year-old spoiler alert!) revealed that one of the World Trade Towers was still standing (end of six-year-old spoiler) thanks to the series’s protagonist, Mitchell Hundred, a k a the Great Machine. With a stroke, the writer Brian K. Vaughan and the artist Tony Harris created an incredible hook for readers while offering something tonally different from everything else on the stands. Batman, this was not.

headline: For Sleepy Drivers, a Portable Alertness Monitor
text: Ever nod off for a brief moment at the wheel? According to a recent National Sleep Foundation poll, 60 percent of Americans have driven a car while feeling tired. The AAA Foundation for Traffic Safety says that one in six fatal accidents involves a sleepy driver — and two out of five drivers (41 percent) acknowledge having at some point fallen asleep at the wheel.

headline: Will Another Suitor Emerge for Tenet?
text: Shares in Tenet Healthcare jumped more than 53 percent on Friday morning, to $6.59, in the wake of Community Health Systems’ $3.3 billion hostile bid for the hospital operator.

headline: Holiday Wish List | Sara Moonves
text: Fresh off a shoot in St. Barts for T: Travel, the fashion editor Sara Moonves knows a thing or two about fun in the sun. A native Californian, she’s dreaming of surfboards and Eres string bikinis this season. Where she plans to put these items to good use is anyone’s guess. Cartagena or Mustique, anyone?

headline: Weekend Competition: Define Friendship
text: In November, co-vocabularists generously offered definitions of family; this weekend, Schott’s Vocab is soliciting definitions of friendship.

headline: Euro Bonds Rejected by Germany and France
text: BERLIN  The leaders of France and Germany on Friday rejected calls to introduce euro zone bonds as a means of deterring speculators and protecting the euro and further joined forces to keep the issue from gaining ground at a summit meeting of European officials next week.

headline: In Italy, a Political Opera About Opera
text: MILAN  La Scala opened this week with a new and in many respects outstanding production of Wagner’s “Walküre.” No matter how much opera has declined as a popular pastime in this country, the start of the season here remains the grandest event on the Italian cultural calendar, attracting glitterati and heads of state who pay roughly the price of a used Alfa for a ticket and the chance to preen before paparazzi and television cameras.

headline: One Way to Retire an Old Rifle
text: Earlier this year, as part of the tools of war series, At War published photographs of Taliban small arms from Helmand province, along with data on the types of firearms in insurgent use. The photographs included images of bolt-action rifles, including one, a Lee-Enfield rifle, that dated to 1915.

headline: In Cancún, a Roar of Indignation From Bolivia
text: As the United Nations conference on climate change in Cancún, Mexico, entered its last official day on Friday, one thing was clear: whatever the final outcome, real progress on reining in the emissions responsible for global warming would have to wait for another time.

headline: Former Goldman Programmer Found Guilty of Code Theft

headline: Promotion Renews Manhattan Theater Club’s Focus on Off Broadway Home
text: Signaling changes to come in how it selects and produces new plays, Manhattan Theater Club will promote its associate artistic director, Mandy Greenfield, to the new position of artistic producer in January. The theater’s artistic director, Lynne Meadow, said in a recent interview that Ms. Greenfield would take the lead in selecting, developing and mounting work for the club’s Off Broadway stage at City Center.

headline: Stamkos Dry Spell Hardly a Slump
text: After scoring 21 goals in his first 22 games this season, Steven Stamkos will play a pair of high-profile contests in his native Canada this weekend carrying a six-game goal-less slump. That this is a story only shows how far the Tampa Bay Lightning center has come in a short time.

headline: Working on the Ending
text: When you’re a young writer, you subtract the birth dates of authors from their publication dates and feel panic or hope. When you’re an old writer, you observe the death dates of your favorite writers and you reflect on their works and their lives.

headline: Pass the Pasta!
text: With a few simple ingredients from your pantry and refrigerator, you can create quick, easy and elegant pasta dinners, explains Martha Rose Shulman in this week’s Recipes for Health. She writes:

headline: Virtual Scalpel
text: Why is everyone always out to get Kay Scarpetta? In PORT MORTUARY (Putnam, $27.95), the stern taskmaster of Patricia Cornwell’s elaborately techno-savvy novels has just finished a six-month course at the Dover Air Force Base military mortuary that has qualified her as a forensic radiologic pathologist. Which means she’s now up to snuff on the cutting-edge computer systems that will allow her to perform virtual autopsies at her new $30 million headquarters in Cambridge, Mass., a private facility with federal and military ties.

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: FAME: What the Classics Tell Us About Our Cult of Celebrity,  by Tom Payne (Picador, paper, $16.) Moving between ancient literature and today’s trashy tabloids, Payne advances a persuasive, if unsettling, definition of what fame is and has ever been.

headline: My Mailbox Overrunneth (With Junk Mail)
text: Direct mail companies advertise that direct mail accounts for “only” 2.4 percent of trash in landfill in the United States, and that the recycling of direct mail offerings has increased 700 percent since 1990.

headline: A Christmas Carol From Young Jean Lee
text: It’s no surprise that the cast of the theater-themed “Glee” have hit the top of the iTunes charts with its sugar-cookie rendition of “Welcome Christmas.” But theater fans of a more downtown stripe might be surprised to know that a new Christmas song, performed by the subversively funny playwright Young Jean Lee, will be vying for some holiday attention.

headline: Paperback Row
text: BLOOD-DARK TRACK: A Family History,  by Joseph O’Neill (Vintage, $15.95.) First published in 2001, O’Neill’s reconstruction of the lives of his grandfathers — one Turkish, one Irish, both imprisoned on suspicion of subversion during World War II — is a double narrative involving an unsolved 65-year-old murder, a rusted pistol, clandestine train travel and assignations in the dark. O’Neill “tirelessly turns the soil of his grandfathers’ lives, discovering proofs of guilt or innocence in the offhand utterances of relatives, in obscure documents . . . and in shards of local history, politics, language and custom,” Colin Harrison wrote in the Book Review.

headline: App Smart Extra: Apps for Apps
text: Lists of favorite apps, as in Thursday’s App Smart column, generally allow for a good balance of breadth and brevity — which helps explain why such columns are widely circulated.

headline: Inside the List
text: DARK HORSE: When Jaimy Gordon’s “Lord of Misrule” — No. 30 on this week’s extended hardcover fiction list — shot out of nowhere to win the National Book Award last month, most reviewers were caught flat-footed. At awards time, only a handful of publications had reviewed the book, including The Washington Post, where Jane Smiley praised Gordon’s ear for dialogue and “eye for a horse,” and The Daily Racing Form, which saluted her vivid evocation of a low-stakes West Virginia racetrack in the early 1970s.

headline: U.S. and Allies Plan More Sanctions Against Iran
text: WASHINGTON  President Obama’s chief nuclear adviser said Friday that the United States and its allies planned new sanctions in an effort to test “Iran’s pain threshold” and force the country into suspending its production of nuclear fuel.

headline: Tragedy in Black and White
text: In the austral summer of 2005-6, the veteran magazine journalist Fen Montaigne traveled to Palmer Station in Antarctica to work with the highly regarded polar ecologist Bill Fraser. For nearly five months, Montaigne gamely weighed and banded Adélie penguins and their predators, attached radio tags to feathers, dodged shooting streams of gack (giant-petrel vomit), sifted through guano in search of silverfish otoliths and reveled in the sensory delights of “the most alien and beautiful place on the planet.”

headline: Learned Lolita
text: Characters should want something in every scene, Kurt Vonnegut once advised fiction writers, even if it’s only a glass of water. The idea is that yearning makes us human, and our idiosyncratic desires often get us into interesting forms of trouble. At the start of his new novel, “Sunset Park,” Paul Auster merrily disregards Vonnegut’s rule, introducing Miles Heller as a man with no longings or hopes who has trained himself to want “as little as humanly possible.” On the surface, “Sunset Park” is fairly straightforward, without Auster’s trademark postmodern flourishes. Yet he tests the rules throughout, as if the experiment were to write a conventionally satisfying novel while bucking many of the conventions of how to write fiction.

headline: Hallucinatory Effects
text: Jim Carroll died at the age of 60 a year ago. Rumor has it that his death had something to do with liver damage due to substance abuse. If that is incorrect, repeating it here is no more or less unfair than the way he himself massaged the facts of his life for public consumption. Carroll was a product of his imagination, like many of the best poets (Col. Tom Parker, Guillaume Apollinaire, Josef von Sternberg), and he was one of the best ­poets. There’s a parallel time and world inhabited by those who understand that all information is legend, that experience is show business. That’s why Hollywood is the dream factory and Carroll’s first commercial poetry collection was “Living at the Movies” (and perhaps why his “Selected Poems” is called “Fear of Dreaming”). He lived in his head. Doesn’t everyone? The difference is that he knew it.

headline: All the King’s Men
text: Thomas B. Allen, the author of several books about American warfare, has a strangely neglected topic in the Americans who opposed the Revolutionary War. There hasn’t been a big book about the loyalists since before the Bicentennial.

headline: European Exotic
text: Hedy Lamarr, born Hedwig Kiesler in 1914 in Vienna, enjoyed an early if not particularly auspicious start in Max Reinhardt’s theater, and a few bit parts in movies before the Czech director Gustav Machaty cast her as the centerpiece of “Ecstasy.” The idyll of a young bride, married to a frigid older man, who finds liberation in the arms of a virile engineer was genuinely audacious in its concentration on a woman’s thwarted desire. But what made it the scandal of its time — 1933 — and onward were bucolic nude scenes of the star swimming and chasing a runaway horse, and rapturous close-ups of her sexual awakening. Seeing it now, one imagines generations of adolescents approaching it expecting soft-core titillation and being disappointed by the wholesomeness of a girl who is less sex goddess than pudgy teenager with small breasts (about which more to come). In an all-but-silent movie that has more in common with Leni Riefenstahl’s mountain-girl films (not to mention Soviet paeans to the Noble Worker), Hedwig is radiantly and un-self-consciously “au naturel,” lovely but as yet unformed, ­undefined.

headline: Waterworld
text: Simon Winchester’s books are often driven by dramatic events: homicide, eruption, earthquake. They’re thriller-histories, and he does them brilliantly. He made his name with “The Professor and the Madman,” a gripping account about murder, insanity and the making of the Oxford English Dictionary. His subsequent output revealed a taste for big Earthy subjects. “The Map That Changed the World” spun the history of geology into a popular beach book. Later books turned the same trick with volcanoes (“Krakatoa”) and earthquakes (“A Crack in the Edge of the World”).

headline: Arenas Endures Year of Turmoil, Changes
text: About the only constants with Wizards star guard Gilbert Arenas have been drama and its consequences, particularly in the year since his biggest drama, the ill-advised day last December when he brought guns into the Wizards locker room to allegedly confront teammate Javaris Crittenton over an unpaid gambling debt.

headline: Snowing in Antarctica
text: John Goodge, left, a professor of geological sciences at the University of Minnesota-Duluth, and Jeff Vervoort, an isotope geochemist from Washington State University, will be writing occasional posts from their research expedition in Antarctica.

headline: No Chocolate in the Library

Short of creating his own Dewey Decimal System, Mr. Bennett, 38, said he plans to install a kiosk to help customers navigate his shop: The Chocolate Library.

headline: ‘The Closer,’ With Kyra Sedgwick, Will End Next Year
text: Joining the ranks of other popular cable series that have recently wrapped up or are planning to pack it in, TNT said on Friday that the coming season of “The Closer,” its long-running crime drama starring Kyra Sedgwick as a Southern detective relocated to Los Angeles, will be its last. TNT said the decision was Ms. Sedgwick’s to conclude the show.

headline: The Economic Sweet Spot of Presidential Terms
text: THE American economy, and the American stock market, tend to do much better when a president’s term is nearing an end than they do when the term is beginning. If that pattern continues, the news from both Wall Street and Main Street may get better over the next two years.

headline: How to Avoid Being Taken in by a Ponzi Scheme
text: PONZI schemes are in the news again. The Justice Department announced this week that it had brought criminal and civil cases against more than 500 people for fraud schemes that involved more than $10 billion in losses. At the same time, there has been a flurry of lawsuits from Irving H. Picard, the bankruptcy trustee in the Bernard L. Madoff case. Mr. Picard is hitting a deadline for filing lawsuits seeking to recover money for people swindled in Mr. Madoff’s Ponzi scheme, which came crashing down two years ago today.

headline: Hive-minds and Kleptocrats

headline: Timberwolves Put a Good Spin on Being Bad
text: The Minnesota Timberwolves are, by most measures, a perfectly abysmal basketball team. Only one N.B.A. squad currently boasts an inferior record to the lowly Wolves, and a deeper look into Minnesota’s performance doesn’t yield a rosier outlook. If teams exist in this league solely for the purpose of winning games, then the very existence of the Timberwolves franchise is an abject failure. It takes a unique brand of incompetence to build a roster this incapable, and in that regard, Minnesota is impressive in their impotence.

Bloomberg told his business-world peers on Friday that if they cared about their city and, more pointedly, their companies, they needed to support his call for comprehensive immigration reform. The economy is suffering because of Washington’s failure to change restrictive policies, he said, and talented entrepreneurs were taking their ideas to other countries that are only too happy to host them.

headline: Letter: The Professor of Micropopularity
text: Carlo Rotella’s article, about the film professor and Focus Features C.E.O. James Schamus, is a paean to what a liberal-arts education should be about — the appreciation and contemplation of truth and beauty. This ought not be limited to classes like Schamus’s; it should be an essential part of every education. The next generation will be the first in our nation’s history to be less educated while spending more time in school because of the obsessive focus on education as only a means to a future paycheck. I hope Schamus’s students wander far and wide and continue the essential pollination of all our “professional” endeavors with his particular brand of “weird.”

headline: Letters: Junking Junk Food
text: Judith Warner correctly identifies that our culture has to change if we’re going to stem the tide of America’s obesity epidemic. When she examines how to change the nation’s smoking and eating norms, however, she quotes David Kessler, the former F.D.A. commissioner, as saying, “It was a shift in cultural attitudes, not laws or regulations, that led Americans to quit smoking.” We at Public Health Law and Policy strongly disagree.

headline: Putting Climate Science in Its Place

headline: Letter: A Big, Fat Miracle
text: As the author of a book on the use of enteral nutrition to treat Crohn’s disease, I am all too familiar with the skepticism Fred Vogelstein faces because of his son’s use of the ketogenic diet for epilepsy (Nov. 21). Like the keto diet, enteral nutrition — an all-liquid diet — has been recognized for decades as an effective treatment for Crohn’s. But in spite of randomized, controlled trials confirming its efficacy, few doctors prescribe it, and patients who try it face the same “curiosity bordering on alarm” that Vogelstein describes. Unfortunately, the proliferation of quack dietary treatments has made gaining acceptance of nutritional therapies that actually have solid science behind them an uphill battle.

headline: Letter: Killing a Dead Horse
text: Sadhbh Walshe’s anecdote distilled a sentiment I have struggled to articulate since the economic downturn: despite our collective temptation to indulge in defeatist lamentations over our imagined powerlessness — given the job market, mortgage crisis, health care and so on — our work may lie in the situation that is right before us, whether that be the opportunity to extend love to a friend, a neighbor or an animal in need. These seemingly small gestures may be our ‘‘right work’’ at the moment. Thank you for reminding us how immeasurably powerful we human beings are in the best and worst of times.EMMA LYNN WORTHNew York

headline: A Gentle Nudge About the Deficit
text: With the recent deal to extend the Bush tax cuts, cut payroll taxes and extend unemployment benefits, it may seem like Washington does not care quite as much about the deficit as some politicians have let on. And given that the policies needed to get long-term fiscal problems under control (higher taxes, fewer government services) are unpopular in the short-term time frame under which politicians face re-election, it seems unlikely that we should expect much movement on these issues in the near future.

headline: Shifting Amid, and Asserting, His Own Cinema
text: WHEN Bernardo Bertolucci was asked in 1996 if he knew that artists always put themselves in their work, he responded by quoting an author he refused to identify: “We work in the dark  we do what we can  we give what we have. Our doubt is our passion, and our passion is our task. The rest is the madness of art.”

headline: No New Charges in British Phone-Hacking Case

headline: Bringing Love to Strong Women
text: LIKE a presidential election or the arrival of a rare astronomical body, the release of a new James L. Brooks movie is always an event. It’s been six years since his last directorial effort, “Spanglish,” and 13 since the release of “As Good as It Gets,” which won Academy Awards for Jack Nicholson and Helen Hunt. At 70 Mr. Brooks could easily rest on his laurels: a roster of credits that includes “The Mary Tyler Moore Show” and “Taxi,” “Broadcast News” and “Terms of Endearment,” not to mention his current day job as an executive producer of “The Simpsons”; he was also a writer and producer on “The Simpsons Movie” in 2007. Instead he’s getting back into the game with “How Do You Know,” a romantic comedy (which Columbia Pictures will release on Friday) about the intertwined lives of a professional softball player (Reese Witherspoon), her self-assured boyfriend (Owen Wilson), an executive (Paul Rudd) in legal trouble, and his father (Mr. Nicholson).

headline: Farewell, Four Loko
text: Four Loko In the East Village from Claire Glass on Vimeo.

headline: A Convergence of Hot Rod Covers
text: Whether the goal is escapist entertainment or ambitious self-betterment, digging into a good book can be one of life’s great pleasures.

headline: Why M.&A. May Rebound
text: After a long drought, companies and private equity firms may be ready to make deals again, oddly enough because of cash, debt and taxes.

headline: Fretting at the Gas Pump
text: Gasoline prices are rising again.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Norway and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Norway, Peru, Kashmir and Haiti.

headline: Resorts for Skiers of Every Type
text: A rundown of some of the best winter retreats for extreme skiers, families, nonskiers and luxury-seekers.

headline: From Vail to Gstaad, Lures Beyond the Slopes
text: THE latest crop of new and improved ski lodges work hard for your money. It’s no longer enough to offer ski-in/ski-out access, a downy duvet and hot chocolate by the lobby fire. In an effort to extend their appeal to the occasional skiers or nonskiers in the family, resorts have expanded their off-mountain attractions, adding diversions like increasingly lavish spa treatments, hot-air balloon rides and bowling. Children get special attention at these elevations, with nonski activities tailored to them, including hotel scavenger hunts and mountaineering classes. Guests still check in for the slopes, but now there’s much more to do after the lifts close. These newcomers best represent the ski-free entertaining trend.

headline: A Season of Ski Happenings: Polo, Competitions, Carnivals
text: From a slope rodeo to a costume contest on skis, a selection of events for doers and watchers alike.

headline: Avalanche Survival: Know Your Snow
text: IT was a skier’s fantasy: four feet of powdery, fresh snow draped across the backcountry of Red Mountain Pass in Colorado. But the dream quickly turned nightmarish when, just a few feet from my skis, the slope tore open and a gash ripped across the mountain like a zipper. I fell into a shallow crevice and watched as a slab of snow broke into chunks that tumbled down like giant cinderblocks.

headline: Is Disentis Skiing’s Next Big Secret?
text: IN the early 1990s, Powder magazine, the proudly die-hard ski rag that has weaned countless future ski bums, published an article in which the author spoke of a mystical ski area of unprecedented off-piste challenge. So paranoid was the writer that this mountain’s pristine slopes and elevator-shaft chutes would soon be overrun by, well, the rest of us, that he wouldn’t even name the place. He would only call it — tantalizingly — Valley X.

headline: In Zurich, a District Cleans Up
text: Though questionable characters still populate parts of Aussersihl, bohemian boutiques and avant-garde galleries have moved in over the past few years in other parts of the neighborhood.

headline: Switzerland’s Valley Z
text: In Disentis, Switzerland, powdery valleys are served by a resort’s ski lifts, but they are ungroomed and uncrowded, for now.

headline: Bill Clinton Holds Court in Impromptu White House News Conference
text: Former President Bill Clinton held a remarkable, spur-of-the-moment news conference at a White House podium on Friday to announce his backing for the tax compromise President Obama reached with Republicans this week.

headline: Rendering Elgar’s Mercurial Impressions
text: At his best Colin Davis brings a magisterial British reserve touched with wildness to his conducting. This blend of seeming opposites is rarely 50-50. It depends on the piece. And certain composers are best suited to Mr. Davis’s passions, among them Berlioz, Sibelius and Stravinsky.

headline: Where Is Reggie Bush’s Heisman?
text: The Heisman Trophy is, presumably, somewhere in New York City.

headline: Sanders Rails Against Tax Bill — For Hours and Hours
text: 7:04 p.m. | Updated Senator Bernard Sanders, independent of Vermont, took to the floor of the Senate at 10:24 this morning to denounce the tax cut deal struck between the White House and congressional Republicans — and kept going for more than eight hours.

headline: The Week in Pictures for Dec. 10
text: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include the new 42nd Street, the Chelsea Hotel and a memorial for a Beatle.

headline: Chic In Review | When Giorgio Met Gaga
text: All the fashion news of the week that’s fit to reprint.

headline: Illness Forces Navratilova to Leave Charity Climb
text: Had the climb gone according to plan, it would have been shared every step of the way, every dollar raised, Martina from Mount Kilimanjaro calling out to the world for a good cause.

headline: At Michael’s With Kirsten Dunst and ‘All Good Things’
text: The last time the Bagger was at Michael’s, we were having lunch with a midget (his term) wrestler named Puppet.

headline: Laughing and Crying at Ghosts, Fictive and Real
text: Perhaps the best way to describe Jack Ferver’s new “Rumble Ghost,” which reinterprets the 1982 horror film “Poltergeist” and later morphs into a psychodrama-therapy session, is that it’s a piece of theater with some dancing and a lot of choreography. In any case, it’s darkly funny.

headline: Private Negotiations Within a Public Setting
text: At the start of Risa Jaroslow’s new piece, “The Partner Project/Scene in Public,” a woman (Elise Knudson) walks briskly around the edge of the audience and then onto the stage, wearing a light coat. This may be a nod to New York’s frigid weather. But the fact that it takes a moment to register Ms. Knudson as a dancer, stepping from public realm to stage, seems emblematic of Ms. Jaroslow’s work, which has frequently blurred the lines between art and life in its use of nondancers and its preoccupation with community.

headline: Boyfriend Is Charged in Designer’s Death
text: Read the full version of this article appearing in Saturday’s newspaper.

headline: Formula One Confirms 4-Cylinder Engines for 2011
text: From our colleagues at the Formula One blog:

headline: Echoes From a Distant Contemporary Past
text: This is a collectors’ show. Nothing wrong with that. After all, collectors are people, too  very important people. They are the ones who keep the lights on and the curators running. Without patrons like the Medici, Pope Pius IV and the kings of France, we would not have Michelangelo, Leonardo or Versailles.

headline: The Airport Playhouse Is Grounded for Good
text: THE Airport Playhouse in Bohemia was in financial peril when Ed Brennan and his wife, Terry, started running it six years ago, Mr. Brennan said.

headline: Peter C. Marzio, Director of Museum of Fine Arts, Houston, Dies
text: Peter C. Marzio, the director of the Museum of Fine Arts, Houston, for the last 28 years, died this morning of cancer, the museum announced. He was 67. During his tenure, the museum’s attendance increased from 380,000 people annually to over 2 million, and its endowment grew from $25 million to over $700 million. A full obituary will follow.

headline: Finding Some Keys to Free Bach’s Music
text: THE harpsichordist Bradley Brookshire is on a mission. Mr. Brookshire, an assistant conductor at the Metropolitan Opera and the director of graduate studies at the Purchase College Conservatory of Music, means to infuse Bach’s oeuvre with the lifeblood he thinks revisionists have drained out of it. And his performing colleagues are on board.

headline: Raunchy Provocateur Exhibits a Different Passion
text: A perceptive listener might have recognized chords from “Jesus Christ Superstar” being pounded on a piano in a cramped rehearsal space on West 30th Street in Manhattan on Thursday night, but not the potentially sacrilegious way this musical was being performed.

headline: Noir-Infused Intrigue at a Lonely Bus Depot
text: I haven’t yet seen “Spider Man: Turn Off the Dark” on Broadway, but I did get a mild case of arachnophobia while watching “The Tangled Skirt,” Steve Braunstein’s overlong but deftly mannered play now onstage at New Jersey Repertory Company in Long Branch.

headline: Rookie’s Dunks Earn Online Views and On-Court Smiles
text: LOS ANGELES  Blake Griffin first dunked a basketball when he was 13, in the gym of his junior high school in Oklahoma. Nobody remembers it, probably, except for him.

headline: Apples With Candied Bacon à la Mode
text: Mark Bittman pairs sweet and savory in a simple dessert.

headline: The Game Is Big, but the Crowd Should Be Enormous
text: Almost 110,000 people are expected to watch when Michigan plays Michigan State in Ann Arbor on Saturday, a crowd that will shatter the hockey attendance record by more than 30,000. The notion of a crowd that size, roaring in temperatures expected to be at the freezing mark, a seething well of fans reaching up and up into the overcast wintry sky, gives pause to Rick Comley, the Michigan State coach.

headline: Apples With Candied Bacon à la Mode
text: Time: About 30 minutes

headline: Finally, a Dessert With Some Meat in It
text: BACON’S near-ubiquity has only occasionally extended to the dessert tray, but maybe it’s not a bad idea. I’ve been offered candied bacon a couple of times in the past year, and it got me thinking of a trail of ingredients. Bacon is, after all, a close cousin to lard, and lard makes a significant contribution to the best pie crusts. (You may not know it, but if you find most pie crusts disappointing, it’s a lack of lard, or butter, or both.)

headline: Amazon Extends Holiday Free Shipping Deadline
text: For people who are still in the “making a list, checking it twice” phase of Christmas shopping, Amazon.com has extended the deadline for free shipping in time for the holiday.

headline: Choosing Recipients of Charity
text: December is the season of solicitations, and besides the catalogs peddling obscure gadgets and enormous hunks of meat from the Great Plains, you’ve also probably received an impressive pile of pleas from various nonprofit institutions.

headline: Expanding Bacon’s Horizons
text: Bacon, apples, ice cream: Not exactly a classic combination, but a good one. Read more in this week’s Minimalist column.

headline: Rebuilt Theater Opening Amid Debate
text: It has a storied past that includes names like Eugene O’Neill and Edward Albee, and on Saturday the newly renovated Provincetown Playhouse will be opened to the public by New York University, which says it spent $4.5 million restoring a building that has played an important role in Greenwich Village and theatrical history.

headline: How to Divide Up Your Charity Budget
text: This weekend’s Your Money column was born of personal frustration. The charitable solicitations that pile up around this time of year are a nagging reminder to me that my family doesn’t do as good of a job as it should of thinking strategically about philanthropy.

headline: In a Crumbling Castle, a Coming-of-Age Story
text: “I Capture the Castle,” a gentle British heirloom currently being presented by the Shakespeare Theater of New Jersey through Jan. 2, falls neatly within the genre of coming-of-age plays. Unfortunately, it can be difficult to tell this type of tale when the actress playing the character who is supposed to be maturing is already a grown woman.

headline: Expecting Declarer May Ruff in the Dummy? Lead a Trump
text: The Bobby Nail Life Master Open Pairs at the Fall North American Championships in Orlando, Fla., last month was won by two young Japanese bridge professionals, Kazuo Furuta and Hiroaki Miura. They finished a board ahead of Fred Gitelman of Las Vegas and Brad Moss of San Anselmo, Calif., with Steve Garner of Chicago and Roy Welland of New York third.

headline: Early Mass, With Its Exoticism Intact
text: The Ensemble Organum, the French early-music choir directed by Marcel Pérès, has explored a rich repertory that runs from old Roman chant to Josquin, with occasional detours to examine Sufi and other Middle Eastern traditions. Mr. Pérès’s research and his view of history as a fluid continuum in which diverse influences mingle have led him to unusual and sometimes provocative ideas about how early church music might have sounded in its time.

headline: It’s What She Knows: The Luxe Life
text: AT 39 and with four features to her name, Sofia Coppola finds herself caught in something of a double bind  the predicament of the auteur whose constancy risks being seen as predictability, or worse. Her admirers detect in her work a good eye, impeccable taste, an exactitude with indistinct moods and feelings. Her detractors claim that her frame of reference is narrow, that she makes the same film over and over again.

headline: Braised Leg of Lamb With Olives and Celery Root Purée
text: Time: About 5 hours

headline: Seven-Hour Lamb, in About Five
text: SEVERAL years ago, I made a dish known as “seven-hour leg of lamb.” A much-esteemed, classic preparation, it called for braising the meat in wine and aromatics for the better part of a day, at which point, said the recipe, I’d serve forth a silky, tender cut of meat so soft you could cut it with a spoon.

headline: Strands Tied Into a French Knot
text: Among the many gifts that can be ascribed to the brilliant French pianist Pierre-Laurent Aimard, a knack for illuminating connections among the works he plays is certainly high on the list. In recent seasons Mr. Aimard has linked canonical pieces by Bach with modern fare by Xenakis, Ligeti and Elliott Carter; found common ground for Mozart and Stockhausen; and even convincingly played Mr. Carter’s music alongside a bit of Rachmaninoff.

headline: Leadership on the Field Made Him a Legend
text: In the annals of life lessons, coach wisdom has become canonical and perhaps none more so than Vince Lombardi’s, a fact that is news only to those whose exclusive contact with football has come from “Friday Night Lights.” Lombardi took over the Green Bay Packers in 1959, when the team was largely an object of derision, and led the franchise to five National Football League championships and two Super Bowl victories before the ‘60s had come to a conclusion.

headline: Now Baking | Blue Bottle Brooklyn Goes Beyond Coffee
text: When Blue Bottle Coffee decided to plant slow-drip roots in New York City asphalt earlier this year, I was excited, sure, but such scoops are better left to the barista trackers. It wasn’t until a few weeks later, when James Freeman (that’s Mr. Blue Bottle to you) told me about the second phase of his Williamsburg invasion that the mania hit. He’d be bringing the pastry program to Brooklyn in the fall, he said.

text: More Photographs

headline: McShane Retains Lead at London Classic; Anand Beats Carlsen
text: Luke McShane managed to draw against Vladimir Kramnik in a game that went 139 moves, while Viswanathan Anand beat Magnus Carlsen, who suffered his second loss of the tournament.

headline: For Would-Be Authors, a Chance at a Happy Ending
text: HUNTINGTON, N.Y.

headline: Horns Pointed Toward the Future
text: WHEN the tubist Charles Daellenbach and four compatriots formed the Canadian Brass 40 years ago, successful brass quintets were few and questions about the way forward were many.

headline: Once-Burned, Highland Is Bullish on Debt
text: After getting burned in the credit crisis, Highland Capital Management is optimistic again about high-yield debt.

headline: Walters and Winfrey Together Tie for Second
text: ABC’s hourlong Barbara Walters interview special with Oprah Winfrey on Thursday night attracted 13.1 million viewers, according to Nielsen’s estimates, enough to tie CBS’s “CSI” as the second-most-watched show in prime time. Both shows lagged just slightly behind “The Mentalist” on CBS at 10 p.m., which garnered 13.3 million viewers. CBS led the night ahead of ABC, winning the 8 p.m. hour with its comedies “The Big Bang Theory”(12.1 million) and “$#*! My Dad Says” (9.5 million). ABC broadcast the holiday specials “Shrek the Halls” at 8 (6.9 million) and “Prep and Landing” and 8:30 (7.5 million). Fox ranked third and NBC fourth.

headline: Why C.E.O.’s Should Stop at City Hall
text: This past Wednesday, Jim Gray, a wealthy construction executive from Lexington, Ky., flew to New York City for a whirlwind round of meetings. Mr. Gray, 57, is the chief executive of Gray Construction, a family-owned business that builds large industrial facilities for the likes of Toyota, Siemens, Caterpillar and other giant manufacturers. It has around $500 million in annual revenue.

headline: Canvas? Paint? No, Just Sound
text: LONDON — The Turner Prize, awarded annually to a British artist 50 or younger, tends to be won by someone who pushes the definition of “art” in novel and provocative (or derivative and irritating, take your pick) ways.

headline: Sexuality in Modernism: The (Partial) History
text: WASHINGTON  With the exhibition “Hide/Seek: Difference and Desire in American Portraiture,” one of our federally funded museums, the National Portrait Gallery, here in the city of “don’t ask, don’t tell,” has gone where our big private museums apparently dare not tread, deep into the history of art by and about gay artists.

headline: Spices of the ’60s in Lone Star Recipes
text: In the imaginary geography of pop, Texas is where thinkers get rowdy, restless, heartbroken and drunk. A Texas double bill, the Old 97’s and Hayes Carll, lived up to the reputation on Thursday night at the Bowery Ballroom.

headline: Nascar Driver Sues ExtenZe
text: Robby Gordon, the Nascar car owner and driver, has filed a $690,000 lawsuit against ExtenZe, formerly a sponsor of Gordon’s Sprint Cup team, claiming that the maker of male enhancement pills did not adhere to the terms of their sponsorship agreement.

headline: With Filibuster, C-SPAN Has a Hit on Its Hands
text: Mr. Sanders has gone to C-SPAN.

headline: 2010 on Pace to Be Warmest on Record, NASA Says
text: An analysis of average global temperatures through November by NASA’s Goddard Institute for Space Studies shows 2010 on pace to become the warmest year since the collection of temperature data began 130 years ago. NASA previously ranked 2005 as its warmest year ever.

headline: Body Fell From Plane, Authorities Say
text: BOSTON  A North Carolina teenager whose body was found in a Boston suburb last month had most likely stowed away inside a plane’s wheel well and fallen as it lowered its landing gear, the authorities said Friday.

headline: Naismith’s Papers Fetch Record $4.3 Million
text: David Booth grew up in Lawrence, Kan., the college town where James Naismith began coaching basketball at the University of Kansas a few years after inventing the sport in Springfield, Mass., in 1891.

headline: Look of the Moment | Phoebe Philo
text: The Look: Tux Redux — here reinvented as a jumpsuit. Smoking!

headline: How Does a State Get a House Seat?
text: With the release of new population figures coming soon, some states are preparing to gain House seats and others bracing to lose them.

headline: Sunday Preview
text: This week’s Travel section, the Ski Guide 2011, includes a compendium of information to help any skier through the coming season. Christopher Solomon reveals the next great unexplored ski haven: the off-piste runs of a resort in Disentis, Switzerland. There, he found “a 2,000-foot ski run blanketed with nearly untouched powder even though the latest storm had swept through nine days earlier,” he writes. “And we were alone. Not bad at all.”

headline: Court Rejects Industry Challenge to Limits on Smokestack CO2
text: Efforts to restrict greenhouse gas emissions through an international agreement still appear mired in an array of disputes on display in Cancún climate talks.

headline: Agency’s Shtick Is Jewish Humor for a Good Cause
text: In these darkening days between Hanukkah and Christmas, here is a story to keep your spirits high  a story of cooperation between Jews and Christians, between people named Seinfeld and Samberg and people named Morgan and Lohan. A story of celebrities putting ethnic differences aside to raise money for charity.

headline: The Dan and Dave Show
text: TWO wolves were eating at the Lion. Dan Abrams, NBC’s chief legal analyst and founder of the Mediaite Web site, was sharing a table at the boisterous Greenwich Village restaurant with Dave Zinczenko, editor of Men’s Health and author of the best-sellers “The Abs Diet” and “Eat This, Not That.” The men are active investors in the Lion, their first joint venture in a decade of friendship that tends to be characterized in the gossip pages as “bachelors in a bromance,” as Mr. Zinczenko, 40, put it, laughing.

headline: Events in Westchester
text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around the Hudson Valley. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com, or by mail to Westchester Calendar, Metropolitan, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

headline: Events on Long Island
text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around Nassau and Suffolk Counties this week. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com, or by mail to Long Island Calendar, Metropolitan, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

headline: The Surprise Trip to the Briefing Room
text: The unannounced visit by President Obama and former President Bill Clinton to the White House briefing room was a surprise to absolutely everyone – including Mr. Obama’s top advisers.

headline: Events in Connecticut
text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in Connecticut this week. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com, or by mail to the Connecticut Calendar, Metropolitan, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

headline: Power Spots
text: Miss being exiled to Elaine’s Siberia? Here are other restaurants that cater to power diners.

headline: A Good Way to Begin a Story
text: I DON’T recall my first night at Elaine’s, but I know why I was there.

headline: Events in New Jersey
text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state. Items may be submitted by mail to New Jersey Calendar, Metropolitan, The New York Times, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405; or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: Special Cakes, on and Off TV
text: When Corina Elgart, 33, of Huntington, N.Y., was a criminal investigator in Washington, she never dreamed she’d be competing in “Next Great Baker,” the TLC reality-show spinoff of Buddy Valastro’s juggernaut, “Cake Boss.” But she is in fact whipping up cakes for special occasions with the other contestants on the show, which had its season premiere on Dec. 6.

headline: On the Street | Style at the Greenmarket
text: New Yorkers in their stylish winter dress to prove once again, that there is abundant holiday cheer.

headline: Recipes for Party Dips and Appetizers
text: Festive snacks for your Oscar party.

headline: A Pulsating Scene, For Dinner or Dancing
text: THE red carpet and the doorman distinguish Sugar Dining Den and Social Club from its outlet-store neighbors on Voice Road in Carle Place. This combination restaurant and nightclub, which was opened in May by Brian Rosenberg, a former hotel executive, and Randy Narod, an entrepreneur, makes a big first impression.

headline: The Chocolatier’s Tale
text: Lisa’s Chocolates and Gifts occupies a small, freestanding building that abuts a picturesque pond, with llamas grazing in the meadow nearby. In its bucolic setting, this plank-sided country store in Canterbury looks to be from the Norman Rockwell era, though it opened in 1997.

headline: A Void in Ethnic Dining Filled on Restaurant Row
text: ALTHOUGH ethnic restaurants have been proliferating throughout Connecticut, especially in Fairfield County, there remains one big void: North African and Middle Eastern cuisine. The arrival of the Fez in Stamford in May has helped fill that void.

headline: When Wrinkle-Free Clothing Also Means Formaldehyde Fumes
text: The iron, that relic of households past, is no longer required to look neat and freshly pressed. Why bother when retailers like Nordstrom offer crisp “wrinkle-free finish” dress shirts and L. L. Bean sells chinos that are “great right out of the dryer.”

headline: Mexicans Suggest That They Killed a Drug Leader
text: MEXICO CITY  He walked the streets with a book of his own spiritual quotes. They called him “the craziest one,” for his odd, cultic hybrid of Christianity and grisly violence, which included rolling severed heads into a nightclub four years ago.

headline: Baking Magic
text: It’s 9 a.m. and David Meltzer and Simone Williams have been working for about 10 hours already. Grinding grain with their grist mill, mixing in other organic and antibiotic- and hormone-free ingredients, and then forming and kneading dough by hand, the two are committed to creating extraordinary breads for their company, All You Knead Artisan Bakers.

headline: A Contemporary Spot for Classic Greek
text: SOON after you sit down at Elia Taverna, a nine-month-old Greek restaurant in Bronxville, a server will bring you a basket of warm pita and a small bowl of delicious assorted olives in oil, garlic and lemon. If you’re an adult, you will be offered a complimentary glass of red or white wine (there is no liquor license yet). And if there are any questions about the menu, the waiter will fill you in as if he had all the time in the world, even though the restaurant is likely to be crowded.

headline: Clinton at White House Sets Twitter on Fire
text: Political Washington watched, slack-jawed, as President Obama on Friday offered former President Bill Clinton the White House briefing room and Mr. Clinton took it – for a full half-hour.

headline: For Future Iron Chefs, More Places to Learn
text: THE students’ questions were as pointed as the knives they were carefully sharpening on steel rods.

headline: What I Wore: Olivia Kim of Opening Ceremony
text: The the vice president for creative at Opening Ceremony shares her wardrobe choices as she moves between cities.

headline: In Comfort Here and There
text: OLIVIA KIM, 33, is the vice president for creative at Opening Ceremony, the design house and department-store-style emporia. She works at the company’s Centre Street headquarters overseeing design of the collection, store visuals and the wholesale showroom. CHLOE MALLE

headline: Puppet Masters Try to Bring Art Out of the Shadows
text: BEIJING

headline: Full Wallets, but Using Health Program for Poor
text: AFTER immigrating to New York City from China in the 1970s, Z. Y. Tung and his wife worked hard — he as a bank manager, she as a public school secretary — lived frugally and saved every penny they could for the next generation.

headline: Use of Cholera Vaccine in Haiti Is Now Viewed as Viable
text: The World Health Organization is shifting its position in favor of vaccinating against cholera, acknowledging a growing clamor for ways to slow Haiti’s outbreak.

headline: Breakfast(s) at My Place(s)
text: If an award existed for ensuring that New Yorkers ate well on Sunday (and every other day), Eli Zabar, whose gastronomic empire includes E.A.T. on Madison Avenue, the Vinegar Factory, Eli’s Manhattan and Eli’s Bread, would be a serious contender. He has been growing vegetables on the Vinegar Factory rooftop for 15 years, and he took over the farmers’ market in Amagansett, N.Y., in 2008. Mr. Zabar, 67, lives on the Upper East Side with his wife, Devon Fredericks, 60, who works for the company, and their 19-year-old twin boys, Sasha and Oliver. DONNA PAUL

headline: Notes from a Young American in Congo: Treating Rape Victims
text: “She was running from the soldiers in the field when she tripped and fell.”

headline: Verdict Is Guilty in Abduction of Elizabeth Smart
text: A federal jury in Utah on Friday convicted an itinerant street preacher, Brian D. Mitchell, in the 2002 abduction of Elizabeth Smart, disregarding defense claims that he was insane.

headline: What Works in the Classroom? Ask the Students
text: How useful are the views of public school students about their teachers?

headline: Sinatra Is Long Gone, but the Room Is Still Packed
text: At this Midtown temple of southern Italian cooking, Sal Scognamillo, the third-generation executive chef and co-owner, greets newcomers and regulars alike, readily admitting the place never would have lasted if Frank Sinatra had not taken up frequent residence in a curtained-off alcove upstairs. Famous visitors — like Jennifer Lopez, Sean Combs, Florence Henderson and Carroll O’Connor — are immortalized in photos near the entrance, on 56th Street between Broadway and Eighth Avenue. All visitors can take a bit of the place with them — Patsy’s cookbooks, pasta and red sauce are displayed in a case along with a ceramic vessel labeled “Ashes of Problem Customers.” The offerings have not changed much since the beginning, in 1944, and still pack the house. On Wednesday night, the crowd included a family on its annual holiday visit. DIANE CARDWELL

headline: Gates Regrets Rejection of ‘Don’t Ask’ Repeal
text: ABOARD A UNITED STATES MILITARY AIRCRAFT  Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates said on Friday that he was disappointed “but not surprised” by the Senate vote late Thursday that dimmed chances for repeal this year of the “don’t ask, don’t tell” law.

headline: A Mysterious Pillar, and More on Tolerance Jingles
text: A Firefighting Antique

headline: Secret Cable Discusses Pfizer’s Actions in Nigeria Case
text: Pfizer was accused of hiring investigators “to uncover corruption links” to Nigeria’s former attorney general and apply pressure to drop lawsuits against the company over a controversial 1996 test of antibiotics on children with meningitis, according to a secret State Department cable that related a company official’s account.

headline: Trying to Move Forward From Under the Rubble
text: His body was bruised and bloated, his mind losing its sentience.

headline: The Holiday Entertaining Arsenal
text: A collection of videos and photos with recipes for drinks, hors d’oeuvres, cookies and more to feed a festive crowd.

headline: 8 Are Charged With Fraud Over Claims From Oil Spill
text: The Department of Justice has filed fraud charges against eight people over claims of damages related to the BP oil spill.

headline: Gunfire Will No Longer Be Met by Silence
text: Derick Scott grabbed the large brass bell from a fold-out table and raised a bullhorn to his mouth.

headline: James T. Lynn, Budget Director in Ford Administration, Dies at 83
text: James T. Lynn, a housing secretary in the Nixon administration who cut government spending as President Gerald R. Ford’s budget director died on Monday in Bethesda, Md. He was 83.

headline: Talk of a Sale Circles a Movie Studio
text: Is Focus Features on the block?

headline: Laura Stanley, Nicholas Hollot
text: Laura Margaret Stanley and Nicholas Christopher Hollot were married Saturday at St. James Episcopal Church in New London, Conn. The Rev. Michel Belt, the church’s rector, performed the ceremony.

headline: Janice Nittoli, Richard Tofel
text: Janice Nittoli and Richard J. Tofel are to be married Sunday evening at the Sunningdale Country Club in Scarsdale, N.Y. Judge Ronald E. Richter, who presides in Family Court in Queens, is to officiate.

headline: Rachel Penski, Ryan Fissell
text: Rachel Penski and Ryan Fissell were married Saturday evening at Studio 450, an event space in New York. Megan Bess, a friend of the bride’s who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion, officiated.

headline: Sue Yoo, Matthew Murakami
text: Sue H. Yoo, a daughter of Sandra Yoo and Ji Sung Yoo of Queens, was married Saturday evening to Matthew Murakami, the son of Toshiko Murakami and Hidenori Murakami of San Diego. The Rev. Dr. Arnold Isidore Thomas, a minister of the United Church of Christ, performed the ceremony at Riverside Church in Manhattan.

headline: Deborah Rosmarin, Michael Shlisky
text: Deborah Fay Rosmarin and Michael David Shlisky were married Saturday evening at Temple Beth Sholom in Roslyn Heights, N.Y. Rabbi Alan B. Lucas performed the ceremony, with Cantor Ofer Barnoy taking part.

headline: Catharine Clark, Eric Robinson
text: Catharine Mary Clark and Eric Selinger Robinson are to be married Sunday. Cantor Jen Cohen performed the ceremony at Temple Beth Sholom in Cherry Hill, N.J.

headline: Debra Fiterman, Alexander Arbit
text: Debra Grace Fiterman and Alexander Ron Arbit were married Saturday evening in Minnetonka, Minn. Rabbi Harold J. Kravitz performed the ceremony at the Adath Jeshurun Congregation, where he is the senior rabbi, with the assistance of Rabbi Adam Stock Spilker.

headline: Ashley Brunk and Joshua Arnold
text: Ashley Elizabeth Brunk and Joshua Paul Arnold were married Saturday in New York. The Rev. Paul D. Arnold, a United Methodist minister and the father of the bridegroom, performed the ceremony at Christ Church United Methodist.

headline: Katherine Helm, James Haley
text: Katherine Ann Helm and James Francis Haley Jr. were married Saturday evening at 632 on Hudson, an event space in New York. Judge Marilyn Hall Patel of United States District Court in San Francisco, for whom the bride was a law clerk from 2008 to 2009, officiated.

headline: Susan Freeman, Gabriel Kaufman
text: Susan Isabel Freeman and Gabriel Benjamin Kaufman are to be married Sunday evening by Rabbi Esther L. Lederman at the Fairmont Hotel in Washington.

headline: Jennifer Glaisek, Steven Ferguson
text: Jennifer Carrie Glaisek was married Saturday afternoon to Steven James Ferguson in Nyack, N.Y. Robert S. Knoebel Jr., the village justice with the Nyack Justice Court, officiated at the home of the bride’s parents.

headline: Josephine Hodge, Harrison Schweiloch
text: Josephine Jane Dyer Hodge and Harrison Schweiloch were married Saturday at the First Presbyterian Church of Navasota, Tex. The Rev. Diane K. Prevary, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony, and Rabbi Barry Richard Diamond assisted.

headline: Catharine Gaul, Byron Stigge Jr.
text: Catharine Leslie Gaul and Byron John Stigge Jr. were married Saturday evening at Middle Collegiate Church in New York. The Rev. Dr. Jaqueline J. Lewis, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony.

headline: Courtney King and Christopher Murphy

Murphy of Boston. The Rev. John P. Spencer, a Roman Catholic priest and a cousin of the bridegroom, performed the ceremony at the St. James Chapel of the Archbishop Quigley Pastoral Center in Chicago.

headline: Molly Patrick, Josh Epstein
text: Molly Patrick and Josh Epstein were married Saturday evening at the University Club in Manhattan. Rabbi Daniel G. Zemel, a cousin of the bridegroom, officiated.

headline: Jill Linker and Jay Weintraub
text: Jill Sari Linker and Joseph Samuel Weintraub were married Saturday evening at the Ritz-Carlton hotel in Naples, Fla. Cantor Steven I. Weiss, a cousin of the bride, officiated.

headline: Daphne Limmer and Daniel Saperstein
text: Daphne Rose Limmer and Daniel Tanney Saperstein were married Saturday evening at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx. Rabbi Seth M. Limmer, a cousin of the bride, officiated.

headline: Shadow Puppets in Love
text: A husband and wife in Beijing talk about their efforts to keep the art of shadow puppetry alive in Beijing.

headline: Don Meredith Favored His Wits Over His Playbook
text: In almost everything he tried, Don Meredith was a natural. He played football because that’s what young boys in Texas do  and because he grew up tall, rangy and rifled-armed, the prototype quarterback, then and now.

headline: Tirades Against Nobel Aim at Audience in China
text: BEIJING — As much of the world on Friday focused their eyes on the empty seat in Oslo that starkly represented the absence of the Nobel laureate Liu Xiaobo, a lone Chinese blogger posted the image of a chair on the country’s most popular microblogging site.

headline: Appointment Fight Divides Judges
text: Here is one for the “only in New Jersey” file: A state Supreme Court justice refuses to participate in any rulings because he objects to another jurist’s serving temporarily on the court.

headline: Organ Donation: Let the Market Rule?
text: A year and a half ago, Angelica Nieves was doing fine, working as a housekeeper in a hotel and living on her own in Brooklyn. When she started experiencing a shortness of breath, her doctor said it was asthma.

headline: Haitian Candidate Rejects Offer for a Runoff
text: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  Michel Martelly, the presidential candidate whose partisans have fiercely protested election results they consider rigged, said in an interview on Friday that he had rejected an offer to participate in a runoff election as a third candidate.

headline: National Semiconductor Sales Forecast Disappoints
text: The National Semiconductor Corporation, a maker of chips that control power in electronic devices, forecast third-quarter sales lower than analysts’ estimates, citing weaker-than-expected demand from mobile phone makers. Revenue will be $344 million to $359 million, National Semiconductor said late Thursday. That compares with $382.3 million estimated by analysts surveyed by Bloomberg. Demand from handset manufacturers is lower than usual in the run-up to year-end holidays, and distributors of National Semiconductor chips are reducing inventory, the company said. Stock in National Semiconductor, which is based in Santa Clara, Calif., fell $1.16, or 8 percent, to $13.81 a share on Friday.

headline: Despite Wealth, Nassau County Is in Fiscal Crisis
text: MINEOLA, N.Y.  Facing a huge budget deficit when he took office in January, Nassau County Executive Edward P. Mangano did not impose a hiring freeze. He did not stop borrowing to subsidize some of the richest school districts in the country. He did not eliminate the Police Department’s beloved mounted unit.

headline: 38 Days Later
text: It’s over. It’s really over. Two Republican concessions have brought the curtain down on the midterm elections of 2010. And the Senate race in Alaska, whose outcome is already known, moved one step closer to being official.

headline: For Lee, More Value May Come From Texas
text: For months, the widespread assumption in baseball has been that the Yankees would overwhelm Cliff Lee with millions of dollars more than the Texas Rangers could afford, making him the solution to a depleted starting rotation.

headline: In Choice of Yankees or Rangers, Lee Is Picking a Tax Rate, Too
text: For Cliff Lee, choosing between the Yankees and the Rangers is about more than deciding which team will give him the best chance to win a World Series ring. If both teams offer him similar seven-year contracts, it will also be about taxes.

headline: Mrs. Doubleday’s Indiscretion

headline: Lennon’s Return
text: When I entered their room, bed is where the Lennons were.

headline: Gift Cards With Bells and Whistles
text: This year, retailers’ gift cards record messages, light up or smell like gingerbread. Some feature the work of noted photographers, others incorporate personal photos. Some can be sent via text message or Facebook posts, and others are tactile (like the one with little holes for a finger puppet).

headline: Miller Challenge Is Rejected in Alaska
text: A state judge in Alaska on Friday rejected claims by Joe Miller, the Republican Senate candidate in last month’s election, that write-in votes cast for Senator Lisa Murkowski had to be perfectly spelled to be counted.

headline: For Big Rivalry, Carrying the Ball 315,000 Yards
text: PHILADELPHIA  In the wee hours of Friday morning, with temperatures in the teens, a young man built like a gazelle ran along a darkened Route 202 in New Jersey  shirtless and carrying a football.

headline: Violations and Lockout Mire Brooklyn Complex
text: Several notable features of Flatbush Gardens, a 59-building rental complex in East Flatbush, Brooklyn, are missing from its inviting ads, which show comely young couples enjoying life there.

headline: Joseph Bramlett, Ex-Stanford Golfer, Draws Comparisons to Woods
text: When Joseph Bramlett shot a final-round 68 on Monday, finishing in the top 25 at the PGA Tour qualifying school and securing a spot on the tour for the 2011 season, some predictable headlines popped up around the country. That Bramlett is a California native, that he went to Stanford, that he wears the Nike swoosh and celebrates the holing of crucial putts with a fist pump were all-too-irresistible similarities to a certain other golfer.

headline: Above The Law: Challenging Putin's Party
text: Opposition candidate Olga Safronova challenges Prime Minister Vladimir Putin's ruling party in local elections in Siberia and discovers just how much power it has.

headline: In New Jersey, a Backlog of Governor’s Nominees Await Confirmation
text: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey wants big changes at the state’s Sports and Exposition Authority, calling for it to sell or close the Izod Center and two horse racing tracks. In March, he named three allies to join the authority’s board to help carry out his agenda.

headline: Lottery Numbers
A Puppet Party Rebels
text: A rebellion by a puppet party in Siberia, and the ruling party’s response, seemed to underscore how laws intended to guarantee free and fair elections carry little weight in Russia.

headline: The Possible Dream?
text: The debate over United States immigration policy in recent years has been in equal parts tortuous and ineffectual. And one interested party had for the most part been relegated to the fringes: the hundreds of thousands of illegal immigrants who were born abroad but brought to America when they were children. Claimed by neither their parents’ homelands nor the nation they grew up in, unable to work legally here, they exist in a curious limbo.

headline: In Siberia Race, Ruling Party Uses Clenched Fist
text: NOVOSIBIRSK, Russia — On the eve of regional elections, an opposition candidate named Olga V. Safronova arrived at a school for a campaign finale. She planned a rousing speech with a refrain that Russia had been seized by a dictatorial ruling party.

headline: After Attack on Royal Limo, Questions and Reproach
text: LONDON  The British police promised an investigation into the attack on a limousine carrying Prince Charles and his wife, Camilla, while security experts and the news media raised questions Friday about how the royal couple were placed into the potentially dangerous situation.

headline: Wide Swings in Turnout Viewed as One Sign of Russian Vote Fraud
text: NOVOSIBIRSK, Russia  It was not hard to spot signs of possible fraud in Olga V. Safronova’s losing campaign for regional assembly in Siberia, according to nonpartisan election analysts. Consider two neighboring polling places in her district, No. 860 and No. 864.

headline: Illinois: Ex-Kaplan Official Convicted in Threats
text: A former dean at the Washington Post Company’s Kaplan higher-education unit was found guilty by a federal jury in Chicago of making threats in e-mails and Web postings. Bennie Wilcox, a former Kaplan University dean of law and legal studies, was convicted on all six counts on Friday and faces up to 18 years in prison. Mr. Wilcox, 45, denied writing the 2007 messages and postings and said he was framed in retaliation for filing a whistleblower lawsuit accusing Kaplan of committing fraud to get federal aid.

headline: As Ants Crawl Over Crucifix, Dead Artist Is Assailed Again
text: In 1989, Donald Wildmon, founder of the American Family Association, mailed a pamphlet reproducing details from collages by the New York artist David Wojnarowicz (1954-1992) to every member of Congress, to various news media outlets and to religious leaders across the country.

headline: China’s Shadow Puppets
text: The owners and curators of a shadow puppet museum in Beijing feel their lives’ work has been spurned and want to take their collection to the United States.

headline: China’s Inflation Hit a 28-Month High in November
text: SHANGHAI — The booming Chinese economy is showing signs of overheating, according to a raft of new data, and that could spell trouble for this nation’s growth early next year.

headline: Estate Tax Cutoff Draws Special Fire in Congress
text: WASHINGTON  The White House has worked aggressively to shift attention from the plan to continue the Bush-era tax cuts for high-income taxpayers and to focus instead on how its deal with Republicans will stimulate the economy. But many Congressional Democrats say one component in the package will stimulate nothing except their continuing fury: a generous tax exemption for wealthy estates that will benefit only a small number of super-rich Americans.

headline: Saturday: Storied Slacker
text: In Italy for 30 years under the Borgias they had warfare, terror, murder and bloodshed, but they produced Michelangelo, Leonardo da Vinci, and the Renaissance. In Switzerland they had brotherly love — they had 500 years of democracy and peace, and what did that produce? The cuckoo clock.

headline: North Pole Noir

headline: In Archive, New Light on Evolution of Eisenhower Speech
text: The phrase that would emerge as the most enduring legacy of what became, arguably, the most famous farewell address since George Washington’s evolved over 20 months and was agreed to only a few days before it was delivered.

headline: Boyfriend Charged in Death at Soho House
text: A man who accompanied his girlfriend, a fashion designer, to the exclusive Soho House in Manhattan was charged in her death on Friday, more than a day after the woman’s body was found submerged in a bathtub in a fifth-floor room of the members-only club.

headline: Stoudemire’s Mixed Bag Helps Knicks Win Seventh Straight
text: Everywhere Amar’e Stoudemire turned Friday night, he left a lasting mark: on the record books, on the league’s top draft pick and on a crowd that cheered him as if he were their own. Even his mistakes seemed larger than life.

headline: When Lenders Won’t Listen
text: At the end of this week’s Fixes column on ESOP, an organization in Ohio that helps prevent foreclosures, I promised to share some stories of homeowners’ experiences. I also asked readers to write in with their own mortgage tales. Many did. The stories illustrate why trusted, nonprofit, third-party intermediaries like ESOP, which know how to communicate productively with both homeowners and lenders — and are committed to finding solutions — are needed to ease the housing crisis. Even better, a few readers offered suggestions about how to avoid this problem in the future.

headline: Using Waste, Swedish City Cuts Its Fossil Fuel Use
text: KRISTIANSTAD, Sweden  When this city vowed a decade ago to wean itself from fossil fuels, it was a lofty aspiration, like zero deaths from traffic accidents or the elimination of childhood obesity.

headline: Before Army-Navy, a Really Long Run
text: In what has become another hallowed tradition at the United States Military Academy at West Point, a team of runners takes turns carrying a football from campus to the site of the Army-Navy game. No fumbling is allowed.
