headline: In Tapes, Nixon Rails About Jews and Blacks
text: YORBA LINDA, Calif. — Richard M. Nixon made disparaging remarks about Jews, blacks, Italian-Americans and Irish-Americans in a series of extended conversations with top aides and his personal secretary, recorded in the Oval Office 16 months before he resigned as president.

headline: Bill Clinton Holds Forth on Tax Plan, for Starters
text: WASHINGTON  They have been foes and they have been, kind of, friends. And on Friday afternoon, President Obama and former President Bill Clinton walked unexpectedly into the White House briefing room for a news conference that was part surreal flashback, part one-two political punch.

headline: Clinton Says U.S. Is Committed to Mideast Peace but Reverting to Old Strategy
text: WASHINGTON  Three days after the Obama administration gave up its push for a freeze in Jewish settlement construction, Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton said Friday that the United States was still committed to a Middle East peace agreement. But she offered no new concrete proposals to revive the paralyzed process, beyond a renewed pledge to press both the Israelis and the Palestinians.

headline: Serbia: Court Acquits 10 Accused Of Helping War Crimes Suspect
text: Ten people accused of helping Gen. Ratko Mladic, a Serbian war crimes suspect, elude an international hunt were acquitted Friday by a Belgrade municipal court, which concluded that the statute of limitations had expired for some of the charges. The defendants were accused of helping General Mladic from 2002 to 2006. Judge Dragan Garic ruled Friday that the statute for some of the charges had expired in 2008 and 2009, although the trial started before those dates. The acquittal was a blow to the government, which has argued that it was doing all it could to capture the former general and pursue his protectors, crucial steps toward joining the European Union. The prosecutor’s office said it would appeal. General Mladic, 68, charged by a United Nations tribunal with genocide, is accused of masterminding the 1995 massacre of 8,000 Muslims in Srebrenica and other atrocities.

headline: Bloggingheads: G.O.P. Tax Hypocrisy?
text: David Corn of Mother Jones and James Pinkerton of Fox News, right, debate the Obama-G.O.P. tax deal.

headline: Wrong Fix for British Universities

The legislation they opposed, a tripling of university tuition fees, is bad public policy, both myopic and unfair.

headline: Civil Rights in California
text: However the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit rules in California’s pivotal same-sex marriage battle  and it should uphold the civil rights of Americans  the court has already set one standard that the Supreme Court should follow.

headline: Stoudemire Adds to Scoring Streak, but Is Far From N.B.A. Mark
text: When Amar’e Stoudemire, above, scored at least 30 points for the seventh consecutive game with a 36-point effort Friday night in a win over Washington, he not only matched a personal mark but also a Knicks’ one. The Knicks’ record was set by Willie Naulls in 1962.

headline: Activists Say Web Assault for Assange Is Expanding
text: LONDON  The online activist group Anonymous, which has been waging a campaign of cyberattacks in defense of WikiLeaks, opened new offensives on Friday as Internet security experts said that tens of thousands more supporters had downloaded the attack software in the days since the WikiLeaks founder, Julian Assange, was jailed in Britain.

headline: Will Universal Sell Focus Features?
text: Universal has denied reports that it may sell off its art house film production unit, Focus Features, to Alec and Tom Gores, a pair of entertainment industry investors. Our colleague Brooks Barnes reported on the courtship between the parties for DealBook.

headline: Consensus Emerges On Common Climate Path
text: Dec. 11, 9:59 a.m. | Updated What a difference a year makes. Climate talks ended in Copenhagen one year ago in raucous, then deflated, division, with the resulting accord noted, but not formally embraced, by the nearly 200 countries aiming to make good on an 18-year-old pledge under the first climate treaty to limit dangerous human-driven warming.

headline: Naismith’s Rules Are Sold
text: David Booth grew up in Lawrence, Kan., the college town where James Naismith began coaching basketball at the University of Kansas a few years after inventing the sport in Springfield, Mass., in 1891. Booth and his family lived on 1931 Naismith Drive. Booth’s connection to Naismith grew stronger Friday when he agreed to pay $4.3 million at a Sotheby’s auction for the two yellowed, typewritten pages on which Naismith memorialized the 13 rules of basketball.

headline: Climate Talks End With Modest Deal on Emissions
text: CANCÚN, Mexico  The United Nations climate change conference began with modest aims and ended early Saturday with modest achievements. But while the measures adopted here may have scant near-term impact on the warming of the planet, the international process for dealing with the issue got a significant vote of confidence.

headline: 30 Seconds With Magic Johnson
text: Magic Johnson, who has joined the effort to have the N.F.L. return to Los Angeles, was an honorary co-chairman of a recent fund-raiser in Harlem. It marked the collaboration of Mount Sinai School of Medicine’s Center for Multicultural and Community Affairs with Jazzmobile, which provides free music education and performance programs to children throughout the neighborhood. The center and Jazzmobile aim to interest children and young adults in careers involving math, science, medicine and music. Johnson, 51, won five N.B.A. championships as a point guard with the Los Angeles Lakers. In 1991, he was found to have the virus that causes AIDS.

headline: Conductor Who Told Jets No Puts Family First

headline: Burmese Couple Build Life in the Bronx
text: Bae Reh and his wife, Moo Pro, were raised on a five-mile-long patch of land they were not permitted to leave, except to gather leaves to fortify the bamboo huts in which they slept. The couple had no knowledge of the outside world. They had never heard of America and certainly could not find it on a map. There were no newspapers, just a magazine and a television station, both operating under strict political control.

headline: Propping Up a Drug Lord, Then Arresting Him

text: This interview with Marc Cenedella, founder and C.E.O. of TheLadders.com, a job search site, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

headline: If Bill Clinton Were President
text: WASHINGTON — By the end of last week, it certainly looked as if Barack Obama had outsourced his presidency to Bill Clinton. First, he cut a Clintonian-style deal with Republicans on tax cuts and then he literally turned over the White House lectern to his predecessor.

headline: The Online Reservations That Restaurants Love to Hate
text: YOU probably all know the name of the online restaurant reservation service that went public last year and enjoys a market capitalization of well over a billion dollars: OpenTable.

headline: One Corner of Stocks That Fared Just Fine
text: AFTER a four-month stock market rally, some investors are starting to wonder if equities could be on the verge of finally outshining bonds.

headline: New Challenges for Obama’s Education Agenda in the Face of a G.O.P.-Led House
text: WASHINGTON  For two years, backed by a friendly Congress and flush with federal stimulus money, President Obama’s administration enjoyed a relatively obstacle-free path for its education agenda, the focus of which is the $4 billion Race to the Top grant program.

headline: Keeping Secrets WikiSafe
text: WASHINGTON — Can the government still keep a secret? In an age of WikiLeaks, flash drives and instant Web postings, leaks have begun to seem unstoppable.

headline: Following the Money, Doctors Ration Care
text: UNEQUAL access to health care is hardly a new phenomenon in the United States, but the country is moving toward rationing on a scale that is unprecedented here. Wealthy people will always be able to buy most of what they want. But for everyone else, if we stay on the current course, the lines are likely to get longer and longer.

headline: Remembering U.C.L.A. Streak’s End
text: Nearly 37 years later, Dwight Clay still keeps a video disc in his briefcase. Just in case. Just so he can prove to doubters that he indeed was the Notre Dame guard whose decisive shot stirred a 71-70 upset that broke U.C.L.A.’s 88-game winning streak on Jan. 19, 1974.

headline: Technology Outpaces Privacy (Yet Again)
text: HOW far does consumer privacy protection lag behind data-collection systems, those advanced technologies that media companies use to gather, share and profit from our personal information?

headline: For This Cruise Line, Better Pack Your Lunch
text: A FEW weeks ago, the Haggler asked for tales of cruise vacations gone wrong, and as ever, readers delivered. But a lot of the stories had less than outrageous endings because most cruise-line operators responded to aggrieved vacationers with brisk apologies and partial refunds.

headline: Letters to the Editor: World Cup 2022 and the Earth
text: To the Sports Editor:

headline: Declassified Papers Show U.S. Recruited Ex-Nazis
text: After World War II, American counterintelligence recruited former Gestapo officers, SS veterans and Nazi collaborators to an even greater extent than had been previously disclosed and helped many of them avoid prosecution or looked the other way when they escaped, according to thousands of newly declassified documents.

headline: Feel Free to Read This Later, on Your Phone
text: OUR evolutionary roots are showing when we sit down at the computer.

headline: The Fed? Ron Paul’s Not a Fan
text: Ben S. Bernanke, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, has been attacked for failing to foresee the financial crisis, for bailing out Wall Street, and, most recently, for injecting an additional $600 billion into the banking system to give the slow recovery a boost.

headline: Losing a Job, Mourning a Lifestyle
text: AS a therapist in private practice and a volunteer at a free mental health clinic in Los Angeles, I have become aware of a new group of severely depressed people: those who have lost their jobs in the entertainment industry. Their skills have become dispensable in this economy, and their sense of self-worth has plummeted along with their bank accounts.

headline: Elizabeth Edwards, Through Many Eyes
text: Who was your Elizabeth Edwards?

headline: Lakers’ Ron Artest Turns Defense Into an Art Form
text: LOS ANGELES  Ron Artest cast the bait, spinning into the shadow of Chicago’s Taj Gibson and giving him a clear path to the rim. As Gibson gathered the ball, Artest pounced, slapping it from Gibson’s hands, off his chest and out of bounds.

headline: Can College Graduates Create Their Own Jobs?
text: We’ve just published a profile of Scott Gerber, who is founder of a promotional video company, Sizzle It, and who recently created a nonprofit organization called the Young Entrepreneur Council. If you read the story, you’ll see that the goal of the organization is nothing less than eradicating youth unemployment and underemployment. Instead of finding jobs, Mr. Gerber and his organization encourage college graduates to create their own jobs — by starting a business.

headline: Letter: The Local Tax Burden
text: To the Editor:

headline: Stage and Screen (and Retail)
text: I WAS born in Alabama; my father was a lawyer and a Rhodes scholar. He died when I was a kid, and I never got to fully know him. I resent it to a certain extent. I thought he had a great mind, and it’s sad that I never had a chance to explore it.

headline: Newly Released Nixon Tapes
text: NBC report.

headline: Back Then: 1969
text: Jim Morrison, the lead singer of The Doors, last week received a posthumous pardon for his 1970 convictions for profanity and indecent exposure, which followed a raucous 1969 performance in Florida. Several weeks after the concert, 30,000 people held a rally for decency in entertainment at the Orange Bowl. The Associated Press was there:

headline: Prime Number
text: 1: The ranking of students in Shanghai on standardized tests for reading, math and science administered in about 65 countries. Students from the United States finished far behind: 17th in reading, 23rd in science and 31st in math, which was significantly below the average.

headline: Laugh Lines
text: JAY LENO

headline: ‘Whispering Fire on a Crowded Planet’
text: Marc Roberts, my favorite climate cartoonist (and perhaps the only one), has a biting riff out on the conclusion of the climate negotiations in Cancún, Mexico, which reached agreement early this morning on an outline for further actions, but with heaps of conditionality and scant signs of hard commitments.

headline: A Friend’s Mistake, an Understudy’s Chance
text: Hempstead, N.Y.

headline: Fighting Words
text: As G.M. prepares to roll out its plug-in, Chevy Volt, the company’s chief executive, Daniel F. Akerson, took a shot at Toyota’s popular hybrid, the Prius.

headline: Gizmos Come to Play at Winter Meetings
text: ORLANDO, Fla. — Like a rapidly spreading fire, word began to circulate Wednesday through the crowded lobby of the Dolphin Hotel at baseball’s winter meetings. General managers, scouting directors and at least one owner had heard the news and were eager to see if it was true.

headline: A Giants Project Is Paying Off
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  His coach took notice when Jason Pierre-Paul, in his first practice a week before the first game of his only season of major college football, sent a 315-pound offensive lineman tumbling sideways onto his ear during a pass rush drill.

headline: The Loud, and Memorable, Voice of Lombardi
text: In 1967, Vince Lombardi was being interviewed on camera by NFL Films for a CBS documentary about him. But Lombardi, normally hyperexpressive on the sideline, at practices and in the locker room as the Green Bay Packers’ coach, was not delivering.

headline: Planned Fire Dept. Fees for Motorists Criticized
text: A plan by the New York Fire Department to allay severe budget cuts by charging motorists up to $490 to respond to accidents and car fires has touched off blistering criticism and calls for the City Council to outlaw the policy.

headline: Obama to Meet With Executives
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama will host a roundtable with about 20 corporate chiefs on Wednesday, according to the White House, part of an attempt to ease strained relations with business.

headline: One Billionaire Bows Out of the Next America’s Cup
text: Ten months after Larry Ellison and his BMW Oracle Racing team, lawyers included, celebrated victory over Alinghi in the America’s Cup, it remains uncertain where BMW Oracle will defend its very expensive prize.

headline: Straight Outta Hoboken
text: TO the best of my knowledge, Frank Sinatra acknowledged the existence of rap music only once in his life: at the lavish 1995 tribute in honor of his 80th birthday, after the hip-hop trio Salt-n-Pepa performed a special-lyrics version of their hit “Whatta Man,” he turned to his wife, Barbara, and said, “Marvelous.”

headline: Canadiens’ Price, Once Fans’ Target, Is Now a Favorite
text: No player entered the N.H.L. season facing more pressure than Canadiens goaltender Carey Price.

headline: The Care and (Healthy) Feeding of the Jaguars
text: JACKSONVILLE, Fla.  The Jaguars’ high-traffic cafeteria used to be a snack trap, characterized by unmarked sugars, hidden calories and hard-to-see preservatives. With its cookie buffet and pizza day, the players ate it up, never stopping to think the low-grade fuel they were pumping into their bodies could be making the team sputter.

headline: What Progressives Don’t Understand About Obama
text: Oakland, Calif.

headline: New Backing for Gas Line Through Asia
text: MOSCOW  A plan to build a regional natural gas pipeline across war-ravaged southern Afghanistan, long thought to be impractical given the dismal security there, moved a step closer to becoming a reality on Saturday.

headline: Mensches and Mentors in the Press Box
text: What a mournful year it has been for those of us who grew up in or around New York without ESPN or WFAN, and whose primary sports enlightenment came rolled up in the back pockets of our fathers as they returned home from work.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, Dec. 12
text: As lawmakers head into what is expected to be the final week of the 111th Congress, the Sunday morning talk shows focus on the fate of the administration’s controversial tax cut deal.

headline: Edwards Eulogized as Defender of Her Family
text: RALEIGH, N.C. — In the moments before the funeral for Elizabeth Edwards began here Saturday afternoon, women from the Edenton Street United Methodist Church removed a spray of white lilies and yellow roses from her coffin. Men wiped the rain from the lid, preparing it to be wheeled into the sanctuary, where 1,100 people waited.

headline: Poland, Bastion of Religion, Sees Rise in Secularism
text: SWIEBODZIN, Poland  A statue of Jesus, one of the tallest in the world, stands on the flat frozen fields of this small western Poland town, its arms outstretched and gaze fixed straight ahead at a community trying to push back a rising tide of secularism.

headline: Giants-Vikings Game Is Moved to Monday
text: A big winter storm in the Twin Cities has left the Giants stranded in Kansas City. Pat Hanlon, the Giants’ vice president for communications, said the team would stay the night there.

headline: Now Grandma Can ‘Win a Trip’ Too
text: Each time I announce my annual “win-a-trip contest,” to take a university student with me on a reporting trip to the developing world, I get indignant letters.

headline: Win-a-Trip With Nicholas D. Kristof
text: The columnist invites students and those over the age of 60 to enter a contest for a reporting trip to Africa in 2011.

headline: Announcing Win-a-Trip 2011 — With a Twist!
text: As my Sunday column notes, I’m now accepting entries for Win-a-Trip 2011 — and this time, I’ll be taking not only a student but also someone 60 or over. I’m hoping for lots of applications from both ends of the demographic spectrum.

headline: Jobless Aides Comb the Democratic Market
text: WASHINGTON — Seemingly desperate times call for desperate measures, which explains why Jonathan Lipman found himself sitting in a hospital room in early November, his day-old son resting on his shoulder, thumbing his BlackBerry searching for a new job on Capitol Hill.

headline: Scandal and a Schism Rattle Atlanta’s Schools
text: ATLANTA  Did any school district in the country have a tougher week than the one in Atlanta?

headline: House Is a Star of a Movie, and of a Real-Life Dispute
text: GOLDEN, Colo.  With its distinctive clamshell design, columns of glass windows and mountain perch, the “Sculptured House” is best known for its prominent role in the 1973 Woody Allen sci-fi comedy “Sleeper.”

headline: The Ponzi Scheme That Changed My Life
text: IT was a “Remember where you were when ... ?” moment: on Dec. 11, 2008, I was standing under a palm tree in Santa Monica when my cellphone rang.

headline: Samuel P. King, Judge and Critic of Hawaiian Charity, Dies at 94
text: Samuel P. King, a federal judge who mobilized the power of the pen to topple overseers of one of the nation’s wealthiest charities, a 19th-century trust set up by Hawaiian royalty to educate the kingdom’s natives, died Tuesday in Honolulu. He was 94.

headline: Along a Course of Purling Rivers, a Raw Divide
text: MISSOULA, Mont. — In this region famous for both its angling and its authors, Annick Smith has a long history with the Blackfoot River.

headline: Led by Crosby, Penguins Are on a Hot Streak
text: The Penguins are still without Jordan Staal, and they are also missing Evgeni Malkin, but going into Saturday night’s game at Buffalo, they had won 11 straight, the second-longest winning streak in their history.

headline: Sunday: The Wish
text: I am Eloise. I am six. I am a city child. I live at the Plaza.

headline: A Race to Capture a Bounty From Shipping
text: SAVANNAH, Ga.  Port officials here are racing to dig six feet of mud from the bottom of the Savannah River by 2014. In the world of major waterway expansions, that is an impossibly tight timeline.

headline: He Found Bag of Cash, But Did the Unexpected
text: TEMPE, Ariz.  For a homeless man like Dave Tally, the $3,300 in cash that he found in an abandoned backpack a few weeks ago would have gone a long way. Food. Shelter. Repairs to his bicycle. Spending it would not have been a problem.

headline: Gay Bashing at the Smithsonian
text: EACH Aug. 4, my wife Alex and I visit a church to light candles for two people we loved who both died tragically on that day two years apart  my mother, killed at 64 in a car crash, and Alex’s closest friend from graduate school, killed by AIDS at half that age. My mother was Jewish but loved the meditative serenity of vast cathedrals. Alex’s friend, John, was a Roman Catholic conflicted by a religion that demonized his sexuality. Our favorite pilgrimage is to an Episcopal church, Grace Cathedral in San Francisco, not as some sectarian compromise but because of its AIDS chapel, a haunting reminder of the plague that ravaged that city’s population, especially its gay men, some time ago.

headline: Staffs Worry About Shifts in County Health System
text: As Tia Speat strode through the quiet halls of Oak Forest Hospital last week passing out fliers about the nurses union’s contract negotiations with Cook County officials, angry nurses accosted her with questions and complaints about proposed cuts in service and staff.

headline: Reality Check
text: The failed attempt by the U.S. to bribe Israel with a $3 billion security assistance package, diplomatic cover and advanced F-35 fighter aircraft  if Prime Minister Bibi Netanyahu would simply agree to a 90-day settlements freeze to resume talks with the Palestinians  has been enormously clarifying. It demonstrates just how disconnected from reality both the Israeli and the Palestinian leaderships have become.

headline: Buried in Peru’s Desert, Fossils Draw Smugglers
text: OCUCAJE, Peru  Nestled between the Andes and the Pacific, the sparse desert surrounding this outpost in southern Peru looks like one of the world’s most desolate areas. Barren mountains rise from windswept valleys. Dust devils dance from one dune to the next.

headline: Protecting Peru's Fossils
text: Simon Romero reports on Peru's efforts to halt the illegal trade of fossils that are found in the Peruvian desert.

headline: Health Care and the Deficit
text: Here is a basic truth about the deficit: In the long run, it cannot be fixed, without reining in spending on Medicare and Medicaid.

headline: Lessons for a Modern City Found in Success Stories From Abroad
text: James Warren writes a column for the Chicago News Cooperative.

headline: A CD Label That Plays to Sounds of Chicago
text: When the pianist Bradley Parker released his first LP in 1979, he went to the Chicago Tattooing and Piercing Company parlor on Belmont Avenue and had the album title, “Latin Black,” inked across his left forearm. This was novel among artists in the ’80s, when tattoos belonged primarily to sailors and biker gangs.

headline: Justice Stevens and the Death Penalty
text: In the current "New York Review of Books," the retired Justice John Paul Stevens makes a compelling argument for abolishing the death penalty. He explains how it fails to meet the Supreme Court’s own standards for execution and persists only because of misguided political and cultural reasons.

headline: In the Peruvian Desert, a Troubled Trove
text: Peru’s Ocucaje Desert holds one of the most coveted troves of marine fossils known to paleontology, a set of treasures that faces plundering by thieves.

headline: China’s Army of Graduates Struggles for Jobs
text: BEIJING — Liu Yang, a coal miner’s daughter, arrived in the capital this past summer with a freshly printed diploma from Datong University, $140 in her wallet and an air of invincibility.

headline: China's 'Ant Tribe'
text: The reporter Andrew Jacobs follows a young man from his provincial hometown to Beijing to look for work.

headline: Our Envoys, Ourselves
text: Washington

headline: Let’s Race! If Only in Our Minds
text: I was rolling up the bike lane on Eighth Avenue on my way to work recently when a man on a Trek roared past with legs pumping like Greg LeMond.

headline: Lost and Found
text: Out in one of the pastures lies a pocket knife with a serrated blade. I lost it at least 10 years ago, but I think about it every time I walk the fence-line. Somewhere, too, there’s a pair of lined work gloves. And where are my gaiters? Or, for that matter, the wonderful pair of flip-flops that vanished?

headline: Agencies Challenged by Demand for Diapers
text: Damikka Griffin, a social worker, would like it if her low-income clients did not have to choose between necessities like paying their phone bill and rent, or diapering their infants. When she can take diapers with her on a trip to a client’s home, it makes her job easier.

headline: Snowstorm Shifts Giants Game to Monday
text: The Giants’ flight to Minneapolis was diverted to Kansas City on Saturday because of a snowstorm. Late Saturday, their game against the Minnesota Vikings was also diverted  to Monday night.

headline: New York Governor Vetoes Fracking Bill
text: Gov. David A. Paterson of New York on Saturday vetoed legislation intended to curtail natural gas development using the technique called hydraulic fracturing until a closer review of its effects can be undertaken.

headline: A Beating on My Beat
text: Moscow

headline: A Vermont Senator Becomes a Twitter Sensation
text: BOSTON  “I’m not here to set any great records, or to make a spectacle,” Senator Bernard Sanders, independent of Vermont, said Friday, about a minute into his speech on the Senate floor. By the time he stopped talking, nearly nine hours later, Mr. Sanders was an ascendant, if unlikely, Internet star.

headline: Obama Calls Turkish and Mexican Leaders on Diplomatic Leaks
text: WASHINGTON  President Obama for the first time joined in his administration’s diplomatic repair work in the wake of the disclosure of numerous American cables by WikiLeaks, calling the leaders of Turkey and Mexico on Saturday in an effort to smooth things over.

headline: In Africa, the Laureate’s Curse
text: Lagos, Nigeria

headline: Readers With Plenty to Say
text: LATE at night, at home in the Eastern time zone, Karen Garcia awaits the electronic publication of The Times’s daily dose of two Op-Ed columnists. Her goal: read fast, formulate a hurried response and fire back with her “comment.”

text: UNIONDALE, N.Y — Islanders General Manager Garth Snow, speaking at Nassau Coliseum on a night when more than a thousand Quebec Nordiques fans came to the arena to show the National Hockey League that their city deserves a team, said that the Islanders “aren’t going to play one day longer than we have to in this arena.”

headline: Distance and Politics Affect Lawmakers’ Spending on Travel
text: The retiring State Representative Joe Crabb led all members of the Texas House in government-financed travel expenses in the last fiscal year, according to a Texas Tribune review of expense reports.

headline: Stockholm Hit by Blasts After E-Mail Warning
text: STOCKHOLM  One man was killed and two other people were injured when two explosions hit the heart of Stockholm’s city-center shopping district on Saturday evening, the police in the Swedish capital said. The country’s foreign minister called the blasts a terrorist attack, and an e-mail to news organizations minutes before the blasts seemed to link them to anger over anti-Islamic cartoons and the war in Afghanistan.

headline: Profit Outweighs Risk in Juárez Factories
text: In 2009, more than $42 billion in trade value moved through the ports that Ciudad Juárez shares with El Paso, representing 15 percent of the total trade between the United States and Mexico. That number is estimated to be even higher in 2010.

headline: Anthony Knows the Drill: Practice, Then Sidestep Queries on the Knicks
text: Carmelo Anthony had finished his workout, and now it was time for reporters to begin theirs.

headline: For Local Hiring Law to Succeed, Plenty of Cooperation Is Required
text: Jonathan Weber writes a regular column for The Bay Citizen.

headline: Punch to Army’s Gut as Navy Hits Ball Loose
text: PHILADELPHIA  His gold helmet tilted back on his head and the black under his eyes smeared, Army quarterback Trent Steelman, looking spent in every way, hobbled to the locker room after the Black Knights lost to Navy for the ninth straight time.

headline: City Finds Millions, but Reaps Little in Case
text: A former engineer at the San Francisco Department of Building Inspection who stands accused of a lengthy list of building-related crimes was also creative, the authorities said, when it came to another dubious deed: hiding assets.

headline: Swedenborgian Church
text: Built in 1895, the Swedenborgian Church at the corner of Washington and Lyon Streets in Pacific Heights is a National Historic Landmark. Warm and wooded, it was designed and constructed by prominent artists and architects of the Arts and Crafts movement and is regarded as one of California’s earliest buildings in that style. HANK PELLISSIER

headline: Lives With Polished Veneer Are Snared in S.E.C. Inquiry
text: In the fall of 2006, Arnold and Annabel McClellan settled into a new school and social year. The couple sent their younger child to an exclusive Episcopal nursery school. Their elder took his place at one of the most traditional private schools in San Francisco.

headline: A Secretive Banking Elite Rules Trading in Derivatives
text: On the third Wednesday of every month, the nine members of an elite Wall Street society gather in Midtown Manhattan.

headline: As the Ground Shifts, Biden Plays a Bigger Role
text: WASHINGTON  It was the end of a long and testy gripe session with House Democrats on Wednesday, and Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. had had enough.

headline: Gators Hire Assistant From Texas to Coach
text: As the Heisman Trophy ceremony began in New York on Saturday night, the college football world suddenly got whiplash from looking down to Gainesville, Fla.

headline: Holder Calls Terrorism Sting Operations ‘Essential’
text: MILLBRAE, Calif.  Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. has defended the use of sting operations orchestrated by government informers, telling advocates for the civil rights of American Muslims on Friday night that the tactic is an “essential law enforcement tool in uncovering and preventing terror attacks.”

headline: Photo Replay: Cam Newton
text: A look back at the career that led to a Heisman Trophy for Auburn quarterback Cam Newton.

headline: Poll Suggests Risks for Obama if Liberals Feel Taken for Granted
text: A new poll from Marist University is suggestive of a potential worst-case scenario for President Obama. As he endures criticism from his left over his handling of the tax policy debate with Republicans, his approval rating has declined among liberals, according to the poll: 69 percent of them now approve of his job performance as compared with 78 percent in November. Likewise, his approval rating has declined among Democrats: to 74 percent from 83 percent. However, there has been no comparable improvement in Mr. Obama’s standing among independents.

headline: Beth Straus, Who Revamped New York Botanical Garden, Dies at 94
text: Beth Straus, who was a transformative figure at the New York Botanical Gardenfor nearly a half century, helping to revamp its image from that of a public park to that of a museum and fostering one of its crown jewels, the Peggy Rockefeller Rose Garden, died on Monday at her home in Somesville, Me., on Mount Desert Island. She was 94.

headline: Peter C. Marzio, Houston Museum Director, Dies at 67
text: Peter C. Marzio, who as the director of the Museum of Fine Arts, Houston for nearly 30 years elevated it to major-museum status through an ambitious program of physical expansion and a commitment to Latin American, Hispanic and Asian art, died on Thursday in Houston. He was 67.

headline: Isles’ Boisterous Crowd Is Filled With Nordiques Fans
text: UNIONDALE, N.Y.  An estimated 1,100 fans of the old Nordiques traveled to Nassau Coliseum from Quebec for Saturday night’s game between the Islanders and the Atlanta Thrashers, an effort to show the N.H.L. that their city deserves a team.

headline: Onetime Prodigy Shows Renewed Signs of Promise
text: Tennis players fantasize about drubbing the top-ranked Rafael Nadal. Luke McShane, an English grandmaster, got to live out the chess version of such a dream last week at the London Chess Classic, where he soundly defeated Magnus Carlsen, the world’s No.1 player, in the first round.

headline: Heisman Triumph Tinged With Hurt
text: The presentation of the 2010 Heisman Trophy had about as much suspense as a Harlem Globetrotters game. For 13 star-kissed games, Auburn quarterback Cam Newton seemed to toy with opponents  from overmatched nonleague teams to the meat of the Southeastern Conference  as if they were the Washington Generals.

headline: Luck Could Revisit a New York Moment
text: At a lunch table overlooking the bustle of Times Square on Saturday afternoon, Stanford quarterback Andrew Luck smiled after he misspoke.

headline: Prisoners Strike in Georgia
text: In a protest apparently assembled largely through a network of banned cellphones, inmates across at least six prisons in Georgia have been on strike since Thursday, calling for better conditions and compensation, several inmates and an outside advocate said.

headline: Andrew Luck’s New York Moment May Not Be His Last
text: At a lunch table overlooking the bustle of Times Square on Saturday afternoon, Stanford quarterback Andrew Luck smiled after he misspoke.

headline: Fans’ Target Becomes Their Favorite
text: No player entered the N.H.L. season facing more pressure than Canadiens goaltender Carey Price.

headline: In Amsterdam, a Rich Survey of Islamic Art
text: A globally renowned collection of Islamic art is on view at De Nieuwe Kerk (Dam, International Exhibition Centre, Gravenstraat 17; 31-20-626-8168; www.nieuwekerk.nl) through April 17. Assembled by Prof. Nasser D. Khalili, a well-known scholar and benefactor, it includes over 500 objects, among them illuminated Korans and manuscripts, paintings, gold, jewels, textiles, ceramics, glassware, lacquerware, metalwork and wood carvings.

headline: Orwellian Centrism
text: I don’t usually bother looking at the Washington Post. But I’m inside the Beltway right now, so I spared a peek — and for my sins ended up reading Dana Milbank, who praises Obama for punching the hippies.

headline: Are Giants Better Off Facing Favre?
text: The snowstorm that postponed the Vikings-Giants game to Monday night will give Brett Favre an extra 31 hours to heal, possibly allowing him to extend his streak of consecutive games started. You could interpret that as bad news for the Giants, who would otherwise face Tarvaris Jackson.

headline: Park Slope Plane Crash | A Collision in the Clouds
text: This is the first in a week-long series of stories and multimedia marking the 50th anniversary of the December, 1960, air disaster in New York City.

headline: Park Slope Plane Crash | Were You There?
text: “The principal came into my room, looking very distracted and asked if he could sit with me for a minute,” said Vera McLoughlin, a second-grade teacher at Public School 77 on Second Street in Park Slope. “Then he told me what had happened and said he was not going to let the students out at lunchtime.”

headline: After Attack Hits Sweden, Focus Turns to Suspect
text: STOCKHOLM — A day after two explosions struck central Stockholm, killing the man suspected of being a suicide bomber and wounding two other people, investigators began to focus on the possibility that the person responsible was a disaffected Iraqi-born Swede who had attended college in Britain.

headline: Roof Falls In, Sending the Giants’ Game to Detroit
text: MINNEAPOLIS  The roof of the Metrodome deflated early Sunday morning under the weight of the heaviest snowfall in almost two decades, forcing the N.F.L. to move the game scheduled to be played there between the Minnesota Vikings and the Giants to another domed stadium in Detroit on Monday night.

headline: Comment Etiquette, Public Editor-style
text: NYTimes.com is a fertile field for readers to offer comments on news stories, opinion pieces and blogs, as I pointed out in my Sunday, Dec. 12 column. But you might ask: how does the Public Editor himself moderate comments? So I thought I would offer here a bit of information on the comment moderation approach that I take.

headline: The Doom of Broder
text: Uh-oh. David Broder says the tax deal marks the beginning of Obama’s recovery. The president is doomed.

headline: Suicide Attacks Leave at Least 15 People Dead in Iraq
text: BAGHDAD  Suicide attacks on Sunday struck a government compound in the Sunni heartland of western Iraq and a Shiite procession northeast of Baghdad. A third suicide bombing appeared to have been averted north of Baghdad when security forces in Balad shot and wounded the driver of a pickup truck packed with explosives.

headline: 6 Americans Killed by Bomb at a New U.S.-Afghan Outpost
text: ZHARE, Afghanistan  Six American soldiers were killed and more than a dozen American and Afghan troops were wounded on Sunday morning when a van packed with explosives was detonated at a new jointly operated outpost in southern Afghanistan.

headline: Holden Scores Winner for Bolton
text: The American international Stuart Holden, who missed two games with a thigh injury, returned to the lineup for Bolton Wanderers on Sunday and scored the game winning goal two minutes before the end of the match. Holden’s goal gave Wanderers a 2-1 win over visiting Blackburn Rovers in the English Premier League.

headline: Japan Plans Military Shift to Focus More on China
text: TOKYO  In what would be a sweeping overhaul of its cold war-era defense strategy, Japan is about to release new military guidelines that would reduce its heavy armored and artillery forces pointed north toward Russia in favor of creating more mobile units that could respond to China’s growing presence near its southernmost islands, Japanese newspapers reported Sunday.

headline: Blast in Kandahar Kills Six
text: A van exploded beside a joint outpost in southern Afghanistan on Sunday, killing six Americans.

headline: Out of Our Brains
text: Where is my mind?

headline: The Students of Act Out
text: Photos of students in an acting class where gay issues take center stage.

headline: Germany Signals Support for Euro-Zone Members
text: FRANKFURT  In a shift of tone that may signal more commitment to keep the euro zone in one piece, Germany’s finance minister ruled out the possibility that any country would ever be ejected from the European monetary union, and said calls to restore the Deutsche mark were “unrealistic nostalgia.”

headline: Onstage, Young Star Reins in Her Hair
text: Just 10 years old, and Willow Smith has already learned one of the tenets of effective management: delegate, delegate, delegate.

headline: A Gem From the Nationals Features an Odd Trump Trick
text: The best-played contract at the Fall Nationals in Orlando, Fla., last month was also the worst-defended. Such is bridge sometimes.

headline: Steele to Announce Decision on R.N.C. Run
text: The battle for control of the Republican National Committee will take a new turn on Monday when Michael Steele announces whether he plans to step down as party chairman or will disregard the onslaught of criticism about his oversight of the committee and seek a second term.

headline: 'Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf?'
text: Tracy Letts, Amy Morton, Madison Dirks and Carrie Coon in a scene from the production at the Steppenwolf Theater in Chicago. (Video courtesy of the production)

headline: Video of Metrodome Roof Collapsing
text: Maybe the Giants miscalculated by not traveling to Minneapolis earlier in the week, but the collapse of the Metrodome roof certainly makes the issue moot.

headline: Straying From the Canon With Unfamiliar Fare
text: By no means has the vital English cellist Steven Isserlis excluded the standard repertory for his instrument from his purview, on record or onstage. But bringing to light unfamiliar and worthy works by second-tier Romantics as well as contemporary composers seems to give Mr. Isserlis special delight. That his interests can draw sizable numbers of palpably engaged listeners is a credit to his estimable skills, enlightened advocacy and communicative powers.

headline: Celebrating Steve Reich, a Bit Early
text: If he thinks about such things, Steve Reich is probably just getting used to being 74, having attained that age on Oct. 3. But composers’ 74th birthdays are really just the starting bell for celebrations of their 75th, and Axiom, one of the Juilliard School’s resident new-music ensembles, offered an all-Reich program as an early tribute on Thursday evening at Alice Tully Hall.

headline: Helping Gay Actors Find Themselves Onstage
text: One by one the students in Brad Calcaterra’s acting class stood at the front of the room and tearfully, joyfully, brazenly talked about being gay. A young lesbian laughed about her first kiss. A gay man described living with H.I.V. since the 1980s. A transgender woman performed high kicks. Before one man said anything his body shook, and he began to sob.

headline: Bloomberg Rules Out Presidential Run
text: Despite renewed speculation about his presidential aspirations, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg on Sunday categorically ruled out running for the White House in 2012 in an appearance on “Meet the Press” on NBC.

headline: A Playfully Roasted Old Chestnut
text: There’s no Sugar Plum Fairy in “The Hard Nut,” Mark Morris’s version of “The Nutcracker,” and no prima-ballerina dances to the music Tchaikovsky wrote as a grand pas de deux. Instead the adagio of that grand pas de deux (with its tremendous series of slow downward scales) becomes a grand ensemble. It contains moments, however, when it suddenly becomes a true — but anti-grand — pas de deux, in which both hero and heroine dance (rather than a woman dancing with the help of a male cavalier).

headline: Offering Sturm Galore, Fire and Drang as Well
text: Go for the fireballs, stay for the self-mythologizing and angst: That could be the pitch for Rammstein, the German rock band that played its first American show since 2001 on Saturday night at a sold-out Madison Square Garden. During the concert flames shot up from the stage, down from the rafters and sideways from flamethrowers mounted in microphones and on a set of angel wings; fireworks added explosions and showers of sparks. At one point a man ran around the stage in a flaming suit, with an E.M.T. on hand to snuff him out.

headline: Up Close, Yes. Personal? In Varying Degrees.
text: During Justin Bieber’s five-song performance on Friday night at Madison Square Garden the videographers for the overhead screens all seemed to be leaning back. The audience could not look into his soul.

headline: Sincerest Form of Flattery: Some Joke!
text: Days before Thanksgiving the CBS late-night host Craig Ferguson was informed by a fan on Twitter that he had a particularly ardent French admirer. Some might say a copycat. Others might say a plagiarist.

headline: Start, Then Start Again on a Newly Made Stage
text: Nicole Wolcott is a queen of the quick cut. For her, movement works best when it’s snappy, with an emphasis placed on crisp, rhythmic precision. It’s as if the body truly is an instrument: virtuosity is found in a rapid sideway glance, pivoting feet, a hip that sinks and shakes like a piece of machinery, or a brisk plunge to the floor. There’s no denying that skill is involved, but for the viewer it doesn’t take long for fatigue set in.

headline: In My Father’s House, That Airless, Bitter Place
text: Merging astronomy, Buddhist philosophy, and political and social unrest, “Mundane History” may carry a modest title, but its ambitions are exactly the opposite. A simple, almost spare family drama told through strong, purposeful images, this first feature from the Thai director Anocha Suwichakornpong parallels the emotional dynamic of a single home with the tumult of an entire country.

headline: Monday: Now … and Then
text: The latest Monday puzzle, followed by the first Monday puzzle.

headline: Egon Schiele Seen From Many Angles
text: Egon Schiele is dancing with himself again. The Viennese Expressionist artist — who died in 1918 but has been regularly reincarnated by the American performance artist John Kelly — can once more be found performing an angular pas de trois with two mirror images at the Ellen Stewart Theater at La MaMa. And if you haven’t ever seen Egon and his Alter Egons (that’s what they’re called), you have missed one of the sweetest testaments to artistic self-involvement ever staged.

headline: Opposites Attract, and React, in a Dark Neighborhood
text: Tommy Smith pulls strange bedfellows from the urban melting pot and has them collide in “The Wife,” a sort of warped, contemporary “La Ronde” at the Access Theater. Jew and gentile, black and white, immigrant and native: Mr. Smith’s characters meet and try to connect. But this is no earnest, let’s-all-get-along tale. It’s too odd and prickly and prone to the dark side.

headline: Life Among the Upper Crust, Seen From Two Generations
text: As a girl Deborah Mitford weathered the Great Depression with her parents and was forced to leave Swinbrook House, the Oxfordshire manse that she loved. “I minded more than I can say,” she says about this transition. At Swinbrook “the woods belonged to my father and we never met a soul.” At a more modest family home, Old Mill Cottage in High Wycombe, outside London, the Mitfords had to take walks on footpaths that were open to the public.

headline: Slow Start for ‘Narnia’ and ‘The Tourist’
text: Smooth sailing it was not at the weekend box office, where “The Chronicles of Narnia: Voyage of the Dawn Treader” experienced weak ticket sales in North America, and “The Tourist” flopped. “Dawn Treader,” a $140 million 3-D fantasy from 20th Century Fox and Walden Media, sold about $24.5 million in its first weekend, enough for No. 1 but on the low end of expectations. “Dawn Treader” sold a solid $67 million overseas, but unless it performs very well domestically — something Fox says is possible given strong exit polls — the “Narnia” franchise, based on the books of C. S. Lewis, could end here. The weekend was much worse for two stars considered among Hollywood’s most bankable: Johnny Depp and Angelina Jolie saw their new film, “The Tourist,” fizzle in second place with about $17 million. That result may not sound terrible, but “The Tourist” cost GK Films about $100 million to make and Sony Pictures Entertainment tens of millions to market. Sony acknowledged that sales were “soft” but said the studio expected the overseas reception to be “substantially stronger.” “Tangled” (Walt Disney Studios) was third with about $14.6 million for a three-week total of $115.6 million. “Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 1” (Warner Brothers) was fourth with $8.5 million in its fourth weekend for a total of $257.7 million, while “Unstoppable” (Fox) was fifth with $3.8 million for a five-week total of $74.3 million.

headline: ‘Come Fly Away’ to Vegas
text: Twyla Tharp’s “Come Fly Away,” a dance musical set to the songs of Frank Sinatra, reopened in Las Vegas this weekend with a new name, “Sinatra: Dance With Me,” and a slightly new face. The production has been retooled by Ms. Tharp with revised choreography and an abbreviated running time of 80 minutes, with no intermission. Most dancers from the Broadway run, which closed in September, have been retained, including the Tony Award nominees Karine Plantadit, Keith Roberts and John Selya. The show opened Saturday, the day before what would have been Sinatra’s 95th birthday.

headline: Photo Replay: Dec. 12
text: A view of the day in sports, with lots of snow and ice, plus some Polynesian canoes.

headline: 'The Hard Nut'
text: Images from a performance by the Mark Morris Dance Group.

headline: Z100 Jingle Ball
text: Photos from this year’s concert at Madison Square Garden.

headline: Another Concussion for Packers’ Rodgers
text: Aaron Rodgers sustained his second concussion of the season in the Packers’ 7-3 loss to the Lions on Sunday, another serious blow to a quarterback accustomed to punishment and a potentially devastating one to Green Bay’s playoff prospects.

headline: Risky Borrowers Find Credit Again, at a Price
text: Credit card offers are surging again after a three-year slowdown, as banks seek to revive a business that brought them huge profits before the financial crisis wrecked the credit scores of so many Americans.

headline: To Lead Chicago, Emanuel Must First Prove He Lives There
text: CHICAGO  Rahm Emanuel, the former White House chief of staff, this week faces perhaps the most significant challenge to his effort to become mayor of this city.

headline: Three Tied for Lead of London Chess Classic
text: Viswanathan Anand and Luke McShane, the co-leaders, drew on Sunday, which allowed Magnus Carlsen to catch them by beating David Howell.

headline: Steele to Reveal Whether He Wants to Keep His G.O.P. Job
text: WASHINGTON  The battle for control of the Republican National Committee will take a new turn on Monday when Michael Steele is set to announce whether he will step down as party chairman or disregard the onslaught of criticism about his leadership and seek a second term.

headline: Knicks Get Aggressive as Streaks Continue
text: Carmelo Anthony basked in a glowing reception, then spent much of Sunday afternoon shaking his head. The pregame cheers for Anthony soon disappeared, drowned out by the salutes to another purposeful effort from Amar’e Stoudemire and the Knicks.

headline: Jets Assistant Tripped Dolphins Rookie
text: Monday, 10:38 a.m. |N.F.L. and Jets Investigating

headline: Up From the Saudi Arabian Desert
text: In the empty desert, Saudi Arabia is building entire cities envisioned as spaces for education, industry, living, and more importantly, as islands from which social change might seep out, without antagonizing fundamentalist forces within the country.

headline: WikiLeaks Taps Power of the Press
text: Has WikiLeaks changed journalism forever?

headline: Navratilova Leaves Hospital After Kilimanjaro Attempt
text: Martina Navratilova was released from a Nairobi hospital Sunday, three days after being taken off Mount Kilimanjaro because she had developed high-altitude pulmonary edema, an accumulation of fluid in the lungs.

headline: Russian Protests Erupt Over Soccer Fan’s Killing
text: MOSCOW  Ethnic tensions briefly boiled over in Moscow over the weekend, as thousands of young men massed outside Red Square, venting their anger over the fatal shooting last week of a soccer fan by a migrant from the North Caucasus.

headline: Gang-related Shootings in Vancouver Leave 10 Wounded
text: OTTAWA  Ten people were shot early Sunday morning in a residential and commercial neighborhood of Vancouver, British Columbia. While it occurred in a part of the city not known for crime or gangs, Vancouver police characterized the shooting as “an outrageous display of gang-related violence.”

headline: Off-Duty Officer Is Shot in the Bronx
text: An off-duty New York police officer was shot after an argument outside a Bronx diner early Sunday, the police said.

headline: Wal-Mart Tries Again for New York City Store
text: The New York City Council was supposed to hold a hearing this Tuesday about a renewed campaign by Wal-Mart to open its stores in the city.

headline: Who Needs Ice? Synthetic Surface Extends Season
text: Ice would not seem hard to come by in Fort Chipewyan, a tiny outpost on Lake Athabasca in northeastern Alberta. A small aboriginal community, it is accessible in winter only by a 100-mile road built from ice.

headline: Digital Divide Is a Matter of Income
text: Household income is the greatest predictor of Internet use for Americans, according to a recent study by the Pew Research Center.

headline: News From the Advertising Industry
text: Accounts

headline: More Christians Flee Iraq After New Violence
text: QOSH, Iraq  A new wave of Iraqi Christians has fled to northern Iraq or abroad amid a campaign of violence against them and growing fear that the country’s security forces are unable or, more ominously, unwilling to protect them.

headline: Iraq: Christians on the Run
text: Some Iraqi Christians fled north after October's church massacre in Baghdad. Like Iraq's other ancient but vulnerable communities, they fear extremists seek to drive them from the country altogether.

headline: Jets’ Swoon Continues at an Inopportune Time
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Inside his postgame fishbowl of a news conference, only glass walls stood between Coach Rex Ryan and about a hundred Jets fans. This arrangement in the new stadium no longer seemed cutting edge, as angst replaced the typical pep rally outside.

headline: Web Focus Helps Revitalize The Atlantic
text: WASHINGTON  How did a 153-year-old magazine  one that first published the “Battle Hymn of the Republic” and gave voice to the abolitionist and transcendentalist movements  reinvent itself for the 21st century?

headline: Will the North Compromise Or Hold Fast?
What’s the Worst Part of the Jets’ Loss?
text: If the Jets were hoping to bury their embarrassing Monday night loss to the Patriots — literally, at one point — and right their ship with a strong performance against the Dolphins, they sure missed their chance.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 4,420 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war and 1,411 who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans recently:

headline: Suit Against Austrian Banker Is Denounced
text: A lawyer for the Austrian banker accused in a civil complaint on Friday of being an accomplice in Bernard L. Madoff’s worldwide Ponzi scheme said on Sunday that the charge is “ridiculous” and “does not reflect reality.”

headline: As China Rolls Ahead, Fear Follows

headline: Detroit’s Monsters Thrive on a Diet of Cheap Gas
text: CARACAS, Venezuela  Ascending the narrow streets that wind through this city’s hillside slums, the graffiti steadily gets more radical and anti-American, repeatedly proclaiming “Yankees go home!” amid murals denouncing President Obama and Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton.

headline: A.&P. Files for Bankruptcy
text: Chris Ware/Bloomberg News

headline: Some Early Nods for Oscar Hopefuls
text: The race toward the little gold man moves past mere conjecture and educated guessing this week, with the Golden Globe nominations on Tuesday, and announcements from several industry groups – including the American Film Institute and critics from New York, San Francisco, Toronto and Chicago – about what they considered the year’s best way to spend two hours in the dark.

headline: The Nets Give the Lakers All That They Can Handle
text: NEWARK  The Nets’ new owner, Mikhail D. Prokhorov, released a statement last month offering an aspiration for his team. The Nets, Prokhorov said, would someday “like to resemble the Lakers.”

headline: At 86, Finding a Way to Pass the Time That’s Left
text: Mary Ruberto spends most of her time alone in her apartment, though not by choice. She is an avid reader, and her only companions are the characters she follows in her books and her pet Chihuahua, Chiquita Juanita.

headline: Christians in Iraq
text: Christians in Iraq are fleeing persecution in Baghdad and Mosul.

headline: Florida’s Hiring of Muschamp Is Bold and Risky
text: The head-coaching jobs at Texas, Florida and Ohio State  in varying order  are widely considered to be the most attractive in college football. All three programs have enormous war chests, resources of local talent and long histories of Heisman Trophy winners and national titles.

headline: Hackers Disrupt Sites Run by Gawker Media
text: Web sites belonging to Gawker Media abruptly stopped publishing new material on Sunday after mischief-making hackers gained access to the company’s servers.

headline: Washington Examiner Helps Capture Fugitives
text: The Washington Examiner is known around the nation’s capital for its conservative bent, bite-size news reports and price that cannot be beat: it is given away on the Metro.

headline: Defending Champion Ousted as Women’s World Championship Reaches Quarterfinals
text: Alexandra Kosteniuk, the defending champion, was beaten on Sunday, but Humpy Koneru and Hou Yifan, the two highest-ranked players at the start of the tournament, advanced.

headline: Time Warner Views Netflix as a Fading Star
text: For the past year, executives at big media companies have watched Netflix with growing resentment  for its success in delivering movies and television shows via the Internet, for its stock price nearly quadrupling, for its chief executive being named businessperson of the year by Fortune magazine.

headline: Out of Power Soon, and Out of Sorts Now
text: WASHINGTON  As House Democrats met privately to weigh the tax deal negotiated by the White House, an angry chant spontaneously rolled across the room.

headline: In Snowy Conditions, a Patriots Wonderland
text: CHICAGO  The famous New England game that was played as if in a snow globe, when Adam Vinatieri launched a field goal into a snowy night and propelled the Patriots into a dynasty, is commemorated by pictures the team still sells. No moment from the Patriots’ 36-7 humiliation of the Chicago Bears in a snowstorm Sunday will be immortalized like Vinatieri’s franchise-altering boot in 2002. But on a day when a snow-related collapse in Minneapolis captured the headlines, the Bears’ own crumble nearly matched that of the Metrodome roof for shock value.

headline: Vintage American Cars in Venezuela
text: With gas as low as 10c a gallon, Venezuelans can afford to own vintage American cars.

headline: Heightened Fiscal Pressures Loom for Tarrytown
text: The property tax cap proposed by Governor-elect Andrew M. Cuomo would leave most school districts in the state unable to cover increases in salaries, pensions and health care, the New York State School Boards Association concluded in a report to be released soon.

headline: More Bluster Than Results for Ryan
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.

headline: Metropolitan Diary
text: DEAR DIARY:

headline: Madoff Lawsuits Are Headed for Court
text: With the final deadline for litigation having passed at midnight on Saturday, at least 1,000 individual civil lawsuits will now go forward to try to recover more than $50 billion for the victims of the global Ponzi scheme orchestrated by Bernard L. Madoff.

headline: Book Tour as Warm-Up
text: Now that the former Alaska governor Sarah Palin has wrapped up her 14-state book tour for “America by Heart,” her second book in two years, another potential Republican candidate for president has stepped up for his turn. Tim Pawlenty, the governor of Minnesota, announced on Friday that next month he would begin a multistate tour to promote his book, “Courage to Stand,” to be released by Tyndale House Publishers in January.

headline: Bankers in Energy Are in Short Supply
Struggling in the Downturn, A.&P. Files for Bankruptcy
text: The Great Atlantic & Pacific Tea Company, the troubled supermarket operator, filed for bankruptcy protection on Sunday to reorganize its finances after struggling with a big debt load and stiff competition.

headline: Lee’s Silence Keeps Yankees and Rangers Hung in Suspense
text: As a pitcher, Cliff Lee is the model of brisk efficiency, walking virtually no one and often retiring the side in order.

headline: Rep. Ron Paul, G.O.P. Loner, Comes In From Cold
text: WASHINGTON  As virtually all of Washington was declaring WikiLeaks’s disclosures of secret diplomatic cables an act of treason, Representative Ron Paul was applauding the organization for exposing the United States’ “delusional foreign policy.”

headline: Middle East Becomes Bigger Player
text: LONDON

headline: Lottery Numbers
Facebook Wrestles With Free Speech and Civility
text: PALO ALTO, Calif.  Mark Zuckerberg, the co-founder and chief executive of Facebook, likes to say that his Web site brings people together, helping to make the world a better place. But Facebook isn’t a utopia, and when it comes up short, Dave Willner tries to clean up.

headline: The Almost Forgotten: Los Angeles’ Homeless
text: The problem of homelessness seems intractable in Los Angeles, but city leaders are rallying around a new plan.

headline: Carmelo Anthony Watch Provides a Few Clues
text: In between his “I don’t want to talk about it” moments, Denver’s Carmelo Anthony revealed a couple of clues to the tea-leaf readers about his future Sunday.

headline: Economic Reports for the Week of Dec. 13
text: ECONOMIC REPORTS Data this week will include retail sales and the Producer Price Index for November and business inventories for October (Tuesday); Consumer Price Index and industrial production for November (Wednesday); weekly jobless claims, housing starts for November, current account deficit for the third quarter and the Philadelphia Fed’s manufacturing index for December (Thursday); and leading economic indicators for November (Friday).

headline: In Mustang Makeovers, Trainers Tame Wild Horses for Adoption in 100 Days
text: MURFREESBORO, Tenn.  On the brown dirt floor of Tennessee Miller Coliseum, Dale Lively covered the eyes of his mustang by wrapping a cloth around its head, then rode it toward a small wooden bridge.

headline: Nassos Daphnis, an Artist of Geometry, Dies at 96
text: Nassos Daphnis, a Greek-American artist who deployed brilliantly colored geometric forms in precise formal relationships to create nervous, dynamic paintings on a heroic scale, died on Nov. 23 in Provincetown, Mass. He was 96 and lived in Manhattan.

headline: The Work of Nassos Daphnis
text: Images by the painter.

headline: Los Angeles Confronts Homelessness Reputation
text: LOS ANGELES  It was just past dusk in the upscale enclave of Brentwood as a homeless man, wrapped in a tattered gray blanket, stepped into a doorway to escape a light rain, watching the flow of people on their way to the high-end restaurants that lined the street.

headline: John B. Fenn, Nobel Winner Who Studied Large Molecules, Dies at 93
text: John B. Fenn, who shared the 2002 Nobel Prize for chemistry for developing a technique that sped up the development of new drugs and the study of the molecules of life, died Friday in Richmond, Va. He was 93.

headline: Watch It, Martha: This George Is a Stealth Bomb
text: CHICAGO — Tracy Letts has a national profile — a modest international one, even — on the strength of his name as a playwright. “August: Osage County,” his bleak, brilliant comedy-drama about an imploding American family, collected most of the major theater awards, including the Tony for best play and the Pulitzer Prize.

headline: Defenders of WikiLeaks Swarmed Wrong Target
text: OTTAWA  It is not clear if the mistake first appeared on a blog or flitted around in a Twitter message. But whatever its source, it swept Mark Jeftovic and his company, EasyDNS, into both sides of the storm over corporate support, or the lack thereof, for WikiLeaks.

headline: American Classics in Venezuela
text: America and its power may not be a popular concept on the streets of Caracas in 2010, but Venezuelan roads are still packed with American cars from the 1970s.

headline: 50 Years Later, Traces of an Air Crash Linger in Rusty Metal, and Memories
text: It was the accident pilots and passengers in the still-new jet age had feared the most  a distinctly new kind of catastrophe, one that had never happened over a major urban area, one that would have seemed far less terrifying a few years earlier, when planes were smaller and slower.

headline: Inmates in Georgia Prisons Use Contraband Phones to Coordinate Protest
text: The prison protest has entered the wireless age.

headline: In This Journey, Every Sunday Is Moving Day
text: Real estate stories, of claustrophobic kitchens, tyrannical landlords and rodent-size roaches, are a New York rite of passage. Stories of misery, unexpected good fortune or strange living arrangements  surely every New Yorker has one.

headline: Cuomo Plans to Push for a Cap on Property Taxes
text: Governor-elect Andrew M. Cuomo has a full plate awaiting him when he is inaugurated next month, including a gaping budget deficit. But Mr. Cuomo is already making clear to legislative leaders that one of his priorities is to cap local property taxes, which would have large consequences statewide for homeowners and school districts.

headline: Taxi TV Screens Gain Ad Business in New York
text: Take a taxi through the East Village this week, and there is a good chance that a commercial for the Blue Man Group  playing nearby on Astor Place  will pop up on the miniature television facing the back seat.

headline: Public Broadcaster Is to Sell Current, a Trade Publication
text: Current, the newspaper that has covered the public broadcasting business every two weeks for three decades, is leaving the hands of its longtime owner, WNET.org, the New York City public broadcaster. The board of WNET.org last week approved an agreement to sell Current to the American University School of Communication, whose board has also approved the move.

headline: Administrator of BP Fund Offers Bonuses to Spill Victims Who Bypass Suits
text: Kenneth Feinberg, who administers the $20 billion fund formed by BP to compensate people for losses from the gulf oil spill, is offering what amounts to a signing bonus to entice more victims to give up their right to sue BP or other companies involved in the disaster.

headline: Judicial Scrutiny Before Death
text: The Obama administration no longer has to worry about an immediate legal challenge to its policy of targeting terrorists, including American citizens, for assassination. A federal judge threw out a lawsuit brought by the father of Anwar al-Awlaki, an American citizen hiding in Yemen who is on the government’s target list. He said the father had no standing to sue.

text: To the Editor:

text: To the Editor:

headline: Drawing a Line in the Water
text: THE crisis in the Yellow Sea, which was set off by the North Korean shelling of South Korea’s Yeonpyeong Island last month, is probably mystifying to many Americans. Why did the North fire a deadly artillery barrage at a sparsely inhabited, relatively insignificant island? Why has the United States dispatched an entire aircraft-carrier group to the scene?

headline: And the Oscar for Teaching Goes to ...
text: To the Editor:

headline: Preying on Veterans
text: The for-profit education industry has been pushing back hard against new Education Department rules that will make it easier to rein in predatory schools that strip students of financial aid, saddle them with crushing debt and give them nothing in return. But the evidence is mounting that the new rules might not be enough to prevent some of the worst abuses.

headline: A Serious Man
text: There is a conceit, especially popular among the press corps, that the salvation of America depends exclusively on self-described moderates and centrists. If there’s a path out of gridlock and insolvency, this theory goes, it can’t be charted by consistent conservatives or liberals. Instead, the nation needs the leadership of ideologically flexible, politically ambidextrous mavericks: Democrats like Evan Bayh, perhaps, and Republicans like Susan Collins, with President Michael Bloomberg waiting to sign whatever compromises they devise.

headline: Shut Those Doors
text: As soon as Governor-elect Andrew Cuomo takes office, he should close a half-dozen more of New York’s ruinously expensive, and half-empty, juvenile detention facilities. He should also press the State Legislature to revoke a wasteful law that keeps facilities scheduled for shutdown open and staffed for a full year, even when there is not a single child in custody.

headline: They Haven’t Learned
text: The oil industry, its lobbyists and its Congressional allies are predictably furious at the Obama administration’s decision not to allow exploratory oil drilling in the eastern Gulf of Mexico and off the Atlantic coast. The decision was unquestionably the right one.

headline: Bones of Contention
text: Laramie, Wyo.

headline: Block Those Metaphors
text: Like it or not  and I don’t  the Obama-McConnell tax-cut deal, with its mixture of very bad stuff and sort-of-kind-of good stuff, is likely to pass Congress. Then what?

headline: A New City in Saudi Arabia
text: Photos of King Abdullah Economic City, a 65-square-mile development at the edge of the Red Sea.

headline: At Kosher Chefs’ Cook-Off, Forget Foie Gras
text: Culinary school had its frustrations for Seth Warshaw, the executive chef and owner of Etc. Steakhouse, a kosher restaurant in Teaneck, N.J. He had enrolled in a prestigious cooking school in Manhattan, but it quickly became clear that his religious restrictions rendered many hallmarks of fine French cooking  like rich creams and luscious crustaceans  off-limits.

headline: Rangers Hand Capitals Sixth Defeat in a Row
text: The road to the Winter Classic has become bumpy for Alex Ovechkin and the Washington Capitals, and the Rangers provided the biggest pothole so far with a 7-0 trouncing Sunday night at Madison Square Garden.

headline: Reviving a Ritual of Tending to the Dead
text: The volunteers are taught to begin at the head, washing the face before proceeding to the neck and right shoulder. The right side is to be washed before the left side, the front before the back. There are prayers to say. Small talk is forbidden.

headline: In Tax Benefits to the Middle, Political Lift for Obama
text: WASHINGTON  With the Senate poised to hold a key vote on Monday on the tax cut deal between President Obama and Republicans, the political jousting has focused on what the agreement does for the wealthy by extending all of the Bush-era tax rates, and for the unemployed, by continuing jobless aid.

headline: Saudi Urban Projects Are a Window to Modernity
text: JIDDA, Saudi Arabia  Just off a desert road about an hour’s drive from this port city, an enormous arched gate capped by three domes rises out of the sand like the set for a 1920s silent film fantasy. It is, instead, a fantasy of contemporary urban planning, the site of what one day will be King Abdullah Economic City, a 65-square-mile development at the edge of the Red Sea. With a projected population of two million, the city is a Middle Eastern version of the “special economic zones” that have flourished in places like China.

headline: Buick Underwrites MSN Travel Show ‘Re: Discover’

headline: Finding Inspiration with the Sartorialist
text: Regularly visiting the Sartorialist, a picture blog created by Scott Schuman, is akin to a serendipiter’s journey with a guide whose eye for detail, gift for framing and hopeful outlook help you see how many beautiful people there are. And not just among the Beautiful People. Mr. Schuman also finds considerable style in a house painter, all in white, or the keeper of a delicatessen in Rome, in his long smock. On the Sartorialist, a single image can prompt hundreds of comments. A spot on the blog is so coveted that there are guides online to getting noticed. In five years, Mr. Schuman’s singular vision has transformed him from someone who documents style to someone who also influences it.

headline: Getting a Taste of ‘The Fighter’
text: How often do you hear the phrase “hood pass” uttered from a Lincoln Center stage? Not often enough, as far as the Bagger is concerned. A few weeks ago, during a Q. and A. after a screening of “The Fighter,” Mark Wahlberg invoked his when an audience member asked about the depiction of residents in Lowell, Mass., where “The Fighter” was set and filmed. As a hardscrabble kid, Mr. Wahlberg suggested, he was off the hook for any negative response and left the question to his director, David O. Russell. Echoing what he told the Bagger in a later interview, Mr. Russell said that he took all of his cues from the residents themselves and that they were cool with their unvarnished depiction. “They’re very alive and very unpretentious and very open,” he told us.

On Sunday’s episode of “Sarah Palin’s Alaska,” Ms. Palin, the former half-term governor and 2008 Republican nominee for vice president, hosted Kate Gosselin, the star of “Kate Plus Eight,” for a day that began with preparations for a camping trip and ended with Ms. Gosselin standing uncomfortably beneath a rain-soaked tarp before calling it quits and going home.

headline: Putin Croons in English for Hollywood Stars

But video posted online by Russia Today, the Kremlin’s English-language satellite channel, confirms that this event did take place Friday night at a benefit concert for children with cancer in St. Petersburg.

headline: Police Say Early Detonation of Bomb Averted Disaster in Sweden

headline: Study Shows Depth of Unemployment for Blacks in New York
text: The headline on a new report tells the bad news: “Only One in Four Young Black Men in New York City Have a Job.” The report, prepared by the Community Service Society of New York, has other unhappy news about this group — that the unemployment rate for African-American men in New York, age 16 to 24, was 33.5 percent from January 2009 through June 2010, while the labor force participation rate was 38 percent.

headline: Monday Reading: The Outlook for Gas Prices
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: Scan It Yourself, and Other Thoughts About the Google Digitizing Settlement
text: As the New York Times series Humanities 2.0 has discussed, digitally savvy academics are both excited and anxious about Google’s plan to digitize tens of millions of books and create an online library and bookstore. While the proposal remains in legal limbo, the result of a class action lawsuit, the debate continues.

headline: Berlusconi Pleads for Support Ahead of Confidence Vote
text: ROME  Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi knows a good crisis when he sees one. As he prepares for a crucial no-confidence vote Tuesday that could upend his leadership, he is betting that the financial problems engulfing Europe will provide yet another miraculous salvation for his political career.

headline: Park Slope Plane Crash | The Neighborhood in 1960
text: Edwardian and Victorian row houses were scarred with peeling paint, broken windows and missing stoop stones. Scavengers pilfered abandoned or burned-out homes for radiators and brass pipes to sell as scrap metal. Residents called a group of rat-infested buildings on Prospect Park West a “serious blight” and a breeding place for “prostitution, crime, vice, narcotics and immorality.”

headline: Icahn Pulls Tender Offer for Lions Gate
text: Carl C. Icahn has called “cut” in his long-running battle for Lions Gate Entertainment.

headline: ‘Black Swan’ Leads Broadcast Film Critics Association Nominations
text: Is it time to start the dancing metaphors for “Black Swan”? Darren Aronofsky’s ballet thriller waltzed off with a record 12 nominations from the Broadcast Film Critics Association, including best picture; best actress (Natalie Portman); best supporting actress (Mila Kunis); best director (Mr. Aronofsky); best original screenplay; and a host of craft awards from makeup to sound.

headline: New Derivatives Rules Could be ‘Disastrous,’ Energy Companies Say
text: Banks, asset managers and energy companies are imploring regulators to go easy in writing new capital and margin requirements for derivatives trading, escalating the debate about some of the thorniest provisions in the Dodd-Frank Wall Street overhaul legislation.

headline: Tom Walkinshaw, Former Formula One Team Boss, Dies at 64
text: Tom Walkinshaw, engineering director for one of Michael Schumacher‘s two championship seasons with the Benetton Formula One team, died Sunday after suffering from cancer, The Guardian confirmed. He was 64.

headline: Hirsch Stepping Down From La Cucina Italiana Board
text: George A. Hirsch, announced he would step down from his position as chairman of the board and publishing director for La Cucina Italiana, the popular 80 year-old food magazine. Mr. Hirsch, 76, who is probably best known as the founding publisher of New York magazine, will leave once a new publisher is selected.

headline: Force of Habit: Seth Green and ‘Robot Chicken’ Return to ‘Star Wars’
text: It’s that time of the year again, when there’s a planet Hoth-like chill in the air, visions of midi-chlorians and power converters dance in our heads, and joy is spread by a familiar bearded figure — namely, George Lucas — when his “Star Wars” movies take their lumps from “Robot Chicken,” the stop-motion animated comedy series created by Seth Green and Matthew Senreich. In “Robot Chicken: Star Wars Episode III,” which makes its debut Friday on Cartoon Network’s Adult Swim channel, an all-star cast lends its voice to a third installment of knowing, willfully nerdy send-ups of the “Star Wars” saga, including Zac Efron (playing Anakin Skywalker); the “Star Wars” veterans Anthony Daniels, Billy Dee Williams and Ahmed Best; Donald Glover of “Community”; Seth MacFarlane, Mr. Green’s boss at “Family Guy”; and of course Mr. Green himself.

headline: On Our Radar: Extreme Weather Grips U.S.

The article highlights the volume of small-business transactions, provides some average multiples, and offers comparisons to the prior year. The picture isn’t pretty.

headline: ‘Dexter’ Watch: Annoyed by the Season Finale?
text: The reaction to the season finale of “Dexter” on Sunday night is surely divided into distinct camps: people who were annoyed and people who hated it. I fall into the first camp. The season was incredibly strong in my mind, and “Dexter” certainly remains one of the best shows on television, but the final hour has left me padding about the house exasperated.

headline: U.S. Middle East Envoy Attempts to Restart Peace Process
