Mitchell, holding talks here on ways to improve the atmosphere between Israel and the Palestinians and ultimately negotiate over the core issues that separate them.

headline: Robert Stern Wins Driehaus Prize for Classical Architecture
text: At a time when contemporary architecture tends to get most of the attention, at least one award recognizes classicism. Robert A. M. Stern, the dean of the Yale School of Architecture, has been named the 2011 recipient of the Richard H. Driehaus Prize for Classical Architecture. Established in 2003 through the University of Notre Dame School of Architecture, the prize honors the practitioners of traditional, classical, sustainable architecture and urbanism.

headline: Wilson Chandler Expands His Range
text: The Knicks’ eight straight wins have brought plenty of praise for all of the team’s new toys, but behind them is a New York mainstay quietly enjoying the best season of his career. With the substantial shadows of Amar’e Stoudemire and Raymond Felton providing ample living space, Wilson Chandler has finally found a comfortably efficient place in the Knicks’ offense.

headline: Del Toro Is Committed to New Video Game Series
text: Who needs capricious and sometimes financially imperiled movie studios to finance and release ambitious content when there’s a whole world of video game companies waiting to do it? Certainly not Guillermo del Toro. Having withdrawn himself from “The Hobbit” movies when the future of that film franchise was less certain, Mr. del Toro, the “Pan’s Labyrinth” and “Hellboy” director, has found a new dark fantasy series to keep him busy, but it won’t be coming soon to a theater near you. On Monday, the video game publisher THQ Inc. said it had struck “a multiyear agreement” for Mr. del Toro to create a new game trilogy called inSANE.

headline: Accounts and People of Note in the Ad Industry

headline: Jets Not to Be Outdone by Metrodome Roof
text: Today’s N.F.L. extra credit question is to decide which event in an eventful weekend represented the bigger collapse. Choice A is the Metrodome roof, with its aftermath being the league having to move the Giants-Vikings game to not just another day but another city. Choice B is the Jets’ imploding hopes for world domination and pop culture stardom.

headline: Numberplay: Octopus Games
text: The discussion on last week’s Newton’s Cradle puzzle is still very much alive. Gary has posted an interim solution update, but the problem is far from being completely solved, and Gary’s experiments are still in progress. We welcome further ideas and results of experiments by readers on this very interesting executive toy. Gary and I considered having another post featuring new experiments on the Newton’s cradle, but decided to wait. We may still do so in the future, as new theoretical and experimental insights on this marvelous contraption become available.

headline: Tokyo Pop | A Marc Jacobs One-Off
text: Forget lacquerware bowls and silk kimonos: If you’re on the hunt for a truly only-in-Japan souvenir, look no further than Marc Jacobs’s new Tokyo flagship store. It’s the only place in the world where you’ll find the designer’s “AOYAMARCJACOBS” T-shirt, emblazoned with a clever portmanteau that makes a reference to the store’s neighborhood (the quiet, upscale Aoyama). There are other reasons to visit, especially since the award-winning space, by Stephan Jaklitsch Architects, is destined for a spot on the list of the city’s design must-sees. Although the shirt is not Jacobs’s only recent nod to Asia — his spring 2011 collection for Louis Vuitton featured a satin cheongsam — at approximately $75, it’s likely his most affordable.

headline: Birds Do It ... We Do It ... and No One Knows Why
text: Everyone yawns, but no one knows why. We start when we are in the womb, and we do it through old age. Most vertebrate species, even birds and fishes, yawn too, or at least do something that looks very much like it. But its physiological mechanisms, its purpose and what survival value it might have remain a mystery.

headline: Giving a Performance a Good Score
text: When charged with the task of writing the score for the acting vignettes in The New York Times Magazine’s Great Performers feature, the musician Owen Pallett was presented with a couple of challenges. First, he had to compose the score while on his own solo tour. Secondly, he had to put the music together within the space of a week. He ended up assembling 14 pieces of music that bring to mind classic movie scores while also maintaining elements of Mr. Pallet’s musical style. The compositions were recorded by a 32-piece orchestra in Prague. In a phone interview from his tour bus in Europe, Mr. Pallett answered a few questions about the project. Here are excerpts from that interview.

headline: Notes From the Underground | Dynasty Handbag
text: The veteran performance artist Jibz Cameron lit up the stage as part of the latest installment of Shelly Mars’s “Bulldyke Chronicles,” a performance art variety show of sorts, at Dixon Place. Cameron (who appeared as her best-known character, Dynasty Handbag) performed elements of an unnamed work in progress, bringing the small audience to hysterics with her perfectly over-the-top physical comedy.

headline: Photo Replay: Dec. 13

headline: Tenant’s Typical Headaches, but in Grand Style
text: Irene Front does not like to complain. So her relatives and home aide do it for her. They have been asking Ms. Front’s landlord to fix the heat, get rid of the mice that leap onto her bed when she sleeps and repair the doorbell that has been broken for weeks.

headline: A Meaningful December for the Colts
text: Sunday’s games cleared up a few things. The New England offense is Super Bowl-ready, after the Patriots became the first team to clinch a playoff berth this season. The Jets’ offense, which has been missing in two straight losses, is not. The collapse of the Metrodome’s roof gave an unanticipated jolt to Zygi Wilf’s argument that the Minnesota Vikings need a new stadium. And the San Diego Chargers have to be close to collapse before they start playing like a playoff team.

headline: Neurosexism
text: Neuroscience supported sexism, where dissimilarities between men and women are attributed to differences in brain function.

headline: The Difficulty of Proving Financial Crimes
text: Recent columns on DealBook by Andrew Ross Sorkin and Jesse Eisinger asked why federal prosecutors have not brought any significant cases against senior corporate executives related to the financial meltdown. A partial answer to the question can be found in a decision issued on Friday by the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit that reversed the conviction of a financial executive accused of accounting fraud for lack of evidence of any intent to defraud or mislead.

headline: Women’s Team Wins ‘The Amazing Race’
text: For the first time in its 17 seasons of globe-trotting “The Amazing Race” has been won by an all-woman team. Viewers saw Nat Strand and Kat Chang reach the finish line first on CBS on Sunday night, beating another female duo, Claire Champlin and Brook Roberts. Several men-women pairs have won the competition’s $1 million prize but television critics have wondered when two women would do so. Women have won other reality shows, like “Survivor” on CBS. The “Amazing Race” finale drew almost 12 million viewers on Sunday. When the series returns in February it will be broadcast for the first time in high definition.

headline: Healthy Holiday Appetizers
text: Everybody is looking for ideas for cocktail snacks at this time of year. The problem with traditional party platters is that they’re often not the healthiest  perhaps one reason that come January you’ll see a lot of new diet cookbooks in stores.

headline: Scenes of Troop Life, in the Round
text: A sea of trucks, weapons bristling. A cramped bunk room where beams of sunlight dissect the cool darkness. And mustard yellow tents, almost as far as the eye can see. These are 360-degree scenes from the places deployed soldiers with the First Battalion, 87th Infantry Regiment in Kunduz, Afghanistan, call home. Each tells a small part of the story of their life at war.

headline: Saving a Korean District
text: SEOUL — The leafy hillside neighborhood is called Bukchon, a district in central Seoul that constitutes the city’s last remaining collection of traditional courtyard houses.

headline: Study of Baby Teeth Sees Radiation Effects
text: Men who grew up in the St. Louis area in the early 1960s and died of cancer by middle age had more than twice as much radioactive strontium in their baby teeth as men born in the same area at the same time who are still living, according to a study based on teeth collected years ago by Washington University in St. Louis.

headline: Just One Look | Donna Karan Pre-Fall Collection
text: The pre-fall collections, being shown in New York over the next several weeks, arrive in stores in May to fill the gap between bikinis and furs.At her presentation late last week, Donna Karan was heavily accessorized (a cast on her arm could have easily been mistaken for a cool new style of cuff!) and dressed in her signature black layers. But the dresses, skirts and shirts she showed that day were as light and easy as they come in fabrics like cotton poplin and crushed viscose. A palette of washed-out camp colors brought it all down to earth.

In addition to the first-rate cupcakes (including some with bright holiday toppings), there are muffins, textbook-fudgy brownies, gooey pecan bars, dense cookies and cheesecakes.

headline: Does Science Need More Republicans?

That’s all good and well, considering the disturbing statistics he cites – including a Pew finding that only 6 percent of American scientists are Republican.

headline: Warhol Foundation Threatens to End Financing of Smithsonian Exhibitions
text: The Andy Warhol Foundation is threatening to stop its financing of Smithsonian Institution exhibitions if the institution does not restore a work of art that was removed from an exhibition after it drew attacks by the head of the Catholic League and some Republican members of Congress. The Warhol Foundation gave $100,000 to the Smithsonian for the exhibition, “Hide/Seek: Difference and Desire in American Portraiture,” at the National Portrait Gallery, from which the work was removed.

headline: ‘The Social Network’ Shows Early Strength

The film, which won top honors from Boston and Los Angeles critics’ groups on Sunday, has now been anointed with the big-dog prize from the New York Film Critics Circle, considered among the most prestigious of the industry groups. The truthy drama also earned David Fincher another nod for best director.

headline: A Spanish Import on the Upper West Side

Jesús Núñez, who owned the restaurants Polenta and Flou in Madrid but closed them because of the economic crisis there, is poised to open a showcase for his very personal, sometimes deconstructed, foamed, pulverized or molecularized take on Spanish food here. (Did he also fall in love with a New Yorker who did not want to move to Spain? Yes.)

headline: Los Angeles Museum of Contemporary Art Paints Over Mural
text: Street art – graffiti, uncommissioned public art, call it what you will – has found greater acceptance in the gallery and museum world over the last several years but the fit hasn’t always been comfortable. Anyone looking for evidence of the tensions now has a marquee example. The Los Angeles Museum of Contemporary Art, run by the former New York gallery owner Jeffrey Deitch – a longtime champion of street art – late last week ordered a wall mural it had commissioned by Blu, an Italian graffiti artist, to be whitewashed because it found the artwork inappropriate. The mural, on a wall of the museum’s Geffen Contemporary wing, was planned as a kind of advertisement for an ambitious exhibition focusing on street art that the museum will open in April. But as Blu neared completion of the mural – which conveyed a strident antiwar message, showing rows of caskets draped with one-dollar bills instead of flags – the museum changed its mind and began painting it over on Thursday.

headline: Poisoned Debate Encircles a Microbe Study’s Result

headline: Green Heating? Not So Impossible After All

headline: Swedish Bombing Suspect’s Drift to Extremism

headline: Modern-Dance History Times Five, With Plenty of Theatricality

The women of the title are Germaine Acogny, Carmen de Lavallade, Dianne McIntyre, Bebe Miller and Jawole Willa Jo Zollar, all contemporary-dance royalty who direct schools and companies. Seeing them on a program together is like going to a female, modern-dance version of those all-star ballet gatherings like “Kings of the Dance.” Only interesting.

headline: Football Dominates Sunday Night Again
text: The Philadelphia Eagles-Dallas Cowboys game delivered this year’s highest ratings for “Sunday Night Football” on NBC. Nielsen’s preliminary overnight estimates for the game were slightly higher than those for this season’s first Sunday-night game, which drew 25.3 million viewers. CBS ranked second, benefiting partly from its own football coverage: an overrun of its afternoon games drew more than 20 million viewers in the first half-hour of prime time. CBS’s “60 Minutes” drew approximately 17.2 million viewers while the season finale of “The Amazing Race” garnered 11.7 million. ABC was third with new episodes of “Desperate Housewives” at 9 (11.5 million) and “Brothers & Sisters” at 10 (8.8 million). Fox finished fourth with new episodes of its comedy lineup.

headline: Computer vs. ‘Jeopardy’ Stars

Watson Sr., is almost ready for a televised test: a bout of questioning on the quiz show “Jeopardy!” I.B.M. and the producers of “Jeopardy!” will announce on Tuesday that the computer, Watson, will face the two most successful players in “Jeopardy!” history, Ken Jennings and Brad Rutter, in three episodes that will be broadcast the week of Feb. 14. One million dollars will be on the line; if Watson wins, the money will be donated to charity. “Jeopardy!” producers said the computer qualified for the show by passing the same test that human contestants must pass.

text: In today’s 18 and Under column, Dr. Perri Klass, a pediatrician, explains that attention deficit problems are complex and often misunderstood. She writes:

headline: Killings of Afghan Relief Workers Stir Debate
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  At least 100 relief workers in Afghanistan have been killed so far this year, far more than in any previous year, prompting a debate within humanitarian organizations about whether American military strategy is putting them and the Afghans they serve at unnecessary risk.

headline: A Second Look at Estrogen’s Benefits
text: In recent years, women have heard only bad news about the menopause hormones estrogen and progestin, which have been linked to higher rates of breast cancer and other illness.

headline: Tax Breaks Bring Hope for Hiring
text: To many manufacturing companies, the tax cut proposal now being considered in Washington may be just enough to spur additional spending and hiring.

headline: Execution 150 Years Ago Spurs Calls for Pardon
text: MANKATO, Minn.  On Dec. 26, 1862, thirty-eight doomed Dakota Indians wailed and danced atop the gallows, waiting for the trapdoors to drop beneath them. The square scaffold, built here to accommodate the largest mass execution in United States history, swayed under their weight.

headline: A Detailed Look at Indian Point’s Environmental Effects
text: More than 90 percent of the striped bass that hit the protective screens in the Indian Point nuclear plant’s cooling system survive, but only 38 percent of the alewives do, according to a new environmental impact statement prepared by the Nuclear Regulatory Commission.

headline: Piracy Fight Shuts Down Music Blogs
text: Thanksgiving Day had barely begun when Kevin Hofman’s BlackBerry buzzed. It was one of the technical operators of OnSmash.com, Mr. Hofman’s popular hip-hop blog, telling him that the site had gone mysteriously blank just after midnight.

headline: Strong American Voice in Diplomacy and Crisis
text: Richard C. Holbrooke, the Obama administration’s special representative for Afghanistan and Pakistan since 2009 and a diplomatic troubleshooter who worked for every Democratic president since the late 1960s and oversaw the negotiations that ended the war in Bosnia, died Monday evening in Washington. He was 69 and lived in Manhattan.

headline: In a Single-Cell Predator, Clues to the Animal Kingdom’s Birth
text: The Environmental Protection Agency is worried about a lot of things in our water — polychlorinated biphenyls, dibromochloropropane, Cryptosporidium parvum — to name just a few of the dozens of chemicals or organisms they monitor. However, in nearly every creek and lake, and throughout the oceans, there is one important group of multisyllabic microbes that the E.P.A. does not track, and until recently, most biologists heard and knew very little about — the choanoflagellates.

headline: Jets Suspend Alosi for Tripping Player
text: After spending Monday afternoon engaged in damage control, an art they have practiced with relatively high frequency this season, the Jets punished their strength and conditioning coach, Sal Alosi, for tripping an opposing player on the sidelines during Sunday’s 10-6 loss to the Miami Dolphins.

headline: Israel’s Arabs and Jews, United by Flames
text: EIN HOD, Israel  The flames encircled Ed Sernoff’s house in this Israeli artists’ village in the Carmel hills near the northern port city of Haifa, licking a corner of the stone structure and cracking a window but otherwise leaving it intact. A small child’s playhouse survived in the middle of the mostly charred garden, but the chalet-style home that Mr. Sernoff’s son had built next door was destroyed.

headline: Atheist Ads on Buses Rattle Fort Worth
text: FORT WORTH  Stand on a corner in this city and you might get a case of theological whiplash.

headline: Harlem Hospital Doctors Threaten to Strike
text: Doctors at Harlem Hospital are threatening to strike over issues arising from the city’s decision to loosen the hospital’s ties with Columbia University, union officials said Monday.

headline: The Room Is Booked, Until the Hotel Says It Isn’t
text: When is a confirmed hotel reservation not confirmed? When the hotel has sold your room to someone else, as Linda and Michael Morgan learned over the Thanksgiving holiday.

headline: From the Delta to Winter’s Deep Blues
text: CREEDE, Colo.  Mary Jean Wallace has a stockpile of wood and a caulking gun to patch the drafty walls in the barely winterized cabin that she will be living in through her first winter in the Rocky Mountains. The wardrobe of her old life in Louisiana was tossed aside this fall  linen giving way to flannel, flip-flops to fleece.

headline: At Aqueduct, More Bettors, but Little Sense of Life
text: With the failed bookie operation known as the New York City Off-Track Betting Corporation forced to shut its doors, the numbers of horse players trooping to Aqueduct racetrack have swelled. It’s a whole new world for the OTB crowd. Instead of hanging out in dreary parlors rank with the air of crushed hopes and misplaced dreams, they can hang out at a race course rank with the air of crushed hopes and misplaced dreams.

headline: The Human Incubator
text: Sometimes, the best way to progress isn’t to advance — to step up with more money, more technology, more modernity. It’s to retreat.

headline: A Key Figure in the Future of Yahoo
text: “I shouldn’t make a comment on that,” said Masayoshi Son, the usually voluble serial entrepreneur who is one of the richest men in Japan. “It’s too delicate a question. Too sensitive right now.”

headline: Iraq: 4 Killed at Shiite Observance
text: Four people were killed and more than a dozen were wounded Monday in attacks on three groups of Shiite Muslims observing the religious holiday of Ashura. In the worst attack, a suicide bomber struck the end of a procession in Diyala Province, killing 4 people and wounding 15, mostly women. In Baghdad, a roadside bomb exploded near a procession, wounding four, and three others were hurt in a blast near a Shiite mosque. For several years, largely Sunni insurgent groups have attacked Shiites during the holiday, which commemorates the centuries-old death of a revered imam.

headline: France: Boy Held in Hostage-Taking
text: The police on Monday arrested a teenager armed with two swords who had held 20 children hostage at a nursery school in the eastern city of Besançon, the Interior Ministry said. The 17-year-old hostage-taker was described as “more depressed or even suicidal than dangerous,” said Laurent Gresset, the regional secretary of the police union Alliance. After hours of negotiations, Mr. Gresset said, the police entered the school quietly and shot the youth with a stun gun, then arrested him.

headline: Contrite Jets Suspend Coach After Sideline Trip of Dolphin
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  Minutes before the Jets’ strength coach, Sal Alosi, expressed remorse Monday for purposely tripping an opponent on the sideline during a game the day before, Dicky Maegle answered his telephone in Katy, Tex.

headline: France: Veiled Driver’s Fine Rescinded
text: A court in Nantes threw out a $30 fine on Monday that had been imposed on a woman who wore an Islamic veil while driving in April. The court ruled that the veil moved with the driver’s head and did not obstruct her vision. The fine created a furor in France, which has approved a ban on similar veils that goes into effect next spring; the driver, Sandrine Mouleres, 31, is a Muslim convert who has written a controversial autobiography. Also on Monday, a court upheld the firing for insubordination of an employee of a day care center, Baby Loup, in Chanteloup-les-Vignes, for refusing to remove her veil.

headline: Anthropology Group Tries to Soothe Tempers After Dropping the Word ‘Science’
text: The battle of the anthropologists  those who hew closely to scientific tradition versus those who take a more humanistic approach  flared again Monday, as the organization that represents both sides tried to patch things up.

headline: A Career in Diplomacy
text: Richard C. Holbrooke’s career spanned decades, continents and Democratic administrations.

headline: Workers’ Safeguards Strengthened by N.Y. Law
text: Gov. David A. Paterson signed into law some of the nation’s strongest protections against wage theft on Monday, after months of lobbying by immigrants’ advocates and labor unions that said New York lagged behind other states on the issue.

headline: Sudan: Vote Called Off on Fate of Town
text: The Obama administration’s special envoy to Sudan said Monday that a referendum on the future of the oil-rich town of Abyei would not be held on Jan. 9 as scheduled. The envoy, J. Scott Gration, left, said that too many questions on this “difficult and emotional issue” remain to be resolved, but President Omar Hassan al-Bashir of Sudan and Vice President Salva Kiir from southern Sudan are trying to find a political solution over the disputed border town by that date. A separate referendum on southern Sudan’s independence seems to be on track for the Jan. 9 deadline, he said. The United States has appointed another ambassador, Dane Smith, to concentrate on resolving the conflict in Darfur in western Sudan, Mr. Gration said.

headline: Steele Seeks Second Term to Run G.O.P.
text: In the face of overwhelming criticism about his stewardship of the Republican National Committee, Michael Steele, the party chairman, declared Monday evening that he has no intentions of quietly stepping aside and vowed to seek re-election to lead the party into the 2012 presidential campaign.

headline: Overcoming Difficulties, One by One, With a Little Aid
text: When Melissa Razick was 7 months old, doctors told her mother that she would never speak, but her mother did not believe them.

headline: Panel Set to Study Safety of Electronic Patient Data
text: Almost two years ago, President Obama pledged $19 billion in stimulus incentives to help convert the nation’s doctors and hospitals to using a paperless system of electronic health records intended to improve the quality of care and reduce costs. But the conversion is still a slow work in progress.

headline: Warner Brothers Won’t Fight ‘Yogi Bear’ Video Parody
text: A video parody of “Yogi Bear” that’s much darker than your average episode of that vintage Hanna-Barbera cartoon – not to mention the coming Warner Brothers film adaptation – isn’t a viral marketing campaign gone awry. But the studio said on Monday that it wouldn’t try to take down the Web satire, either.

headline: Tax-Cut Package Passes Crucial Senate Test
text: WASHINGTON  With robust bipartisan support, the Senate on Monday advanced the tax-cut package negotiated by President Obama and Congressional Republicans, increasing pressure on House Democrats to set aside their opposition.

headline: No Favre, but Lots of Fans in Detroit
text: DETROIT  It was time for strange allegiances and circumstances for Detroit Lions fans on Monday. They gathered at Ford Field to see an N.F.L. game, but it involved the Giants and the Minnesota Vikings.

headline: For New Year’s Eve, the Tie-Ins Erupt
text: SURELY there is no moment when more Americans lock lips than at midnight on Dec. 31, when a kiss marks the New Year, and that is why Nivea Lip Care ties its biggest marketing effort of the year to New Year’s Eve.

headline: Queens Court for Veterans Aims to Help, Not Punish
text: New York City’s second criminal court program tailored to military veterans opened in Queens on Monday, expanding the state’s efforts to provide treatment for defendants who may be struggling to cope with the experiences of war.

headline: How Lincoln Undid the Union
text: On Dec. 11, 1860, with South Carolina’s secession looming, President-elect Abraham Lincoln wrote a letter to Illinois Rep. William Kellogg, a fellow Republican. Publicly, Lincoln was keeping silent on the emerging crisis. But his letter was designed to achieve one objective: to sabotage a sectional compromise to save the Union.

headline: Phillies Come Out of Nowhere in Winning Bid for Lee
text: Nobody wants to be unemployed around the holidays, but Clifton Phifer Lee of Little Rock, Ark., did not seem to mind. The Yankees, the Texas Rangers and, now, the Philadelphia Phillies were eagerly awaiting Lee’s decision on where to continue his career, at $20 million or more per season.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Embattled G.O.P. Chief Is Seeking a Second Term
text: WASHINGTON  In the face of overwhelming criticism about his stewardship of the Republican National Committee, Michael Steele, the party chairman, declared Monday evening that he had no intentions of quietly stepping aside and vowed to seek re-election to lead the party into the 2012 presidential campaign.

headline: Chuck Jordan, Innovative G.M. Designer, Dies at 83
text: Chuck Jordan, a General Motors designer who dreamed up automotive confections dripping with tailfins, chrome and postwar exuberance, then helped reshape the look of G.M. cars as the company grappled with foreign competition and steeper fuel costs, died Thursday at his home in Rancho Santa Fe, Calif. He was 83.

headline: Man Stabbed His Parents, Then Jumped in Front of a Train, the Police Say
text: A 31-year-old man fatally stabbed his mother and critically wounded his father in their Brooklyn home on Monday morning, then jumped into the path of an oncoming subway train, the police said.

headline: Speculators Are Eager to Bet on Madoff Claims
text: The lawsuits filed by the trustee seeking money for Bernard L. Madoff’s fraud victims may be a blow for the defendants — but they are catnip for an obscure breed of Wall Street traders speculating on the outcome of the enormous Madoff bankruptcy case.

headline: Bloggingheads: Socialism U.S.A.?
text: Noam Scheiber, left, of The New Republic and Timothy Carney of the Washington Examiner debate whether Obama's policies are socialistic.

headline: Lombardi Shows Avoid Hornung’s Gambling
text: The gambling that got Green Bay Packers halfback Paul Hornung suspended for the 1963 season was not mentioned in the HBO Sports documentary about Coach Vince Lombardi that premiered last Saturday and is only alluded to in the new Broadway play about Lombardi.

headline: A Hole in Old Routines After OTB Parlors’ Last Day
text: The end looked like this: five old guys sitting around a Chinese bakery, sipping coffee, the hour and minute hands on five wristwatches creeping together at the top of the dial. “It’s about time,” one said, reaching for a cane and falling in behind the others, on oversize physical-therapy shoes, onto Queens Boulevard.

headline: Michelle Paterson Steps Into the Limelight, Briefly
text: The ladies streamed in to the Park Avenue Tavern on Monday for a holiday lunch in honor of Michelle Paige Paterson, a woman who is all but unknown to most of the state.

headline: Man Is Questioned in Shooting of Off-Duty N.Y. Officer
text: A suspect in the shooting of an off-duty New York police officer during a dispute early Sunday was taken into custody Monday in Waterbury, Conn., the New York police said.

headline: As Electoral Ground Shifts, Bloomberg Could Skip the Party
text: On Sunday, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg flatly ruled out an independent run for president in 2012. On Monday, he appeared at the national unveiling in New York of No Labels, a group that aspires to build a grass-roots movement for political independents and independent-minded voters in both parties, and talked again about loosening the grip of both parties on the political process.

headline: Photo Replay: Brett Favre
text: A look at the highlights of Minnesota Vikings quarterback Brett Favre’s career, as his long-standing consecutive-start streak comes to an end.

headline: Amgen Drug Slows Spread of Cancer but Doesn’t Extend Life
text: Amgen’s bone drug denosumab delayed the spread of prostate cancer to bones in a clinical trial, the company said late Monday. However, the drug did not prolong the lives of men.

headline: Richard Holbrooke, RIP
text: I’ve never met an abler diplomat, or a smarter one, than Richard Holbrooke. He was inevitably the brightest guy in the room, and usually the most pragmatic and hardest-working – and he was also a friend whom I admired hugely. His death today is a tremendous loss for all of us who knew him, and for the country as well. Richard never achieved his dream of becoming secretary of state, but he leaves a legacy around the world – from Bosnia to East Timor, from AIDS clinics in South Africa to his legions of followers in the United States – that exceeds that of many Secretaries of State. He was simply a legendary public servant, and an inspiration.

headline: With Their Dome Deflated, the Vikings Still Need a Home
text: MINNEAPOLIS  The deflated roof hung limply inside the Metrodome like a pie crust Monday, and the Minnesota Vikings’ chances of playing next Monday night’s game against the Chicago Bears there may be sagging as well.

headline: 4 Bodies Found Along a Suffolk Road
text: The police in Suffolk County have discovered four bodies over the past three days along Ocean Parkway in Oak Beach.

headline: Should We Pull Back in the Mideast?
text: To the Editor:

headline: New Round of Comments on Drilling
text: Gov. David A. Paterson ordered state environmental officials on Monday to complete revisions to their proposed standards for a controversial type of natural-gas drilling by June and submit them to a new round of public comment.

headline: Darek Braunecker, Agent for Cliff Lee, Is Getting Noticed
text: As the baseball world awaited word on where Cliff Lee was going to pitch next year, the man conducting negotiations on Lee’s behalf was approaching the biggest moment of his professional career.

headline: New Guidelines Make Teacher Tenure Less Automatic in New York City
text: In most schools across the country, tenure is not something to be gained, but something to be lost. Virtually every new teacher earns it, including in New York City, where all a principal has had to do to give a teacher almost guaranteed lifetime employment is to check a box on a computer program.

headline: The Definition of Science
text: To the Editor:

headline: Tuesday: La Liz
text: We have two familiar names making “guest solver” appearances this week. Today, the beloved and prolific constructor Elizabeth Gorski waxes prosaic. Merl Reagle will join us on Saturday.

headline: Years of Wrangling Lie Ahead for Health Care Law
text: By contradicting two prior opinions, Monday’s court ruling in Virginia against the Obama health care law highlighted both the novelty of the constitutional issues and the difficulty of forging consensus among judges who bring differences in experience, philosophy and partisan background to the bench.

headline: Just One Ruling, But an Outsize One
text: WASHINGTON  By the numbers, President Obama is beating opponents of his signature health care bill two to one in federal court. Of the three district court judges who have ruled on the merits of constitutional challenges to the landmark Affordable Care Act, two have sided with Mr. Obama.

headline: Law Will Proceed, Administration Says
text: WASHINGTON  A court decision striking down a central provision of the new health care law will not disrupt efforts to carry it out, even though the ruling could increase confusion and embolden critics, Obama administration officials and employers said Monday.

headline: N.B.A. Players Voting on Step Toward Dissolving Union
text: N.B.A. players are considering dissolution of their union as another means to combat sweeping changes to their labor agreement. The effort may ultimately prove to be more theatrical than substantive.

headline: Giants Defeat Vikings in Detroit
text: The Giants beat Minnesota, 21-3, at Ford Field a day after the roof of the Metrodome in Minneapolis collapsed.

headline: Flashy Goal Is Nothing New for a Rookie
text: N.H.L. players got their first glimpse of why Linus Omark has been dazzling European hockey fans for years, and his flamboyant style has been ridiculed by some and embraced by others.

headline: After Months in Limbo, Paterson Aide Charged in Abuse Case Is Fired
text: He got his start as an intern but rose to become one of Gov. David A. Paterson’s most trusted and powerful aides, with a designated room at the Executive Mansion in Albany for overnight stays.

headline: Holocaust, Remembered
text: To the Editor:

headline: Familiar Faces Round Out Mets’ Coaching Staff
text: The Mets announced their major league coaching staff Monday, adding Ken Oberkfell as bench coach and the former Oakland Athletics hitting coach Dave Hudgens as hitting coach. They also announced they were bringing back Mookie Wilson as first-base coach and replacing the bullpen coach Randy Niemann with Jon Debus, an old colleague of Manager Terry Collins’s from their days with the Dodgers and in the Japanese league.

headline: Development Costs Imperil San Francisco’s Cup Bid
text: The organizers of the next America’s Cup said they would accelerate negotiations with other potential hosts for the next event if San Francisco’s board of supervisors does not amend its proposal, which will be voted on Tuesday.

headline: The Obama Health Care Law: Legal and Political Opposition
text: More than 20 legal challenges were mounted against some aspect of the sweeping health law, with the individual coverage requirements fueling a constitutional battle.

headline: A U.N. Plan for Israel
text: The bloggerAndrew Sullivan has called America’s policy toward Israel “assisted suicide.” That may be an exaggeration, but on Friday it became less of one. The occasion was a speech by Hillary Clinton, much anticipated after the collapse of talks between Israelis and Palestinians.

headline: Ben Franklin’s Nation
text: After you read this column, go to YouTube and search “Hans Rosling and 200 countries.” You’ll see a Swedish professor describe the growth of global wealth and well-being over the past 200 years.

headline: Adding Fairness to the Tip
text: BESIDES being major names in the culinary world, what do Lidia Bastianich, Mario Batali, Tom Colicchio, Bobby Flay, Danny Meyer, Keith McNally, Drew Nieporent, Jean-Georges Vongerichten and Michael White have in common? In recent years, their restaurants have been caught up in a wave of lawsuits  almost all class action  alleging violations of labor laws regarding wages and overtime. And new suits are being filed almost daily. What’s behind this onslaught?

headline: What Ike Got Right
text: LAST week the National Archives released a trove of drafts and notes that shed new light on President Dwight D. Eisenhower’s farewell address, in which he warned America about the “military-industrial complex.”

headline: Corrections
text: EDITORS' NOTE

headline: College, Jobs and Inequality
text: Searching for solace in bleak unemployment numbers, policy makers and commentators often cite the relatively low joblessness among college graduates, which is currently 5.1 percent compared with 10 percent for high school graduates and an overall jobless rate of 9.8 percent. Ben Bernanke, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, cited the data recently on “60 Minutes” to make the point that “educational differences” are a root cause of income inequality.

headline: The Latest Health Care Decision
text: It was no great surprise that a federal district judge in Virginia, nominated by President George W. Bush, declared a provision of the health care reform law unconstitutional. Yet his decision offers at least some hope for health care reform because it bends over backward to limit the scope of his ruling in two important respects.

headline: Congress and the Court
text: David Henderson was discharged from the military in 1952 after two years of duty in Korea when he was diagnosed with paranoid schizophrenia. He received a disability rating of 100 percent and full benefits. Almost 50 years later, he filed a claim for added coverage of in-home care. The Department of Veterans Affairs denied it. He appealed  15 days after the statutory 120-day period for his appeal had ended.

headline: Sweden’s Near Miss
text: No country is immune from terrorism in today’s world, not even Sweden, with its unusually open society, traditional commitment to peace and wariness of military alliances.

headline: Panel Is Critical of Obama Mortgage Modification Plan
text: The Treasury Department’s loan modification program, which has been criticized as ineffective almost since its inception, came in for another battering in a Congressional report released Tuesday.

headline: Word of the Day | ethnology
text: ethnology •\eth-ˈnä-lə-je\• noun

headline: Giants’ Weekend Trip and Favre’s Streak Are Over
text: When the Giants were stranded Saturday in Kansas City, Mo., they tried everything to keep themselves amused. They had the rookies sing, they played electronic games, they held meetings and walk-throughs in ballrooms usually reserved for corporate luncheons and family gatherings.

headline: Finally on a Field, the Giants Get the Job Done
text: DETROIT  The Minnesota Vikings had to do without a lot Monday night.

headline: I.B.M. Supercomputer ‘Watson’ to Challenge ‘Jeopardy’ Stars
text: An I.B.M. supercomputer system named after the company’s founder, Thomas J. Watson Sr., is almost ready for a televised test: a bout of questioning on the quiz show “Jeopardy.”

headline: Lee Agrees to Return to Phillies
text: Cliff Lee, the biggest name on the free-agent market this off-season, agreed on Monday night to return to the Philadelphia Phillies, spurning more money and contract years from the Yankees, according to a person in baseball with knowledge of the negotiations.

headline: America’s Cup Threatens Move
text: The organizers of the next America’s Cup said they would accelerate negotiations with other potential hosts for the next event if San Francisco’s board of supervisors does not amend its proposal, which will be voted on Tuesday. The threat came after a flurry of proposals and counter proposals during the past week that call broadly for the Cup organizers to spend tens of millions of dollars to repair part of the San Francisco waterfront in return for development rights there after the event concludes in 2013. The organizers and the city, though, are in a dispute about how much should be spent on the repairs and by whom; what property the developers can develop; and other matters.

headline: Cliff Lee Accepts Late Bid by the Phillies
text: All along, the Yankees knew they were fighting the Texas Rangers for Cliff Lee. But they also had a sense of dread, a feeling that a stealth team might steal the latest pitcher of their dreams. They had reason to be worried.

headline: Giants Running Headlong Toward Eagles
text: The best news for the Giants on Monday night, other than the fact that they can finally go home, is that their running game appears to be in top form heading into Sunday’s showdown against the Philadelphia Eagles.

headline: McCartney Plays Apollo, His ‘Holy Grail’
text: Paul McCartney played the Apollo on Monday and was demonstrably proud to do so. “It’s the holy grail,” he muttered early in the set. “I dreamed of playing here for many a year.” Then he touched the Lucky Log, the hunk of elm that’s long been placed onstage as a charm for the theater’s Amateur Night performers.

headline: News Quiz | December 14, 2010
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper.

headline: Jacob Lateiner, Pianist and Scholar, Dies at 82
text: Jacob Lateiner, a concert pianist renowned for his interpretations both of Beethoven and of 20th-century music, died on Sunday in Manhattan. He was 82 and lived in Manhattan.

headline: News Quiz | December 14, 2010
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper.

headline: South Africa’s World Cup Success Was Boost for Russia and Qatar
text: The formula for selecting a World Cup site was reconfigured because of the successful and entertaining tournament in South Africa this year. And after the surprising (to some) and controversial (to some) choices of Russia and Qatar as hosts of the tournament in 2018 and 2022, there has been a lot of explaining over the selections.

headline: South Africa’s World Cup Success Was Boost for Russia and Qatar
text: The formula for selecting a World Cup site was reconfigured because of the successful and entertaining tournament in South Africa this year. And after the surprising (to some) and controversial (to some) choices of Russia and Qatar as hosts of the tournament in 2018 and 2022, there has been a lot of explaining over the selections.

headline: Deciphering Stoudemire-Nash Split
text: For more than five seasons in Phoenix, Steve Nash and Amar’e Stoudemire renovated the pick-and-roll, the league’s most-often-used play, and created one of the league’s most devastating tandems.

headline: Test Yourself | English, Dec. 14, 2010
text: Test your reading skills with today’s question, created by Danielle Hoagland and Judith McCaffrey at Grammarlogues from the article “In the Wild, a Big Threat to Rangers: Humans.”

headline: Police Say Early Detonation of Bomb Averted Disaster in Sweden
text: STOCKHOLM  Two days after a bomber killed himself and slightly wounded two people in a commercial district here crowded with Christmas shoppers, investigators offered glimpses of a suspect who, in the pattern of other Islamist terrorists, moved unobtrusively between Europe and the Middle East as he prepared to martyr himself, only to botch the operation in a manner that suggested a clumsy do-it-yourself attack.

headline: A Ruling on the Health Care Law
text: WHO ruled that a key provision in the Obama health care law is unconstitutional? WHO filed the case?

headline: Carlyle to Sell ManorCare Real Estate for $6.1 Billion
text: 8:29 p.m. | Updated The Carlyle Group solidified its standing as one of the year’s busiest deal makers this week with an agreement late Monday to sell the real estate of its big nursing home operator, HCR ManorCare, to the real estate investment firm HCP for about $6.1 billion.

headline: Daily Lexeme: Maegbot

headline: Too Painful to Remember, or to Forget
text: One by one, the stories stun and stagger. Children barely old enough for school, raped by the priests who befriended them. Teenagers, invited to sleepovers at the rectory. Seminarians, manipulated and seduced by their confessors.

headline: Is School Stressing You Out?
text: A new documentary film, “Race to Nowhere,” looks at the stresses of school and the pressures to succeed. Do you feel intense pressure to build an impressive résumé or college application? Do your commitments and responsibilities – classes and extracurricular activities – leave you feeling stressed out? How can schools and parents ease the pressure on students?

headline: Release on Bail of WikiLeaks Founder Is Delayed by Appeal
text: LONDON — Julian Assange, the jailed founder of the anti-secrecy group WikiLeaks, was ordered freed on $315,000 bail on Tuesday but remained at least temporarily in custody awaiting a final decision on whether he will be extradited to Sweden over allegations of sexual offenses against two women.

headline: Berlusconi Survives Confidence Vote
text: ROME  Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi narrowly survived two confidence votes on Tuesday, avoiding the collapse of his government but prolonging Italy’s political agony.

headline: Does Economic Inequality Cause Crises?
text: Edward L. Glaeser is an economics professor at Harvard and the author of the forthcoming book “Triumph of the City.”

headline: Seedorf’s Increasingly International Footprint
text: You might think Clarence Seedorf is much older than he is. He has been a professional soccer player at the highest echelons of the game for more than half his life. And his list of accomplishments includes four Champions League winner’s medals with three different teams, the first in 1995 when he was a teenager sprinting through the midfield for Ajax of Amsterdam.

headline: An Artist Once Shunned, Now Celebrated at Istanbul Museum
text: With his first retrospective in Turkey — “The Enemy Inside Me,” which runs through March 6 at the Istanbul Modern — the artist and filmmaker Kutlug Ataman has come full circle.

headline: E.U. States Ready to Back European Central Bank Fund Request
text: Euro zone governments stood ready Tuesday to back contingency plans from the European Central Bank to shore up its reserves against losses from bond purchases.

headline: Goldman Pushes Back on Bear Stearns Charges
text: Goldman Sachs, in a major submission to the Financial Crisis Inquiry Commission, has denied  that it precipitated the collapse of two Bear Stearns hedge funds by lowering the valuation of subprime assets they held.

headline: Russia Approves Road That Will Run Through Forest
text: MOSCOW  Environmentalists on Tuesday appeared to lose a protracted battle to prevent construction of a highway through one of the Moscow region’s last remaining forests, just months after President Dmitri A. Medvedev succumbed to a public outcry and temporarily halted the project.

headline: The Nutcracker Chronicles: Elvis and the Mirlitons
text: MEMPHIS — More American history has taken place in Memphis than I’d realized. I knew a little about the blues and rock ‘n’ roll here – but, though I sharply remember the news of the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr.’s assassination, I’d forgotten it also happened here, at the Lorraine Motel. The Memphis friend who gave me a guided tour of the city’s highlights included that and more in a packed morning itinerary. We also stopped at the Arcade Restaurant, where Elvis used to hang out and where I had prematinee brunch.

headline: How I Saved My Company: Oceanblue Divers
text: The signs began to emerge shortly after Oceanblue Divers celebrated its second anniversary in the fall of 2008 — just as the stock market tanked. As the economy collapsed, travel became a much tougher sell. Twelve people attended the company’s monthly happy hour instead of the usual 80 or 100. Soon, trips that normally attracted 15 to 25 divers were leaving with five to 10.

headline: Industry Group Sees Airline Profits Improving
text: PARIS  Profitability among airlines is improving, propelled by a strong third quarter, especially in the Asia-Pacific region. But the sector is still “fragile” and European carriers in particular remain hamstrung by relatively weak demand, an industry group said Tuesday.

headline: A Few Injury Downers for the Giants in Detroit
text: A quick bad news roundup on an otherwise good night for the Giants:

headline: The Man Who Took On Obama Health Care — and Won One Round
text: Kenneth T. Cuccinelli II, Virginia’s attorney general, is quick to cite the legal basis for challenging President Obama’s signature legislative achievement: Congress has no power to punish people who choose not to buy private health insurance, he says.

headline: BP to Sell Pakistan Assets to Pay for Spill
text: BP said on Tuesday that it would sell Pakistan assets to United Energy Group for $775 million in cash, as it continues to raises money to pay for the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico.

headline: Raid on Islamic Groups in Germany
text: BERLIN  The German Interior Ministry ordered simultaneous raids in three states on Tuesday against what it called Salafist networks suspected of seeking the imposition of an Islamic state. The action signaled growing concern over the radical messages of some Islamic groups.

text: Tuesday will be overcast and cold, with highs in the mid-20s and a decent chance for more snow, so bundle up.

headline: WikiLeaks Founder’s Statement From Prison
text: Julian Assange, the founder of WikiLeaks, denounced Visa, MasterCard and PayPal as “instruments of U.S. foreign policy,” in a statement relayed by his mother to Australian television on Tuesday.

headline: Bond Yields Rise as the Fed Continues Its Buying Program
text: Bond prices fell and stocks were slightly higher on Tuesday after the Federal Reserve said it was continuing its bond purchases because the recovery was continuing at a rate that has been insufficient to lower unemployment.

headline: Pies ‘n’ Thighs Chicken and Biscuits Pop Up in Chinatown
text: The Hester Street Fair in Chinatown was last summer’s destination for artisanal popsicles, snow cones and lobster rolls (and nonedible things like handmade clothing). At the organizers’ Big Social Holiday Market, a pop-up that opens on Friday in the Open House Gallery at 201 Mulberry Street (Kenmare Street), the big draw will be fried-chicken biscuits from Pies ’n’ Thighs in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, the best thing that has ever happened to a boneless chicken breast.

headline: The SPECTRE of Inequality
text: I’m still a couch potato, box of tissues close at hand. So I’m watching stuff my Tivo thought I might want to see, which happened to include the old Bond film Thunderball.

headline: Jay Feely’s Secret Is Out
text: Jay Feely’s 5-yard touchdown run against the Broncos on Sunday — the first touchdown by an N.F.L. kicker since 2001 — was the spark that helped the Cardinals end a  seven-game losing streak. But the play also let him reveal a secret he has been keeping.

headline: Globes Shine on ‘King’s Speech’
text: 10:11 a.m. | Updated  LOS ANGELES— Voters for the 68th annual Golden Globes have circled around “The King’s Speech,” the period drama about George VI, the British king, and the overcoming of his stuttering problem, handing it seven nominations including best drama. Colin Firth (best actor in a drama), Geoffrey Rush (best supporting actor), Helena Bonham Carter (best supporting actress) and Tom Hooper (best director) were among the cited. Other front-runners announced Tuesday morning included “The Fighter” and “The Social Network,” both of which got six nominations, including best drama, best director and best actor. “Inception,” “The Black Swan” and “The Kids are All Right” each received four nominations.

headline: Golden Globe Nominations Are Announced
text: “The King’s Speech,” the film about a stuttering member of the British royal family and the speech therapist who helps him deliver a crucial oration, was the most nominated movie at Tuesday’s announcement of the Golden Globe nominations, receiving seven nods including best dramatic motion picture, as well as nominations for actors Colin Firth, Geoffrey Rush and Helena Bonham Carter, and its director, Tom Hooper. Other films with multiple nominations included “The Social Network,” “Black Swan,” “The Fighter” and “Inception,” which will all vie for best drama at the awards ceremony on Jan. 16.

headline: Morning Take-Out
text: –Found: One Goldman Sachs MasterCard. Each night that Buckley T. Ratchford, a partner at the firm, doesn’t come on Stephen Colbert’s show, one digit of the credit card number will be revealed. Mr. Colbert would like to talk about Wall Street bonuses.

headline: ‘Spider-Man’ Economics: Recouping That Initial Investment
text: “Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark” has made headlines as the most expensive musical in Broadway history. At $65 million, it had an initial budget that is more than twice as big as that of the previous record holder, “Shrek the Musical.” The new show even rivals the cost of many major Hollywood films  — which, given that they can be distributed cheaply worldwide, have a much bigger potential audience than this live show can ever hope for.

headline: ‘Spider-Man’ Economics: Recouping That Initial Investment
text: “Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark” has made headlines as the most expensive musical in Broadway history. At $65 million, it had an initial budget that is more than twice as big as that of the previous record holder, “Shrek the Musical.” The new show even rivals the cost of many major Hollywood films  — which, given that they can be distributed cheaply worldwide, have a much bigger potential audience than this live show can ever hope for.

headline: The Challenge of Selling Yoplait
text: Rarely do one-of-a-kind brands like Yoplait come up for sale. So when the French private equity firm PAI Partners said a few months ago that its 50 percent stake in Yoplait was in play, it came as no surprise that a parade of possible buyers — including well-known companies like Nestlé and PepsiCo — lined up.

headline: Do Vitamins Interfere With Sleep?
text: Millions of Americans take a daily multivitamin, but anecdotal reports have suggested the pills may interfere with sleep. In today’s “Really?” column, Anahad O’Connor takes a look at the research.

headline: Mitt Romney Comes Out Against Tax Deal
text: Mitt Romney, the former governor of Massachusetts, on Tuesday added his voice – and a 2012 flavor – to the growing chorus of Republican discontent with the tax compromise the party’s Congressional leaders reached with President Obama.

headline: Bangladesh Factory Fire Kills at Least 20
text: DHAKA, Bangladesh  A fire at a garment factory north of Dhaka, the capital, killed at least 20 people and injured dozens on Tuesday, in the latest blow to the country’s largest industry.

headline: Following WikiLeaks Founder’s Bail Hearing on Twitter

headline: Actress Thora Birch Fired From ‘Dracula’
text: The producers of the Off Broadway revival of “Dracula” fired their star actress Thora Birch on Friday, four days before the play’s first performance, the production’s director and Ms. Birch said in interviews on Monday. Ms. Birch, a 28-year-old actress, is best known for the films “American Beauty” and “Ghost World,” and was preparing to make her New York stage debut. She said that she was “in a state of shock” over her dismissal and the subsequent order from the producers to leave the theater immediately.

headline: Deferral? Denial? Acceptance? A Daughter Tells Her Story
text: For the past 14 months, I’ve been chronicling my experiences and emotions as my daughter Nicole traveled the exciting and at-times bumpy road of the college admissions process. Today’s column, though, is for Nicole to write. –Caren Osten Gerszberg

headline: Tuesday Reading: The Latest on the Health Care Law
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: Rock Fame: Won, Lost and Re-enacted
text: Twenty-five years ago, Dee Snider had the kind of success that most rock ’n’ roll performers only dream of: million-selling records, sold-out concerts and an image bad enough to get him invited to testify before a Congressional committee investigating sex and violence on the nation’s airwaves. (He wore his incisor teeth sharpened to the hearing.)

headline: Duchene Rewards Colorado’s Faith
text: Matt Duchene wore the gleeful grin of a teenager when the Colorado Avalanche selected the 18-year-old with the third overall pick in the 2009 N.H.L. Draft. He meant no disrespect to the teams that drafted before Colorado: the New York Islanders first and then the Tampa Bay Lightning. It was just that, as a kid growing up in Ontario, Duchene worshiped Joe Sakic and the Avalanche.

headline: Dublin Blocks Bank Bonus Payments
text: LONDON  Allied Irish Banks, the lender that is being bailed out by the government, has decided not to award senior staff about 40 million euros ($53 million) in bonuses for 2008 after the country’s finance ministry intervened late Monday.

headline: Oh, That’s Why It Seemed Familiar

headline: Recouping the Cost of ‘Spider-Man’
text: As the budget for the Broadway musical “Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark” has ballooned to a record-breaking $65 million, the conventional wisdom has been that the show would need to run for four years before it made back that initial investment. Where did that figure come from? At the Economix blog, Catherine Rampell performs some impressive, Peter Parker-esque calculations to show why the musical is unlikely to turn a profit before 2014, unless it gets bitten by a radioactive pile of money.

headline: The Phillies Are Now the Hunted
text: It is going to take awhile to think about the Phillies as the overlords of baseball, the team that can outspend and outrecruit all of the others.

headline: Mary Lynn Rajskub Turns Back the Clock on ’24’
text: Until its clock ran out in May, the Fox thriller “24” told the real-time, minute-by-minute story of one person from a shadowy government agency doing whatever it takes to keep the nation safe from evildoers and sinister global conspiracies. And that person was Chloe O’Brian, the dour, dry-witted computer expert played by Mary Lynn Rajskub, who each week provided invaluable support to Jack Bauer, the Counter-Terrorism Unit (C.T.U.) field agent played by Kiefer Sutherland. (Your perspective on the series and its heroes and sidekicks may vary, of course.)

text: Thanks to all who read and commented on my recent Stone post, “Out of Our Brains.” Lots of interesting, challenging, and important issues were raised, but I’d like to react very briefly to just a few recurring themes, and to add one important, and accidentally omitted, note of thanks.

headline: Park Slope Plane Crash | How It Happened

headline: Stranded: A Photo Collection of Breakdowns

headline: The Uncanny Ouch-Man: Hugh Jackman Hurt Taping ‘Oprah’ Stunt
text: Though he’s better known for his portrayal of the comic-book hero Wolverine, Hugh Jackman might as well have been rehearsing for a role in the “Spider-Man” musical when a stunt he was taping for “The Oprah Winfrey Show” went wrong on Tuesday. Mr. Jackman, who is one of several Australian celebrities being filmed at the Sydney Opera House for a series of special episodes called “Oprah’s Ultimate Australian Adventure,” was zipping onto the set while suspended in a wire harness device called a flying fox, but at the end of his speedy trip collided with a lighting rig suspended above the stage. The Press Association said Mr. Jackman was bleeding from his right eye as he was removed from the rigging, and taping was halted for about 10 minutes while he received medical treatment (and a glass of red wine), but the actor returned to the set with a black eye and bandages to finish his interview. “That was so much fun until the end,” Mr. Jackman said.

headline: Just One Look | Zac Posen Pre-Fall Collection
text: The Pre-Fall Collections, being shown in New York over the next several weeks, arrive in stores in May to fill the gap between bikinis and furs.Zac Posen has been looking at the work of the interior designer Madeleine Castaing who is the subject of a lush tome, The World of Madeleine Castaing, from Rizzoli. This was evident in upholstery-inspired fabrics, bits of fringe and Roman-shade like draping of the some of the more artfully engineered pieces that Posen turned out for Pre-Fall. (A laser cut leather dress with bouclé inserts cuts a bombshell figure.) But another muse made a cameo appearance in the collection: Tina Turner, the designer’s 7 year-old poodle. That is her face, in silhouette, on the sweater that anchors one of our favorite looks.

headline: Hitchens and the Paranoid Center
text: I see that Christopher Hitchens has followed in Ron Rosenbaum’s footsteps and angrily denounced “rational conservatives” (namely, me) for failing to offer adequate resistance to Tea Party paranoia and conspiracy theorizing, and for daring to hope that some good — i.e. a renewed seriousness about deficit spending — might come of the right-wing uprising. After a whirlwind tour of Glenn Beck’s more lunatic forays, Hitchens concludes:

headline: Does China Face a ‘Peak Coal’ Threat?
text: China’s ravenous appetite for energy puts the country at risk of reaching a point of  “peak coal,” when demand for coal will outstrip domestic production capacity, a growing number of experts believe.

headline: Wanted: More Girls on Screen
text: You don’t watch movies the same way after you have children, because you see the screen through their eyes. That is true, apparently, for the stars who create those movies in the first place.

headline: Big Appliances Put Out as Trash Are Vanishing, Puzzling the City
text: Over the last several months, 22,741 New Yorkers contacted the city’s Department of Sanitation and arranged for the pickup of refrigerators, air-conditioners and freezers. In more than 11,000 instances, the machines vanished before sanitation workers arrived in their white trucks to pick them up.

headline: Just in Time for the Holidays: Cage Against the Machine
text: The musicians crowded into a London studio, dozens of them, to record a song for charity. Waiting for their cue, they held guitars and drumsticks, and stood at attention by the microphones. Then the producer gave the count: “Quiet in the studio: one, two …”

headline: Video of Unrest on Rome’s Streets After Berlusconi Wins Vote
text: Updated | 3:43 p.m. Following a narrow vote of confidence in Italy’s Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi from the Italian Parliament on Tuesday, protesters on Rome’s streets — demonstrating against austerity measures and a variety of government failings — clashed with police and set cars on fire in several parts of the city. Dramatic images and video of the anger on the streets was posted online by witnesses to the unrest.

text: Monitoring a man’s response to pornography as a means of establishing his sexuality.

headline: 1935 Pricing at the Frick for a Day: No Charge

headline: Immigrants Make Paths to Suburbia, Not Cities
text: WASHINGTON — Immigrants fanned out across the United States in the last decade, settling in greater numbers in small towns and suburbs rather than in the cities where they typically moved when they first came to this country, new census data show.

headline: E.M.S. Puts Itself in Play
text: The Emergency Medical Services Corporation announced on Tuesday that it was “reviewing various strategic alternatives to enhance stockholder value.” Its shares jumped nearly 19 percent.

headline: Ebb Foundation Donates $1 Million to Broadway Cares
text: The Fred Ebb Foundation has given Broadway Cares/Equity Fights AIDS a gift of $1 million, the largest donation in the organization’s history. The contribution is to be announced on Tuesday.

headline: Ram and Sienna Recalled for Brake Problems
text: Brake-related problems have caused Chrysler to recall about 76,000 of its 2010–11 Rams and Toyota to recall about 94,000 2011 Sienna minivans.

headline: U.S. Concludes N. Korea Has More Nuclear Sites
text: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration has concluded that North Korea’s new plant to enrich nuclear fuel uses technology that is “significantly more advanced” than what Iran has struggled over two decades to assemble, according to senior administration and intelligence officials.

text: My family and I will be in Paris on New Year’s Eve. We’re having a hard time finding a moderately priced restaurant around the Trocadéro or the Eiffel Tower. Or do you suggest we look in some other arrondissement?

headline: Illinois Mayor Is Found Dead in His Home
text: CHICAGO  The state police are investigating the death of the mayor of Springfield, Ill, whose body was found at home early Tuesday morning on a day he was supposed to appear in court to answer a lawsuit.

headline: A Return to Film, and an Introduction to the Red Carpet
text: Riding a little wave of critical love, the Australian actress Jacki Weaver won a Golden Globe best supporting actress nod for the thriller “Animal Kingdom” – her first movie role in 12 years. Ms. Weaver, at home in Australia doing “Uncle Vanya” with Cate Blanchett with the Sydney Theater Company, heard the news in the wee hours of the morning, she told the Baguette (a.k.a Paula Schwartz), and popped open some bubbly to celebrate with her husband. “We figured we deserved French Champagne,” she said.

headline: Hanukkah for Economists

headline: First Look | Lulu Frost for J.Crew
text: “Who doesn’t love jewelry?” asks Marissa Webb, the head of women’s design at J. Crew. “Jewelry is the perfect accessory to dress up or down any look or add a girly element to a more utilitarian, rugged look.” Building on the success of previous guest collections by designers like Fenton Fallon and Miriam Haskell, J. Crew sought out Lisa Salzer of Lulu Frost for the next collaboration on its list. (“I’m a huge Lulu Frost fan and even have pieces stashed in my purse for a fashion emergency,” Webb confesses.) Known for her estate piece aesthetic, Salzer and her team put a vintage twist on modern designs — 10k gold necklaces, bracelets and earrings with handmade chains and antique glass crystals. The pieces are available just in time for the holidays — not to mention all of those holiday parties.

headline: The 99ers Are Coming
text: As Michael Powell wrote last week, President Obama’s compromise with Republicans may keep the existing 99-week structure of unemployment in place, but it does nothing to help those Americans who are, or will become, unemployed beyond 99 weeks.

headline: Memorable Moments From Hockey’s Shootouts
text: The Oilers rookie Linus Omark had the hockey world talking shootout again this week, thanks to a creative attempt against Tampa Bay. The move resulted in the game-winning goal, as well as some vocal complaints from Lightning players who thought it was excessive.

headline: Stranded Drivers Rescued in Canada
text: OTTAWA  Even in a country that prides itself at shrugging off winter, it was an exceptional storm. Several hundred drivers spent more than 24 hours stranded in their cars and trucks snowbound a major Ontario highway before the police and military rescuers extricated them on Tuesday.

headline: The Voices of Hepatitis
text: One in 20 people will come into contact with hepatitis virus at some point, but fortunately, only a small percentage develop a lasting case of the disease. Still, millions suffer from a chronic form of hepatitis.

headline: A Portrait of New York in Numbers
text: How has your community changed since 2000? How many immigrants are there? And where have they come from? How much do your neighbors earn? What kind of jobs do they do? How many single women live around you? How about single men?

headline: The Nutcracker Chronicles: Booker T Meets Tchaikovsky
text: MEMPHIS — The Orpheum, where Ballet Memphis played “The Nutcracker” over the weekend, stands at the end of Beale Street, once the hub of the blues. So after the matinee, this is where I continued my Memphis tourism. Different brands of music pour out of almost every building, and here is A. Schwab, founded in 1876, choc-a-bloc with voodoo items and tourist knickknacks; I bought an Elvis fridge magnet.

headline: France Says Google May Have Misused Its Search Advantage
