headline: Mullen Expresses Impatience With Pakistan on Visit
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  America’s top military officer visited Pakistan’s capital on Tuesday, carrying what he called a strong sense of “strategic impatience” with the government here over its failure to clear insurgents from border havens where they prepare lethal attacks against American and allied forces in Afghanistan.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Afghanistan and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Afghanistan, Italy and Gaza.

headline: Swiss Banker Is Accused of Advising Americans to Evade Taxes
text: Federal prosecutors on Tuesday accused a former UBS banker of advising wealthy American clients to avoid disclosing their hidden offshore accounts held at a smaller Swiss bank because they were unlikely to attract scrutiny from the United States tax authorities.

headline: Juan Williams Signs Two-Book Deal With Crown
text: Since his contract as a senior news analyst at NPR was terminated in October, Juan Williams has found no shortage of platforms from which he can express himself. In addition to the new contract he signed with the Fox News Channel, amid a dispute over remarks he made on “The O’Reilly Factor,” he has now entered into a two-book deal with the Crown Publishers imprint of the Crown Publishing Group at Random House, the imprint said on Tuesday.

headline: Senate to Pick Up Its Pace
text: After weeks of slow and often-stalled action dealing with just one bill at a time, the Senate is going to try a change of pace.

headline: Great Bankruptcy Boom Is Fading
text: The bankruptcy of the Great Atlantic & Pacific Tea Company, with some $2.5 billion in assets, hardly would have registered on the Richter scale of troubled companies in 2009. This year it’s one of the largest — a shift that reflects the improving fortunes of the credit markets and the economy.

headline: Now Reading | Colors on Collectors
text: The winter 2010-11 issue of Colors, which is out on Wednesday, marks its 20th anniversary.

headline: Heat Coach Fills Defense With Incentives
text: Though the Miami Heat has one of the N.B.A.’s top five offenses, it has yet to unlock its full potential. For whatever reason, the magical formula with which LeBron James, Dwyane Wade and Chris Bosh can truly be unleashed has eluded the team’s brain trust.

headline: Fed Goes Ahead With Bond Plan
text: WASHINGTON  The Federal Reserve, batting away unusually fierce criticisms, forged ahead on Tuesday with its effort to prop up the economic recovery by buying $600 billion in Treasury bonds.

headline: Swedish Prosecutor Raises Possible Extradition of WikiLeaks Founder to U.S.
text: Updated | 6:11 p.m. A Swedish prosecutor raised the possibility that Julian Assange, the founder of WikiLeaks, could eventually be extradited to the United States in a statement posted online on Tuesday.

headline: House Democrats to Make Final Push on ‘Don’t Ask, Don’t Tell’
text: House Democratic leaders have decided to make one last push to repeal the military’s ban on gays serving openly before the end of the lame-duck Congress.

headline: Photo Replay: Dec. 14
text: A view of the day in sports, including women’s luge in Utah.

headline: Cashman Emphasizes Patience After Lee Gets Away
text: The Yankees are not expected to make any drastic moves in an attempt to address their starting pitching needs after failing to sign their prime free-agent target, the ace starter Cliff Lee, General Manager Brian Cashman said.

headline: BMW Names New Head of Exterior Design
text: Karim Habib, the designer behind the BMW 7 Series and 2007 Concept CS, is returning to the brand after defecting in March 2009 to Mercedes-Benz. Mr. Habib, 39, will become head of exterior design, succeeding Anders Warming, who left to lead design efforts at Mini.

headline: Union Chief Pays a Visit to the Knicks
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — With N.B.A. players taking the preliminary step of voting for the dissolution of their union to combat a lockout, Billy Hunter, the executive director of the National Basketball Players Association, visited the Knicks on Tuesday and called the likelihood of decertification “pretty far off.”

headline: How to Unlike Pages on Facebook
text: Facebook makes it easy to become a fan of people, bands and random brands by clicking the Like button at the tops of their pages. These pages show up in the Likes and Interests section of your own profile. Facebook shows three of your likes at random every time someone looks at your profile.

headline: On Our Radar: Chernobyl to Open to Tourists
text: Ukraine will open the sealed zone around the doomed Chernobyl nuclear reactor to visitors beginning next year, the country’s Emergency Situations Ministry declared. The nuclear reactor exploded nearly 25 years ago, killing dozens and spreading radioactivity across Europe. A spokeswoman for the Ukrainian agency says the tour will be medically safe and will be “positive in conveying very important messages.” [Associated Press]

headline: A ‘Control Freak’ Finds a Way to Expand
text: Almost a year ago, we published a small-business case study that weighed the potential pros and cons of geographic expansion for Thinking Caps Tutoring, a company that offers study skills coaching, subject tutoring and test preparation to middle- and high-school students in the New York area. Alexandra Mayzler, who founded Thinking Caps and who described herself as a “control freak,” feared the quality of her highly personalized services would suffer if she expanded hastily. But she also said she wanted to build an enduring “stand-alone brand, not an Alexandra brand.”

headline: The Taliban Remembers an American Envoy
text: The Taliban statement on the death of Richard C. Holbrooke, the chief American envoy to the region, carried a dignified, almost somber tone. It seems they took him seriously, as they do all enemies and as Mr. Holbrooke took them.

headline: Cowen’s Counsel of Despair
text: Tyler Cowen’s essay in the latest American Interest is nominally about income inequality, but really it’s about the pernicious role that big finance plays in modern political economy. Cowen isn’t worried about inequality per se, but he is worried about the forces that give rise to it, and specifically the boom-bust cycle of Wall Street investment — and more specifically still, the way the “bust” part of the cycle tends to make taxpayers suffer more than the Wall Street investors themselves, thus incentivizing further recklessness and still worse crack-ups down the road:

headline: To Think, Perchance to … Debating the Dream Act
text: December 15, 2010, 10:10 a.m. | Updated Overview | What difficulties do undocumented immigrant children face when it comes time for them to go to college? What are the pros and cons of the legislation that has been proposed to address these difficulties? In this lesson, students engage in a roundtable debate on the Dream Act and will then write a letter to their United States senators either supporting or opposing the legislation.

headline: Icahn Loses Bid for Lions Gate Seats
text: Shareholders of Lions Gate Entertainment, the TV and movie studio, elected all of the company’s nominees to the board on Tuesday, dealing a blow to Carl C. Icahn.

headline: Nielsen Drops Its Radio Ratings Service
text: The Nielsen Company has ended its two-year experiment in radio ratings.

headline: Matthew Kenney Restaurant Gets Even More Peruvian
text: Bar Paya Menu

headline: Hello, Patti: What’s Next for La LuPone?
text: Even as a supporting character in the Broadway musical “Women on the Verge of a Nervous Breakdown” Patti LuPone is letting her diva flag fly as the scorned wife and domineering mother Lucia. What next for La LuPone after “Women” closes on Jan. 23? Among the projects that the two-time Tony Award winner (“Gypsy,” “Evita,”) is considering is a return to the center-stage spotlight as another diva, the title character in the musical “Hello, Dolly!”

headline: Family Fighting, Golden Globes-Style
text: LOS ANGELES— As the smoke from the Golden Globes nominations starts to clear, the studios behind this year’s contenders are left with an interesting challenge.

headline: The Real Estate Collapse? It’ll Be in the Final
text: In 2008, when most Americans were fleeing the real estate market, David Mann was charging toward it. After selling a clothing manufacturing company in Manhattan that he had helped run, Mr. Mann, 32, decided to pursue a master’s degree in real estate development.

headline: First Look | ManiaMania Spring 2011
text: Some young designers have that golden touch. And when it comes to Melanie Kamsler and Tamila Purvis, the duo behind the aptly named Australian jewelry label ManiaMania, we mean that quite literally. Fans like Devendra Banhart, Erin Wasson and Alexandra Richards are, well, mad for the bohemian pieces with a rock ‘n’ roll edge. “Seeing our pieces on people is still a pretty big deal,” Purvis admits. The model Abbey Lee Kershaw (whose day-to-day look is loaded with mystic metals) recently appeared in the brand’s spring 2011 campaign — further testament to its hip factor.

headline: India and China Cautious On Eve of a State Meeting
text: NEW DELHI  When leaders from the world’s most dynamic major economies get together, how do they plan to discuss their increasing dominance over global growth?

headline: Blatter’s Advice to Gay Soccer Fans Draws Criticism
text: Sepp Blatter has never been shy. But Blatter, the FIFA president, has been garrulous since the executive committee of soccer’s world governing body awarded the 2018 World Cup to Russia and the 2022 edition of the championship to Qatar.

headline: Airgas Judge: See You Next Year
text: If you were an arbitrager in Airgas hoping against the odds that the Delaware Chancery Court would provide a Christmas present, you would likely be disappointed.

headline: Sidestepping the U.S. Dollar, a Russian Exchange Will Swap Rubles and Renminbi
text: MOSCOW  Russia and China are poised to take a small but symbolic step in their expanding economic relationship, a move that in the long term could make the dollar less relevant to business between the two nations.

headline: Crossroads GPS Announces First Post-Election Ad Buy
text: Crossroads GPS, a Republican-friendly advocacy group with ties to Karl Rove, announced its first major post-election expenditure Tuesday — a $400,000 radio ad campaign in 12 districts across the country, urging the House Democrats to call for a vote on the tax-cut package.

headline: Could ‘Extremities’ Bring Katie Holmes Back to Broadway?
text: Katie Holmes is considering starring in a Broadway production of William Mastrosimone’s psychological drama “Extremities,” about a woman who turns the table on her would-be rapist and then struggles along with her two roommates about what to do with him. A spokeswoman for Ms. Holmes, a television and film actress and the wife of Tom Cruise, confirmed that she had been approached about the role; the spokeswoman had no further information. Ms. Holmes made her Broadway debut in 2008 in a revival of “All My Sons.”

headline: Emanuel Testifies in Chicago Residency Challenge
text: CHICAGO – It was a campaign appearance no candidate would wish for, least of all one who knows the ins and outs of political imagery and messaging as well as Rahm Emanuel. Yet there was Mr. Emanuel on Tuesday, seated at the front of a crowded basement meeting room, under oath, answering fierce, pointed questions from people who believe that he should not become mayor of Chicago.

headline: Some in Brooklyn Co-op Oppose Historic District Plan
text: When Glenn Van Bramer’s 25th-floor apartment flooded two days ago, it was not the first time he had to worry about his early-1930s art collection. “Part of our ceiling just began to sag, fill with water,” said Mr. Van Bramer, who has lived in the co-op building, at 75 Livingston Street in Brooklyn, for 12 years.

headline: Federal Money for Alternative Energy Is Drying Up
text: The relationship between the government and renewable energy has always been a close one — but also a difficult one. The relationship is going to get more difficult as stimulus programs and tax cuts run out in two weeks — and that may throw America’s alternative energy programs up in the air.

headline: Honolulu Symphony Shuts Down
text: The Honolulu Symphony has officially gone out of business. A United States Bankruptcy Court judge on Monday approved the orchestra’s liquidation, The Associated Press reported. The orchestra was running out of money and mired in a labor dispute. It stopped performing in October 2009 and filed for reorganization under Chapter 11 of the Bankruptcy Code but asked the court to convert the filing to Chapter 7, liquidation. The symphony said it was founded in 1900 and calls itself the oldest American orchestra west of the Rockies.

headline: ‘The Fighter’ Punches Above Its Weight in Awards Battle
text: When you make a boxing movie, there can be few better fans than Robert De Niro. The Raging Bull himself hosted a party for “The Fighter” at his Tribeca Film Center on Monday night, the director David O. Russell told us. “He said the best thing,” Mr. Russell said from his hotel in New York. “You know, my best compliment is that it was honest. That to me is a lot, coming from a man of few words.”

headline: By Landing Lee, Phillies Make Claim to New Empire
text: Two weeks after the World Series, in the afterglow of the first pennant in franchise history, the Texas Rangers’ top executives flew to Little Rock, Ark., to meet with their ace pitcher, Cliff Lee. The purpose was to emphasize to Lee; his wife, Kristen; and his agent, Darek Braunecker, that the Rangers were serious about keeping him.

headline: FrontPoint Fires Health Care Team
text: FrontPoint Partners — a hedge fund firm hit with $3 billion worth of redemptions — fired its 12-person health care team in the weeks after the group was ensnared by an insider trading case in early November, according to a person with knowledge of the situation who spoke on the condition of anonymity.

headline: Just One Look | Vera Wang Pre-Fall Collection
text: The Pre-Fall Collections, being shown in New York over the next several weeks, arrive in stores in May to fill the gap between bikinis and furs.For Pre-Fall, Vera Wang was thinking back to school — in a manner of speaking. The designer, who went to Chapin, recalls having to wear a mint green shirt and a dark green skirt of indeterminate fabric content and flat shoes. This look has the colors and the components of a typical school uniform — the gray skirt, the “knee socks,” the crest — but all grown up. “My fantasy school uniform,” Wang says.

headline: How to Avoid Tow Truck Scams
text: From our colleagues at Bucks:

headline: Westerly, R.I., Waits for Its Development Angel
text: WESTERLY, R.I.  The mutual fund investor Charles M. Royce has spent millions buying and redeveloping properties in this waterfront town on the Connecticut border  his way, associates say, of strengthening a community where he has summered for many years. His biggest venture by far is Ocean House, a $140 million hotel, resort and condominium that opened last summer in the moneyed enclave of Watch Hill.

headline: Howard Sherman, Executive Director of American Theater Wing, to Step Down
text: Howard Sherman, the executive director of the American Theater Wing, which co-presents the Tony Awards, announced on Tuesday that he would step down when his current contract ends on June 30, after eight years in the position. In a statement, Mr. Sherman said that he did not have a new job lined up but that he believed in making his intentions known rather than quietly seeking his next opportunity; the business side of New York theater is an insular world, and gossip tends to spread quickly when a top executive is coming or going. Theodore S. Chapin, chairman of the board of the Wing, credited Mr. Sherman with raising the profile of the organization through its “Working in the Theater” television program, video and Web-based programs, podcasts, and Twitter. Mr. Sherman developed new internship and education programs for aspiring artists, and he also conceived and supervised a 2009 collection of essays, “The Play That Changed My Life,” contributed by leading playwrights and edited by Ben Hodges. He also serves as the point man on the Tonys for the Wing, which created the awards in 1947 and now co-presents them with the Broadway League, a trade group of theater owners and producers.

headline: NBC’s ‘Sing-Off’ Soars Again
text: NBC’s holiday-season singing competition, “The Sing-Off” validated its growing expectations Monday night by moving up again in the ratings, reaching legitimate hit status.

headline: A Progress Report on Gay Employee Health Benefits
text: Updated | 3/4/13 with new details in chart.

headline: Gelb on Zeffirelli, the New ‘La Traviata’ and More at the Met
text: Is the Metropolitan Opera’s new production of “La Traviata” part of a “large dastardly plot” against the director Franco Zeffirelli? Not at all, said Peter Gelb, the Met’s general manager, at a panel discussion on Monday night.

headline: Kin Shop
text: THE black soup arrives at the table already staining the sides of its wide white bowl, an inelegant-looking thing, lampblack-hued, shimmery with oil, menacing, its velvet surface rippled by off-white tangles of squid, by dull green spears of long bean. Stab a spoon into it to discover coins of flesh that lie in its depths, squid rings stuffed with brisket. The smell of sesame drifts upward on threads of steam.

headline: Reviewing Kin Shop
text: @import url("http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/css/multimedia/bundles/SlidingGallery.css");

headline: The Borders That Love Crosses
text: Love and the meeting of cultures are explored in one-acts by Sophia Romma now at the Cherry Lane Theater. Directed by Charles Weldon for the Negro Ensemble Company as part of the troupe’s recent takes on intolerance, “With Aaron’s Arms Around Me” is plainspoken, while “The Mire” is a farcical fable. Each takes a refreshing, almost sideways approach to the subject of ethnic tension.

headline: Autism’s Season of Hope
text: Darkness falls early this time of year, and for many of us (my hand is raised here), the shorter days bring a sadness, a gloom.

headline: A Decision vs. ‘The Decision’
text: Cliff Lee did not turn his free-agent sweepstakes into reality television, the way LeBron James did in July with his ostentatiously produced drama that culminated with the announcement of the Decision on ESPN.

headline: Beyond Political Science
text: Reacting to the Dot Earth discussion of Republicans and science, two readers, Redmond Clark of Barrington, Ill., and Christopher Yaun of Portsmouth, N.H., offered very distinct, and compelling, approaches to fostering progress when science frames, but does not determine, politically charged policy debates.

headline: Week 15 in Fantasy Football: The Waiver Wire
text: The brothers Sablich are here to help with fantasy football analysis for Week 15. Check back on Thursday for their weekly matchup analysis and their reader Q. & A. and follow them on Twitter for more advice leading up to game time on Sunday.

headline: Richard Holbrooke, Man of Letters
text: Richard Holbrooke was, like Daniel Patrick Moynihan, one of those rare public intellectuals who managed to combine a life in world affairs with the life of the mind. In his role as a diplomat, he seemed to maintain ironic distance on himself, watching as he conducted negotiations at the highest level and reflecting on his own activities and decisions. And when he died this week, he left a legacy in letters as well as in statecraft.

headline: Richard Holbrooke, Man of Letters
text: Richard Holbrooke was, like Daniel Patrick Moynihan, one of those rare public intellectuals who managed to combine a life in world affairs with the life of the mind. In his role as a diplomat, he seemed to maintain ironic distance on himself, watching as he conducted negotiations at the highest level and reflecting on his own activities and decisions. And when he died this week, he left a legacy in letters as well as in statecraft.

headline: Tequila Shots and Mock Bravado Accompany Globe Nods
text: Is everybody over the excitement of seeing Johnny Depp compete with himself — and with Cher — at the Golden Globes? No? Here, a grab-bag of nominee reactions. Slice, dice, rinse, repeat.

headline: Espada Charged With Stealing From Nonprofit
text: Pedro Espada Jr., the outgoing State Senate majority leader who was defeated in the September Democratic primary as scandal swirled around him, was indicted along with his son on Tuesday on charges that they embezzled more than $500,000 from the nonprofit health care network they operated in the Bronx.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Afghanistan and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Afghanistan, Italy and Gaza.

headline: Room at the Top at Goldman Sachs
text: Wall Street rivals usually follow where Goldman Sachs leads. It is unlikely to be any different when the findings of Goldman’s Business Standards Committee become public early next year. But on one important point Goldman lags some big competitors — the separation of the chief executive and chairman jobs. Now it has a chance to catch up.

headline: Bret Baier Signs ‘Multiyear Deal’ With Fox News
text: Fox News said Tuesday that it had extended the contract of Bret Baier, the channel’s main political news anchor.

headline: It’s Date Night, and Lots of Strangers Are Along for the Ride
text: I once took a date to a murder scene.

headline: Dreaming of a Post-Christmas Congress
text: The Senate majority leader, Harry Reid of Nevada, said on Tuesday that Democrats were not prepared to give up any of their priorities and would work as long as it takes – right up until the end of the 111th Congress on Jan. 4 – to deal with their punch list of major items: the tax package; the New START arms control treaty with Russia; a huge spending bill; a bill to authorize repeal of the military’s don’t ask, don’t tell policy; and an immigration measure that would create a path to citizenship for certain illegal immigrants brought to the United States as young children.

headline: The Richest Counties in America
text: Today the Census Bureau released the latest American Community Survey numbers, which contain all sorts of delicious data nuggets. I’ll probably blog a few choice items from this release over the next few days.

headline: Neil Diamond, Alice Cooper to Join Rock Hall
text: Neil Diamond, Alice Cooper, Tom Waits, Dr. John and Darlene Love are the latest inductees to the pantheon of the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame, the organization will announce on Wednesday morning.

headline: Asked and Answered | Paul Jasmin
text: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#84", 592, 400, true, chameleonData);

headline: Putting a Classroom Where Stables Once Stood
text: Where once was heard the clip-clop of hooves, next year will sound with the pitter patter of schoolchildren’s feet: On the Upper West Side, the private Stephen Gaynor School is expanding into the building that formerly housed the Claremont Riding Academy.

headline: Mining the Buzz for the Year’s Top Ads
text: The end of the year is bringing the usual looks back on Madison Avenue at the high and low points of the last 12 months. Now, with social media increasingly important as a marketing tool, those year-end lists are expanding to include assessments of the conversations consumers had in 2010 about ads they liked and disliked.

headline: Robin Givhan Leaving The Washington Post
text: Robin Givhan, the Pulitzer Prize-winning writer who became one of The Washington Post’s biggest stars of the last generation, is leaving the paper to join Tina Brown’s reconstituted Newsweek.

headline: Asian Players Fill Semifinal Slots at Women’s World Chess Championship
text: The two highest ranked players, Humpy Koneru and Hou Yifan, have qualified, as has Zhao Xue. The final qualifier will be determined after tie-breaker games on Wednesday.

headline: Tacombi at Fonda Nolita and Cascabel Taqueria
text: Tacombi at Fonda Nolita, 267 Elizabeth Street (Prince Street), (917) 727-0179, tacombi.com, doesn’t feel like a restaurant as much as an art installation, a gallery with a taqueria set up in the middle of a concrete garage just off Houston Street. Tacos are served from a vintage Volkswagen van with a roof that pops open like the lid on a shoe box — you exchange cash for casino chips at a counter, line up at the van, then take your food to one of the hand-painted folding tables or counters scattered around the cavernous space.

headline: Police Seek Suspects in Robbery of 90-Year-Old Man
text: The police are seeking two men who attacked and robbed a 90-year-old man in his Harlem building. The victim, Jessie Little, was returning home to 15 West 139th Street from grocery shopping on the afternoon of Dec. 4 when he was approached from behind by two men, the police said. “One of them put an arm around my neck and pulled me to the ground,” Mr. Little told the Manhattan news site DNAInfo. “The other guy took the money from my pocket.” They took $380, Mr. Little said. Anyone with information about the crime is urged to call or log on to Crimestoppers.

headline: How New York's Racial Makeup Has Changed Since 2000
text: Maps detail the change in population of white, black, Hispanic and Asian residents in New York City.

headline: Coney Island’s Shore Theater Is Named a Landmark
text: The Shore Theater in Coney Island, a neo-Renaissance Revival contemporary of the Cyclone and the Wonder Wheel, is now a landmark. The Landmarks Preservation Commission approved the designation for the Shore and three other buildings on Tuesday afternoon. The Shore, originally known as the Coney Island Theater, was built between 1924 and 1925. Beginning in the mid-1960s, the theater began housing musical revues and burlesque. A few years later, following a brief experimentation with adult film, it catered to a (presumably) different demographic: bingo players. Today, at seven stories high, the vacant building is one of the tallest in the area.

headline: Without Blood Sausage, It Just Wouldn’t Be Christmas
text: “WE Estonians believe all kinds of things,” said Ell Tabur, a beaming blonde, her arms plunged to the elbow in a tub of barley, onions, blood and marjoram. Ms. Tabur was among about 30 Estonian-Americans who gathered on a recent Saturday to make traditional blood sausage for Christmas Eve at the New York Estonian House (Eesti Maja), a cozy town house near the mouth of the Midtown Tunnel.

headline: Paris Back When the Modernist Feast Was First Moveable
text: Paris isn’t what it once was. And neither is PBS.

headline: There Will Be Blood Sausage
text: Inside the annual blood sausage-making party — an Estonian Christmas tradition — held in New York.

headline: The Girl With the Book About the Famous Author
text: The Stieg Larsson story continues  this time with a new book by his enigmatic companion, Eva Gabrielsson. Ms. Gabrielsson, right, who lived with Larsson, the Swedish crime novelist, for 30 years until his death in 2004 at 50, has written a book that chronicles their life together and the creation of Larsson’s blockbuster “Millennium” series, which began with “The Girl With the Dragon Tattoo.” The Gabrielsson book, not yet titled, will also shed light on the mysterious fourth novel in the series, her publisher, Seven Stories Press, said. Ms. Gabrielsson has said she has a partial manuscript of the fourth novel saved on a laptop computer but she hoped it would never be published. Her book is scheduled for publication in the United States in June, her publisher said on Tuesday. In a statement Ms. Gabrielsson said she hoped the book would give the trilogy’s fans “some answers to their many questions.”

headline: ‘Sing Off’ Rises
text: Monday’s edition of “The Sing Off” improved in the ratings over its debut, earning 9.4 million viewers, according to Nielsen’s estimates, lifting NBC to second place for the night. CBS finished No. 1 over all, winning the 10 o’clock hour by a big margin with “Hawaii Five-0” (11.1 million), which outpaced ABC’s rerun of “Castle” (5.2 million) and NBC’s struggling drama “Chase” (4.6 million). Fox ranked third with repeats, while ABC was fourth.

headline: Re-examining the Poison Pill
text: The poison pill is in flux.

headline: Golden Globes Show Love and Snubs
text: LOS ANGELES — Golden Globe voters predictably circled around “The King’s Speech” on Tuesday, nominating that highly praised period drama about a stuttering King George VI for seven trophies, including for best drama.

headline: Keeping Score: Where Does the Phillies’ Rotation Stand in History?
text: Sean Forman is the creator of Baseball-Reference.com, an online baseball encyclopedia of players, teams and box scores in the major and minor leagues.

headline: Casting Announced for Kushner Play
text: 7:17 p.m. | Updated  Initial casting has been announced for the New York production of Tony Kushner‘s new play, “The Intelligent Homosexual’s Guide to Capitalism and Socialism With a Key to the Scriptures,” which will run at the Public Theater from March 22 through June 12, 2011, with opening night set for May 5.

headline: Taking an Insider’s Look at Seattle’s Outsider Poet
text: Peter Sillen is developing a specialty as a post-Beatnik preservationist. Having profiled the Atlanta musician Robert Dickerson in “Benjamin Smoke” (directed with Jem Cohen), he crosses the country to examine a performer with a similar set of influences and pathologies in “I Am Secretly an Important Man,” a portrait of the Seattle poet and performer Steven Jay Bernstein.

headline: Church Seeks to Replace Its Busy Organ
text: The language could not have been more dire.

headline: The Fun House Awaits
text: LIKE any Frenchman worth his fleur de sel, the new Pierre Hardy boutique immediately poses challenging questions.

headline: A World of Chocolates on the Lower East Side
text: A new shop in the East Village has dozens of chocolate brands from 10 countries, a collection that will rapidly expand. For now, about half of what’s carried is predictable: Jacques Torres, Michel Cluizel, Neuhaus and Lindt, to name a few, but the real attractions are the more recherché lines, like Génaveh from Luxembourg, with precious bonbons in pretty boxes; William Dean’s elaborately decorated assortments from Florida; and Pacari’s Ecuadorean bars in exotic flavors.

headline: Gifts for Wine and Cocktail Lovers
text: NOBODY is easier to please at the holidays than wine lovers. Spirits and cocktail fans, too. Just don’t try to get too creative with your gifts.

headline: Hand-Pulled Candy Canes From Zoë’s Chocolate
text: Let the children have the green, white and red peppermint candy canes from Zoë’s Chocolate, and maybe even the red-and-white cinnamon ones. But for the adults, set aside those that have blue stripes among the red and white. They’re anise and delicious, brightly flavored like the others, with natural seasonings and oils.

headline: Nate Appleman, Rising Star, Turns Up in a Chipotle
text: ONCE again, Nate Appleman is making people scratch their heads.

headline: Vanilla, Fresh From Madagascar
text: Tim McCollum and Brett Beach, former Peace Corps volunteers, stuck around Madagascar after their tour of duty and developed Madécasse, a company that works with a group of 30 farm families so they can not only grow cacao and vanilla beans but also process them into excellent products and make more money. If devoted bakers are on your gift list, a collection of vanilla products and chocolate bars should please them.

headline: Dining Calendar
text: Tea for Tchaikovsky

headline: Effort Falters on San Francisco Bay Delta
text: SAN FRANCISCO  A high-stakes effort to remake the San Francisco Bay Delta, the West Coast’s largest estuary, is looking as fragile as the degraded delta itself these days.

headline: Brooklyn: The Brand
text: FOR a place selling beer and pulled pork sliders, the Brooklyneer has provoked a lot of controversy.

headline: Determined to Find Her Voice
text: Melissa Razick had severe developmental delays as a child. With help from The Neediest Cases Fund, Ms. Razick is working towards earning her G.E.D.

headline: Trailer: 'Tron: Legacy" Motion Comic
text: A trailer for the motion comic "Tron: Legacy"

headline: Streaks Link UConn and U.C.L.A.
text: STORRS, Conn.  About 15 years ago, Geno Auriemma met John Wooden, who put a grandfatherly hand on his knee as the two coaches talked basketball. Then, after Connecticut won the 2000 N.C.A.A. women’s title, Wooden said that he enjoyed the selfless way the Huskies played.

headline: Mitch McConnell Chokes Up
text: The Crying Caucus just got its newest member — Senator Mitch McConnell.

headline: A Miracle Escape on a Day of Draws at London Chess Classic
text: Vladimir Kramnik let a winning position against Magnus Carlsen slip through his fingers on Tuesday. So Carlsen remains tied for the lead with one round to go.

headline: How to Decorate Holiday Cookies
text: Melissa Clark, the author of the Good Appetite column, demonstrates how to make and decorate festive cookies the fast and easy way.

headline: Reopening a House That’s Still Divided
text: PHILADELPHIA — The convulsive currents that roil the telling of American history have become so familiar that they now seem an inseparable part of the story itself. Here is a nation, conceived in liberty and dedicated to a proposition of human equality, that, for much of its first century of life, countenanced slavery, institutionally supported it and economically profited from it. The years that followed have been marked by repair, reform and reversals; recompense, recrimination and reinterpretation. Extraordinary ideals and achievements have been countered by extraordinary failings and flaws, only to be countered yet again, each turn yielding another round of debates.

headline: Save the Children Breaks With Soda Tax Effort
text: Over the last year, Save the Children emerged as a leader in the push to tax sweetened soft drinks as a way to combat childhood obesity. The nonprofit group supported soda tax campaigns in Mississippi, New Mexico, Washington State, Philadelphia and the District of Columbia.

headline: Opposition to Health Law Is Steeped in Tradition
text: “We are against forcing all citizens, regardless of need, into a compulsory government program,” said one prominent critic of the new health care law. It is socialized medicine, he argued. If it stands, he said, “one of these days, you and I are going to spend our sunset years telling our children, and our children’s children, what it once was like in America when men were free.”

headline: The Adoration Aside, There Are Dangers to Being an R&B Heartthrob
text: A set piece of many concerts by male soul singers is the segment in which a woman is pulled from the crowd for an intimate serenade. It’s reliable material: the woman, mesmerized; the singer, empowered; their interactions, varying degrees of cozy; the audience’s screams, loud.

headline: Vikings Set to Move Outside for Game
text: MINNEAPOLIS  Inspectors determined Tuesday that the torn Metrodome roof could not be repaired this week, so the Vikings are moving ahead with a backup plan  using TCF Bank Stadium at the University of Minnesota for their game Monday night against the Chicago Bears.

headline: Chávez Seeks Decree Powers
text: CARACAS, Venezuela — President Hugo Chávez requested temporary decree powers on Tuesday from the National Assembly. The request, submitted less than a month before a new legislature convenes with a bolstered faction of opposition lawmakers, opens a new phase of tension between the president and his critics.

headline: House Leader in New Bid to Repeal ‘Don’t Ask’
text: House Democratic leaders have decided to make one last push to repeal the military’s ban on gay men and lesbians serving openly before the end of the lame-duck Congress.

headline: A Man Who Knew the People Who Mattered, and Wrote About Them
text: When the novelist Louis Auchincloss died last January, at 92, his timing could hardly have been worse. J. D. Salinger died the next day, obliterating much of the attention that would have come Auchincloss’s way. To put it in Holden Caulfield’s words, “People never notice anything.”

headline: Pelosi’s Spokesman Is Stepping Down
text: Brendan Daly, the chief spokesman for Speaker Nancy Pelosi and a close adviser to her since she joined the Democratic leadership in 2002, is leaving his Capitol Hill post to join a Washington public relations firm.

headline: Hammerstein History in Photos
text: Little ink has been spared when it comes to cataloging the achievements of the lyricist Oscar Hammerstein II, who, with the composer Richard Rodgers, wrote some of the most iconic shows in the American musical theater canon, including “South Pacific,” “The Sound of Music” and “Oklahoma!”

headline: From Clearwire, 4G for the Home
text: Simplicity is a big deal here at Gadgetwise, and few things in the digital universe are more complicated than setting up a wireless home network.

headline: Holiday Cookies: If It’s Festive, It Flies
text: Last December, The New York Times asked readers to send photos and recipes of their holiday cookies. About 100 people answered the call, filling the inbox with creations that were classic (sugar cookies), endearingly oddball (chocolate-pepper cookies in the shape of frogs) or both (meringue mushrooms that looked as if they’d fallen off a bûche de Noël).

headline: TV Encore for Game 7 of 1960 Yankees-Pirates Series
text: When the MLB Network shows Game 7 of the 1960 World Series at 8 p.m. on Wednesday, viewers will learn a bit more about what Mickey Mantle was thinking when he found himself way off first base with the Yankees trailing the Pirates, 9-8.

headline: An Earth Mother Holds Her Own Among the ‘Nutcracker’ Bonbons
text: There’s one element of “The Nutcracker” that America embraces as Europe does not. In the various entertainment dances that occur in Act II, there’s a comic number for a mother of many clown-children, La Mère Gigogne. Her English name is usually Mother Ginger.

headline: Buried Treasure in Baltic Has Vintage Taste
text: MARIEHAMN, Finland — When Christian Ekstrom, a local diver, finally got to explore a sunken two-masted schooner he had known about for years, he found bottles, lots of bottles, so he brought one to the surface.

headline: Medicare Wasn’t Always So Popular
text: My column this week looks at the history of opposition to expansions of the social safety net, such as Social Security and Medicare. The best example may be Ronald Reagan’s opposition to Medicare in the 1960s.

headline: Still Elegantly Adjusting to Adversity
text: To suggest that the pianist Leon Fleisher has a long history of turning disadvantages into opportunities is to understate the case by an order of magnitude. In 1965, at an early peak of his growing fame, Mr. Fleisher faced a crippling condition in his right hand, a mysterious malady that might have ended many a pianist’s career.

headline: Air Force Blocks Sites That Posted Secret Cables
text: WASHINGTON  The Air Force is barring its personnel from using work computers to view the Web sites of The New York Times and more than 25 other news organizations and blogs that have posted secret cables obtained by WikiLeaks, Air Force officials said Tuesday.

headline: Chanos Starts a New Fund
text: James Chanos, the short-seller known for his call on Enron and who of late has been a vocal critic of investing in China, has raised $20 million for a new hedge fund called Kriticos International, according to regulatory filings.

headline: Politics Enables Mexican Fugitive to Defang a Law
text: MEXICO CITY  Despite being a federal fugitive, accused of laundering millions of dollars for one of Mexico’s most ruthless drug cartels, Julio César Godoy says he simply walked into the national legislature here unnoticed in September, right past the cordon of federal police officers watching the building.

headline: Revisiting Holbrooke’s Last Remarks
text: It used to takes decades for legends about the supposed last words of famous people to seep into the culture and morph through constant repetition, until some enterprising scholar would look for hard evidence and soberly conclude that the well-known observation was most likely a myth or misunderstanding.

headline: Intelligence Reports Offer Dim View of Afghan War
text: WASHINGTON  As President Obama prepares to release a review of American strategy in Afghanistan that will claim progress in the nine-year-old war there, two new classified intelligence reports offer a more negative assessment and say there is a limited chance of success unless Pakistan hunts down insurgents operating from havens on its Afghan border.

headline: A Kitchen-for-Rent Is a Lifeline for the Laid-Off
text: In New York’s culinary world, with its unending appetite and closet-size kitchens, it is an unimpressive building housing a seven-day-a-week, 24-hour revolving-door operation built on need, ambition and nostalgia.

headline: Richard C. Holbrooke on TimesTalks
text: Richard C. Holbrooke, a diplomatic troubleshooter who worked for every Democratic president since the late 1960s, died on Monday. He spoke with James Traub during a TimesTalks event in May 2009.

headline: Former Prime Minister of Britain Embarks on a Global Opportunity at N.Y.U.
text: A half-year ago, he resigned as British prime minister after a bruising campaign and some stiff criticism of his politicking skills. But on Tuesday, Gordon Brown was pressing the flesh again  this time at New York University, where he talked about his new book, led a discussion with selected students and eased into the Greenwich Village institution that will be his academic home for the next two years.

headline: Give Up on the Estate Tax

headline: Post-Holbrooke Question: ‘What Now?’
text: WASHINGTON  When President Obama turned to Richard C. Holbrooke during a White House meeting on Afghanistan last year, Mr. Holbrooke spoke gravely of the historic challenge the two men faced, likening it to when Clark M. Clifford advised Lyndon B. Johnson about what to do in Vietnam.

headline: Recipes for Cookies and Bars
text: Gingerbread, brownies, salty chocolate chip cookies and additional recipes for sweets.

headline: Madoff Kin to Mourn in Private
text: The body of Mark Madoff, the older son of Bernard L. Madoff, was set to be cremated on Tuesday with no funeral service planned, according to a person close to the family.

headline: Advise and Obstruct
text: The Senate’s power to advise and consent on federal judicial nominations was intended as a check against sorely deficient presidential choices. It is not a license to exercise partisan influence over these vital jobs by blocking confirmation of entire slates of well-qualified nominees offered by a president of the opposite party.

headline: Restaurants and Companies Brooklynize
text: Small restaurants and large companies are lining up to hitch their wagons to Brooklyn’s D.I.Y. chic.

headline: Airport Apps Put You First in Line
text: IT goes without saying: Holiday travel is brutal. Security lines are longer. Planes are more crowded. The battle for storage space heats up as travelers vie to stuff all those gift-laden bags in overhead bins. And if bad weather hits, your delayed or canceled flight may make you tardy for Christmas or New Year’s dinner — that is, if you even make it out of the airport.

headline: Jets’ Moore Is on the Side of the Steelers’ Harrison
text: In four days, the Jets’ Brandon Moore and the Pittsburgh Steelers’ James Harrison will be at cross purposes. Moore is a right guard and Harrison is a ferocious outside linebacker.

headline: No to New York? There Must Be Some Mistake
text: The Dodgers and the Giants did it. Johnny Carson did it. So did I.B.M., American Airlines, the United States Olympic Committee and President Gerald R. Ford.

headline: We’ve Only Got America A
text: Former President José María Figueres of Costa Rica has a saying I like: “There is no Planet B”  so we’d better make Plan A work to preserve a stable environment. I feel the same way about America these days. There is no America B, so we’d better make this one work a lot better than we’ve been doing, and not only for our sake. When Britain went into decline as the globe’s stabilizing power, America was right there, ready to pick up the role. Even with all our imperfections and mistakes, the world has been a better place for it. If America goes weak, though, and cannot project power the way it has, your kids won’t just grow up in a different America. They will grow up in a different world. You will not like who picks up the pieces. Just glance at a few recent headlines.

headline: No Theft Conviction, but Items Remain Seized
text: The question sounds simple enough: If the police take items from a man who they believe stole them, but he is never convicted of any crime, does he get the items back?

headline: A Rent Spike May Loom at Stuyvesant Town
text: Thousands of tenants at Stuyvesant Town and Peter Cooper Village will face a potential spike in rents and more uncertainty over the future when a year-old accord expires Wednesday, ending a period of calm at the financially troubled complexes in Manhattan.

headline: How to Turn Off Voters
text: In New York State, and especially in New York City, voting is a difficult and frustrating task. That may help explain why in the last three elections, New York ranked 47th out of the 50 states and the District of Columbia in average voter turnout  a miserable record.

headline: Region Is Reshaped as Minorities Go to Suburbs
text: Metropolitan New York is being rapidly reshaped as blacks, Latinos, Asians and immigrants surge into the suburbs, while gentrification by whites is widening the income gap in neighborhoods in Manhattan and Brooklyn, according to new census figures released on Tuesday.

headline: Prior, Former All-Star, Joins Yanks
text: An All-Star pitcher who had deliberated for several days about whether to sign with the Texas Rangers or the Yankees came to terms Tuesday with the Yankees on a new contract.

headline: As Knicks Add Wins, Minutes Mount, Too
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  Coach Mike D’Antoni’s orders are music to a player’s ears, but havoc on his lungs. D’Antoni’s rotation is tight and his directive is to run.

headline: Emanuel Gets a Grilling by Chicagoans Who Think He’s Not Chicagoan Enough
text: CHICAGO  Rahm Emanuel’s campaign to become mayor of this city has looked like a perfectly orchestrated political play: cheerful morning hand-shakings at train stops, tours of neighborhoods as cameras whir, pronouncements on education, energy, the police.

headline: A Couple Joined by Cancer, Bound by Love
text: When Johana Calvache’s husband received a cancer diagnosis, she did not panic. Even though her daughter had lost her eyesight to the disease at age 4, she did not descend into self-pity. Her first instinct was to fight.

headline: Richard Holbrooke
text: Richard Holbrooke was an iconic American diplomat. Best known for negotiating an end to the Bosnian war, he had a career that spanned nearly five decades, starting as a young field officer in the Mekong Delta in Vietnam. When he died this week at age 69, he was serving as President Obama’s special representative for Afghanistan and Pakistan, trying to bring some measure of sanity and stability to the region.

headline: ‘Operation Dark Heart’ Author Sues for Uncensored Edition
text: WASHINGTON  A former Defense Intelligence Agency officer whose Afghan memoir was belatedly censored by the Pentagon filed a lawsuit on Tuesday seeking to have the book’s full text restored in future printings.

headline: Video Captures Man Confronting School Board Before Shooting

headline: Words of Diplomacy
text: Richard Holbrooke, the Obama administration’s special representative for Afghanistan and Pakistan since 2009, died on Monday at age 69. Below is an excerpt from an Op-Ed article he wrote for The Times on Sept. 14, 1999, about the issue he is most identified with: ending the wars in the former Yugoslavia. Read the full article and others by Mr. Holbrooke.

headline: Bay Says He Will Be Ready for Spring Training
text: Jason Bay emerged from his West Coast hibernation Tuesday and declared that he had no more effects from the concussion that ended his season in late July. Bay was at Citi Field for the Mets’ annual Christmas party and said he had been working out and expected to be ready for the first day of spring training.

headline: Ruling Has Some Mulling the Necessity of Mandating Insurance
text: WASHINGTON  Though they have battled for more than a year, President Obama and the health insurance industry agree that the requirement for most Americans to obtain insurance, struck down by a federal judge, is absolutely essential to the success of the new health care law.

headline: Lee the Grinch to Wright’s Santa at Mets’ Party
text: Rarely does one event have a big effect on both New York baseball teams, but Cliff Lee’s decision to join the Phillies did, leaving both the Yankees and the Mets reeling. The Yankees had hoped to sign Lee, while the Mets were hoping he would go somewhere far, far away.

headline: A Last Chance to Make History
text: The chances of ending the military’s ban on open service by gay and lesbian soldiers improved significantly on Tuesday when House Democratic leaders said they would introduce a fast-track repeal bill and quickly send it on to the Senate. Once the House bill is approved, the onus will be on Senate leaders to act swiftly, and on a handful of moderate Republicans to fulfill their promise to bring long-denied justice to the military’s ranks.

headline: Terminally Frugal: How to Save at Kennedy Airport
text: Saving money and spending time in airports don’t generally mix, so it was with great professional satisfaction that I gazed into the oversized salad bowl before me at Kennedy Airport on Monday.  Within it, my self-assembled masterpiece of mesclun, grilled chicken, marinated mozzarella, sun-dried tomatoes, carrots, broccoli and dried cranberries topped with a thick vinaigrette. Next to it, my computer, open to Facebook thanks to the terminal’s free Internet. How tempting to issue a triumphant status update: “Seth Kugel has assembled a beautiful salad at Kennedy International Airport for just $3.60!”

headline: Airplanes and Helicopters on an Icy Runway

text: WASHINGTON  Republicans are under pressure from the Tea Party movement and some other conservatives to reject the compromise tax bill, potentially complicating its passage and highlighting how the Republican Party is likely to face a persistent rightward push when it takes control of the House next month.

headline: New York Betrayed, Abandoned and Rejected
text: Cliff Lee’s decision to not sign with the Yankees is the latest snub in a long line of many that the city has experienced.

headline: Executives Look for Place on the Obama Team
text: WASHINGTON  Terry McGraw, the chairman and chief executive officer of the McGraw-Hill Companies, said he had been “very pleasantly surprised” by President Obama’s recent efforts to promote the interests of American business. But Mr. Obama could do better, he added, if he had a high-powered adviser with more of a business bent in the White House.

headline: 85 Years Ago, Pro Hockey Roared Into the Garden
text: On Dec. 15, 1925, professional hockey made its debut in New York before a capacity crowd of 17,000 at the grand opening of Madison Square Garden. Regimental bands and the Montreal Canadiens were on the ice for the first N.H.L. game in the city, and hundreds of New York’s society elite in tuxedos and gowns filled the most expensive seats.

headline: The Hottest Race Around: G.O.P. Leadership Fight
text: WASHINGTON  For all the talk about the new tools of politics, for all the talk about the rising influence of outside groups and third-party alliances, the fight to lead the Republican National Committee highlights a telling lesson: The old establishment is still a coveted place to be.

headline: G.O.P. Panelists Dissent on Cause of Crisis
text: WASHINGTON  The Republican members of the commission appointed by Congress to investigate the causes of the financial crisis plan to release on Wednesday a document that assigns government housing policies substantial blame for the origins of the 2008 financial crisis.

headline: U.S. Called Vulnerable to Rare Earth Shortages
text: HONG KONG — The United States is too reliant on China for minerals crucial to new clean energy technologies, making the American economy vulnerable to shortages of materials needed for a range of green products — from compact fluorescent light bulbs to electric cars to giant wind turbines.

headline: Phys Ed: The Benefits of Exercising Before Breakfast
text: From the archives.The holiday season brings many joys and, unfortunately, many countervailing dietary pitfalls. Even the fittest and most disciplined of us can succumb, indulging in more fat and calories than at any other time of the year. The health consequences, if the behavior is unchecked, can be swift and worrying. A recent study by scientists in Australia found that after only three days, an extremely high-fat, high-calorie diet can lead to increased blood sugar and insulin resistance, potentially increasing the risk for Type 2 diabetes. Waistlines also can expand at this time of year, prompting self-recrimination and unrealistic New Year’s resolutions.

headline: Faulty Weld Is Suspect in Rupture of Pipeline
text: WASHINGTON  The natural gas pipeline that ruptured in September, killing eight people and burning dozens of houses in a suburb south of San Francisco, may have had a badly welded seam in a stretch of pipe that was supposed to be seamless, federal investigators said Tuesday.

headline: Enrique Morente, Celebrated Flamenco Singer, Dies at 67
text: Enrique Morente, one of the world’s most celebrated flamenco singers, whose work embraced both traditional styles and contemporary influences as diverse as George Gershwin and Leonard Cohen, died on Monday in a Madrid hospital. He was 67.

headline: Three-Team Deal Could Affect Carmelo Anthony
text: The Nets, the Los Angeles Lakers and the Houston Rockets agreed in principle to a three-team deal Tuesday that involved three players. The trade’s most significant effect, however, could rest with a player who was not involved: Carmelo Anthony.

headline: Sweden: F.B.I. Aids Bombing Inquiry
text: Swedish investigators looking into the botched explosions that killed a 28-year-old suicide bomber in a crowded shopping district in Stockholm are being assisted by a team of F.B.I. experts who specialize in analyzing bomb fragments, a spokeswoman for the Swedish security police said Tuesday. Diplomats said the seven-member F.B.I. team, whose assistance was requested by the government of Prime Minister Fredrik Reinfeldt, arrived in Stockholm less than 24 hours after the weekend attack that lightly wounded two passers-by. Swedish officials have said that the Iraqi-born Swede who has been identified by investigators as the bomber, Taimour Abdulwahab al-Abdaly, probably had accomplices and that high priority was being given to identifying them.

headline: F.B.I. Breaks Up Child Pornography Ring
text: LOS ANGELES — An investigation into an online child pornography ring has led to the arrests of 16 men in the United States, as well as arrests in South America, Europe and New Zealand, Federal Bureau of Investigation officials announced on Tuesday.

headline: Senate Democrats Introduce Spending Bill
text: WASHINGTON  Senate Democrats on Tuesday unveiled a $1.1 trillion spending bill to finance the federal government through the end of the fiscal year on Sept. 30. Republicans said they would oppose it and insist on a temporary spending measure through the early part of next year when they hold the majority in the House and six additional seats in the Senate.

headline: Georgia: Lawsuit Over Muslim Woman’s Head Scarf
text: The American Civil Liberties Union has filed a lawsuit on behalf of a Muslim woman in Georgia who was arrested in 2008 when she refused to remove her head scarf while entering the Douglasville Municipal Court to accompany her nephew to a traffic hearing. The woman, Lisa Valentine, verbally protested the order and was briefly jailed for contempt of court. Ms. Valentine is suing the City of Douglasville and court officers for damages, arguing that her religious freedoms were violated. Georgia has since recommended that religious head coverings be permissible in the state’s courthouses, but Ms. Valentine is asking for the recommendation to be made a binding policy.

headline: Louisiana: Justice Department May Sue BP
text: The Department of Justice could sue BP over the Gulf of Mexico oil spill as soon as Wednesday, joining the sprawling federal litigation that already involves some 23,000 plaintiffs, The Wall Street Journal reported on Tuesday. Judge Carl J. Barbier, who is running the centralized litigation from New Orleans, issued an order in October that all “master complaints” should be filed by Dec. 15. Stephen J. Herman, a leader of the group of plaintiffs’ lawyers in the case, said that he had not heard that the government was preparing to join the litigation, but added, “It was inevitable that they were going to file suit.”

headline: San Francisco Approves Cup Plan
text: After several days of modifications, the San Francisco Board of Supervisors unanimously approved a plan to host the 34th America’s Cup along its northern waterfront. Mayor Gavin Newsom was to sign the bid late Tuesday and present it to the organizers of the race, who want a deal in place by Friday. The organizers, though, are pushing for additional assurances the plan will give them the ability to recoup the nearly $500 million they expect to spend on the event. Some of those details were expected to be worked out by the end of the week. If not, the organizers have said they will seek another site.

headline: U.S.O.C. Board to Vote on Expanding
text: The United States Olympic Committee’s board of directors is expected to vote Thursday on whether to add five members to the board. Four of the new directors will fill positions created by the board after an independent advisory panel headed by Paul Tagliabue recommended that the body be expanded to 15 members from 11. The fifth would fill a vacant position created by the departure of the board member Stephanie Streeter, who served in 2009 as acting chief executive before stepping down later that year.

headline: Sudan: President Cancels Zambian Trip
text: Sudan’s president, Omar Hassan al-Bashir, who is wanted on genocide charges, abruptly canceled his planned trip to Zambia to attend an environmental conference starting Wednesday, according to Zambia’s state radio. Zambia had invited Mr. Bashir even though it was legally bound to arrest him because it is a member of the International Criminal Court, but nearly 30 African human rights and other groups have since flooded the Zambian government with letters and faxes of protest. Mr. Bashir has been forced to skip two other high-profile international events in the past two weeks.

headline: Kosovo: Report on Organ Trafficking
text: A report on the illegal harvesting of and trafficking in human organs in Kosovo will be presented Thursday to the Council of Europe, a 47-nation group that deals with issues of human rights. According to Agence France-Presse, the report says that ethnic Albanian guerrillas of the Kosovo Liberation Army trafficked in organs of Serb prisoners after the 1999 Kosovo conflict. Prime Minister Hashim Thaci  one of the leaders of K.L.A. units during the conflict with Serb security forces  fiercely denied the accusations, the news agency said. Past investigations by the United Nations war crimes tribunal dealing with the Balkan wars did not produce credible evidence on organ trafficking, according to a former tribunal official. But the former chief prosecutor Carla Del Ponte raised the issue as hearsay in her 2008 memoirs.

headline: Pakistan: Party Leaves Governing Bloc
text: An Islamic party withdrew from the governing coalition after Prime Minister Yusuf Raza Gilani ousted its minister on Tuesday. Muhammad Azam Khan Swati, who held the portfolio for science and technology, had been involved in a public fight with a colleague, Hamid Saeed Kazmi, minister for religious affairs. Mr. Swati had accused Mr. Kazmi of corruption; Mr. Kazmi denied the allegations. The decision is unlikely to bring down the governing coalition, led by the Pakistan Peoples Party of President Asif Ali Zardari, but is likely to weaken an already fragile government, analysts said.

headline: A Bayesian Take on Julian Assange
text: Suppose that you are taking the bullet train from Kyoto, Japan to Tokyo, as I did yesterday. The woman seated across from you has somewhat unusual facial features. You are curious to know whether she is Japanese, Caucasian, or some mix of both.

headline: Refugee Boat Sinks Near Australia

headline: Novartis Seals Alcon Deal for $12.9 Billion
text: Novartis, the giant Swiss drug maker, said on Wednesday that it had reached an agreement with Alcon, the eye-care company, wrapping up a yearlong effort to buy the 23 percent of Alcon it does not already own. Novartis will use its stock to pay the equivalent of $168 for each Alcon share, valuing the transaction at $12.9 billion.

headline: Do You Text at the Dinner Table?
text: More and more attention is being paid to the time that students – and parents – are spending on digital devices, with concerns being raised over issues like driving while texting, the downside of constant connectivity and the psychological effects of excessive texting. Now let’s turn to family time. Do you use your cellphone during dinner? If so, why? Do your siblings and parents think it’s O.K., or do they disapprove?

headline: Simon Property Bids $4.8 Billion for British Mall Chain

headline: At a Berlin Apartment for Rent: Boxing, Chess, Sleep
text: A decade ago, the Berlin-based Dutch artist Iepe Rubingh, inspired by a French comic strip, hit on an idea. Why not combine “the No. 1 thinking sport” (chess) and “the No. 1 fighting sport” (boxing)? Mr. Rubingh did just that, and a new sport was born: Chessboxing, in which rounds of chess alternate with rounds in the ring (you can win with a knockout or a checkmate).

headline: International Court Seeks Indictments in Kenya Vote Violence
text: LAMU, Kenya — The prosecutor of the International Criminal Court is seeking to indict several high-ranking Kenyan politicians, including the finance minister and a former national police chief, for crimes against humanity in what he calls an orchestrated campaign to displace, torture, persecute and kill civilians during Kenya’s election crisis in 2007 and early 2008.

headline: The Nutcracker Chronicles: Nashville, Not Nuremburg

headline: Volkswagen Courts Female Drivers, but Not Exclusively
text: With an eye toward tripling sales in the United States by 2018, Volkswagen of America is pushing aggressively for new market share. But the brand’s most visible promotional activities this year have suggested an apparent — if not openly acknowledged — strategy to win female buyers in particular.

headline: Icahn Offers to Buy Dynegy for $665 Million

In urging shareholders to reject the bid, he argued that others would be willing to pay more than Blackstone’s final offer of $5 a share.

headline: The Insurance Market Without a Mandate

headline: China Leader Calls on India to Be a Partner in Asia
text: NEW DELHI  Kicking off a three-day tour of India on Wednesday, the Chinese premier, Wen Jiabao, encouraged the two countries to partner, not compete, as the world’s balance of power tilts toward Asia.

headline: Imagining a Renewable Utah
text: To cut human-generated carbon dioxide emissions by 80 percent, an oft-quoted goal, the electricity sector might have to reduce its own emissions even more because other sectors like agriculture or aviation could find 80 percent impossible. Many states have quotas for reliance on renewable electricity, but the highest is California’s at just 33 percent.

headline: Invincible Ignorance
text: So Republican members of the Financial Crisis Inquiry Commission are going to issue their own report, placing primary blame on the government — because it’s always the government’s fault.

headline: An Energy Menu That Works for the Long Haul
text: WASHINGTON — Here’s an update on the remarkable discussion at Energy Innovation 2010. On a panel I ran, the physics Nobelist Burton Richter called for a social movement for energy progress, not built around climate but around the underlying energy challenge (and opportunity) that largely transcends political or ideological labels. “We need an Energy Party, not a Tea Party,” he said.

headline: Emotional Spell-Check
text: ToneCheck, an e-mail-outbox filter that works as a sort of emotional spell-check, offers typists a chance to reconsider their words before hitting "send."

headline: Who Do You Wish Would Snub Us?
text: The Department of Hurt Feelings is open for business. Please take a seat on the couch.

headline: For Wall Street Banks, Little ‘Flexibility’ on Pay
text: Wall Street may not have much wiggle room with pay this year — even as shareholders and other critics assail supersize bonuses.

headline: Chrysler and VW Recall Nearly 750,000 Vehicles
text: 10:39 a.m. | Updated

headline: Obama Talks Taxes with Business Executives
text: President Obama once again urged lawmakers to pass the compromise tax cut package that is on the Senate floor, saying that he is “convinced” that it will help spur economic growth.

headline: Rip Torn in Plea Deal for Bank Arrest
text: A picaresque life in which you’ve won a Tony Award and an Emmy Award, starred in “The Beastmaster” and “The Larry Sanders Show” alike and been preserved on film wrestling Norman Mailer to the ground may earn you a special place in the hearts of the people, but it doesn’t exempt you from obeying the law. Rip Torn has pleaded guilty to charges stemming from a January incident in which he was arrested after taking a loaded revolver into a bank in Litchfield, Conn., The Associated Press reported. David Shepack, a Connecticut prosecutor, told The A.P. that Mr. Torn pleaded guilty Tuesday to reckless endangerment, criminal trespass, criminal mischief and illegally carrying of a firearm and received a two-and-a-half-year suspended sentence and three years’ probation; he will have to submit to random drug and alcohol tests as part of the probation. A lawyer for Mr. Torn said the actor was thankful that no one had been injured and that he had not been sent to jail.

headline: Sky-High SATs, but the Team’s at Rock Bottom
text: PASADENA, Calif.  Of all colleges, it would seem, the California Institute of Technology should have the least trouble doing the math. Yet its basketball team was left guessing about the precise length of its conference losing streak, which began in 1985.

headline: Coburn Takes Aim at the Idled Rich
text: In the big tax cut debate, some lawmakers have focused on the unemployed, pressing for extended jobless aid, and others on the richest Americans, fighting for a lower tax on wealthy estates, for example. But Senator Tom Coburn, Republican of Oklahoma, raises an often overlooked point: sometimes the rich and the unemployed are one and the same.

headline: What Is Money?
text: There’s a lot to be said about the right-wing attack on the Fed, none of it good. But I’d like to highlight one aspect of this discussion that has been striking me: the conservative focus on the evils of increasing the money supply.

headline: Vain Glorious | Damascena Body Serum
text: What: Damascena Body Serum, the first body product from the rose-based skincare line Duchess Marden.

headline: What We’re Reading: A Good Year for Wall Street
text: Links from around the Web.

headline: Park Slope Plane Crash | Scarred Roofs and Jet Parts
text: Fifty years later, on a gray December day, there is little to indicate that the corner of Seventh Avenue and Sterling Place in Park Slope, Brooklyn, bore violent witness to the worst air disaster at the time, that the disembodied leviathan tail of a ruined jet came to rest here amid flaming carnage and falling brick.

headline: Wednesday Reading: Gift Ideas for Wine Lovers
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: Triangle of Vulnerabilities
text: The triple threat of government debt, poor economic growth and banking instability.

headline: Anti-Austerity Protest in Greece Turns Violent
text: ATHENS  Thousands of Greeks took to the streets of the capital on Wednesday for a protest against a fresh wave of austerity measures which was marred by violence as a general strike brought international travel and public services to a standstill.

text: JOIN THE LIVE CHATVISIT WHITEHOUSE.GOV

headline: New Estimates of Food Poisoning Cases
text: The federal government on Wednesday significantly cut its estimate of how many Americans get sick every year from tainted food.

headline: Bloomberg Hires 2 to Lead Opinion Venture
text: 12:13 p.m. | Updated Bloomberg L.P. is making a foray into opinion writing, a move intended to further broaden the company’s reach beyond its bread-and-butter financial news service.

headline: Assessing the ‘Surge’: A Survey of Baghdad Neighborhoods
text: To study the ground-level effects of the American troop buildup, reporters and video journalists for The New York Times visited Baghdad's neighborhoods, interviewing residents, Americans on patrol and Iraqi officials.

headline: Going Down the Road
text: Damien Cave, Diana Oliva Cave and Ruth Fremson traveled to central Florida to discover how small black communities along Route 17 have changed over past decades.

headline: Behind the Scenes at the MoCA benefit
text: This year's MoCA benefit, directed by the artist Doug Aitken, featured the singers Devendra Banhart, Beck and Caetano Veloso. A look behind the scenes at rehearsals.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: An aggregation of links by the reporters and editors of Diner’s Journal.

headline: Report Names Kosovo Leader as Crime Boss
text: PARIS  A two-year international inquiry has concluded that the prime minister of Kosovo led a clan of criminal entrepreneurs whose activities included trafficking in organs extracted from Serbian prisoners executed during the Kosovo conflict in 1999.

headline: DeMint Plans to Stall Arms Treaty
text: As the Senate prepares to take up President Obama’s new arms control treaty with Russia on Wednesday for the first time, a Republican opponent of the pact plans to force the entire text to be read in hopes of keeping it from being approved in the lame-duck session.

headline: Dannon Settles With F.T.C. Over Some Health Claims
text: The Dannon Company agreed to settle Federal Trade Commission charges that it had improperly claimed that some of its popular yogurt and dairy drinks could help prevent common illnesses and relieve irregularity, the commission announced Wednesday.

headline: That Lady With the Scales Poses for Her Portraits
text: In ancient Egypt she was known as Maat, the goddess of harmony and order, depicted in the Book of the Dead as a kind of personified jeweler’s scale, weighing a human heart against a feather to determine a soul’s fate in the afterlife.

headline: Wage Growth Slows in Western Nations
text: PARIS — The global financial and economic crisis led to a “considerable slowdown” in the growth of real wages in the West last year, while accentuating gaps between the highest and lowest earners in many countries, according to a United Nations report released on Wednesday.

headline: Looking at Lady Justice
text: Images from a new book, “Representing Justice,” which examines the iconography of Lady Justice and her blindfold.

headline: McConnell Seeks Tide-Us-Over Plan, Not Yearlong ‘Binge’
text: The Senate Republican leader, Mitch McConnell of Kentucky, accused Congressional Democrats on Wednesday of attempting “one last spending binge” before Republicans take control of the House in January and occupy six more seats in the Senate.

headline: Staph’s Trail Points to Human Susceptibilities
text: Scientists have finally found an answer to one of the great mysteries about the most deadly bacteria, Staphylococcus aureus  why it attacks primarily humans and not animals. And they now have an idea of why some humans are particularly susceptible to these bacteria that kill 100,000 Americans a year, far more than any other microbe.

headline: Now Sparkling | Cocotay’s Vintage Gems
text: Purchasing estate jewelry can be a daunting (and expensive) experience. The twins Coco and Tay Blaisdell took a fresh approach when they set up their brand Cocotay, curating antique gems and chains and restoring them. The best part? The pieces don’t cost a fortune. A clear rhinestone and emerald drop necklace ($225) has the same effect as the crown jewels, sans the pretension. Extracting the best elements of vintage pieces, the sisters rework them into fresh designs that blend the past with the present. This holiday season looks especially frosted.

headline: The Shock of a Simple Scene in Haiti
text: Frederic Dupoux, a 26-year-old sound engineer, was born and raised in Port-au-Prince, Haiti. As a photographer, he has worked for Getty Images and Le Monde. His conversation with Teresa Tomassoni, part of the Turning Point series on young photographers, has been edited.

headline: Chinese Shelter Operator Is Accused of Selling Laborers
text: BEIJING  The Quxian Beggars Shelter in Sichuan Province did not provide much in the way of succor to the bedraggled men who sought help from its founder, a pig farmer named Zeng Lingquan.

headline: Rangers Look to Join the N.H.L. Elite
text: PITTSBURGH  If the Rangers want to make the leap from a securely playoff-bound sixth-, seventh- or eighth-place team to top contender, they can do it on Wednesday night. A victory over the Penguins here would propel them up alongside Washington and Montreal, keep them ahead of hotly pursuing Boston and Tampa Bay  and, most emphatically, make people see the Rangers as one of the big boys.

headline: Mark Madoff’s Widow Speaks
text: Stephanie Madoff, the widow of Mark Madoff, issued a statement Wednesday morning through her spokeswoman, RoseMarie Terenzio. Mr. Madoff committed suicide on Saturday, the second anniversary of the arrest of his father, Bernard L. Madoff, who is serving a 150-year prison sentence for perpetrating an enormous Ponzi scheme.

headline: Some Checklists for Those Applying, or Already Decided
text: Ms. Dunham is the counseling department coordinator at Cherry Creek High in Denver, whose students are blogging their college admissions process in a series on The Choice.

headline: What Class Rank Says About Health
text: Do straight-A students live longer?

headline: Siemens to Sell I.T. Unit to Atos for $1.1 Billion
text: BERLIN — Siemens, the largest diversified industrial group in Germany, said on Wednesday that it had reached an agreement to sell its information technology solutions and services business to a French competitor, Atos Origin, for 850 million euros, or $1.1 billion.

headline: Reversing Course, a Former Holdout Pulls Iraq Toward a Political Anchor
text: BAGHDAD  Ayad Allawi, who years ago fought off ax-wielding assassins dispatched to London by Saddam Hussein’s secret police, is not a man to concede defeat easily. And he still would not  exactly  on Wednesday.

headline: Patriot League Puts Off Decision on Football Scholarships
text: The Patriot League has delayed a decision on awarding football scholarships for at least two years and will continue to field its teams with a need-based financial-aid system.

headline: From Behind Bars, T. I. Has a Top 10 Debut
text: T. I. may be impeded from many things while he serves a prison sentence after a recent parole violation, but not from cracking the Top 10 on the album sales chart. This rapper’s latest release, “No Mercy,” sold 159,000 copies in its first week, according to Nielsen Soundscan figures reported by Billboard.com, good enough to make it No. 4 for the week but a far cry from the 568,000 copies his previous album, “Paper Trail,” sold in its first week in 2008 when it made its debut at No. 1. This week’s top seller was once again “The Gift,” by Susan Boyle, which moved 243,000 copies and has racked up 1.43 million sales in five weeks.

headline: Nets’ Hidden Benefit in a Carmelo Anthony Trade
text: In what seems to be an obvious prelude to their further pursuit of Carmelo Anthony, the Nets will reportedly ship out the versatile and talented Terrence Williams in exchange for two first-round picks. The reported move would give New Jersey a total of five first-rounders in the next two drafts, a collection of assets that when paired with the No. 3 pick Derrick Favors, should be more than enough to satisfy the Denver Nuggets in a potential trade.

headline: British Mall Owner Rejects Simon Property’s Bid
text: 7:52 p.m. | Updated The board of Capital Shopping Centers of Britain rebuffed a $4.8 billion overture on Wednesday from the American developer Simon Property, the latest development in the highly contentious mating dance between the two mall owners.

headline: Orwell and the Financial Crisis
text: Barry Ritholtz catches AEI purging mention of deregulation from Peter Wallison’s bio. Wallison is co-director of AEI’s financial deregulation project; but he’s also one of the Gang of Four demanding that the Financial Crisis Inquiry Commission not so much as mention deregulation in its report.

headline: Senate Democrats Try New Route to Repealing ‘Don’t Ask, Don’t Tell’
text: 5:30 p.m. | Update The House of Representatives voted to approve a repeal of “don’t ask, don’t tell,” 250 to 175.

headline: Political Rashomon on Financial Crisis Panel
text: What caused the financial crisis? You might want to check someone’s political voting record before asking. It comes down to partisanship, as our colleague Sewell Chan reports on Wednesday.

headline: Sunday Senate Session Evokes an Old-Time Sermon
text: With Democrats hoping to hash through a busy end-of-year agenda, the majority leader, Harry Reid of Nevada, announced on Wednesday morning that he would keep the Senate in session on Sunday.

headline: How to Choose Between Fish and Farmers?
text: It is safe to say that the fight over the tiny delta smelt has few rivals in the annals of drawn-out endangered species controversies — and this for a fish that is not even formally listed as endangered. On federal and state lists, the fish, which spends its time in the brackish waters of the San Francisco Bay Delta, is merely threatened.

headline: Discovering a Grandfather’s Link to Civil Rights
text: George Edmund Haynes died in 1960, 10 months before his grandson, Bruce D. Haynes, was born. Growing up in Harlem, Bruce was never told much about him.

headline: A Modern-Day Greek Drama
text: David Brooks: Gail, do you mind if I talk to you about death? There were two deaths this week that are on my mind in very different ways, but somehow both take me back to classical Greece.
