headline: With Facebook Tie, Clicker Wants to Be Personal Web TV Guide
text: Clicker, a guide to television shows on the Internet, wants to be more personal.

headline: ‘Tron: Legacy': The Motion Comics Treatment
text: With the highly anticipated release of “Tron: Legacy” on Friday the question arises of how to pass on to a new generation the fan enthusiasm that made the original 1982 “Tron” movie a cult favorite.

headline: What’s in a (First) Name
text: The e-mail from a reader, Kris DeWeese, put her concern front and center, right in the subject line: Please write about calling elderly by their first names.

headline: Kicking Mom Out of Playgroup
text: Zibby Right spent three years staying home with her twins, their days a whirlwind of activity (and activities). She knew all along that when preschool began they would have less time — and she even found a job (she’s working over at the groupon-like site Gaggle of Chicks) and was looking forward to the hours of the day she would have back for grown-up things.

headline: Slumping Magic Looking for a Spark
text: Certain spots in Orlando call themselves the Happiest Place on Earth, but the Magic locker room is not one of them.

headline: Quote Unquote | Welcome to 2010
text: –John Galliano tells Women’s Wear Daily about his sudden realization that he is living in the 21st century.

headline: Border Patrol Agent Dies in Shootout in Arizona
text: PHOENIX  A late-night shootout Tuesday between Border Patrol agents and gunmen in a remote area of Arizona near the border with Mexico left one agent dead and four suspects in custody, and the authorities said they were searching Wednesday for one man who got away.

headline: The Caucus: Obama and Business Leaders
text: President Obama met with chief executives from approximately 20 corporations on Wednesday morning to try to reset his relationship with American business, John Harwood of CNBC and The New York Times reports.

headline: Games and Other Diversions to Turn Into Holiday Gifts
text: Software has long been a popular holiday present, at least if video games count. But this year could signal the emergence of a new trend: apps as gifts.

headline: Searching for Clues in a Western Whodunit
text: Forget John Wayne, the Dude and the breakout teen star. There was one topic of gossip at the New York premiere of “True Grit” on Tuesday night: what’s up with the Golden Globes?

headline: Watch Out for Bylsma in HBO’s “24/7″
text: Move over, Rex Ryan. Bruce Boudreau and Dan Bylsma are about to take over HBO.

headline: In Defense of $500 Shoes
text: Ramit Sethi runs the Web site, I Will Teach You To Be Rich.

headline: Praying for Rain in Iraq
text: BAGHDAD — One day not long ago, as the sun shone relentlessly, several hundred Muslims gathered here in the Imam al-Adham Mosque to hold a special prayer associated with times of crisis.

headline: TimesCast | December 15, 2010
text: An update on health care reform; new guidelines for surviving a nuclear attack; and 50 years after the Park Slope plane crash.

headline: Report Forecasts Steady Growth for City’s Economy
text: New York City’s economy will grow at a steadily rising pace over the next few years, though unemployment will decline only gradually, according to a report from the economists in the city comptroller’s office that was released on Wednesday.

headline: Drury Tries to Fit Into Upbeat Rangers Locker Room
text: PITTSBURGH — Chris Drury, the soft-spoken veteran team captain, is back in the Rangers dressing room, recovered from a broken index finger and ready to play for the first time in eight weeks.

headline: House Set to Follow Senate in Approving Tax Deal
text: WASHINGTON — The Senate on Wednesday approved the $858 billion tax plan negotiated by the White House and Republican leaders, and House Democrats said they expected to pass the bill on Thursday after a final, and seemingly futile, effort to change a provision that benefits wealthy estates.

headline: A Jittery Night in Moscow After Rumors of a Demonstration
text: MOSCOW  Moscow was jittery on Wednesday after rumors spread that migrants from the Caucasus planned a street protest in response to the weekend’s ethnic attacks.

headline: YouTube Said to Seek a Producer of Web Video
text: SAN FRANCISCO  YouTube, the video site owned by Google, is in talks to buy Next New Networks, a Web video production company, according to two people briefed on the discussions. The acquisition would be YouTube’s first major foray into producing original content, and demonstrates how intently it is focused on offering professional videos rather than just short clips by amateurs.

headline: Vocabulinks
text: An occasional assemblage of notable vocabulary and linguistic debate from around the Web.

headline: A Business Owner Reflects on a Failure to Pay His Taxes
text: On his way from Philadelphia to the Jersey Shore for some senior-week revelry in the early ’80s, 17-year-old Gary Barbera had business on his mind. He had seen a newspaper advertisement for a 1971 Chevy Nova and decided to buy it  not for cruising with his buddies but as an investment. Later that week, after giving the Nova a good wash and some detailing, he sold his very first car, at a profit of $360.

headline: Homes for $700,000
text: A two-bedroom house in Los Angeles, an ancient property in Rhode Island and a standalone condo in Washington state.

headline: Flogging Video Sparks Protest in Sudan
text: Dozens of women were arrested in the Sudanese capital, Khartoum, on Tuesday, at a protest sparked by graphic video that appeared to show a Sudanese woman being flogged by laughing police officers.

headline: Just One Look | Burberry Pre-Fall Collection
text: The Pre-Fall Collections, being shown in New York over the next several weeks, arrive in stores in May to fill the gap between bikinis and furs.

headline: Any Requests?
text: While Mr. Silver is on vacation, and the posting here is somewhat less frequent, we thought it would be a good time to invite fans of FiveThirtyEight (FiveThirtyEighters? FiveThirtyEightians?) to weigh in on their favorite posts from the past.

headline: Chris Paine Returns with ‘Revenge of the Electric Car’
text: Chris Paine, director of the 2006 documentary “Who Killed the Electric Car?” says he was “shocked” by the runaway success of that film. The choice of words is appropriate, as Mr. Paine prepares that film’s sequel: the far more General Motors-friendly “Revenge of the Electric Car”

headline: Have You Been Tempted to Cheat on Your Taxes?
text: We’ve just published a conversation with Gary Barbera, a Philadelphia auto dealer who pleaded guilty to filing false tax returns and was recently sentenced to three years’ probation. He says he neglected to tell his accountant about certain bonus checks he’d been awarded by Chrysler. Now under house arrest, Mr. Barbera must wear an ankle bracelet, but he is allowed to go to work every day to run his dealership.

headline: For Red Cross, Aid Conditions Hit New Low in Afghanistan
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  The International Committee of the Red Cross, which usually seeks to avoid the public eye, held a rare news conference here on Wednesday to express deep concern that Afghanistan security had deteriorated to its worst point since the overthrow of the Taliban nine years ago and was preventing aid groups from reaching victims of conflict.

headline: Jets Suspend a Coach Indefinitely
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  On Wednesday, the events surrounding the Jets, their sideline, their suspended strength coach and their great wall of inactive players felt like an N.F.L. version of a “A Few Good Men.”

headline: What You Get for ... $700,000
text: LOS ANGELES

headline: In London, a House in the Mews
text: A two-bedroom, two-bath house, once a stables for horses, is on the market for $2.4 million.

headline: F.D.A. Issues New Warning on Illegal Supplements
text: The Food and Drug Administration issued a broad new warning about some dietary supplements and bodybuilding and sexual enhancement products on Wednesday in a letter asking manufacturers and trade groups to help police the growing industry.

headline: House Hunting in ... London
text: A TWO-BEDROOM TWO-BATH MEWS HOUSE IN CENTRAL LONDON

headline: Margaret Mead Is Dead of Cancer at 76
text: Margaret Mead, the anthropologist, author, lecturer and social critic, died yesterday at New York Hospital after a yearlong battle with cancer. She was 76 years old.

headline:
PRESIDENT PROCLAIMS A NATIONAL
EMERGENCY; AUTO PRICES ROLLED
BACK; RAIL STRIKE ENDS; ALLIES
GIVE UP HAMHUNG; WU REJECTS
TRUCE
text: Washington, Dec. 16--President Truman proclaimed a state of emergency this morning and delegated many of his own war powers to Charles E. Wilson, the new Mobilization Director. Soon afterward the defense program moved into higher gear.

headline: Ski Trend: Sled-Like Mountain Coasters Offer Thrills
text: Carving a path down a mountain on skis or a snowboard takes training. But several ski resorts are now offering downhill thrills that don’t require any Alpine skills by installing mountain coasters.

headline: Beauty Spots
text: THICKENING AGENTS Sometimes the frizzy-haired girls get all the attention (at least when it comes to products). But there is help for the limp-locked: Living Proof, which makes the popular product No Frizz, recently introduced a new daily hair-care system called Full. The collection includes a sulfate-free shampoo and conditioner, a root-lifting spray and a thickening cream that the company says creates “a micro-pattern of thickening points on each strand.” Available at Sephora or LivingProof.com ($24 per item).

headline: Wildly Abrasive
text: NOT long ago, Jessica Chavkin, a children’s clothing designer who lives in Gramercy, returned from a two-week trip to smog-saturated Beijing and Shanghai, and booked a Deep Sea Detox massage and body wrap treatment, costing $165, at a Bliss spa. “My skin just felt puffy,” she said. She also spent $35 more for a process called dry brushing, which entailed natural bristles being run over her skin in short, quick strokes.

headline: Arthur Fiedler, 84, Conductor Of Boston Pops 50 Years, Dies
text: Arthur Fiedler, conductor of the Boston Pops Orchestra for 50 years and one of the world's best- known musical figures, died yesterday morning at his home in Brookline Mass. He was 84 years old.

headline: 4 Contractors Charged in $80 Million Fraud Scheme
text: Four contractors were arrested and charged Wednesday with misappropriating more than $80 million for work on the development of an automated timekeeping system for New York City employees.

headline: Twitter Courts Businesses to Advertise
text: Twitter has a message for businesses: the micro-blogging site is open for business.

headline: Making Middle Eastern Fruit Compote
text: I started cooking recipes from a book while I was living on Thompson Street in the spring of 1970 (in between demonstrations against the bombing of Cambodia and the like). Interestingly enough, the first book was Craig Claiborne‘s “New York Times Cookbook,” or perhaps his “Menu Cookbook,” or maybe both.

headline: Robert Moses, Master Builder, is Dead at 92
text: Robert Moses, who played a larger role in shaping the physical environment of New York State than any other figure in the 20th century, died early yesterday at West Islip, L.I. Mr. Moses, whose long list of public offices only begins to hint at his impact on both the city and state of New York, was 92 years old.

headline:
BIG ATOMIC PLANT NEAR PITTSBURGH
SUPPLYING POWER
text: Washington, Dec. 18--The country's first large-scale civilian atomic power plant started generating electricity for commercial use today.

headline: The 10 Things to Talk About This Weekend
text: 1. Book tours as preliminary presidential runs. Barnes & Noble is the new Iowa.

headline: Death Preceded Safety Agency’s Warning on Ford Windstar
text: The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration’s unusual warning last month to owners of more than half a million recalled Ford Windstars to quickly fix rusty rear axles before they could break was prompted in part by the death of a Massachusetts man.

headline: Brezhnev Attempted to Advance Soviet Goals Through Detente; Soviet Leader Used Consensus in Politburo on Domestic Issues
text: As the leader of the Soviet Union, Leonid Ilyich Brezhnev was a canny and careful Communist Party functionary who sought to make his country the military equal of the United States and promote its political influence around the world through the policy of detente.

headline: Britain and China Sign Agreement on Hong Kong
text: PEKING, Dec. 19 -- Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher today signed the agreement formally committing Britain to surrender Hong Kong to China in 1997 in return for terms guaranteeing a 50-year extension of its capitalist economic system.

headline: In Senate, a War of Words Over Christmas
text: Tensions are rising in Washington.

headline: Branch Rickey, 83, Dies in Missouri
text: COLUMBIA, Mo. Dec. 9--Branch Rickey, a dominant figure in baseball for half a century, died tonight in Boone County Memorial Hospital at the age of 83.

headline:
U.S. TROOPS MOVE IN PANAMA IN EFFORT TO SEIZE NORIEGA;
GUNFIRE IS HEARD IN CAPITAL
text: WASHINGTON, Wednesday, Dec. 20 -- The United States launched a military operation in Panama early this morning designed to topple the Government of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega.

headline: CNBC: A Recovery in Loan Demand
text: Todd Maclin, chief executive of commercial banking at JPMorgan Chase, tells CNBC that he has seen a recovery in the demand for loans since March.

headline: Will Cliff Lee Be Better Known in Philadelphia?
text: Cliff Lee’s decision to sign with the Philadelphia Phillies and leave millions on the table had some fans scratching their heads. But Lee also gave up the chance to make even more money through endorsements, advertisements and other business opportunities that he might have made playing in New York for the Yankees.

headline: ‘Driving Miss Daisy’ to Extend
text: Confirming recent speculation, the Broadway production of “Driving Miss Daisy,” starring Vanessa Redgrave, left, James Earl Jones and Boyd Gaines, will extend through April 9, 2011, the producers of the show announced Wednesday. All three actors will remain with the production, which was scheduled to run through Jan. 29, 2011.

headline: Stumptown at the Whitney
text: Today, a new coffee bar opened at the Whitney Museum of American Art. It’s in the garden level of Marcel Breuer’s brutalist masterpiece, a walnut-paneled coffee cart that’s acting as a place-holder until a new museum cafe will be opened by Union Square Hospitality Group in the spring. In the meantime, you can visit the coffee bar (without paying admission) and get a cappuccino made on a Strada, the next-generation pressure profiling espresso machine from La Marzocco.

headline: A Dance Troupe Thrives in Dayton
text: DAYTON, Ohio  This city has gone bust more than once, so a contemporary dance troupe that has lasted more than 40 years may be the ultimate example of cultural survival here.

headline: Goldman Sachs’ $111 Million Bonus Windfall
text: This year’s bonus may not matter much for some senior executives at Goldman Sachs.

headline: Techies as the Person of the Year Are Rare
text: At just 26, Mark Zuckerberg, the co-founder and chief executive of Facebook, is joining a select group of presidents, kings, popes, dictators, freedom fighters and other influential people selected by Time magazine as Person of the Year.

headline: Reader Idea | The Oil Spill as a Case Study in Technical Writing
text: Here is another in our Great Ideas From Readers series.

headline: Auto Research Group Says Mileage Mandate Will Cost Jobs
text: YPSILANTI, Mich.  A study by an auto industry research group said on Wednesday that requiring automakers to meet fuel economy standards of 60 miles per gallon by 2025 would decrease sales because cars and trucks would become more expensive, and could eliminate up to 1.3 million jobs nationwide.

headline: A Community of Teachers and Students Responds to the Gulf Oil Spill
text: I asked Paul Allison, an English teacher at the East-West School of International Studies in Flushing, Queens, and the technology liaison for the New York City Writing Project, to write a guest post for us about a school-based social media site that he and a group of teachers from the Gulf and around the country developed in response to this spring’s oil spill. (Full disclosure: I’ve known Paul since 1986, when I was his student teacher at New York City’s High School of Art and Design. We have also both been members of the New York City Writing Project for more than 25 years.)

headline: The Gulf Oil Spill as a Topic for Classroom Inquiry
text: Though the oil spill first happened in April, a brief glance at the regularly updated summary of events on the spill’s Times Topics page makes it clear that the scientific, environmental, economic, legal, political and emotional repercussions will be in the news for a long time.

headline: District 36
text: IS the democratic dance warehouse of the 1980s and ’90s back? That’s the bold ambition behind District 36, a new 14,800-square-foot dance club in the garment district that’s trying to recall the days when Paradise Garage and the Sound Factory dominated New York night life.

headline: Consider the Matter, and the Meeting, Closed
text: Be careful what you blog:

headline: ‘New Start’ Treaty Advances in Senate
text: The Senate voted on Wednesday to open debate on a new arms control treaty with Russia eight months after President Obama signed it, but opposition from Republican lawmakers have raised questions about whether Democrats can push the pact through before the end of the year.

headline: Obama Tries Charm Offensive on Group of Top Executives
text: WASHINGTON  Forget about the sharp critiques that President Obama leveled at Wall Street and corporate America during his first two years in office.

headline: How Much Did Jets Know About Alosi’s Sideline Wall?
text: Greg Bishop reported not long ago:

headline: Carlsen Wins London Chess Classic
text: Magnus Carlsen beat Nigel Short in the last round Wednesday to win the London Chess Classic for the second time.

headline: Twitter Financing Raises Its Value to $3.7 Billion
text: Twitter has raised a big new round of venture capital, $200 million, valuing the company at $3.7 billion.

headline: ‘Spa Living’ Condo to Get New Spa Operator
text: The developers of an East Side condo tower conceived as one of the country’s first “spa living” residences said Wednesday that they were forming a partnership with a new spa operator, American Leisure, after severing ties in October with Miraval, the resort based in Tucson.

headline: AMC Gets on Board Post-Civil War Drama ‘Hell on Wheels’
text: For its next original series AMC is going back to the ’60s — the 1860s, that is. On Wednesday AMC, the cable-television home of the period drama “Mad Men” (as well as “Breaking Bad” and “The Walking Dead”), said it had committed to a full season of “Hell on Wheels,” a series set in post-Civil War America. In a news release AMC said “Hell on Wheels,” which is created and written by the sibling screenwriters Joe and Tony Gayton (“Faster”), would star Anson Mount as Cullen Bohannan, a former soldier in the Confederate Army who, in searching for the Union soldiers who killed his wife, finds his way to a lawless town called Hell on Wheels, and to the construction of the first transcontinental railroad. The release said the series would explore “the railroad’s institutionalized greed and corruption, the immigrant experience and the plight of the newly emancipated African-Americans during Reconstruction.” Additional cast members include the rapper Common (whose acting credits include “Just Wright” and “Date Night”) and Colm Meaney (of the “Star Trek” spinoffs “The Next Generation” and “Deep Space Nine”); no premiere date has been announced.

headline: New Car Smell Blamed in Hit-and-Run
text: Many drivers enjoy the so-called “new car smell,” a mix of volatile organic compounds that rise from the plastic, leather, cloth, wood and other interior components of cars fresh off the assembly line. The aroma is so popular that some companies even sell “new car smell” air fresheners.

headline: U.S. Sues Companies for Spill Damages
text: The Department of Justice filed a civil lawsuit Wednesday in New Orleans against the oil giant BP and eight other companies over the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico.

headline: Fiscal Patriotism: Peterson Responds
text: I posted a blog item earlier this month expressing my disappointment that Pete Peterson used the phrase “fiscal patriotism” in commenting on the need to reduce budget deficits.

headline: The Best of 2010: 'Gatz'
text: Ben Brantley narrates a look the marathon reading of F. Scott Fitzgerald's novel "The Great Gatsby," staged by Elevator Repair Service.

headline: Toys for a Downtown Power Couple
text: FRIENDS who attended David Barton and Susanne Bartsch’s annual toy drive last Friday were surprised to read, a few days earlier in Page Six, that the couple had separated.

headline: Scene City: David Barton and Susanne Bartsch, Though Separated, Are Hosts of Toy Drive
text: The couple’s merged social circles were on display at the toy drive, now in its 10th year.

headline: A Video Whirlwhind of the Year in Movies
text: In case you didn’t catch it when it was making the Internet rounds yesterday, here is a cool montage of every movie released in 2010, from “Red” to “Inception” to “Burlesque,” along with other Golden Globe favorites. Clip reel, we salute you.

headline: Rate Your Parenting, Briefly
text: Abraham Piper, clearly a fan of brevity, runs a Web site called TwentytwoWords. His daily goal is to curate the Web into short snippets and to condense life into questions of less than two dozen words.

headline: Giants Lose Steve Smith for the Season
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  The receivers of Giants past made haunting appearances Wednesday at the team’s practice facility. Victor Cruz chatted up reporters in the locker room. Ramses Barden hobbled into the cafeteria with a walking boot.

headline: Europe Staggers as Critical Summit Looms
text: BERLIN  Europe’s smoldering financial crisis flared up on Wednesday, with riots over austerity spending in Greece, new signs of troubles in Spain and little indication that European leaders were moving any closer to agreement on a systemic approach to long-term stability.

headline: BMW and Subaru Have Best Resale Value, Says Kelley Blue Book
text: BMW and Subaru are the 2011 model-year winners of the Kelley Blue Book Best Resale Value Awards, which is based on the publication’s projection of how well new models are expected to retain their original list price after five years of ownership.

headline: Bing: Still Trying to Keep Up With Google
text: 6:35 p.m. | Updated to reflect that the Bing feature that allows users to continuously scroll through image results is not new.

headline: ‘Messiah’ Season, in All of Its Hues
text: You might think that the fixation musical organizations have on Handel’s “Messiah” at this time of year would get old quickly, given that this big work’s domination of so many concert halls and churches reduces the variety of New York’s musical life. Yet the annual parade of “Messiah” performances offers a fascinating variety all its own. Instrument design and performing sensibilities have changed radically since the work’s 1742 premiere, and competing performing traditions have arisen, the latest based on the conceit that contemporary musicians can approximate Handel’s sound world.

headline: Speaking of Henry Ford
text: Over at Jalopnik, Justin Hyde takes note of an article by Henry Ford that ran in The New York Times in 1931. To observe the newspaper’s 80 years of publishing, The Times’s editors sought views of the next 80 years from several notable people, including William James Mayo, a founder of the Mayo Clinic.

headline: An Android Phone That Says ‘Google’
text: As the year winds down, we’ve all got problems. Economic slump. Wars. Unemployment.

headline: Some Books for the Stockings of Less-Experienced Players
text: In the next two columns let’s look at some of the items you might buy for the bridge player on your give-to list. For the less experienced, many good products came out in the past year. The first four are by two of the most prolific bridge book writers on the planet.

headline: Sing Out, Maria: Tyne Daly Brings Her ‘Master Class’ to Broadway
text: Tyne Daly will play Maria Callas in the Manhattan Theater Club’s coming Broadway production of the Terrence McNally play “Master Class.” Additional casting is still to be announced.

headline: Park Slope Plane Crash | Covering the Story
text: They called it the “Brooklyn shack,” a warren of newspaper offices near the Police Department’s Park Slope precinct station house, and the reporters were sitting there, divining the direction of that particular Friday morning’s news, when they were rocked by the crash that seemed to split the sky open.

headline: Paulson’s New Highly Regulated Hedge Fund
text: Big European institutions looking to invest with John Paulson but without all those pesky restrictions like lock-up periods now have another option: a unique share class of the manager’s flagship fund that’s more highly regulated than the original.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Greece and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Greece, India, Russia and Iran.

headline: Stepping Out in Style, and Comfort
text: WHEN Toi Washington, 34, began her search for knee-high boots, her requirements were simple. They had to be cute and comfortable. Ms. Washington usually wears labels like BCBG Generation, but she is not particularly loyal to any one brand. To her surprise, two pairs of Naturalizers caught her eye, and she didn’t hesitate to buy both. It was her first comfort footwear purchase.

headline: Virgin Atlantic Says It’s Been Approached About Deals
text: Richard Branson’s Virgin Atlantic Airways has received recent approaches about potential partnerships with other carriers, the British airline said on Wednesday.

headline: New Car Smell Blamed in Hit-and-Run
text: From our colleagues at the Green blog:

headline: What Happened Was… | How Doug Aitken Stole the Show, part II
text: You had to be there.

headline: Bon Jovi Gets White House Appointment
text: Jon Bon Jovi ain’t gonna be just a face in the crowd. You’re gonna hear his voice, when he shouts it out loud — at the White House Council for Community Solutions.

headline: Shopping With Philip Gorrivan
text: An interior designer went shopping for attractive doormats for the city or the country.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Greece and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Greece, India, Russia and Iran.

headline: American Express Gives $100,000 to Help Ellis Island Group
text: On the brink of extinction last spring, the nonprofit organization charged with restoring Ellis Island will benefit from a $100,000 gift from American Express, the credit card company is to announce on Thursday.

headline: Making a Photo Book With Scanned Images
Katabatic Winds of Antarctica
text: John Goodge, left, a professor of geological sciences at the University of Minnesota-Duluth, and Jeff Vervoort, an isotope geochemist from Washington State University, will be writing occasional posts from their research expedition in Antarctica.

headline: Using Winter Squash al Dente
text: When cooking Italianate dishes with winter squash or pumpkin, I almost always cook the squash until it is very soft. For ravioli fillings I generally roast it, yielding a puree that is relatively low in moisture and that benefits from caramelization in the oven; for risottos I typically cook the squash with onions or shallots before the rice even goes in, then add more once I begin moistening the rice with liquid — or use roasted squash. And very good it all is, in that dense, pumpkin-pie way we’re used to with these fruits.

headline: Noel in the Museum, Medieval Edition
text: Despite a hiatus of sorts in recent years, on the eve of its 25th-anniversary season, Anonymous 4 seems as strong as ever, continuing to demonstrate the qualities that have made it a perennially popular a cappella ensemble. In the Metropolitan Museum’s acoustically vibrant Medieval Sculpture Hall on Tuesday evening, the four women sang with their trademark vocal blend, sparing use of vibrato and purity of tone in a program called “Noel: Four Centuries of Christmas.”

headline: MoMA Sending Abstract Expressionists to Canada
text: For the last three months they have been taking a star turn at their home, the Museum of Modern Art, in the sprawling “Abstract Expressionist New York” show. But in an unexpected move, a host of paintings by Jackson Pollock, Mark Rothko, Robert Motherwell, Lee Krasner and other titans of the New York School will soon be heading north on tour. The museum announced Wednesday that the exhibition – or at least a large chunk of it – would travel to the Art Gallery of Ontario, where it will be on display from May 28 through Sept. 4. The show will feature about 100 well-known works from the Modern’s collection. And as of now, the Art Gallery of Ontario – once run by Glenn D. Lowry, the Modern’s director – will be the only other site to host the exhibition.

headline: Twitter Financing Raises Its Value to $3.7 Billion
text: Twitter, the micro-blogging phenomenon, raised $200 million in a new round of venture capital financing led by Kleiner Perkins Caulfield & Byers, Claire Cain Miller of The New York Times reports. Spark Capital, Benchmark Capital and Union Square Ventures also participated.

headline: Juilliard Players Join the Fierce Give and Take of a Prokofiev Concerto
text: The Juilliard Orchestra, the school’s flagship student ensemble, can, as you might expect, handle just about any music you put in front of it, and it seems likely that its public concerts would pack Alice Tully Hall even if they were not free. As it is, the tickets disappear quickly, and listeners hoping for seats released at the last minute form a line down West 65th Street.

headline: Michigan Republican to Head House Intel Panel
text: Representative Mike Rogers, a Michigan Republican, has been tapped to chair the House Intelligence Committee in the next Congress.

headline: 2 in Race to Lead Johnson & Johnson
text: After a year marked by embarrassing consumer product calls, Johnson and Johnson on Wednesday set in motion a horse race between two longtime executives to succeed William C. Weldon, 62, the chief executive and chairman.

headline: Suffering of a Noble, Romantic Soul Man
text: Tank opened his Tuesday night show at S.O.B.’s with a harangue, lamenting the decline of the sort of classic soul he prefers, and proffers, in favor of music that’s younger and dumber. He suggested he should maybe give up singing for rapping, or maybe make an illicit sex tape to get noticed, an unkind allusion to R. Kelly’s legal troubles. He wouldn’t have to consider these options, though, if only R&B was how it used to be.

headline: Home Labs on the Rise for the Fun of Science
text: One day Kathy Ceceri noticed a tick on her arm and started to worry that it was the kind that carried Lyme disease. So she went to her home lab, put the tiny arachnid under her microscope, which is connected to her computer through a U.S.B. cable, and studied the image.

headline: Theater Talkback: When Familiar Words Are Heard Anew
text: “Wahuhrah, wahuhrah …,” exasperated pause, “words.” That, more or less, is how Rory Kinnear pronounces the immortal redundancy “words, words, words” in Nicholas Hytner’s new production of “Hamlet” for the National Theater in London. Those words (words, words) have of course been uttered more times than any calculator could compute.

headline: Looking at Income Class and Votes for Obama
text: In light of the Census Bureau’s release on Tuesday of data from the American Community Survey, a blogger from The Big Picture who writes under the pseudonym Invictus suggested we investigate how income may have affected the 2008 presidential election.

headline: Large Gulf Remains in Stuyvesant Town Rent Case
text: Landlords and tenants appear to be far apart on what the legal rents should be for thousands of apartments in the beleaguered Stuyvesant Town and Peter Cooper Village complexes on the East Side of Manhattan.

headline: Downtown Stalwarts Flock to a Gay Wedding
text: One of the often overlooked accomplishments of the experimental theater scene in New York is the longevity of its major figures. Richard Foreman and the Wooster Group have been producing consistently for decades. Following them, artists like Richard Maxwell and the Elevator Repair Service have built long, fertile careers without the usual detours to Hollywood made by more mainstream artists. There is a real pleasure not only in following these artists as they evolve over years, but also in their kind of often elusive work, which provides valuable and revealing context.

headline: New Feud Over Oversight Panel Job
text: The night before Democratic leaders were expected to tap Representative Edolphus Towns as the party’s senior member on the House oversight committee in the next Congress, Mr. Towns abruptly announced he wasn’t up for the job.

headline: House Easily Passes ‘Don’t Ask, Don’t Tell’ Repeal
text: The House of Representatives Wednesday handily approved a repeal of a ban on gay men and lesbians serving openly in the military, ratcheting up the pressure on Senate Republicans who have resisted holding a vote to overturn the ban on procedural grounds.

headline: MDC, Often Acquisitive, Makes Another Deal
text: MDC Partners, the advertising holding company that owns agencies like Crispin Porter & Bogusky and Kirshenbaum Bond Senecal & Partners, is making another acquisition.

headline: Watching ‘The Fish’ Fade to Black
text: MAX FISH, a bar on the Lower East Side of Manhattan, celebrated its 21st anniversary last Sunday. Balloons adorned the pastel walls, tin trays freighted with lasagna and chickpeas were unwrapped, and rock bands thundered through sets in the back lounge. But the mood was less exuberant than reflective. Days earlier, patrons learned that the storied dive bar would be shuttered at the end of January, another victim of high rent.

headline: A Winning ‘Loser’
text: NBC’s two-hour season finale of “The Biggest Loser” on Tuesday night attracted 11 million viewers, the show’s largest audience in almost a year, according to Nielsen’s estimates. Although that reality series drew higher ratings for its fall finale in 2009 (13.5 million), NBC still easily ranked second for the night over all, earning 7.7 million at 8 for its game show “Minute to Win It.” CBS dominated the night at No. 1, leading during every time slot and producing the night’s largest audience with “NCIS” at 8 (19.8 million). Following it, CBS’s “NCIS: Los Angeles” drew 16.8 million at 9, while “The Good Wife” attracted 11.7 million at 10. In third and fourth places, Fox and ABC broadcast mostly repeats.

headline: Thursday’s Week 15 N.F.L. Matchup: 49ers at Chargers
text: 49ers (5-8) at Chargers (7-6)Thursday, 8:20 p.m.Line: Chargers by 9

headline: Heeding Audience Cues and Ping-Pong Balls
text: A contest involving swigs of whiskey forms one section of Witness Relocation’s “I’m Going to Make a Small Incision Behind Your Ear to Check and See if You’re Actually Human.” This is called “Worst Whiskey Contest”; a brief journalistic investigation on opening night last week at the Bushwick Starr unearthed that the title comes from the quality of the alcohol (Philadelphia, $9.99 a liter, for those connoisseurs of economy out there).

headline: The Financial Impact of Divorce on College Students
text: Here’s some more evidence of how divorce is utterly devastating to one’s financial life – and the financial lives of one’s family.

headline: U.S. Rethinks Strategy for the Unthinkable
text: Suppose the unthinkable happened, and terrorists struck New York or another big city with an atom bomb. What should people there do? The government has a surprising new message: Do not flee. Get inside any stable building and don’t come out till officials say it’s safe.

headline: Angry Birds Takes Over the iPhone
text: For $25, lovers of Angry Birds can now display their affection for the game by buying cases for the iPhone and iPod Touch that display the various characters in the game. You can choose between red or yellow kamikaze heroes, or one of the smirking  green pigs.

headline: Agreement Seems Near on Long-Stalled Lower East Side Project
text: The Lower East Side may be in the grips of a full-on gentrification, with a rotating cast of boutiques, hotels and cafes continuously flocking there, but several forlorn patches of land have remained frozen in time.

headline: For Kevin Spacey, a Reviled Lobbyist Is No Mere Villain
text: In its current state Facebook has many virtues. Moviemaking is not among them.

headline: New Chancellor Getting Up to Speed, in a Hurry
text: Cathleen P. Black rounded the corner Wednesday on two weeks of whirlwind school visits to prepare for her new job as city schools chancellor, stopping in for 45 minutes at the high-performing Medgar Evers College Preparatory School in Crown Heights, Brooklyn.

headline: Wid Chapman’s Vivid Dormitory Commons in Brooklyn
text: Many colleges have residences for their students. Those that don’t often rely on companies like Educational Housing Services, in Manhattan, which builds and operates dorms and student lounges that colleges can rent — like the one in Brooklyn Heights, designed by Wid Chapman.

headline: The New I:Wing Fan
text: The i:wing, which mimics the movements of a bird in flight, is more than just a new kind of fan. It’s like a robotic, breeze-making pet.

headline: Painting Without Pain: The Basics
text: WHEN I first painted houses during summer breaks from college, I was lucky no one was watching. My abstract period, as I like to remember it, was an oil-over-latex, enamel-on-glass, dripping binge of experimentalism that paved the way for latter-day masterpieces.

headline: Sales at Ligne Roset, Intérieurs and Others
text: During the Dransfield & Ross sample sale, today and Friday, pillows, linens and decorative accessories will be marked way down (fake crocodile frames, originally $59, are $15; 16-inch round fake shagreen placemats, regularly $34, are $12; occasional tables, originally $405, are $140); 54 West 21st Street (Fifth Avenue), Suite 1201, (212) 741-7278 or dransfieldandross.biz.

headline: Lillian August Opens in Manhattan
text: Lillian August doesn’t do anything small scale. The 23-year-old company’s flagship store in Connecticut is 75,000 square feet; its first New York City store, which opened last week, is a mere 17,000.

headline: Doormats
text: AS winter approaches, and shoes and boots begin to accumulate muck, a good doormat comes in handy. For an interior designer like Philip Gorrivan, though, finding attractive doormats is a year-round quest.

headline: Charlie Baker on Creating Windows for Hermès
text: It’s the time of year when the windows of most Madison Avenue retailers are dressed up for the holidays with Christmas trees and other seasonal decorations. The ones at Hermès, however, stand stylistically apart from the rest. There are plenty of trees — but not of the evergreen variety.

headline: Up Close: A Party Planner of Choice
text: Bronson Van Wyck was recently named the readers’-choice event designer of the year by BizBash. Here are some examples of his party designs.

headline: Antiques Cherished for Their Imperfections
text: Make-do’s — scarred, centuries-old domestic objects that were mended in unusual ways — have a devoted following and a deconstructed aesthetic that would look at home in a high-end design store.

headline: Leaving the Tinsel to Professional Hands
text: Three designers and the homes that they’ve fluffed for clients during the holiday season.

headline: ‘Somewhere’ There Is a Free Lunch
text: “I can’t believe it, you came late and you got something that is that exciting,” Nora Ephron said to the Bagger at a lunch for “Somewhere” on Wednesday afternoon, peering jealously at our plate: sweet potato ravioli with brown butter, winter squash and a few bright cranberries. Have some, we said, and a forkful was gone.

headline: Tree-Trimming Advice From the Experts
text: PHOEBE HOWARD, a Florida decorator, got her start in the design business by providing Christmas decorating services. At one point, she was fluffing four houses a day. She suggests putting out citrus, pomegranates and cranberries mixed together in bowls with fresh greens, as she once did. “It smells good and looks good,” Ms. Howard said.

headline: Even the Tree Has a Stylist
text: CAMPION PLATT, an architect known for designing swanky spaces like Manhattan’s MercBar, renovated the Upper West Side town house owned by his publicist, R. Couri Hay, this year. And as a special favor, later this week he plans to decorate Mr. Hay’s Christmas tree for him. There will be lavender tinsel, one garland of signed Warhol dollar bills and another made from celebrity photographs Mr. Hay snipped from magazines during the year  images of his “favorite scandals and beauties,” Mr. Platt said, including Tiger Woods, Lindsay Lohan and Carla Bruni. A video installation showing moody black-and-white Manhattan holiday images, which is also Mr. Platt’s firm’s Christmas greeting, will be playing continuously on Mr. Hay’s flat-screen television. To be sure, Mr. Platt is doing a bit of cross-pollinating by planting his name on Mr. Hay’s festivities, but he is also making sure that the decorations for Mr. Hay’s annual Christmas party are on a par with the interior architecture.

headline: In Make-Do Objects, Collectors Find Beauty Beyond Repair
text: REUSE is all the rage these days: Witness the rise of fixers, tinkerers and hackers  that scrappy set of do-it-yourselfers who gather in collectives from Brooklyn to Berlin to breathe new life into broken objects that would have been consigned to the junk heap a few years earlier.

headline: A-List Parties: More Taste, Less Flash
text: AMONG the heirloom antiques that Bronson Van Wyck, the Manhattan party planner, keeps in his cavernous Flatiron district apartment is a giant map of England from the 1930s, on which each social engagement of King George VI was meticulously plotted.

headline: Old Meets Efficient in an English Terrace House
text: The Christophers family lives in an 1840s house in Birmingham, England, retrofitted to be carbon neutral.

headline: An English House That Generates as Much as It Consumes
text: BIRMINGHAM, England

headline: Tannenbaum Talks About Alosi and Building of Jets’ Wall
text: The transcript of General Manager Mike Tannenbaum’s conference call with reporters on Wednesday, as provided by the Jets. Tannenbaum said that the strength coach Sal Alosi had told inactive players to stand side by side on the sideline to obstruct Dolphins players on punts. A previous post discussed the ethics of that and whether other Jets might have known.

headline: Tech Talk Podcast: Loving Your Phone
text: Just how attached are you to that smartphone? Would you say you’re in love? J.D. Biersdorfer chats with Damon Darlin, the technology editor for The New York Times, about gadgets becoming objects of affection – at least until they’re replaced. Mr. Darlin says that electronic devices have become increasingly personal, often functioning as extensions of our brains, and it is the software we really love.

headline: Front Row: Unbridled Fashion Returns to the Red Carpet
text: Cases of individuality have emerged at recent red carpet events, a change from the safe choices celebrities have made for fear of style pundits’ judgments.

headline: Writer Races to Victory From Way Off the Pace
text: KALAMAZOO, Mich. — Jaimy Gordon’s novel “Lord of Misrule,” which won the National Book Award for fiction last month, was such a long shot that even Ms. Gordon and her publisher, Bruce McPherson, didn’t think it had much of a chance. Ms. Gordon wore an old dress to the award ceremony and didn’t bother to prepare any remarks. On learning that the book had been selected as a finalist, Mr. McPherson, the owner and sole full-time employee of McPherson & Company, a tiny press in Kingston, N.Y., only reluctantly upped the print run to 8,000 copies, from 2,000.

headline: On Our Radar: Cold in Florida, Chinese Premier in India
text: Near-record cold descends on Florida, but fruit growers say they have so far emerged relatively unscathed. “We certainly did not have anything catastrophic last night,” an orange grower says after night temperatures drop below freezing. [Reuters]

headline: Red Carpet Dress-Up Is Stylish Again
text: IS it safe for unbridled fashion to return to the red carpet?

headline: TV Cables: Making the Right Connection
text: Sam Grobart discusses the different kinds of television cables, and advises against buying needlessly expensive ones.

headline: An Enforcer for Consumer Finance Rules
text: Richard Cordray, Ohio’s attorney general, is about to take his battle against foreclosure fraud, abusive payday lenders and misbehaving global financial houses to Washington.

headline: A Sherlock Holmes Tale That’s Hardly Elementary
text: “Perhaps the greatest of the Sherlock Holmes mysteries is this: that when we talk of him we invariably fall into the fancy of his existence,” T .S. Eliot wrote in a 1929 review of “The Complete Sherlock Holmes Short Stories.”

headline: Newly Released Books
text: With “Armageddon,” “Disaster” and “Cruelty” in their titles, some of this month’s new books don’t seem to have the holiday spirit. But in the hands of a gifted novelist or a clever illustrator, prison, grief, infidelity — even the end of the world — have their pleasures.

headline: Bank of America Starts Talks on Soured Mortgages
text: In a bid to turn down the temperature in what promises to be an extended legal battle, Bank of America has opened a dialogue with investors who want the bank to buy back tens of billions in soured mortgages.

headline: Is Google Too Big to Shop?
text: This week, Steve Pearlstein, a columnist for The Washington Post, locked horns with Google over the thorny subject of the search giant’s dominance and its quest to spread into new corners of the Web by buying other companies.

headline: Browsing: Shopping Snapshots for Dec. 16
text: After 10 years with Lutz & Patmos, Marcia Patmos has introduced her own collection; boot selections for the season and more.

headline: California: Sheriff’s Deputies Brawl
text: Seven Los Angeles County sheriff’s deputies have been suspended from duty after a brawl at a holiday party for employees of Men’s Central Jail. About 100 people had gathered last Friday at the Quiet Cannon banquet hall in Montebello when an argument involving several deputies turned violent around 11:30 p.m. No shots were fired, but at least two people were injured, according to a sheriff’s spokesman, Steve Whitmore. All the deputies involved have been suspended with pay, but the department released little other information.

headline: The Americans Are in Our House. What Will the Taliban Think?
text: KUNDUZ, Afghanistan—Life in troubled Kunduz Province can be summed up in a word: precarious. [see Alissa J. Rubin’s Times story Taliban Extend Reach to North, Where Armed Groups Reign]

headline: Showing Their True College Colors
text: Passion for college football can be found just about everywhere – including the floor of the House of Representatives.

headline: Los Angeles Schools to Seek Sponsors
text: LOS ANGELES  The football field at a public school here, in the second largest school district in the country, soon may be brought to students by Nike.

headline: MacKenzie Miller, Trained Champion Horses, Dies at 89
text: MacKenzie Miller, who trained champion thoroughbred horses for nearly half a century and at the age of 71 saddled the 1993 Kentucky Derby winner, Sea Hero, died on Dec. 10 in Lexington, Ky. He was 89.

headline: China’s Push Into Wind Worries U.S. Industry
text: PIPESTONE, Minn. — Finishing the 20-story climb up a ladder inside a wind-turbine tower, Scott Rowland opened the top hatch to reveal a panorama of flat farmland dotted with dozens of other turbines.

headline: Counting the Victims in a Honeymoon Killing
text: GUGULETU, South Africa  The Honeymoon Murder, as the crime is often called, has proved to be more than a riveting whodunit. South Africa’s honor seems on the line, as is the dignity of Guguletu, this crime-bedeviled township near Cape Town where the abduction happened.

headline: At the Garden, the Buzz Is Back, and So Are the Knicks
text: Sent an e-mail to somebody Wednesday afternoon that ended, “I’m at the Knicks game.”

headline: Louisiana: Ex-Official Guilty
text: Anthony Jones on Wednesday became the second chief technology officer under former Mayor C. Ray Nagin of New Orleans to plead guilty to federal charges related to a kickback scheme involving a vendor. Mr. Jones is charged with conspiracy to commit bribery for accepting $20,000 in payoffs in 2006 and 2007 in exchange for “approving and expediting payments” to companies owned or controlled by Mark St. Pierre, a technology vendor. Last month, Greg Meffert, pleaded guilty to federal charges and admitted receiving nearly $900,000 in kickbacks in exchange for steering millions of dollars of work to Mr. St. Pierre. Mr. St. Pierre is facing trial in February. Mr. Jones was demoted from chief technology officer in 2008 for claiming that he had a college degree, which was untrue, and forced to resign in 2009 for a variety of reasons, including filing false invoices.

headline: Q&A: FIFA’s Chuck Blazer
text: Chuck Blazer is the general secretary of Concacaf, the regional confederation that includes the United States. He is also the only American on FIFA’s powerful 24-man executive committee (a member since 1996), which recently awarded the 2018 and 2022 World Cups to Russia and Qatar. He said he cast his vote for Russia (2018) and the United States (2022), which lost out to Qatar in the fourth round of voting. Blazer spoke by telephone on Monday with Jack Bell of The Times from Abu Dhabi, where he is serving of the chairman of the committee that oversees the Club World Cup.

headline: Ruling Is Upheld Against Executives Tied to OxyContin
text: A federal district judge in Washington has upheld the disbarment of three former top executives of the company that made the prescription painkiller OxyContin, ruling that they should still be prohibited from involvement in any government-financed health care program.

headline: At Carlyle, an Effort to Close the Gender Gap
text: As a young investment banker, Karen H. Bechtel could remember standing out at high-level corporate board meetings for one reason: She was the only woman present.

headline: Kilpatrick Indicted in Criminal Ring
text: DETROIT  The city’s imprisoned former mayor, Kwame M. Kilpatrick, and two top aides rigged contracts, collected millions of dollars in bribes and defrauded taxpayers, the federal government said on Wednesday in a 38-count indictment that characterizes Mr. Kilpatrick’s inner circle as a long-running criminal organization.

headline: Lineman Steps Out of the Trenches to Save a Stranger’s Life
text: Last week, Warren Sallach, a road maintenance worker from Brenham, Tex., called Matt Hoffman, a senior defensive end at Rowan University in Glassboro, N.J. They had never met, and Sallach froze when Hoffman answered.

headline: The Best of 2010: 'The Aliens'
text: Charles Isherwood narrates a look at Annie Baker's play.

headline: Canada Faulted for Lax Oil Sands Oversight
text: OTTAWA  An extensive review of Canada’s oil sands released on Wednesday rejected several claims from both the energy industry and environmentalists while accusing Canadian governments of inadequate oversight of the projects.

headline: East Slope vs. West Slope: Two Options for the Coatless
text: There are plenty of alternatives to the classic camel coat. Pick your look: East Coast ski patrol or Sun Valley winter hippie.

headline: Six Victories, but Five First-Round Draft Picks
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.

headline: Ski Bunnies on City Slopes
text: EARLIER this month, when the temperatures in New York at last dropped to a seasonally appropriate level, Hilary Gallagher, a clerk at Intermix in SoHo, was watching as shoppers filtered into the store and, with their winter jackets discarded on the dressing room floor, tried on what Ms. Gallagher described as “the urban ski get-up”: Fair Isle sweaters (long and belted from D & G on sale for $859; loosely draped from Juliette Jake at $285) layered with fur vests (honey-colored raccoon by Theory, $1,200; cropped fox by Yves Salomon, $495; hooded mink by Cassin, $4,595).

headline: The Tears of John Boehner
text: Crybaby. Wimp. Sensitive man. The reviews of John Boehner’s sobfest in a “60 Minutes” profile last Sunday have been all over the map, fueling a debate on when it’s appropriate for men in public life to cry.

headline: Rising Interest Rates and the Fed’s Red Ink
China Agrees to Intellectual Property Protections
text: WASHINGTON  Senior Chinese officials pledged on Wednesday to better crack down on software piracy and other violations of intellectual property rights as part of a series of commercial agreements after two days of talks here.

headline: Fashion Triumph: Deflecting the Male Gaze
text: LEANDRA MEDINE, a fashion blogger who lives with her parents on the Upper East Side, was thumbing through the hangers in her bedroom closet on a recent Monday morning, pulling out the sort of items that she calls “sartorial contraceptives”: a blouse with erect shoulder pads from Zara; a floral, curtainlike blazer by Zimmermann; high-waisted lime green trousers by Opening Ceremony; drop-crotch utility pants; an ostrich-feather miniskirt; a cape.

headline: Lee Returns, Saying He ‘Never Wanted to Leave’
text: PHILADELPHIA  On a frigid Wednesday afternoon with blustery winds and snow showers, Cliff Lee again put on a Phillies jersey and fans began longing impatiently for spring.

headline: He Sold a Vision at Fox, and Marketers Bought It
text: FOUR decades later, Jon Nesvig, the dean of network sales executives, can still recall details of his first job.

headline: Bloomberg to Publish Editorials
text: Being mayor of New York City would be a large enough platform for just about anyone. But apparently not for Michael R. Bloomberg.

headline: Health Suits Stir Concerns on Court Partisanship
text: PENSACOLA, Fla. — With a loose web of conservative plaintiffs leading the charge, and judicial rulings breaking thus far along ideological lines, the drive to scuttle the Obama health care law is once again highlighting the role of partisanship in America’s courts.

headline: On Health Law, Check Back in a Generation
text: WASHINGTON  When President Obama signed the health care bill into law last spring, White House aides predicted that the political benefit to their party would be almost immediate, going so far as to suggest that some provisions, like the one requiring insurance companies to cover pre-existing conditions, would help Democratic chances in the November elections.

headline: At Issue in Emanuel Hearing: Boxes in Basement
text: CHICAGO — The contents of Rahm Emanuel’s basement took center stage on Wednesday in an election board hearing to determine whether he can run for mayor.

headline: For G.M.’s, Finding an Ace Is the Easy Part
text: Every baseball fan  every serious fan, anyway  has a little bit of Raymond Babbitt in him. That’s the Dustin Hoffman character from “Rain Man,” who knows precisely when Fernando Valenzuela is scheduled to pitch for the Dodgers. The game the ace pitches is the one fans want to see.

headline: Wind Power for Boston, Made in China
text: Goldwind USA and A-Power Energy Generation Systems are not the only big Chinese-owned wind energy companies setting up shop in this country.

headline: Life Sentence for Plotting To Set Off Blasts at J.F.K.
text: A former Guyanese politician convicted of plotting to blow up fuel tanks at Kennedy International Airport was sentenced on Wednesday to life in prison.

headline: U.S. Tries to Build Case for Conspiracy by WikiLeaks
text: WASHINGTON — Federal prosecutors, seeking to build a case against the WikiLeaks leader Julian Assange for his role in a huge dissemination of classified government documents, are looking for evidence of any collusion in his early contacts with an Army intelligence analyst suspected of leaking the information.

headline: A Voice for Radio, With Oprah’s Ambition
text: At Mercy High School in Farmington Hills, Mich., Dawn Hill’s classmates voted her “most likely to become Oprah.” Ms. Hill, 24, is a local producer and a fledgling voice-over artist for commercials on the radio stations WBLS and WLIB. Her primary responsibilities are “The Yolanda Adams Morning Show,” on WLIB (1190 AM), which plays gospel music, and “Middays With Egypt,” on WBLS (107.5 FM), which plays R&B. Raised in Detroit, she graduated from Howard University in 2008 and lives in Harlem with two roommates.

headline: In Whitman’s Pocket, an Imagined Lincoln
text: The librarian wheels out the box on a little wooden trolley that reminds me of a dim-sum cart or a hospital gurney. Inside it is the poet’s notebook, dismembered with surgical care by a long-ago conservator, each leaf pressed between sheets of adhesive silk as if it were a fragment of the Dead Sea Scrolls. This private, portable thing is now splayed open, immobilized.

headline: Coming to Grips With Lugging an iPad
text: CALL it the male iPad dilemma: too large to slip into a pants pocket, too stiff to be curled up like a magazine and too precious to leave unprotected. With its rigid tablet shape, Apple’s iPad has raised an awkward consideration for many men: how to carry it in a manner that is practical and yet, well, masculine.

headline: Walk In, Grab a Muffin and Watch a Newspaper Reinvent Itself
text: TORRINGTON, Conn.

headline: Clinton Pledges Bigger Role for Besieged State Department
text: WASHINGTON  Seeking to reassert the State Department’s role as the primary agent of Washington overseas, Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton on Wednesday announced an ambitious overhaul of diplomacy and development. And she promised to do it without spending a lot more money.

headline: Sweden Bombing Doesn’t Soil Image of Tolerance
text: STOCKHOLM — As they consider the suicide bombing that recently rocked their country, many Swedes have taken comfort from the attack’s most enduring image, as captured by a security camera: a man in a red jacket kneeling by the dying bomber, asking if there was anything he could do for the man while other bystanders, spying unexploded pipe bombs still strapped to the man’s waist, backed away, shouting, “Bomb! Bomb! Bomb!”

headline: Security Council Removes Restrictions on Iraq
text: UNITED NATIONS  The United States, tying up loose ends as its occupation of Iraq winds down, pushed through three Security Council resolutions on Wednesday that lifted restrictions left over from the confrontation with Saddam Hussein.

headline: In France, Civil Unions Gain Favor Over Marriage
text: PARIS  Some are divorced and disenchanted with marriage; others are young couples ideologically opposed to marriage, but eager to lighten their tax burdens. Many are lovers not quite ready for old-fashioned matrimony.

headline: As Koreans Pour In, a Town Is Remade
text: PALISADES PARK, N.J.  Two decades ago, the police here sometimes roused Jason Kim in the wee hours, but not because he was in trouble. There were few Koreans in town, and few of them spoke English, so whenever one was arrested, the police needed Mr. Kim to translate the Miranda warning.

headline: Fraud Charges in New York’s Payroll Overhaul
text: Of all the city programs that have ever gone wrong in New York, few could compare to CityTime, an automated system meant to streamline employee timekeeping.

headline: Making It, Until a Slip on the Ice Threw Life Into Crisis
text: In February, Evelyn De La Cruz slipped on a patch of ice on the sidewalk and felt a sharp pain in her left ankle.

headline: Black, White and Plaid All Over
text: CALL it chromophobia.

headline: Hunt Is On for Serial Killer in Long Island Deaths
text: The theory that the deaths of four people whose bodies were found in recent days on a Long Island beach are victims of a serial killer gained momentum on Wednesday when the authorities determined that all of them were women.

headline: Trading Up: Shadow Plaids
text: While colorful plaids can read as weekend wear, black and white plaids have a stylishly professional, low-key mien. Here’s an assortment of plaids of a different color to get you started.

headline: Photo Replay: Dec. 15
text: A view of the day in sports, from snow-covered ski mountains to snow-covered football stadiums.

headline: NATO Push Deals Taliban a Setback in Kandahar
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  As the Obama administration reviews its strategy in Afghanistan, residents and even a Taliban commander say the surge of American troops this year has begun to set back the Taliban in parts of their southern heartland and to turn people against the insurgency  at least for now.

headline: Taliban Extend Reach to North, Where Armed Groups Reign
text: KUNDUZ, Afghanistan  This city, once a crossroads in the country’s northeast, is increasingly besieged. The airport closed months ago to commercial flights. The roads heading south to Kabul and east to Tajikistan as well as north and west are no longer safe for Afghans, let alone Westerners.

headline: Goodell Is Confident About Chances of Labor Agreement
text: FORT WORTH  Commissioner Roger Goodell said Wednesday that reaching a new collective bargaining agreement by the end of the postseason is “realistic,” although he declined to characterize the state of negotiations. Goodell and team owners spent their meeting focused primarily on labor issues, although several owners declined to reveal what was discussed behind closed doors.

headline: Arms Pact Passes One Test as Senate Acts to Debate It
text: WASHINGTON — The Senate opened debate on Wednesday on a new arms-control treaty with Russia with an early test vote showing that President Obama is right on the edge of securing its approval.

headline: Thursday: Ill-Fated
text: There were three parts to cracking today’s theme. The first part was actually cracking it. The next was realizing how many phrases can fit the theme (there are even a few more). The last was noticing how the theme entries all fit into place — two stretched the full width of the grid, crossing two others along the way.

headline: At Hospital, Preparing for a Strike
text: New York City’s public hospital system has drawn up contingency plans to keep emergency services running at Harlem Hospital Center if physicians fulfill their threat to walk out, hospital officials said Wednesday.

headline: Irish Drug Maker Settles Charges of Improper Marketing
text: The Irish pharmaceutical company Elan has agreed to pay $203.5 million to resolve criminal and civil complaints that it improperly marketed the antiseizure medicine Zonegran for weight loss and mood stabilization, the Justice Department said on Wednesday.

headline: Espada and Son Plead Not Guilty to Embezzling From Health Network
text: There was no swagger, and no theatrical denunciation of his political rivals.

headline: Lottery Numbers
4-Goal Burst by Rangers Takes Focus Off Penguins
text: PITTSBURGH — The Rangers seemed almost like an afterthought Wednesday, with Sidney Crosby and the glamorous Penguins making their HBO debut later in the night, many talking about the Winter Classic on Jan. 1 at Heinz Field, and Pittsburgh leading this game by a goal.

headline: A Green Detroit? No, a Guzzling One
text: Portland, Ore.

headline: Begging for Your Pay
text: Romulo Saldana was looking for work.

headline: Get the Lead Out of Hunting
text: Santa Barbara, Calif.

headline: In Skidmore, Mo., a Killing Lingers
text: The memory of the nightmare surrounding the troublemaking of Ken Rex McElroy, and later his killing, continues to loom large in the small town of Skidmore, Mo.

headline: N.H.L. Excited About HBO Documentary
text: The hierarchy of the National Hockey League was ecstatic. In the conference room at their headquarters, they had just screened the first episode of “24/7 Penguins/Capitals: Road to the NHL Winter Classic” hours before it aired Wednesday night on HBO.

headline: Heat and Cavaliers Pass in the Night
text: MIAMI  An N.B.A. season can feel like a highway to forever, but one head-on collision in early December might have shaped the Miami Heat as the irresistible force it was expected to be and the Cleveland Cavaliers as the wreckage that LeBron James left behind.

headline: Knicks Can’t Beat Buzzer or Celtics
text: The release felt solid  the way it had all game  whether it was a silky jumper or violent dunk. This time, Amar’e Stoudemire stepped behind the 3-point arc, outside his normal range. The ball left his right hand and settled into the net, igniting the loudest roar Madison Square Garden had heard in years, the apparent game-winner at the buzzer topping Paul Pierce’s apparent game-winner with 0.4 of a second left.

headline: Town Mute for 30 Years About a Bully’s Killing
text: SKIDMORE, Mo. — The murder of Ken Rex McElroy took place in plain view of dozens of residents of this small farm town, under the glare of the morning sun. But in a dramatic act of solidarity with the gunman, every witness, save the dead man’s wife, denied seeing who had pulled the trigger.

headline: Bob Feller, Whose Fastball Dazzled, Dies at 92
text: Bob Feller, who came off an Iowa farm with a dazzling fastball that made him a national celebrity at 17 and propelled him to the Hall of Fame as one of baseball’s greatest pitchers, died on Wednesday in Cleveland, where he had played for the Indians for 18 years. He was 92.

headline: Last Word: Bob Feller
text: Bob Feller is one of the greatest baseball pitchers ever to play the game. He began his major league career as a teenager in 1936, throwing a fastball the game has not seen since.

headline: Seeking an Equation for Wins
text: A look at the the California Institute of Technology men’s basketball team.

headline: Italy: Court Upholds Convictions of Americans in Kidnapping Case
text: An appellate court in Milan upheld on Wednesday the conviction of 23 Americans charged with kidnapping an Egyptian cleric in 2003 and ordered even harsher sentences. All but one of the Americans are Central Intelligence Agency operatives. Defense lawyers said they planned to file appeals, which would go to Italy’s highest court. Robert Seldon Lady, a former C.I.A. base chief in Milan, was sentenced to nine years, one more than his previous conviction, while the 22 other Americans received seven-year sentences, up from five years. The Americans were also ordered to pay a total of $1.33 million in damages to the Egyptian cleric,  Hassan Mustafa Osama Nasr, who was kidnapped in Milan. Prosecutors said that he was taken to Egypt, where, he said, he was tortured. Italy has never formally requested the extradition of the Americans. Through their lawyers, they have pleaded not guilty in the past.

headline: Curators Criticize Controversial Art’s Removal
text: A talk on Wednesday at the New York Public Library by the curators of a controversial exhibition at the National Portrait Gallery in Washington drew a show of support for the gallery, as well as criticism of its parent institution, the Smithsonian, which two weeks ago decided to remove an AIDS-themed artwork from the show after it came under attack.

headline: Maynard W. Glitman, Arms Negotiator, Dies at 77
text: Maynard W. Glitman, a diplomat who led the American side in negotiating the intermediate-range nuclear forces treaty, signed by the United States and the Soviet Union in 1987, died on Tuesday in Shelburne, Vt. He was 77 and had homes in Fletcher and Burlington, Vt.

headline: France: Freedom for Noriega Rejected
text: A court in Paris on Wednesday rejected a request for the release of the imprisoned former Panamanian dictator Manuel Antonio Noriega, who is serving a prison term in France after his conviction on money-laundering charges. In July, Mr. Noriega, who ruled Panama from 1983 to 1989, was sentenced to seven years in prison for laundering $3 million in Colombian drug money through international banks and into French accounts in 1988 and 1989. Mr. Noriega had been extradited from the United States to France in April after spending 15 years in a Miami prison on charges that included cocaine trafficking. The government of Panama has requested that Mr. Noriega be extradited to serve three 20-year prison terms for human rights abuses and involvement in the disappearance of political opponents. Yves Leberquier, Mr. Noriega’s lawyer, asked for “just a bit of humanity,” noting his client’s many years in prison.

headline: Germany: A Contribution for Auschwitz
text: Germany will contribute $80.5 million over the next year to help carry out conservation work at Auschwitz-Birkenau, the site of the former death camp, the Foreign Ministry said. Foreign Minister Guido Westerwelle said that “with the contribution to the Auschwitz-Birkenau Foundation, Germany bears witness to its historical responsibility to commemorate the Holocaust and to convey this to future generations.”

headline: Ukraine: Investigation of Ex-Premier
text: Prosecutors are investigating a former prime minister, Yulia V. Tymoshenko, who is accused of mishandling hundreds of millions of dollars when she was in office, officials said Wednesday. Ms. Tymoshenko, now the opposition leader, denounced the inquiry as a politically motivated effort by her rival, President Viktor F. Yanukovich, to sideline her. She was not arrested, but she said she had been told by prosecutors that she should not leave Kiev, the capital, while the inquiry was under way.

headline: A Provocative Artwork That Provoked
text: To the Editor:

headline: Italy’s Crisis of Confidence
text: Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi of Italy survived a parliamentary vote of confidence on Tuesday, but his discredited government no longer commands a working majority. That is not a situation Italy can put up with for very long. New leaders, new elections and a more honest approach to governing are urgently needed.

headline: Can a Black President Afford to Act Angry?
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Politicization of a Respected Court
text: When Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey chose not to renominate Justice John Wallace Jr. to the State Supreme Court in May, it was a case of political overreach. The situation is now a national disgrace, thanks to the governor, the State Senate president, Stephen Sweeney, and Justice Roberto Rivera-Soto.

headline: Heroic, Female and Muslim
text: What’s the ugliest side of Islam? Maybe it’s the Somali Muslim militias that engage in atrocities like the execution of a 13-year-old girl named Aisha Ibrahim. Three men raped Aisha, and when she reported the crime she was charged with illicit sex, half-buried in the ground before a crowd of 1,000 and then stoned to death.

headline: On Borrowed Time
text: No American has worked harder to build better relations with Pakistan’s army than Adm. Mike Mullen, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff.

headline: Cartel Gunmen Buy American
text: As the body count in the Mexican drug wars mounts beyond 30,000, federal authorities have tracked more than 60,000 guns in the past four years back across the border to American dealers. Congress, enthralled with the gun lobby, has done nothing about a legal loophole increasingly at the heart of the carnage  the dealers’ freedom to make multiple sales of AK-47s and other battlefield assault rifles without having to report to federal authorities, as the law requires for handgun sales.

headline: The Crying Game
text: We’ve had to adjust to so many strange developments lately. I’m sure we’ll get used to having a speaker of the House who weeps a lot.

headline: The Case for Renewable Ethanol
text: To the Editor:

headline: House Votes to Repeal ‘Don’t Ask, Don’t Tell’
text: WASHINGTON — The House on Wednesday handily approved a repeal of a ban on gay men and lesbians serving openly in the military, ratcheting up the pressure on Senate Republicans who have resisted holding a vote on procedural grounds.

headline: Officials Back Plan to Restore California Bay Delta
text: Federal and state officials said Wednesday that they supported construction of a massive structure around California’s environmentally crippled delta to make deliveries of fresh water to farms and cities more reliable.

headline: With Alzheimer’s Patients Growing in Number, Congress Endorses a National Plan
text: Congress has voted unanimously to create, for the first time, a national plan to combat Alzheimer’s disease with the same intensity as the attacks on AIDS and cancer.

headline: Florida: Neo-Nazi Guilty of Murder
text: A New Port Richey jury on Wednesday found John Ditullio Jr. guilty of murder and attempted murder. Mr. Ditullio, 24, was accused of stabbing Patricia Wells and Kristofer King in March 2006; Mr. King, who was 17, died. The trial, a second attempt to convict Mr. Ditullio after a mistrial last year, drew national attention because the court paid to have a cosmetologist cover Mr. Ditullio’s prominent tattoos, including a swastika on his neck. His lawyer, Bjorn E. Brunvand, argued that another man in the neo-Nazi group that Mr. Ditullio hoped to join had actually committed the crimes. The jury deliberated for 11 hours; the penalty phase of the trial will begin Thursday. Mr. Ditullio could be sentenced to death.

headline: Penguins’ Duo Isn’t So Dynamic
text: PITTSBURGH — What does the Penguins’ 4-1 loss to the Rangers on Wednedsay night have in common with the Penguins’ 3-2 loss in Philadelphia on Tuesday night?

headline: Votes to Ban Pet Projects Did Not Deter Requests
text: WASHINGTON  Dozens of senators who voted to ban the practice of earmarking nevertheless requested nearly $1 billion for pet projects in the spending bill released Tuesday.

headline: Word of the Day | matriculate
text: matriculate •\mə-ˈtri-kyə-ˌlat\• verb

headline: Some Georgia Inmates Return to Work
text: Inmates in several Georgia prisons were divided over how to continue their protest on Wednesday, with some returning to work after a six-day strike. Many vowed to continue boycotting their jobs until their demands were met.

headline: Amnesty for Brazil Dictatorship Is Challenged
text: RIO DE JANEIRO  A human rights court said that a Brazilian amnesty law covering crimes during the country’s 21-year dictatorship was invalid and that the country was responsible for the forced disappearance of at least 70 peasants and militants who were part of a resistance movement.

headline: Immigration to U.S., After Dip, Is Back Up
text: The flow of immigrants to the United States has resumed, after falling to the lowest level in decades during the recession, a new study finds.

headline: News Quiz | December 16, 2010
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper.

headline: Corrections
text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: U.S. Bioethics Commission Gives Green Light to Synthetic Biology
text: The president’s bioethics commission says there is no need to temporarily halt research or to impose new regulations on the controversial new field known as synthetic biology.

headline: Test Yourself | English, Dec. 16, 2010
text: Test your reading skills with today’s question, created by Danielle Hoagland and Judith McCaffrey at Grammarlogues from the article “Sweet Potatoes Step Out From Under Marshmallows.”

headline: Mapping Our Neighborhoods, Mapping America
text: WHERE in the United States have more immigrants been settling in recent years?

headline: WikiLeaks Founder Is Released on Bail
text: LONDON  Julian Assange, the founder of WikiLeaks, was released from jail on $315,000 bail on Thursday, and he vowed in a defiant speech to continue to release classified documents and to fight extradition to Sweden for questioning about accusations of sexual offenses.

headline: Daily Lexeme: Clout-Shoe
text: Today’s word, in association with the admirable Oxford English Dictionary, is

headline: G.M. Buys Back $2.1 Billion Preferred Shares From U.S.
text: The United States Treasury says  General Motors has repurchased the rest of the preferred shares owned by the government for $2.1 billion.

headline: What Is the Best Idea of 2010?
text: Every December for the past 10 years, The Times Magazine has presented The Year in Ideas, a roundup of theories, prototypes, events and products that “helped make each year, for better or worse, what it was.” The innovations reflect their times, and some of them — like the inclusion of online social networks in 2003, may tell the future. What new ideas from 2010 do you think have the potential to shape the future? Which will become “time capsules” that remind of us who we were and what we cared about when 2010 is a distant memory?

headline: Republican Split, Democratic Opportunity
text: Simon Johnson, the former chief economist at the International Monetary Fund, is the co-author of “13 Bankers.”

headline: Spanish Builder Raises Hochtief Bid to $6.5 Billion
text: Grupo ACS, the Spanish construction company, has raised its hostile takeover offer for its smaller German rival Hochtief.

headline: France’s Wealth Fund Offers to Buy Areva’s STMicro Stake
text: France’s sovereign wealth fund said on Thursday that it was ready to offer 695 million euros for Areva’s 10.9 percent stake in STMicroelectronics.

headline: Brady Goes to Top of  Chart, Passing Rivers
text: Luis DeLoureiro operates NFLStatAnalysis.net and is a contributor to the Cold Hard Football Facts.

headline: In Madrid, the Holiday Spirit in Miniature
text: Madrileños celebrate Christmas with the same gusto that they celebrate life, enjoying the holiday in all its manifestations: from attending Christmas-themed concerts to skating on the ice rinks specially set up in plazas. It also seems as if everyone takes to the streets, wandering from plaza to plaza to check out the wide variety of items in the temporary stalls selling gifts, as well as Christmas wreaths and ornaments. For sustenance, they snack on churros and hot chocolate.

headline: Obama Cites Afghan Gains as Report Says Exit Is on Track
text: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration plans to further step up attacks on Al Qaeda and Taliban insurgents in the tribal areas of Pakistan, to address one of the fundamental weaknesses uncovered in its year-end review of its Afghanistan war strategy.

headline: The Early Word: Af-Pak Review and Tax Votes
text: From Today’s Times:

headline: Alcon and Dynegy Deals Reach a Climax
text: They are not in time for year-end banker bonuses, but on Wednesday we approached closure on two of the more notable deals of 2010: Novartis’s acquisition of Alcon and Dynegy’s attempt to sell itself. They each provide their own distinct lessons for deal makers.

headline: Spain Borrowing Costs Jump Ahead of E.U. Summit
