text: PARIS — Spain paid a sharply higher interest rate on an auction of long-term bonds Thursday and a new strike hit Greece, illustrating the pressures on European leaders heading into a summit meeting to find a solution to the bloc’s debt problems.

headline: Bloggingheads: Anti-Christian Art?
text: Jeff Sharlet, left, of Harper's and Helen Rittelmeyer of National Review debate the controversy at the National Portrait Gallery.

headline: My Health Insurance Rates Just Went Down
text: A couple of weeks ago I received my renewal costs for our health insurance coverage. I’m now covering 11 out of 12 workers (one is on his wife’s policy). The company — i.e. me — pays two-thirds of this cost, the employees pay the rest.

headline: Park Slope Plane Crash | Voices of Those Who Were There
text: They were there on Dec. 16, 1960, the day the plane went down.

headline: South Korea to Hold Artillery Drills on Island
text: SEOUL, South Korea  South Korea said on Thursday that it would hold artillery drills in the coming days from the island attacked by the North last month, as an American governor traveled to Pyongyang, the North Korean capital, to try to ease tensions between the Asian neighbors.

headline: The Afghan War Review
text: President Obama on Thursday presented a review of his strategy for the war in Afghanistan. Mr. Obama formally presented the review at the White House. He was joined by Vice President Joseph R. Biden, Secretary of State Hillary Clinton, Defense Secretary Robert Gates and others.

headline: Zipbuds Address Earphone Hazards, WWI
text: Back in European History class in junior high, many teenagers were taught that World War I was brought about, in part, because of “entangling alliances.” And this, of course, is not unlike earbuds.

headline: Jets’ Westhoff Says Patriots Use Sideline Walls, Too
text: The special-teams coach Mike Westhoff probably went into Wednesday hoping to stamp out the flame on the Jets’ latest controversy. He  wound up stoking the fire instead. He told reporters that he had no knowledge of a plan, carried out by the strength coach Sal Alosi, to align players on the sideline to obstruct punt return gunners.

headline: Judge Bars Twitter Updates From London Courtroom During Assange Bail Hearing
text: 8:11 a.m. | Update: Julian Assange will be released on bail, after an appeal against an earlier ruling in his favor was turned down by a high court judge in London on Thursday, Britain’s Press Association reports.

headline: Carlyle Sells Additional Stake to Abu Dhabi
text: The Carlyle Group said on Thursday that a state-owned Abu Dhabi fund would invest an additional $500 million in the buyout firm, which is preparing for an initial public offering sometime next year.

headline: A New Way to Buy Some Wind Power
text: Millions of people think about buying solar cells for their roofs, but far fewer would consider owning a wind turbine.

headline: True Guitar Hero, With More Love and Less Leer
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  “Do you want me?” Prince sang shortly into his concert at the Izod Center, his first of two shows here before he performs on Saturday night at Madison Square Garden. He knew the answer would be an affirmative roar. And his opening song was a boast: “Laydown,” from his most recent album, “20Ten” (NPG), announced, “From the heart of Minnesota/Here come the purple Yoda” and matter-of-factly asserted, “Everybody wanna be me.”

headline: The Day Planes Fell From the Sky
text: Photographers for The New York Times and other publications captured the site moments after the plane came down in Park Slope as journalists, here for WNYC, broadcast live updates across the airwaves.

headline: A Taste of Montreal at Vic’s Bagel Bar
text: Manhattanites no longer have to trek to Boerum Hill, Brooklyn, and wait on line at Noah Bernamoff‘s Mile End Deli for Montreal-style meats. At Vic’s Bagel Bar, 544 Third Avenue (36th Street), the owner, Vic Glazer, gets regular deliveries of smoked meat, smoked turkey and smoked beef salami. The meats are layered into sandwiches, including the Ellen Barkin, using the smoked meat ($7.95). Mr. Bernamoff’s wife, Rachel Cohen, is an old friend of Ms. Glazer’s, which is how the connection was made. “I’ve known Rachel since we were at Yeshiva together,” Ms. Glazer said. Ms. Glazer also sells the smoked meat by the pound, $30; the salami is $28 a pound. If you insist on a Montreal-style bagel, then it’s Mile End, 97A Hoyt Street (Atlantic Avenue), for you after all. Meanwhile, check out what Robert Sietsema has to say about the Montreal-New York culinary connection.

headline: Security Forces Open Fire on Protesters in Ivory Coast
text: DAKAR, Senegal  Security forces loyal to President Laurent Gbagbo of Ivory Coast opened fire on demonstrators in the economic capital, Abidjan, on Thursday, beating and killing marchers who had planned to disrupt state television, one of the principal underpinnings of the government’s hold on power, according to observers and news reports.

headline: Has President Obama Kept His Promises to American Indians?
text: President Obama last year promised American Indian leaders from across the country that his administration would work to improve what he called the federal government’s history of broken promises to tribal nations.

headline: The Strange Case for Mitt Romney
text: David Frum, puzzling over the inconsistencies in Mitt Romney’s recent op-ed attacking the tax deal:

headline: Hedge Funds Are High on European Equities
text: Hedge funds bought European stocks during the last month at the most frenzied pace in five years, according to a new report from the Swiss investment bank UBS, in what could be a bullish sign for equities.

headline: Sunrise, Sunset: Jon Stewart Revisits His Start at ‘The Daily Show’
text: ‘Tis the season for retrospection, so let’s turn back the clock to 1999, when a greener, more naïve nation was still giddy from the release of Windows 98 and the creation of the euro, and eagerly looking forward to can’t-miss, millennium-defining events like “Star Wars: Episode I – The Phantom Menace” and Woodstock ’99, while somewhere a young Jon Stewart was making his preparations to take over as host of “The Daily Show.”

headline: In Pursuit of the Perfect Brainstorm
text: Last month, in a small room on the fifth floor of a high-rise building in San Mateo, Calif., three men sat around a table, thinking. The place was wallpapered with Post-it notes, in a riot of colors, plus column after column of index cards pinned to foam boards. Some of the cards had phrases like “space maximizers” or “stuff trackers” written on them. Many had little three-dimensional ink drawings and titles, like “color-coded Tupperware horizontal stacker.” It looked as if these guys had been locked in and told they couldn’t leave until they dreamed up 1,000 of the wackiest home-storage items they could imagine.

headline: Vain Glorious | A Facial That Really Saved Face
text: One of life’s more sobering moments is the morning after a great party. That goes double during art fairs like the recent Miami Basel, where a single evening can leave you wanting less a hangover cure than a complete makeover.

headline: Week 15 N.F.L. Game Probabilities: Mixed News for Jets
text: Brian Burke, a former Navy pilot who has taken up the less dangerous hobby of N.F.L. statistical analysis, operates Advanced NFL Stats, a blog about football, math and human behavior.

headline: Composing a Church-Going Western
text: At the party following the New York premiere of “True Grit” on Tuesday night, the 14-year-old star, Hailee Steinfeld, held court with her 15-year-old best friend, Katee Cassidy, prancing around the Pool Room at the Four Seasons restaurant holding hands. The prancing was greatly helped by the fact that Ms. Steinfeld had changed out of the purple stilettos she wore on the red carpet and into silver glitter hi-tops. Toward the end of the night, another of the movie’s stars, Jeff Bridges, dressed down too, getting all Dude-like in his wrinkled white shirt and posing for photos with a glass — of what appeared to be water — in his hand. As usual, Joel and Ethan Coen, who wrote and directed the film, declined to talk. But the Bagger was glad to find Carter Burwell, the film’s composer. Mr. Burwell has always written music for the Coens, as well as for Spike Jonze’s films, like “Where the Wild Things Are.” This awards season he is also represented by “The Kids Are All Right.” He lives and records in New York; the score for “True Grit” was composed at the Manhattan Center with a 70-piece orchestra. And it was being fine-tuned until the very last moment – the last recording session was held Nov. 8. Mr. Burwell is a member of the Academy, but, he revealed to us, that didn’t make him an expert on who would win the Oscar for best score. (Readers, you’re on your own.) But Mr. Burwell did clue us into the process of composing that memorably grand music. An edited version of the conversation follows.

headline: Remedies: Honey for Coughing
text: More than a third of American adults use some form of complementary or alternative medicine, according to a government report. Natural remedies have an obvious appeal, but how do you know which ones to choose and whether the claims are backed by science? In this occasional series, the New York Times “Really?” columnist, Anahad O’Connor, explores the claims and the science behind alternative remedies that you may want to consider for your family medicine cabinet.

headline: Morning Buzz | Mayor Bloomberg Wants a New Mouthpiece
text: There’s a chill in the air. This is not a bad day to pull your long underwear out of mothballs.

headline: First Lidstrom Hat Trick Took Only 1,442 Games
text: Nicklas Lidstrom has four Stanley Cup rings, six Norris Trophies and an Olympic gold medal. After 19 N.H.L. seasons and 1,441 games, however, Lidstrom never had a hat trick.

headline: Morning Take-Out
text: –Basel bank regulators said rules on capital requirements would have cost financial institutions $797 billion had they been in place at the end of last year.

headline: Goldman Trader Set to Create Fund
text: Morgan Chia-Wen Sze, global head of the proprietary trading desk that Goldman Sachs is shutting down, is preparing to create his own hedge fund, to be called Azentus Capital.

headline: Park Slope Plane Crash | The Constellation Comes Down
text: Arthur Mazza was a 28-year-old firefighter assigned to Engine 159 on Staten Island. Calls of a plane crash sent him and his colleagues racing to Miller Army Airfield. There, as smoke billowed from between the trees, he saw two bodies lying naked and unidentifiable. Their impact had painted wide, red circles in the snow.

headline: Basel Report Shows Banks Have Way to Go to Meet Capital Rules
text: FRANKFURT  The largest global banks, especially those in Europe, may be hundreds of billions of dollars short of the capital reserves needed to comply with new regulations and may face pressure to shed risky assets as a result, according to figures released Thursday by two influential regulatory panels.

headline: European Central Bank to Nearly Double Its Capital Reserves
text: FRANKFURT — The European Central Bank said Thursday that it would nearly double its capital reserves, a step that had been expected as a way for the bank to maintain its integrity as its holdings in European government bonds increase.

headline: ‘Fighter’ and ‘King’s Speech’ Lead SAG Nominations
text: The union which allows actors to get unemployment has announced its favorite performances of the year. The Screen Actors Guild gave high marks to “The Fighter” and “King’s Speech,” which both received four nominations, including best ensemble, the group’s version of best picture. The other best ensemble honorees: “Black Swan,” “The Social Network” and “The Kids Are All Right.”

headline: Bonobos, a Web Retailer, Raises $18.5 Million
text: Kathy Willens/Associated PressBonobos co-founders Brian Spaly, left, and Andy Dunn.

headline: Biden Blasts Republicans Over Christmas Comments
text: Visit msnbc.com for breaking news, world news, and news about the economy

headline: In India, Chinese Leader Pushes Trade
text: NEW DELHI  China and India set ambitious new economic targets on Thursday by pledging to nearly double their trade in the next five years to $100 billion annually. But the two Asian giants appeared to make little progress on tough geopolitical differences over Pakistan, terrorism and their disputed border.

headline: Dec. 19 — 25
text: Classical

headline: To Attract the Next Google, the City Seeks a New College
text: The later version of this story that appeared in the newspaper can be read here.

headline: 2010 Anthems: From a Kiss-Off to Jolts of Hope
text: 1. ARCADE FIRE “The Suburbs” (Merge). Memories of suburbia, questions of integrity, thoughts on time passing and portents of decline fill the ambivalent anthems on Arcade Fire’s third album. Their misgivings are all subsumed in music that can be punky or (more often) orchestral, with ascendant melodies that stubbornly radiate hope.

headline: Bring On the Birds: A Holiday Count Begins
text: Attention, bird-watchers: the National Audubon Society’s Christmas Bird Count is under way. The annual census, which began on Tuesday and runs through Jan. 5, relies on volunteers throughout the Western Hemisphere who head out with binoculars, spotting scopes, bird guides, cellphones, mobile apps and notepads. They scan trees and fields, reporting on every bird they see over a 24-hour period.

headline: Thursday Reading: The Latest on Tax Cuts
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: Of Triumphs, Trials and a Golden Year for Spain
text: “Bravo España!” said President Nicolas Sarkozy of France in late July as he barged into a television interview during the Tour de France to shake hands with the Spanish cyclist Alberto Contador.

headline: The Purpler the Bruise, the Sweeter the Song
text: 1. RICK ROSS “Teflon Don” (Maybach Music/Slip-N-Slide/Def Jam) Finally, a new hip-hop superhero: on his fourth album, Rick Ross fully inhabits his Rick Rossness, celebrating his growth as a rapper and the return of new money as an aesthetic. On this meaty record he’s devastating 10 different ways, an artist who keeps awakening new skills and ambitions, and burying his past deeper and deeper.

headline: Washington Capitals: Glass Half Full?
text: WASHINGTON — The Washington Capitals entered Wednesday night’s matchup with the Anaheim Ducks hungry for a victory. But once again they fell short, losing, 2-1, in overtime. The Caps have lost seven in row, going from the N.H.L.’s No. 1 team to a club that is just 2 points ahead of the next two teams in the Southeast division.

headline: Renewal, the Sensual and Fraught Candor
text: 1. JASON MORAN “Ten” (Blue Note) A pianist often hailed first for his ideas, Mr. Moran has spent the last decade forging an urgent, elegant style with the Bandwagon, which is to say the drummer Nasheet Waits and the bassist Tarus Mateen. This album, true to the pliable strength and tumbling grace of the band, doubles as a testament to jazz’s endless renewal.

headline: European Court Rules Against Irish Abortion Law
text: LONDON  Ireland, where it is virtually impossible to obtain a legal abortion, will most likely have to rewrite its laws after a European court ruled Thursday that it had violated its own Constitution by failing to provide abortion services to a pregnant woman who had cancer.

headline: Redrawing Rhythmic Strategies
text: 1. STEVE COLEMAN AND FIVE ELEMENTS “Harvesting Semblances and Affinities” (Pi). Not that Mr. Coleman, the alto saxophonist, ever disappeared, but this feels like a return, his strongest and prettiest record in more than a decade. The band, with the singer Jen Shyu and the miraculous drummer Tyshawn Sorey, sounds lifted by the music’s complex latticework, deeply programmed but set spinning.

headline: Wish We Were There | Tobago
text: The announcement of Caribbean Airlines’s new weekly non-stop service between New York and Tobago, brought us back to Winter 2009, when T Travel touched down (with a stop in Trinidad, alas) on one of the Carib’s last flash-free holdouts. Let’s review, shall we?  Go to article….

headline: Video: Picking the Right Cable for Your TV Connection
text: For those who know nothing about the different kinds of connections you can make between a display and a source (DVD player, set-top box, etc.) colleague Suzanne Spector and I made this over-the-top cheesy video as a sort of primer. Anyone who ever had to watch an instructional film in school should feel right at home here.

headline: Slowly Altering Expectations
text: It would be nice to tie up 2010 with some sweeping theme. But the truth is that when you are in the woods, all you can see is the trees. Except of course when someone else paints a picture of your particular forest, and you don’t recognize it. Jennifer Homans’s “Apollo’s Angels” has gotten a lot of attention for its declaration that ballet is dying, but critics have no doubt been muttering this darkly since Louis XIV was the Sun King. Ms. Homans’s cutoff point is Balanchine’s death, but almost 30 years later you can finally see that a new generation has brought a resolute contemporaneity to the form, offering us new ways to look at and think about ballet. Let’s start the best-of list there.

headline: Vibrant Scene’s 20th-Century Base
text: KEELY GARFIELD’S intimate dance-theater explorations at Duo Multicultural Arts Center, the inimitable New York City Ballet star Wendy Whelan, Ralph Lemon’s gorgeous elegy at the Brooklyn Academy of Music: the list of top-notch artists working in this city in 2010 goes on and on. And that’s not counting exciting foreign imports like Alain Buffard of France, the American expatriate Rob List and the Brazilian Bruno Beltrão. Dance is all over the map these days, with no one ruling orthodoxy, myriad distinctive voices and a sensibility that seems, in all its messy force and interdisciplinary variety, distinctively 21st century. These artists aren’t fringe or experimental; they’re simply contemporary.

headline: Park Slope Plane Crash | Sights and Sounds
text: Video: The sights and sounds of the Park Slope Plane crash, with original WNYC broadcasts and archival images.

headline: Tax Deal Hits Procedural Snag in the House
text: WASHINGTON The $858 billion tax cut package negotiated by the White House and Republican leaders hit a procedural snag on Thursday, as liberal Democrats skirmished with party leaders over its estate-tax provisions. At issue was whether the House would vote on an amendment to tax a larger proportion of wealthy estates and to apply a higher rate than was provided for in the compromise package.

headline: City Opera Faces Hard Times With Daring
text: IN the face of severe economic challenges many performing-arts institutions are panicking. But this is exactly the wrong time for an institution to compromise its mission. Staffs may have to be trimmed; offerings may have to be scaled back. But why the institution matters must come through more than ever in its programming.

headline: Poetry Pairing | Dec. 16, 2010
text: In our weekly “Poetry Pairing” series, we collaborate with the Poetry Foundation to feature a work from its American Life in Poetry project alongside content from The Times that somehow echoes, extends or challenges the poem’s themes. Each poem is introduced briefly by Ted Kooser, a former United States poet laureate.

headline: Exotic Timbres in the Darkness
text: LE POèME HARMONIQUE AND THE JACK QUARTET There is a joke that goes: How many music critics does it take to change a light bulb? None. They don’t mind being in the dark. Well, that may be. Darkness played an important role in two extraordinarily moving performances this year. The French early-music group Le Poème Harmonique presented its stunning account of Emilio de’ Cavalieri’s “Lamentations of Jeremiah” at St. Mary the Virgin in January, as a Tenebrae service in which the lighting (mostly by candle) was gradually diminished until the final stanza was performed in darkness. And the Jack Quartet, playing from the four corners of the Austrian Cultural Forum’s concert hall in September, surrounded its audience  which sat in total darkness for 70 minutes  with the exotic timbres of Georg Friedrich Haas’s String Quartet No. 3 (“In iij. Noct.,” 2001).

headline: Honda Recalls Fit Over Faulty Headlight Wiring
text: Honda says it is recalling about 143,000 Fit hatchbacks from the 2007-8 model years because the low-beam headlights might fail. The recall covers about 1.35 million vehicles worldwide.

headline: What, and Who, Worked (Mostly) on Classical Stages
text: ONCE again, after a one-year hiatus taken for no particular reason, the Special Awards Committee for Classical Music has bestowed its highly anticipated prizes for the year. Committee members used the science of pure arbitrariness to honor the following categories:

text: Hailee Steinfeld, 14, attended her first movie premiere and red carpet as the star of the new Coen brothers film “True Grit.”

headline: Senate Battle Over Spending Bill Escalates
text: The Senate Republican leader, Mitch McConnell of Kentucky, introduced a stopgap spending measure on Thursday to keep the federal government financed through Feb. 18.

headline: Behind the Poster: ‘Anything Goes’
text: A ship usually takes center stage in the advertising for any revival of the Cole Porter musical “Anything Goes.”

headline: Feller Proud to Serve in ‘Time of Need’
text: In 2006, Alan Schwarz interviewed Bob Feller for a chapter in his book “Once Upon a Game: Baseball’s Greatest Memories.” They collaborated on this essay, in which Feller, nicknamed Rapid Robert for his fastball, reflected on his decision to enlist in the Navy during World War II and miss almost four seasons of major league baseball. Feller died on Wednesday at age 92.

headline: Viewpoints: Splitting Blankfein’s Roles
text: Lloyd C. Blankfein, chief executive and chairman of Goldman Sachs, is one of the few bank heads to hold both posts. Rob Cox, the United States editor for Reuters Breakingviews, thinks the two responsibilities should be divided — not just in the name of good corporate governance, but to protect Goldman’s bottom line as well. DealBook’s Andrew Ross Sorkin talks to Mr. Cox in an interview.

headline: Ask an Expert About Holiday Stress and Children
text: The winter holidays are often a stressful time for adults, but this time of year can also take a toll on children.

headline: Art Newman, 67, Blackstone Bankruptcy Team Founder, Dies

headline: 5 Accused as Insider Trading Inquiry Broadens
text: 8:45 p.m. | Updated Federal authorities on Thursday arrested three employees of some of the world’s largest technology companies on charges that they leaked confidential corporate information. The charges are the latest brought by the government in its rapidly expanding investigation into insider trading on Wall Street. A fourth employee pleaded guilty and is cooperating with investigators.

headline: F.D.A. Plans to Revoke Approval for Breast Cancer Drug
text: The Food and Drug Administration said on Thursday that it would move to revoke approval of the widely used drug Avastin as a treatment for breast cancer because the drug was not effective in helping patients.

headline: G.M. Buys Back $2.1 Billion Preferred Shares From U.S.
text: From our colleagues at DealBook:

headline: Putin Speaks His Mind, and Then Some, on Television
text: MOSCOW — Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putin on Thursday said that an outburst of nationalist violence in Moscow proved that Russia could not allow its law enforcement bodies to weaken, despite the arguments of “our liberal intelligentsia.”

headline: Boyfriend Is Indicted in Designer’s Death
text: Nicholas Brooks, the boyfriend of Sylvie Cachay, was indicted by a grand jury in connection with her Dec. 9 death in a SoHo hotel room, prosecutors said this morning.

headline: Global Puck: Development Program and American Success at the World Juniors
text: It takes several seconds to say United States national team development program, but you can also say U.S.N.T.D.P. or even just N.T.D.P., which is still a bit of a tongue-twister. But the long and the short of it is that this program, operating in the shadows of Michigan Stadium which just last week attracted a world-record crowd to a hockey game, is the main reason why the United States is favored to win gold at the upcoming world under-20 (junior) championship in Buffalo and Lewiston, N.Y. Check that — not just favored to win a gold medal, but to repeat as gold medalists.

headline: The Cinematic State of Things
text: IN any given year, if you see enough movies — out of habit, ardor or obligation — you will start to notice patterns and clusters. By December the temptation will be nearly overwhelming to generalize from this data, to turn coincidences into trends and trends into matters of world-historical significance. The ad hoc, arbitrary, week-in-week-out sampling of stories and pictures must add up to something, right? Otherwise why bother?

headline: Remembering Feller
text: Days like Thursday, when the sports news offers colliding story lines from different eras, it is hard not to feel a pang of nostalgia for a simpler age. Sure, the days of Bob Feller’s prime had their downside  a big one: the military he served in and the sport he played were still largely segregated  but when your choice of news is whether the Jets’ Rex Ryan knew his strength coach was trying to take out opposing players (or when did he know it), the story of Feller’s life seems so much more appealing, even when you know you’re peering through the gauze filter of history.

headline: Unexpected, Unfiltered, Unbelievable, Unctuous
text: GREAT UNEXPECTATIONS A few new shows in 2010 were surprisingly good, like “The Walking Dead,” the zombie thriller on AMC, but the best offerings were mostly in their second seasons and predictably well done: “Glee,” “Modern Family” and “The Good Wife” all started in 2009.

headline: Ben Brantley’s Top 10 of 2010
text: Photos of “Bloody Bloody Andrew Jackson,” “The Merchant of Venice” and other shows.

headline: Hath Not a Year Highlights? Even This One?
text: O.K., so the big picture wasn’t all that pretty. At times 2010 seemed intent on recapping everything that has been least appealing about New York theater in the first decade of the 21st century. Big, empty-headed musicals that coasted on brand-name appeal (“The Addams Family”); tepid revivals of mothball-scented hits from another era (“Promises, Promises”); star-heavy productions on Broadway of shows that didn’t belong there (Patrick Stewart and T. R. Knight in “A Life in the Theater,” James Earl Jones and Vanessa Redgrave in “Driving Miss Daisy”); spectacles in which frantic technical design upstaged the performers (“Women on the Verge of a Nervous Breakdown”).

headline: Park Slope Plane Crash | The Boy Who Fell From the Sky
text: America met Stephen L. Baltz on Dec. 16, 1960, held him in a collective embrace for a day and then, grieving, let him go. It was as if some celestial central casting agency had carefully assigned the role of courageous survivor to an 11-year-old boy whose life — had it been spared — would have lent to the senseless wreckage one single note of grace.

headline: Park Slope Plane Crash | A Little Brother Remembers
text: William Allen Baltz was 4 years old when his brother, Stephen, died following the Park Slope plane crash, having struggled for a day to survive at Methodist Hospital in Brooklyn.

headline: Mongolian Dissident Confined to Hotel, Family Says
text: BEIJING  An ethnic Mongolian dissident who completed a 15-year prison sentence last week for political crimes has been confined to a luxury hotel in Inner Mongolia along with his wife and son, according to a family member who spoke with the police earlier this week.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: An aggregation of links by the reporters and editors of Diner’s Journal.

headline: VW’s Take on the London Taxi
text: In his film “Night on Earth,” the director Jim Jarmusch combines stories set in five different taxis in five different cities around the world. Volkswagen seems to have a similar idea.

headline: Dramatic Pause: Stephen Colbert to Perform Pinter in One-Time Reading
text: Now the Machiavellian schemes of Stephen Colbert are laid bare: all those highbrow cultural guests he’s been hosting lately on “The Colbert Report” weren’t there because they’re smart and entertaining and make for good television — they were helping Mr. Colbert establish his bona fides for his own erudite artistic pursuits.

headline: Amazon Provides a Dose of Humor
text: Dec. 21: Updated to reflect corrections about Edgar Allan Poe.

headline: 2010, In the Rearview Mirror
text: From Al Pacino’s Shylock to “The Walking Dead,” from the country chanteuse Taylor Swift to “The Social Network,” this week’s Arts & Leisure section looks at the highs and lows of 2010 in theater, dance, film, TV, pop and classical music and art. What were your cultural favorites (and least favorites) of this past year? Leave a comment, and let us know.

headline: Y&R Creative Employees Reunite
text: Advertising is an industry of constant change, with people moving from one agency to another while the agencies are opening, combining and closing. That can make it hard to develop lasting ties to other employees.

headline: Blaming Drivers in F1
text: Is this a trend? I can think of three recent incidents of team directors blaming their drivers publicly for bad seasons, bad results, things that should not have happened. There are no doubt more – and it’s kind of surprising.

headline: Ski Trend: Rockered Skis
text: Over the last couple of seasons, expert skiers at Western resorts known for deep snow have been using some unusual-looking gear: skis that are not only very wide — now standard for powder — but skis that have noticeably upturned, almost cartoonish-looking tips and tails.

headline: U.S. Energy Choices and Global Climate Plans
text: There’s plenty to ponder in the newly released summary of the Annual Energy Outlook 2011 by the Department of Energy. While all such forecasts are implicitly uncertain, this one helps clarify where to focus efforts to cut greenhouse gas emissions; reinforces the importance of resolving questions about how to safely expand, while not stopping, extraction of vast domestic reserves of natural gas; and powerfully challenges proponents of accelerated deployment of today’s menu of renewable energy technologies or nuclear power plants to lay out a credible strategy for supplanting coal.

headline: Obama Says Afghanistan War Is ‘On Track’
text: President Obama on Thursday said that the war in Afghanistan was “on track” toward achieving its military and political goals but that progress was coming “slowly and at a very high price” for the Americans fighting there.

headline: Fill-In | The ‘Imagine Diet’
text: Directions: Fill in the blanks in the first nine paragraphs of the article “Real Evidence for Diets That Are Just Imaginary.”

headline: ‘Spider-Man’ Economics, Part II
text: Earlier this week I put together a back-of-the-envelope estimate for how long it would take “Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark” to earn back its initial investment. The end result — four years — was based on ticket sales alone, assuming an almost-full house every night.

headline: A Call for a Federal Office to Guide Online Privacy
text: A Commerce Department task force called for the creation of a “Privacy Bill of Rights” for online consumers and the establishment of an office within the department that would work to strengthen privacy policies in the United States and coordinate initiatives with other countries.

headline: ‘Good’ Cholesterol May Lower Alzheimer’s Risk

headline: Patrick Kennedy Packs Up 63 Years of Family History
text: WASHINGTON  Nightfall on the Kennedy era in Washington looks like this: Representative Patrick J. Kennedy’s office space surrendered to a Republican, his family memorabilia in boxes, and Mr. Kennedy yearning for a role away from the public eye.

headline: A Beltway Sojourn for Spacey
text: “I don’t think for people outside of the beltway, anyone knows who Jack Abramoff is, which is actually part of the fun in playing a character like that, because you don’t feel like you have to do a imitation,” Kevin Spacey told the Bagger over lunch recently.

headline: First-Time and Strategic Defaulters, Sloppy Payers, Abusers and Distressed Borrowers

headline: Yankees Complete Deal for Russell Martin
text: The Yankees made their first move of note after losing Cliff Lee to Philadelphia by completing a one-year, $4 million deal with the the former All-Star catcher Russell Martin, who is expected to be the starting catcher in 2011. The deal was first reported by MLB.com on Monday.

headline: Happy December Birthday
text: “It’s for his birthday,” I told the shopkeeper, who had, of course, assumed it was a Christmas gift.

headline: ‘Shakespeare in Love’ Sequel to Be, Apparently, After Miramax-Weinstein Deal
text: Where does one go after “Shakespeare in Love,” which ends with its title character immersing himself in the writing of “Twelfth Night” while his sweetheart, Viola, is bound for the New World? What comes next? “Shakespeare in Tears”? “Shakespeare in Bed, Eating Bon-Bons”? “Shakespeare in a Disappointing Marriage With Anne Hathaway, Running Out the Clock While Thinking of Gwyneth Paltrow“?

headline: After Vote, FIFA Increasingly Flexible on 2022 Requirements
text: Ever since the start of Major League Soccer in 1996, begun after the World Cup experience two years earlier, international soccer officials have lamented the American league’s March to November schedule. Now, it appears, FIFA’s calendar isn’t as sacrosanct as Sepp Blatter would have you believe.

headline: Holiday in Chernobyl, Book Now
text: Next year, as Ukraine marks the 25th anniversary of the Chernobyl nuclear disaster, the country will also officially open the area around the plant to tourists for the first time. During a visit to the area on Sunday, Viktor Baloga, Ukraine’s minister of emergency situations, told reporters that tours to Chernobyl will begin next month, according to an article (in Ukrainian) on his ministry’s Web site.

headline: TimesCast | December 16, 2010
text: The White House releases its year-end assessment of the war in Afghanistan; Republicans and Democrats wrangle votes; and Larry King's final show after 25 years on CNN.

headline: Blake Edwards, Prolific Comedy Director, Dies at 88
text: Blake Edwards, a Hollywood master of screwball farces and rude comedies who was probably best known for the “Pink Panther” movies, died Wednesday in Santa Monica, Calif. He was 88.

headline: More Coffee? How About a Drink?
text: We’ve updated The Filter  (the guide to New York coffee for The Scoop, the iPhone and iPad app from The New York Times). The additions reflect a bounty of coffee shops and coffee bars surfacing in unlikely parts of town.

headline: A Weekend in Paris
text: Has Paris lost its edge? Mais non! The city’s bohemians are just harder to find.

headline: Video of Julian Assange’s Statement After His Release on Bail
text: Updated | 1:44 p.m. As my colleagues Ravi Samaiya and Alan Cowell report, Julian Assange, the founder of WikiLeaks, walked out of the Royal Courts of Justice in London on Thursday night, after his release on bail, and made a brief statement.

headline: Following in Father’s Parallel-Universe Footsteps
text: When “Tron” opened in 1982, it seemed to offer irrefutable proof that the next cinematic revolution would be digitized and possibly in DayGlo. The movie starred Jeff Bridges as a video game designer sucked into an electronic world (a nice metaphor for an industry that often puts technological trippery above art) that was eye-popping and lid-dropping, with jolts of beauty blazing amid a morass of sluggish storytelling. The main attractions — bleeding-edge computer-generated imagery and an alternative reality aglow with pulsing phosphorescent colors usually found under the sea or black lights — pointed toward a brave new world. But the public largely didn’t buy into that world, and the film sputtered at the box office.

headline: Decade of the Living Dead
text: Barry Ritholtz expresses amazement at the way the Fannie-Freddie-CRA lie — the claim that gubmint bureaucrats forced all those poor bankers into making bad loans — not only persists, but seems to be growing in influence.

headline: Fed Proposes Rules to Cut Debit Card Fees
text: The Federal Reserve, fulfilling a Congressional order to examine whether merchants were being charged excessive fees to process debit card transactions, proposed new rules on Thursday that analysts said could cut those fees as much as 90 percent.

headline: The Kennedy Family: A Legacy of Public Service
text: Members of the Kennedy family have been fixtures in American politics for decades.

headline: Bright Fodder for Future Revivals
text: FROM far away the contemporary theater might seem to be anything but contemporary. On Broadway, where the media attention focuses, familiar war horses make regular appearances — you again, Hedda? — while each season another theater is colonized by retro-rock musicals allowing baby boomers to let the good times of yesteryear roll again. You might say the past is the present, and the future too, to borrow a line from an oft-revived Eugene O’Neill classic.

headline: Charles Isherwood’s Top 10 of 2010
text: Photos of “Tigers Be Still,” “American Idiot” and other shows.

headline: Photographs of Old New York Go Digital
text: Wrap one hand around a cup of something warm and the other around your mouse as we take you on a brief journey through today’s Internet.

headline: A Grolar Bear? The Perils of Shrinking Arctic Ice
text: Shrinking ice sheets in the Arctic Ocean could be promoting breeding between different species, creating hybrid whales and bears, according to a paper published on Thursday in the journal Nature.

headline: Opening Doors And Reaching New Heights
text: MULLING over the dances of 2010 my mind flies first to three modern-dance works I saw this spring, all by female choreographers. In March, at the Baryshnikov Arts Center, the choreographer Liz Gerring presented the premiere of “Lichtung/Clearing.” I watched this twice; both occasions showed powerfully the world she had created onstage.

headline: Plan to Charge Motorists for Fire Services Bothers Some
text: A Bloomberg administration plan to charge motorists for sending New York City fire trucks racing to respond to accidents and vehicle fires has touched a nerve. It also promises a nasty showdown.

headline: ‘Spider-Man’ Opening Delayed Again
text: The lead producers of the new Broadway musical “Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark” have decided again to delay its opening night, now scheduled for Jan. 11, until sometime in February, two people involved with the musical said on Thursday. With preview performances now under way the delay is intended to provide more time for the creators to stage a new final number, make further rewrites to the dialogue and consider adding and cutting scenes and perhaps inserting new music from the composers, U2’s Bono and the Edge, who will resume working full-time on the show in late December.

headline: ReTweet | Blake Edwards 1922-2010
text: — HS

headline: Blake Edwards, Prolific Comedy Director, Dies at 88
text: Blake Edwards, a writer and director who was hailed as a Hollywood master of screwball farces and rude comedies like “Victor/Victoria” and the “Pink Panther” movies, died Wednesday night in Santa Monica, Calif. He was 88.

headline: Senators Have Votes, if Time Permits, to Repeal ‘Don’t Ask, Don’t Tell’
text: Sixty-one senators have now expressed support for repealing the military’s “don’t ask, don’t tell” policy, appearing to clear the way for passage if Democrats can bring the bill to a vote before the holidays.

headline: Nokia Sues Apple for Patent Infringement in Europe
text: BERLIN — In the latest salvo of a protracted legal battle, Nokia sued Apple on Thursday in Britain, Germany and the Netherlands, alleging that the U.S. technology company used 13 of its patents, including a basic touch-screen maneuver, without its permission.

headline: The Energy Future Ain’t What It Used To Be
text: The price of natural gas and electricity will be low over the next quarter-century, and crude oil will become more expensive but not radically so, the Energy Department predicted on Thursday, in a report that contradicts widely held notions.

headline: 36 Hours in Paris
text: HAS Paris lost its edge? Mais non! The city’s bohemians are just harder to find. The artsy denizens and creative tastemakers, always on the hunt for cheaper rents, have migrated to the city’s fringes, like Belleville and the former red-light district of Pigalle. There are even fashion-forward hangouts in the postcard-perfect center — a pop-up restaurant here, a taxidermy-stuffed speakeasy there. And, of course, a modern take on the classic Parisian bistro or boulangerie will never go out of style.

headline: Be Cynical About the Refinance Process
text: As least until recently, we’ve been in the midst of a refinancing boom. So consumers applying for refinancings should at least expect some delays.

headline: Finance A-Listers Come Out for UJA-Federation Dinner
text: Nachas, Yiddish for joy, was in high supply Wednesday night as more than 1,100 members of New York’s Jewish community gathered to honor two of their own at the UJA-Federation’s annual Wall Street Dinner.

headline: Barcelona’s Under-Sung Hero of Moderisme
text: Often hailed as the most modern of the modernistas, Lluís Domènech i Montaner’s most important buildings in Barcelona have been designated a World Heritage Site.

headline: Barcelona’s Other Architect, Domènech
text: IT’S sometimes hard to have a conversation about Barcelona that does not include the name Gaudí in it. The world is so gaga for Antoní Gaudí — the genius of Catalan modernisme (the Spanish version of Art Nouveau) whose early 20th-century buildings are virtual emblems of the city — that most of his modernista contemporaries go little noticed by tourists.

headline: How Does Your Hospital Room Make You Feel?
text: During a conversation with the wife of one of my former surgery patients, I was surprised to learn that her husband had chosen to receive his postoperative chemotherapy treatments at a hospital across town from mine. His wife assured me that he had liked the highly respected colleague I had referred him to; what had troubled him was that the doctor’s office and the hospital chemotherapy infusion suites were, well, depressing.

headline: A Hospital Room With a View
text: With the current emphasis on reining in costs, increasing productivity and improving safety, it’s hard not to view the personal amenities offered by certain hospitals with some level of suspicion. While the well-appointed lobbies, personalized meal services and private rooms with a view — all designed to make hospitals feel un-hospital-like — can be meaningful to patients, families and even clinicians and staff, few of us have ever acknowledged their role in patient care. Instead, we tend to deride these nonclinical services as fluffy perks at best and frivolous manifestations of profit-driven medicine at worst.

headline: Popcast: Top 10 Albums of 2010
text: This week on Popcast, The Times’s weekly music podcast: the first of a three-part review of the year in pop and jazz, with our critics discussing their Top 10 lists, 2010’s most intriguing artists and the fine art of listmaking itself.

headline: Asked and Answered | Emma Reeves
text: As the former photography director for Dazed & Confused, AnOther and Tar Magazines, Emma Reeves has worked with some of the sharpest shooters in the game. She’s also made stops at V and The Journal, and worked as a curator. (She pulled together David Armstrong’s “Mad About the Boy” at Half Gallery last month.) So when Christian Parkes, the head of marketing for Levi’s, reached out to her to create the programming for the brand’s Photography Workshop at 18 Wooster Street in SoHo, she says, “it was a natural fit.” The revolving door of installations, spread over 10 weeks and including “Tiny Vices,” curated by Tim Barber, an exhibition of Taschen’s mega-book “Portrait of a City,” speaking engagements by the likes of Bruce Davidson, and a workshop with state-of-the-art Leicas, was by all counts a smashing success. We caught up with the busy multi-hyphenate as she readied for Saturday’s triumphant closing party, to talk about Levi’s, lessons and the potential of participatory retail.

headline: Citigroup Opens Bank of the Future, Flat Screens and All
text: @import url("http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/css/multimedia/bundles/SlidingGallery.css");

headline: James, a Co-Star in Miami, Visits Stoudemire’s Stage
text: Miami

headline: Student Challenge | Caption a Times Photo With a Quotation
text: Winter break is almost here, and it’s time for our third Student Challenge:

headline: Finding Stylistic Significance in Rebounding
text: If we consider basketball to be a constant series of possessional puzzles, there is a seemingly endless number of ways for players to navigate to their desired ends. Knowing which players are talented enough to solve the puzzle and generate points for their respective teams is essential, but it’s just as crucial to understand the stylistic differences that influence the ways players score, pass, defend, and even rebound.

headline: You’re Roasted: Comedy Central Plans Satiric Salute to Donald Trump
text: When you examine the balance sheet of Donald J. Trump, is there really anything that funny about him, other than his relentless self-promotional streak, the seesawing fortunes of his “Apprentice” reality-television franchise, his string of marriages and his enigmatic hairline? That’s for the comedians to figure out: Mr. Trump, the real-estate mogul and media personality, will be the next victim guest of honor at a Comedy Central roast, the cable channel said on Thursday. “The Comedy Central Roast of Donald Trump” will be taped on March 9 – the first such roast to be filmed in New York since 2005, back when Comedy Central felt the comedian Jeff Foxworthy deserved the distinction – and broadcast in the spring. No slander-slinging panelists were immediately announced for the event, but if tradition holds, Mr. Trump can look forward to a speedy elimination from a future season of “Dancing With the Stars.”

headline: Slipper Index
text: Sales of slippers (and loungewear) as an indication of economic conditions.

headline: Former Icahn Lieutenant Plans Fund
text: Keith Meister, who was widely described as the billionaire activist investor Carl C. Icahn’s right-hand man, is starting an event-driven hedge fund that will be seeded by Soros Fund Management, people who have been briefed on the matter say.

headline: ‘Source Code’ to Open South by Southwest Film Festival
text: “Source Code,” a geeky, sci-fi thriller directed by Duncan Jones, will open the South by Southwest Film Festival in Austin.

headline: Apple to Open Its Mac App Store in January
text: Apple on Thursday announced that its Mac App Store will open for business on Jan. 6.

headline: Germany Will Begin Afghan Exit Next Year
text: BERLIN  Germany, which has the third largest military force in Afghanistan, will start withdrawing its 4,800 troops as early as next year, ending its mission there by 2014, the foreign minister told Parliament on Thursday.

headline: Media Decoder: Larry King's Last Show
text: Brian Stelter and David Carr on Larry King's final show on CNN.

headline: Larry King Signing Off
text: Related: As Larry King Leaves CNN, Everyone’s Talking

headline: A Platform For Dancers To Mix It Up
text: WHEN Judy Hussie-Taylor became the executive director of Danspace Project in 2008, she was a relative outsider whose career was mainly allied with arts organizations in Colorado. But her brief tenure has proven that having a high profile is overrated.

headline: Operas Absurd, Surreal and, of Course, Satirical
text: ‘LE GRAND MACABRE’ Avant-garde and Avery Fisher Hall aren’t usually mentioned in the same breath, but Alan Gilbert, the music director of the New York Philharmonic, turned the usually decorous space into a haven for the quirky characters of Ligeti’s surrealist, modernist opera. The work was vividly realized by Mr. Gilbert and a fine cast of singers in a sold-out production designed and directed by Doug Fitch, featuring imaginative multimedia and fantastical costumes by Catherine Zuber.

headline: Philharmonic Renewed Under a Bold Conductor
text: WITH the arrival of Alan Gilbert as the music director of the New York Philharmonic in 2009 came the promise of youthful vigor and bold initiatives. But who could have anticipated that by the midpoint of Mr. Gilbert’s second season the Philharmonic would be a potent, even groundbreaking force for contemporary music? The most striking example of Mr. Gilbert’s expansive view of the Philharmonic’s potential  and the greatest triumph achieved by any New York musical institution in 2010  came in May, when the orchestra presented the New York premiere of Gyorgy Ligeti’s opera “Le Grand Macabre”

headline: How Do You Say ‘Billionaire’ in Esperanto?
text: For a small group of linguists, scholars, and dreamers who have become accustomed to having their invitations overlooked, it was no small thing when George Soros, the billionaire, walked into the room to celebrate with them.

headline: Europe Set to Extend Rescue Fund
text: Casting aside their differences over how to contain the continuing debt crisis, Europe’s leaders on Thursday pledged to do “whatever is required” to defend their embattled currency.

headline: App Smart Extra: Stocking Stuffers for Teens
text: Thursday’s App Smart column offers ideas for people who want to give apps as gifts. Probably the hardest group to buy for, though, is teens, since they don’t like to talk to adults about anything, least of all their phones.

headline: A Workout to Make Pulses and Pedals Race
text: SEEN from the street, the cycling studio at SoulCycle, at Third Avenue and 83rd Street, is a gleaming white glass box  said to be inspired by London’s White Cube gallery. “The corner buzzes for us,” said Julie Rice, an owner.

headline: Streetscapes | Early Commercial Architecture
text: Some New York stores have vanished, but their distinctive architecture remains.

headline: Berms Built to Stop Oil Are Seen as Ineffective
text: A chain of sand berms built by the State of Louisiana to block and capture oil from BP’s runaway well in the Gulf of Mexico stopped a “minuscule” amount of oil and was largely a waste of money, the staff of the presidential commission investigating the spill said in a report issued on Thursday.

headline: North American Car of the Year Finalists Are Announced
text: The three finalists for North American Car of the Year honors were announced on Thursday, with the Hyundai Sonata, Chevrolet Volt and Nissan Leaf vying for bragging rights. One will receive the top honor on Jan. 10 during the Detroit auto show.

headline: The Insiders | Matt Kliegman and Carlos Quirarte
text: Matt Kliegman and Carlos Quirarte are the owners of the Smile, a restaurant/general store/downtown hangout. For breakfast, lunch or dinner, this cozy boîte hosts regulars like Hedi Slimane, Terry Richardson and Kate and Laura Mulleavy of Rodarte. By night, Kliegman and Quirarte operate the Jane Ballroom and are about to open their first nightclub, an ironic hipster strip joint on Clarkson Street and the West Side Highway, aptly named the Westway.

headline: In 500 Billion Words, New Window on Culture
text: With little fanfare, Google has made a mammoth database culled from nearly 5.2 million digitized books available to the public for free downloads and online searches, opening a new landscape of possibilities for research and education in the humanities.

headline: Yahoo May Shut Down Some Services
text: Dec. 17, 2:59 p.m. | Updated  Adding at the end that on Friday, Yahoo said it was not closing Delicious.

headline: Is Nexus S the One?
text: Google's new phone could be the best Android phone to buy, according to The New York Times' technology columnist.

headline: Unemployment Continues to Fall in City
text: Despite a dropoff in hiring of retail sales clerks heading into the holidays, the unemployment rate for New York City edged down again in November, to 9.1 percent, according to figures released Thursday by the State labor department.

headline: Portraits of Phantoms, Struggling to Stand Out
text: The man in the red robe looks familiar. It takes a minute to place some of the details  ah, yes, that louche cover-up, cocked elbow and rakish eye belong to Sargent’s Dr. Samuel Jean Pozzi. But this stranger doesn’t have a beard, and he sits rather than stands. At some point  it’s hard to say exactly when  you realize that he is also black.

headline: Now Heating | Pop Art Pop Tarts
text: With the $3 cupcake firmly entrenched across America, there’s a new contender for your playfully ironic baking dollar: designer organic Pop Tarts. The kitschy breakfast junk food is undergoing an artisanal reimagination thanks to Candice Reynolds, whose Atlanta-based Red Queen Tarts brings a small-batch, Slow Food ethos to that American classic.

headline: Theater Listings: Dec. 17 — 23
text: Theater

headline: Officials Designate Public Lands for Solar Projects
text: The Interior Department has identified some two dozen potential sites for large-scale solar power installations on public lands in six Western states as part of an effort to encourage development of renewable energy on public lands and waters.

headline: Plenty of 2012 Debates, But No Candidates (Yet)
text: Political junkies: mark your calendars.

headline: Keeping Score: Anthony’s Potential Impact on Knicks
text: Carmelo Anthony was in the headlines this week when it was reported that he would not sign the contract extension offered to him by the Denver Nuggets unless he was traded to the Knicks.

headline: CNN Fills the Gap Between King and Morgan
text: CNN has a month of time to fill between Larry King’s last day and the first day for his replacement, Piers Morgan. Mr. King’s final edition of “Larry King Live” will be broadcast on Thursday.

headline: Another Season, Another Off Broadway Production for Amy Herzog
text: Amy Herzog, whose “After the Revolution” was one of the theater season’s best-reviewed plays during its fall run at Playwrights Horizons, will have a springtime followup: LCT3 announced that her new play, “4000 Miles,” would begin previews on June 6, with a June 20 opening date, at the Duke on 42nd Street.

headline: Oracle’s Profit Up 28%, Beating Forecast
text: SAN FRANCISCO  Continued technology spending by large corporations helped propel Oracle’s revenue to a 47 percent gain, and profit rose 28 percent in its second quarter.

headline: Awareness: Of Medicines and Mismeasurements
text: Giving the correct dose of an over-the-counter pediatric medicine is critical, but the package labeling and dosing information can be virtually incomprehensible. And an overdose can be deadly.

headline: Build We Won’t
text: It’s been obvious for a while that America, once the nation of heroic infrastructure, has become the place that can’t build stuff — the place whose greatest city continues to rely on a century-old tunnel under the Hudson, and can’t muster the political will to build another.

headline: A Workout Space for Hard-Core Pedaling
text: Seen from the street, the cycling studio at SoulCycle, at Third Avenue and 83rd Street, is a gleaming white glass box — said to be inspired by London’s White Cube gallery. “The corner buzzes for us,” said Julie Rice, one of the two owners.

headline: Leslie Wohlman Himmel
text: Ms. Himmel, 56, is a managing partner at Himmel + Meringoff Properties, which owns and operates more than two million square feet of office and retail space in New York City, including 521-33 West 57th Street and 729 Seventh Avenue. Ms. Himmel is active on the Real Estate Board of New York, serving as chairwoman of its Economic Development Committee, which she founded in 1992.

headline: Hiring a Lawyer for Loan-Modification Help
text: STRUGGLING homeowners can sometimes benefit from hiring a lawyer to try to modify a mortgage or avert foreclosure, but avoiding scam artists and sketchy practices requires vigilance.

headline: The Implants Loophole
text: A recently recalled artificial hip made by a unit of Johnson & Johnson, designed to last 15 years or more, is failing worldwide at unusually high rates after just a few years.

headline: The Single-Story House Makes a Comeback
text: ELLIE SALMAGGI, a medical secretary, reared four children in a two-story Dutch colonial in Water Mill. And when the four, now ages 29 to 37, had all flown the coop, Ms. Salmaggi wanted to downsize.

headline: Humans, Like Animals, Behave Fearlessly Without the Amygdala
text: In the 1930s, researchers discovered that when a certain part of monkeys’ brains was removed, the animals became fearless. They approached snakes, started batting them around like sticks and played with their hissing tongues.

headline: Risks: Fewer Heart Problems Among Moderate Drinkers
text: A new study suggests that what matters to your health is not how much alcohol you drink, but how and when you drink it.

headline: This Shrine to Steak Deserves a Little More Respect
text: A reader wanted to know whether she could take her young children to the Peter Luger steakhouse in Brooklyn. You’ll see how I answered, and what other readers had to say about that, below. Also: Where to take parents who resemble George Costanza’s, from “Seinfeld.” Now, to the questions!

headline: In Old Lyme, Fighting a Curb on Year-Round Use
text: ROSEMARY BREEN owns two houses but is ready to downsize. Approaching 60, and with a disabled husband, Ms. Breen, a school nurse, hopes to sell their colonial in Newington and move to their wood-shingled Cape Cod in Point O’ Woods, one of several beach communities in the shoreline town of Old Lyme.

headline: Producers Ask Audience to Help Bring Back ‘The Scottsboro Boys’
text: Undertaking an unusual poll-cum-pledge-drive among theatergoers, the producers of the Broadway musical “The Scottsboro Boys,” which closed on Sunday because of weak ticket sales, are asking fans and others to commit on the show’s Web site to buying $99 tickets if the musical were to reopen on Broadway this spring.

headline: Developing in a ‘Final Frontier’ of Hoboken
text: EVEN in a tough real estate market, certain niches are considered evergreens for developers  and Hoboken rental property is clearly one. The latest evidence is a local builder’s plans to erect a 113-unit rental tower on a vacant lot beside the light-rail tracks on the west side, starting work as soon as possible next year.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Pakistan and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Pakistan, India and Germany.

headline: Report Shows How Pakistan Still Bedevils Obama
text: WASHINGTON — When the Obama administration began earlier this year to assess its progress in Afghanistan and Pakistan, some officials suggested reversing the usual bureaucratic shorthand and calling it the “PakAf review.”

headline: Week 15 in Fantasy Football: Matchups and Q. & A.
text: The brothers Sablich are here to help with fantasy football analysis for Week 15. They will also answer reader questions until 5 p.m. Eastern on Friday. Post a question below and follow them on Twitter for more advice leading up to game time on Sunday.

headline: Fireside Sitting When Jack Frost’s Nipping
text: WINTER in New York City usually comes with an urge to hunker down at home to escape the cold. But while the blasting heat from apartment radiators may be warming, it’s not exactly as cheering as a fireplace.

headline: Junkyard Architecture
text: THE economic downturn and a shift to recycled and repurposed material have brought out the creative side of architects and builders.

headline: Park Slope Plane Crash | The Readers Remember
text: Hundreds of readers have sent in their memories of the day two airliners collided over New York City. They include friends and relatives of those who died, a list of whom can be read here. This brief selection has been lightly edited.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Pakistan and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Pakistan, India and Germany.

headline: Elite Colleges Continue to Fill Slots Early
text: As high school students who have applied for early admission to selective colleges receive their decision notifications this week, they may have difficulty putting that “Yes,” “No,” or “Maybe” in a broader, statistical context.

headline: Childhood: A Caffeine Buzz From Soft Drinks
text: A small study at an urban pediatric clinic suggests that children younger than 12 are routinely consuming so much caffeine that it could interfere with their sleep. The source, almost exclusively, is caffeinated soft drinks, like Coca-Cola.

headline: The Far-Ranging Artistic Alliances That Shaped a Sculptor
text: Artists are supposed to be relentless networkers, but the multitasking, multicultural sculptor-designer Isamu Noguchi was industrious even by this standard. The staggering depth and diversity of his connections come to light in “On Becoming an Artist: Isamu Noguchi and His Contemporaries, 1922-1960” at the Noguchi Museum in Long Island City, Queens.

headline: A Cause and a Solution for Haiti
text: So far, the news from Port au Prince is grim: cholera infections are on the rise across Haiti, more than 2,000 people have died, and the end is nowhere in sight.

headline: Architectural Souvenirs of Bygone Stores
text: IF you’ve bought all your presents, Christmas Eve is a good moment to visit half a dozen stores that don’t sell anything, don’t take returns and don’t accept credit cards. These ghost businesses vanished from New York decades ago, but left behind their distinctive architecture as a gift to the street.

headline: How Do You Say ‘Billionaire’ in Esperanto?
text: For a small group of linguists, scholars and dreamers who have become accustomed to having their invitations overlooked, it was no small thing when the billionaire George Soros walked into the room to celebrate with them, Alison Leigh Cowan of The New York Times reports.

headline: ‘Home Theaters’ for the Victorian Age
text: Victorian toymakers spun off products from the latest theatrical productions soon after the plays opened. Printers manufactured miniature paper and wood theaters with accurate sets and costumed actors dangling on wires, footlights that burned gas or oil, and scripts for children to memorize.

headline: House Tour: Old Saybrook, Conn.
text: WHAT Three-bedroom house.

headline: Not Quite a Sprint iPhone, but Close
text: For people still shaking a fist at AT&T for its sole distribution of the iPhone, your workaround is here. It’s called the ZTE Peel, sold by Sprint, and it adds a 3G-to-Wi-Fi connection to an iPod Touch, giving it the capability to act as a phone.

headline: Drug Makers New Targets for U.S. Fraud Inquiries, Report Says
text: Four pharmaceutical companies paid more than half of the $19.8 billion in civil and criminal settlements the last 20 years for improper billings to federal and state governments, according to a report Thursday by Public Citizen’s Health Research Group.

headline: Holiday Fun With Joe Yoga and in Parks
text: This week the miser offers a mixed bag of cheap events to help get you fired up or chilled out, depending on your holiday needs.

headline: A Few Boring Ways to Spend $300,000
text: Pocketing $300,000 from the CFDA/Vogue Fund in mid-November, Billy Reid did not consider (a) having a Paris runway show; (b) spitting out some dresses for the Oscars; or (3) inviting his friends over for beer and shrimp. “There was a day when I would have said it would go for a party,” Mr. Reid, who operates his men’s and women’s design business from Florence, Ala., said today, a month after winning the fund’s top prize.

headline: Wyden to Have Prostate Surgery — and Maybe Miss Votes
text: Senator Ron Wyden, Democrat of Oregon, will undergo surgery on Monday for early-stage prostate cancer, his office said, potentially denying Democrats a crucially needed vote at the end of an extremely busy lame-duck session.

headline: Reflections on the Self and the Wider World
text: PHILADELPHIA — Signs of genuinely vital artistic life are irregular in the Philadelphia Museum of Art’s ambitious survey of early work by the innovative Italian postwar artist Michelangelo Pistoletto. But it is not for lack of trying.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene: 'Rabbit Hole'
text: John Cameron Mitchell, the director of the drama “Rabbit Hole,” discusses a scene from the film.

headline: Guggenheim Defends Show of Trustee’s Art
text: When the New Museum presented an exhibition of artwork belonging to one of its trustees, “Skin Fruit: Selections From the Dakis Joannou Collection,” outraged critics questioned the decision, saying such a show represented, among other things, too much curatorial power for a serious benefactor.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene: ‘Rabbit Hole’
text: After scoring its lead actress, Nicole Kidman, Golden Globe and SAG nominations this week, the drama “Rabbit Hole” arrives in theaters on Friday. Adapted by David Lindsey-Abaire from his Pulitzer-Prize winning play, the film centers on a couple who must cope with the loss of their young child.

headline: Patient Voices: Lupus
text: Hair loss, mouth ulcers, kidney disease, skin rashes, mental fog — the symptoms of lupus are mysterious, diverse and unique to each person. Six people discuss a life with lupus.

headline: Holiday Shipping Deadlines Approaching
text: If you’re planning to buy your Christmas gifts online or at least ship them and haven’t done so yet, you may want to act soon.

headline: Getting to Know Schumann Again, With Some Favorites
text: As the Schumann bicentennial year winds down, the classical music critics of The New York Times would like to share their latest thoughts about Schumann recordings. Some of their opinions have changed, others not, since their last survey of the field in 2004.

headline: Marking Time in Spirals, Pretzeling Through Space
text: In her program notes Tara O’Con thanks the Chocolate Factory staff “for letting us have an entire week to simply spend time in the space.”

headline: Casually Tough, Steeled by Ghosts
text: From this distance, the early 1960s Edinburgh and London acoustic folk scenes that produced the singer and guitarist Bert Jansch seem credulous, pious, sentimental to the point of mysticism, a lot of impressionable boys and girls trembling before the authentic.

headline: Leader and Players, Deeply Bound
text: Even as rehearsals were under way for the three important concerts by the Saito Kinen Orchestra in Carnegie Hall’s extensive festival JapanNYC, there was lingering uncertainty over the extent to which the conductor Seiji Ozawa, the festival’s artistic director, would be able to participate. Mr. Ozawa, 75, has been debilitated with health problems, including surgery and treatments for esophageal cancer and the worsening of chronic back ailments.

headline: Charades of Normalcy After Death of a Child
text: In the movies the death or endangerment of a child justifies both serious acts of violent revenge and violent displays of serious acting. Victorian literature, belonging to an age when people had — and lost — more children than is common today, treated juvenile mortality as an opportunity for high, almost consoling, sentiment. The famous image of Charles Dickens weeping as he sent little Nell into the great beyond is an emblem of cathartic, therapeutic sympathy. We modern souls, with fewer offspring, longer life expectancies and less metaphysical and moral certainty, are less easily soothed by vicarious grief.

headline: Heartaches and Harmonies
text: SONGWRITERS have been translating heartache into melody for centuries, scoring the human condition with weather-worn notebooks and battered guitars. As the Irish folk singer Frank Harte once said, “Those in power write the history, while those who suffer write the songs.”

headline: Funny Guys, Serious Business
text: “Let’s just hope it gets ugly, and then we’ll all have fun,” Conan O’Brien privately joked about his future at “The Tonight Show” back in 2004, never imagining just how ugly  and how far from amusing  his clash with Jay Leno would become. But who could have predicted that, instead of passing him the baton, Mr. Leno would beat him about the face and neck with it? Or at least that was the reigning narrative as this strange battle unfolded in January 2010.

headline: A Physical Choreography, Turning Women Into Targets
text: On returning to the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater after some months, the initial pleasure is always the same  and it’s powerful. These dancers! As soon as the curtain lifts, there’s a firm fullness of tone; a way of making dance positions register as volumetric solids larger and more three-dimensional than the body itself; a textured, rhythmic acuity; an athletically formal grace; and a glowing love of sheer performance.

headline: A New ‘Nutcracker’

headline: The Man Behind the New ‘Nutcracker’ in Town
text: For many American children Christmas and “The Nutcracker” go together like candy and cane. You can’t walk into a supermarket in December without hearing Tchaikovsky’s music for the ballet, or at least some version thereof, and white-wigged Nutcracker dolls can be found at the 99-cent store.

headline: CBS Survives
text: As the 21st edition of “Survivor” draws to a close, Wednesday’s episode helped lift CBS to No. 1 over all in the night’s ratings. According to Nielsen’s estimates, “Survivor: Nicaragua” attracted 12.4 million viewers, fewer than CBS’s “Criminal Minds” in the 9 p.m. hour (13.8 million) but the largest audience for the series since its season premiere. Wednesday’s episode, the last before the “Survivor: Nicaragua” finale on Sunday, easily outperformed its 8 p.m. time-slot competitors, including the first half of NBC’s reality competition “The Sing-Off,” which averaged 8.4 million from 8 to 10. NBC ranked second for the night, garnering 6.9 million viewers at 10 for a rerun of “Law & Order: SVU,” although that too lagged behind CBS’s drama “The Defenders” in the hour (10.2 million). Fox was third with a new episode of “Human Target” at 8 (5.8 million) and the season finale of “Hell’s Kitchen” at 9 (5.9 million). ABC finished fourth with a lineup of sitcom reruns.

headline: Ron Paul Appears Poised to Irk the Fed Chief

headline: A Closer Look at the G.D.P.
text: As the end of the year approaches, it seems appropriate to look at the economy from a macro-perspective – that is, at the level of gross domestic product or G.D.P. – to determine if the economy is growing, and if so, what G.D.P. components are contributing to growth. While this is not a definitive analysis of the economy, it does show if things are moving in the right direction. All of the statistical information that follows is from the Bureau of Economic Analysis, or B.E.A., and is inflation-adjusted.According to the National Bureau of Economic Research, the recession ended in June 2009, or the end of the second quarter of 2009. Since then, the U.S. economy has grown for 5 consecutive quarters at the following quarter to quarter rates: 1.6 percent, 5.0 percent, 3.7 percent, 1.7 percent and 2.5 percent. This is a median growth rate of 2.5 percent. The median growth rate for the first five quarters of the early 1990s and early 2000s expansions were 2.7 percent and 2 percent respectively, placing the growth rate of the current recovery right in the middle of the pack. This also indicates that slower growth at the beginning of a recovery is not atypical.

headline: Disappointed in Softball, but Will She Be Disappointed in Love?
text: In “How Do You Know,” a romantic comedy about missed opportunities, scripted and otherwise, Reese Witherspoon wears an industrial-strength smile and a laser twinkle that looks as if it’s set on kill. Although she’s routinely cast in frothy fare, Ms. Witherspoon comes with a hard, intimidating edge that most directors ignore. Maybe she prefers light and lovely over dark and dangerous. But as she showed in Alexander Payne’s 1999 comedy, “Election,” in which she played a ferocious high-school climber in a dazzling performance that has hung over her career like an unmet dare, she can be a beautiful menace.

headline: Culture of Recession? Or Vice Versa?

headline: A Dive Into Paganism and Promiscuity

Yet another project nurtured to fruition by the prolific producer and industry multi-hyphenate Larry Fessenden, this grubby dive into drugs, murder, paganism and promiscuity will need more than a cast stuffed with fanboy favorites to hold audiences in their seats.

headline: Gaza Mends, but Israelis See Signs of Trouble

Construction projects — sewage treatment plants, schools — are getting started but far fewer than needed. The border with Egypt, once sealed, is open but few people cross because security clearance is hard to get. And rockets and mortar shells fly daily from here into Israel, as Israeli troops carry out brief raids.

headline: The Revolution Next Time?

headline: Up Front: Garrison Keillor

headline: Mark Twain’s Riverboat Ramblings
text: Samuel L. Clemens was a cheerful promoter of himself, and even after he’d retired from the lecture circuit, the old man liked to dress up as Mark Twain in a fresh white suit and take a Sunday morning stroll up Fifth Avenue just as churches were letting out and see the heads turn and hear his name murmured, the crowds of Presbyterians and Episcopalians standing awe-struck as the most beloved mustache in America passed by, tipping his silk hat to the ladies. Mr. Twain’s autobiography was meant to be a last stroll around the block, and to build up suspense and improve sales, Sam told everybody that he was writing one and that it contained material so explosive it would need to be embargoed for a hundred years. That century has passed now and here it is, Volume 1 of “The Complete Authentic Unexpurgated Edition, Nothing Has Been Omitted, Not Even Scandalous Passages Likely to Cause Grown Men to Gasp and Women to Collapse in Tears — No Children Under 7 Allowed to Read This Book Under Any Circumstance,” which made Sam front-page news when all three volumes of the “Autobiography of Mark Twain” were announced last spring. The book turns out to be a wonderful fraud on the order of the Duke and the Dauphin in their Shakespearean romp, and bravo to Samuel Clemens, still able to catch the public’s attention a century after he expired.

headline: Massachusetts: Guilty Plea for Lying Way Into Harvard
text: A man who authorities said falsified his academic record to get into Harvard University pleaded guilty Thursday to larceny, identity fraud and other charges. Adam Wheeler, 24, was sentenced to two and a half years in prison, 10 years of probation and $45,000 in restitution. According to the sentence, Mr. Wheeler will serve only 30 days in prison. In May, Mr. Wheeler was charged after forging his transcripts and receiving more than $50,000 in scholarships and grants from Harvard. Mr. Wheeler applied to the university as a transfer student, sending fabricated records from M.I.T. and Philips Academy. In reality, Mr. Wheeler attended a public high school in Delaware and Bowdoin College.

Magnitsky, a lawyer who died in pretrial detention last year. Russia condemned the move, saying that European politicians were jumping to conclusions before the investigation into Mr. Magnitsky’s death had been concluded. Mr. Magnitsky’s colleagues have identified 60 Russian officials who they said played a role in jailing Mr. Magnitsky and denying him medical care.

headline: Letter: Networker on a Mission
text: Most political activism requires some simplification of the issues to garner public support. The question is whether John Prendergast’s simplifications undermine the causes to which he is dedicated. I think they do. They understatethe scale of the interventions neededto effect change, even as they exaggerate the potential of American clout, and they understate the complexity of the problems facing these countries, which can lead him to champion potentially disastrous ideas. Underlying these simplifications is a deeply American faith in our own capacity — for doing good, for getting things done — a faith that Hollywood has always been happy to indulge. I wish that Prendergast would focus more on the capacity of local people, many of whom are working at extraordinary personal risk to bring peace to their lands. The question shouldn’t be “What can we do to end the suffering in these countries?” but rather “What can we do to help people within their societies overcome the enormous political and economic challenges they face?” The difference is all in where you place the emphasis.

headline: Bigger Is Easier

headline: Drury Shows Rangers What They’ve Been Missing

headline: Zimbabwe: First Lady Sues Over Cable
text: President Robert Mugabe’s wife, Grace, has sued The Standard, an independent weekly, for reporting on a State Department cable obtained by WikiLeaks. The cable quoted a mining executive implicating her and the head of the Reserve Bank, Gideon Gono, in illegally profiting from the sale of diamonds mined in eastern Zimbabwe. Through her lawyer, she called the report false and demanded damages of $15 million, The Herald, a newspaper controlled by Mr. Mugabe, reported Thursday.

headline: Round Up the Usual Prospects
text: To no one’s shock, the lame-duck session is offering daily profiles in hypocrisy by lawmakers who made loud campaign vows to “change the culture” of Washington. In the Senate, prominent Republicans who took the anti-earmark pledge as part of the Tea Party crusade against deficits now must deal with a mammoth $1.2 trillion government spending bill that happens to be routinely packed with their own customized pork. What to do?

headline: For Iraqi Security, the Ultimate Sacrifice
text: In a country fractured by sect and ethnicity, Bilal Ali Muhammad’s last act — throwing himself onto a suicide bomber — was a burst of heroism set against the viciousness that still stalks Iraq.

headline: Small Steps on Global Warming
text: Given the chaos at last year’s global warming meeting in Copenhagen, delegates to this year’s sequel in Cancún, Mexico, hoped mainly to stop the bleeding. In fact, they did more than keep the battered United Nations process alive. Delegates were freed of the expectations of the conference in Copenhagen  which failed to achieve its main objective: a legally binding treaty limiting emissions. And they found common ground in a few achievable steps that will increase trust among nations and could form the basis for stronger measures down the road.
