text: Robert P. George, left, of Princeton and Cornel West of Princeton discuss the corrosion of our values.

headline: There Oughta Be a Law. Well, There Is.
text: Let’s be clear. We like bicycles. They are good for our air, good for our health, and, perhaps even someday, good for our traffic problems. New York City has about 483 miles of bike paths, some going back to the 1800s, and is adding 50 miles of bike lanes a year. City officials have recently been handing out data showing that these lanes “calm” traffic and cut down on fatalities.

headline: Acronym
text: Mark Scheerer writes in response to my column on the 20th anniversary of the World Wide Web: "Tim Berners-Lee says his friends gave him a hard time because his term, World Wide Web, 'yielded an acronym that was nine syllables long when spoken.' I believe it actually yielded an abbreviation or a set of initials -- not an acronym, or letters which form a word."

headline: Sides Far Apart on a Potential Pistons Sale
text: After months of negotiations, talks to sell the Detroit Pistons have hit a major impasse as Karen Davidson, the team’s owner, and Mike Ilitch, the leading candidate to buy the club, remain far apart on price.

headline: Blackwater Founder in Deal to Sell Company
text: Erik D. Prince, the founder of the private security firm formerly known as Blackwater Worldwide, has reached a deal to sell his embattled firm to a small group of investors based in Los Angeles who have close ties to Mr. Prince, according to people briefed on the deal.

headline: Japan Announces Defense Policy to Counter China
text: TOKYO — Japan announced a new defense policy on Friday that will respond to China’s rising military might by building more submarines and other mobile forces capable of defending Japan’s southernmost islands.

headline: Isolated County in Tibet Is Linked to Highway System
text: China announced Thursday that it had connected a Tibetan county, Medog, to the nation’s highway system, ending the relative isolation of the area. Until Wednesday, Medog, in the eastern part of the Tibet Autonomous Region, was the last county in China with no highway linking it to the outside world, officials said. The announcement was made on the front page of China Daily, an English-language newspaper, and signaled the pride that Chinese officials have in the country’s rapid infrastructure development.

With its endless buzz of people, cars and street parties, this city throbs with energy. But a new exhibition at Gallery BMB (Yantra Annexe, Queen’s Mansion, Ghanshyam Talwatkar Marg, Near Cathedral School, Fort; 91-22-6171-5757; www.gallerybmb.com), running through Jan. 10, shows photographs from the 1930s and ’40s that portray the city in a different light: notably, calm and peaceful.

The perfume equivalent of a vertiginous heel, it contains come-hither hints of Indonesian patchouli, tiger orchid and toffee. Python-printed packaging and a faceted bottle reminiscent of hand-blown Murano glass make it the perfect powder-room accessory for the unapologetic stiletto set. $95 for 3.3 ounces; available Jan. 15 at Saks Fifth Avenue. Call (800) 347-9177 for more information.

headline: Machinations, Criminal And/or Familial
text: BOARDWALK EMPIRE (HBO) This drama about the machinations — criminal, political, social, sexual — in Atlantic City during Prohibition combines themes of HBO’s two best series. Like “The Sopranos,” “Boardwalk” examines the conflicted ethics of New Jersey racketeers. Like “The Wire,” it explores the charcoal-gray territory where cities are forced to operate. Like those series, “Boardwalk Empire” boasts a rocking credit sequence, affecting direction that doesn’t intrude and a cast that never seems to be “acting.”

headline: The President and the Passions
Greene, With Curiosity
text: This interview is for our annual Ideas Issue, and because you’re a physicist at Columbia University who specializes in string theory and the secret life of invisible particles, let mestart by asking you this: Do you think the fieldof physics is continuing to provide the world with big, important, Einstein-level ideas?  Absolutely. Physics grapples with the largest questions the universe presents. Wheredid the totality of reality come from? Did time have a beginning?

headline: A Physicist Solves the City
text: Geoffrey West doesn’t eat lunch. His doctor says he has a mild allergy to food; meals make him sleepy and nauseated. When West is working — when he’s staring at some scribbled equations on scratch paper or gazing out his office window at the high desert in New Mexico — he subsists on black tea and nuts. His gray hair is tousled, and his beard has the longish look of neglect. It’s clear that West regards the mundane needs of everyday life — trimming the whiskers, say — as little more than a set of annoying distractions, drawing him away from a much more interesting set of problems. Sometimes West can seem jealous of his computer, this silent machine with no hungers or moods. All it needs is a power cord.

headline: When $250,000 Equals $315,000
text: We’ve heard from several readers who wanted to know how much money households with $250,000 a year in adjusted gross income — that is, those who would have been affected by the Democrats’ original proposal on the Bush tax cuts — actually make. The answer seems to be about $315,000 a year.

headline: Granting Anonymity
text: Transparency is secretive business. WikiLeaks, the swashbuckling new-media organization whose motto is “We open governments,” relies on a technology of extreme reticence called Tor Hidden Services — a part of the Tor Project, a nonprofit organization dedicated not to light and clarity but to shadows and opacity, to the increasingly difficult art of keeping secrets online.

headline: Letters: The Stress-Testing of Jamie Dimon
text: I worked for JPMorgan Chase for around 14 years until I lost my job in the wholesale mortgage division in 2009. Jamie Dimon is a tremendous leader. Not infallible, of course, but a very solid one. What set Jamie apart from the rest was that he appreciates ideas. Even though I was seven or more levels from the top, I would, on occasion, send him some ideaI had that was bigger than my small department. Without fail, he would respond by thanking me or letting me know that he had passed it on to the appropriate leadership. But what about the future of JPMorgan Chase? Jamie won’t be there forever. Sooner or later a successor will arise. And since our nation must be even more risk-conscious thanJamie, we must remember that no matter how much thought and time is put into the succession decision,it may place us in the position of facing a far-too-big-to-fail bank that is headed by a successor not nearlyso astute, sure-footed or thoughtful as Jamie Dimon. That is the issue.

headline: Letter: Cardioball
text: It was with a sense of déjà vu that I read Michael Sokolove’s article about the University of Oregon’s fast-tempo football team. Oregon shares the same preliminary good fortune that the University of Illinois basketball team had in 2005 — a very quick team from a school that most national fans know little about. Unfortunately, on Jan. 10, Oregon will discover, just as Illinois did, that speed in a B.C.S. bowl game or an N.C.A.A. basketball final is neutralized by incessant TV timeouts that give your opponent ample time to rest up. In today’s sporting world, quickness will never have the impact it had in John Wooden’s day, except perhaps in boxing, where the timeouts are

headline: Two Sought in Brooklyn Subway Robberies
text: The police are seeking the suspects in two unrelated cellphone robberies in the subway system in Brooklyn. In the more recent, a man sat beside a 23-year-old woman on a Manhattan-bound C train en route to the Jay Street station around 6:15 Tuesday evening, showed her the handle of a gun and instructed her to put her cellphone in his jacket pocket. She did as she was told. The man got off at Jay Street and fled.

headline: You’re a Big Girl Now
text: One of the great picture-book traditions is to offer up a worst-case scenario (“There’s a Nightmare in My Closet” springs to mind), then allow children to resolve it through the simultaneous intimacy and remove of story­telling. And it is one of Mo Willems’s many achievements to be, if not the first, then certainly the best author to present the dread heartbreak of the lost stuffed animal — in this case a certain beloved Knuffle Bunny.

headline: Blatter Apologizes for Comments About Gay Sex

text: After a while this monthly post is starting to write itself: Once again, Nevada registered the highest unemployment rate in the nation in November, at 14.3 percent, and North Dakota again recorded the lowest jobless rate, at 3.8 percent.

headline: Whistles in the Distance
text: They’re big, they’re fast, they whistle loudly. So you wouldn’t think trains needed a public relations campaign among the younger set. But it’s undeniable that these behemoths have receded drastically from everyday American life. Two new, wonderfully illustrated books bank on trains’ innate appeal while giving children a keener sense of their former glory and power.

headline: Oh, the People You’ll Eat!
text: Norton Juster and Jules Feiffer are names of ancient power. Half a century ago, they collaborated on the children’s classic “The Phantom Tollbooth.” Juster, an architect, went on to become a professor of design and write more books; Feiffer went on to become Feiffer. Now they’ve teamed up again for “The Odious Ogre,” a large and handsome picture book that should bring pleasure to a lot of people — and not only children. Like “Oh, the Places You’ll Go!” and “Shrek!” this book is really meant for ages 3 to 300.

headline: We Can Finish By Christmas, Reid Says
text: With a voluminous spending bill shoved off the table and the debate over the arms control treaty with Russia well underway, Congress could easily finish its business before Christmas, Senator Harry Reid, the majority leader, said on Friday morning from the Senate floor.

headline: A Heroic Feat: With New Date for Opening, ‘Spider-Man’ Could Set Previews Record
text: The Broadway musical “Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark” will delay its opening night by four weeks, until Monday, Feb. 7, to provide more time for its creators — the director Julie Taymor and U2’s Bono and the Edge — to make changes in the $65 million show before theater critics review it, the lead producer announced on Friday. As a result, the musical will now have a total of 10 weeks of preview performances, one of the longest stretches in Broadway history.

headline: Unpaid Medical Bills and Your Credit
text: When Darryle Watson, 52, of Texas tried to refinance his mortgage last fall, he was in for a surprise. Being meticulous about paying his bills on time, Mr. Watson thought he would quality for a big reduction in his monthly payments. It turned out that four unpaid medical bills he wasn’t even aware of had hurt his credit score. Mr. Watson is now trying to track down the collection agencies that are handling the bills to determine how much he owes.

headline: Vatican: Pope Compares Fundamentalism With Secularism
text: Pope Benedict XVI compared religious fundamentalism to secularism on Thursday, decrying violent attacks on Christians in the Middle East and more subtle hostility from Western institutions. “It should be clear that religious fundamentalism and secularism are alike in that both represent extreme forms of a rejection of legitimate pluralism and the principle of secularity,” he said. He also decried “hostility and prejudice” against Christians in Asia, Africa and in the Middle East, citing the October attack on a Syrian Catholic church in Baghdad in which 58 people died. “Christians are the religious group which suffers most from persecution on account of its faith,” he said.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: An aggregation of links by the reporters and editors of Diner’s Journal.

headline: China: Last County Linked to Highway System
text: China announced Thursday that it had connected a Tibetan county, Medog, to the nation’s highway system, ending the relative isolation of the area. Until Wednesday, Medog, in the eastern part of the Tibet Autonomous Region, was the last county in China with no highway linking it to the outside world, officials said. The announcement was made on the front page of China Daily, an English-language newspaper, and signaled the pride that Chinese officials have in the country’s rapid infrastructure development.

headline: Cleaning Up the Madoff Mess
text: Irving H. Picard, the trustee appointed by the court to liquidate Bernard L. Madoff’s Ponzi scheme, has filed hundreds of lawsuits in his effort to reclaim money from those investors who profited from the scheme to pay back those investors who lost money.

headline: Italy: Sentence Upheld in Murder of British Student
text: Italy’s highest court on Thursday upheld the 16-year sentence of a man convicted of killing a British exchange student in Perugia in 2007. Rudy Guede, a Perugia resident born in Ivory Coast, was one of three people convicted of the murder and sexual assault of 21-year old Meredith Kercher during what prosecutors said was a sex-game gone wrong. Mr. Guede had been sentenced to a 30-year term, reduced to 16 on appeal. The other defendants, Amanda Knox, a Seattle college student, and Raffaele Sollecito, her former Italian boyfriend, are appealing prison sentences of 26 and 25 years respectively. Mr. Guede’s lawyer, Walter Biscotti, said he was disappointed with the outcome of the trial. “We did everything that we could,” he said.

headline: Empathy 101
text: The first time Jessamyn Conell-Price met Moira Nichols, they had a lively lunch with several of Mrs. Nichols’s friends, all of whom volunteer at the community library. Then the two women chatted a bit in Mrs. Nichols’s apartment and took a stroll around the neighborhood.

headline: Nicked at Night
text: In 2004, when “Late Night With Conan O’Brien” was still following “The Tonight Show With Jay Leno” like a puppy trailing a Clydesdale, O’Brien was asked how he felt about Leno’s new five-year contract extension. Having secretly been promised the “Tonight Show” job by NBC once that contract was up (with Leno’s reluctant, bewildered assent), that beamish redhead couldn’t resist stirring the caldron anyway: “Let’s just hope it gets ugly, and then we’ll all have fun.”

headline: Clear the Snow Before You Go
text: AS snow falls in New Jersey this winter, brooms may be moving over car roofs faster than in a Quidditch match at Hogwarts. A state law that took effect in October requires motorists to clean ice and snow off all exposed surfaces of vehicles before they start rolling. Fines range from $25 to $75.

headline: Pakistan’s Palette of Blood and Tears
text: KARACHI, Pakistan  In this chaotic city of 18 million people, an exhibition of works by Pakistan’s most significant contemporary artists shows just how imbued with violence daily life here is: on the street, in the air and in the debate about the future course of the nation.

headline: Yao’s Fragile Feet Could End Career
text: A sad truth may be defining the legacy of Houston Rockets center Yao Ming: his feet may be too fragile to endure the wear and tear of playing professional basketball.

headline: A Healthful Twist on Holiday Appetizers
text: In this week’s Recipes for Health, Martha Rose Shulman draws inspiration from the tapas of Spain and the crepes of France to offer light bites for the holiday season. “There are plenty of healthy options for foods you can eat with one hand while balancing a drink in the other — and I’m not just talking about crudités,” she writes. Here are five festive appetizer ideas.

headline: The Art of Counting the Days
text: Who doesn’t have an old date book (or two) collecting dust somewhere, an essentially useless item we keep for the pretty pictures or the memories or both? David P. Earle, an L.A.-based artist and writer, has a few — “I love to find my own doodles,” he says — but that’s only part of the inspiration behind his new project, “The Open Daybook.”

headline: E.P.A. Sets Tighter Rules for Hudson River Cleanup
text: The Environmental Protection Agency announced tighter requirements on Friday for the second phase of General Electric’s cleanup of chemical pollution in the Hudson River, imposing a stringent limit for the first time on how much contamination can be capped and sealed on the riverbed rather than removed.

headline: Weekend Competition: Nifty Ways to Leave Your Lover

text: One of the people accused of being a supplier was a 30-year-old Brooklyn man, possibly better known to some as a seller of ice cream from a Mister Softee truck. Whatever money he saved, he said in an interview, he would eventually squander on cocaine to use or, occasionally, sell.

headline: What the New Insider Trading Cases Mean
text: With the arrest of four defendants, including three experts, on insider trading, federal prosecutors continue to crack down on the disclosure of confidential information. The criminal complaint filed on Thursday contains a wealth of details about the direction of the investigation — and gives some indication about potential developments.

headline: A Spiritual Defense of Gifts
text: After we discussed gift giving on Motherlode a few weeks ago — with lots of talk about experiential or charitable gifts, rather than more “stuff” — I heard from Amy Julia Becker. Becker is a seminary graduate who writes often about ethics and is more than familiar with the clash of morality and materialism. So I was a bit surprised to receive her e-mail in which she asked to write a guest post defending (sort of) all that “stuff.”

headline: Daly Says N.H.L. Revenue Sharing May Change
text: According to N.H.L. deputy commissioner Bill Daly, the league’s system of sharing revenue with lower-profile teams in large markets will likely change in the next collective bargaining agreement. In the C.B.A. that was negotiated in 2005, it was decided that teams in markets with television households of 2.5 million or more would not qualify for revenue sharing. As a result, the Islanders, New Jersey Devils and Anaheim Ducks are on the outside looking in.

headline: Neither These Vikings nor These Bears Keen on Ice
text: Ah, the joys of winter. There is nothing like the holiday spirit, time with friends and family, city-crippling snowstorms, collapsing football domes and the dulcet tones of N.F.L. players whining about having to play outdoors. These are the joys of winter in Minneapolis this week, with the N.F.L. approving the Vikings’ plan to play their home game against the Bears in the University of Minnesota’s outdoor stadium. Ear muffs in Minneapolis are coming in mighty handy, and not just because the high temperature Friday will not crack 15 degrees Fahrenheit.

headline: Lesbian Coach’s Exit From Belmont U. Has Nashville Talking
text: NASHVILLE  The day before Thanksgiving break, the members of the Belmont University women’s soccer team gathered in the locker room after a strength training session. Their coach, Lisa Howe, had something to say.

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: SUNSET PARK,  by Paul Auster (Frances Coady/Holt, $25.) In this tale of an Ivy League dropout lying low in Brooklyn waiting for his underage girlfriend to turn 18, Auster’s goal seems to be a conventionally satisfying novel that bucks many conventions of fiction.

headline: Running in Place
text: For Damon, the white South African protagonist of “In a Strange Room,” travel is a mostly pleasureless compulsion. In each of the three linked stories that make up this novel, he moves from place to place and country to country “in acute anxiety,” like a fever running its course. He is fleeing something — a romantic disappointment is mentioned in the first story, and hints of post-­apartheid moral exhaustion pervade all three. Yet what he experiences over the course of his travels is not the fool’s paradise of distraction from himself but just the opposite: the steady revelation of a central aspect of his character. By the third story, in which he travels to India with a mentally ill friend who comes apart disastrously, some immense, sad reality of life seems to be asserting itself through Damon’s quest to keep himself moving, long past any hope that his travels will heal him. Written in spare, controlled prose, these stories have a powerful cumulative effect that is on one level hard and comfortless, yet somehow also tender and humane.

headline: Paperback Row
text: ARTHUR MILLER: 1915-1962,  by Christopher Bigsby. (Harvard University, $19.95.) Tapping previously unseen material, Bigsby situates the great American playwright (1915-2005) in the political and social battles of his times, lavishing nearly 700 pages on his early work and greatest triumphs — including the towering drama “Death of a Salesman.”

headline: Fiction Chronicle
text: THE ACCIDENT  By Ismail Kadare.Translated by John Hodgson.  Grove, $24.

headline: Bush on Bush
text: They call themselves, smugly, “41” and “43,” meaning the 41st and 43rd presidents of the United States. You’re supposed to prefer the father, all graciousness and handwritten little notes, over the son, who — even in memoirs written at age 64 after two terms as president — seems callow. But I would take George W. Bush’s schoolboy petulance and solipsism, which at least seem authentic and human, over George H. W.’s grandee-with-a-switchblade any day. There is something very modern, almost New Agey, and endearingly insecure, about the tone and posture the son adopts in “Decision Points.” Even as he’s bombing Baghdad back to the Stone Age, he’s very much in touch with his feelings. In college, he says, he was appalled to learn how the French Revolution betrayed its ideals.

headline: The Solitary Life
text: In one of his notebooks from 1820, Giacomo Leopardi, the greatest Italian poet of the 19th century, wrote that “it is not enough to understand a true proposition; one must also feel the truth of it.” Writers of the Romantic age are supposed to make such statements. Theirs was the era of “the spontaneous overflow of powerful feelings” and “the holiness of the heart’s affections.” Coming from Leopardi, however, that credo can seem a little peculiar. Stunted by scoliosis, wearied from melancholy and badgered throughout his 38 years by his mother, a reactionary marchesa who stormed around the family palazzo in her riding boots, Leopardi was never an adventurer of felt experience. He spent most of his life confined by his parents to their home in the provincial hill town of Recanati, nestled above the Adriatic Sea.

headline: The Patriarch
text: Thomas Jefferson has often been described as an enigma. He was a slave owner who declared that all men are created equal. Despite insisting that he had no political ambition, he spent much of his life in politics. The third president of the United States, he saw himself foremost as a farmer, gardener and philosopher. Jefferson’s character was so multilayered and contradictory that successive generations have identified with and celebrated utterly different aspects of the same man. In a similar fashion, historians and biographers have studied various facets of his life — from the obvious, like his political thought, to the more obscure, like his love of wine. Now Virginia Scharff, a professor of history at the University of New Mexico, has sought to understand Jefferson through his relationships with the women he loved: his mother, Jane Randolph; his wife, Martha; his daughters and granddaughters; and his slave mistress, Sally Hemings.

headline: Person of the Year
text: FORT LEWIS, Wa. — Mark Zuckerberg is a name I grew quite familiar with even through my year in Kandahar. Facebook was the novelty through which I interacted with most of the world back home. Though it was accessible only on our trips to the forward operating base — no connectivity on our stranded outpost in the Zhari District. Despite all that Facebook meant to me while at war, I was less than thrilled to find that Mr. Zuckerberg had been named Time Magazine’s Person of the Year.

headline: The Euro’s Uneven Benefit in Europe
text: THE euro has been good for German exporters, and seems likely to get even better in the coming year. It has also been good for the Netherlands, which was the fourth-largest exporter in the euro zone in 2000 and now ranks second. But France and Italy suffered during the last decade as their shares of euro zone exports declined.

headline: More on Citi’s Credit Card Overhaul
text: In this weekend’s Your Money column, I pick apart Citigroup’s credit card reboot. It’s discontinuing a number of cards and introducing four new ones. A few perks are going away, some potentially lucrative ones are appearing for the first time, and the net result is … uncertain.

headline: In New York, for One Night Only, Nissan Drops Top on Murano

Keeping company with the new crossover convertible were the 2011 Quest minivan and Ellure concept, all of which bowed at November’s Los Angeles auto show.

headline: 5,000 Donors Help Louvre Buy a Painting
text: PARIS  The Louvre announced Friday that it had raised $1.3 million from thousands of online donors to buy a luminous Renaissance painting of three nude women that has never been displayed in public.

headline: The General Theory of Reservations
text: Friends, roam-ins, countrymen, lend me your ears. I come to bury Caesar salad, not to praise it. You call me for reservations when conventional methods fail, and since you are honorable diners, I try to accommodate your every ambition, but noble intentions are oft interred with fish bones. Allow me this brief moment to explain how reservations work, and the seating that subsequently follows.

headline: Estate Tax Will Return Next Year, but Few Will Pay It
text: Almost no one will have to worry about paying the estate tax under the tax legislation just approved by Congress. By one estimate, from Alan Rothschild, the chairman of the American Bar Association’s real property, trust and estate law section, less than one-half of 1 percent of people who die in 2011 will be hit by the estate tax. In contrast, 10.5 percent paid the estate tax in 1977.

headline: ‘Grey Gardens’ Team Will Make a Musical Out of ‘Far From Heaven’
text: Off Broadway’s Playwrights Horizons is reuniting with the composer and lyricist of its Tony Award-winning “Grey Gardens” on a new commission for a musical version of “Far from Heaven,” the 2002 film starring Julianne Moore as a 1950s housewife coping with a closeted gay husband and her romantic feelings toward a black gardener.

headline: The Revolution Is Being Shot on Digital Video
text: IN the closing credits for his independent confection “Guy and Madeline on a Park Bench,” the young director Damien Chazelle doesn’t just announce that he shot on film — he also names the black-and-white stock: Eastman Kodak Double-X Negative Film 7222. It’s a fitting coda to an enchantingly sincere romance about two people in love, or perhaps not quite, who sometimes break into song and dance. Mr. Chazelle, born in 1985, wears his nostalgic influences lightly, including John Cassavetes and the French New Wave, and has said that film was the only way to go for the story and aesthetic he was aiming for. I bet he also collects vinyl.

headline: Nuggets Need More Nene
text: Last night’s instant classic between the Spurs and Nuggets had it all: intrigue that naturally surrounds the league’s best team, great individual performances by the biggest names, a hotly contested result, a game-winner, would-be game-winner, controversial foul calls, and a finale that could propel this contest to Game of the Year status.

headline: Finding Needles in Google’s 500-Billion-Word Haystack
text: Google’s new online database, which allows users to sort through more than 500 billion words and phrases, might have been unveiled a little sooner than Thursday. But Jean-Baptiste Michel, one of the brains behind the database, confessed that the visualization tool that instantly charts a word’s frequency in books published between 1500 and 2008 was so engaging that he, his colleague Erez Lieberman Aiden, and others who saw the project kept getting distracted by trying out new phrases to graph.

text: The hardcover list this week is a mix of resurrected heroes and villains (the first volume of “Brightest Day,” at No. 2), mutant intrigue (“X-Force: Sex and Violence,” at No. 7) and zombies (yet another collection of “The Walking Dead,” at No. 8).

headline: James Looks at Home on the Garden Floor
text: LeBron James took the stage in front of a roaring audience. His play  good or bad  did little to influence the decibel level at Madison Square Garden on Friday night, and the noise reached ear-shielding levels by halftime. Instead, it was the Knicks who silenced the crowd during a second-half performance that seemed like a relapse to the poor play of the past few seasons.

headline: Motivators of 2010: Technology and Greed
text: Capitalism and con artistry: the economic catastrophe we faced in 2008 may have been avoided, at least for now. But it left behind a reservoir of dread and cynicism that have seeped into every corner of American life, even the movies. That unease found its way into one 2010 megahit, Christopher Nolan’s diabolical “Inception.” However convoluted and impenetrable, this cinematic labyrinth sabotages the very idea of reality with its notion of dream invasion, theft and implantation.

headline: Bergamo, Italy, a Medieval Town of Art and Architecture Near Milan
text: THE moon gently illuminated Piazza Vecchia, in the northern Italian town of Bergamo, one late October evening. Shadows speckled Renaissance-era buildings, houses with wrought-iron balconies and grand arched columns, while light created a glimmering sheen over the red brick squares of the plaza. From a 12th-century bell tower came the final echoes of the 100 tolls that once signified this town’s 10 p.m. curfew.

headline: Pinball Museums Light Up Around the Country
text: STEP inside the Shops at Georgetown Park, a shopping mall in Washington, D.C., and you’ll find two nine-foot-tall flippers and a giant floating silver ball. It’s not a piece of public art  it’s the entrance to the new National Pinball Museum.

headline: Restaurant Review: Koffmann’s in London
text: Retirement, it seems, did not suit Pierre Koffmann. The French chef, who once earned three Michelin stars at La Tante Claire, his restaurant in London’s Chelsea district, which he moved briefly to the Berkeley Hotel, in Knightsbridge, threw in his toque in 2004.

headline: Traveling in Southeast Asia With a Rock-Star Baby
text: SOON after landing in Ho Chi Minh City, we started to understand the implications of what we’d undertaken when our baby disappeared. At a corner pho shop, the waiter plucked her from our arms as soon as our noodle soup arrived. We didn’t see her again until the meal was over; we found her in the kitchen surrounded by the restaurant’s entire staff. At our hotel, she was instantly scooped up by a grinning receptionist who carried her outside and paraded her up and down the street, introducing her to everyone who lived along that narrow alleyway. In a teeming market in the old Chinese district of Cholon, a small mob flocked around us, hands outstretched to hold her.

headline: Wilmington, N.C.: Coolness Heats Up
text: Downtown Wilmington, N.C., has long been highly walkable, with pockets of real beauty and charm, forever promising a sleepy coolness that never quite materialized. But things are coming around.

headline: Study: Some Viewers Were Misinformed by TV News
text: News organizations can educate voters about public policy and economic conditions, but they can also misinform voters. As if to prove the point, a study released Friday found that “substantial levels of misinformation” seeped out to the electorate of the United States at the time of the midterm elections this year.

headline: The Perils of Crossing the Country in a 1958 Cadillac Eldorado
text: In this Sunday’s Automobiles section, I wrote about a cross-country trip I took with a friend in my 1958 Cadillac Eldorado, and of all of the joys and jolts that attend travel in a car from the days before cruise control and satellite radio, before even cup holders.

headline: Cable Shows Nations Going Easy on Cuba
text: WASHINGTON  Cuba is getting a free pass on its human rights abuses from many of the world’s leading democracies, with visitors from Canada, Australia and Switzerland failing to criticize the Castro regime or meet with dissidents while on the island, according to a confidential diplomatic cable sent to the State Department from Havana.

headline: Not Nominated, but Not Unloved
text: To celebrate the Friday afternoon at the end of a long week of accolades the Bagger would like to give some attention to those people who – like the forthright Stephen Dorff  – have not been adorned with any laurel wreaths so far. Actually, we’d like to point you to the slidelist that our pals over at New York Magazine put together, of the 25 best performances of the year that won’t win an Oscar.

headline: The Seguine Mansion
text: George Burke bought his historic Staten Island house in 1981, and painstakingly restored it, often with his own hands. The mansion, a New York City landmark, is open to the public four times a year.

headline: Weekend Fare
text: There won’t be any Do-Si-Dos or Thin Mints here. Members of the Lower Eastside Girls Club will be selling tins of holiday cookies on Saturday from 1 to 4 p.m. at La Vie, the club’s cafe, at 64 East First Street (First Avenue). The cookies, baked by the girls and young women, will be 50 cents to $2 each, with the proceeds to benefit the club. There will also be music and free prosecco (for adults). Tickets are $15 in advance (available online) or $20 at the door.

headline: Bill to Grant Legal Status to Immigrant Students Heads to a Vote in the Senate
text: The Obama administration joined with Latino leaders and immigrant advocates on Friday in a full-court press on behalf of a bill to grant legal status to hundreds of thousands of illegal immigrant students, which faces a decisive vote on Saturday in the Senate.

headline: The Seguine Mansion, a Tour Inside and Out
text: George Burke, 80, tells the stories behind the renovation of the mansion and some of his favorite treasures.

headline: A Mansion’s Ardent Admirer and Devoted Steward
text: WHEN George Burke was growing up on Staten Island in the 1930s and ’40s, he used to ride horses with a pair of sisters, Elizabeth and Belle Seguine. The Seguine girls, as they were called, lived in the Prince’s Bay section in a Greek Revival mansion, a sumptuous 16-room house an ancestor named Joseph Seguine had built in 1838. The colonnaded portico faced formal gardens, and a broad sloping lawn offered an expansive view of Raritan Bay.

headline: Fake or Real?
text: Those buying fake trees might not be doing the environment any favors.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Virginia and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Virginia, England, Ivory Coast and Belgium.

text: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#190", 592, 490, true, chameleonData);

headline: Turning Geek Into Chic
text: IT was a school night in November, and a ragtag band of self-appointed biologists was trolling the Web for discount lab equipment, the way some people scan Gilt for designer deals. Coming across a new NanoDrop Spectrophotometer, a device used to measure quantities of DNA, they perked up.

headline: The Baker’s Apprentice: Ciabatta
text: Emily Weinstein, who wrote a series on this blog about learning to cook, is now learning to bake with the food writer Dorie Greenspan. This week, the baker Sarah Black steps in for a lesson in making bread.

headline: On the Street | The Suit
text: More than 2,000 people cavorted in Santa garb last weekend for SantaCon, after a blast of arctic air set fashion on a winter track. Heads were sealed in hats and scarves.

headline: The Generous New Estate Tax
text: In his Wealth Matters column this week, Paul Sullivan looks at the impact of the new tax law on the estates of the wealthy. He concludes that only the richest of the rich will end up paying an estate tax over the next two years and that even those few people will be able to reduce their tax bill by taking advantage of the exemption for gift taxes.

headline: A Stealth Camera That Captures Big Cats
text: A few years back, scientists at Panthera, a nonprofit organization devoted to protecting large cats worldwide, were lamenting the state of survey technology to a member of their board, J. Michael Cline.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Virginia and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Virginia, England, Ivory Coast and Belgium.

headline: Oh, Come In. Glad to See You. Would You Like a Book?
text: It’s been more than eight years since I visited Ed Schmidt at home. A marvelously candid host, he told his dozen or so guests that he felt guilty that his theater writing wasn’t providing enough money for his wife. Still, he argued, striving to be Thornton Wilder, futile as it may be, is a noble pursuit. Then he served lamb stew.

headline: With 2.24 Million Watching, Larry King Bids Farewell
text: Larry King went out on top.

headline: In Defense of Stuff, Part 2
text: KJ Dell’Antonia a regular contibutor to Slate’s XXFactor blog (along with her own, RaisingDevils.com) has tried the “experiences are more valuable than gifts” approach. This Hanukkah in fact. It didn’t go all that well. And, like Amy Julia Becker this morning, Dell’Antonia has come to the conclusion that sometimes “stuff” is everything it’s cracked up to be.

headline: Posts From the Past
text: First, thank you to everyone who sent in their favorite vintage FiveThirtyEight post. Using an exacting and extremely scientific process, we picked 10 finalists from those nominations. Vote for your favorite in the comment section (the post that gets the most votes will win absolutely nothing).

headline: It’s Law: Obama Signs Compromise Tax Plan
text: President Obama signed the sweeping $858 billion tax bill into law on Friday afternoon, the culmination of a lawmaking process that featured intensive negotiations with Republicans and loud expressions of frustration from Democrats.

headline: Of All the Places to Kayak, Spots Reopen at Superfund Site
text: Everybody in the glop! Bowing to public outcry, the city will reopen two kayak launch spots along the newly Superfund-designated Newtown Creek, Assemblyman Joseph Lentol announced today.

headline: Charm, in Search of T.L.C.
text: THIRTEEN years ago, when James J. Schoenig moved with his family to the village of Brewster, about 50 miles north of Manhattan in Putnam County, he was drawn to its shady side streets lined with Victorians, and the small downtown complete with its own small movie theater.

headline: Beating the Streets Through Wrestling
text: The Beat the Streets foundation is helping turn around the city's once-dismal reputation for scholastic wrestling.

headline: Court Backs Patents for Diagnostic Tests
text: Diagnostic tests used to determine whether a patient is getting the proper dose of a medicine can be patented, an appeals court ruled Friday in a closely watched decision.

headline: Tax Cuts for Energy, Too
text: The just-concluded fight in Congress over taxes has mostly been viewed as an argument over the Bush-era tax cuts, but it was also a cliffhanger make-or-break deal for a variety of energy taxes.

headline: An End to Her Furnished Sublet Chapter
text: FOR nearly all of her postcollegiate life, Allison Castillo lived in fully furnished sublets. There were a few years when she actually owned a large piece of furniture  a bed  but “it was given to me by a friend who was moving out of town,” she said. So that didn’t quite count.

headline: Nothing Personal ...
text: Every year we receive holiday cards from friends with just a photo. No note or greeting, just names. We write something personal on each card to show our appreciation for their friendship. May I stop sending cards to these photo-only people? If they can’t be bothered to write a heartfelt note, why should I? S. Jacobs

headline: How Important Is the College You Choose?
text: Is the particular college you attend that important?

headline: Bobsledder Chose War to Repay the Army
text: LAKE PLACID, N.Y.  The Olympic bobsled pilot John Napier did not take any practice runs Thursday in advance of this weekend’s World Cup races here.

headline: Is Going to an Elite College Worth the Cost?
text: AS hundreds of thousands of students rush to fill out college applications to meet end-of-the-year deadlines, it might be worth asking them: Is where you spend the next four years of your life that important?

headline: Turning the Pages on 2010
text: OCTOBER, for mysterious reasons, once was known as “National Book Month,” but that tradition has largely lapsed, likely because so few people have the time to read for pleasure in that full-throttle period of deadlines and midterms that precedes the holiday rush.

headline: Echoes of Antiquity, With Avant-Garde Influences
text: For “Winds and Strings of Change,” a concert mixing indigenous Japanese hogaku pieces and contemporary works for traditional instruments on Thursday evening, the Miller Theater at Columbia University was either half full or half empty, according to your philosophical bent. The program was part of JapanNYC, a major festival that Carnegie Hall is presenting in its own auditoriums and in spaces around the city.

headline: Boehner Names Intelligence Panel Members
text: Representative John Boehner, who takes over as Speaker of the House in the 112th Congress, named his appointees to the important House Intelligence Committee on Friday. They will join Representative Mike Rogers of Michigan, who had already been named committee chairman.

headline: No Moving to Speak of, but Plenty of Speaking
text: At the start of “Made in China,” a new work by the collaborators Dragana Bulut and Milka Djordjevich, it’s not so much about what you see as what you hear (“Swan Lake”) and then, consequently, imagine (a lake). For those first few seconds the bare expanse of stage at Danspace Project, where the piece opened on Thursday night, seems as still as water.

headline: Paintings That Bring Nature Inside
text: COLD SPRING HARBOR, N.Y.

headline: WikiLeaks Founder Speaks Australian
text: Updated | 6:33 p.m. As a crowd of reporters and bystanders watched, and filmed, Julian Assange, the founder of WikiLeaks, visited a police station in the English town of Beccles on Friday, where he is obliged to check in each day as a condition of his release on bail.

headline: Group Calls Attention to Treatment of Carriage Horses
text: What could be more romantic than a holiday ride around Central Park in a horse-drawn carriage?

headline: Idiosyncratic Imagery
text: The traditional, Western way of approaching a painting is to treat it like a window. Linear perspective, developed during the Renaissance, even provided a scientific method for creating a sense of space opening up inside that picture window. But what if you scrapped the idea of the window, as modern painters did? And then decided to treat painting like a photograph or book? Perhaps you can see where we’re headed, from the title of “R. H. Quaytman: Spine, Chapter 20” at the Neuberger Museum.

headline: Big Deal | 15 Central Park West, Success Etched in Stone
text: When the developers set out to build 15 Central Park West, which has become something of a personality in its own right in a city obsessed with real estate, they were gambling that the rich and famous would embrace an aesthetic that evoked New York of the 1920s and 1930s.

headline: Rack of Lamb With Pimentón, Garlic and Olive Oil
text: Time: 30 minutes

headline: A Progressive Slant on Rack of Lamb
text: THE classic way to prepare rack of lamb is to top it with a mixture known as persillade, a combination of chopped parsley, minced garlic, olive oil and bread crumbs  almost always made from French-style white bread. Though perhaps a bit conservative, it’s undeniably delicious; in fact, most meat tastes good with a layer of persillade smeared on it.

headline: Talking to the Wall, and Not Liking the Answers
text: The last time we saw Judith Ivey on the Long Wharf stage, about a year and a half ago, she was playing one of the great Southern matriarchs, the quintessential Tennessee Williams monster-mother, Amanda Wingfield, in “The Glass Menagerie.” It was a performance that Charles Isherwood described in The New York Times as “a perfectly judged mixture of chiffon and steel” and a production that ended up in New York almost exactly a year later.

headline: A Celebration With a Little Harmony and a Lot of Funk
text: LEE FINKELSTEIN knows that for a lot of Long Islanders, Thanksgiving this year was not quite as funky as usual. And for that, the co-founder and manager of the 12-man band Funk Filharmonik has an explanation.

headline: Canadian Museum Backs Smithsonian Protest
text: The National Gallery of Canada has thrown its support behind a Canadian artist, AA Bronson, who is seeking to have one of his works withdrawn in protest from a National Portrait Gallery show, “Hide/Seek: Difference and Desire in American Portraiture.” The artist said he objects to the Smithsonian’s decision to pull a video from the show after it was criticized by the religious right.

text: My colleague Sam Grobart has posted a video explaining what cables you need for your TV. Now I am going to help you save some money on them.

headline: Brown Betty in a Boozy Cloak
text: FOR years, I was flummoxed by the idea of hard sauce. Why would anyone want to eat a sauce that you cut with a knife?

headline: Spreading the Care
text: The comments on this week’s column on kangaroo care were extraordinary.  Reader after reader told personal, emotional stories of how they did kangaroo care — wearing a baby for many hours a day on a parent’s chest — with their premature babies.  I particularly liked the story sent in by Anita Bruce of Modesto, Calif.: her five- and seven-year-old boys also took turns kangarooing their preemie sister.  Many other readers discussed the wonders of holding their newborns of normal weight, and even older children.  Clearly, kangaroo care was already familiar to many people, and its benefits instinctively appreciated.

headline: What the Rabbi Said
text: “A husband you want?” the old rabbi mumbled in Yiddish-accented English.

headline: Don Van Vliet, ‘Captain Beefheart,’ Dies at 69
text: Don Van Vliet, an artist of protean creativity who was known as Captain Beefheart during his days as an influential rock musician and who later led a reclusive life as a painter, died Friday. He was 69 and lived in Trinidad, Calif.

headline: 1 Artist, 2 Shows, 2 Mediums, 1 Vision
text: One of the most interesting figurative sculptors around, Huma Bhabha — born in Pakistan in 1962; now living in Poughkeepsie, N.Y. — recently began making large-scale photo-based works she calls drawings. And although her approach to both forms is similar, they’ve been separated in her two current solo shows, with sculptures at Salon 94 Bowery on the Lower East Side, and drawings with a few sculptures at Peter Blum Chelsea.

headline: A Racing Rush, With a Ferrari or an ’83 Toyota
text: Anything that can make me passionate about a 1983 Toyota Corolla has to be special. And yet at its best, Gran Turismo 5, Sony’s breath-snatching and definitive new racing simulator, is even better than special. It’s excellent.

headline: Shopping and Giving: The App

headline: A Turquoise Link to Willie Nelson
text: IT’S a curious paradox of the arithmetic of modern life. New creations  from films and books to paintings and plates  flourish via the absurdly simple creative equation: A + B = C. But if a creator is himself a chimera, a sum of a few parts, the same math doesn’t compute. Take James Franco, whose multifarious career paths seem to puzzle the most supposedly wide-open minds.

headline: Just When Should You Believe a Falsecard?
text: Here are some suggestions for the intermediate-to-advanced player on your holiday give list. In addition to the sites listed in Thursday’s column, the Bridge World Web site is also a good place to buy books.

headline: Early Harvests, Early Debuts
text: Two whites from Long Island’s early, especially ripe 2010 vintage have already made their debuts. The French, whose wine vocabulary seems limitless, would call them vins de plaisir  wines of pleasure.

headline: Gary Chapman, Internet Ethicist, Dies at 58
text: Gary Chapman, an educator, writer and widely recognized expert on the impact of high technology on society and public policy, died Tuesday while on a kayaking trip in Guatemala. He was 58.

headline: Power Suits Take On New Meaning

headline: ‘A Christmas Carol,’ the (Operatic) Sequel
text: Several composers have made operas of “A Christmas Carol,” the Dickens classic, but none of the works have gained a foothold in the seasonal repertory. The latest, Thomas Pasatieri’s “God Bless Us, Every One!,” may have better luck, partly because it offers a fresh view of the story’s characters. Here they are seen 20 years after the Ghosts of Christmas Past, Present and Future have transformed Scrooge from a miserly malcontent into a charitable model citizen and Christmas celebrator.

headline: Shop With a Worldview
text: At Épicerie Fine, a gourmet shop in Millburn, you’re likely to be greeted with a cheerful “Bonjour” by Béatrice Wandelmer, who owns the shop with her husband, Sami El Sawi.

headline: Greek Traditions, With Little Twists
text: STEP into Taverna Mykonos and you instantly know that a lot of effort has been made on your behalf, from the mahogany and marble surfaces to the olive oil that accompanies the bread. Subtle cues (a throw pillow in your booth) coax you to get comfortable.

headline: War and Then Maybe Peace: Eric Braeden and Neil Patrick Harris on Twitter
text: The actors Eric Braeden and Neil Patrick Harris, a star of the CBS sitcom “How I Met Your Mother,” seem to have called a truce in their Twitter war on Friday.

headline: A Rout for CBS
text: CBS dominated the ratings on Thursday night as most of network television ran repeats in advance of the holidays. CBS’s sitcoms at 8 and 8:30 were two of the only non-reruns and delivered the largest prime-time audiences. According to Nielsen’s estimates, 13.5 million viewers tuned in to CBS’s “Big Bang Theory,” and “$#*! My Dad Says” garnered 10.5 million at 8:30. CBS’s reruns of “CSI” (9.2 million) and “The Mentalist” (10.1 million) followed at 9 and 10 and easily led their time slots. In second place Fox broadcast back-to-back reruns of “Bones,” averaging 5.2 million viewers from 8 to 10, while ABC ranked third with its holiday special at 8, “A Charlie Brown Christmas” (6.4 million), followed by repeats of “Grey’s Anatomy” (4 million) and “Private Practice” (3.1 million). NBC finished fourth, with reruns.

headline: The Man Who Hated Christmas
text: BOB liked to say how much he hated Christmas. This amazed me and my sister. We’d look at each other: How could anyone hate Christmas? But he’d say it again and again: “Bess, I hate Christmas.” He had a variation on this: “Bess, I hate Christmas trees.” He’d shake his head thoughtfully and chuckle: “They’re nothing but trouble. You struggle with them and fight over them and then they die and drop needles everywhere and you have to drag them out on the street.”

headline: Egg, Spinach and, Always, BlackBerry
text: Rarely is Sunday a full day of leisure for Christine C. Quinn, 44, the BlackBerry-addicted speaker of the City Council, who lives in Chelsea. She and her partner,  Kim M. Catullo, 44, a corporate lawyer, may go out to breakfast or for a walk with their dog, Sadie, a shar-pei and Labrador retriever mix. But even on the street, the job does not stop.

headline: Twigs and Trains, Illegal Spaces and Chocolate Babka
text: THERE is still time (through Jan. 9) to catch the 19th annual Holiday Train Show at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx. But if you cannot make it, or want to see it later in the year, there’s a new picture book titled, appropriately enough, (New York Botanical Garden, $14.95).

headline: Conversation Across Centuries With the Father of All Bloggers
text: Sure, you could turn to self-help celebrities like Marianne Williamson or Joel Osteen for advice on how to live. But Sarah Bakewell, an author and part-time cataloger of rare books at the National Trust in London, decided to reach much further back than the best-seller list to the 16th-century nobleman, wine grower and essayist Michel Eyquem de Montaigne.

headline: Another Legal Twist In Ansel Adams Case
text: The legal dispute between a California man who says a box of glass-plate negatives he bought at a garage sale are the work of Ansel Adams and the famed photographer’s trust has entered a new phase.

headline: Chronicle of a Changing City

headline: Giants’ O’Hara, Leading in Pro Bowl Voting, Plans to Play Sunday
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Shaun O’Hara of the Giants is leading the National Football Conference in fan votes to play center in the Pro Bowl. But he has played only four games.

headline: Best Buy Feels the Pressure of Rivals on the Web
text: At barely 10 a.m., holiday shopping was in full swing at a Best Buy on the Upper West Side. A harried father searched for a new Xbox for his children. A personal assistant picked up video game accessories for her boss’s twins. One young woman fiddled with a coffeemaker, while another paid for a DVD player.

headline: Beneath the Dead Sea, Scientists Are Drilling for Natural History
text: EIN GEDI, Israel — Five miles out, nearly to the center of the Dead Sea, an international team of scientists has been drilling beneath the seabed to extract a record of climate change and earthquake history stretching back half a million years.

headline: One Suit, Many Kringles? Not in Santaland
text: The sun had barely committed to its Saturday morning rounds when the people in the plush red suits began dotting the streets of New York.

headline: The Tailor Draws a Line
text: Dec. 18, 1860Sometimes a single speech alters the atmosphere, like a bolt of lightning before a rainstorm. One thinks of Barack Obama’s oration at the 2004 Democratic convention, which propelled an obscure Illinois state senator into the political stratosphere. Or Ronald Reagan’s speech at the 1964 G.O.P. convention, which anointed a former actor and T.V. pitchman as the messiah of the conservative movement. Or Lincoln’s Cooper Union address, which conferred national status upon a mostly failed regional politician.

headline: Explaining the Crisis With Dogma
text: What was that about?

headline: A Catholic School Meets a Challenge
text: When Eric Ostrow was hired last year to teach drama at Xavier High School in Manhattan, as a newcomer he chose two impeccably innocuous shows for student productions. The first was a comedy, “Epic Proportions,” and then came the musical “Grease,” with its script scrubbed of profanity and one character’s unwed pregnancy papered over in euphemisms.

headline: After Injury, Receiver Told Rodgers to Stay Out
text: Donald Driver saw it in the eyes of Aaron Rodgers. Rodgers, Green Bay’s quarterback, was not quite right after taking hard hits on back-to-back plays and sustaining his second concussion of the season against the Lions last week, but he still wanted to go back into the game.

headline: Fate of Arms Treaty Tied to Policy on Gays
text: WASHINGTON  Vexed and cornered, Republican opponents of the advancing effort to allow gay men and lesbians to serve openly in the military pulled out a final card Friday, suggesting that the future of an arms treaty with Russia was endangered by Democratic efforts to repeal “don’t ask don’t tell” at the end of the lame-duck session.

headline: U.S. Official Expresses Confidence in Pakistan
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  Hoping to reassure Afghans about cross-border attacks, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff said Friday that it was “very possible” that Pakistan would be able to root out insurgents from havens inside its territory that serve as a launching point for lethal strikes in Afghanistan.

headline: Mexican Leader’s Crime Effort Fails to Advance
text: MEXICO CITY  President Felipe Calderón’s effort to reorganize local police forces and clamp down on money laundering in the fight against organized crime has suffered a setback with the failure of the Mexican Congress to move forward on the initiatives.

headline: Judge Says Case Against Immigration Officials in New Haven Raids Can Proceed
text: A federal judge ruled late Thursday that the former chief of the Immigration and Customs Enforcement agency and other senior officials could be held liable in a lawsuit claiming that federal officers violated the constitutional rights of suspected illegal immigrants arrested in predawn raids three years ago in New Haven.

headline: Santa via Cellphone: Shopping Online Without a Computer
text: This holiday season, consumers are beginning to shop and make purchases on their mobile phones. The shift from buying presents in front of the computer at home or work to doing it during bus commutes or while standing in line at cafes is small, but, for the first time, noticeable and even significant.

headline: Newly Built Ghost Towns Haunt Banks in Spain
text: YEBES, Spain  It is a measure of Spain’s giddy construction excesses that 250 row houses carpet a hill near this tiny rural village about an hour by car outside of Madrid.

headline: The Week in Culture Pictures, Dec. 17
text: A slide show of photographs of cultural events from this week.

headline: Can Airports Be Fun?
text: Few who fly — or fly coach, anyway — would disagree that the entire experience of air travel from check-in to landing carries with it an overwhelming sense that everyone involved has simply given up. Watch people as they enter airports: shoulders rise, expressions grow steely, civility erodes. Things that shouldn’t be a big deal — learning that you’ll have an on-time departure or receiving a free bag of potato chips — feel like winning lottery tickets, so low have our expectations become.

headline: Brooklyn’s Allure? Fancy Cakes, Dahling
text: FLOWERS are blooming in the dead of winter on the fringes of Brooklyn. Inside Lindsey Gamble’s bakery, an out-of-the-way, nearly hidden storefront at President and Columbia Streets near the waterfront, butter cream tiers and gum paste orchids climb high. A pile of blue fondant Tiffany boxes seems to tip precariously beside an edible high-heel shoe and diamond ring. Sweet, golden watch parts are about to be placed on a giant “Alice in Wonderland” cupcake.

headline: Two States Sue Bank of America Over Mortgages
text: The attorneys general of Arizona and Nevada on Friday filed a lawsuit against Bank of America, accusing it of engaging in “widespread fraud” by misleading customers with “false promises” about their eligibility for modifications on their home mortgages.

headline: Laid-Off OTB Employees Face the Future Apprehensively
text: The ceiling of the union hall was festooned for the holidays with red and green streamers, but a gloom hung over the room on Friday morning as a few hundred former employees of the New York City Off-Track Betting Corporation trudged in.

headline: Vilified by Fans, but Exiting Victorious
text: LeBron James finally arrived at Madison Square Garden on Friday, 51 days and 26 games later than expected. For this, he was greeted with boos instead of cheers, an interrogation instead of fawning questions and several insulting newspaper illustrations.

headline: The Week in Culture Pictures, Dec. 17
text: More Photographs

headline: Much to Worry About, but Mostly, a Son She Outlived
text: Arleen Griffith owes $1,500 in back taxes, wages a daily war against addiction and has asthma, emphysema and sarcoidosis, a potentially deadly inflammation of the organs.

headline: How Not to Wreck a Nonstick Pan
text: THIS all began when I was trying to come up with a clever idea for a Hanukkah present for my older son. Having exhausted all the sports-themed possibilities, I decided to buy him a griddle since he has become quite the pancake chef.

headline: Tests Detect Alzheimer’s Risks, but Should Patients Be Told?
text: Marjie Popkin thought she had chemo brain, that fuzzy-headed forgetful state that she figured was a result of her treatment for ovarian cancer. She was not thinking clearly — having trouble with numbers, forgetting things she had just heard.

headline: Death of an Omnibus
text: It was big: 1,900 pages. It was expensive: $1.2 trillion. And it was loaded with Washington’s favorite  white meat: more than 6,000 earmarks. But on Thursday night, it went the way of the rest of the dinosaurs: “The Senate majority leader, Harry Reid of Nevada, said Thursday night that he was abandoning efforts to pass a $1.2 trillion spending measure to finance the government through Sept. 30 because Republicans would not support it,” reported The Times’s David M. Herszenhorn. “Mr. Reid said he would work with the Republican leader, Mitch McConnell of Kentucky, on a stop-gap spending bill instead. Senate Republicans also said they would not support a House-passed temporary spending measure running through the end of the fiscal year on Sept. 30. Instead, they want to develop a separate measure running only through the early part of next year.”

headline: A Monsignor Is Defrocked for Abusing a Student
text: A once-influential Roman Catholic monsignor who oversaw fund-raising for the Archdiocese of New York, running the annual Alfred E. Smith political dinner during the tenure of Cardinal John J. O’Connor, has been removed from the priesthood after an eight-year church review of sexual abuse accusations against him, the archdiocese announced on Friday.

headline: Tug of First Baseball Home Returns Wood to Cubs
text: On Dec. 10, Kerry Wood and his wife, Sarah, attended the funeral for Ron Santo in Chicago. The extended Cubs family said goodbye to a man who devoted his life to the long-suffering team, but the event helped bring Wood back home.

headline: Dreaming of a Feinstein Christmas, Just Like the Ones We Used to Know
text: Each December they gather in a room on Park Avenue at 61st Street, huddled into booths and at low tables with chilling Champagne bottles. Some are stars of bygone eras  recently, Joan Collins, Celeste Holm and Florence Henderson were tucked into banquettes at the back of the room. Some are not, like Cynthia Wilson, an awe-struck, gray-haired woman from England who traveled to America expressly to sit in that room for five nights.

headline: City Critic: Finding the Real Santa
text: The City Critic meets the one and only real Santa Claus. He lives in a department store.

headline: White House Issues Long-Delayed Science Guidelines
text: The Obama administration issued long-awaited, long-delayed guidelines on Friday to insulate government scientific research from political meddling and to base policy decisions on solid data.

headline: Mexican Police Drone Plane Crashes Near El Paso Home
text: HOUSTON  A small unmanned plane belonging to the Mexican federal police crashed in a residential neighborhood in El Paso this week, but no one was injured and the drone was quickly returned to the Mexican government, officials from both governments said Friday.

headline: The Postman Always Pings Twice
text: Washington

headline: Size Protects Government Contractors That Stray
text: WASHINGTON  Weeks into the largest oil spill in American history, government officials met in Washington to discuss ways to compel BP, which leased the drilling rig, to move faster in stopping the spill.

headline: With New Tax Bill, a Turning Point for the President
text: WASHINGTON  With the stroke of a pen, President Obama on Friday enacted the largest tax cut in nearly a decade and, in the process, took a big step toward reinventing himself as a champion of compromise in a politically fractured capital.

headline: French Vogue’s Top Editor to Leave at End of January
text: Carine Roitfeld, the sharp-boned, high-heeled stylist who turned French Vogue into a vehicle for profits and glamour, startled the fashion world on Friday by saying she would step down as editor in chief of the magazine.

headline: Republicans Prepare for Looming Budget Battle
text: WASHINGTON  The collapse of a government-wide spending package in the final days of this Congressional session sets up a politically charged fiscal showdown early next year, testing the determination of Republicans about to take over the House with promises to slash an array of domestic programs.

headline: Leaving for Hawaii, Sans One Obama
text: WASHINGTON  At least some Obamas will be leaving for Hawaii on Saturday.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Surging Rangers Face a Stern Test in the First-Place Flyers
text: Rangers Coach John Tortorella is known for his slow burns, but he is a happy man these days. He felt especially good Thursday afternoon, the day after his team rallied for four unanswered goals in the last 10 minutes in Pittsburgh to beat Sidney Crosby and the Penguins, 4-1.

headline: Christie Picks Klein Ally for New Jersey Schools
text: Gov. Chris Christie has selected as New Jersey’s education commissioner a nationally known school administrator who drove some of New York City’s most controversial education policies, a move that signals the governor’s continued intent to upend the educational establishment and put his stamp on the state’s schools.

headline: Economic Boom in Washington Leaves Gaping Income Disparities
text: WASHINGTON  As incomes fell across America over the past decade, new census data show that one place registered a remarkable rise: the nation’s capital.

headline: Ex-Detainee Wants Judge to Dismiss Conviction on Single Count in Bombings
text: Lawyers for Ahmed Khalfan Ghailani, the former Guantánamo detainee who was acquitted of more than 280 counts of murder and conspiracy last month in a terrorism trial in Manhattan, asked the trial judge on Friday to dismiss the sole count on which he was convicted.

headline: China: 2 Seamen Rescued, but 25 Are Still Missing
text: Two seamen cast overboard when a Vietnamese cargo ship sank in waters between China and Vietnam were rescued Friday, although 25 others remain missing, the Chinese media reported. According to the Xinhua news agency, a Chinese maritime rescue team found the two men in the South China Sea more than 30 miles from where the vessel sank Thursday in what Vietnamese officials described as gale-force winds. The ship, Phu Tan, was traveling between two Vietnamese ports when it capsized in rough seas about 115 miles off the coast of Hainan Island, China.

headline: Haiti: Cholera Vaccine Pilot Program Recommended
text: There is enough approved cholera vaccine stockpiled in the world to vaccinate only 50,000 people, a panel of cholera experts convened by the Pan American Health Organization said Friday. Given the shortage, the panel recommended starting a pilot program in Haiti to test vaccination strategies and waiting for more vaccine to be made. A second manufacturer may be approved by the World Health Organization within six months, making it eventually possible to produce one million doses a year. About 110,000 Haitians are known to have had cholera since the outbreak began in October; 2,405 have died.

headline: The Gingrich Who Stole Christmas
text: The calendar is collapsing. Only a week until Christmas! Only a month until the beginning of the presidential election!

headline: Garden Ticket Sales Strong for UConn’s Bid to Tie Longest Streak
text: Madison Square Garden has hosted its share of big events, from the Ali-Frazier fights to championships for the Knicks and the Rangers. On Sunday, another momentous one could be added to the list when the University of Connecticut’s women’s basketball team tries to tie the N.C.A.A. Division I record for most consecutive wins.

headline: Unease Grows About Future of Financing for Pell Grants
text: With the lame-duck Congress winding down and a $5.7 billion gap in financing looming for next year’s Pell grants  and a further $8 billion gap for the following year  there is growing uncertainty about the future of the grants, the nation’s most significant financial-aid program for college students.

headline: New York Flop Becomes a Hit Everywhere Else
text: It closed a month after it opened Off Broadway. Entertainment Weekly selected it as one of the worst shows of 2006. Most New Yorkers don’t even remember it. Yet John Cariani’s “Almost, Maine,” an earnest 19-character play about the romantic happenings one cold night in northern Maine, has since been produced around the world, including in Australia, Dubai and South Korea. A Spanish-language version will be presented this spring in Mexico City. More than 600 companies, amateur and professional, have put it on in the United States and Canada.

headline: Saturday: Kingly Reagle
text: Please welcome Merl Reagle into the guest-solving chair of distinction. He’s a one-man crossword syndicate, with his clever Sunday puzzles appearing weekly in The San Francisco Chronicle, The Washington Post, The Los Angeles Times and many others. He was a star of the movie Wordplay and appeared (nearly human-colored) in an episode of The Simpsons.

headline: Whose Party Is It?
text: The far left is foaming at the mouth.

headline: Games vs. Governing
text: The Senate still has two major tasks ahead in the remaining days of the lame-duck session: allowing open military service by gay and lesbian soldiers and ratifying the vital New Start nuclear arms treaty with Russia. In both cases, approval will have to come from a solid majority of Democrats and a handful of Republicans who are willing to set aside destructive partisanship.

headline: Walter Haeussermann, Rocket Scientist, Dies at 96
text: Walter Haeussermann, a leading member of the team of German rocket scientists headed by Wernher von Braun who were brought to the United States after World War II to help develop ballistic missiles, died on Dec. 8 in Huntsville, Ala. He was 96.

headline: Turn In Your Bin Ladens
text: THE 500-euro note is sometimes called the “Bin Laden”  after all, Europeans may never see the 500 euro, but they know it is out there somewhere. Unfortunately, Al Qaeda’s leader and the 500-euro bill are connected in another way: high-denomination bills make it a lot easier for terrorists to operate.

headline: The World This Week
text: A look back at the big news stories of the week.

headline: Protecting the Internet
text: The intensely competitive nature of the Internet is vital to the American economy and democracy. So we worry that rules proposed this month by Julius Genachowski, the chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, to guarantee the Internet’s openness may not be able to guarantee the survival of that competition.

headline: Cholera and Haiti
text: With a cholera epidemic raging in Haiti, the United Nations recently issued an urgent appeal for $174 million to provide clean water, sanitation, food and medical treatment. As of this week, it had raised 25 percent of it.

headline: After Bumpy Year, Woods Takes Back Seat to Youth
text: Has the PGA Tour really decided to de-emphasize Tiger Woods in its promotional materials and switch the focus to the emerging group of strong young players going into 2011? If the first FedEx Cup promotional piece of the new year and remarks by the PGA Tour commissioner are any indicators, the answer is yes.

headline: ‘Things Are Coming Together’
text: Brenda Vigna is generous, even when there is not much to give. A single mother of four living in a trailer park, she adopted her daughter’s pregnant classmate out of foster care in 2008.

headline: Getting to the Heart of Health Costs
text: To the Editor:
