text: To the Editor:

headline: Education for Prisoners
text: To the Editor:

headline: Jewish Feminist Funerals
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Path Out of the Shelters
text: To the Editor:

headline: Advice on Afghanistan, From Gorbachev in 1986
text: To the Editor:

headline: Sharing Stories of a Man Who Loved Big Challenges
text: There were tears and laughter and embraces as the crowd began to build Friday night in the Manhattan apartment of Richard C. Holbrooke at a private memorial gathering for the diplomat they remembered as a boss, a source and a friend.

headline: Photo Replay: Heat 113, Knicks 91
text: LeBron James makes his first trip to Madison Square Garden since passing on the Knicks to play in Miami.

headline: Bloggingheads:  Giving Diplomats Respect
text: Matthew Yglesias, right, of the Center for American Progress and Daniel Drezner of ForeignPolicy.com discuss the militarization of foreign policy.

headline: Photo Replay: Dec. 17
text: A look at the day in sports from a high school championship football game in Pennsylvania to a World Cup skiing event in Val Gardena, Italy.

headline: Corrections
text: NEW YORK

headline: Venice in Winter: Photos
text: To the Editor: Anyone looking to see more of “Venice in Winter” (Nov. 28) may have far to look. Bookshelves are crowded with volumes featuring Venice in garish summer finery, or of people wearing masks during Carnival, or of the colorful stucco buildings on Burano. Note: the operative word is “color.” For those seeking the beautifully atmospheric Venice of mists and shadows, precious few books pertain. These, however, succeed marvelously.

headline: Fowler vs. McIlroy, Via Twitter
text: A trans-Atlantic Twitter tempest helped enliven the off-season when Lee Westwood, the world’s new No. 1 player, tweeted about PGA Tour players voting one of their own — Rickie Fowler — as the tour rookie of the year over Rory McIlroy, the 21-year-old from Northern Ireland.

headline: Los Angeles: Deluge of Calls in ‘Grim Sleeper’ Case
text: The Los Angeles Police Department was inundated with phone calls Friday within 24 hours of the release of photographs of women that had been found in the home of the suspected “Grim Sleeper” serial killer. Hundreds of people claimed to recognize women from the photographs as relatives or friends who were missing or dead, while others claimed to be in the photographs themselves, according to a police official. Lonnie David Franklin Jr. is accused of killing 10 black women between 1985 and 2007. The police released the photographs because they suspected some of the women pictured were his victims as well. Though five people have been tentatively identified, detectives plan to conduct interviews with callers before positively identifying any, according to Mary Grady, a police spokeswoman.

headline: The Weekend Word: A Senate Saturday
text: From Today’s Times:

headline: Rex Ryan Denies Billick’s Accusation
text: On Friday, Rex Ryan denied that he had any knowledge of his team’s sideline shenanigans and said that Brian Billick should have talked with him first before making such an accusation.A few highlights of Rex Speak:

headline: Pakistan Says It Didn’t Tell Spy’s Identity
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  An official of the Directorate for Inter-Services Intelligence, Pakistan’s top spy organization, angrily denied Saturday that it was responsible for revealing the name of the Central Intelligence Agency’s top clandestine officer in Pakistan.

headline: The Case for Benching McNabb and Starting Grossman
text: It’s hard to advocate that Rex Grossman should be the Redskins’ starter. (You won’t get me to do it.)

headline: Urban Forager | Earthy, Crunchy Burdock
text: Foraging in winter has its obvious challenges — freezing temperatures, dying flora, and scarce edible greens save for hardy garlic mustard and field garlic. But even in the hard frost-bitten ground, it’s still possible to find wild burdock poking its gigantic leaves out from the remnants of fall foliage, reminding us of root-vegetable deliciousness underfoot.

headline: The Different Costs of Motherhood
text: Outright sexism is obviously still a part of the workplace today, but it’s also vastly reduced. The pay gap between men and women of identical qualifications, experience, work hours and career choice has shrunk greatly in the last few decades. Some researchers believe it is now close to zero — not zero, though not far from it.

headline: A Fake vs. a Real Tree
text: In these eco-conscious times, many people want to shrink their environmental footprint while still enjoying the trappings of the holiday season. In some cases, the earth-friendly alternative – pass the tofurky – is a pretty obvious choice.

headline: Richard Holbrooke, Thirsting for a Role in History
text: LONDON — It was the worst of times in the siege of Sarajevo. No venture outside the Holiday Inn, which had become a media fastness in a city under siege, was safe from the daily staccato of sniper fire, mortars and artillery shells. And there at my door, in the first winter of the war, was Richard C. Holbrooke, asking if he could borrow space on my floor for him and his sleeping bag.

headline: Cards? Flowers? In Senate, a Real Pal Objects
text: Senator Ron Wyden, Democrat of Oregon, announced this week that he has early-stage prostate cancer and will be undergoing surgery on Monday. And it is hardly a surprise that Mr. Wyden, who is known for working across the aisle on complicated issues, has received an outpouring of support from his colleagues.

headline: The Supreme Court and Obama’s Health Care Law
text: When it comes to the future of the Obama administration’s health care plan, the judicial math can seem simple.

headline: Back Then: 2007
text: Larry King ended his run as the 9 p.m. fixture on CNN last week. Between his radio career and his stint on television, he did about 50,000 interviews. When Jacques Steinberg of The Times visited him in Beverly Hills in 2007, he had recently undergone a procedure for a clogged artery.

headline: Suggesting Activities for Shaq in Boston
text: Celtics center Shaquille O’Neal has always been a man of many interests. He has rapped, acted, trained with SWAT teams and engaged in amateur philosophy during his many career stops.

headline: The Teary, Busy, Ugly Lame-Duck Congress
text: WASHINGTON — There were moments last week when official Washington seemed to careen out of control. Emotions were raw. Plans were in flux. People were on edge.

headline: Prime Number
text: 100,000: The approximate number of Cuban cigars seized over a recent two-week period by customs officials at Chicago O’Hare International Airport, The Associated Press reported last week. Customs officials usually confiscate about 2,000 Cuban cigars over two weeks. But tighter security and new restrictions on air cargo parcels have sent seizures soaring. And what of the cigars? The United States Customs and Border Protection plans to destroy them.

headline: Ivory Coast President Orders U.N. to Leave
text: ABIDJAN, Ivory Coast  The president of Ivory Coast ordered United Nations and French peacekeepers to leave the country immediately on Saturday, hours after men in military uniforms fired on a United Nations patrol.

headline: Springtime for Hypocrites
text: It has been a great week on the hypocrisy front. A couple of high points:

headline: Senate Blocks Bill for Young Illegal Immigrants
text: The Senate on Saturday blocked a bill that would have created a path to citizenship for certain young illegal immigrants who came to the United States as children, completed two years of college or military service and met other requirements, including passing a criminal background check.

headline: Senate Repeals Ban Against Openly Gay Military Personnel
text: WASHINGTON  The Senate on Saturday struck down the ban on gay men and lesbians serving openly in the military, bringing to a close a 17-year struggle over a policy that forced thousands of Americans from the ranks and caused others to keep secret their sexual orientation.

headline: Acrostic: Like Mouflons
text: For those who weren’t able to get the free version of last weekend’s Puns and Anagrams puzzle, download it by clicking here.

headline: When Children Are Caught in the Cycle of Poverty
text: The economic collapse has taken a toll on vast segments of society, but it has affected some groups disproportionately. Among those are children.

headline: Bomb Kills 2 Afghans in Attack in Kandahar
text: KANDAHAR, Afghanistan  A suicide car bomb exploded Saturday on the outskirts of Kandahar City, killing two civilians and wounding 11 more, including seven children, Afghan officials said. But the bomber’s target, a district governor, escaped unharmed.

headline: Parliament Vote Puts Iraq Closer to a New Government
text: BAGHDAD  Iraq moved one step closer to finally forming a government on Saturday as lawmakers overturned a contentious decision barring three prominent Sunni Arabs from national politics.

headline: Judges Reinstate Travel Ban for Kosovo Ex-Leader
text: PARIS  A former prime minister of Kosovo awaiting trial in The Hague has been told he cannot be given temporary release from prison and return home because his presence there could increase threats to witnesses who have agreed to testify against him.

headline: For a Father and Three Sons, Sharing the Role of Caretaker
text: Alan Garcia, 15, sat on a bench while his classmates played basketball. The other students might have thought he was too lazy or too shy to play. The truth was simpler: His family was too poor. Alan’s father could not afford to buy him a pair of sneakers for gym class.

headline: At Camp, a Haven From Troubles
text: “Things you do at camp are between you and the people who went to camp.”

headline: After the Death of Her Mother, Grief and Fear
text: “Her hands are stuck in a fist. She can’t balance when she walks. When she’s mad she starts throwing things, banging on tables and doors and walls. She can’t really speak.”

headline: Flyers Show Discipline
text: The Philadelphia Flyers grabbed first place over all in the N.H.L. last week, unseating rival Pittsburgh and ending the Penguins’ 12-game winning streak. While the Penguins’ run attracted attention, the Flyers went 8-1-3 at the same time and have continued winning. They went into Saturday’s game against the Rangers having lost only 3 of their previous 25 games in regulation.

headline: Take Coyotes Off List of Teams Likely to Move
text: The Phoenix Coyotes seem set to stay in Glendale, Ariz., after last Tuesday’s approval by the Glendale City Council to pay $197 million to keep the financially troubled team at Jobing.com Arena.

headline: Opening the Bag of Mortgage Tricks
text: ALL the revelations this year about dubious practices in the mortgage servicing arena  think robo-signers and forged signatures  have rightly raised borrowers’ fears that companies handling their loans may not be operating on the up and up.

headline: It’s Time to Rethink the Charity Deduction
text: NOW that Congress has actually managed to enact tax legislation, it may be time to consider some bigger issues. I hope that broad-based tax reform will be high on the list of both major parties.

headline: Marriott and Leela Open Hotels in India
text: India’s growing popularity among jet-setters continues to translate into new hotels. Marriott Hotel and Resorts, for example, decided to open its 500th property  in the historic city of Pune last month. Nightly rates at the hotel, which includes 416 rooms and a convention center, start at 8,000 rupees (about $180).

headline: Q. and A. With Jim Kelly
text: Jim Kelly, a former Buffalo quarterback, and his former Bills teammates Thurman Thomas and Andre Reed have traveled to an undisclosed military base in the Persian Gulf region to play flag football with service members. They are participating in the Connect to Home Bowl, sponsored by Tostitos in conjunction with the U.S.O. Kelly, 50, a member of the Pro Football Hall of Fame, led the Bills to four consecutive Super Bowl appearances from 1991 to ’94.

headline: The Words of the Year
text: There are buzzwords and there are great words. (Retweet.)

headline: Neediest | A Special Night
text: Destine, Raymond and Miguel, veterans of Trail Blazers summer camp, represent their camp at a fund-raising gala.

headline: James Brought His Reality Show to the Garden
text: New York has an insatiable appetite for sports superstars, though they have snubbed the city recently.

headline: Astronomer Sues the University of Kentucky, Claiming His Faith Cost Him a Job
text: In 2007, C. Martin Gaskell, an astronomer at the University of Nebraska, was a leading candidate for a job running an observatory at the University of Kentucky. But then somebody did what one does nowadays: an Internet search.

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: To the Sports Editor:

headline: Oprah’s Network Is Her Highest Hurdle
text: BEFORE Oprah Winfrey jetted off this month to Washington for the Kennedy Center Honors, then to Sydney for overseas tapings of her talk show, she had a simple request for the security staff at her house near Los Angeles:

headline: What’s a Quiet Guy Doing on Real Estate’s A-List?
text: WHEN General Growth Properties buckled under a mountain of debt and filed for bankruptcy last year, deal watchers assumed that Simon Properties, the nation’s largest mall owner, would swoop in and buy it. So many people were stunned when Brookfield Asset Management, a lesser-known company that is based in Toronto, beat out Simon last May and snagged a major ownership stake.

headline: Before UConn, There Was Wayland
text: The 1950s were a predictably conservative era at tiny Wayland Baptist University, on the high plains of West Texas, where women could not wear shorts even to walk to the gym from their dormitories.

headline: Fashion Capital’s Slimmer, Sleek Look
text: The Garment district is home to more than 2,000 fashion-related businesses, including up-and-coming designers with a dream of becoming the next Marc Jacobs or Vera Wang.

headline: In Lost Season, Cowboys Begin to Find Way Back
text: IRVING, Tex.  The yellow sticky note hanging from DeMarcus Ware’s locker last week carried the sort of well-meaning platitude usually reserved for self-help aisles. And fragile locker rooms.

headline: Transplants Cut, Arizona Is Challenged by Survivors
text: PHOENIX — First, it was distraught patients awaiting organ transplants who protested Arizona’s decision to no longer cover such operations under its Medicaid program.

headline: If Opportunity Knocks, Open the Door
text: This interview with Cathleen P. Black, former chairwoman of Hearst Magazines, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant. It was conducted before Ms. Black’s selection as chancellor of New York City’s public schools.

headline: So Much for Reinventing Ourselves Online
text: “GREETINGS, Your Highness,” the message began. “I had the pleasure of dining in your kingdom last night.”

headline: What’s Just Around the Bend? Soon, a Camera May Show You
text: ANYONE who has witnessed the megapixel one-upmanship in camera ads might think that computer chips run the show in digital photography.

headline: Reasons to Smile (for Now)
text: EVEN some market bears are no longer sounding entirely gloomy.

headline: When Companies Were Conquerors
text: THE Canadian writer Stephen R. Bown has a nice idea for a book with “Merchant Kings: When Companies Ruled the World: 1600 to 1900” (St. Martin’s Press/Thomas Dunne Books).

headline: Letters: The Health Care Balance
text: Readers respond to “Following the Money, Doctors Ration Care” (Economic View, Dec. 12).

headline: Nets Bringing a Touch of TMZ to the N.B.A.
text: NEWARK  Kris Humphries stared at his shoelaces as the color rose in his cheeks. Humphries, a 6-foot-9 Nets forward, had missed 9 of 10 shots in the previous game, a loss to Philadelphia, but that was not the subject that made him blush and stammer before a rebound victory Thursday night against the Washington Wizards.

headline: Learning to Tame Your Office Anxiety
text: Q. You’re feeling anxious at work, and you think it’s affecting your performance. What causes anxiety, anyhow?

headline: Giants Deploy 3-Safety Whirl and Bewilder Rival Offenses
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  In the spring, Perry Fewell, the Giants’ first-year defensive coordinator, noticed the potential to remake a defense that had collapsed the previous season. It was a matter of fitting the pieces.

headline: Bank of America Suspends Payments to WikiLeaks
text: In a sign of the increasing tensions between WikiLeaks and the corporate world, Bank of America has said it will no longer help process payments for the organization, which released a huge cache of secret State Department cables in late November and has threatened to “take down” a major United States bank with another data dump.

headline: Karen Sortito, Who Told 007 to Start Drinking Smirnoff, Dies at 49
text: Karen Sortito, a movie-marketing executive who pushed the limits of product tie-ins when she put the world’s most famous Aston Martin driver, James Bond, behind the wheel of a BMW and put him in business with Visa cards, Smirnoff vodka, Heineken beer and even L’Oréal lipstick (“Bond Bordeaux”), died in Manhattan on Monday. She was 49.

headline: A Passion for Technology
text: I GREW up in India, in the foothills of the Himalayas in a town called Mussoorie, just north of Delhi. It is about 7,500 feet up; our house was on the edge of the forest. It was beautiful. The next set of hills is the main Himalayan mountain range, so we were surrounded by majestic white peaks.

headline: Being Father Helps Lead Jets’ Holmes Out of His Shell
text: FAIRBURN, Ga.  In the third quarter of Super Bowl XLIII, Santonio Holmes III fell asleep in the stands. He awoke just before his father caught the winning touchdown pass for the Pittsburgh Steelers, sprinted down the stairs and jumped into his arms, creating an instant, indelible image, which remains his father’s favorite.

headline: Familiar Face Halts Rangers’ Momentum
text: PHILADELPHIA  The Rangers’ dream week ended with a sobering dose of reality Saturday afternoon. They hung tough against the N.H.L.’s first-place team, but in the end, there were too many turnovers and too much Nikolay Zherdev.

headline: The N.H.L. Players Union Votes to Appoint Fehr as Its Leader
text: The members of the N.H.L. Players’ Association voted overwhelmingly to appoint Donald Fehr as the executive director, the union announced in a statement Saturday.

headline: Paul Revere’s Ride Against Slavery
text: Cambridge, Mass.

headline: Gone With the Myths
text: New Haven

headline: Immigration Vote Leaves Obama’s Policy in Disarray
text: The vote by the Senate on Saturday to block a bill to grant legal status to hundreds of thousands of illegal immigrant students was a painful setback to an emerging movement of immigrants and also appeared to leave the immigration policy of the Obama administration, which has supported the bill and the movement, in disarray.

headline: A Baseball Fan Among Baseball Fans
text: The back seat of Bob Feller’s car had suddenly become uncomfortable, because for six days I was still trying to ask the question I had to ask. I had followed Feller and his wife, Anne, across a continent in an adventure that extended from a Tuesday night at the Bomber Bowl in Richland, Wash., to a Sunday morning at a small shop in Cooperstown, N.Y., down the street from the Baseball Hall of Fame.

headline: When Mom’s an Astronaut, Waiting Is One Challenge
text: MOSCOW  Jamey Simpson has some advice for any 10-year-olds whose mothers are blasting off from Baikonur Cosmodrome, the massive Soviet-era space complex in Kazakhstan.

headline: Senate Rejects Amendment Blocking New Start Treaty
text: WASHINGTON — The Senate on Saturday beat back the most serious Republican effort to block approval of a new arms control treaty with Russia this year, after President Obama reassured lawmakers that it would not constrain American plans to build a missile defense system in Europe.

headline: On the East Coast, a Three-City Rivalry Transformed
text: When Cliff Lee signed with the Phillies, the transformation was complete. Philadelphia officially became New York.

headline: A U.S. Crew’s Urgent Flight Into the Afghan Desert
text: FORWARD OPERATING BASE WILSON, Afghanistan  Beneath the blanket, the veiled Afghan woman slid her feet along the stretcher toward her hips, causing her knees to rise. She was in labor, with contractions two minutes apart, seeking a comfortable position in a military helicopter as it rushed over the desert below. Her baby was in a breech position, lodged in the birth canal.

headline: South Korea Plans to Proceed With Military Drill
text: PYONGYANG, North Korea  Despite growing international pressure to cancel a live-fire artillery drill off the coast of North Korea, the South Korean military on Sunday showed no signs of backing away from its planned exercise, which the North said could lead to “catastrophe” on the Korean Peninsula.

headline: Energized by New City and Its Barbecue, Jones Thrives With the Chiefs
text: On Thanksgiving night, Thomas Jones stood atop a stage in front of thousands in downtown Kansas City, Mo. At that moment, he felt, for the first time in forever, that he had found a home.

headline: Heat Offers Blueprint for Disrupting the Knicks’ Offense
text: A demoralizing loss to the Heat told a painful truth about the Knicks’ place in the Eastern Conference hierarchy, but of greater significance was a revelation of the team’s offensive limitations. Even the league’s best offenses can be countered, and Miami, a team evidently schooled in the machinations of Mike D’Antoni’s offense, unveiled something of a blueprint for stopping the Knicks.

headline: China Pressed to Account for Uighurs’ Fate
text: BEIJING  A human rights organization has called on the Chinese government to publicly account for the fate of 20 ethnic Uighurs who were deported to China from Cambodia one year ago as they awaited a determination on their asylum applications with the United Nations.

headline: A Giving Guide
text: Nicholas D. Kristof recommends giving gifts that can touch human lives.

headline: In Belarus Campaign, a Veneer of Pluralism Emerges With the West in Mind
text: MINSK, Belarus — With campaign fliers promising “action instead of promises,” Yegor Vasilievsky stood outside a busy shopping center here on Friday, drumming up support for a challenger to Belarus’s president, Aleksandr G. Lukashenko. He had been at it for four hours and had managed, remarkably, to stay out of jail.

headline: The Gifts of Hope
text: So what would your aunt prefer as a holiday gift — another Mariah Carey CD, or the knowledge that she’s sending a little girl in Haiti to school for a year?

headline: New York Botanical Garden, 4:00 P.M.
text: The Holiday Train Show at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx features scale models of the city’s landmarks as a backdrop.

text: To the Editor:

headline: Curtailing Air Pollution
text: To the Editor:

headline: Oil and Gas Drilling
text: To the Editor:

headline: Keeping Up With the Commentariat
text: Last week in this space, I wrote about the lively domain of readers who comment online about Times articles, editorials, Op-Ed columns and blogs. I observed that the comments system, which is moderated by Times staffers, yields a rich body of commentary but struggles to handle the volume and has spawned quite a few reader complaints. Not surprisingly, my column on comments generated quite a few comments.

headline: ‘Some Sign of Brooklyn, Some Sign of Queens’
text: To the Editor:

headline: Sunday: Hope for Clear Skies
text: In case you weren’t aware of an “Event on Dec. 21, 2010, viewable in North and South America,” this puzzle serves as a nice heads-up. The event’s climax will occur at 3:17 a.m. Eastern time on Tuesday. A complete explanation and visual display of the theme appears below.

headline: Providing Medical Services for Peanuts
text: Since cash remains scarce in rural Zimbabwe, the barter system has helped keep both Chidamoyo Christian Hospital and its patients alive.

headline: Zimbabwe Health Care, Paid With Peanuts
text: CHIDAMOYO, Zimbabwe  People lined up on the veranda of the American mission hospital here from miles around to barter for doctor visits and medicines, clutching scrawny chickens, squirming goats and buckets of maize. But mostly, they arrived with sacks of peanuts on their heads.

headline: Disunion Extra
text: Disunion readers might want to see two related pieces on Sunday’s op-ed page: Jill Lepore writes that Henry Wadsworth Longfellow’s most famous poem, published on Dec. 20, 1860, wasn’t really about Paul Revere and his famous ride, but a wake-up call about the looming Civil War. And Edward Ball writes that even though neo-confederates like to say the Civil War was about states’ rights, a quick glance at South Carolina’s ordinances of secession shows that the only right the South cared about concerned the ownership of other human beings.

headline: Comments on the ‘Humanitarian Gift Guide’
text: My Sunday column is a variant of the gift guides that are proliferating everywhere in the news media — gift guides for electronics, perfumes, clothing, etc. I always find that the question I get asked the most is: What can I do? What’s a good group to support? So this column is an attempt to answer those questions, listing a number of little-known charities at home and abroad that I think do good work. Of course it’s far from an exhaustive list, omitting in particular the bigger and better-known groups. I also had a similar list a year ago, with different groups. And I’d also welcome your suggestions for other groups (or other humanitarian gifts) that should be on this list.

headline: How the Study Was Conducted
text: The study by scholars at Northwestern University and the University of Chicago  Lee Epstein, William M. Landes and Judge Richard A. Posner  relies on a database of Supreme Court decisions and votes that was created by Harold J. Spaeth with the support of the National Science Foundation about 20 years ago.

headline: Justices Offer Receptive Ear to Business Interests
text: WASHINGTON  Almost 40 years ago, a Virginia lawyer named Lewis F. Powell Jr. warned that the nation’s free enterprise system was under attack. He urged the U.S. Chamber of Commerce to assemble “a highly competent staff of lawyers” and retain outside counsel “of national standing and reputation” to appear before the Supreme Court and advance the interests of American business.

headline: Justice Scalia and the Tea Party
text: When the Tea Party holds its first Conservative Constitutional Seminar next month, Justice Antonin Scalia is set to be the speaker. It was a bad idea for him to accept this invitation. He should send his regrets.

headline: The U.S.S. Prius
text: As I was saying, the thing I love most about America is that there’s always somebody here who doesn’t get the word  and they go out and do the right thing or invent the new thing, no matter what’s going on politically or economically. And what could save America’s energy future  at a time when a fraudulent, anti-science campaign funded largely by Big Oil and Big Coal has blocked Congress from passing any clean energy/climate bill  is the fact that the Navy and Marine Corps just didn’t get the word.

headline: The Tax-Cut Deal
text: As it became clear last week that Congress would pass the tax-cut deal he made with Republicans, President Obama said it “proves that both parties can in fact work together to grow our economy and look out for the American people.” It proves no such thing.

headline: The Bipartisanship Racket
text: JEEZ, can’t we all just get along? Can’t we be civilized? Can’t we reach across the aisle, find common ground and get things done? Can’t we have a new Morning in America as clubby and chipper as MSNBC’s daily gabfest, “Morning Joe”?

headline: A Gay Commander in Chief: Ready or Not?
text: WASHINGTON

headline: Comeback Against Malaria
text: More than a decade ago, international health and development agencies, including the World Health Organization and the World Bank, started a campaign to cut the number of malaria cases and deaths in half by 2010. By 2005 the effort was in such disarray that the toll from malaria had actually gotten worse, not better.

headline: 400 Hours and Counting
text: Mercifully, there are only 400 hours of tape recordings left to be released in the appalling Oval Office maunderings of Richard Nixon, the president who secretly recorded himself in hopes of securing a grand place in history. The tapes undid him in the Watergate scandal, and their steady release across the years has confirmed Nixon, among other things, as a foul-spirited bigot.

headline: Derivatives Clearinghouses
text: To the Editor:

headline: Senate Repeals ‘Don’t Ask, Don’t Tell’
text: In The New York Times, our colleague Carl Hulse reports on the Senate vote that struck down the ban on gay men and lesbians serving openly in the military. He writes:

headline: Fans Take Break From Shopping to Greet Davis and Weigh In on Frugal Mets
text: As holiday shoppers strolled around Union Square on Saturday with bags in hand, a member of the Mets smiled for cameras at a meet-and-greet appearance, an ambassador for a franchise that has not been a buyer in the off-season. The irony was rich.

headline: Wrestler Sees Legal Move; Prosecutor Sees Assault
text: CLOVIS, Calif.  At 17 years old, Preston Hill is known around the Fresno area as an accomplished wrestler, a leader of his high school team, the Buchanan Bears, and a potential candidate for a college scholarship in the sport he loves.

headline: Brooklyn Shooting Leaves One Dead and One Injured
text: A 44-year-old man was killed and his female passenger was wounded early Saturday when a man fired several bullets into their car outside an apartment building in Brooklyn, the police said.

headline: Frank Emi, Defiant World War II Internee, Dies at 94
text: For nearly four years, through scorching summer heat, dust storms and frigid winters, 11,000 residents of the United States were forced to live in barracks, surrounded by barbed-wire fences, guard towers and searchlights at the Heart Mountain Relocation Center in the northwest Wyoming desert.

headline: Israeli Airstrike Kills Militants in Gaza
text: GAZA  At least four Palestinian militants were killed in an Israeli airstrike in central Gaza late Saturday as they were preparing to fire a crude, locally-produced rocket into Israel, Palestinian security officials said.

headline: George Pickow, Artist Who Chronicled Musical Life, Is Dead at 88
text: George Pickow, a photographer best known for the thousands of album covers in which he captured the titans of folk, jazz and pop music  including Theodore Bikel, Louis Armstrong and Lena Horne  in their midcentury prime, died on Dec. 10 in Roslyn, N.Y. He was 88 and lived in Port Washington, on Long Island.

headline: 9/11 Health Bill Wins Support From G.O.P.
text: WASHINGTON  Senator Kirsten E. Gillibrand said Saturday that she and other sponsors of a stalled 9/11 health bill had won new Republican support for the measure and intended to try again to pass it before the end of the 111th Congress.

headline: Brooklyn Man Held in Death of His Mother
text: A Brooklyn man smothered his 86-year-old mother with a pillow on Friday morning, then, believing she was dead, called the police, the authorities said. Yet the woman, Frida Tsirinsky, survived for another 24 hours before dying in a hospital on Saturday.

headline: Custer’s Last Stand Was Only the Beginning
text: GOLDEN, Colo.  It is one of the great mythic and mysterious military battles of American history.

headline: Confidential Swedish Police Report Details Allegations Against WikiLeaks Founder
text: LONDON — Julian Assange, the founder of WikiLeaks who was released from a British jail late last week, is facing a new challenge: the leak of a 68-page confidential Swedish police report that sheds new light on the allegations of sexual misconduct that led to Mr. Assange’s legal troubles.

headline: With Two Trades, the Magic Bets on the Present
text: Two seasons ago, the Orlando Magic surprised and flourished throughout the playoffs. A loss to the Lakers in the N.B.A. finals proved how close the team was to a championship, but dissatisfied with the runner-up result, Otis Smith, Orlando’s general manager, initiated a major shake-up.

headline: California Boy, 9, Becomes Youngest U.S. Chess Master
text: A boy from Santa Clara, Calif., has become the youngest master in United States history, and there seems to be fewer concerns about his achievement than the previous record holder.

headline: New Online-Date Detectives Can Unmask Mr. or Ms. Wrong
text: Never mind whether your date is smart or good-looking. How do you know you aren’t flirting with a felon?

headline: Corrections
text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: Art of Deal Eludes Ellison in Cup Talks
text: Jonathan Weber writes a regular column for The Bay Citizen

headline: While Families Lose Homes to Foreclosure, State Agency Delays Federal Aid
text: Benjamin Chavarria, an unemployed construction worker, has fallen $20,000 behind on his mortgage. If he does not pay the full amount by Jan. 6, his lender, the California Housing Finance Agency, said it will seize his four-bedroom home in Richmond, which is fast becoming the epicenter of the region’s foreclosure crisis.

headline: As Winter Dawns, the Sound of Drums Fills the Air
text: It may buzz at night or during Cubs games, but no one would describe predawn Wrigleyville as a beehive of activity  especially on the darkest day of the year, at the onset of winter.

headline: Emanuel Hearing Yields Pictures of a Basement, With Doses of Tedium and Theatrics
text: The Rahm Emanuel mayoral eligibility dispute may now drag itself from a North Side crawl space to the Circuit Court of Cook County.

headline: Globalism and Chicago: A Link We Can’t Ignore
text: James Warren writes a column for the Chicago News Cooperative

headline: Old-School Politician Thrives in a Changed Ward
text: Edward M. Burke, alderman of the 14th Ward since 1969, is widely regarded as the most powerful member of the Chicago City Council. But as he prepares to run unopposed for an 11th full term, the communities that make up his Southwest Side ward are going through vast and sometimes painful changes.

headline: State’s Tort Reform Makes Lawyers Wary of Taking on Patients
text: The leg pain Connie Spears felt was excruciating and familiar. She’d had blood clots before, and doctors had installed a filter in one of her heart’s main veins. At a Christus Santa Rosa hospital in San Antonio, where Mrs. Spears sought help the Friday before Memorial Day, the emergency room doctor ran some tests and discharged her with “bilateral leg pain.” He told her to follow up with her primary-care physician.

headline: Richards and Her Hair Have Their Cultural Moment
text: Among the many photos of Ann Richards on the wall of Holland Taylor’s dressing room was one in which the former Texas governor’s dark wardrobe blended into the photo’s dark backdrop, leaving the focus solely on Ms. Richards’s face and her chalk-white swirl of hair.

headline: Party Switching Lifts G.O.P., but It’s No Guarantee of Election Victory
text: Ross Ramsey, the managing editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column.

headline: Lawmaker Suggests Vote to Regulate Illicit Casinos
text: In Laredo, electronic gambling machines and the parlors that house them are akin to the reptile’s tail that grows back after being cut off.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Old Mint
text: Built in 1874, the indestructible Granite Lady at Mission and Fifth fought off staggering earthquakes and scorching infernos in its time. While money production and storage ceased in 1937, plans are afoot to make the structure a museum dedicated to the history of San Francisco.

headline: Delaware Girl Sets 2-Mile Record
text: Haley Pierce, a 16-year-old junior from the Tatnall School of Delaware, won the girls’ two-mile run in a meet-record 10 minutes 28.63 seconds at the 57th annual Bishop Loughlin Games at the New Balance Track and Field Center in Upper Manhattan. Lynn Strauss of State College, Pa., held the previous mark of 10:36.50, set in 1981. “I had the meet record in mind on my trip from Delaware,” Pierce said.

headline: Politics in Iraq Casts Doubt on a U.S. Presence After 2011
text: This article was reported by Steven Lee Myers, Thom Shanker and Jack Healy and written by Mr. Myers.

headline: A New Front Line
text: Given Iraq’s military shortcomings, American and Iraqi officials had long expected some American military presence in Iraq, even if only in an advisory role.

headline: Vows:  Steve & Sara
text: Sara Tenenbein and Steve Hofstetter's whirlwind romance started on JDate.  The spark was immediate, and a mere 51 days later, Steve proposed to Sara on his birthday.

headline: Road No Relief for Knicks, and Losing Streak Grows
text: CLEVELAND From the recent and still vivid memories of Paul Pierce’s closing jumper and LeBron James’s complete game against them, the Knicks can now add another unwanted highlight.

headline: Popularity of ‘Don’t Ask’ Repeal May Have Drawn Republican Votes
text: Here’s an important, but not surprising, statistic from Saturday’s vote to repeal the military’s “don’t ask, don’t tell” policy.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, Dec. 19
text: Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. tops the Sunday talk show lineup this weekend as Congress wraps up the lame-duck session.

headline: Phil Cavarretta, National League M.V.P. in 1945, Dies at 94
text: Phil Cavarretta, who played 20 seasons for the Chicago Cubs and won the National League’s most valuable player award and batting championship in 1945, the last time the Cubs captured a pennant, died Saturday in Lilburn, Ga. He was 94.

headline: Walt Dropo, Star at UConn and 1950 Rookie of the Year, Dies at 87
text: Walt Dropo, one of the University of Connecticut’s greatest athletes, who broke into the major leagues with the Boston Red Sox, won the American League’s Rookie of the Year award in 1950 and became a reliable hitter and first baseman for 13 years, died Friday. He was 87 and lived in Peabody, Mass.

headline: Militants Kill Afghan Soldiers in 2 Attacks
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  Insurgents intensified pressure on Afghan security forces on Sunday, killing five Afghan Army training officers in a suicide attack in Kabul and attacking an army recruiting center in the northern city of Kunduz. At least four Afghan soldiers and four police officers were killed in the Kunduz assault in a firefight that lasted more than 12 hours, government officials said.

headline: Istanbul Mosque Gets ‘Majestic’ Makeover
text: Standing in the main sanctuary of Suleymaniye Mosque, Amin, a cleaner of the mosque’s carpets, raised his hands in joy. “It’s Suleymaniye, it’s muhtesem,” he said, using a Persian word meaning “majestic.” The reason for celebration: the completion of a three-year restoration of the 453-year-old imperial mosque.

headline: Tony Romo Is Engaged; Wish Him Well
text: Fairly or unfairly (probably unfairly), the Fifth Down has poked more fun at Tony Romo than at any other player.

headline: Chinese Premier Praises Pakistan’s Fight Against Terrorism
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Prime Minister Wen Jiabao of China praised Pakistan’s efforts to combat terrorism and promised to further advance the two countries’ strategic partnership and economic cooperation in a speech to the Parliament on Sunday.

headline: The Winning Idea to Raise the Savings Rate
text: In May, TIAA-CREF, the asset manager, started a competition for ideas to raise the savings rate to 10 percent in the next two years, with a grand prize worth $50,000.

headline: Namath, Belichick and Gamesmanship vs. Cheating
text: Joe Namath addressed the Jets’ sideline wall controversy with a video at his Web site. He discussed the boundary between gamesmanship and cheating, and related a few stories: about playing at Oakland and mysteriously finding a muddy field; about losing a playbook at Buffalo; and about a ball that wasn’t properly pumped at Oakland (because George Blanda might have liked it that way).

headline: Andrés Iniesta: Barcelona’s Once-in-a-Lifetime Guy
text: LONDON — If ever we doubt that sporting values still hold in the mercenary modern era, then the last weekend before Christmas was gold dust.

headline: Reading the Giants and Eagles
text: A reading list in the hours before Giants-Eagles on Sunday at 1 p.m.:

headline: In 3-D Broadcast, Big Is Bigger, But Eyes Grow Weary
text: When Zydrunas Ilgauskas of the Miami Heat took the court at Madison Square Garden on Friday night, the benefit of watching basketball in 3-D became immediately apparent. On ESPN’s 3-D broadcast, the 7-foot-3 Ilgauskas towered over the players for the Heat and the Knicks in a manner that has no true equivalent in a standard broadcast. The effect would be familiar to anyone accustomed to watching basketball on television who is sitting in good seats in an arena: a sudden appreciation for the physical size of the players on the court.

headline: High Line’s Next Phase: Less Glitz, More Intimacy
text: Thirty feet above street level and just west of 10th Avenue near 25th Street, the view westward between a pair of old buildings reveals tall smokestacks and a sliver of the Hudson River in the distance.

headline: Democrats Scramble to Save Votes to Ratify Nuclear Pact
text: WASHINGTON — The top two Senate Republicans declared Sunday that they would vote against President Obama’s nuclear treaty with Russia as the bipartisan spirit of last week’s tax-cut deal devolved into a sharp battle over national security in the waning days of the session.

headline: Live Analysis: Eagles 38, Giants 31, Final
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Over the years, the Giants and the Philadelphia Eagles have created memories that live in their franchises’ lore. On Sunday, the teams added another indelible moment, one that could send the teams in opposite directions with the playoffs looming.

headline: iPads Arrive at Delta Gates at Kennedy
text: Delta recently installed iPads for public use at  dining areas at several of its gates in Kennedy Airport.

headline: South Korea Starts Live-Fire Drills on Island Near the North
text: PYONGYANG, North Korea  South Korea began live-fire artillery exercises on Monday, escalating a confrontation with North Korea even as an American official reported “important progress” in breaking through the North’s isolation in talks here in the North Korean capital.

headline: Real Strangeness in Imaginary Kingdom
text: It took until he was 55, but Simon Rattle finally made his Metropolitan Opera debut on Friday night. Mr. Rattle, who has been a major conductor for 30 years and the artistic director of the Berlin Philharmonic since 2002, led the season premiere of Debussy’s “Pelléas et Mélisande,” a revival of Jonathan Miller’s gothic 1995 production. At the end of this four-hour evening, some of the most ardent participants in the ovation for Mr. Rattle were the musicians in the orchestra pit, who stood and heartily applauded.

headline: Sweat | Training Champions, One Bruise at a Time
text: Recently, Mike Torriero found himself in a familiar situation.

headline: Gas Prices Soar in Iran as Subsidy Is Reduced
text: TEHRAN  Gasoline prices nearly quadrupled on Sunday and the riot police guarded filling stations around the capital as deep cuts in subsidies on fuel and other essential goods took effect.

headline: After Belarus Vote, Riot Police Attack Protesters
text: MINSK, Belarus  Antigovernment protesters were beaten back by swarms of riot police officers on Sunday when they tried to storm the Belarus government headquarters here in an outburst of anger and frustration over the apparent and, many said, wholly unsurprising re-election of the country’s authoritarian president, Aleksandr G. Lukashenko.

headline: Indian Party’s Leader Stands by Singh
text: NEW DELHI  With the governing Indian National Congress Party reeling from a damaging scandal, Sonia Gandhi, the party’s president, called Sunday for party leaders to “confront corruption head on” and create more transparent procedures for awarding government contracts.

headline: Part Goofy, Part Glorious, All Man
text: The first thing you should know about Les Ballets Trockadero de Monte Carlo’s current engagement at the Joyce Theater is that there isn’t a nutcracker in sight. The second is that a stage filled with snow isn’t all there is to the notion of seasonal festiveness.

headline: Men in Tights
text: Images of a performance by the all-male troupe Les Ballets Trockadero de Monte Carlo.

headline: Paleomonetarism
text: I used that term — it’s probably not original, but who knows? — in a recent post about the increasingly obscure meaning of the money supply. The best example would surely be Ron Paul, who’s now going to have oversight over the Fed. If you read his stuff, it’s very clear: money is a well-defined quantity that the Fed controls, and inflation comes from — indeed is defined as — increases in that quantity.

headline: Ireland the Model
text: Oh, my: I missed this, but ran across it when doing some research:

headline: From the Locker Room to the Library
text: Every year around this time I get the same question. It usually happens in Stevenson Library — the one that is open 24 hours — sometime between 2 a.m. and 4 a.m.

headline: A Life Built on Illusion: More Tease Than Strip
text: On the theory that the biographer of a stripper needs a tease, Karen Abbott opens “American Rose” with Gypsy Rose Lee on the verge of something big. It’s 1940, and Ms. Lee, known in this book more comfortably as Gypsy, is about to perform at the World’s Fair and cement her status as a national treasure. As proof that Gypsy appealed to patriots of all stripes, Ms. Abbott cites a congratulatory telegram written 19 years later by Eleanor Roosevelt: “May your bare ass always be shining.”

headline: Eagles Stun Giants on Game’s Final Play
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  The words from both locker rooms were the same. Nothing else was.

headline: A Troupe Celebrates Its Voyages of Discovery Through 25 Years
text: If there is any company working today whose dancers pack a more sophisticated and vibrant kinetic punch than those of Ronald K. Brown/Evidence, I can’t think of it. This is truly an ensemble of individuals, each putting a particular stamp on the moment-by-moment progression of Mr. Brown’s dances. Joel Sulé Adams, Arcell Cabuag, Otis Donovan Herring, Maresa D’Amore Morrison, Waldean Nelson, Francine Ott, Annique Roberts, Shola Roberts, Lilli-Ann Tai, Clarice Young and, of course, Ronald K. Brown: it is worth taking the time to write out  and read  all of their names.

headline: UConn Women Match the Streak of U.C.L.A.’s Men in the 1970s
text: As the clock ticked down, many of the 15,232 fans at Madison Square Garden began chanting, “Eighty-eight, eighty-eight,” serenading the Connecticut women into history as well as onto victory.

headline: New Music With the Energy of Youth
text: Arriving at the Metropolitan Museum of Art on Friday night for the second of this season’s New York Philharmonic Contact! concerts, you could wonder where the thrill had gone. Reports of previous installments in this admirable new-music imperative  two last season and a third in November  promised an air of excitement. But here in the Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium, which was slightly more than half full, the mood was reserved.

headline: DeSean Jackson Dazzles Again, Preens Again
text: It will be hard to criticize DeSean Jackson for anything after a dazzling 65-yard punt return won the game for the Eagles on the last play of the game Sunday.

headline: It May Seem Like a Sacrifice, but It Turns Into Much More
text: The diagramed deal occurred in the Barbara Kantor Memorial Flight A/X Swiss Teams during the Summer North American Championships in New Orleans.

headline: Faithful to Two Worlds: The Marines and the Artistic Life
text: WASHINGTON — He’s an artist on his way to his second war, and he wants to make one thing perfectly clear: He is not a Marine who paints, but a painter who fights.

headline: A Real Science of Mind
text: In recent years popular science writing has bombarded us with titillating reports of discoveries of the brain’s psychological prowess.  Such reports invade even introductory patter in biology and psychology.  We are told that the brain — or some area of it sees, decides, reasons, knows, emotes, is altruistic/egotistical, or wants to make love.  For example, a recent article reports a researcher’s “looking at love, quite literally, with the aid of an MRI machine.”  One wonders whether lovemaking is to occur between two brains, or between a brain and a human being.

headline: Coughlin Screams at Punter on Field After Loss
text: In his postgame news conference, Giants Coach Tom Coughlin said he took full responsibility for the loss and for the final play.

headline: A Trouper Unleashes Backstage Tales
text: Once a child star, always a child star: At 46, the British actress, dancer and entertainer Bonnie Langford exhibits the snap, crackle and pop of an eternally stage-struck trouper who was born in a trunk and has been frolicking in sawdust since she was old enough to walk. A gymnastic wonder, she can execute a 180-degree kick as though she were taking a baby step.

headline: Imax Ticket Sales Lift ‘Tron: Legacy’
text: A traditionally soft weekend for moviegoing  all of that shopping to do, all of those holiday parties to attend  proved no exception as “Tron: Legacy” opened to solid but not spectacular results, “Yogi Bear” underperformed, and Reese Witherspoon bombed in “How Do You Know.” “Tron: Legacy,” a $170 million sequel starring Jeff Bridges (above) and backed by a three-year marketing campaign, was No. 1 for Walt Disney Studios with an estimated $43.6 million in sales. Imax sales contributed 24 percent of that gross, indicating strong interest from core science-fiction fans; the question now is whether Disney can keep the momentum going over the Christmas holiday period and reach a wider audience. “Yogi Bear” (Warner Brothers) was second with $16.7 million, an underwhelming total considering this picture had the benefit of higher-priced 3-D screenings. “The Chronicles of Narnia: The Voyage of the Dawn Treader” (20th Century Fox) was third with about $12.4 million for a two-week total of $42.8 million, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles box office statistics. In its first weekend in wide release “The Fighter” (Paramount Pictures and Relativity Media) was fourth with $12.4 million, a strong result for a gritty adult drama that cost $25 million to make. “The Tourist” (Sony Pictures Entertainment and GK Films) was fifth with $8.7 million for a two-week total of $30.8 million. Sony’s romantic comedy “How Do You Know,” directed by James L. Brooks for over $100 million as a vehicle for Ms. Witherspoon, sold $7.6 million in tickets. Fox Searchlight’s “Black Swan,” starring Natalie Portman, performed better despite playing in 959 theaters compared with 2,483 for “How Do You Know.” The weekend total for “Black Swan” was about $8.3 million.

headline: Ozawa’s Children Accept Award for Him
text: The confluence was almost perfect. The Japanese conductor Seiji Ozawa was to receive the Shigemitsu Award for distinction in international cultural affairs after his Carnegie Hall concert with the Saito Kinen Orchestra on Saturday evening. The award, established a decade ago to honor Mamoru Shigemitsu, the Japanese foreign minister who engineered his country’s entry into the United Nations in 1956, is presented annually on Dec. 18, the anniversary of that event. Peter Grilli, the president of the Japan Society of Boston, won the award last year, and when the society subsequently took over administration of the award, he determined that Mr. Ozawa would become the first Japanese winner. What he didn’t realize at the time was that on the very evening of the award presentation, Mr. Ozawa would be conducting Benjamin Britten’s great internationalist creation, the “War Requiem.” In the words of the society’s news release, the work “echoes the antiwar sentiments of Foreign Minister Shigemitsu’s General Assembly speech as Japan was inducted into the United Nations.” But as it happened, the performance of this imposing work left Mr. Ozawa  suffering from sciatica and still depleted after surgery for esophageal cancer early this year  exhausted and unable to attend the presentation at a postconcert party for the performers at a restaurant near Carnegie. Instead Mr. Grilli  in the presence of Yutaka Shigemitsu, a 92-year-old nephew of the foreign minister, who founded the award  presented the award to Mr. Ozawa’s daughter, Seira, and son, Yuki.

headline: Adding Another Layer to ‘War Requiem’ Story
text: Benjamin Britten’s “War Requiem,” commissioned for the 1962 consecration of a new cathedral in Coventry, England, where an old cathedral was destroyed by German bombing in World War II, was the great internationalist statement of a pacifist. To drive the point home in the first performance Britten wanted vocal soloists from Britain (Peter Pears), Germany (Dietrich Fischer-Dieskau) and the Soviet Union (Galina Vishnevskaya, who, barred from traveling to England, had to be replaced by the British soprano Heather Harper).

headline: Movies as a Form of Music
text: The Japanese composer Toru Takemitsu, an avid film buff, once said that he loved movies because he experienced them as music. Maki Takemitsu, his daughter, focused on her father’s significant contributions to the movie world for a tribute she organized as part of Carnegie Hall’s JapanNYC Festival. The concert on Friday evening at Zankel Hall featured arrangements of Mr. Takemitsu’s soundtracks by four jazz musicians who worked closely with him.

headline: Putting Faith Vocations to the Real-World Test
text: God never really shows up in the first half of “The Calling,” a two-part, four-hour look at seven young adults who are pursuing religious leadership roles. That makes for a frustrating first two hours; you wish some or all of these always-in-motion people would just sit still and talk about their ideas of God and religion and what they think the future holds for their faiths.

headline: Artist/Warrior

headline: The Ordinary Can Pave the Road to Insanity
text: As the groom drones on with a tedious wedding toast, the bride’s face goes blank. Then her eyes become watery, and her mouth gets wider and wider until, as he nervously makes another unnecessary aside, she looks like the figure in Munch’s painting “The Scream.”

headline: All Aboard an Alt-Rock Time Machine
text: Weezer couldn’t just play its best album, “Pinkerton” from 1996, all the way through at Roseland on Saturday night and fill out the concert with other songs. That would be too simple, not layered enough with self-consciousness, rightful pride and lingering questions.

headline: Monday Always Rings Twice
text: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — If you’re a regular reader of Wordplay, it’s probably hard to remember when Monday crosswords were a challenge. You’re no longer in the prime market demographic but you know people who are. In this season of sharing, think about introducing a friend to the sport. Make sure you mention that Monday puzzles are easiest and they get harder as the week goes on. Sudoku and KenKen and most other newspaper puzzles provide a degree-of-difficulty indication but with crosswords, for some reason, it’s a secret. Pass it on.

headline: There Goes the Sun
text: WHAT is the winter solstice, and why bother to celebrate it, as so many people around the world will tomorrow? The word “solstice” derives from the Latin sol (meaning sun) and statum (stand still), and reflects what we see on the first days of summer and winter when, at dawn for two or three days, the sun seems to linger for several minutes in its passage across the sky, before beginning to double back.

headline: Pope Says Sex Scandal Has Hit Unimaginable Dimension
text: ROME  Pope Benedict XVI said Monday that the continuing sexual abuse scandal in the Roman Catholic Church had reached a “degree we could not have imagined” this year, and that the church must reflect on its failures, help the victims and prevent abusers from becoming priests.

headline: DeSean Jackson’s Postgame Comments
text: The postgame transcript from the Eagles’ DeSean Jackson, as provided by the Giants. A Fifth Down post on Sunday questioned whether it was wise for Jackson to start celebrating before scoring on his 65-yard punt return, especially given his history of mishaps at the 1-yard line. He explains here that he was trying to kill the clock by running sideways as he neared the goal line. But he also added: “Like I said, I like to do some things for excitement. That’s what the fans and all the crowd pay for, so I like to bring that out.” As it turns out, the clock hit zero before Jackson reached the Giants’ 20-yard line.

headline: Potash Merger Creates Global Player in Russia
text: Uralkali said Monday that it had agreed to acquire Silvinit for $8.1 billion in cash and shares, combining two Russian potash producers to create a major new player in the global market for the fertilizer ingredient.

headline: The Temporary Vegetarian: Fall Vegetable Cookpot: Braised Red and Green Cabbage
text: Didier Elena, the executive chef at Adour Alain Ducasse, makes cabbage rolls that are not the stuff of peasant life, but neither are they hard to make. They simply take time.

headline: C Is for Christmas Wish: Cookie Monster Gets on ‘Saturday Night Live’
text: Even if you missed this viral video from November in which Cookie Monster laid bare his desire to host “Saturday Night Live,” you’d have to be a Snuffleupagus-sized Scrooge not to be charmed by the above scene from Saturday’s “S.N.L.” broadcast in which Jeff Bridges, the show’s proper host, shared his opening monologue with that gluttonous Muppet for a duet of “Silver Bells.” (Equally charming was the Lebowski-like tendency of Mr. Bridges to refer to his furry blue co-star simply as “Cook.”)

headline: Andy Reid Missed Two Challenges, Pereira Says
text: The Eagles’ rally gave Coach Andy Reid a key victory and also saved him some postgame grief. Mike Pereira, an analyst for Fox and the former N.F.L. vice president for officiating, said that Reid erred by not challenging two calls on Sunday against the Giants. Those two, in addition to a booth review that wasn’t reversed but that maybe should have been, wound up costing the Eagles three scores, he said.

text: PARIS  Europe was slammed by new winter storms on Monday, forcing airlines to cancel or delay thousands of flights and further aggravating travelers after two days of snowy disruption that already had left many airplanes grounded. The repercussions were felt around the globe.

The site offers packages for getaways near or within the cities where it already lists daily deals, as well as a few more faraway locales.

Following so far?

headline: Monday Reading: Credit Scores and Medical Bills
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: E.V.’s Are Here, but Expect Wait for Charging Stations
text: The Chevrolet Volt and Nissan Leaf were delivered to their first customers last week, and a small fleet of Think City electric vehicles were handed over to the State of Indiana for use in state parks. The plug-in E.V. has arrived, and it begs the question: will a public charging network be available to support the cars?

headline: Paterson on Paterson, the Governor and the Man
text: In a wide-ranging, at times emotional interview last week, the departing New York governor, David A. Paterson, talked about a variety of topics, including his fears of getting along without the help of his staff, the focus of a front page article on Monday. But that was hardly all. He also discussed how unhappy his son has been over the last four years, how being governor affected his marriage and how difficult it will be to adjust to life as an ordinary citizen.

headline: Reading, Writing, ‘Rithmetic and Relationships
text: Children go through ups and downs like everyone else. But even in elementary school, some children  are shy and awkward, and they can easily become social outcasts, anxious about social interactions and maybe a tad depressed. Normal adolescent angst can spiral out of control for these young people, taking them on a trajectory that can lead to major depression by adolescence — unless, research suggests, they have a simple but valuable asset: a friend.

headline: Time Lords A-Leaping: Steven Moffat Explains the ‘Doctor Who’ Christmas Special
text: Just a handful of television narratives have become synonymous with the holiday season: a misfit reindeer with the help of an outcast elf provides crucial help to Santa Claus on a foggy Christmas Eve night; a sensitive boy takes pity on an underdeveloped would-be Christmas tree; a humanoid alien traverses time and space in a high-tech ship camouflaged as a vintage British telephone booth.

headline: Corporate Deal Makers Cautiously Return
text: As the dark clouds of economic uncertainty lift, the environment for corporate deal-making is looking brighter.

headline: Google Adds Warnings About Hacked Sites
text: This has been a busy year for security on the Web. Over the last 12 months a number of big-name Web sites suffered a form of security breach, including Twitter, Facebook, Gawker Media and Google. In some cases, hackers took over the infrastructure of the sites and in others, hackers gained access to users’ personal information.

headline: Share Your Christmas Memories of New York City
text: For me, Christmastime has always been set in one neighborhood, Park Slope, Brooklyn, where my parents, little sister and I moved in 1970. I left in 1991 — going the whole way to Carroll Gardens — but still came back on Christmas Day. A few years ago, my wife and son and I drove to my mother’s house that morning wearing coats over our pajamas.

headline: Strain on College Mental Health Centers
text: Today’s parents probably remember the college’s counseling office as the place to go with the blues about a romantic breakup or when they were conflicted about their major. Those rites of passage still trouble students, but campus psychologists increasingly treat severe mental illness. Surveys show nearly half of college students who seek counseling on campus today suffer depression, anxiety, eating disorders, self-cutting, alcohol abuse and other serious issues.

headline: This Week’s Health Industry News
text: It’s been a busy few weeks, especially as different judges weighed the constitutionality of the new health care law and the Food and Drug Administration issued some important decisions.

headline: Coaching Carousel Already in Full Spin
text: It’s the most wonderful time of the year, unless you’re an N.F.L. head coach with a struggling team. Want a taste of the high-wire act of a coach’s life? The Giants’ shocking collapse against the Philadelphia Eagles reignited talk that Tom Coughlin’s job could be on the line — even though the Giants can clinch a wild-card spot in the playoffs Sunday with a victory over Green Bay.

headline: Investigation Opened After Britain’s ‘X Factor’ Lives Up to Its Name

headline: Parenting Run Amok Awards

headline: With $8 Million on the Line, It Is More Than Just a Game

headline: Fashion’s Night Out
text: New York City, for one night, seemed to forget that there was a recession. Streets were packed, stores were crowded and gobs of people were carrying shopping bags on Madison Avenue.

headline: ‘True Grit’ and the Cult Writer’s Cult Writer
text: Last awards season we had Thomas Cobb, the little-known author of “Crazy Heart,” the novel which in movie form won Jeff Bridges his long-overdue Oscar. And this year there’s Charles Portis, the better-known but far more reclusive writer of “True Grit,” the novel remade by the Coen brothers  (and, again, a Jeff Bridges vehicle). Mr. Portis is known as “a cult writer’s cult writer,” according to Charles McGrath, favored for his subtle wit, lustrous dialogue and keen observation. The journalist Ron Rosenbaum has said he is “perhaps the most original, indescribable sui generis talent overlooked by literary culture in America.”

headline: Video of Opposition Protests in Belarus
text: As my colleague Michael Schwirtz reports, postelection protests in Belarus were violently suppressed on Sunday, and arrests of opposition activists continued on Monday.

headline: Bad Weather Disrupts Travel in Europe
text: Snow in Western Europe has left travelers stranded at airports and other transit hubs, including London Heathrow, Orly in Paris and Frankfurt Airport in Germany, and has led to worldwide disruptions. And things might get worse before they get better, as more icy conditions are expected for Tuesday.

headline: Blini at the Buffet
text: In November, I offered to make blini as an hors d’oeuvre for a Thanksgiving dinner. The hostess liked the idea, and I liked her reason: “They are instant festivity,” she wrote in an e-mail.

headline: The Look | Holiday Fetes
text: Holiday parties are in full swing. And while it’s safe to say we all gladly expect eggnog, Champagne and decorated cookies, run-of-the-mill festive sequined dresses are a bore. This year’s look is decorated bright white minimalism. Dress up an easy frock, like the Row’s marina dropped-waist silk one, with a printed evening clutch and a sparing spruce of jewels. The real party-gossip piece? Sergio Rossi limited-edition pumps knotted in satin or velvet. You’ve seen them on Anne Hathaway and Emma Watson, but not like this. It’s the perfect cocktail of “It” item splashed with unexpected simplicity.

headline: Life and Death Decisions Weigh on Junior Officers
text: QURGHAN TAPA, Afghanistan — The hill wasn’t much to behold, just a treeless mound of dirt barely 80 feet high. But for Taliban fighters, it was a favorite spot for launching rockets into Imam Sahib city. Ideal, American commanders figured, for the insurgents to disrupt the coming parliamentary elections.

headline: What About Lehman?
text: Seemingly lost amid all the attention on insider trading are the long-running federal and state investigations into Lehman Brothers. But in his last days in office, the New York attorney general, Andrew M. Cuomo, plans to file civil charges against Ernst & Young, Lehman’s outside auditor, a person briefed on the matter told DealBook on Monday.

headline: Updates to Twitter Allowed in British Courts
text: The head of the judiciary in England and Wales ruled on Monday that reporters and other observers can send updates to Twitter and other short text messages from courtrooms while trials are in session so long as the messages do not impede the judicial process.

headline: What to Give the Doorman? Not the Smoking Jacket

With some large luxury buildings employing dozens of doormen, porters and handymen, the mental math can be daunting. What to give without seeming too cheap?

headline: Eagles Comeback or Giants Collapse?
text: Were it not for their three Super Bowl victories, the Giants’ main role in N.F.L. history would be to define the limits of Titanic collapses. Their latest cannonball into that ocean of woe came Sunday against the Eagles, prompting the question: what other franchise (O.K., aside from the Cubs) blows a 21-point lead in just over eight minutes, only to have its fans instantly debate where it ranks on their list of soul-crushing losses. What other fans can say, “Well, at least it wasn’t a playoff game like when we blew a 24-point lead against the 49ers in 2003!”

headline: Capturing the Government
text: Peter Orszag’s well-remunerated transition from the White House to one of the banks that our federal government recently bailed out provoked a thoughtful post from Will Wilkinson, who suggested that the revolving door between Wall Street and Washington illuminates a “tension within the progressive strand of liberal thought.” No matter how ingeniously or idealistically progressives deploy government power “as a countervailing force against the imagined oppressive and exploitative tendencies of market institutions,” he wrote, “it seems that time and again market institutions find ways to use the government’s regulatory and insurer-of-last-resort functions as countervailing forces against their competitors and, in the end, against the very public these functions were meant to protect.”

Lew already had bruises after a month as President Obama’s budget director when, on Thursday, his former boss, Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton, belatedly hosted a farewell party for him. Amid the holiday splendor of a State Department reception room, colleagues sent him off with a memento: a helmet like those of diplomats in war zones.

headline: On Our Radar: Environment Trumps Politics, Dalai Lama Says
text: The international community should focus on environmental problems like climate change, the Dalai Lama told U.S. diplomats last year. Melting glaciers, deforestation and polluted water from mining projects were problems that “cannot wait,” while Tibetans can wait 5 to 10 years for a political solution, the exiled Tibetan Buddhist leader told Timothy Roemer, the United States ambassador to India, in a secret cable obtained by the Web site Wikileaks. [The Guardian]

headline: Iran Lets Gas Prices Soar, but Drivers Seem Unfazed
text: TEHRAN Seemingly unaffected by a sharp increase in gasoline prices that went into effect at midnight on Sunday, drivers jammed the streets here on Monday after the government lifted traffic restrictions aimed at reducing severe air pollution.

headline: A South Korean Tenor Makes His Mark at the Met, With La Scala Next
text: The South Korean tenor Yonghoon Lee won a lot of fans at the Metropolitan Opera for his recent performances in the touchstone title role of Verdi’s “Don Carlo” at the Metropolitan Opera, starting with his Met debut on Nov. 29. Roberto Alagna, who sang the role in the Nov. 22 premiere of Nicholas Hytner’s new production and garnered all the opening-night reviews, was the big-name draw of “Don Carlo,” along with the young conductor Yannick Nézet-Séguin.

headline: Assessing the Kings by Their Own Rubric
text: Evaluating the success of N.B.A. teams requires assessments in two different frameworks. Objective measures of performance (won-lost record, efficiency differential, the “four factors,” etc.) offer a very straightforward, quantitative means of determining a given team’s standing. Additionally, because the chief operators of N.B.A. franchises primarily look to achieve very particular goals, the execution of the team’s plan also becomes a crucial part of the evaluative process.

headline: ‘War Horse’ Corrals Its American Cast
text: If its life-size horse puppets were not sufficiently challenging, the coming Lincoln Center Theater production of “War Horse” will also employ an ensemble of 35 actors, all new to the play. On Monday, Lincoln Center Theater said the cast of its “War Horse,” adapted from the Michael Morpurgo novel and first presented by the National Theater in London, would feature Seth Numrich (of the current Broadway production of “The Merchant of Venice”) as Albert, a young man whose beloved horse, Joey, is sold to the cavalry at the outbreak of World War I. Other cast members include Boris McGiver (Broadway’s “Desire Under the Elms”) and Alyssa Bresnahan as Albert’s parents; Peter Hermann (Broadway’s “Talk Radio”) as a German officer; and the singers Liam Robinson and Katy Pfaffl.

headline: Blankfein Sees Investment Banking Revival, Analyst Says
text: Investment banking is the business that Lloyd Blankfein, chief executive of Goldman Sachs, sees as having the most potential next year, according to a new Wall Street analyst report.

headline: Obama to Sign ‘Don’t Ask’ Bill on Wednesday
text: President Obama will sign the repeal of the military’s ‘don’t ask, don’t tell’ policy into law Wednesday morning, and may hold a news conference before leaving for Hawaii later in the week, his press secretary, Robert Gibbs, said on Monday.

headline: Engine Makers Sue to Block E15 Fuel
text: The Environmental Protection Agency’s approval of more ethanol in the fuel recipe for some cars faces another federal court challenge.

headline: National Portrait Gallery Rejects Artist’s Request to Remove His Work
text: The National Portrait Gallery in Washington will not comply with an artist’s request that it remove a work of his from the exhibition “Hide/Seek: Difference and Desire in American Portraiture,” the gallery’s spokeswoman said Monday afternoon. The artist, AA Bronson, asked last week that the gallery remove from the show his photograph “Felix, June 5, 1994,” which shows the body of Mr. Bronson’s partner shortly after he died of AIDS, to protest the removal of another work after it was criticized by members of the religious right and some congressional Republicans.

headline: A Pop-Up Larder in Echo Park
text: For 10 days this month, a group of enterprising young women converted a carriage house in Los Angeles’s Echo Park neighborhood into a larder that they called the Cantry. They christened themselves the Pantlers — after the name given to the servant in charge of the bread and the pantry of a great house — built shelves and lined them with an assortment of canned and pickled goods, tinctures and creams, and drawings and zines. Small jars containing tea lights and flowers were tied to bicycle wheels suspended from the ceiling, becoming clever D.I.Y. chandeliers to light the long refectory-style table made by a woodworker friend. Through word of mouth and Facebook posts, people came to trade and barter their own wares for ginger beer, pomegranate jelly, bacon-infused bourbon, pie fillings and sundry items. A neighbor even offered to trade music for goods. Every night a guest chef cooked a family-style dinner while D.J. friends spun tunes and recipes were shared. The Pantlers are all makers, “obsessed with food, gardening and doing things for themselves,” and had talked about sharing their kitchen, home lab and garden experiments for over a year before opening the Cantry. If you missed the Pantlers in Echo Park, visit their online trading post and watch for news of the next pop-up larder.

headline: At W, Ice Skating Five Stories Above Downtown Manhattan

Through Feb. 15, the wraparound outdoor terrace on the fifth floor has been transformed into an ice-skating rink, complete with a corner ice bar.
