text: Web content introduces 2011 Ford Explorer.

headline: Rooster Will Rise Again in Broadway Transfer of ‘Jerusalem’
text: If you’re disappointed that 2011 won’t offer enough opportunities to see Mark Rylance on Broadway when “La Bête” wraps up its run on Jan. 9, you won’t have to be without him for very long: he’ll return next year in “Jerusalem” when that Jez Butterworth play transfers to Broadway in the spring, making good on Mr. Rylance’s vow in November that it would do so.

headline: Zombiegenesis: A Better Picture
text: Actually, this might be a better picture for making the point about how rightists used the temporary bulge in Census hiring to spread the false impression of soaring government employment:

headline: Did Anyone See a Naked Lion?
text: The lions flanking the entrance of the New York Public Library at 42nd Street have gone undecorated this holiday season.

headline: Skype Looks for a Spot in Offices and Cellphones
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Skype has become one of the Internet’s most popular services — so much so that it is even used as a verb to describe a phone call over the Internet, as in “Skype me.”

headline: Giants’ Future Depends on Getting Past Collapse
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — A day after collapsing in a 38-31 loss to the Philadelphia Eagles, the Giants were sifting through the wreckage of the demoralizing defeat Monday at their practice facility.

headline: Stalin Rose From Czarist Oppression to Transform Russia Into Mighty Socialist State
text: Joseph Stalin became the most important figure in the political direction of one-third of the people of the world. He was one of a group of hard revolutionaries that established the first important Marxist state and, as its dictator, he carried forward its socialization and industrialization with vigor and ruthlessness.

headline: JETLINER CARRYING 258 TO U.S CRASHES IN SCOTTISH TOWN
text: LONDON, Dec. 21 -- A Pan Am Boeing 747 on a flight from London to New York with 258 people aboard crashed tonight in a southern Scottish village, British military authorities reported. The airline said it knew of no survivors.

headline: Augmented Reality on Your Phone
text: Over the weekend I used a new iPhone application,  Word Lens, to perform magic tricks for anyone who would watch. Word Lens isn’t really a magic app, but using it was kind of magical for me, almost like  seeing Houdini perform in real life. The app is an augmented reality program that can translate text from English to Spanish, and the other way around, instantly through the iPhone’s camera.

headline: Dame Peggy Ashcroft, Acclaimed British Actress, Is Dead at 83;
text: Dame Peggy Ashcroft, an actress who was in the forefront of British theater for more than half a century, died yesterday in London. She was 83 years old.

headline: News Quiz | Farewell, 2010
text: Say goodbye to 2010 by taking our 25-question quiz. After you answer each question, click on the related resource to see a Times article, Times Topics page, blog post or graphic. (For a print version of the quiz, download this PDF.)

headline: Looking Back at 2010: Teaching Ideas
text: We’re suckers for end-of-the-year retrospectives, and for weeks now we’ve been collecting interesting examples, both from within The Times and from around the Web. We’ve also written some puzzles, quizzes and questions of our own.

headline: VOYAGER SUCCEEDS IN HISTORIC FLIGHT
text: EDWARDS AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., Dec. 23 -- Sweeping out of a clear desert sky and into aviation history, the experimental airplane Voyager landed safely here early today, completing the first nonstop flight around the world on one load of fuel.

headline: Wealthiest Negress Dead
text: Mrs. C. J. Walker, known as New York's wealthiest negress, having accumulated a fortune from the sale of so-called anti-kink hair tonic and from real estate investments in the last fourteen years, died yesterday morning at her country estate at Irvington-on-Hudson. She was proprietor of the Madame Walker hair dressing parlors at 108 West 136th Street and other places in the city. Her death recalled the unusual story of how she rose in twelve years from a washerwoman making only $1.50 a day to a position of wealth and influence among members of her race.

headline: I.F. Stone, Iconoclast of Journalism, Is Dead at 81
text: I. F. Stone, the independent, radical pamphleteer of American journalism hailed by admirers for scholarship, wit and lucidity and denounced by critics for wrongheadedness and stubbornness, died of a heart attack yesterday in a Boston hospital. He was 81 years old and lived for many years in Washington.

headline:
Bush Pardons 6 in Iran Affair, Aborting a
Weinberger Trial; Prosecutor Assails 'Cover-Up'
text: WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- Six years after the arms-for-hostages scandal began to cast a shadow that would darken two Administrations, President Bush today granted full pardons to six former officials in Ronald Reagan's Administration, including former Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger.

headline: Numberplay: Figuring It Out in Your Head
text: We’ve had some puzzles involving pretty heavy calculations in recent weeks, like the analysis of the Newton’s Cradle and the quickest probabilistic strategy for Paula the Octopus. The debates on both of these puzzles are still on, and they are not completely resolved. So I thought we’d do some lighter stuff here today, involving tricks to doing mental calculations.

headline: A Doctor’s Mammogram Mission Turns Personal
text: Dr. Marisa Weiss scheduled her mammogram this spring, just as she does every year. She had just turned 51, and after having annual scans for a decade, she knew what to expect: her dense breast tissue made reading the films difficult  “like looking for a polar bear in a blizzard”  and the technician would probably ask her to sit for a few extra views.

headline: Anwar el-Sadat, the Daring Arab Pioneer of Peace with Israel
text: "Sadat! Sadat!" tens of thousands of Cairenes chanted at the grinning figure in the open limousine. ''Sadat! The man of peace!'' It was the night of Nov. 21, 1977. President Anwar el-Sadat had just returned from his epochal journey to Jerusalem. Egypt's people were giving their frenzied approval to what his trip had achieved - an Egyptian-Israeli thaw that set the stage for the peace treaty of 1979.

headline:
Gorbachev, Last Soviet Leader,
Resigns; U.S. Recognizes Republics' Independence
text: MOSCOW, Dec. 25 -- Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the trailblazer of the Soviet Union's retreat from the cold war and the spark for the democratic reforms that ended 70 years of Communist tyranny, told a weary, anxious nation tonight that he was resigning as President and closing out the union.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: An aggregation of links by the reporters and editors of Diner’s Journal.

headline: The Scents and Tastes of Home
text: Next week I am planning an update on some of the many people whose stories appeared on Motherlode during the year. (If anyone reading would like to send such an update, the address is belkin@nytimes.com)

headline: Five Questions About a List About Movies About Theater
text: Christmas is a season of lists. Santa has one, of course. The New York Times’s blogs have several, from T Magazine’s luxe wish list to the Carpetbagger’s pre-Oscar list-o-mania to Paper Cuts’ book-o-rama.

headline: Free Pines in the City, if You Know Where to Go
text: Lush green wreaths and garlands can cost a bundle in Manhattan at Christmastime, but regular users of the Hudson River bike path on the West Side of Manhattan have a better place to gather bounteous boughs by the sack-load for free near 96th Street in Riverside Park.

headline: Basking in a Workout’s Long, Mysterious Afterglow
text: It’s a cold day and you have just finished a grueling session at the gym, sweating away on an elliptical cross-trainer. Or you had a tough workout in the swimming pool. Or in a spin class. Or you just finished a hard run or a long, fast bicycle ride.

headline: The Post-Workout Bonus
text: After a vigorous run, ride or swim, the feeling of warmth in your body can linger for hours. But are you burning extra calories once the workout is over? Gina Kolata explores the aftereffects of exercise in today’s Personal Best column.

headline: Yves Saint Laurent: New Vintage III
text: Only YSL can make vintage as good as new. After the success of not one but two environmentally feel-good capsule collections, New Vintage, initiated by YSL’s creative director, Stefano Pilati, and Julie Gilhart, is having another go. New Vintage III’s moxie is quite simple: reclaim, recycle and sustain. “The collection is materially comprised of garments made from recycled fabric and from existing patterns instead of new ones, to start a dialogue with the market using known codes and a common language that are reassuring and familiar,” says Pilati about the 180 pieces that will be available this week. Metallic wide leg trousers, velvet tuxedo suiting jackets and leopard-print wrap dresses with a hint of disco pay a refreshing nod to Saint Laurent’s iconic 1970s designs. You’ll have a second chance to finally own that missed ready-to-wear piece, and no doubt appreciate the brand’s intelligent use and reuse of its existing resources.

headline: Five Years In, Gauging Impact of Gates Grants
text: SEATTLE — Five years ago, Bill Gates made an extraordinary offer: he invited the world’s scientists to submit ideas for tackling the biggest problems in global health, including the lack of vaccines for AIDS and malaria, the fact that most vaccines must be kept refrigerated and be delivered by needles, the fact that many tropical crops like cassavas and bananas had little nutrition, and so on.

headline: Tending to Your Eyes
text: Poor vision can lead to job loss, social difficulties and the pain and cost of falls and accidents. And though routine eye exams can help to detect the early signs of vision loss and prevent the progression of some eye diseases, few adults make their annual appointments, writes Jane Brody in this week’s Personal Health column.

headline: In Africa’s Year, Eto’o Is Continent’s Best
text: Samuel Eto’o, the face of soccer in Africa, was named the continent’s player of the year Monday, the fourth time the Cameroon forward has won the award.

headline: How a Torn Aorta Can Do Lethal Damage
text: The death of the veteran diplomat Richard C. Holbrooke last week shocked Americans and his many colleagues around the world. Mr. Holbrooke, 69, was a larger-than-life figure, a fearless and robust man who was apparently struck down without warning.

headline: Through the Mill
text: Q. Is there a limit to how often paper can be recycled?

headline: Sausage Pinwheels
text: 1 16-ounce roll Jimmy Dean pork sausage, preferably spicy1 8-ounce package Pillsbury Crescent Rolls.   1. Bring the sausage to room temperature. Using a rolling pin, roll the crescent dough into a rectangle, pinching together the perforations. Spread the sausage evenly on the dough, leaving a half-inch border.2. Roll up the dough lengthwise and pinch together the seam. Wrap in plastic wrap and refrigerate for at least 2 hours. 3. Preheat the oven to 400 degrees. 4. Slice the roll into ½-inch slices and place on a foil-lined pan sprayed with cooking spray. (Parchment paper may also be used; no spraying necessary.) Bake for 15-17 minutes or until browned. Serves 8. Recipe from Donna Meade Dean.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Belarus and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Belarus, Afghanistan and South Korea.

headline: Another Extension for ‘Merchant of Venice’ on Broadway
text: Hath not a Jew eyes? Hath not a Jew hands? And hath not a Jew some much deserved time away from Broadway coming up? He does, but he’d better keep it quick as “The Merchant of Venice” is extending again.

headline: Iran Jails Leading Filmmaker for 6 Years
text: Updated | 5:03 p.m. Jafar Panahi, a celebrated Iranian filmmaker who was arrested in February and accused of working on an “anti-regime” film, was sentenced to six years in prison on Saturday in Tehran, his lawyer told an Iranian news agency on Monday.

headline: Mini Unveils Paceman Concept Ahead of Detroit Auto Show
text: Mini revealed on Sunday its latest concept car, the Paceman: a two-door coupe based on the four-door Countryman model. Described by the company as a “sports activity coupe,” it will have its debut at the Detroit auto show in January.

headline: London: Tuberculosis Cases Have Increased 50 Percent in Last Decade, Lancet Says
text: London is the tuberculosis capital of Western Europe, according to a recent article in the medical journal Lancet, which said that cases there increased 50 percent in the last decade.

headline: F.C.C. Poised to Pass Net Neutrality Order
text: 6:42 p.m. | Updated  The chairman of the Federal Communications Commission appears to have the votes he needs to pass new rules for net neutrality.

headline: More Critics Join ‘The Social Network’
text: All you folks who are tired of the year-end best-of lists – and commenters, we know who you are! – stop reading now, because there are yet more annual kudos to announce. “The Social Network” continues its sweep of critics, bloggers and other fans of procrastinating on Facebook, earning plaudits from the Chicago Film Critics Association, the professional cinephiles polled by IndieWire and the Palm Springs International Film Festival, which will bestow an ensemble award on the film.

headline: Tell Us the Worst Christmas Gift You Ever Received
text: Dear Santa,

headline: Off-Season Training Program Has Kept Vonn on Course
text: Lindsey Vonn’s rigorous and revamped off-season workout program was designed to keep her upright on the course, to keep mistakes from turning into devastating falls. She has put those skills to extensive use this World Cup season.

headline: Barneys Chief Sells Chelsea Co-op
text: MARK LEE, the new chief executive of Barneys New York, whose recent decision to fire two longtime buyers at the store caused a stir in the fashion world, has sold his apartment in Chelsea for $2.95 million, the full asking price, according to city records.

headline: For Tavis Smiley, a New Home on PBS
text: The broadcaster Tavis Smiley is changing the co-producer of his weeknight PBS talk show to WNET.org, from the Los Angeles station KCET-TV.

headline: Spacesuit Archives
text: In a National Air and Space Museum storage facility, there is a collection of 200 historic spacesuits. Science writer Henry Fountain takes a look at these NASA relics.

headline: For Air Cargo, a Screening Conundrum
text: Ever since 9/11, each new security threat to airlines has increased the rigor of passenger screening. They have to remove their shoes and carry liquids only in small containers. They have to take off their belts and take laptops out of their cases. Now, they have to submit to full-body scanning machines and intrusive pat-downs.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Belarus and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Belarus, Afghanistan and South Korea.

headline: Iraqi Premier Proposes Cabinet Ministers to Parliament
text: BAGHDAD  Iraq’s prime minister set forward the skeleton of his new government on Monday night, proposing ministers to fill a majority of cabinet seats and bringing a bitter nine-month impasse one faltering step closer to resolution.

headline: A Space Wardrobe
text: A collection of spacesuits, some worn by famous astronauts and others that never made it into space.

headline: The Right Stuff to Wear
text: SUITLAND, Md. — Stashed in a Smithsonian storage building in this Washington suburb are some of the engineering wonders of the space race.

headline: Do Digital Billboards Waste Energy?
text: Last spring, the paper’s Driven to Distraction series explored the potential risks of digital billboards, which critics sometimes refer to as “TV on a stick.” Some cities and states are debating whether to prohibit or regulate this new form of advertising for fear that it can distract drivers and raise the rate of accidents.

headline: Having Fun Across Generations
text: It must have been a heady week of rehearsals for the Ensemble ACJW, the performing arm of the Academy, a collaboration among Carnegie Hall, the Juilliard School and the Weill Music Institute.  Simon Rattle, in town to conduct “Pelléas et Mélisande” at the Metropolitan Opera, took charge of the prodigiously talented ensemble, augmented this time by alumni of the program and a few guests.

headline: A Marriage That Defied Separation and War
text: John and Abigail Adams not only had one of the most documented marriages in early American history, but their partnership  chronicled in some 1,200 letters  was also uncannily modern. It was a marriage based on mutual intellectual passions, enduring sexual and emotional chemistry, and commitment to a shared political vision. For the irascible and highly volatile John, Abigail was a psychological anchor and trusted confidante; for the saucy and independent Abigail, John was a brilliant and courageous visionary who shared her love of books and playful sense of humor. She called him “My Dearest Friend.” He called her “Miss Adorable” and his “Heroine.”

headline: Aszure Barton & Artists at Baryshnikov
text: The Canadian choreographer and her group unveiled “Busk,” a work set to live Gypsy music, at the Baryshnikov Arts Center.

headline: Set to Live Gypsy Music, Otherworldly Vignettes of Characters Adrift
text: The Canadian choreographer Aszure Barton gets around. She is the “Two and a Half Men” of the dance world, although some people might think that’s a good thing. For the past several years she has created works for established groups like American Ballet Theater and the Martha Graham Dance Company, as well as choreographed the Broadway production of “Threepenny Opera.” Last weekend at the Baryshnikov Arts Center  Mikhail Baryshnikov is also a longtime supporter of Ms. Barton  she unveiled “Busk,” an evening-length work for her own group, Aszure Barton & Artists, that explores aspects of what it means to perform.

headline: Drawing on Fond Childhood Memories for a Pairing of Beethoven and Berio
text: The cellist Edward Arron, in introducing the eighth season by the Metropolitan Museum Artists in Concert at the Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium on Saturday evening, said that he initially heard the opening piece  Beethoven’s 14 Variations in E flat for piano trio  played by the Beaux Arts Trio in that same hall when he was, to use his term, a little kid. Even then, Mr. Arron said, he was struck by the work’s theme, which seemed “almost comically simple.”

headline: A Few Instruments Go a Long Way
text: Perhaps your house, like many, has an upright piano in it that doesn’t get a lot of use anymore — the children are grown and gone, or the ol’ hands have a touch of arthritis, or no one ever really learned to play the danged thing in the first place. And perhaps you’re moderately annoyed every time you look across the room and see the inactive beast — essentially, a 700-pound, $3,000 picture-frame holder.

headline: Explaining the Statistics on Temporary Hires
text: Reading my article on temporary workers in Monday’s Times, Daniel Indiviglio, an associate editor at The Atlantic, questions whether companies are really behaving that much differently than they have in previous recessions, when temporary jobs were the first to come back.

headline: Another Merry Christmas With the ‘Brandenburgs’
text: The Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center’s concerts of Bach’s “Brandenburg” Concertos each December have become almost as much a New York holiday staple as the avalanche of “Messiah” and “Nutcracker” performances. For more than a decade, the society has offered all six concertos in one sitting in programs that tend to sell out. Any suggestion of abandoning the tradition has been adamantly opposed.

headline: 'The Shop Around the Corner'
text: A. O. Scott looks back at the holiday classic starring James Stewart and Margaret Sullavan.

headline: There’s No Such Thing as the New Normal
text: Carl Richards is a certified financial planner in Park City, Utah. His sketches are archived here on the Bucks blog, and other drawings are available on his personal Web site, BehaviorGap.com.

headline: Barbour’s Comments Focus Attention on Race
text: In a new interview, Governor Haley Barbour of Mississippi recalls the 1960s-era civil rights struggle in his hometown of Yazoo City, saying, “I just don’t remember it as being that bad.”

headline: Cables Shed Light on Ex-K.G.B. Officer’s Death
text: LONDON  Shortly after the radiation poisoning in London of a former K.G.B. officer, Alexander V. Litvinenko, a senior Russian official asserted that Moscow had been tailing his killers before he died but had been waved off by Britain’s security services, according to a cable in the trove of secret American documents released by WikiLeaks.

headline: Critics’ Choice: New CDs
text: DIDDY-DIRTY MONEY

headline: Football and Survivors Prove Popular
text: The two-hour conclusion of “Survivor: Nicaragua” lifted CBS to second place in the ratings on Sunday night behind only NBC’s “Sunday Night Football.” According to Nielsen’s estimates, approximately 13.4 million viewers tuned in to the 21st-season finale of “Survivor,” on the low side for a finale of this franchise but still solid compared to much of the rest of the night’s programming. CBS’s Sunday night ratings also benefited from strong results earlier for “60 Minutes” (17.9 million), which followed an overrun of the network’s afternoon football coverage that delayed the start of its prime-time schedule. NBC’s “Sunday Night Football” matchup between the Green Bay Packers and the New England Patriots dominated overall in prime time. Although final audience figures were not available on Monday, preliminary overnight estimates for the game were among this season’s highest but down from last week’s Philadelphia Eagles-Dallas Cowboys broadcast, which drew 25.7 million viewers. ABC was third behind NBC and CBS with back-to-back movies: “The Santa Clause 2” from 7 to 9 (6 million) followed by “The Santa Clause 3” from 9 to 11 (6.4 million). Fox finished in fourth place with reruns.

headline: In Lacrosse, Separating the Harrisons From the Grangers
text: There are so many great traditions at this time of year, and not all of them revolve around the holidays. Take, for instance, Inside Lacrosse’s annual roundup of the best names in the college game. For the fourth consecutive year, the magazine’s staff has separated the Draper Donleys from the Redmond Killpacks and delivered the best monikers in the country. Now fans can argue over, among other things, whether Baxter Lanius IV deserved to be a first-teamer over Brantley Beach.

headline: The Secession Ball
text: Adam Goodheart, a contributor to Disunion, appeared on WBUR’s “Here and Now” to discuss the series and South Carolina’s decision to secede from the United States 150 years ago yesterday.

headline: Critics’ Picks Video: ‘The Shop Around the Corner’
text: In this last, hurried week of holiday shopping, A. O. Scott looks back at a simpler shopping experience; the kind that could be found at “The Shop Around the Corner.”

headline: More Than One Part of France Is Fizzy
text: OBSESSED with Champagne? I plead guilty. But you must understand, your Honor, it’s not just Champagne. I’m obsessed with almost all sparkling wines.

headline: Philip IV, Restored
text: Keith Christiansen and Michael Gallagher of the Met discuss the restoration of a Velazquez portrait.

headline: Reconsidered, a Met Velázquez Is Vindicated
text: For nearly 60 years the portrait of a baby-faced Philip IV by Velázquez hung in the Metropolitan Museum of Art’s European paintings galleries, a stunning example of the only 110 or so known canvases by that 17th-century Spanish master. Majestic in size, it was rare in its depiction of a young, uncertain monarch and was the earliest known portrait of Philip by Velázquez, who, as the king’s court painter, went on to record his image for decades.

headline: Eugene Goldwasser, Biochemist Behind an Anemia Drug, Dies at 88
text: Eugene Goldwasser, a largely unsung biochemist whose 20-year pursuit of an elusive protein led to the development of a widely used anemia drug that became one of the biggest products of the biotechnology industry, died Friday at his home in Chicago. He was 88.

headline: Bones Give Peek Into the Lives of Neanderthals
text: Deep in a cave in the forests of northern Spain are the remains of a gruesome massacre. The first clues came to light in 1994, when explorers came across a pair of what they thought were human jawbones in the cave, called El Sidrón. At first, the bones were believed to date to the Spanish Civil War. Back then, Republican fighters used the cave as a hide-out. The police discovered more bone fragments in El Sidrón, which they sent to forensic scientists, who determined that the bones did not belong to soldiers, or even to modern humans. They were the remains of Neanderthals who died 50,000 years ago.

headline: Council Approves West Side Apartment Towers
text: The City Council on Monday unanimously approved the development of five additional glass apartment towers, a hotel and a school on an eight-acre parcel on the West Side where developers have already turned a onetime railroad yard into an upscale residential community.

headline: Scott Conant Says He’s Closing Faustina as the Cooper Square Hotel Changes Hands
text: Scott Conant just called to say he was closing Faustina, in the Cooper Square Hotel, on Wednesday because he was told that the hotel had been sold and that the new owners wanted to run the restaurant there themselves.

headline: Recipes for Festive Main Courses That Feed a Crowd
text: Roasted lamb, fresh ham, lasagna and other main courses for a big holiday meal.

headline: In Map of Brain Junction, Avenues to Answers
text: Working with human brain tissue removed in surgery, researchers have identified the components of a critical part of the brain’s architecture: the synapse, or junction where one neuron makes a connection with another.

headline: Ending Homelessness
text: Project H3, an outreach program, helps people living on the streets in Phoenix find stable shelter. Video by Scott Foreman.

headline: For Activist Funds, a Long-Term Approach to Investing
text: Ann Johansson for The New York Times Jeffrey Ubben, chief executive of ValueAct Capital, an activist hedge fund, says his firm has an advantage over rivals because it focuses on the long run.

headline: Just Imagine (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Attention Must Be Paid (3 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Homes at Risk, and No Help From Lawyers
text: In California, where foreclosures are more abundant than in any other state, homeowners trying to win a loan modification have always had a tough time.

headline: Hardships of a Nation Push Horses Out to Die
text: DUBLIN  In this country of lush green landscapes, celebrated for its traditional love of horses and the generations of racing thoroughbreds it has bred to conquer the racetracks of the world, the Dunsink tip on the outskirts of the Irish capital is a place that wounds the heart.

headline: U.S. Military Seeks to Expand Raids in Pakistan
text: WASHINGTON  Senior American military commanders in Afghanistan are pushing for an expanded campaign of Special Operations ground raids across the border into Pakistan’s tribal areas, a risky strategy reflecting the growing frustration with Pakistan’s efforts to root out militants there.

headline: Young Female Chimps Play Out Motherly Role
text: Young female chimpanzees like to play with sticks as if they were dolls, according to a new study in the journal Current Biology.

headline: T. Rex’s Relatives Had More Items on Their Menu
text: Although Tyrannosaurus rex liked to dig its teeth into flesh, many of its relatives had beaks, fewer teeth and longer necks and preferred plants, according to a new study.

headline: Antitrust Suit in Michigan Tests Health Law
text: DETROIT  When the Justice Department filed an antitrust lawsuit against Blue Cross Blue Shield of Michigan in October, the unusual action was widely seen as a warning shot to dominant health insurance carriers in many other states.

headline: Ex-Lobbyist in Alabama Pleads Guilty in Bribery
text: Jarrod D. Massey, a former Alabama lobbyist at the center of a bribery scandal that has shaken the state government, pleaded guilty on Monday in federal court in Montgomery, Ala., to conspiring to pay state lawmakers in exchange for their votes for pro-gambling legislation.

headline: Recalling a Brooklyn Disaster Otherwise Forgotten
text: Quite understandably, there were powerful remembrances last week of the December day 50 years ago when death poured down from the skies above New York. Nothing like it had ever happened here: two planes colliding in midair, fiery wreckage landing on city streets, 134 people dying, including 6 on the ground in Brooklyn.

headline: Many Challenges, but Also Many Helping Hands
text: They began as arguments do between mothers and sons. Turn down the music. Which boys are you hanging around with? No, you cannot have those sneakers.

headline: AT&T Will Buy More Spectrum
text: AT&T agreed to buy wireless spectrum from Qualcomm for $1.93 billion to expand its fourth generation, or 4G, broadband capacity.

headline: American Objects
text: Objects from the travels of Dan Barry, the “This Land” columnist for The Times.

headline: After Oil Spill Crisis, a Protector Keeps Watch
text: CARLISLE, La.

headline: Hot Tropical Air and Travels With Jonesy
text: FLYING has been a part of my life since I was a kid. So when I started working right after college and had to fly a lot, I was already a seasoned traveler.

headline: Computers and Cabbage at a Food Bank That Works
text: Not much has been easy for Madelyn Ruiz, a Florida native, since she arrived in New York in October after a job overseas fell through. For the first time in her 33 years, she has been living in shelters, most recently in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn.

headline: We’re All Conservatives Now
text: Last week conservative activist David Horowitz, author of the Academic Bill of Rights, e-mailed me to report, in sorrow, that Penn State University had weakened “the only academic freedom provision . . . worthy of the name.” What the university had done was revise an 1987 statement stipulating that “it is not the function of a faculty member . . . to indoctrinate his/her students with ready made conclusions on controversial subjects.” That sentence disappeared, as did a warning against “introducing into the classroom provocative discussions of irrelevant subjects not within the field of [the instructor’s] study.” The National Association of Scholars Web site declares that academic freedom at Penn Sate is “ruined.” The left had won again, and the university world remains a bastion of radical political forces.

headline: Ill Prepared for Snowfall, Britain Crawls to a Halt
text: LONDON — If there were a contest for the worst weather-related suffering in Britain in the last few days, who would win?

headline: The Myth of Fast-Forwarding Past the Ads
text: ZOMBIES attacked during a commercial break on the AMC zombie drama “The Walking Dead” last month. The flesh eaters were just about to feast on a man and woman when rescue came in the form of the Toyota Corolla, the subject of the 30-second spot.

headline: Vick Stirs Debate in the M.V.P. Vote
text: If the N.F.L. season were to end today, who would be the most valuable player? There are two clear choices: New England quarterback Tom Brady and Philadelphia’s Michael Vick.

headline: Justice Dept. Is Criticized as Corruption Cases Close
text: WASHINGTON  The Justice Department has shut down a wave of high-profile investigations of members of Congress over the past few months, drawing criticism that the government’s premier anticorruption agency has lost its nerve after the disastrous collapse last year of its case against former Senator Ted Stevens.

headline: New Security Features From Google
text: It is becoming increasingly perilous to surf the Web. Scores of poorly secured sites are being commandeered constantly by criminals and used to abuse visitors.

headline: Prospect of WikiLeaks Dump Poses Problems for Regulators
text: Lennart Preiss/Associated PressWikiLeaks founder, Julian Assange.

headline: F.E.C. Rejected Counsel With Its Vote on Senator
text: WASHINGTON  When the Federal Election Commission voted last month to close an investigation into a $96,000 payment to Senator John Ensign’s former lover, it overrode the findings of its own staff lawyers, documents made public Monday showed.

headline: Ivory Coast’s Leader Tightens Vise on Man Who Defeated Him in Presidential Race
text: ABIDJAN, Ivory Coast  The president of Ivory Coast on Monday stepped up the pressure on the man who defeated him in an election last month, cutting off food and medical help to his headquarters in a hotel here guarded by United Nations peacekeepers.

headline: Diary of a New York Lawyer
States’ Rights, but to What?
text: One hundred and fifty years ago today South Carolina declared its independence from the United States. The move had been in the offing since early November, when Abraham Lincoln’s election led the state’s leaders to fear that Washington would begin to restrict slavery in the territories and in their own state. That was the proximate cause, at least; there was more to it. Beyond the election, South Carolina was no longer happy in a union with the free states, where northern opponents of slavery were allowed to openly denounce the “peculiar institution” in Congress and in their home states.

headline: Discussing Civil Rights Era, a Governor Is Criticized
text: WASHINGTON  In an interview that set off a new round of debate on Monday about racial attitudes and politics, Gov. Haley Barbour of Mississippi, a potential Republican presidential candidate, recalled the 1960s civil rights struggle in his hometown, Yazoo City, saying, “I just don’t remember it as being that bad.”

headline: Paterson Fined $62,125 Over World Series Tickets
text: The state ethics commission imposed a record fine of $62,125 on Gov. David A. Paterson on Monday for soliciting and accepting free tickets to the 2009 World Series from the New York Yankees. The panel said he knew he had broken the law and then lied under oath to cover it up.

headline: City Will Require Police to Report on School Arrests

headline: Haiti: Election Results Delayed Until O.A.S. Review

The final tally from the Nov. 28 election had been expected Monday, but verified cases of fraud and disenfranchisement have led to an impasse and instability. Haitian and international officials have not said how long the recount will take, nor have the candidates said whether they will respect the result.

headline: Britain: OK 2 Txt n Tweet in Court, Judge Rules
text: The head of the judiciary in England and Wales ruled Monday that observers can send Twitter postings and text messages from courtrooms while trials are in session, so long as the messages do not impede the judicial process. The decision, meant to guide courts until a full review is completed, came a week after a London judge barred those present at a bail hearing for Julian Assange, the WikiLeaks founder, from posting messages to Twitter.

headline: Russia and Latvia to Rehash History
text: Presidents Valdis Zatlers of Latvia and Dmitri Medvedev of Russia used the first official post-Soviet visit by a Latvian head of state to announce the establishment of a joint commission to study the history of the two countries, a major sticking point in their relations. Russia objects to Latvia and other Baltic countries referring to their decades as part of the Soviet Union as an occupation, and insists that Latvians collaborated with the Nazis. They also discussed the status of Latvia’s 335,000 non-citizens, another unresolved issue from Soviet rule, of whom over 221,000 are ethnic Russians.

headline: Keep Arizona Elections Clean
text: Until not long ago, Arizona politics were an open sewer of corruption. But the state adopted a system of public campaign financing in 1998, and, since then, more than half of all candidates for office in Arizona have opted for this money.

headline: Google’s Next Deal

headline: China: Beaten Journalist May Be Brain Dead
text: A journalist who was severely beaten by a group of men in the western region of Xinjiang has been declared brain dead by doctors, journalists reported Monday. Sun Hongjie, a reporter with The Beijiang Morning Post, was beaten at a construction site on Saturday in the town of Kuitin, according to a colleague at the newspaper and Twitter posts by other Chinese journalists. The colleague declined to say what Mr. Sun was reporting on. At least two other prominent journalists, Fang Shimin and Fang Xuanchang, have been beaten by club-wielding thugs this year.

headline: Celestial Holidays
text: This is it, the shortest day of the year, the longest night. Winter, which begins Tuesday at 6:38 p.m. Eastern time, will get no darker than this. Slowly, inexorably, the days will begin to yawn wider and wider, and night will begin to contract. The change is just a few seconds at first  New Year’s Eve in Manhattan will be only 28 seconds longer than Christmas Eve. By mid-March, the days will be growing by some 2 minutes and 40 seconds apiece, and then the rate of change slows again until late June.

headline: Tommaso Padoa-Schioppa, 70, a Champion of the Euro, Dies
text: MILAN  Tommaso Padoa-Schioppa, an economist and former Italian finance minister who was one of the driving forces behind the creation of the European Union’s single currency, died Saturday in Rome. He was 70.

headline: California: New Governor Eliminates a Watchdog
text: Jerry Brown will eliminate the inspector general’s office when he takes over as governor in January. His transition team said Monday that the move would help streamline operations and save $700,000. Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger created the office to help curb waste and fraud and scrutinize spending of federal stimulus money. The Legislature put the office’s $2.8 million budget under the governor’s office budget, which Mr. Brown has pledged to cut 25 percent. In a letter addressing the cut, the inspector general, Laura Chick, wrote, “Creating this office sent a potent message: We are watching.”

headline: Don Van Vliet
text: Summer of 1969. Parents away. A 50-foot audio cable runs from the stereo through a window across the porch to the lawn, where it terminates in headphones with my head between them. I’m lying on my back in the Sacramento night. On the turntable is “Trout Mask Replica,” just released, which I’ve listened to again and again. It is the magnum opus of the Magic Band led by Captain Beefheart, a k a Don Van Vliet, who died on Friday at age 69.

headline: The Arduous Community
text: For the past few years, there has been a strange motif running through my social life. I’d go out with some writers, and they’d start gushing about someone named Erica Brown. “She has an inner light,” one of them once said. I’d be out with my wife and some of her friends, and they, too, would be raving about Erica Brown. “If she taught a course in making toast, I’d take it,” somebody remarked.

headline: Last Ban Standing

headline: For Knicks’ Big Two, Help Is Needed
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  Amar’e Stoudemire worked his way past a phantom defender on one court Monday while his teammates zigged and zagged up another. Knicks Coach Mike D’Antoni paced while watching the action as the team president Donnie Walsh scanned it from the sideline.

headline: A Plan to Make Homelessness History
text: This is a story about a plan to end chronic homelessness in the United States. It’s not an indeterminate “war on homelessness,” but a methodical approach to do away with a major social problem. Each day, roughly 700,000 people in the country are homeless. About 120,000 are chronically homeless. They often live on the streets for years and have mental disabilities, addiction problems and life-threatening diseases like heart disease, cancer and diabetes. They are also five times more likely than ordinary Americans to have suffered a traumatic brain injury, which may have precipitated their homelessness. Without direct assistance, many will remain homeless for the rest of their lives — at enormous cost to society and themselves.Against this backdrop, the 100,000 Homes Campaign has set the goal of placing 100,000 chronically homeless people — pinpointing those who face the greatest risk of dying on the streets —  into permanent supportive housing by July 2013. It’s the human welfare equivalent of NASA’s race to put a man on the moon. Whether the goal is achieved or not, the campaign is shifting the way cities address a problem that has often been seen as more of a nuisance than a public health emergency.

headline: Academy Deems Original Scores Too Unoriginal
text: Should Carter Burwell start working up revenge fantasies? Mr. Burwell, the composer of the scores for “True Grit” and “The Kids Are All Right,” recently told the Bagger that he was worried the Academy wouldn’t accept his work, deeming it not original enough, and it turns out he was right. “True Grit” was ruled ineligible, as was Clint Mansell’s score for “Black Swan,” according to a report in Variety. Both were disqualified because they include pre-existing music. (“True Grit” has 19th-century church hymns, and “Black Swan” features Tchaikovsky’s “Swan Lake.”) “The Kids Are All Right” and Michael Brook’s score for “The Fighter” are also expected to be banned because they rely too heavily on songs, which the Academy frowns on. Apparently even music professionals tend to prefer things you can sing along to, giving those films an unfair — in the Academy’s view — edge.

headline: Mines in Afghanistan: Old Weapon, New Threat
text: They can be as small as hockey pucks, intended not so much to kill as to sever a victim’s legs. Often encased in plastic with only slivers of metal in their fuses, they can be hard to detect. Buried close to the surface, they are sensitive enough to be detonated by dogs or goats.

headline: Brooklyn Frauds Are Playing Out in Polish, Police Say
text: A 73-year-old Polish woman from Greenpoint, Brooklyn, picked up the phone in late November and heard a young man’s voice speaking in Polish: “Hey, auntie, it’s me.”

headline: Defective Bomb Found on Rome Subway
text: ROME  With tensions high on the eve of what is expected to be another round of large demonstrations here, the Rome police found a rudimentary, defective bomb under a seat in the subway on Tuesday, officials said.

headline: Isakson Adds Another Republican Vote for Arms Treaty
text: Another Republican senator announced Tuesday morning that he would vote for the new arms control treaty with Russia as the Senate moved toward approving it.

headline: Death Comes to Riverdale
text: In issue No. 6 of “Life With Archie,” which will go on sale Dec. 29, Archie Andrews, the famous redhead from Riverdale, will deal with a death in the extended family. Geraldine Grundy, one of the gang’s high school teachers, will lose her battle with cancer.

headline: Notes On Government Employment
text: I see that my various posts on government employment have brought out a variety of complaints — OK, there was a temporary spike from the Census that’s being misused, but isn’t there an upward trend, isn’t that a bad thing, etc..

headline: As China Rises, So Does Vietnam
text: One of the biggest beneficiaries of China’s rapid economic ascent is not China at all, but rather its historic rival, occasional enemy and fellow socialist neighbor to the south, Vietnam.

headline: Seeing Your Children as Perfect
text: About a year ago at this time I ran a post titled “How Well Do You Know Your Children.” It was specifically about parents’ perceptions of their children’s nutrition and exercise habits (those with preschoolers reported that their children ate healthy food and exercised regularly, and those with middle-school children reported that theirs did not) and how often our perceptions are wrong (when examined more closely, there was very little difference in eating and exercise between the two age groups.) More broadly, my post raised the question of how regularly there is “a mismatch between what we see when we look at our children, and what is really there.”

headline: When the Diagnosis Is ‘Dead Butt Syndrome’
text: My butt, unfortunately, is dead.

headline: The End Seems Near for Favre
text: What looked like the end for Brett Favre came ingloriously, if somewhat fittingly, face down on a frozen field, the latest and unwisest of his innumerable comebacks looking less wise with every pained blink. Not even the Mr. Sunshine of “Monday Night Football,” Jon Gruden, could paint a smiley face on this one. Favre looked old, dazed and thoroughly beaten.

headline: Putting a Price on Side Pockets
text: Hedge fund investors stuck in side pockets, those opaque segregated accounts, may be able to buy some clarity.

headline: Laundromat Worker Is Shot to Death in Brooklyn
text: A 45-year-old man working at a laundromat in Brooklyn was shot and killed late Monday as he was taking out the garbage from the store, the authorities said.

headline: Kings of Leon Concert Postponed After Bus Fires
text: This isn’t the kind of hot act that Kings of Leon wants to be known as: two buses belonging to the band caught fire in London, causing no serious injuries but forcing the postponement of a concert at O2 Arena, BBC News reported. A bus at the arena caught fire, which spread to another tour bus in the loading bay, and about 60 firefighters came to the scene on Tuesday morning to put it out. The BBC said ambulance crews had also arrived to treat six people for smoke inhalation, and a spokesman for the London Fire Brigade said the fire had burned out both buses but had not affected the arena’s stage or seating area.

headline: Losing Hope About a Recovery
text: When will the economy begin to recover? The National Bureau of Economic Research’s Business Cycle Dating Committee says the recovery began in June 2009, but unemployed Americans beg to differ:

headline: South and West See Large Gains in Latest Census
text: WASHINGTON  The Census Bureau rearranged the country’s political map on Tuesday, giving more Congressional seats to the South and the West at the expense of the Northeast and the Midwest  changes that will have far-reaching implications for elections over the next decade.

headline: Spurned by Groupon, Google Goes Hunting
text: After failing to win over Groupon with a $6 billion bid, Google is courting the social buying site’s rivals, according to The New York Post.

text: 3:37 p.m. | Updated The truth has been visible for a while: Detroit guard Richard Hamilton is not a happy Piston.

headline: Scream Real Loud: ‘Pee-wee Herman Show’ Coming Back to HBO
text: Like a self-perpetuating argument composed of the phrase “I know you are but what am I?,” the Möbius strip that is “The Pee-wee Herman Show” continues to cycle forward and wrap around itself. On Tuesday HBO said it would shoot the Broadway production of “The Pee-wee Herman Show,” which stars Paul Reubens as that impish man-child of its title, for a special to be shown next year. Pee-wee historians – and you know who you are – may recall that HBO previously broadcast a “Pee-wee Herman Show” special in 1981, taped at the Roxy Theater in Los Angeles. That show, which Mr. Reubens and his colleagues at the Groundlings comedy theater began performing in 1980, would go on to form the basis of the “Pee-wee Herman Show” currently being presented at the Stephen Sondheim Theater on Broadway. HBO said it would tape its new “Pee-wee” special immediately after the show’s Broadway run ends on Jan. 2; a broadcast date wasn’t announced.

headline: Lawyer Describes Solitary Confinement of Suspected WikiLeaks Source
text: As Julian Assange, the founder of WikiLeaks, continues to grant interviews to the world’s media each day — including a revealing discussion with John Humphreys of the BBC on Tuesday — his supporters and critics alike have been offered glimpses of the estate in the English countryside where he is enduring what his lawyer jokingly referred to as “not so much a house arrest as a manor arrest.”

headline: EBay Sends Shoppers to Offline Stores
text: To help last minute holiday shoppers, EBay is sending them to bricks and mortar stores.

headline: Neediest | Seeking Self-Control
text: A teenage son works to control his anger and repair his relationship with his mother.

headline: Delays Persist for Travelers in Europe
text: LONDON  Prime Minister David Cameron said Tuesday that he had offered “military assistance” to the owner of Heathrow Airport, still struggling to clear a backlog of thousands of people left stranded by bad weather and the airport’s inability to deal with the problem.

headline: Elder Tech: What’s Important
text: Conversations about elderly parents and technology usually center on safety, in particular on devices designed to alert a call center in case of trouble. But our parents are more than the sum of their maladies. Instead of keeping them safe, can’t some of these devices help keep them happy?

headline: Why Apple Removed a WikiLeaks App From Its Store
text: Apple on Tuesday confirmed that it had removed from its online store an iPhone and iPad app that let users view the content on the WikiLeaks site and follow the WikiLeaks Twitter account.

headline: New York and New Jersey Will Lose House Seats
text: WASHINGTON — New York will lose 2 of its 29 seats in the House, while New Jersey will lose 1 of its 13 seats, both as a result of population shifts recorded in this year’s census.

headline: Santa’s Request List, N.H.L. Style
text: Christmas is almost here. Have you sent your letter to Santa Claus yet? There may still be time, but many N.H.L. personalities aren’t taking any chances. They’ve made sure their notes to the North Pole are already in the mail.

headline: Arms Treaty With Russia Headed for Ratification
text: WASHINGTON  An arms control treaty paring back American and Russian nuclear arsenals won a decisive vote in the Senate on Tuesday, clearing it for final approval and handing President Obama an important foreign policy victory.

headline: Favre Goes Off On a Shield Of His Own Making
text: It was hard to miss the symbolism of the final moments Monday night, when the Chicago Bears, so comfortable in their 40-14 blowout, already had on their division championship hats. The only parting gifts the Minnesota Vikings received were a few snowballs hurled at them by furious and freezing fans, and the sobering sight of their quarterback looking like a punch-drunk fighter who had finally taken one too many walks into the ring after strangely thrusting himself back into a season that had melted down.

headline: Barbour Seeks to Clarify Comments on Civil Rights Era
text: Gov. Haley Barbour of Mississippi sought to clarify remarks he made about his hometown during the civil rights era, calling it a “difficult and painful era,” especially for African-Americans.

text: A Brooklyn firefighter was arrested on Tuesday in connection with a fatal hit-and-run accident in October that left a Guatemalan immigrant dead.

headline: Arlen Specter’s Closing Argument
text: Senator Arlen Specter of Pennsylvania, a veteran of several Supreme Court nomination battles and a wily Senate tactician for three decades, bid farewell to the Senate on Tuesday with a stinging critique of the state of partisan politics and the conservative demand for ideological purity in Republican politicians.

text: A look at START nuclear arms treaty in Russia; and the senate on the 9/11 Health and Compensation Act

headline: In California, a Wary Eye on Hillsides as Rain Falls
text: LA CAÑADA FLINTRIDGE, Calif.  The rain had slowed to a mere pitter-patter on the windshield as Sgt. Tracy Stewart began surveying the area early Tuesday morning. Tiny streams of water were running speedily though the gutters and drain basins meant to protect the homes from floods and to ease the risk of mudslides like the ones that crashed through this Los Angeles suburb earlier this year.

text: The Samurai Shopper must admit to a few Mary Poppins moments, particularly at holiday time, when pure sentiment meets unmaxed credit cards. text: LOS ANGELES

text: The Blackstone Group, the private equity behemoth, named 11 new senior managing directors on Monday, effective Jan. 1, according to an internal e-mail.

headline: Brightscope’s Top-Rated 401(k) Plans
text: The quality of your 401(k) plan can have a big impact on your retirement savings. Overall costs of the plan matter, as does the breadth and quality of the investment options. The size of the employer match, if any, makes an enormous difference too in whether you’ll meet your savings goals.

headline: Browsing: Last-Minute Gift Guide
text: Still looking for that special something to say “I love you,” “I respect you,” “Thank you,” or “I am ambivalent about you”? Here are some last-minute gift ideas for procrastinators.

headline: Q&A: Where to Go With a $1,500 Flight Credit?
text: I have a $1,500 flight credit with Continental that I need to use, and I’m planning a 9- or 10-day trip sometime in January or February, but I don’t have my heart set on a destination. My only stipulations are that the destination be reasonably inexpensive (looking to spend around $100 to $150 a day) and reasonably safe for a 24-year-old female solo traveler. I’ve traveled solo to Indonesia, Jordan, Syria and Tanzania. Any ideas would be greatly appreciated.

headline: Which States Will Gain or Lose Seats in Congress
text: The Census Bureau released estimates Tuesday that show which states will lose or gain congressional districts.

headline: 10 Champagnes Worth Seeking Out
text: My column in the dining section this week is on the world of French sparkling wine beyond Champagne. To a certain extent, you could look at these bottles as Champagne replacements. They are cheaper – topping out at $30, which is about where basic Champagne begins nowadays. They can certainly step in and serve in the celebratory role at which Champagne excels.

headline: The Sounds of Silence Lose in British Chart Competition
text: Two ambitious Web campaigns were not enough to prevent a TV talent-show contestant from reaching the top of the British singles chart the week of Christmas — an annual race that has become something of a national sport for British music fans.

headline: Israel Plans Public Appeal to Ask U.S. to Free a Spy
text: JERUSALEM  Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel will officially and publicly appeal to President Obama in the coming days for the release of Jonathan Jay Pollard, the American serving a life term in a North Carolina prison for spying for Israel, Mr. Netanyahu’s office announced Tuesday.

headline: When Good Teaching Pays Off
text: Earlier this year my colleague David Leonhardt wrote about a new study that found that a good kindergarten teacher could greatly improve students’ future earnings. On that basis, an especially strong kindergarten teacher is arguably worth about $320,000 a year, which is the present value of the additional earnings that a full class of students can expect to earn over their careers.

headline: F.C.C. Approves Net Rules and Braces for Fight
text: 8:52 p.m. | Updated  Want to watch hours of YouTube videos or sort through Facebook photos on the computer? Your Internet providers would be forbidden from blocking you under rules approved by the Federal Communications Commission on Tuesday. But if you want to do the same on your cellphone, you may not have the same protections.

headline: Those Ornery Sisters of ‘The Fighter’
text: Pork, Tar, Red Dog, Beaver: these are not craft beers or bad-idea candle scents, they are the nicknames of the big-haired, big-mouthed sisters in “The Fighter.” The seven siblings of half-brothers Micky Ward and Dicky Eklund so captivated the film’s director, David O. Russell, that he told the Bagger that he wished he could make a TV show just about them. (Sounds like a TBS reality series to us.) In The Los Angeles Times, Steve Zeitchik takes a look at the actresses – some professional, some not – who round out the Ward-Eklund clan, many of them chosen from the 3,000 people who turned up for an open casting call in Lowell, Mass., where the movie is set and filmed.

headline: 16-Year-Old Leads Women’s World Chess Championship
text: Hou Yifan needs one more win, or to draw the next two games, to clinch the title and become the youngest world champion in history.

headline: Deutsche Makes Deal In Tax Case
text: Deutsche Bank agreed to pay $553 million and admit to criminal wrongdoing on Tuesday, settling a long-running investigation into tax shelter fraud that prosecutors say generated billions of dollars in bogus tax benefits.

headline: Can Milwaukee’s Offense Survive Jennings’s Injury?
text: The news of an injury to a star player is never cheery, but the announcement that a broken foot will cost Brandon Jennings upwards of four weeks of action is particularly dismal for the struggling Milwaukee Bucks. Jennings isn’t Milwaukee’s best player on either end of the court, but his absence from the lineup should serve as a reminder that things can always get worse for the league’s worst offense.

headline: Observers Comment on Eclipse: ‘How Tiny We Are’
text: Many people skipped sleep, or set their alarms, to make sure they were awake to see the lunar eclipse Tuesday morning.
