headline: The Windsor, a High-End Sports Bar in the West Village
text: THIS quaint corner of West Fourth and 10th Streets doesn’t exactly conjure a sports bar, with its white French windows and sidewalk hedges. Some might recall its previous tenant, the faux speakeasy Charles, which went to absurd lengths to create exclusivity. But upscale sports bars are all the rage these days, and the Windsor does a commendable job keeping up.

headline: Parsing the Airgas Rejection
text: Given the dispute among the Airgas directors that was apparent a few weeks ago, the latest rejection by the Airgas board is bound to have people parsing Talmudically through the Airgas board’s statements.

headline: Overseeing Integrity as Well as Income
text: Mark Emmert had a dual view of the recent seismic rumblings in college sports.

headline: Santa Isn’t Coming to Town
text: Do you believe in Santa? More to the point, do you believe your children should? As Christmas nears, let’s spend some time talking Santa here on Motherlode. Today, two essays from parents who refuse to fib to their children. Tomorrow, two from parents who see believing as a gift, not a lie.

headline: The True Meaning of Christmas
text: Gail Collins: David, I know you’re a big fan of community-building activities. How do you come down on Christmas? I don’t mean the religious feast but the all-encompassing, retail-sales-enhancing holiday season. In which Americans of all stripes celebrate the winter solstice with family gatherings, exchanges of gifts and cards and the singing of really terrible seasonal songs.

headline: Why to Donate Old Goods Now
text: Have a bunch of old clothes or household goods sitting around that you’ve been meaning to donate to charity?

headline: Making the Decision to Replace Yourself
text: In early 2008, Matt Dorey, founder and chief executive of Curve Dental, was at a loss. Three years into building a comprehensive Web-based software package for dentists, he felt the product was ready, but he was not sure how to make Curve a market leader. “The company was getting complicated,” Mr. Dorey said. “I was starting to become conscious of what I didn’t know. It was almost a feeling of loneliness.”

headline: Southern California Digs Out
text: One of the wettest Decembers on record did not cause major damage, but it did leave plenty of mud.

headline: YouTube Invests Again in Video Creators
text: It’s an early Christmas present for 500 of YouTube’s content partners: $1,000 to buy new video equipment.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: An aggregation of links by the reporters and editors of Diner’s Journal.

headline: Siberian Fossils Were Neanderthals’ Eastern Cousins, DNA Reveals
text: An international team of scientists has identified a previously shadowy human group known as the Denisovans as cousins to Neanderthals who lived in Asia from roughly 400,000 to 50,000 years ago and interbred with the ancestors of today’s inhabitants of New Guinea.

headline: How Do You Know It’s Time to Fire Yourself?
text: In a small-business guide about succession that we’ve just published, Katherine Reynolds Lewis writes about business owners who have concluded that it’s time to let someone else run their companies. For example, Matt Dorey, founder of Curve Dental, which makes software for dentists, told Ms. Lewis, “The company was getting complicated. I was starting to become conscious of what I didn’t know.”

headline: TimesCast | December 22, 2010
text: President Obama's last-minute boost from a productive lame duck session; the FCC on differences between wired and wireless Internet; And a look at the iPad.

headline: Time Inc. Installs New Senior Management in Shake-Up
text: Time Inc. is splitting its signature magazine division in two, the latest and final piece of a broader reorganization by the new chief executive, Jack Griffin, to realign swiftly the many diffuse and distinct units within the world’s largest magazine publisher.

headline: Ousted General Will Write a Memoir
text: Gen. Stanley A. McChrystal, the former commander of American and NATO forces in Afghanistan who was relieved of his duties in June, will have his say in a “leadership memoir” to be released in 2012, his publisher said Wednesday.

headline: Toil and Trouble
text: When economists and policy types and members of Congress talk about older Americans working past normal retirement age, an increasing theme of late, we tend to think they mean a few years beyond age 65, right? Working until ages 68 or 69, that is — maybe even 70, though that might be pushing it.

headline: The Case of the Missing o.b. Tampons
text: Updated Speculation about disappearing tampons started surfacing last September.

headline: Senate Passes Arms Control Treaty With Russia, 71-26
text: WASHINGTON — The Senate gave final approval on Wednesday to a new arms control treaty with Russia, scaling back leftover cold war nuclear arsenals and capping a surprisingly successful lame-duck session for President Obama just weeks after his party’s electoral debacle.

headline: Senate Passes 9/11 Health Bill
text: 5:42 p.m. | Updated The Senate on Wednesday approved a bill to cover the cost of medical care for rescue workers and others who became sick from breathing in toxic fumes, dust and smoke after the 2001 attacks on the World Trade Center.

headline: A Greek Bishop’s Anti-Semitic Tirade
text: Updated | 7:19 p.m. Leaders of Greece’s small Jewish community objected on Wednesday to televised remarks by a Greek Orthodox bishop who blamed the country’s financial problems on a conspiracy of Jewish bankers and claimed that the Holocaust was orchestrated by Zionists.

headline: Deal for 9/11 Bill Is Reached in Senate
text: A deal has been reached in the Senate to approve a bill that covers the cost of medical care for rescue workers and others who became sick after responding to the the World Trade Center attack in 2001. The action was a significant turn of events for a bill that once seemed all but dead. Only 12 days ago, Senate Republicans blocked the bill from coming to the floor for a vote. Get all the details from our colleagues at The Caucus blog.

headline: Ex-UBS Banker Pleads Guilty to Insider Trading
text: A former UBS health care banker, Igor Poteroba, pleaded guilty on Tuesday to conspiracy and securities fraud in connection with an insider trading scheme, in which he earned more than $465,000.

headline: Go for Broke | Victoria Beckham Handbags
text: It should surprise exactly no one that the owner of every “It” bag, including almost 100 Birkins, is trying her hand at designing handbags. Victoria Beckham’s first collection, a modest offering of just six styles ($1,800-$13,950), focuses on a central and alluring theme: 24 hours in the life of Victoria.

headline: Involuntary Transparency
text: A new paradigm of enforced openness – associated both with the WikiLeaks disclosures and the ability to make instant online price comparisons.

headline: Thursday’s Week 16 N.F.L. Matchup
text: Panthers (2-12) at Steelers (10-4)Thursday, 8:20 p.m. Eastern, NFL NetworkLine: Steelers by 13½

headline: The Nutcracker Chronicles: Clara Without a Home
text: BERKELEY — In October I made my first visit to Hearst Castle. This month, farther up the California coast, I acquainted myself with a different aspect of its architect, Julia Morgan. In 1908 she designed what is now the Julia Morgan Center for the Arts but was then a Presbyterian church. Still beautiful today, it is not just all wood but all redwood.

headline: Vineyard Theater Rounds Out Season By ‘Interviewing the Audience’
text: Next up at the Vineyard Theater, Off Broadway, are the new play “Picked” by Christopher Shinn (“Dying City,” “Where Do We Live?”) and a work developed by Zach Helm, perhaps best known as the screenwriter of “Stranger Than Fiction,” which depends largely on audience participation, the theater company announced on Wednesday.

headline: Comcast Takeover of NBC Is Delayed Until Next Year
text: 10:00 p.m. | Updated  The long-awaited completion of the takeover of NBC Universal by Comcast will have to wait until the new year.

headline: Homes for $545,000
text: A rustic home in Arkansas, a loft in Washington, D.C., and a condo in Boston.

headline: U.S. Says China Fund Breaks Rules
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration filed a case against China with the World Trade Organization on Wednesday, siding with an American labor union, the United Steelworkers, in accusing Beijing of illegally subsidizing the production of wind power equipment.

headline: Jackson No Match for Swift and Boyle
text: On the Billboard album chart this week Taylor Swift edges past Susan Boyle to return to No. 1, and Michael Jackson’s posthumously assembled new album opens at No. 3, with strong sales around the world.

headline: What You Get for ... $545,000
text: BOTKINBURG, ARK.

headline: Deaf Player at Cal State Northridge Has a Real Feel for the Game
text: ANAHEIM, Calif. — During the California, Berkeley men’s basketball season opener last month against Cal State Northridge, the Straw Hat Band and the student cheering section tried to rattle Matadors forward Michael Lizarraga with chants of “tuna” every time he touched the ball.

headline: Seeking a Meaningful Price on Carbon
text: One month ago, Wesleyan University hosted a weekend conference called “Pricing Carbon.” It was a revival meeting of sorts, bringing together about 500 economists, campaigners, scientists, students and lawmakers seeking, despite recent setbacks, to apply the age-old “polluter pays” principle to carbon.

headline: The Doors Light One Last Fire in Response to Morrison’s Pardon
text: A posthumous pardon granted by the State of Florida to Jim Morrison earlier this month was apparently not the end of a four-decade-old saga that began when Morrison, the Doors’ front man, gave a raucous performance at a Miami auditorium in 1969 that resulted in his being convicted of indecent exposure.

headline: Now Skating | Icy Hot
text: Growing up on the East Coast, I used to regard mild-clime cities with pity around the holiday season. Winters without snow seemed an unnatural, slightly tacky curiosity (Plastic flamingo Santas? Twinkle-lit palm trees?). Then I moved to San Francisco, where winter is a slow, wet leak from fall to spring. There’s no clearly definable season between November and March, and one is as apt to break out the scarf in foggy July as in misty, flower-blooming December. All of which is to say I’ve gotten more flexible about wintertime expectations.

headline: Rome Museum Joins Young Architects Program
text: The Museum of Modern Art and MoMA PS1 have added a third partner to their jointly run annual Young Architects Program. The two museums will collaborate with MAXXI, the National Museum of the 21st Century Arts in Rome, in this year’s competition to transform the courtyard of MoMA PS1 in Long Island City, Queens, for the summer. There will also be a separate installation at MAXXI in Rome.

headline: 9,300 Off-Road Buggies Recalled for Unintended Acceleration
text: About 9,300 off-road electric buggies are being recalled because of the danger of sudden, unintended acceleration, the Consumer Product Safety Commission stated in a news release Wednesday.

headline: Computers That Trade on the News
text: The number-crunchers on Wall Street are starting to crunch something else: the news.

headline: Can We Feel Good About Our Necks?
text: NECKS don’t lie. Sagging there betrays age like the rings on a tree, and now-common Botox and fillers in the face make neck imperfections stand out in stark relief. In her 2006 best-seller, “I Feel Bad About My Neck,” Nora Ephron, by then 65 and a resolved turtleneck wearer, raged against the injustice of having no remedy for her slackening throat skin, short of surgery.

headline: A Work’s Long Road to New York
text: In 1958, while in the Army, the composer Christian Wolff wrote a piece titled “For 6 or 7 Players,” then mailed his manuscript to his mentor, John Cage, without keeping a copy. Mr. Wolff’s work, also known as “Music for Merce Cunningham,” was meant for use in “Rune,” a dance by Cunningham, but never served that purpose.

headline: Obama Press Conference Will Cap Day of Accomplishment
text: The smile on his face said it all.

headline: TimesCast: The 9/11 Health Care Bill
text: After casting the health bill for 9/11 responders as a special-interest giveaway, Republicans lawmakers are drawing criticism from unlikely adversaries.

headline: New Year’s Resolution: Stop ‘n’ Swap
text: As I explain in my article about swaps, many Americans are presenting secondhand items as presents this season out of economic, environmental and charitable concerns.

headline: Evoking the Moods and Mysteries of a Medieval English Christmastide
text: Lionheart has wisely developed a cottage industry in thematic Christmas programs, each built around the repertories and traditions of a single country.

headline: Take it From Jordan: Quick Works in Ads Too
text: Somewhere along the way, Adidas lost track of what it was trying to market with their signature sneakers for Dwight Howard and Derrick Rose.

headline: A Lisping Moment in History
text: When the Bagger met Tom Hooper, the director of “The King’s Speech” at the movie’s New York premiere weeks before Harvey Weinstein started rounding up anybody affiliated with it for promotional duties, we had an interesting talk about how the film’s narrative is helped by the formality of the period. “There’s a lot of drama created by the constraints of how difficult it is for an Australian guy from a different class to interact with the king,” Mr. Hooper said. “It’s like what they say about romantic comedies -– what’s the obstacle in them getting together? You have to invent them. When you go back in time, often there’s so many obstacles, because of the social structures. That’s delicious, watching Geoffrey negotiate that with Colin.”

headline: Despite Economic Woes, Spain Continues Investment in Trains
text: MADRID  Spain overtook France this month as the country operating Europe’s biggest high-speed rail network, underlining the extent to which infrastructure spending has been at the heart of the country’s boom-and-bust economy.

headline: Mats Zuccarello to Make Rangers Debut Against Lightning
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — With Marian Gaborik out for Thursday’s home game against the Tampa Bay Lightning with a recurrence of his groin problems, the Rangers have summoned Mats Zuccarello from their A.H.L. affiliate in Hartford to make his N.H.L. debut.

headline: Stop and Frisk? No, Stop ‘n’ Swap
text: For New Yorkers whose New Year’s resolutions include getting organized or cleaning out their closets, the nonprofit group GrowNYC, which promotes recycling in the city, has scheduled “stop ’n’ swap” events in all five boroughs starting Jan. 8. The swaps are scheduled on Staten Island on Jan. 8, in Manhattan on Jan. 22, in the Bronx on Feb. 5, in Queens on Feb. 12 and in Brooklyn on Feb. 26. You can read about it from our colleagues at the Green blog.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Washington and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Washington, Chicago, Haiti and Italy.

headline: Scene City: Cupcakes for a Cause
text: The Endangered Species Coalition served up sweets and concern at a party to help endangered species a the Little Cupcake Bakeshop.

headline: Minimizing A.M.T. Through Charitable Donations
text: Bucks loves strategies that allow you to beat the system, especially when you can do some good in the process.

headline: Cupcakes for the Endangered Species Coalition
text: “WE are saving panda bears here tonight, right?” asked Waris Ahluwalia, the jewelry designer. “Arden specifically told me that, if I showed up, I would save at least one panda bear.”

headline: Which Truth About Santa?
text: This morning, on Day 1 of our Santa-truth-athon, a guest post explored how often random strangers seem to promise visits from Mr. Claus to our children. This afternoon, a second reader explores unthinking sabotage from a less expected place — her child’s school.

headline: Open Air in Costa Rica
text: A two-bedroom house in Costa Rica’s rainforest was built in 2004 to resemble the open-air homes popular in Indonesia. It’s on the market for $925,000.

headline: House Hunting in ... Costa Rica
text: A TWO-BEDROOM TWO-AND-A-HALF-BATH BALINESE-STYLE HOUSE IN UVITA, COSTA RICA

headline: The 10 Things to Talk About This Weekend
text: 1. Don’t Ask, Don’t Tell, repealed for the military, still applicable for store-bought desserts at your next holiday party.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Washington and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Washington, Chicago, Haiti and Italy.

headline: Six More Banks Repay TARP Funds
text: Six more banks have repaid the government bailout funds they received during the financial crisis, reaping $2.7 billion in proceeds for taxpayers, the Treasury Department announced Wednesday afternoon.

headline: High-Tech Electronics Dressed Up to Look Old
text: This has been a great year for the next new electronic thing. The iPad, new iPhone, the Nexus S, HTC Evo and other Android phones, the Kindle 3 and Microsoft’s Kinect caught the eye of consumers.

headline: A Savory Pancake of Root Vegetables
text: I haven’t made latkes this season, maybe because I’ve been getting my maximum daily requirement of oil in other forms. But the other night, when I was cooking dinner for a few friends and was in the kitchen wanting a snack as I finished making the meal, I ventured into alternative latke territory.

headline: Reality About to Hit 76ers
text: I regret to inform you, adoring basketball public, that the franchise once known as the Philadelphia 76ers has been completely eviscerated. I’m truly sorry for your loss.

headline: As Thrilling as Finding a Groom
text: IN 2003, for his thesis at Parsons the New School for Design, David Yassky wrote of women’s fascination with wedding dresses, a subject Vera Wang once described as a “mad, divine obsession.”

headline: The African Elephant, Split Into Two Species
text: There are two distinct species of elephants in Africa, not one, according to new genetic evidence.

headline: Nepomniachtchi Wins Russian Championship
text: Sergey Karjakin was leading heading into the last round, but lost, which allowed Ian Nepomniachtchi to catch him. Nepomniachtchi prevailed in the playoff to win his first national championship.

headline: Properly Powering a Mac
text: Properly

headline: ‘Spider-Man’ Shutdown is ‘Absolutely False,’ Spokesman Says
text: The Wednesday evening performance of “Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark” has been canceled.

headline: Hilton and Starwood Settle Dispute
text: Ramin Talaie/Bloomberg NewsW Hotel in Time Square, New York

headline: Where the Beers and the Jeers Flow Freely
text: NEW YEAR’S EVE, 2008. My boyfriend and I are at our local bar in Brooklyn. He is drinking a pint of Smithwick’s, and I am nursing a Jameson, neat. I take small sips, and the bartender eyes me. Cheap date, I am.

headline: Photo Replay: Dec. 22
text: The day in sports included college basketball in Lexington, Ky., and ice sailing in the Netherlands.

headline: Hive Health at the Solstice
text: Being a schoolteacher doesn’t allow me much time for beekeeping maintenance during the shorter days of winter. I leave for school in the dark (actually at sunrise, which can be quite spectacular) and I come back home in the dark. My only bee-related activity is to switch on the floodlights when I get home to make sure the hives haven’t been knocked asunder by any bears (unlikely, this year, after New Jersey’s recent bear cull).

headline: So Long, Bailey Building & Loan
text: This is the time of year when families gather to watch Jimmy Stewart play George Bailey, the small-town banker who learns the value of extending credit to his neighbors with a little angelic intervention in “It’s a Wonderful Life.” Though Mr. Bailey remains emblematic of a benign banking system, most Americans probably don’t realize he’s the most endangered species in finance.

headline: Rodgers Likely to Start Against Giants
text: Aaron Rodgers’s streak of 46 consecutive starts at quarterback for the Green Bay Packers was interrupted last week after a concussion — his second this season — on Dec. 12 against the Lions. And as much as he wanted to play, it wasn’t advisable or feasible for him to start against New England last week. Time off and monitoring from the Green Bay medical staff have helped and now, Rodgers appears ready to start in a pivotal matchup with the Giants on Sunday.

headline: A Cynical Position Overcome With Yoga
text: Why did Claire Dederer take up yoga? Short answer: for the same kinds of reasons that Elizabeth Gilbert changed her life in “Eat, Pray, Love,” and to much the same funny, charming, self-deprecating, stealthily inspirational and (quite possibly) best-selling effect.

headline: Small-Business Research Bill Becomes Law, Sort of
text: Back in July 2009, the Small Business Innovation Research program seemed on the cusp of a new lease on life and a makeover. The program, in which the big research grant-making federal departments and agencies set aside a small fraction of those grants for small business, was set to expire at the end of the month, but the House had passed H.R. 2965, the Enhancing Small Business Research and Innovation Act of 2009. The Senate had followed suit, renaming the bill the S.B.I.R./S.T.T.R. Reauthorization Act of 2009. (S.T.T.R. stands for Small Business Technology Transfer, a similar program.)

headline: On Our Radar: Coal Shortage Worsens in China
text: Power cuts and blackouts hit factories and residential neighborhoods in central China as coal supplies dwindle at generating stations. Supplies were strained after a surge in power demand after a cold weather front hit the region this week. Two power stations have completely run out of coal, and 14 other stations have only a few days’ supply, reports said. [Global Times]

headline: Memorable Moments of 2010: Metropolitan
text: These images complement “2010: The Year in Pictures.”

headline: Not Too Large, Not Too Small, but Spoiling for a Fight
text: Male hissing cockroaches in Madagascar are aggressive creatures that ram one another’s heads and flip one another over. They can also flick their abdomens to forcefully whack another male.

headline: The Gift of Guns, Courtesy of Cerberus
text: For employees of AlixPartners, finding a last-minute holiday gift may have gotten a little easier.

headline: Skype Goes Out
text: 10:10 a.m. | Updated A day after suffering a widespread outage of its Internet telephone service, Skype was continuing to try to fully restore service. In a blog post at around noon on Thursday, the company said that it had “seen evidence of a significant increase in the number of people online” to around 10 million (it has hosted as many as 25 million on normal days). Skype added that instant messaging and group video conferencing would take longer to restore.

headline: ‘We Are Not Doomed to Endless Gridlock’
text: President Obama on Wednesday declared the lame-duck session of Congress to be the “most productive post-election period that we have had in decades” and promised to continue seeking common ground next year.

headline: The Key Was Getting West to Hold Tight to That King
text: Ask any of the top New York area players for their favorite event on the local calendar and many will answer that it’s the Von Zedtwitz Double Knockout. As the name implies, a team must lose twice to be eliminated. And often when the final is played, one team is undefeated and the other once defeated. Then the once defeated must win two matches to take the title.

headline: Hollywood’s Class Warfare
text: THE idea of the universal middle class is a pervasive expression of American egalitarianism  and perhaps the only one left. In politics the middle has all but swallowed up the ends. Tax cuts aimed at the wealthy and social programs that largely benefit the poor must always be presented as, above all, good for the middle class, a group that thus seems to include nearly everyone. It is also a group that is, at least judging from the political rhetoric of the last 20 years, perennially in trouble: shrinking, forgotten, frustrated, afraid of falling down and scrambling to keep up.

headline: He Looks Like a Big, Scary Guy, but Really ...
text: MICHAEL SHANNON arrived at Frankies Spuntino in Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn, and avoided the busy back room, preferring to slip into a lone table up front. But at 6 foot 4 with a giant noggin topped off by a brow that could serve as a balcony, he’s tough to miss. Add in the fact that he has been nominated for an Academy Award (“Revolutionary Road”), is currently starring in a bravura one-man show off Broadway (“Mistakes Were Made”) and finished a season as a vividly conflicted character in a big cable series (HBO’s “Boardwalk Empire”), and his days of landing unnoticed are over. The table in front hangs out over the sidewalk, with a kind of proscenium above it, and passing Brooklynites couldn’t help but stare: Oh yeah, that guy, the big, scary one.

headline: The Smallest Dancers Steal Their Own Show
text: Something romantic about the 19th century made it a great era for artists to enter into the imaginations of children. Thanks to Tchaikovsky’s music  with its blend of fantasy, humor, suspense and vehemence, and its “Gulliver’s Travels”-type changes of scale between the miniature and the colossal  it’s not too much to place the “The Nutcracker” ballet among the many great 19th-century depictions of childhood. It takes company among E. T. A. Hoffmann’s original “Nutcracker” tale, “Jane Eyre,” “David Copperfield,” Hans Christian Andersen’s tales, “Huckleberry Finn,” the “Alice” books and the opera “Hänsel und Gretel.”

headline: Anatomy of a Scene: 'Blue Valentine'
text: Derek Cianfrance, the director of “Blue Valentine,” discusses a scene from the film which is on DVD May 10.

headline: A Marriage’s Death, and Post-Mortem
text: “BLUE VALENTINE,” the festival hit that played at Sundance and Cannes this year and made headlines when it received an NC-17 rating (since changed to an R), is not the first drama to toy with chronology in telling the story of a tumultuous relationship. Harold Pinter’s 1978 play “Betrayal” (filmed in 1983) depicts an adulterous affair from end to beginning. A couple of recent French domestic tragedies, Gaspar Noé’s “Irrevérsible” and François Ozon’s “5 x 2,” similarly chart a backward progression, from misery to bliss. Madcap love stories like “Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind” and “(500) Days of Summer” have also experimented with scrambled timelines.

headline: Where the Beers and the Jeers Flow Freely
text: New Year’s Eve 2008. My boyfriend and I are at our local bar in Brooklyn. He is drinking a pint of Smithwick’s, and I am nursing a Jameson, neat. I take small sips, and the bartender eyes me. Cheap date, I am.

headline: Refitting a Houseboat on the Nile
text: After living for years in the Egyptian countryside, the designer Michel Pastore bought and renovated a houseboat in Cairo.

headline: Y Yes? Y Not?
text: I’m going to what Jon Stewart says is the third holiest site of American Judaism tonight — doing Rachel Maddow from the 92nd St. Y. On around 9:15, they say.

headline: Schmoozing in the Service of an Oscar
text: On Monday night in a basement screening room in Midtown Manhattan, using little more than the allure of a free cocktail and a passing hors d’oeuvre, the Oscar-season force that is Harvey Weinstein gathered together a few potentially influential people for a screening of “The King’s Speech.” Kathleen Turner, Joel Grey and Bill Irwin turned up, as did the filmmaker Derek Cianfrance. Not two weeks before, Mr. Weinstein, who runs the Weinstein Company with his brother, Bob, had successfully petitioned the Motion Picture Association of America to change the rating for Mr. Cianfrance’s labor-of-love relationship film, “Blue Valentine,” from NC-17 to R. So there Mr. Cianfrance was, indebted, gamely chatting with all comers in the service of someone else’s moody drama.

headline: Shopping With Seth Box
text: The director of education for Moët Hennessy USA searched for Champagne-worthy glassware.

headline: With Common Application, Many Find a Technical Difficulty in Common, Too
text: The Common Application, the admission form accepted by more than 400 colleges and universities, was created in part to ease the burden on high school seniors. No longer must applicants fill out a dozen different forms to apply to a dozen schools, including the nation’s most selective.

headline: Memorable Moments of 2010: Sports
text: Thursday, 4:45 | Updated We hear you. Any collection of pictures that purports to show memorable moments in sports ought to include the World Series champions — yes, we can say it, the San Francisco Giants — and more than one photo from the World Cup. So here they are. Also, please be sure to see “2010: The Year in Pictures.”

headline: A Common Glitch in the Common Application
text: If you or your child has ever struggled with the “print preview” function of the Common Application — which sometimes reveals that a short-answer essay that appeared to fit as it was entered into the form  has now been cut off midsentence — you may want to look at an article just posted on The Times’s Web site.

headline: Restaurateur Ejects Los Angeles Times Critic
text: If you are an owner of a restaurant that keeps a critic waiting for a table, you could spend the rest of the night trying to make it all better. Or you could just throw the critic out on the street.

headline: Pocketable Cameras for Low Light
text: A new category of cameras can fit in a pocket, but still have sensors large enough to give sharp photos with good color, even in low light.

headline: Sizing a Sensor: No Easy Way
text: This week, you get two columns in one.

headline: After a Narrow Escape, Hou Retains Lead in Women’s World Championship Final
text: Hou Yifan narrowly avoided a loss against Ruan Lufei and leads her with one game to play in regulation.

headline: Delicious Desserts at Stockholm’s Cafes
text: IN London you can enjoy scones with jam and clotted cream in a genteel tearoom; in Paris, macarons on the Champs-Élysées; in Vienna, take your pick of tortes (Dobos, Sacher or linzer?) in some gilded grand cafe. But in Stockholm?

headline: Putting the Sweet in Swedish
text: A wave of new places is bringing some excitement to Stockholm’s cafe scene.

headline: White House Rallies Round National Intelligence Chief
text: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration scrambled on Wednesday to undo the damage from an ABC News clip that appeared to show that James R. Clapper Jr., the director of national intelligence, was clueless on Monday about terrorism arrests in Britain that had been a major news story for hours.

headline: New Tricks for an Old Dog of Hollywood
text: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif.

text: A JibJab video created by the Nets public relations department features bizarre "bonus footage" at the end of the video.

headline: True Gumption: The Making of a Best Seller
text: LOS ANGELES — Now it can be told.

headline: Tracing the Arc of a Tragic Folk Singer
text: IF Kenneth Bowser, a New York documentary filmmaker, succeeds in his crusade to rehabilitate the 1960s protest singer Phil Ochs, he’ll have his daughter to thank.

headline: Brown Leaves Early, This Time From Bobcats
text: Larry Brown’s stay with the Charlotte Bobcats ended much the same way his other jobs had  prematurely.

headline: Google Adds the Human Body to Its Search Functions
text: On Dec. 16, Google released the first version of its Body Browser, a simulation of the human body. Users can travel, as in the 1980s movie “Innerspace,” through various layers of human anatomy, zooming in on internal organs, navigating around bones and peeling back layers of the human body until all that’s left are the stringy tangles of the nervous system.

headline: Happy Holidays From the Nets, JibJab Style
text: The Jets weren’t the only team dealing with home video issues this week.

headline: While Choptank Dries Out, Spasso Prepares to Make a Splash
text: Timing is everything. Just ask Bobby Werhane. Choptank, his Maryland seafood restaurant on Bleecker Street, flooded last week. The restaurant is a double storefront and though only half of it was affected by the water gushing down from an upstairs apartment, his attempt to keep the dry half open ended after the health department said that the fruit flies gathering there would result in a C grade. So the whole thing is closed until mid-January.

headline: Theater Talkback: A Holiday Wish for Better Holiday Theater
text: Despite being described as “instantly forgettable” and “a theatrical lump of coal” by some critics, “Elf,” the adaptation of the Will Ferrell movie, has become a huge hit, grossing more than any show on Broadway last week except for “The Lion King” and “Wicked.” Audiences have also ignored the dismissive reviews for “Donny & Marie: A Broadway Christmas,” one of only a handful of shows that topped $1 million in weekly ticket sales.

headline: Life on a Houseboat Moored on the Nile
text: CAIRO

headline: Support for Israel’s Settlements From Europe’s Right
text: As my colleague Ethan Bronner reports, Israelis are divided over a West Bank settlement construction boom.

headline: 9/11 Payments Must Start Next Month, Judge Says
text: Just as the Senate passed a bill to cover the medical costs of 9/11 rescue and cleanup workers, a federal judge in Manhattan said on Wednesday that payments to a subset of those workers – the more than 10,000 plaintiffs who settled their lawsuits with the city last month — must start going out by late January.

headline: Trading Up: Jewelry for Men
text: It’s hard to find simple, discreet jewelry. Here are some examples and suggestions to help you start your search.

headline: In the Web of Jewelry for Men
text: WOMEN may have valid gripes with fashion and its narrow definition of an acceptable body image. But they can’t say they don’t have choices. In terms of style, professional men have their own corset to wrestle with, one with mere millimeters of wiggle room for lapel size, collar length, tie width and cuff length, and a palette drab enough to make a sparrow feel pavonine by comparison.

headline: Ready for the Golf Years, a Couple Holds an Estate Sale
text: Mimi and Bob Buzbee moved into a golf course community in Austin, Tex., two weeks ago but left many of their belongings in their old house across town. The couple hired a local estate sale organizer, Downsizing Estates, to sell the items for a 40 percent commission before the house closes at the end of this month.

headline: For Estate Sales, Boom Times
text: IT took a few years but Rachel Reeves of Long Beach, Calif., found the exact bedside tables she was searching for at an estate sale last month. Made in the 1950s from cherry wood, they had a colonial revival look, with tapered legs and carved ridges in the drawers. And at $20 for the pair, the price was right.

headline: My Own Private Wyoming
text: IN 1995 I bought a three-year-old log house in Centennial, a tiny southeastern Wyoming town on the slope of the Medicine Bow range in the Rockies. The setting was close to a national forest and exquisitely beautiful, with many miles of ideal mountain hiking, bicycling and ski trails. But the house was wrong for me. During the frustrating time that I lived in it, I wrote an article describing what I thought was my ideal house and began looking for property on which I could build. It took more than 10 years to find what I believed to be the right place.

headline: Pies on Earth
text: A holiday greeting by. R.O. Blechman

headline: A French Museum Inspires a Mexican Chair
text: Casamidy is based in San Miguel de Allende, a bastion of colonial Mexico, but many of the company’s furniture designs are drawn from other cultures. Its new Hiver Opera side chair is an example.

headline: A Designer Who Gives Christmas Trees an Afterlife
text: Many people feel a sense of regret when it comes time to dispose of a Christmas tree. After being decorated and celebrated, the tree is unceremoniously abandoned, which can seem both heartless and wasteful.

headline: Champagne Glasses
text: AS director of education for Moët Hennessy USA, Seth Box is responsible for spreading the word about his company’s spirits, wines and Champagnes — including Dom Pérignon, Krug, Veuve Clicquot, Moët et Chandon and Ruinart — to as many people as possible. Simply put: he regularly takes people out for drinks.

headline: This Lamp’s Wiring Is There for All to Enjoy
text: For its new Wire Nest lighting series, the Gold Leaf Design Group in Chicago has taken a mundane material — iron wire — and turned it into a focal point.

headline: Top Hat, an Imports Store, Opens in SoHo
text: Nina Allen, who imports intriguing oddities through her wholesale company Sweet Bella, seems happy not to be noticed. When she recently decided to open a store, she chose a charming block on Broome Street, between Ludlow and Orchard, that lacks the traffic of the SoHo blocks farther west.

headline: For the Hyper-Neat, a Special Strain Comes With the Season
text: THE only things that mess up the designer Mary McDonald’s exquisitely staged, picture-ready holiday parties are the guests.

headline: Sales at Room & Board, MoMA Design Store and Others
text: All porcelain animal busts are 50 percent off at Site, both in-store and online (the ram head, usually $250, is $125; the gazelle, pictured, usually $150, is $75); 35-11 34th Avenue (35th Street), Astoria, (718) 626-6030 or shopsiteonline.com.

headline: For City Fowl, a Coop to Cluck About
text: For urban farmers looking to retain some big-city sophistication, there is a New York-style solution for housing egg-laying birds: the Chicken Co-op ($3,500). Designed by James Ramsey of RAAD Studio in Manhattan, the three-story structure features stacked nesting rooms and floor-to-ceiling windows.

headline: A Dyed-and-True Imprint
text: IT is rare for fabric makers to get much buzz, let alone credit in fashion bibles like Vogue and Lucky magazines. But Audrey Louise Reynolds, a 27-year-old self-taught designer who lives in Brooklyn, has emerged as the fashion world’s artisanal fabric dyer.

headline: Tech Talk Podcast: Hacker Attacks
text: Hacker attacks are nothing new, but several popular Web sites have been targets in the past few weeks. Bettina Edelstein discusses the recent security scrambles with Brian Stelter, the New York Times reporter who covered the security breach at Gawker Media this month.

headline: 12 Days of Christmas Gifts Cost 9.2% More This Year
text: Even those with a big year-end bonus may think twice about showering a loved one this year with the fanciful mix of piping pipers, leaping lords and assorted birds lauded in choruses of the classic carol “The 12 Days of Christmas.”

headline: Renewed Interest in Converting Natural Gas Into Diesel
text: WASHINGTON  Diesel and jet fuel are usually made from crude oil. But with oil prices rising even as a glut of natural gas keeps prices for that fuel extraordinarily cheap, a bit of expensive alchemy is suddenly starting to look financially appealing: turning natural gas into liquid fuels.

headline: Beauty Spots
text: BUFF AND BUBBLY Harried Upper West Siders looking to set down their shopping bags for a manicure should consider Polished Beauty Bar (polishedbb.com), an eco-friendly nail salon on West 78th Street between Broadway and West End Avenue. Polished is offering a free glass of Champagne for every festive color chosen from its 300-shade, nontoxic Zoya collection (no formaldehyde, toluene or DBP — dibutyl phthalate) through Dec. 31. Monday to Wednesday, receive a free manicure with every pedicure (a $43 value for $30, plus tax and tip).

headline: Palmer Trading Company: A Twice-Told Tale
text: July 1, 1974

headline: European Deal Makers Place Hopes in Emerging Markets
text: LONDON — Investment bankers advising on mergers and acquisitions from their offices in London are counting on business from China, India and other developing economies to make 2011 a busy year for European takeovers.

headline: Multiplying Drivers Run Over Beijing Traffic Plan
text: BEIJING  Here is the plan unwrapped last week by Beijing’s city fathers to tackle the city’s suffocating traffic:

headline: If You Love My Hair That Much, Mom, Take It
text: KAZ CARTER-McGINTY was in the barber’s chair (a red one with a steering wheel) for the first time in his life on a recent Saturday morning. He is 2. Kaz’s hair, light brown and silky straight, fell almost to his shoulders in the back. The bangs in front had previously been cut by his mother, Miko McGinty, who now stood, camera in hand, giving instructions that are a familiar refrain to stylists at the shop, LuLu’s Cuts & Toys in Park Slope:

headline: Iran Stops Fuel Delivery, Afghanistan Says, and Prices Are Rising
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  Government officials expressed alarm on Wednesday about what they described as Iran’s unexplained ban on fuel exports to Afghanistan, asserting that at least 1,400 loaded tankers were parked on Iran’s side of three border crossings.

headline: Where the Pension Checks Stopped
text: The town of Prichard, Ala., was warned for years that its pension fund was dangerously underfunded. Eventually the inevitable happened. In 2009, the fund ran out of money. The pension checks stopped, leaving retirees struggling to stay afloat.

headline: Vote Hurts Obama’s Push to Empty Cuba Prison
text: WASHINGTON  Congress voted Wednesday to impose strict new limits on transferring detainees out of the Guantánamo Bay prison, dealing a major blow to President Obama’s vows to shut down the center and give federal court trials to many of the prisoners.

headline: Helping Arts Groups Realize Grand Plans
text: When ballet companies need new stages for their ballerinas to jeté on, and opera companies need new theaters where their Valkyries can sing, Willem Brans is their go-to man. For more than three decades Mr. Brans, 61, vice president of the Los Angeles-based Arts Consulting Group, has helped conceive and plan new concert halls and raise funds for dozens of performing arts organizations and museums. A former English teacher and journalist, he got into arts management in 1979, as marketing manager for the Dallas Ballet. He lives with his wife, Jo, on the Upper East Side.

headline: A New Chance for Bipartisanship, All Posturing Aside
text: WASHINGTON  Despite a flurry of bipartisan votes, the 111th Congress closed out its run this week with a new round of partisan recrimination. Deposed House Democrats forced a series of votes before their gavels could be pried from their hands, while Republican leaders fumed over the last-minute lawmaking and darkly hinted at revenge. If the Capitol had a caption, it would read: “To be continued. ...”

headline: Ex-Banker for UBS Pleads Guilty in Tax Case
text: A former UBS private banker pleaded guilty on Wednesday to helping wealthy American clients evade taxes through hidden Swiss accounts, an admission obtained in part by prosecutors’ secret recording of a meeting between the banker and an important client.

headline: Christmas in the West
text: When I was old enough to drive I loaded up the little car that my dad got for the price of a lawn mower with some of the most durable of food staples and took them to my high school so I could feel good about the holidays. This was the annual Christmas Food Drive, our chance to give something back to the community, or as the more liberal Jesuits put it, “to commit an act of social justice.”

headline: After Bruising Session, Congress Braces for More
text: WASHINGTON  The 111th Congress ended as it began two years ago, with a burst of legislative productivity, as Democrats forced through a historic social change by lifting the ban on gay men and lesbians serving openly in the military and a major foreign policy achievement in approving the New Start arms control treaty with Russia.

headline: Cal’s Varsity Squad Emerges From a Scrum Only as a Club Team
text: When the United States team arrives in New Zealand for rugby’s World Cup next September, it is likely that several of its members will be past or present players from the University of California, Berkeley.

headline: Alabama Town’s Failed Pension Is a Warning
text: PRICHARD, Ala.  This struggling small city on the outskirts of Mobile was warned for years that if it did nothing, its pension fund would run out of money by 2009. Right on schedule, its fund ran dry.

headline: Span: A Remembrance
text: for Hal Sheets

headline: Senate Passes 9/11 Health Bill as Republicans Back Down
text: WASHINGTON  After years of fierce lobbying and debate, Congress approved a bill on Wednesday to cover the cost of medical care for rescue workers and others who became sick from toxic fumes, dust and smoke after the 2001 attack on the World Trade Center.

headline: ‘Spider-Man’ Shows Are Canceled to Test a New Safety Plan
text: The Broadway musical “Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark” canceled its two Wednesday performances to test a new safety plan for the show’s 38 aerial and stage maneuvers, which involve actors hoisted or tethered in harnesses, including the maneuver that failed at Monday night’s performance when a stunt actor fell more than 20 feet and broke his ribs.

headline: Home-Stretch Buying Lifts Merchants’ Spirits
text: The last-minute holiday surge is heralding the return of the American consumer, who is shedding the recession’s thrifty ways and rediscovering the pleasure of shopping.

headline: Video of Man Walking With Suitcase
text: The police say this suitcase is the one the victim was found in.

headline: Fear and Doubt in Cleveland
text: Lucy Bagby was cautiously hopeful on Election Day in 1860. A pretty, 28-year-old fugitive slave from Virginia, and pregnant with her first child, she lived in Cleveland, a hotbed of abolition sentiment, and worked as a maid for a Republican politician.

headline: For the President, a Moment to Reflect, and Then to Depart
text: WASHINGTON  President Obama on Wednesday made note of his setbacks as well as his victories in the surprisingly productive lame-duck Congress, and served notice that he would resume the fights on immigration, spending priorities and more when the new Congress with its Republican reinforcements convenes in January.

headline: Rex Ryan and Jets Encounter Unusual Distraction
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  Once again on a Wednesday afternoon in this strange Jets season, Coach Rex Ryan took his customary position behind the lectern and spent time answering questions that had nothing to do with football.

headline: Collecting Humiliations of Life to Sell Comfort in Shoes
text: ERIC saw a co-worker who normally wore pants wearing a dress one day, and jokingly asked her who died, to which she replied, “My grandmother.”

headline: Medical Schools in Region Fight Caribbean Flow
text: For a generation, medical schools in the Caribbean have attracted thousands of American students to their tiny island havens by promising that during their third and fourth years, the students would get crucial training in United States hospitals, especially in New York State.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Gillibrand Gains Foothold With Victory on 9/11 Aid
text: The spotlight was shining on her at last, and Kirsten E. Gillibrand, the oft-overshadowed junior senator from New York, did not hold back.

headline: Unruly Streets: Cyclists and the City
text: To the Editor:

headline: Census Impact on 2012 Presidential Race is Limited
text: Under the new allocation of electoral votes that will go into effect in 2012 as a result of this year’s Census, President Obama would have won 6 fewer electoral votes than he did in 2008, gaining 2 in Florida and 1 in each of Washington and Nevada, but losing 2 in both Ohio and New York, and 1 in New Jersey, Pennsylvania, Illinois, Iowa, Michigan and Massachusetts.

headline: Popularity of Juniors Tournament Crosses Border
text: Jack Carlson and Derek Stepan, 19-year-old Americans, flew across Canada’s blue line on a two-on-one break in overtime of the world junior tournament title game in Saskatoon, Saskatchewan, in January. Carlson shot and scored, giving the United States a 6-5 victory and its second world junior gold medal, breaking a streak of five titles by Canada.

headline: Biopsy Shows Yale Player’s Cancer Is Back
text: Mandi Schwartz, the Yale hockey player whose fight with leukemia has drawn two years of prayers in hockey circles and beyond, learned last week that her cancer had returned.

headline: Eisenhower’s Advice
text: To the Editor:

headline: Alternatives to Berlusconi?
text: To the Editor:

headline: Parents of Student Who Committed Suicide Tell Rutgers University They May Sue
text: The parents of a Rutgers University freshman who committed suicide after his intimate encounter with another man was secretly captured and streamed live on the Internet have filed notices that they may sue the university.

headline: The U.N. and the Mideast
text: To the Editor:

headline: Thursday: “Fish”
text: THURSDAY’S PUZZLE — Never look things up, that’s my advice. (Some of the most passionate e-mail I receive on the subject of “obvious errors” comes from deeply offended readers who already live by this adage.) I liked knowing that George Bernard Shaw invented the GHOTI story. I’ve quoted him. I admire Shaw’s plays and loved reading The Perfect Wagnerite. My grandfather who worked for a while as a bobby in London used to listen to Shaw’s rants at Speakers’ Corner in Hyde Park. (He was not impressed by “that grubby little communist.”) Shaw’s plays are as fun to read as they are to watch. There’s usually a long commentary at the beginning, sometimes longer than the play itself.

headline: Ligety Sets Sights on World Cup Overall Title
text: Ted Ligety jumped to the top of the men’s World Cup standings by winning his third consecutive giant slalom last Sunday in Alta Badia, Italy. By early Tuesday morning he was back at his home mountain in snowy Park City, Utah, merely another local in the lift line waiting to get dibs on a colossal dump of fresh snow.

headline: Rep. Patrick Kennedy’s Legacy on Mental Health
text: To the Editor:

headline: Cuomo Names Aide and Veteran New York City Officer to Lead the State Police
text: Governor-elect Andrew M. Cuomo has selected the chief investigator in his attorney general’s office to head the New York State Police, an agency that in recent years has been implicated in repeated efforts by governors and other elected officials to embarrass foes and protect insiders.

headline: Penguins Ride Crosby’s Goal to Win
text: PENGUINS 5, PANTHERS 2 Sidney Crosby matched the second-longest N.H.L. scoring streak in 18 years at 22 games with his first-period goal and Pittsburgh won at home.

headline: Golf Courses: A Gold Mine for Lawsuits
text: Clearly, the good doctor meant no harm. It was just an ordinary afternoon of golf when his ball hooked distressingly off line, hitting another golfer in the eye. Cue the lawyers.

headline: Failing Eyesight, on Top of Other Disabilities, Is Faced Without Complaint
text: Arva Mason is not one to complain. She has been nearly deaf since birth. But since her arrival in the United States from her native Panama in 1984 to be with her mother and siblings, she has silently worked sorting, packaging and assembling products for Brooklyn businesses.

headline: Documents Raise Questions About Russian Case
text: MOSCOW  More than a year after Sergei L. Magnitsky died in a Moscow pretrial detention center, no suspects or arrests have been announced, and authorities have said that they believe neither his medical treatment nor the police officials involved in his prosecution played any role in his death.

headline: After Russian Death, Inquiry Doors Open and Shut
text: MOSCOW — It was more than a year ago when six members of an obscure oversight panel filed into Butyrskaya Prison to look into the death of a prisoner.

headline: Notable Puzzle Achievements of 2010
text: Each year, I collect a list of interesting observations from XWord Info. It’s time to celebrate the Notable Achievements in Crosswords for 2010 and reveal my choice for Puzzle of the Year. (Hint: It was published on the Sunday closest to June 14.)

headline: Concussion Fears Fail to Discourage Packers’ Rodgers
text: The best way to understand Green Bay Packers quarterback Aaron Rodgers’s attitude as he returns Sunday from his second concussion since October may be to look at the play on which he was injured.

headline: American Lobbyists Work for Ivorian Leader
text: WASHINGTON — As the United States continued to push for President Laurent Gbagbo of Ivory Coast to step down, two former Clinton administration officials were trying to present Mr. Gbagbo, who has clung to power despite international condemnation, in a more sympathetic light.

headline: Judge Criticizes Stop-and-Frisk Police Tactics in Housing Projects
text: A Manhattan judge criticized the policing tactics in New York City Housing Authority developments, ruling on Tuesday that officers appeared to be routinely flouting the law by questioning people without legal justification.

headline: Stoudemire and Knicks Rise Up, and the Garden Roars
text: They had watched Paul Pierce take a victory lap and LeBron James take whatever he wanted, and finally the Knicks had seen enough. They took their stand Wednesday night, in the paint and at the rim, and reclaimed Madison Square Garden for themselves.

headline: For Fight at Lambeau, Giants’ Gloves Are On
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Tom Coughlin’s cheeks always provide a gauge of winter, turning crimson as temperatures drop and winds whip. That was never truer than during the N.F.C. Championship Game in Green Bay on Jan. 20, 2008.

headline: Under ‘High-Tech House Arrest,’ WikiLeaks Founder Takes the Offensive
text: BUNGAY, England —When Julian Assange wakes these days, he looks out from a three-story Georgian mansion house overlooking a man-made lake paddled by ducks. Under a blanket of snow, the 650-acre Ellingham Hall estate, a mile back from the closest public road, is as tranquil a spot as can be found in eastern England.

headline: Enzo Bearzot, Who Coached Italy to Cup Title, Dies at 83
text: Enzo Bearzot, who as coach of Italy’s national soccer team in the 1970s and ’80s restored it to a place among the world’s elite teams, winning the World Cup in 1982, died Tuesday in Milan. He was 83.

headline: Obama’s Gamble on Arms Pact Pays Off
text: WASHINGTON  The final approval of a new arms control treaty with Russia may have been a foregone conclusion by the time senators stepped onto the floor on Wednesday. But that was not the way it looked one afternoon last month when White House officials rushed to the Oval Office to tell President Obama that his treaty might be dead.

headline: St. John’s Women Start With 10, Finish With 4
text: The St. John’s women’s basketball coach, Kim Barnes Arico, called her players into a huddle late in a game last weekend. With 2 minutes 13 seconds left and the Red Storm beating Southern Mississippi by 34 points, she instructed her players not to worry about scoring  just run down the clock.

headline: Behind Census Figures Showing Boom in Nevada, a Story of Bust
text: HENDERSON, Nev.  By any measure, it should have been a cause for celebration in a place that surely needs one. The Census Bureau reported that Nevada grew by 35 percent over the last decade, making it the fastest-growing state in the nation.

headline: Sliding Into Second, Even in Winter
text: CLEVELAND  There were no vendors wandering the aisles, no players warming up on a sun-drenched field, no shirtless bleacher faithful.

headline: Temple Lands Florida Assistant
text: Temple will name Steve Addazio as its coach Thursday, according to a person with knowledge of the situation. Addazio, the offensive coordinator at Florida, has agreed to a five-year deal and will be introduced at an on-campus news conference. The person was not authorized to speak about the deal before Addazio’s official introduction.

headline: Museums Should Dig In
text: Rome

headline: Michigan’s Decade of Tarnish Seen in Census Report
text: CONSTANTINE, Mich.  While every other state in the nation gained population over the past decade, Michigan shrank. And yet, as word seeped across frozen towns like this one on Wednesday, almost no one seemed even mildly surprised. This was, many here said with resignation, just one last, official confirmation of Michigan’s long, grim and gloomy slide.

headline: Lame Ducks Triumphant
text: Wow, we’re getting a new nuclear arms control treaty for Christmas. I know some of you were hoping for iPads. But still, big news.

headline: E.P.A. Challenges Texas Over Rules on Emissions
text: HOUSTON  The feud between Texas and the Environmental Protection Agency reached a new level this week, with federal officials saying that they will take over the granting of permits for new power plants and refineries in the state because Texas refuses to regulate its emissions of greenhouse gases.

headline: Memorable Moments of 2010: Arts
text: These images complement “2010: The Year in Pictures.”

headline: Corrections
text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: Word of the Day | acclimate
text: acclimate •\ˈa-klə-ˌmat; ə-ˈkli-mət, -ˌmat\• verb

headline: The Senate Surmounts Politics
text: Wednesday was not a good day for Senator Mitch McConnell’s single-minded project to make Barack Obama a one-term president. Over the minority leader’s objections, 13 Republicans joined every Democratic senator to ratify the New Start nuclear arms treaty with Russia, reducing the size of the countries’ nuclear stockpiles and making the world a safer place. The 71-to-26 vote was the capstone to what now shapes up to be a remarkably successful legislative agenda for President Obama’s first two years.

headline: Montana Jurors Raise Hopes of Marijuana Advocates
text: Marijuana fans are calling it the Mutiny in Montana.

headline: A Matter of Life or Death
text: St. Joseph’s Hospital and Medical Center in Phoenix announced on Tuesday that it will continue to provide life-saving abortion care to patients even though it means losing its affiliation with the local Roman Catholic Diocese.

headline: Survival of Ethics Oversight
text: The House’s incoming Republican majority has wisely concluded the quasi-independent Office of Congressional Ethics better not be dismantled. When they were the minority, Republicans fiercely opposed the creation of the office by Speaker Nancy Pelosi as an oversight tool to bolster the notoriously feeble job done by the members’ own ethics committee.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,426 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American this week:

headline: Oh, Spider-Man!
text: The theatrical extravaganza called “Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark”  currently in previews at the Foxwoods Theater on 42nd Street  has already set one Broadway record. At $65 million, it is the most expensive production ever. It is also likely to have the longest run of previews, eclipsing what is believed to be the record, 71, held by “Nick & Nora,” which was a flop.

headline: James Mann, 90, Dies; Worked on Nixon Impeachment
text: James R. Mann, a South Carolina congressman who played a critical role in drafting the articles of impeachment against Richard M. Nixon and emerged as one of the South’s most eloquent voices on the matter, died Monday in Greenville, S.C. He was 90.

headline: Georgia: Immigrants Found in Truck
text: Six illegal immigrants were discovered in a truck headed for a cargo facility near the Atlanta airport Tuesday night, but they are not suspected of plotting to do any harm, federal authorities said. The men, who were hired to lay carpet at the facility, could not provide proof of legal residency during a routine inspection. They may face deportation, according to the Immigration and Customs Enforcement department. They did not have access to secure areas of the airport, authorities said.

headline: Alaska: Court Ruling Favors Murkowski
text: Joe Miller, the Republican Senate candidate, lost another legal battle when the State Supreme Court ruled Wednesday that voters do not have to spell a write-in candidate’s name perfectly for their vote to be counted. Citing decades of legal precedent, the court ruled that votes should count as long as election officials can determine a voter’s intent. The court also ruled that there was no evidence of fraud or other irregularities in the election. Unofficial state election results show Mr. Miller losing by more than 10,000 votes to Senator Lisa Murkowski, whom he defeated in the Republican primary in August. Ms. Murkowski later returned to the race as a write-in candidate. She declared victory on Nov. 17, after a hand count of write-in votes showed her well ahead. Mr. Miller has not conceded, and he has prevented certification of the race through repeated legal challenges in state and federal court.

headline: Winter Wonderlands
text: The Cleveland Indians have created an enormous winter playground in an effort to get more use, and revenue, out of what would otherwise be a dormant facility. The Indians are not the only ones widening the parameters.

headline: Doctor Arrested in Whistle-Blowing Case
text: Texas officials have filed criminal charges against a West Texas physician over accusations that they say he orchestrated against two nurses who had filed a complaint against him with the state medical board.

headline: Russia: Spying Suspect Joins the Party
text: Anna Chapman, one of the Russians arrested in the spy scandal over the summer in the United States, on Wednesday joined the youth wing of Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putin’s governing party. Ms. Chapman attended a party conference, where she made a short, upbeat speech. She did not describe her political ambitions. “There would be less negativity in society if we each woke up with a smile,” she said. Ms. Chapman, 28, attracted the most attention of those in the spy ring, and since her return to Russia, has continued to enjoy the spotlight. She posed in lingerie for a Russian men’s magazine, and her public appearances are regularly featured in the Russia media.

headline: Iran’s New Foreign Minister Appears in Istanbul
text: Ali Akbar Salehi made his first international appearance as Iran’s foreign minister on Wednesday at an economic summit meeting in Istanbul. Mr. Salehi, a former head of the Iranian Atomic Energy Council, was named to replace Manouchehr Mottaki last week in a surprise move by President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad of Iran, who also attended the Istanbul meeting. Mr. Salehi reiterated his trust in Turkey’s diplomatic efforts to help find a resolution in coming talks over Iran’s nuclear program between Iranian officials and the five permanent members of the United Nations Security Council  the United States, Britain, France, Russia and China, as well as Germany. Turkey is hosting the meeting. When Mr. Salehi was named to the new post, some Iran observers speculated that Mr. Ahmadinejad might try to replace him with a permanent candidate from his inner circle.

headline: Argentina: Ex-Dictator Sentenced in Murders
text: Jorge Videla, a former Argentine dictator, was sentenced to life in prison on Wednesday in the murder of 31 political prisoners who were killed after the 1976 coup that swept him into power. Mr. Videla, 85, is considered to have been the main force behind the violence known as the dirty war that included the forced disappearances of up to an estimated 30,000 people through 1983. In April, Argentina’s Supreme Court overturned a 1990 pardon for Mr. Videla and other military men involved in the dictatorship, paving the way for him to be tried for murder, kidnapping and torture, in the case that led to Wednesday’s sentence. He was sentenced to life in prison in 1985 after another trial, in which he was convicted of murder, torture and other crimes. On Tuesday Mr. Videla told the court that “yesterday’s enemies are in power and from there, they are trying to establish a Marxist regime.”

headline: Iraq: Safety Concerns Mute Christmas Celebrations
text: Christian congregations across Iraq canceled or toned down Christmas celebrations in the wake of several attacks, including a bloody siege on a Catholic church in Baghdad in late October, and recent threats against the country’s dwindling Christian minority. Louis Sako, the Chaldean Catholic archbishop of Kirkuk, said Wednesday that threats from the Islamic State of Iraq, an iteration of Al Qaeda in Mesopotamia, had forced the cancellation of all observances and festivities apart from Christmas prayers, which were being moved to the morning because of safety concerns. In the southern city of Basra, home to about 2,000 Christians, church leaders said they had canceled a New Year’s Eve celebration. Since the assault on the Baghdad church, a new wave of Christians has been fleeing to northern Iraq or abroad.

headline: Take a Spin on the Frozen Mile
text: As soon as Manager Manny Acta heard about the Indians’ plans to construct a winter playground at Progressive Field during the off-season, he knew he had to be a part of it.

headline: News Quiz | December 23, 2010
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper.

headline: Computers That Trade on the News
text: The number-crunchers on Wall Street are starting to crunch something else: the news.

headline: Fred Foy, ‘Lone Ranger’ Announcer, Dies at 89
text: A fiery horse with the speed of light, a cloud of dust and a hearty Hi-Yo, Silver! ...

headline: Bloggingheads: The Age of Facebook
text: Lev Grossman, left, of Time and Jose Antonio Vargas of The Huffington Post discuss the effect of Facebook.

headline: Daily Lexeme: Esurine

headline: Emanuel Off and Running for Mayor of Chicago

A hearing officer had just recommended that Mr. Emanuel’s name be allowed on the city ballot in February, over objections that he had given up his Chicago residency  and his right to run  when he served as President Obama’s chief of staff in Washington.

headline: The Nutcracker Chronicles: Vegas but No Showgirls

In what’s said to be Las Vegas’s quiet season, this is one of the busy days. In the vast pool in front of the Bellagio, hundreds of fountains are dancing like Rockettes to the “Hallelujah” chorus.

text: From the Things We Didn’t Know Could Fill a Book files: Joel and Ethan Coen‘s 2010 remake of “True Grit” may have moviegoers’ attention this weekend and some formidable awards-season buzz. But it will never have one element unique to its 1969 predecessor: a theme song performed by Glen Campbell, the premier balladeer of Kansas technicians and lily-livered men with geographical fixations, and who also played the Texas Ranger La Boeuf in Henry Hathaway’s “True Grit” film.

headline: More Last-Minute Gifts: Videos and Movies
text: In an earlier post I suggested digital music from iTunes as a last-minute gift. Apple’s iTunes store also lets you give movies, along with complete seasons and individual episodes of TV shows, which arrive in an e-mail with a link to redeem. Unfortunately season passes of upcoming episodes can’t be granted, and buying a show’s entire previous season can get pricey ($20 and up) when in reality it’ll probably only be watched once.

headline: Home Sales Struggled Again in November
text: As analysts try to gauge the pace of the economic recovery, they inevitably take the pulse of the housing and job markets. And despite some upbeat trends like stronger retail sales and new reports that showed increases in personal spending, sales of new homes remained at historically low levels last month and the job market showed little sign of momentum.

A suspicious package found at the Ukrainian embassy in the city, was determined not to contain explosives, the Italian news agency ANSA reported.

headline: C.I.A. Secrets Could Surface in Swiss Nuclear Case

Each poem is introduced briefly by Ted Kooser, a former United States poet laureate.

headline: Seeing Things | Season’s Seatings
text: Although it’s lovely to have a fresh Christmas tree, the sight of all those bedraggled branches left at the curb in January is nothing short of depressing. But in London this season, there’s an alternative to the wood chipper: the Christmas Tree Project, a collaboration between Gallery Libby Sellers and the up-and-coming designer Fabien Cappello. The project is an extension of Cappello’s 2009 graduation work at the Royal College of Art, and will recycle spruces, pines and firs into unique, handcrafted three-legged stools designed by Cappello. The stools, which cost about $621 each, can be ordered from the United States too. Obviously, a buyer from the States won’t be able to send in a tree to be recycled, but there will be plenty of “orphans” available in London, where it’s estimated that most of this year’s 976,000 Christmas trees will simply be thrown away. And not only will the trees get new lives; the Woodland Trust, a leading conservation organization in Britain, will get a portion of the profits.

headline: Behind the Scenes: 'The Illusionist'

headline: Patient 1, Society 0
text: A young, healthy patient called me recently requesting a CT scan of his head because of his headaches. He described his symptoms, and they sounded to me like migraines. His clinical picture was not suggestive of a brain tumor and I told him so, but he was persistent. “What if I’m the one 35-year-old who drops dead of a brain tumor while you try to figure out what’s wrong?” he asked.

headline: One Camera in Plain Sight, and One Hidden
text: Sometime next month, in a limited number of cases, the New York Police Department will begin videotaping interrogations. Investigators will be able to use cameras to videotape suspects as part of a pilot program in two precincts: The 67th Precinct in Brooklyn and the 48th Precinct in the Bronx, a police official said.

headline: Brian Hanrahan, BBC Reporter, Dies at 61
text: LONDON  Brian Hanrahan, a veteran BBC reporter who was responsible for one of British war reporting’s most celebrated moments, aboard an aircraft carrier off the Falklands in 1982, died here on Monday. He was 61.

headline: Driving Miss Daisy All the Way to the Bank
text: The week before Christmas is usually news-free on Broadway, so the announcement on Tuesday from the producers of “Driving Miss Daisy” — that the Vanessa Redgrave-James Earl Jones-Boyd Gaines hit had become the first play of the season to turn a profit — normally would have rated as the Rialto’s story-of-the-day. But a certain other show has been generating more news and attention than any Broadway production in many years; even if the “Daisy” folks put wires on Ms. Redgrave and sent her flying above the audience, it still would’ve been hard to break through the press coverage over at the Foxwoods Theater this week. (Anyway, Ms. Redgrave flies just fine with her feet on the ground, thank you.)

headline: Beyond Twitter: What’s Next for Designers in 2011
text: In the midst of the recession, designers could actually help their hard-hit businesses by focusing on e-commerce and social network connections. The ones who did that are looking pretty smart right now, because there are even more new ideas to try in 2011.

headline: Larry Brown’s Departure
text: There is something comforting about a day in which the biggest news hardly seems like news at all. Larry Brown resigning from an N.B.A. team (or being fired, or mysteriously finding the locks changed on his office door) falls into the category of the sun rising in the morning or snow falling in winter. You may need to be reminded which team changed those locks this time (Charlotte) and how many N.B.A. teams remain that haven’t fired him (very few), but be assured that you have plenty of company in your complete lack of surprise.

headline: Pakistan Spy Chief to Ignore U.S. Summons

headline: A Candid Conversation With Julianne Moore
text: For a recent Times Talk event, the Bagger had an opportunity to chat with Julianne Moore about “The Kids Are All Right,” her start as a soap opera actress and why she loves working in indie films. She was charming, funny and forthright, and we’re not just saying that as one redhead to another. Here, the actress discusses why she doesn’t like to over-prepare for movie moments, the reality of filming a sex scene, and how she managed not to look at Mark Ruffalo when she was in bed with him in “Kids.”

headline: Lotus Family Speaks
text: In the dispute between two teams over the use of the Lotus name next season, the family of Colin Chapman, the founder of Lotus, made a statement Thursday to say that it backed the Lotus Renault GP team’s use of the Lotus name. But it said that no team in the series could reflect the historical “Team Lotus,” indicating its disapproval of last year’s Lotus Racing team now using the name “Team Lotus.”

text: Last season, the Charlotte Bobcats posted the best record in franchise history, had the league’s top defense, and made their first-ever playoff appearance. They were better on the court than any of their Bobcat predecessors, and yet everything built in Charlotte was doomed to crumble.

headline: Going Out on a Limb With a Koto and an Oud
text: The Rubin Museum of Art is devoted to the art of the Himalayas and South Asia, but its healthy list of classical and popular music programs is not required to reflect that mission. Even the museum’s world-music series, Spiral Music  so named because it takes place at the foot of a large spiral staircase  ranges freely around the globe, often mixing the sounds of far-flung cultures.

headline: A Rock Star and His Cartoonist Alter Ego
text: MY CHEMICAL ROMANCE is a cartoony kind of band, and that suits the frontman, Gerard Way. Since the group  including the guitarists Ray Toro and Frank Iero and Mr. Way’s younger brother, the bassist Mikey Way  formed in 2001, it has developed a glam-emo aesthetic that seems sprung from a dark and glossy comic book. Its new album, “Danger Days: The True Lives of the Fabulous Killjoys” (Reprise), is full of anthemic tracks that imagine a postapocalyptic future. Gerard Way, 33, created “Umbrella Academy,” a comic book published by Dark Horse about a family of atypical superheroes. Melena Ryzik spoke by phone with Mr. Way at a tour stop in Detroit about discovering his favorite album of the year, “Treats,” by the Brooklyn band Sleigh Bells, and how he was influenced by Brit pop growing up in New Jersey. “At the time, everything in America was so macho,” he said. “The British stuff was the opposite of macho. I heard the Smiths, and that really changed everything for me.” This is an edited version of their conversation.

headline: A New Roof That Works for a Living
text: THERE are green roofs, and then there are green roofs.

headline: Chic in Review | Kate Moss’s School for Scandal?
