headline: Abercrombie’s Ohio Express
text: This is the time of year when news is announced in the hope that no one will notice. You can’t help but think that this was Abercrombie & Fitch’s intention with its filing on Wednesday.

headline: 36 Hours in Marrakesh, Morocco
text: IN 1939, George Orwell wrote of Westerners flocking to Marrakesh in search of “camels, castles, palm-trees, Foreign Legionnaires, brass trays and bandits.” Ever since, the city has been ravishing visitors with its teeming souks, ornate palaces and sybaritic night life. In recent years, a succession of high-end openings and restorations — most notably, the lavish reopening of the hotel La Mamounia — has transformed the city into an obligatory stop for jet-setters. Yet despite Marrakesh’s new cachet, the true treasures of the enigmatic city still hide down dusty side streets and behind sagging storefronts.

headline: A Weekend in Marrakesh
text: Despite the city’s new cachet, its true treasures still hide down dusty side streets and behind sagging storefronts.

headline: The Drama Queen of the Lower East Side
text: IN 1915 Alice and Irene Lewisohn built the Neighborhood Playhouse at 466 Grand Street, seeking to bring high culture to the immigrants crammed into the tenements of the Lower East Side. The prim little Georgian-style structure is in near-mint condition, but not everything has remained the same.

headline: Mina Guiahi and Jesse Levinson
text: FOR MANY COUPLES, the season between Christmas and Valentine’s Day is fraught with drama, because holidays have a way of bringing underlying tensions to the surface.

headline: Los Angeles Museum to Oversee Watts Towers
text: The Los Angeles County Museum of Art said on Thursday that it had completed an agreement with the City of Los Angeles that puts the museum in charge of efforts to repair and preserve the Watts Towers, the cathedral-like spires and crockery-encrusted forms built by the self-taught artist Simon Rodia in his spare time over more than three decades. The towers, which were once almost demolished by the city and then later designated a national landmark, were damaged slightly in the 1994 earthquake and again during a 2008 windstorm.

headline: Los Angeles Museum to Oversee Watts Towers
text: The Los Angeles County Museum of Art said on Thursday that it had completed an agreement with the City of Los Angeles that puts the museum in charge of efforts to repair and preserve the Watts Towers, the cathedral-like spires and crockery-encrusted forms built by the self-taught artist Simon Rodia in his spare time over more than three decades. The towers, which were once almost demolished by the city and then later designated a national landmark, were damaged slightly in the 1994 earthquake and again during a 2008 windstorm.

headline: Canadians Prefer the Mustang Over the Home-Grown Camaro
text: OTTAWA — The decision by General Motors to manufacture the Camaro in Oshawa, Ontario, was widely hailed in Canada as a coup for the country’s auto industry. But it seems that patriotism matters for little in Canadian showrooms.

headline: Consultant Pleads Guilty in Insider Trading
text: 7:49 p.m. | Updated A crucial cooperating witness in the most recent round of arrests stemming from the federal government’s insider trading investigation pleaded guilty this month, according to court documents unsealed on Thursday.

headline: Extremist in Monastery Is Still One Outside It
text: Bruno Dumont’s austere, grimly luminous film “Hadewijch” takes its title from the name of a 13th-century poet, Hadewijch of Antwerp, whose work “The Paradoxes of Love” describes the agony and ecstasy of her 21st-century French namesake. A virginal 20-year-old theology student who is first seen in a monastery where she is preparing to take her vows, Hadewijch, as she is called by the nuns, spends much of her time on her knees, praying before a cross on the wall above her bunk bed in a bare, cell-like room.

headline: In Westchester, Mixed Progress on Affordable Housing
text: MORE than a year after Westchester County settled a federal lawsuit with a promise to create 750 below-market-rate homes in wealthy, predominantly white communities, at least one element of a housing plan is moving ahead.

headline: From Bollywood: Making a Movie to Cover Up a Crime
text: Goofy is as goofy does in Farah Khan’s “Tees Maar Khan,” a Bollywood farce that overdoes the zaniness in frantic high style. Tees Maar Khan (Akshay Kumar) is, we’re told, “India’s sharpest criminal mastermind.” That seems to mean that he can pick locks, escape bumbling cops and cue his goon squad — Dollar, Soda and Burger — to scream in unison: “Tees Maar Khan!”

headline: One Dean’s Perspective on the Common Application
text: Bruce Poch, who has worked at institutions that accept the Common Application since its inception in the mid-1970s, was appointed dean of admissions at Pomona College in Claremont, Calif., in 1987. Since 1995, he has served as the college’s vice president and dean of admissions, a position he will leave at the end of December.

headline: A String of Bulbs Was Our Guiding Star
text: WE never expected that we would want to be anywhere but in Denver for Christmas. But that year, when our first child arrived in August, my wife and I knew we had to go to California and show him off to my parents, brothers, and sisters, all of whom had long despaired that we would ever start a family.

headline: Cyrus Izzo
text: Mr. Izzo, 45, is a co-president of the Syska Hennessy Group, a consulting and engineering company with headquarters in New York.

headline: The Upside? Things Could Be Worse
text: The year now ending has been a sobering one for the commercial real estate industry, as mortgage defaults have multiplied. Two years ago, barely 1 percent of such loans were delinquent. A year ago that was up to 6 percent, and late this year the figure hit 9 percent.

headline: Accounting Board Puts Interim Head in Lead Spot
text: Leslie F. Seidman, a former auditor and accountant for JPMorgan, was named on Thursday as chairwoman of the Financial Accounting Standards Board, which sets accounting rules for American companies.

headline: Tradition Made Nimble, Marked by Buoyant Pulse
text: “How do you like your ‘Messiah’?” should be the refrain of December, when Handel’s perennially popular work is served in interpretations catering to every taste, from rich and indulgent to lean and lithe.

headline: Jazz Improvisation, Casual but Tight
text: Early set at Smalls. Not much action in the house yet, bartender still setting up. Mitch Borden, the club’s founder, sits near the entrance picking out “April in Paris” on a guitar. Every Tuesday evening at 7:30 since September, the pianist Spike Wilner, who manages the club, plays duets with a rotating cast of singers. This week it was Cyrille Aimée, a young French singer who now lives in New York and placed second in last October’s Thelonious Monk competition.

headline: Face the Music
text: One of my relatives, a professional pianist, held a party last year. When we arrived, he was playing piano in the living room, where drinks were being served. We had to scream over the music. He took a short break for dinner then started right in again. I’m sure he thought he was providing entertainment, but the music was overbearing. He’s having another party this year, but I don’t want to sit through a forced recital. We go to his performances and enjoy them, but there’s a time and place for everything, no?

headline: Spiritual Seeker With a Taste For the Satirical
text: Every so often we are shocked  shocked!  to learn that a great artist was not such a great human being. In these disillusioned modern times, we have learned to separate artistic and literary achievement from the artist’s moral character. We may admire the works of Tolstoy, Céline, Picasso and Pollock and overlook their failings as people. Still, the fantasy that spiritual and artistic evolution should go hand in hand is hard to give up.

headline: Colleagues More Than Happy to Go Running After the Boss
text: GETTING into shape is a popular New Year’s resolution, but for many people the motivation to keep up with a fitness routine wanes within weeks or months. One strategy for sticking with it is to follow the example set by active friends or co-workers.

headline: Weekend Miser
text: The week leading up to New Year’s Day can be a time of reflection, renewal and resolutions. Or it can be a time to avoid all those things and squeeze in one more party.

headline: Tracking Racial Identity, But Not Defined by It
text: BOSTON  A spin of the marketing wheel has brought abstract painting back into the spotlight, and much of the new stuff turns out to be rewrapped old stuff. At the same time there are enough artists seriously rethinking existing models that very basic definitions  What does abstract mean? What qualifies as painting?  are in flux. Mark Bradford, a 49-year-old Californian, is one of these rethinkers, and a lean, bright 10-year survey of his work at the Institute of Contemporary Art here gives a sense of what he’s been up to.

headline: The City as It Was, A Web Site Away
text: For decades photographers like Berenice Abbott and Samuel H. Gottscho captured New York City  its streets and neighborhoods, landmark buildings and bridges, famous haunts and hangouts. And for decades thousands of these images and others dating from as early as the mid-19th century have been languishing in the storerooms of the Museum of the City of New York.

headline: Calculating Inflation When Asking for Raises
text: If you’re considering asking for a raise, it can be helpful to know the true rate of  inflation. That way, you can at least ask for your wage to go up as much as prices have. You’ll also want to make sure your boss isn’t trying to pass off a cost-of-living adjustment as your raise, assuming your employer adjusts your wages to keep pace.

headline: Having a Klingon Christmas
text: Readers who like Charles Dickens’s “Christmas Carol” but wish it had more fight scenes and was written in a language almost no one understands will be glad to hear that the classic holiday tale has now been translated into Klingon, a language invented for “Star Trek: The Motion Picture.” Commedia Beauregard, the Minnesota theater company responsible for the project, has been performing “A Klingon Christmas Carol” in Chicago since last month.

headline: U.S. Approved Business With Blacklisted Nations
text: Despite sanctions and trade embargoes, over the past decade the United States government has allowed American companies to do billions of dollars in business with Iran and other countries blacklisted as state sponsors of terrorism, an examination by The New York Times has found.

headline: Mortgage Rates May Have Hit Bottom
text: MORTGAGE rates in 2010 were the lowest in six decades, but a recent and sustained increase may indicate that consumers can expect to pay more in the new year to buy or refinance a home.

headline: Conjuring a Magical Relationship
text: If the tall man with the stiff, lurching walk and sad, baggy eyes in “The Illusionist” looks familiar, it’s because you may have seen him before, creating joyful pandemonium on the beach in “Mr. Hulot’s Holiday.” Familiar yet different, because while the tall man resembles Mr. Hulot’s creator — the great French comic actor and filmmaker Jacques Tati — he has been drawn by hand here, from his retreating gray hair to the pumpkin-hued socks he wears onstage when he’s pulling a plump, recalcitrant rabbit from a hat.

headline: ‘Set Pieces’
text: A new show at the Institute for Contemporary Art in Philadelphia re-purposes pieces from the Philadelphia Museum of Art across town.

headline: Art Imitates Movies in a Series of Scenes
text: PHILADELPHIA  An inspired meeting of the big, encyclopedic museum and the small university kunsthalle is under way at the Institute of Contemporary Art here, where the artist Virgil Marti has taken a turn as guest curator. His show, “Set Pieces,” transports decorative works from the storage rooms of the Philadelphia Museum of Art across town to the institute and is as irreverent as it is resourceful.

headline: I Can’t Wait For Christmas
text: Because when it’s over, they’ll go back to playing chamber music in Penn Station — I hope.

headline: Brian Hanrahan, Longtime BBC Reporter, Dies at 61
text: LONDON  Brian Hanrahan, a veteran BBC reporter who was responsible for one of British war reporting’s most celebrated moments, aboard an aircraft carrier off the Falklands in 1982, died here on Monday. He was 61.

headline: Lawmakers Beat the Bell Out the Door
text: Christmas vacation came early for some members of Congress this year.

text: It’s the day before Christmas, and the top editors of The New York Times are surely tied up at Kennedy Airport by now, desperate to get out of town. Maybe they’ll miss this small review of a rather large book.

text: Viacom said Thursday that it had completed its sale of Harmonix, the maker of the video game Rock Band.

headline: Series of Gaffes Ends Soccer’s Big Year
text: It began as a celebrative year for Sepp Blatter, the president of FIFA, soccer’s world governing body. He took the World Cup to Africa for the first time, although many were sure that South Africa would fail as the host. As it turned out, Blatter, 74, was right. The stadiums were full, the South Africans were welcoming hosts and capable organizers, and fears of violence were unfounded.

headline: Warhol’s Silent Film Portraits
text: Who is the fairest of them all? Edie Sedgwick, that’s who, no contest. Of the 13 subjects of the short films known as “Screen Tests” featured in “Andy Warhol: Motion Pictures” at the Museum of Modern Art, none are loved more by the camera than that doomed “it girl” of the 1960s.

headline: ‘Spider-Man’ Musical Will Resume Performances
text: The Broadway musical “Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark” is a go to resume performances at 8 p.m. Thursday, a spokesman said three hours before curtain — the first show since a stunt actor was seriously injured mid-performance on Monday night.

headline: Shopping, not Watching
text: In advance of Christmas few Americans opted to tune in to network television during prime time on Wednesday. According to Nielsen’s estimates a rerun of CBS’s “Criminal Minds” led the night with just 6.9 million viewers at 9 p.m., while a repeat of the network’s 10 p.m. legal drama “The Defenders” drew 5.6 million. Although both shows delivered high enough ratings to put CBS on top for the night, the network’s annual special “A Home for the Holidays” lagged behind all three of its major network competitors in the 8 p.m. time slot, attracting 3.9 million viewers. Fox and NBC tied for second place over all with Fox broadcasting new episodes of “Human Target” (5.8 million) and “Million Dollar Money Drop” (4.8 million) and NBC earning relatively decent ratings for repeats of “Law & Order: SVU” at 9 (5 million) and 10 (6.5 million). NBC’s new episode of “Undercovers” at 8 garnered 4.2 million viewers. ABC finished close behind the other networks in fourth place with sitcom reruns from 8 to 9:30 followed by a holiday special “CMA Country Christmas,” which averaged 4.3 million viewers from 9:30 to 11.

headline: New Homes for Trigger, A Historian’s Archive And a Kentucky Churn
text: In all the news this year of museums’ shutting down and auctioning their displays, and all the collectors and dealers with legal problems who had to sell possessions, there was a smattering of good omens.

headline: Experts Citing Rising Hopes for Recovery
text: WASHINGTON  Eighteen months after the recession officially ended, the government’s latest measures to bolster the economy have led many forecasters and policy makers to express new optimism that the recovery will gain substantial momentum in 2011.

headline: Europe’s Bad Weather Adds to Heathrow’s Woes
text: LONDON  Huddled together Thursday morning with hundreds of displaced passengers in a large semiheated tent outside Terminal 1 at Heathrow Airport, Dennis and Bonnie Barlow of Virginia were reviewing the high points of their vacation so far.

headline: Skype Struggles to Restore Its Service and Reputation
text: 4:18 p.m. | Updated Skype said that it had stabilized its service after a two-day outage and gave details about reimbursing users. Pay As You Go and Pre-Pay users will receive a credit voucher via e-mail that will give them approximately 30 minutes of free calling anywhere in the world, the company said. Meanwhile, subscribers will get a credit within the next few days for an extra week of service.

headline: Stuffed Pigs and Other Tales of Swag
text: We’ll admit it: the Bagger had a misplaced promotional thrill when we walked into our office one day last Oscar season to discover a big bunch of balloons tethered to a giant cardboard house near our desk. Oh Pixar! We thought fondly. Those folks know from swag. (And hopefully, from tipping their delivery guys really, really well. )

headline: Online Sales Rose 15% This Holiday, Beating In-Store Growth, Report Says
text: Online sales increased more than 15 percent this holiday season, according to data released Thursday, the latest confirmation of the growing importance of Internet commerce during retail’s most lucrative time of the year.

headline: Happy Holidays, Wheels Readers
text: Whatever the mode of transport that conveys you to your destination, the editors and contributors at Wheels wish you safe and happy travels this holiday weekend. We’ll be taking a short break, returning to our regular coverage on Monday, Dec. 27.

headline: Partying With a Camera Geek
text: The Times' technology columnist explains what is special about three new small cameras with large sensors.

headline: Beyond Popping Corks, the Sounds of the New Year
text: SALUTING the new year huddled around the hearth with family and friends — bedecked in sequins and plastic “2011” spectacles, spilling warm Champagne on the sofa — is good, old-fashioned fun. But wouldn’t you rather spend the night with Patti Smith?

headline: Asparagus and Spruce
text: René Redzepi, the chef and co-owner of the restaurant Noma, demonstrates how to eat your Christmas tree with asparagus.

headline: A Week With Cynthia Rowley
text: CYNTHIA ROWLEY, 45, the clothing designer and a West Village resident, has an ever-expanding lifestyle brand, including a line of Band-Aids. She recently introduced Exhibition A, a members-only online marketplace for contemporary art. CHLOE MALLE

headline: Salvia Takes a Starring Role
text: SEVERAL weeks after Miley Cyrus turned 18 in November, a video surfaced showing the pop singer and actor celebrating her adulthood with uncontrollable laughter, garbled speech and a shapely bong. It was neither marijuana nor hashish in the pipe, she explained in the face of public furor, but Salvia divinorum, a powerful hallucinogenic that adults can legally use in California.

headline: Titans in Party Dresses
text: OF the 30 swell young ladies who will be formally introduced to high society during the International Debutante Ball at the Waldorf-Astoria on Dec. 29, the most swell may be Hadley Marie Nagel — a German countess, according to her mother, Susan Nagel, and also a direct descendant, through her father, Jon (a lawyer), of two signers of the Declaration of Independence.

headline: The New Court of Shame Is Online
text: IN late October, Mary Bale walked into a courtroom in Coventry, England, her head bowed. Two months earlier, Ms. Bale, a former bank worker, had been filmed on a security camera, picking up a cat by the skin of its back and tossing it into a garbage bin.

headline: Stars of the See-and-Be-Seen Upend Washington
text: “HAVE you met everyone you want to meet?” Jayne Sandman, flame haired and voluptuous, her pregnant belly layered with gossamer-thin tea-rose silk chiffon, asked her guests. “Is there anyone you need to meet?” echoed Barbara Martin, in a black silk dress adorned with metal chains, accessorized otherwise with a steady stream of acerbic commentary.

headline: Really, Really Last-Minute Gifts
text: You know that uncomfortable moment when someone you haven’t bought a gift hands you one? Thanks to modern mobile phone technology, there is something of an answer for the really, really last-minute shopper.

headline: Lamb and Bean Soup, With a Frying Twist
text: I had ambitious plans for the lamb riblets (a k a breast of lamb trimmed down to neat rectangles) from 3-Corner Field Farm at the Union Square Greenmarket. I would simmer them with Chinese-style spices, heavy on the star anise; trim and bone them; chill them under a weight rubbed with more spice; then deep-fry them and serve them like Peking duck — which would have entailed making pancakes and assembling garnishes.

headline: The Core of the Coming Apple App Store
text: Apple has announced that its Mac App Store will open for business on Jan. 6.

headline: Free and Cheap Calls Without Skype
text: With the biggest calling days of the year just ahead, the  Skype outage yesterday may leave you wondering if you will be able to make cheap (or free) calls to family and friends when you want over the holidays.

headline: Senator to Santa: Come to the Garden State!
text: In the debate over climate change, one Democratic senator is reaching out to a real heavy hitter: Santa Claus.

headline: Complaint Box | Modern Inconveniences
text: Looking back at 2010, I can only wonder why, in an era when the unimaginable has become doable, have some tasks we had down become more complicated?

headline: Daddy and Me
text: A prisoner at Rikers Island reads to his children with the help of a program designed to keep families strong.

headline: On the Street | Holiday Windows
text: The lavish Christmas decoration in many store windows along Madison and Fifth avenues have exotic travel themes, and give no hint of financial restraint.

headline: The Swift Rise of a Governor, as Predicted Over Drinks
text: Even in his most fanciful moments, David A. Paterson never imagined that his boss, Eliot Spitzer, would self-destruct, and that he would abruptly ascend to the job of New York governor.

headline: States Look for Winning Formulas to Spur Lottery Sales
text: ATLANTA  Buy a scratch lottery ticket in Georgia, and you can win music downloads or a seat at an Atlanta Falcons game. In New York, one of the top sellers is an all-black ticket as sleek as an Armani suit. And in Texas, where they brag that everything is bigger, a single ticket goes for $50.

headline: Martha Posner and Larry Fink
text: THEY still live in Martins Creek, Pa., where they were married in May 2000. Their small farm is surrounded by 250 acres of protected forest and farmland. Yet Larry Fink, 69, a prominent photographer, and Martha Posner, 54, a sculptor, have traveled great distances in their appreciation and understanding of each other and their relationship.

headline: Sharyn Meaney, Neil Morton
text: Sharyn Carroll Meaney and Neil James Morton were married Friday on St. John in the Virgin Islands. The Rev. Phil Chalker, a minister with the World Christianship Ministries, officiated at the Westin hotel on Great Cruz Bay.

headline: Mabel Hwang and Jonathan Weiss
text: Mabel A. Hwang and Jonathan David Weiss were married Friday afternoon at the Langham Hotel in Pasadena, Calif. Dr. William I. Weiss, the bridegroom’s paternal grandfather who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated.

headline: Margaret Lannamann and Brian Mahoney
text: Margaret Payne Lannamann and Brian Thomas Mahoney were married Thursday at Christ’s Church in Rye, N.Y. Canon Susan C. Harriss, an Episcopal priest and the church’s rector, performed the ceremony.

headline: Pamela Gould and Bill Scholtz
text: Pamela C. Gould and Bill H. Scholtz were married Friday at City Hall in San Francisco. James M. Illig, a deputy marriage commissioner, officiated.

headline: Deborah Dyer, Richard Phelps
text: Deborah Yerkes Dyer and Richard Augustus Phelps were married Friday at the Boston Park Plaza Hotel. H. Skip Brandt, a justice of the peace for the Commonwealth of Massachusetts, officiated.

headline: Katherine Nolan, Young Lu
text: Katherine Alyssa Nolan, the daughter of Margaret K. Nolan and Dr. Bruce A. Nolan of Miami, was married Thursday to Young Lu, the son of Dr. Shufen Meng and Qi Lu of Newton, Mass. Frank Nuñez, a Universal Life minister, officiated at a nondenominational ceremony that incorporated Chinese and Western customs at the Rusty Pelican restaurant in Miami.

headline: China’s North Korea Shift Helps U.S. Relations
text: WASHINGTON  Few debates have strained relations between the United States and China more this year than how to handle an unruly North Korea. But after a tense week, when the threat of war hung over the Korean Peninsula, the Obama administration and Beijing seem finally to be on the same page.

headline: Tentative Deal Reached to Complete Meadowlands Xanadu
text: The lenders who took over the stalled Meadowlands Xanadu entertainment and retail mall in New Jersey announced on Thursday that they had reached a nonbinding agreement with a new development partner, the owners of the Mall of America in Minnesota.

headline: Tax Inquiry Shifts to Small Swiss Banks
text: The Justice Department has opened a criminal investigation into Swiss regional banks that it suspects may have helped scores of wealthy Americans evade taxes despite a broad crackdown on Swiss secrecy, two people briefed on the investigation said on Thursday.

headline: Black’s Appointment as Chancellor Is Contested
text: ALBANY  Opponents of Cathleen P. Black’s appointment as New York City schools chancellor tried to convince a judge on Thursday that the state education commissioner misinterpreted the law when he approved her selection.

headline: More Germans Look Back at the Mark With Fondness
text: BERLIN  For the infrequent flier landing here from anyplace else in the euro zone, or at least for people with longish memories, there is still a lingering sense of novelty in the single-currency bills that do not need changing for the cab ride into town, the euro coins that buy an S-Bahn ticket in Berlin as easily as a Métro ride in Paris.

headline: Goldman Adopts ‘Brake’ Provision on Bonuses
text: Kenneth R. Feinberg, President Obama’s former pay czar, received a lukewarm reception from Wall Street this year when he suggested that firms adopt a so-called brake provision that would allow employee compensation agreements at big banks to be broken if the government were forced to step and bail them out.

headline: Wisconsin on the Map to Pray With Mary
text: CHAMPION, Wis.  In France, the shrine at Lourdes is surrounded by hundreds of hotels and has received as many as 45,000 pilgrims in a single day. Our Lady of Guadalupe, in Mexico, draws millions of fervent worshipers a year.

headline: Official Under Spitzer Joins Cuomo Staff in Job to Restructure Government
text: Governor-elect Andrew M. Cuomo named two veteran state officials to his senior staff on Thursday, continuing to populate his administration with a mix of seasoned operatives, trusted advisers of long standing and members of politically important minorities.

headline: Good Neighbors
text: THE other car is already there when Jana pulls into the driveway. At first, she thinks it is her father’s car, thinks maybe he’s late leaving for the factory, and she wonders where she can stash the cake  the overpriced, holly-sprigged log she finally brought home to surprise her grandmother  before he finds it. But then she sees the woman on the porch. The woman is wearing a red coat, hat pulled down over her ears. Jana does not recognize her.

headline: Ohio State Players, Including Pryor, Suspended for Five Games in 2011
text: The latest incident in a 2010 college football season defined by suspensions, investigations and controversy has assured that a cloud of scandal will hang over the 2011 season.

headline: A Tug of War, With Strings of Lights
text: Back in 2005, after the first of their children was born, Liz McCarthy saw a strange obsession take hold of her husband, Andrew. He began festooning more and more of their home in the Bronx with brightly colored Christmas lights, claiming he was “doing it for the kids.” Every surface became his canvas: the bushes and flower beds, the 40-foot evergreen on their lawn, their siding, their eaves, their mantel, their kitchen.

headline: Bronx? Cooperstown? Pettitte Is a Man of Many Questions
text: If Andy Pettitte has indeed thrown his last pitch, he will retire with more victories than Whitey Ford, a better winning percentage than Bob Feller, Juan Marichal and Tom Seaver, and the most postseason wins in baseball history. Pettitte also owns a higher earned run average than Bob Welch, Rick Reuschel and Jerry Reuss, despite pitching fewer innings, and has finished in the top three in Cy Young Award balloting once.

headline: In Britain, Tapes Rattle a Political Coalition

headline: The Sidney Awards
text: I try not to fall into a rut, but every December I give out Sidney Awards for the best magazine essays of the year, and every year it seems I give one to Michael Lewis. It would be more impressive if I was discovering obscure geniuses, but Lewis keeps churning out the masterpieces.

headline: Imam Behind Islamic Center Plans U.S. Tour
text: The controversy over plans to build an Islamic center in downtown Manhattan subsided in November, almost abruptly, with the end of an election season that amplified its most emotional underlying issues.

headline: Kenya: Effort to Spare Top Politicians From Charges
text: Members of Parliament are trying to withdraw Kenya from its agreements with the International Criminal Court in an effort to spare top politicians from facing the tribunal. Last week, Luis Moreno-Ocampo, the court’s top prosecutor, said he was seeking crimes against humanity charges against six well-known Kenyans, including three government ministers, for what he said was their role in orchestrating violence after the disputed 2007 election. Parliament passed a motion on Wednesday night asking the government to pull out of the treaty recognizing the court. Prime Minister Raila Odinga has sent mixed signals on whether he supports such a move, and President Mwai Kibaki has yet to comment, though both leaders have said in the past that they will cooperate with the court.

headline: China and Intellectual Property
text: For years, Chinese officials have promised to improve their protection of intellectual property. But the infringement of copyrights, patents and trade secrets has, in many instances, gotten worse. Last week, they made some new promises. While we welcome China’s willingness to utter commitments in this area, we remain skeptical of its ability or desire to protect foreign innovation.

headline: Police Fatally Shoot Man Who Lunged With a Knife

The spy flees the country. The generals resign in disgrace.

headline: Yankees and Damon May Not Fit

If he wants to improve his Hall of Fame candidacy by reaching the 3,000-hit mark, Damon will play for the team that will give him the most playing time in 2011. That is unlikely to be the Yankees, who have discussed a possible reunion with Damon but have not offered a starting role.

headline: Cockfighting Outfits Evade the Law, and Continue to Prosper
text: One by one, Domanick Muñoz pulled bloody and battered rooster bodies out of a pile of feathers, claws and beaks. The birds that were still gasping for life he put out of their misery, plunging a syringe of drugs into their gouged and lacerated bellies. Animal-cruelty officers with Dallas Animal Services took those that were already dead and gingerly placed them into large, black plastic garbage bags.

headline: A Reminder From Chicago: It’s Washington, D.C., U.S.A.
text: WASHINGTON  The Chicago elections board underscored an important rule for politicians Thursday when it cleared Rahm Emanuel to run for mayor, which is that it’s fine to rent your house out to a complete stranger, as long as you leave your wife’s wedding dress stuffed under the stairs, or maybe just some old pasta in the refrigerator.

headline: An Actor Known by Face Lends Voice to ‘True Grit’
text: For nearly 17 years, Joe Stevens managed what for so many others has been impossible: He eked out a modest but steady living as one of those actors whose name you don’t know but whose face you seem to see everywhere. After graduating from the University of Texas in 1986, he founded a theater company in Austin called Cro-Magnum, which in turn led to small parts in more than two dozen Texas-shot movies and television shows, including “Lone Star,” “Selena,” “Varsity Blues” and (as four different characters in four different episodes) “Walker, Texas Ranger.”

headline: California: Woman Dead in Floodwaters
text: Powerful storms that hit Southern California this week may have caused the death of a 39-year-old woman whom police found in her car in Canyon Lake in Riverside County early Thursday. Witnesses reported about 5 a.m. that they had seen the woman drive into floodwaters near the lake. The car later veered off the road and overturned into the lake, a spokeswoman for the Riverside County Sheriff’s Department said. The storm caused severe damage to homes in Riverside, San Bernardino and Orange Counties.

headline: Another Christmas in Kabul

headline: New Head Named for Ethics Office
text: Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. on Thursday named a career prosecutor to oversee the Justice Department’s ethics office, known as the Office of Professional Responsibility, after a federal judge criticized the department’s handling of charges against the late Senator Ted Stevens of Alaska. The prosecutor, Robin C. Ashton, has worked for the United States attorney’s office for the District of Columbia since 1991, serving most recently as an executive assistant who directed actions on civil and criminal cases. The Office of Professional Responsibility investigates allegations of professional misconduct involving Justice Department lawyers; in 2010, for example, it conducted an inquiry into the department’s handling of charges against Mr. Stevens.

headline: A Fisherman Always Welcome, and Now Missed
text: At 6:30 a.m. on Tuesday, crew members of a fishing charter boat sat in the passenger cabin, waiting for customers who did not come. On other, warmer Tuesdays, they could at least count on the arrival of a group of old-timers, but most of that crowd was away for the winter months.

When an admissions officer from Michigan State University visited her high school earlier this month and saw Ms. Vela’s transcript, she was accepted on the spot.

headline: Family Ties and Holiday Shopping Bring Bustle (and Long Waits) to Border Crossing

His white Ford pickup, loaded with a washer, a TV and toys for Christmas, stood motionless less than a mile before the international boundary marking the entrance into Mexico.

headline: Bankruptcy Suit Alleges Fraud in Factory Sale
text: Two years ago, workers at Republic Windows and Doors gained international attention for occupying the factory on Goose Island and demanding money owed after the business abruptly closed three weeks before Christmas. Richard B. Gillman, Republic’s owner, faces felony fraud-related charges related to alleged schemes including moving equipment that he did not own from the Chicago company to an Iowa window factory he and associates were taking over.

headline: The Man Who Brought Trout to a Valley of Gravel
text: PAGOSA SPRINGS, Colo.  The Rio Blanco tumbles out of a range of 12,000-foot mountains in the San Juan National Forest into a picture-perfect valley that’s reminiscent of a miniature Yosemite. In its upper reaches, the Blanco runs in a whitewater cascade, where native cutthroat trout thrive. In the valley, on the meadowland of El Rancho Pinoso, a privately owned ranch that rents out cabins and provides fly-fishing access, the water slows and deepens, providing an excellent habitat for introduced rainbows that frequently exceed 20 inches.

headline: Ranger Has Impressive Debut in an 11-Round Shootout Loss

The Hobbit Wizard is better known as 23-year-old Mats Zuccarello, a 5-foot-7 wing from Oslo who starred for Norway at the Vancouver Olympics, spent two seasons as a top scorer in the Swedish Elitserien and was called up by the Rangers on Wednesday from the Connecticut Whale of the American Hockey League.

headline: Clay Cole, Host of Teenage Dance Shows, Dies at 72

He was 72.

headline: Santa Safari
text: I went on safari this season to track down the true Santa Claus. I found whole herds of them. But which was real? At my first stop, the annual parade of Sidewalk Santas sponsored by the Volunteers of America, I saw several dozen walking up Fifth Avenue as tourists gawked. The next stop was SantaCon, an event that defines itself as a chance for “guys and girls of legal age” to “dress up like Santa and go cavorting around town.” I was startled by the sight of hundreds of Santas crowding streets and bars before gathering at Bethesda Fountain in Central Park. Among them was at least one Jack Skellington Santa, channeling the spirit of “The Nightmare Before Christmas,” alongside a Santa whose suit was adorned with a much-repeated line from “A Christmas Story”: “You’ll shoot your eye out, kid.” I found a rickshaw wallah who dresses like Santa. I asked him why. “It seems to make people happy,” he said. I tracked down the Santa of the “Radio City Christmas Spectacular” — a Kentucky native, it turns out — in his dressing room at the music hall, where he’s been reporting to work for 24 years. Of course, I went to the prime preserve, at Macy’s Santaland. There, I found a 4-year-old girl curled up on Santa’s lap and thought of Edmund Gwenn’s portrayal of Kris Kringle in “Miracle on 34th Street.” It dawned on me that everyone I’d seen was the real Santa, because Santa is whomever we want him to be.

headline: More Consumers Are Letting Insurers Monitor Their Mileage
text: CAR insurance rates have always been based on risk, and risk has usually been measured by the number of miles driven. So drivers often underreport the miles they travel to keep their rates low  at the expense of other drivers.

text: The biggest Christmas present that many people will get this year comes from the federal government. And most will probably fritter it away.

headline: Ideas for Using the 2011 Payroll Tax Break
text: In this weekend’s Your Money column, I encourage readers to be deliberate with the extra money most people are getting in 2011 thanks to a 2 percentage point break on Social Security taxes. It could be worth more than $4,000 in some affluent households, but because it will arrive in many paychecks in regular drips and drabs over the course of the year, plenty of people will fritter it away unthinkingly.

text: MOSCOW  Russia’s president, Dmitri A. Medvedev, on Friday called the New Start treaty “a cornerstone of security for the coming decades,” and spoke warmly of President Obama, saying that “under very difficult circumstances, he managed to make the Senate ratify this document.”

headline: BlackBerrys and iPads Come to the House Floor
text: Tucked into a new rule proposed by the incoming House Republican majority are three little words that could fling the chamber — for good or ill — into the 21st century: “that impairs decorum.”

headline: Tapping a Rough-and-Tumble Life
text: FOR 17 years he was the beefy, impassive security guard on the 11 p.m.-to-7 a.m. shift at the lobby desk of Brittany Hall, a New York University dormitory just off Broadway. He checked ID cards, broke up fights and confiscated beer from under-age drinkers with the quip “I’m going to show you the true definition of alcohol abuse,” before pouring it into the trash. Now and then a student would chat him up for company in the wee hours  learning that he was born in the Bronx in the summer of ’68, that he was a Marine in the 1980s, that he had been an N.Y.U. student but left after junior year and rode a Harley out to San Francisco to read his own poetry where the Beats once blew. But mostly people passed right by, or regarded him as a curiosity, like the student who once said, “Omigod, the security guard is reading Shakespeare.”

headline: Self-Portrait Of the Oilman As Collector
text: AT an Amsterdam auction in 1938 an anonymous American walked away with a Rembrandt for a rock-bottom $65,000. Joseph Duveen, long the pre-eminent art dealer on both sides of the Atlantic, was peeved. Who is this American, he asked his agents in Europe.

headline: Friday Reading: The Best Magazine Essays of 2010
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: Museum Shows Leap Beyond The Frame
text: ON the surface the atrium of the Museum of Modern Art would seem to be a dismal place for dance. There is nothing resembling a proscenium stage in its sparkling white vicinity. The floor isn’t sprung. Crowds can be as thick as Grand Central at rush hour, and those milling about aren’t exactly compelled to stand at rapt attention. In a museum setting performance art  by way of, say, Marina Abramovic  is one thing. Dance is something else: peripheral, elusive and in need of expensive lighting equipment.

headline: Alt-Verdi: ‘Otello,’ Differently
text: THERE are several classic recordings of Verdi’s late masterpiece “Otello.” If you could own only one, the new version conducted by Colin Davis (LSO Live 0700; two CDs) would probably not be the best choice.

headline: Talking Points From a Year Onstage
text: THE full-time critics’ Top 10 lists are settled, and Tony nominations are months away. But the slowest time of the theater year gives other reviewers, writers and editors for The New York Times the chance to recall some of the more offbeat highlights of 2010 — and to look well beyond the confines of Broadway, where plenty of the limelight shines already. Here are moments we won’t soon forget:

headline: Want to Be a Star? Take Your Lumps
text: OPERATIC history abounds in tales of unknowns who stepped in when a star bowed out and emerged as stars in their turn. Thanks to two such episodes in cities far away, the Russian soprano Marina Poplavskaya, 33, is now in the singular position of headlining back-to-back Metropolitan Opera premieres of major productions she has pretested elsewhere, both of works by Verdi.

text: The Schott’s Vocab blog is taking some festive time off, and would like to wish all co-vocabularists a very Merry Christmas.

headline: Multimedia King? Survey Says, ‘Steve Harvey’
text: LET’S review Steve Harvey’s year. (This may take a while.) His syndicated radio show has an audience of six million, and President Obama has been one of his guests. A version of the show appears in prime time on the Centric cable channel. He became the host of the long-running “Family Feud” game show. His advice book “Act Like a Lady, Think Like a Man” spent a good part of the past two years on The New York Times’s hardcover advice best-seller list, was No. 1 for 23 weeks, and is being made into a movie by Screen Gems. The recently published sequel, “Straight Talk, No Chaser,” had an initial printing of 750,000 copies and makes its debut at No. 1 on the advice list on Sunday.

headline: Trilling Songbirds Clip Their Wings
text: AS symbolic shifts go, two recent events in pop music couldn’t have been more illuminating. On Nov. 24 “Burlesque,” a big-screen musical starring Christina Aguilera, opened and landed with a thud, both critically and at the box office. On Dec. 2 came the Grammy Award nominations. Among releases up for the album of the year award are those by Lady Gaga and Katy Perry; Ms. Aguilera, who also released an album, “Bionic,” in 2010, was ignored.

headline: Tree Man | The Long Goodbye
text: The is the last of a series chronicling the experiences of a Christmas tree seller on Broadway.

headline: Film About Transgender Father Is Banned in Thailand
text: Thailand’s film board has banned a movie about a transgender father struggling to raise two children, The Associated Press reported on Friday. The National Film Board ruled on Wednesday that the film, “Insects in the Backyard,” cannot be shown in Thailand because it contains scenes that are immoral and pornographic. The board objected to several scenes, including at least one that showed an explicit depiction of two men having sex, culture and film officials said.

headline: 2010: The Year in Pictures – Bearing Witness
text: In the Week in Review section of The New York Times our colleague Michael Kamber has written a powerful essay on conflict photojournalism which contains a moving tribute to Joao Silva, the New York Times photographer who lost both his legs to a land mine while on patrol with American forces outside Kandahar on Oct. 23. He is currently undergoing rehabilitation at Walter Reed Army Medical Center in Washington, where he will remain for the foreseeable future.

headline: Greek Bishop Equates Zionism to ‘Satanism’
text: A Greek Orthodox bishop who was criticized by Jewish groups, the Greek government and some coreligionists for blaming Greece’s financial problems on a conspiracy of Jewish bankers and claiming that the Holocaust was orchestrated by Zionists issued a statement on Thursday in which he denied that he was anti-Semitic but also equated Zionism to “Satanism.”

Nigerian officials said last week that the settlement would amount to $250 million.

headline: ‘Three Pianos’ to Play a Week Longer
text: Let the wine keep flowing: “Three Pianos,” a boisterously irreverent salute to Schubert in which three pianists get increasingly party-hearty while running through the whole of his 24-song cycle “Winterreise,” has extended its run at the New York Theater Workshop by a week. The show will finish on Jan. 16, making room for rehearsals of the theater’s next production, “Peter and the Starcatcher.”Created and performed by Rick Burkhardt, Alec Duffy and Dave Malloy, “Three Pianos” originated at the Ontological-Hysteric Theater and after a short successful run was added to the New York Theater Workshop schedule, where critics were again largely positive.

headline: The Nutcracker Chronicles: ‘Nut/Cracked’
text: By this stage of December, it’s increasingly hard work to fend off the music of the Sugar Plum solo. Last weekend in Las Vegas I was eating a burger when I heard the familiar twinkle-twink celesta music, looked up and saw a TV ad for a GMC Sierra ending with the onscreen title “Nutcracker.” The next day in a cab from JFK I encountered the same music – this time accompanying a section of Jimmy Kimmel Live illustrating some aspect of the Twelve Days of Christmas.

headline: Covering Climate from Cancún to Katmandu
text: Long before negotiations over strengthening an ailing climate treaty concluded in Cancún, Mexico, with a muted, incremental agreement to keep on negotiating, it was clear that this wasn’t going to be much of a news event.

headline: Lawsuit Filed Over ‘Black Swan’ Production Credit
text: A New York film production company has sued its former president, claiming that “gross lapses in judgment” cost the company millions of dollars in lost revenue and a producer credit on the movie “Black Swan,” Reuters reported on Thursday. The defendant, Aaron Kaufman, called the claims baseless. “Black Swan,” starring Natalie Portman, is considered an Oscar favorite and has been nominated for four Golden Globe awards. In a lawsuit filed in Manhattan federal court, the production company, Overnight L.L.C., led by Rick Schwartz, accuses Mr. Kaufman of misrepresenting his skill and experience and pretending “to be knowledgeable about the financing of motion pictures when he was not.” Mr. Schwartz, who was credited as executive producer on “Black Swan,” has helped produce the movies “Machete,” “Gangs of New York,” “The Aviator” and “The Others.” Mr. Kaufman said it was only after he joined the company and helped secure a role in the production of “Machete” and “Black Swan” that Mr. Schwartz was able to produce any films.

headline: Up Front: Dale Peck
text: The novelist and literary critic Dale Peck is also the author of several children’s books.

headline: Thomas Bernhard, the Alienator
text: For the sympathetic Anglophone charged with reviewing newly translated texts by the Austrian playwright and novelist Thomas Bernhard, the task is a paradoxically onerous one. Put aside the near certainty that Bernhard would have disparaged anything you might say about his work — not just disparaged it, but attacked it with an acid-tongued rant that eviscerated your words, your intellect and your pathetic petit-bourgeois existence. You still have to deal with the almost overwhelming ambition, common to Bernhard fans, to correct his woeful stature in the English-speaking world, as well as the equally oppressive realization that opportunities for doing so are fast running out.

headline: What’s So Funny?
text: The British historian Paul Johnson manages to make “Humorists,” his collection of 14 biographical essays about funny people, fairly pedestrian for most of its brief length. Until the last few pages, when he makes it odious.

headline: Broiled Sardines With Lemon and Thyme
text: Mark Bittman makes fresh sardines, restaurant-style, with crisp skin and smoky flavor.

headline: Chasing Virtue
text: Early in “Poser,” Claire Dederer describes a regular walk she takes with a new-mom friend in her North Seattle neighborhood: “We made a circle around Green Lake, and so our talk traveled. We started with our babies and tried to decipher all the new rules we had to follow. The talk opened out to work, maybe briefly touched the real world, and then, like a tight magic circle, closed back in on babies again. It was a dark enchantment.”

headline: Very Last-Minute Gifts: Digital Craft Patterns
text: If you are reading this for gift ideas at this hour, you are probably at wits end. I already tried e-books, music, videos and video games.

headline: Graphic Books Best Sellers: A Trip to Ancient Japan
text: The latest volume – No. 55! – of the series “Inuyasha” lands at No. 10 on the manga list this week. “Inuyasha” is about a high-school girl who is not only pulled into Japan’s ancient past, she is also bound to a demon. In this installment, Inyuasha mounts an attack on the demon, Naraku, who is up to his usual deceptions. Over by the paperbacks, it was only a matter of time until this happened: the list has been taken over by the slacker series “Scott Pilgrim” and the zombie survival drama that is “The Walking Dead.”

headline: No Quotation Marks on These Sardines
text: FOR years, the only kind of sardines available to the average American were packed in oil, water or tomato sauce, sold in little rectangular cans, first with keys and later with pop-tops.

headline: Ringing in the New Year With Blini
text: People make the party, but blini are always an exciting addition. As Martha Rose Shulman writes in this week’s Recipes for Health:

headline: Restaurant-Style Fresh Sardines
text: If you think all sardines are canned, you’re in for a treat. Fresh sardines are enjoying something of a renaissance, and in this Minimalist column, I suggest an easy way to cook them.

headline: Arabian Knight
text: Lowell Thomas, the pioneering American journalist and filmmaker, was buying dates on a Jerusalem street soon after the holy city had been wrested from Turkish control by British forces in 1917, when he spotted a group of Arabs, led by a most remarkable figure. “A single Bedouin who stood out in sharp relief from his companions; . . . in his belt was fastened the short curved sword of a prince of Mecca, . . . marking him every inch a king. . . . This young man was blond as a Scandinavian. . . . His expression was serene, almost saintly, in its selflessness and repose.”

headline: ‘Play Their Hearts Out’
text: Chapter One

headline: Breaks of the Game
text: In 2004, the star-making machine, in the form of a Sports Illustrated reporter, descended on a 14-year-old basketball player from Fontana, Calif., named Demetrius Walker. The scouting newsletter The Hoop Scoop had recently proclaimed Walker the best eighth grader in the country; now the pre-eminent sports magazine was going to take that hype to a new level. While the article about Walker carried the requisite caveats — about whether he would fulfill his potential and whether it was even fair to be placing such expectations on a kid — it described him as “14 going on LeBron.” The reason was not just Walker’s physical gifts, but also his Amateur Athletic Union coach, Joe Keller, who, according to Keller himself, was keeping Walker on a righteous path — arranging for him to be home-schooled by a tutor, checking to make sure he did his academic work and paying as much attention to the boy’s well-being as to his jump shot. “I’m not going to get a thing out of this,” Keller told S.I. “My only hope is that maybe, one day, when Demetrius is in the N.B.A., he can come back and sponsor my team.”

headline: For Year’s End, Decadent Quiche
text: I GAVE up the whole notion of New Year’s resolutions decades ago. After years of having my best December intentions fade to dust by the end of the first week of January, I stopped making promises.

headline: Recipe for Friendship
text: “As Always, Julia” is an epistolary love story, a romance that began with a fan letter and the gift of a paring knife. The letter was to the writer and historian Bernard DeVoto, who had written in Harper’s about impossibly dull stainless-steel knives. The fan was an ambitious American cook, Julia Child, then living in Paris. The reply came from DeVoto’s wife and general factotum, Avis. Within months, she and Child had gone from “Mrs.” to “Avis” and “Julia, my pet!” Even in the 1950s, things moved fast.

headline: ‘Long, Last, Happy’
text: Water Liars

headline: Oh, the Sweet Terror
text: Barry Hannah, who died of a heart attack on March 1, was a matchless stylist — a word he’d most likely have hated, but all the same. Flip any of his eight novels and four previous story collections open and some rocket of prose will come bursting out:

headline: Notes From a Kidnapping
text: After the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, the Pulitzer Prize-winning reporter David Rohde says, he considered joining the military or becoming a paramedic. Instead, he was thrilled to be dispatched by his editors at The New York Times to Afghanistan, to cover the fighting there.

headline: The Gothamist
text: Early in Edith Wharton’s “House of Mirth,” Lily Bart is offered some wisdom about how to live in the dazzling yet potentially deadening realm of the rich and well born: “The real alchemy,” her suitor, Lawrence Selden, tells her, “consists in being able to turn gold back again into something else; and that’s the secret that most of your friends have lost.”

headline: Faith and Modernity
text: Every winter Fox News, seeking to stir up anger through the land, uncovers evidence of a war on Christmas. Secular humanists ignorant of religion and hostile to its traditions, someone in the studio will declare, want us to say “Happy Holiday” or give Kwanzaa equal standing. But Christmas, as its name suggests, is about Christ. These enemies of Christianity will stop at nothing to get their way. Not even Santa Claus is sacred to them.

headline: Starry Messenger
text: Galileo Galilei, “martyr of science” in the picturesque 19th-­century expression, has undoubtedly attracted more biographers than Copernicus, Kepler, Newton and Einstein combined. His run-in with the Roman Catholic Church over the motion of the earth, his forced confession and his famous stage-­whispered riposte — “e pur si muove,” “but yet it moves” (which surely was never delivered) — are all the makings of high drama.

headline: Thieves’ Paradise
text: Among the unfortunate legacies of the financial crisis of 2008 is a tendency among commentators to soft-pedal the outrage over what happened. In too many accounts, blame is considered impossible to assign given the complexities of modern-day finance. Those inclined to point fingers at Wall Street or Washington are frequently derided as innocents who do not grasp how the world really works.

headline: A City and Stage
text: “Extraordinary Renditions” is either Andrew Ervin’s first collection of stories or his first novel. Even his publishers seem unable to decide. It consists of three overlapping narratives, all set in contemporary Budapest, with some coincidences of character, location and incident; but it’s hard at times not to feel that the underlying rationale binding these stories together is a simple pun. The title refers, obviously, to the practice, developed by the United States government, of moving terrorism suspects to countries less concerned by judicial process for interrogation. Not much less obviously, “rendition” can also refer to a musical performance.

headline: Fiction Chronicle
text: DANIEL  By Henning Mankell.Translated by Steven T. Murray.  New Press, $26.95.

headline: Record Set for World’s Youngest Chess Champion
text: Hou Yifan, a 16-year-old chess player from China, became the youngest world chess champion on Friday, toppling a record held since 1978.

headline: 16-Year-Old Is Youngest Chess Champion in History
text: Hou Yifan, a 16-year-old Chinese chess player, is on top of the women’s chess world.

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: CANTI,  by Giacomo Leopardi. Translated by Jonathan Galassi (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $35.) With Galassi’s definitive English translation, Leopardi may at last become as important to American literature as, say, Rilke or Baudelaire, poets of comparable genius.

headline: Paperback Row
text: ANATHEM,  by Neal Stephenson (Harper Perennial, $16.99.) Set in a world similar but not identical to our own, “Anathem” imagines a monastic order whose members contemplate issues of math, physics and philosophy, and live their lives without electronic technology. But Stephenson’s hero, an ascetic named Erasmas, and his order are called back into the world to save civilization from an extraterrestrial crisis. Stephenson “delights in the language and etymology he has designed for his fictional world . . . and in the 7,000 years of detailed history he has given it,” Dave Itzkoff wrote in the Book Review.

headline: One Sentence Says It All
text: “No book worth its salt is meant to put you to sleep,” says the garrulous shoemaker who narrates the Czech novelist Bohumil Hrabal’s “Dancing Lessons for the Advanced in Age” (1964), “it’s meant to make you jump out of bed in your underwear and run and beat the author’s brains out.” Thirty-three pages into what appears to be an unbroken highway of text, the reader might well wonder if that’s a mission statement or an invitation. “Dancing Lessons” unfurls as a single, sometimes maddening sentence that ends after 117 pages without a period, giving the impression that the opinionated, randy old cobbler will go on jawing ad infinitum. But the gambit works. His exuberant ramblings gain a propulsion that would be lost if the comma splices were curbed, the phrases divided into sentences. And there’s something about that slab of wordage that carries the eye forward, promising an intensity simply unattainable by your regularly punctuated novel.

headline: Baker Street Irregular
text: Any fanatical admirer of Sherlock Holmes knows how he spent the Great Hiatus, those dark years between his dramatic tumble over the Reichenbach Falls in “The Final Problem” and his sensational re-emergence in “The Empty House.” (Unbeknownst even to Watson, Holmes faked his own death and had been traveling incognito in Persia, Egypt, Tibet and other exotic locales.) But aside from writing “The Exploits of Brigadier Gerard” and several other works, touring in Egypt, lecturing in America, serving as a war correspondent in Sudan, supervising a hospital in Cape Town during the Boer War and standing for Parliament, what was Arthur Conan Doyle doing before he brought his great detective back from the grave?

headline: A Variety of Ways Not to Have Christmas
text: It’s a holiday from work and school. It’s wrapping paper torn and scattered about the tree. For the fortunate, it’s a family dinner with good food and minimal drama. But for two groups of people in particular, Christmas is a time to feel like a minority.

headline: The Week in Pictures for Dec. 24
text: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include unemployed OTB workers, the next phase of the High Line, and Christmas lights.

headline: Arrests Made in Stradivarius Theft
text: Three people were arrested for stealing an antique violin worth nearly $2 million from an internationally acclaimed musician while she stopped for a snack at a London sandwich bar, the Associated Press reported on Friday. The South Korean violinist Min-Jin Kym was eating at a sandwich shop outside Euston Station on Nov. 29 when she noticed that her black violin case — which contained a Stradivarius and two valuable bows — was missing, according to the police. The violin, made in 1696, is one of about 400 made by Stradivarius that are still known to exist. The police arrested and charged John Maughan, 26, and two teenagers on Wednesday. The names of the youths, 16 and 14 years old, were not included in news reports because of British law. Mr. Maughan is in custody and the two teenagers are free on bail. The instrument has not yet been recovered and an insurance company has offered a reward for information. Ms. Kym, who is 32, began playing the violin at 6, made her international debut with the Berlin Symphony Orchestra when she was 13 and has performed with other leading orchestras.

headline: G.E. to Sell Mexican Mortgage Unit to Santander
text: General Electric’s finance unit, GE Capital, agreed on Friday to sell its Mexican consumer mortgage division to Santander of Spain for 2 billion pesos, or $162 million, part of the industrial giant’s strategy to sell off noncore financial assets.

headline: Hollywood Dispute Pits Parking Against Organic Food
text: LOS ANGELES  On weekdays, Ivar Avenue is a quiet strip of Hollywood, with a theater, a recording studio, a Jack in the Box, a gay and lesbian elderly housing complex and a film school. Every Sunday morning, it becomes the Hollywood Farmers Market, four bustling blocks of farm and food stands offering everything from oyster mushrooms to California sea bass to a crowd of 8,000 people.

headline: The Nutcracker Chronicles: The Not So ‘Greatest Russian Nutcracker’
text: Oh, these competitive Russians! No sooner did I begin this “Nutcracker” marathon in mid-November by watching the so-called “Great Russian Nutcracker” (the Moscow Ballet, on simultaneous tours of both East and West Coasts of America) than news arrived of a quite different touring production called “The Greatest Russian Nutcracker.” And whereas the “Great Russian” avoids the main ballet metropolises (I saw it at West Point), the “Greatest Russian” was coming to a place near me – the Tribeca Performing Arts Center.

headline: A Santa App for Christmas
text: With Santa about to arrive, there is precious little time left to ramp up children’s excitement to visions-of-sugarplum levels.

headline: Air Travel Survey Reveals Negative View of Screening
text: A survey of  business and leisure air travelers commissioned by the U.S. Travel Association found that more of them described the current screening process as “inconsistent,” “stressful,” or “embarrassing” than described it as being “fair” or “effective.” But most respondents for the survey, released this week, said they believed it is possible to achieve an air travel screening system that is both secure and efficient.

headline: Iraqi Christians Exercise Caution for Christmas
text: BAGHDAD  As they gathered to celebrate the birth of Jesus, the congregation here first contemplated death, represented by a spare Christmas tree decked with paper stars, each bearing a photograph of a member of a nearby church killed in a siege by Islamic militants in October.

headline: For Some Iraqi Christians – Shelter in Istanbul
text: ISTANBUL – A small community of Iraqi Christians is spending this Christmas Eve in a small basement chapel at a community center in Istanbul, straining its 150-person capacity.

headline: In Kanazawa, Japan, Ancient Beauty Fuses With Modern Art
text: ON a sunny early November afternoon in the Japanese city of Kanazawa, the alchemy of autumn had already begun transforming the city’s beloved Kenrokuen Garden from an oasis of leafy greens into a gold-tinged sanctuary. Workers were busy constructing yukitsuri — thick ropes tied to fragile tree branches, intended to brace them against heavy snowfalls — in dramatic pyramids that soar over the gnarled wood. And the transformation continues as the seasons progress.

headline: Deaf Divers Sign in the Soundless Depths
text: AFTER sunset one evening in August, Wendy Dannels prepared for the first night dive of her life off Moalboal, a resort town on the Philippine island of Cebu. She was on a 10-day diving trip on a boat called the Philippine Siren.

headline: Hawaii’s Governor Takes On ‘Birthers’
text: HONOLULU  Gov. Neil Abercrombie of Hawaii, who befriended President Obama’s parents when they were university students here, has been in office for less than three weeks. But he is so incensed over “birthers”  the conspiracy theorists who assert that Mr. Obama was born in Kenya and was thus not eligible to become president  that he is seeking ways to change state policy to allow him to release additional proof that the president was born in Honolulu in 1961.

headline: Décor Preference: Historical Fiction
text: Though Angie Lake bought an apartment built postwar, she strove to make the interior look as if it had been around much longer.

headline: Breakfast and Brunch Recipes
text: Ricotta pancakes, baked eggs with prosciutto, caramel-apple muffins and more dishes for the weekend.

headline: Postwar in Name Only
text: ANGIE LAKE proudly describes herself as a “prewar person,” the sort of New Yorker deeply enamored of built-in bookshelves and decorative molding on every available surface. As she sums it up: “I always lived in a place with a fireplace. And by that I mean a real fireplace.”

headline: Punch Pushes Cocktails Off the Menu at the Drink in Williamsburg
text: One of the unavoidable drinking trends of the fall has been punch. Hardly a cocktail bar has opened in New York in the past few months without giving a nod to the crystal bowl. Forty Four at the Royalton Hotel, 1534 on the Lower East Side and SoHo’s Lani Kai have all made room for punch in their programs. But the recently opened The Drink in Williamsburg has so devoted themselves to the format that the flowing bowls have actually knocked individual cocktails off the menu.

headline: Styles, Très Plural, Play Stages in Paris
text: PARIS  Is there any other ballet company in the world that offers the choreographic range of the Paris Opera Ballet with comparable panache? At the moment the almost imperial grandeur of the troupe is omnipresent at both the gleamingly modern Opéra Bastille, with Rudolf Nureyev’s “Swan Lake,” and at the gilded Palais Garnier, with a triple bill of works by George Balanchine, Trisha Brown and Pina Bausch.

headline: Taurasi May Face Olympic Ban for Positive Drug Test
text: The Turkish basketball federation said Friday that the star player Diana Taurasi had tested positive for a stimulant that was identified as modafinil, a drug that enhances wakefulness and vigilance and is designed to treat narcolepsy, sleep apnea and sleep disorders related to shift work. Modafinil is also used off-label to combat jet lag and attention deficit disorder and recreationally to enhance alertness. The stimulant does not cause the anxiety and jitteriness associated with amphetamines.

headline: In Britain, Many Glass Slippers to Fill
text: LONDON  Some sort of collective artistic unconscious determined that “Cinderella” would be the “Nutcracker” of this year’s Christmas dance season in Britain. There are no fewer than four productions dotted about the country, two of them in London: the Royal Ballet’s grand 1948 production by Frederick Ashton, and Matthew Bourne’s vividly imaginative reworking of the tale as a World War II romance, set during the Blitz. (The other two are versions by Ashley Page for the Scottish Ballet, and by David Bintley for the Birmingham Royal Ballet.)

headline: Downsizing Without Downsides
text: THOUGH Wayne Gordon and Margaret Brown loved their three-bedroom condo on the Upper West Side, once their only child had grown up and moved out, they themselves were eager to move. Their home was too big and, especially, too expensive.

headline: Falcons’ Snelling Raising Awareness About Epilepsy
text: It was a routine school day morning for Jason Snelling, who was 15. His big brother was leaning over his bed, trying to wake him. As with any teenager, it sometimes took coaxing and vigorous pushing and pulling to get him out of bed. This time, however, things went much differently than expected.

headline: Exalted Views, Down-to-Earth Prices
text: AS Fitzgerald might have said, people who live on hills are different from you and me. From Murray Hill to Carnegie Hill in Manhattan, from Brooklyn Heights to Park Slope in Brooklyn, New Yorkers with cash to spend have long sought the high ground. In Staten Island, Todt Hill is a coveted area, as are Grymes Hill and Dongan Hills Colony. But for all its elevation, Ward Hill, on the island’s north shore, has managed to remain below the radar.

headline: A Mysterious Picasso Trove Gains More Accusations but Less Clarity
text: PARIS  At least this much is clear: the art  271 previously unknown sketches, watercolors and collages  is indeed the work of Picasso. But despite several weeks of accusations, counterclaims and deepening investigations, the mystery at the core of the case of Picasso and the electrician seems no closer to being solved.

headline: Food, Film and Parking
text: After 19 years in existence, the Hollywood Farmers Market, which operates on Sundays along Ivar Avenue between Hollywood and Sunset Boulevards, is at the center of a fight that has put on display three of this city’s most powerful passions.

headline: Footnote
text: Members of Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, Suzanne Farrell Ballet, Parsons Dance and other troupes will take the stage for a fund-raising performance for the New York City Dance Alliance’s new foundation on Monday at the Joyce Theater. Money from ticket sales will go toward the foundation’s college scholarship program for young dancers. Tickets and information: (855) NYC-5678.

headline: Grinches Are Good For ABC on Thursday
text: Back-to-back versions of “Dr. Seuss’ How the Grinch Stole Christmas” lifted ABC to second place in Thursday’s prime-time television ratings. The half-hour animated special from 1966 narrated by Boris Karloff drew 6.2 million viewers at 8 p.m. while the 2000 live-action remake with Jim Carrey as the Grinch averaged 6.6 million viewers from 8:30 to 11, according to Nielsen’s estimates. Both versions easily outperformed reruns of NBC’s sitcom line-up and Fox’s two-hour block of “Million Dollar Money Drop” (4.9 million). CBS led the night, however, with repeats including “CSI” at 9 (7.8 million) and “The Mentalist” at 10 (8.7 million).

headline: New Laws in Venezuela Aim to Limit Dissent
text: CARACAS, Venezuela  The National Assembly has approved a sweeping set of laws that impose penalties for spreading political dissent on the Internet, grant decree powers to President Hugo Chávez for 18 months and prevent legislators from breaking with his political movement.

headline: Looking Back at a Prizewinning Defense
text: As much of the tournament bridge world takes a break for the holidays, let’s look back at a brilliant defense played in 1980, at the European Junior Championship, held in Tel Aviv. The diagramed deal occurred during the match between Britain and Greece.

headline: Jackie Robinson, TV Host
text: Jackie Robinson once hosted a TV show exploring the ethical issues of the day with a panel of guests from different faiths and religious groups.  Her are excerpts from a 1958 episode.

headline: How Opera Challenges Translators
text: In a late scene of Mozart’s “Zauberflöte,” the hardy bird catcher Papageno, despairing that he may never have a mate, berates the world and decides to end it all. Seeing a tree, he makes a big show of his misery and threatens to hang himself.

headline: Archive Shows Robinson As Moderator on Morality
text: Unearthed in a college archive, the grainy black-and-white dramatization, made in 1958, tells the story of a bungled purchase order and a boss who wanted the guilty party’s scalp. The company’s managers faced a glaring choice: fire an inept clerk who had it coming anyway, or jeopardize the career of a highly valued executive who, in this instance, was the one who actually slipped up.

headline: Big Deal | Fully Furnished With Anecdotes
text: Sometimes a glance at properties for sale in a given week reveals a lot more than prices in the ever-changing — or not-changing-fast-enough — New York real estate market.

headline: Bruno’s Lawyers Ask Court to Overturn His Conviction
text: Lawyers for Joseph L. Bruno, the longtime Republican leader of the New York State Senate, have asked a federal appeals court to overturn his conviction on fraud charges, following a landmark Supreme Court decision that whittled down the law under which he was found guilty, and to prohibit the government from retrying him.
