headline: A ‘Nutcracker’ Sprouts Alter Egos
text: Once you’ve seen a number of different “Nutcrackers,” you might think you know all the main ways that the old ballet can be retold. But you don’t.

headline: Hamas Confirms Commitment to Cease-Fire
text: GAZA  After a week of heightened tensions along the Gaza-Israel border, Hamas on Friday renewed its commitment to a cease-fire with Israel in an apparent effort to head off further escalation.

headline: Before Winter Classic, Penguins and Capitals Play Another Classic
text: If there was ever a game that lived up to the hype, this was it. The arch-rivals Capitals and Penguins faced off in Washington on Thursday night, just nine days before their matchup in the Winter Classic. In front of a standing room only crowd, a national television audience and the glare of the HBO cameramen who made their way through Washington’s locker room with a palpable sense of entitlement, the Penguins edged the Capitals, 3-2, in a shootout.

headline: Commemorating Bach, Holiday and a Conductor
text: The St. Cecilia Chorus has a long, distinguished history that stretches back to 1906 and includes the first New York performance of the Mahler Third Symphony and the United States premieres of some 60 works. It is an amateur ensemble in the best sense: its singers are in it for the love of the music, and if at times they sing with greater enthusiasm than finesse, their performances have a spirit that carries them through some of the most demanding scores in the choral repertory.

headline: Christmases Past, Present and Sci-Fi
text: Just a handful of television narratives have become synonymous with the holiday season: a misfit reindeer with the support of an outcast elf provides crucial help to Santa Claus on a foggy Christmas Eve night; a sensitive boy takes pity on an underdeveloped would-be Christmas tree; a humanoid alien traverses time and space in a high-tech ship camouflaged as a vintage British police call box.

headline: A Publicist’s Sly Push for the Novel ‘True Grit’
text: LOS ANGELES  Now it can be told.

headline: Early Bid for a Reactor Site Draws Opposition in Texas
text: WASHINGTON  Twenty years ago, the Nuclear Regulatory Commission rewrote its procedure for licensing reactors to cut the time it would take to build new ones. Now an important part of the system is getting its first test, as a Chicago-based nuclear utility clashes with a well-to-do group of Texas ranchers over preapproval of a site about 120 miles southwest of Houston.

headline: Global Puck: At the World Juniors, America’s Chance to Shine
text: The U20 World Championship in Buffalo and Niagara that starts on Sunday might well be the most important I.I.H.F. event USA Hockey has ever hosted outside the Olympics. It is an event guaranteed to be successful at the box office because of its proximity to Canada (more specifically, southern Ontario), but it is also a chance for American hockey fans to assert themselves at the world’s premier pre-N.H.L. event. In some respects, it might come to define USA Hockey’s presence in the American sporting landscape.The World U20 (Junior) Championship started in 1977 in Czechoslovakia. The host cities of Zvolen and Banska Bystrica were considered small — appropriate sites for the inaugural event. The next year the tournament went to Quebec and games were played primarily in Q.M.J.H.L. cities like Chicoutimi, Hull, Cornwall and Quebec City. A few games were played in Montreal but the event’s profile didn’t get a huge boost across Canada because the gold-medal game featured the Soviet Union and Sweden (the former winning, 5-2).

headline: It Seems the Grinch Stole This Year’s Holiday Movies
text: LOS ANGELES  Have a happy holiday. But don’t look for much help from Hollywood.

headline: Air Travelers Face Snarls for Holidays
text: ATLANTA  Reaching cruising altitude between New York and Atlanta on Friday afternoon, the courtly pilot on Delta Flight 1947 broke some happy news for Yuletide romantics, or something less so for those hoping to make a Christmas Eve redeye: a possible white Christmas in the Deep South, something that has not been seen in Atlanta since the 1880s.

headline: Corks Worth Popping for 2011
text: Long Island sparkling wines, which can brighten New Year’s parties and meals, take two forms. Light ones are best used as aperitifs and with finger foods, weighty ones as meal accompaniments. In both cases, their swirling pinpoint bubbles whet the appetite.

headline: Dean Foods Settles Antitrust Case
text: Dean Foods settled an antitrust lawsuit with Northeast Dairy Farmers, agreeing to pay $30 million in damages and buy milk from producers in the region. Dean Foods and the Dairy Farmers of America cooperative were sued last year by the rival group and accused of operating a monopoly in the Northeast. Farmers received lower prices because Dean bought milk exclusively from the cooperative and its affiliates, according to a complaint in federal court in Burlington, Vt. The court has not yet approved the settlement.

headline: Baked Goods and Much More
text: Colchester Bakery’s glittering, lighted sign is as much a community landmark as the bakery itself, which is still operated by the family that established it, in the same spot, in 1947. Period piece though the sign may be, however, the inside of the bakery is a wholesome blend of traditional and modern.

headline: That General-Store Feeling
text: Fairchilds Market in Roseland is part gourmet deli, part wine shop and part gift shop. It also feels something like an old-fashioned general store.

headline: Mylan to Pay $65 Million Over Drug Prices
text: Mylan, a generic-drug maker, agreed to pay $65 million to settle a lawsuit by the federal and Texas governments asserting that the company had inflated prescription drug prices, increasing the cost of reimbursing pharmacies and other providers. The company admitted no wrongdoing in agreeing to the payment. Since 2003, Mylan has been sued by 18 states making similar allegations, according to the company’s 2009 annual report. Last year, Mylan, AstraZeneca and Johnson & Johnson agreed to pay $124 million to settle claims they violated laws by underpaying Medicaid rebates, the Justice Department said.

headline: South Africa Invited to Join Emerging Nations Group
text: South Africa has been formally asked to join a group of major emerging markets, bolstering its position as Africa’s champion. This so-called BRIC group comprises Brazil, Russia, India and China. President Hu Jintao of China wrote a letter to his South African counterpart, Jacob Zuma, to inform him of the decision. He invited him to the BRIC’s third meeting of heads of state in Beijing next year, the Chinese foreign minister, Yang Jiechi, said in a statement on his ministry’s Web site. South Africa, which has a population of 49 million, compared with China’s 1.36 billion, is betting on raising its clout on the world stage by joining BRIC, while strengthening political and trade ties within the bloc.

headline: Versailles Adds a Meal (to Eat Before Dessert)
text: SINCE 1980, Versailles in Greenwich has been a local institution, for croissants or a full breakfast in the morning or a cafe meal at lunch. But since Sept. 14, when this patisserie-cum-cafe moved a few doors down Greenwich Avenue to a slightly larger space, it has served dinner as well. Its business card attests to its versatility: Boulangerie — Patisserie — Bistro Café.

headline: ‘Daddy, Read for Me’
text: THERE once was a man who read an unabridged dictionary from cover to cover to keep from losing his mind. Solitary confinement can do that to you, make you read what you would never look at on the outside, and then read more and more of it, to preserve your sense of humanity, maybe, but certainly to maintain whatever flimsy connection you hold to the world beyond your prison cell.

headline: A Day ‘to Cure What Ails You’
text: The designer Isaac Mizrahi serves as a judge and a co-host with Iman on Bravo’s style smackdown, “The Fashion Show: Ultimate Collection.” Mr. Mizrahi, 49, sells his lifestyle collection on QVC and has his own store in Manhattan. A productive insomniac, he lives in Greenwich Village with his dog, Harry, and often spends Sunday afternoons at a museum, like the Guggenheim, where he recently did a reading. ROBIN FINN

headline: New Restaurant Beckons Old Friends
text: By the time a restaurant opens in New York, there is already a crowd of critics jostling to weigh in on the Internet, so the owner needs to “practice, practice, practice” with free preview dinners before they get there, said Bobby Werhane, who is opening this casual Italian spot on Hudson Street in the West Village on Wednesday. For the price of a tip and filling out a questionnaire, about 30 friends and relatives of Mr. Werhane sampled cured meats, pastas and dessert last Wednesday night.

headline: I Love a Man in Uniform. Especially the Red, Fluffy Kind.
text: BUSY as they were with party-going, gift-acquisition and pine-tree-gazing in Rockefeller Center, some New Yorkers still had time last week for lust. At least according to the following poems about Christmas and romance that were “found” in the Missed Connections section of craigslist.ny.org. They are published verbatim, with only line and stanza breaks added; the titles are the subject headings. ALAN FEUER

headline: Departing Schools Chief: ‘We Weren’t Bold Enough’
text: JOEL I. KLEIN invited me to breakfast last year at an Upper East Side haunt, one of those places where a bowl of yogurt goes for $23 and waiters circle the room sweeping up crumbs like pigeons at a feast.

headline: Mediterranean Flavors, By Way of Sicily
text: IF I were writing a how-to manual for restaurateurs, this might be a rule: Give people with reservations their choice of table, and let the walk-ins have what’s left.

headline: A Marvel That Kept New Yorkers Looking Up
text: It was going to be a long night. The longest night of them all, in fact, the winter solstice. This one would seem even a little longer than most, since for 72 minutes the moon, full and bright as a spotlight, would be dimmed by a total eclipse.

headline: Pakistani Outposts Struck by Large Taliban Assault
text: PESHAWAR, Pakistan  A Taliban group forced into a remote border area by Pakistani military operations struck back Friday with a large and highly coordinated attack against the government’s paramilitary forces, Pakistani officials said.

headline: Rock ’n’ Roll Legends Posed and Exposed (but Only a Little)
text: There are many ways to experience rock musicians. You can listen to their songs, watch them perform or, if they live long enough, read a chronicle of their exploits, like Keith Richards’s recently published “Life.” Another option is to view photographs like those on display in “Rock On! Masterworks of Rock Photography” at the Heckscher Museum of Art in Huntington.

headline: Tchaikovsky and Space Invaders: Not So Far Apart
text: IF Beethoven and Tchaikovsky were alive today, they would be composing music for video games. At least that is what Tommy Tallarico, the prolific composer behind the soundtracks to nearly 300 popular video games, including Earthworm Jim and Tony Hawk’s Pro Skater, contends.

headline: African Huts Far From the Grid Glow With Renewable Power
text: KIPTUSURI, Kenya — For Sara Ruto, the desperate yearning for electricity began last year with the purchase of her first cellphone, a lifeline for receiving small money transfers, contacting relatives in the city or checking chicken prices at the nearest market.

headline: A Meal Worth Eating, and Seeing, Too
text: IN his popular and informative book “Kitchen Confidential,” Anthony Bourdain speculates that brunch presents an opportunity for restaurants to serve less desirable food. That may occasionally be true, although restaurants need not wait until high noon on Sunday to clean out the fridge.

headline: Latin Fusion, Fully Orchestrated
text: IT’S refreshing to encounter a place like Perfecto Mundo in Commack serving vibrant food with distinctive flavors instead of the dreary combination plates so often found in Latin restaurants. If that food is sometimes overly orchestrated, the quality and ambition of what comes out of the kitchen are commendable.

headline: Dante’s Hell, With Those Who Can Relate
text: IN early December, seven men wearing identical pine-green work pants chanted these words from Dante Alighieri’s “Inferno”: “Non è sanza cagion l’andare al cupo.” Their ponderous voices, accompanied by dirgelike sounds from an electric guitar, filled a classroom at Sing Sing Correctional Facility in Ossining, N.Y., where they are all inmates. “It is not without reason that we are taking this journey,” they sang in Italian.

headline: Charlotte, the Queen of Spin Doctors
text: It’s scary to move to a new home all by yourself, torn away from those who raised you. It’s even scarier to learn from a recently acquired friend at the new place that the only reason you’re being treated so well (served big troughs full of yummy food like leftover pancakes every day) is that you’re going to be butchered and eaten.

headline: Rex Ryan News Conference: Sanchez Is Probable
text: The Jets play at Chicago on Sunday, so it’s a homecoming of sorts for Jets Coach Rex Ryan.

headline: Arms Talks Now Turn to Short-Range Weapons
text: WASHINGTON — Fresh from winning Senate approval for a new strategic arms treaty, President Obama plans to return to the negotiating table with Russia next year in hopes of securing the first legal limits ever imposed on the smaller, battlefield nuclear weapons viewed as most vulnerable to theft or diversion.

headline: On Slurs: A Response
text: Thanks to all who read and responded to my post for The Stone, “Speech and Harm.” What follows is a general response to those comments, written with Luvell Anderson.

headline: A Daughter of Malaysia Finds Her Political Star Rising
text: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia

headline: Changing the Family Traditions
text: Mary Devitt’s family counted on certain traditions each Christmas. Her mother cooked the entire meal and served it on the good china, carefully arrayed on a tablecloth she’d appliqued with holly sprigs. The centerpiece was always the same, a Royal Doulton figurine of a little boy with a Christmas tree. Her father sliced the turkey, using the carving set reserved for special occasions.

headline: Revenge Cited in Rome Embassy Attacks
text: ROME  Anarchists who sent letter bombs to the embassies of Switzerland and Chile here on Thursday were trying to avenge their comrades in those countries, a top Italian security official said Friday, as the city remained on alert for more potential attacks.

headline: Editor Said to Get Life Sentence for Uighur Reports
text: BEIJING  An ethnic Uighur journalist working for state radio has been sentenced to life in prison on charges that he spread subversive information around the time of deadly rioting in the western region of Xinjiang last year, a Uighur exile group said Friday.

headline: With Smith Out, the Giants Lose a Leading Man
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Around the Giants’ practice center, receiver Steve Smith has earned a reputation as an amateur videographer, filming short clips of his teammates that he posts on social-networking sites.

headline: Bavaria Booms, but Germans Feel Economic Malaise
text: ERLANGEN-HÖCHSTADT, Germany  By nearly every measure this industrial region in Bavaria, home to exporting giants like Siemens Healthcare, Adidas and Puma, is at the center of Germany’s resilient economic success, driving the nation’s growth even as much of Europe struggles to stay solvent.

headline: Doctor Says a Device He Invented Poses Risks
text: Dr. Scott D. Augustine, the inventor of a widely used piece of surgical equipment, now has a better idea  he wants hospitals to stop using the device during certain operations, asserting that it poses a danger to patients.

headline: Thinking of Aretha
text: Nineteen sixty-seven was a tough year in many respects  riots, protests, an unwinnable war  but I can’t think of it without thinking of the glory of Aretha Franklin, a woman in her mid-20s, introverted and somewhat shy, who sang soul and rock ’n’ roll with the power and beauty of a heavenly choir.

headline: Spanish Takeover Bid Rattles German Markets
text: Talk about a takeover with a twist: few would believe that a debt-heavy construction conglomerate that relies on the stagnating Spanish economy for most of its revenue could take over a 137-year-old, cash-rich German blue chip.

headline: Turkey: Military Exercises Planned
text: Turkey, Afghanistan and Pakistan agreed to hold a joint military exercises in March and to cooperate against drug trafficking, terrorism and extremism, the presidents of the three countries announced Friday after a summit meeting in Istanbul. High-level military officials and intelligence experts from the three countries met in Ankara earlier in the month to discuss strategy, the Turkish Foreign Ministry said.

headline: Christmas With Lincoln
text: December 25, 1860

headline: A Bittersweet Christmas Story
text: Snow was predicted for Lincoln, and there was every reason to think it would be a really fine Christmas.

headline: The First Lady on the Trail of Santa
text: HONOLULU – While President Obama and daughters Malia and Sasha slipped off to the beach on Christmas Eve, Michelle Obama, the first lady, took care of a little holiday business: answering telephone calls from children inquiring as to the whereabouts of Santa Claus.

headline: Fan’s Unforgettable Day, in Year He’d Like to Forget
text: From his front-row seat in the end zone at Heinz Field last Sunday, Robert Formola watched his favorite football team, the Jets, defeat the Pittsburgh Steelers. He sat with the family of cornerback Darrelle Revis, watched quarterback Mark Sanchez scramble for a touchdown and screamed as the Jets’ defense recorded its final stop as time expired.

headline: Ryan Expects Sanchez to Start Against Bears
text: Barring a significant setback, quarterback Mark Sanchez will start Sunday for the Jets against the Chicago Bears. With a victory, the Jets would clinch a wild-card playoff berth.

headline: Suffer the Little Children
text: As we celebrate this Christmas with the sound of tiny feet rushing toward a tree to rip open presents, let’s take a moment to consider the children less fortunate  the growing number who live in poverty in this country.

headline: Newcomers From Russia Are Reviving a Church
text: Olga Komenko’s girlhood memories live within the walls of the domed and cupolaed Orthodox Church of the Holy Trinity at Pennsylvania and Glenmore Avenues in East New York. There, she danced Thursday evenings away with other young parishioners at weekly socials, wrote letters to servicemen during World War II and was married in 1944.

headline: Redistricting Looms Large in Congress
text: The political jockeying over how to draw new Congressional districts began in earnest this week after new census data showed almost a dozen seats shifting to the South and West, leaving Republicans poised to build on their gains from November’s midterm elections and forcing several northern Democratic incumbents to begin plotting to save their jobs.

headline: Ravens’ Rice Isn’t Bigger, Just Better
text: OWINGS MILLS, Md.  Wilbert Montgomery, the Baltimore Ravens’ 56-year-old running backs coach, has been working with his star pupil, Ray Rice, for almost three years  or long enough for Montgomery and Rice to communicate without even speaking.

headline: G.O.P. to Open House to Electronic Devices
text: WASHINGTON  The iPad is coming to Capitol Hill.

headline: The Street-Level Solution
text: When I was growing up, one of my father’s favorite sayings (borrowed from the humorist Will Rogers) was: “It isn’t what we don’t know that causes the trouble; it’s what we think we know that just ain’t so.” One of the main insights to be taken from the 100,000 Homes campaign and its strategy to end chronic homelessness, which I wrote about in Tuesdays’ column, is that, until recently, our society thought it understood the nature of homelessness, but it didn’t.

headline: To Virginia’s Family, Yes, Santa Claus Is Still Real
text: A 6-year-old girl was sitting in the back seat of her grandfather’s truck last month, debating the existence of Santa Claus. She had questions and theories and logistic concerns, but mostly she had doubts. Her 9-year-old brother in the seat beside her was equally unconvinced. Their grandparents stared silently ahead, pretending not to listen.

headline: Revival of a Church
text: Rev. Vladimir Alexeev has brought life back to the Orthodox Church of the Holy Trinity in East New York.

headline: The Tannenbaum Chronicles
text: This year, my favorite Christmas story involves Rachel Maddow’s mother. “A friend gave her a remote control for the Christmas tree,” said Maddow. It was the best present ever, liberation from a lifetime of crawling under the tree every morning and night to put in or pull out the plug.

headline: 4 Friends’ Toast of 60 Years: Merry Anniversary!
text: Sixty-one years ago, on Christmas Day, two Brooklyn couples held separate weddings in Manhattan. The next morning, before setting off on a joint honeymoon, they met at the Waldorf-Astoria for breakfast.

headline: Past, Present and Yet to Come
text: What are your Christmases made of? A tree full of ornaments as old as you are? A customary feast, if not of roast beast? Perhaps they’re composed of wassail and yule, nog and Nöel, Scrooge, “Scrooged,” Pickwick and Charlie Brown. Or Handel and Berlioz, Garland, Cole, Crosby and Clooney, the Rockettes and the dance of a Sugar Plum Fairy, even Bedford Falls and “The Bishop’s Wife.” To Christians everywhere, Christmas comprises, above all, a decree from Caesar Augustus and in the same country shepherds abiding.

headline: Victim’s Kin Heartened by Commutation Reversal
text: The phone rang at 9 a.m. Friday with unexpected news from Michigan’s governor, and Larry Puma let the relief wash away the pain of the past two days, though not the last 22 years.

headline: With a Spike in Crime and Police Layoffs, Anxiety Deepens in Newark
text: NEWARK  The violence that broke out on St. James Place here on Friday morning had a familiar ring.

headline: When Hockey Moms Lace Up
text: For most of her 44 years, Terri Reid hated hockey.

headline: City’s Horse Racing Channel Flickers Back Onto Screens
text: A few letters on the sign above the door of the off-track betting parlor just below Times Square still flicker neon-red, but the inside is completely dark. Stickers on the door make clear that legal horse betting in a public place no longer exists here or in most parts of the city.

headline: Roy R. Neuberger Dies at 107; Applied a Stock Trader’s Acumen to Art
text: Roy R. Neuberger, who drew on youthful passions for stock trading and art to build one of Wall Street’s most venerable partnerships and one of the country’s largest private collections of 20th-century masterpieces, died on Friday at his home at the Pierre Hotel in Manhattan. He was 107 and had lived in New York City for 101 years.

headline: Looking Forward to a Dorm Room to Call His Own
text: Preston Chaney is a man of few words. If he were given to boasting, he might reveal that he is the first person in his family to graduate from high school, and will be the first to attend college.

headline: David Fay, Director of U.S.G.A., to Retire at End of Year
text: David Fay, whose 21-year tenure as the executive director of the United States Golf Association, the sport’s governing body, has been characterized by an encyclopedic knowledge of the rules, a wry sense of humor and decidedly populist sensibilities, announced in a statement Friday that he would retire at the end of the year.

headline: Sally Goodrich, Who Aided Afghans After 9/11 Loss, Dies at 65
text: Just three months after losing her son Peter on Sept. 11, 2001, aboard United Airlines Flight 175 — the second plane to crash into the World Trade Center — Sally Goodrich received a diagnosis of ovarian cancer.

headline: NATO Night Raid in Kabul Leaves Afghan Guards Dead
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  NATO forces, acting on apparently faulty intelligence, killed two Afghan private security guards and wounded three others in a gun battle early Friday that could lead to renewed criticisms of foreign forces by President Hamid Karzai.

headline: Lottery Numbers
On a Small Scale, Sustainable Energy Transforms Lives
text: Tiny renewable energy systems that light just one home at a time are playing an epic, transformative role in the lives of poor people in developing countries who live far the electricity grid.

headline: Pace Signs Deal to Build a Dormitory in Lower Manhattan
text: Pace University signed an agreement with a developer this week to build a 24-story residence hall in Lower Manhattan as part of a plan to consolidate its far-flung operations and create a downtown campus.

headline: A Coming Assault on the E.P.A.
text: Republicans in the next Congress are obviously set on limiting the Environmental Protection Agency’s authority under the Clean Air Act to regulate a wide range of air pollutants  even if it means denying the agency money to run its programs and chaining its administrator, Lisa Jackson, to the witness stand. Fred Upton, who will become the next chairman of the House Energy and Commerce Committee, says he plans to call Ms. Jackson so often for questioning that he’ll guarantee her a permanent parking space on Capitol Hill.

headline: In N.F.L., a Team’s Wealth Says Little About Its Record
text: Money doesn’t buy everything, especially wins in the N.F.L.

headline: A Playoff Loophole for the Flailing 49ers
text: The San Francisco 49ers are two games away from making history.

headline: At Last, a Border Crackdown
text: After nearly two years of foot-dragging while the death toll in the Mexican drug wars rose beyond 30,000, the Obama administration is finally stepping up the fight against the easy movement of illegal guns across the United States’ border with Mexico and into the hands of violent drug cartels.

headline: Dan Kurzman, Military Historian, Is Dead at 88
text: Dan Kurzman, who wrote military histories that illuminated little-known incidents in World War II and an exhaustively reported account of the first Arab-Israeli war, died Dec. 12 in Manhattan. He was 88 and lived in North Bergen, N.J.

headline: The Police and the Schools
text: School officials across the country are revisiting “zero-tolerance” disciplinary policies under which children are sometimes arrested for profanity, talking back to teachers or adolescent behavior that once would have been resolved in meetings with parents. The reappraisals are all to the good given that those who get suspended or arrested are more likely to drop out and become entangled in the criminal justice system permanently.

headline: Saturday: Santa, Santa, Santa
text: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — Today we have a rare New York Times puzzle from the editor of the Newsday crossword, Stanley Newman. You can learn all about him, his many books and his Crossword University cruises at his Web site. I love this quote: “In 1990, Stan fulfilled a lifelong dream by appearing as a contestant on a TV game show. During his three weeks of appearances on The Challengers, hosted by Dick Clark, his cash winnings totaled $112,000, plus several cases of Rice-a-Roni and Niagara spray starch.”

headline: Evergreen, Ever Delicious
text: Copenhagen

headline: Corrections
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Freed From Prison, Long Island Man Takes to Pulpit
text: CORAM, N.Y.  A Long Island man whose prison sentence in the fatal shooting a 17-year-old in front of his home was commuted by Gov. David A. Paterson said Friday that he was haunted by what he had done.

headline: Our Alzheimer’s Risk: Better to Know?
text: To the Editor:

headline: Boehner’s Tears
text: To the Editor:

headline: Jails Closer to Home
text: To the Editor:

headline: Hospitals Send Bill if Mental Patients Win Suits
text: Daniel J. Langevin was 35, mentally ill and broke. He had been living in psychiatric institutions on and off since his early 20s.

headline: Making Sure Restaurant Workers Get Their Due
text: To the Editor:

headline: Knicks Feeling Fuzzy About Holiday Slot
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  Amar’e Stoudemire is nobody’s Christmas elf.

headline: Photo Replay: Dec. 24
text: Santa on skis, a world record and more.

headline: Karen Tuttle, Violist and Teacher, Dies at 90
text: Karen Tuttle, a violist and teacher whose singular approach to her instrument  which entailed the expression of deep feeling, the attainment of great physical comfort and occasionally the literal rending of garments  drew disciples from around the world, died on Dec. 16 at her home in Philadelphia. She was 90.

headline: Holiday on Saturday Christmas
text: NEW YORK

headline: A Hard-Nosed Leader Emerges in Dallas
text: As the week ended, the Dallas Stars were fighting Detroit for the top spot in the Western Conference, which was surprising because few observers considered Dallas a playoff team this season.

headline: The Early Word: Playing by the Rules
text: From Today’s Times:

headline: Superstitions and a Run at a Super Bowl
text: Dustin Keller is the starting tight end for the Jets. To read about his I Eight One celebration of food, visit his Web site at iEIGHTone.com.

headline: Female Bomber Kills Dozens in Pakistan, Official Says
text: PESHAWAR, Pakistan  A suicide bomber, believed to be a woman, attacked a checkpoint in the northwestern tribal area on Saturday where people displaced by fighting were lining up for food.

headline: For Toronto Fans’ Protest, the Breakfast of Nonchampions
text: As the Toronto Maple Leafs continue to languish near the bottom of the N.H.L. standings, showing no signs of ending their 42-season Stanley Cup drought, an unusual protest developed. A fan identified only as Jack M. by The Toronto Sun threw frozen waffles at the team as it left the ice at Air Canada Centre in Toronto after a loss this month to Edmonton.

headline: Pope Calls for Solidarity With Iraqi Christians
text: ROME  Pope Benedict XVI called Saturday for political leaders to express solidarity with Christians in Iraq and to work for peace in the Middle East and other war-torn regions in his annual Christmas greeting.

headline: A Strong Start by the Mavericks
text: They may not be getting the headlines, but the Mavericks have become one of the hottest teams in the league, winning 16 of their last 17 to give them the second-best record (23-5) in the Western Conference.

headline: All the Ways Your Jewelry Can Disappear
text: In this weekend’s “Wealth Matters” column, Paul Sullivan offers a sobering (though practical) reminder that any fancy new bauble ought to trigger an instinct to insure it. Jewelry tends to disappear more often around this time of year than any other, whether it’s because of theft or mere loss.

headline: Hungary Waves Off Criticism Over Media Law
text: Hungary Prime Minister Viktor Orban, poised to take over presidency of the European Union, is fighting back against criticism from Germany and other countries over a new Hungarian law that some fear could be used to curb press freedom.

headline: Phoenix Abuzz as a Palin Buys a Home Nearby
text: PHOENIX  Bristol Palin, the 20-year-old daughter of Sarah Palin, has bought a five-bedroom house in Maricopa, a modest community south of Phoenix, setting off a flurry of speculation as to exactly what her plans  and those of her famous mother  are for the desert dwelling.

headline: A Firmly Drawn Presidential Line Between Work and Play
text: KAILUA, Hawaii  If there is one thing President Obama craves during his leisure time, it is privacy.

headline: Second Sunday: Wry Tangles
text: Each answer in these puzzles will make one 90-degree turn somewhere along its length. Where it turns, and in which direction, is for you to discover. The starting square for each answer is given, as is its initial direction (north, east, south or west). Every square in the completed grid is used in exactly two answers — no more, no less.

headline: The Job of a Jet Is to Go All Out So Returners Aren’t Able To
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  With less than three minutes left in a game that the Jets led at the time by 3 points, Steve Weatherford hit a less-than-majestic, end-over-end punt that traveled only 29 yards from scrimmage last Sunday at Pittsburgh.

headline: Giants Once Again Have Playoff Hopes and Coach to Save
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  At the end of team meetings the night before particularly big games, Giants Coach Tom Coughlin has tried to pump up his players by showing motivational material: footage of mixed martial arts fights.

headline: Escape From the Deepwater Horizon
text: Caleb Holloway survived the fatal blowout and oil spill. Using 3-D animation, and newly uncovered images, The New York Times reconstructs his escape from the burning oil rig.

headline: China Raises Interest Rates Again to Cool Inflation
text: BEIJING  China’s central bank announced on Saturday that it was raising interest rates for the second time in about two months in what appears to be a long-term campaign to suppress inflation as many ordinary Chinese express discontent with rising consumer prices.

headline: The Résumé? No, Let’s Talk About You
text: This interview with Robert A. Eckert, chairman and chief executive of Mattel, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

headline: Letters: The Charity Incentive
text: Readers respond to “It’s Time to Rethink the Charity Deduction” (Economic View, Dec. 19).

headline: Someday, Store Coupons May Tap You on the Shoulder
text: CLIPPING coupons is a hassle. Intentionally. If shoppers were to redeem any more than just a sliver of them, manufacturers would have a self-created financial catastrophe on their hands.

headline: Fiji? Bermuda? She’ll Take Antarctica
text: THIS is my seventh season conducting research in Antarctica, or working “on the ice,” as we call it. I’m usually here for three months at a time. My current stint, at the Lake Fryxell field camp in the McMurdo Dry Valleys, is for only a month, which is a luxury. But if that sounds as if I don’t enjoy it, that’s not true at all. There’s nothing else I’d rather do.

headline: The Graceful Move You Might Have Missed
text: Dwyane Wade had a television show, too. It was not in prime time, or sponsored, or technically his. But 33 hours before LeBron James made “The Decision” last July, Wade went on ESPN to announce he would re-sign with the Miami Heat.

headline: The New Car With Mystery Add-Ons
text: IT’S the holidays and you want uplift.

headline: Stimulus, Without More Debt
text: THE $858 billion tax package signed into law this month provides some stimulus for our ailing economy. With the unemployment rate at 9.8 percent, more will certainly be needed, yet further deficit spending may not be a politically viable option.

headline: Why Investor Optimism May Be a Red Flag
text: NOW that the market has risen, investors are becoming optimistic again about stocks.

headline: Enough With the Elevator Pitch. What’s the Concept?
text: LOS ANGELES

headline: A Mortgage Nightmare’s Happy Ending
text: TWO and a half years ago, Robert and Amy Ahleman, a construction contractor and a financial services employee, were mired in a mortgage nightmare. After missing just one loan payment on their modest, well-kept bungalow in Bensalem, Pa., the couple began receiving notices from their lender. Default fees and eviction threats followed.

headline: Christmas Cheer Around the World
text: People celebrated Christmas from Lithuania to Afghanistan.

headline: How Superstars’ Pay Stifles Everyone Else
text: This article was adapted from “The Price of Everything: Solving the Mystery of Why We Pay What We Do,” by Eduardo Porter, an editorial writer for The New York Times. The book, to be published on Jan. 4 by Portfolio, examines how pricing affects all of our choices.

headline: A Year of Milestones and Millstones
text: In 2010, celebrations for some, chagrin for others.

headline: Behind the Many Faces of Innovation, 2010
text: LAST week was Doyle Doss’s busiest of the year. An advocacy group for the homeless had called from St. Louis to buy 12 of his Kandle Heeter Candle Holders, which promise “dry, radiant space heat from a candle” for just $29.95 each. He also had a bunch of laminated wildlife portraits — priced at $14.95 and sized to “make your refrigerator happy” — to put in the mail, and so many wearable hummingbird feeders on order that he had to hire part-time help to build them all.

headline: From Cooking to Candles
text: MY parents had high expectations for my sister and me. My father consulted in developing countries for various companies and was an adventurer. He was gone for six months of the year; we’d join him during summer vacation. Once my mother, father, sister and I were dropped off in the bush in Alaska with nothing but small blow-up boats and had to fend for ourselves for a week. We’re all accomplished fishermen.

headline: Firestorm Aboard the Deepwater Horizon
text: The worst of the explosions gutted the Deepwater Horizon stem to stern. Photographs of the burning rig were provided to The Times by a worker on a nearby boat.

headline: Soldiers’ Pictures on Christmas Day
text: A Year at War

headline: How the Rig Crew Responded to the Blowout
text: Video and diagram showing the final moments of the Deepwater Horizon oil rig.

headline: Opponents’ Timeout Calls Put Heavy Wait on Kickers
text: Giants kicker Lawrence Tynes recalls almost nothing of the moment that, but for a lucky break a few minutes later, might have defined his career. The Green Bay Packers called a timeout right before he tried a field goal at the end of regulation of the N.F.C. championship game in the 2007-8 season. Tynes remembers that. And he recalls thinking he should have gone back to the sideline to try a few more practice kicks in the brutally cold weather.

headline: Fears Growing of Mugabe’s Iron Grip Over Zimbabwe
text: HARARE, Zimbabwe  The warning signs are proliferating. Journalists have been harassed and jailed. Threats of violence are swirling in the countryside. The president’s supposed partner in the government has been virulently attacked in the state-controlled media as a quisling for the West. And the president himself has likened his party to a fast-moving train that will crush anything in its way.

headline: Deepwater Horizon’s Final Hours
text: The worst of the explosions gutted the Deepwater Horizon stem to stern.

headline: Molded by Father and Brothers, Sullinger Becomes Star at Ohio State
text: COLUMBUS, Ohio — When the text messages pop up in Ohio State Coach Thad Matta’s phone, they always bring a laugh but barely ever a response. They come from the former Ohio State guard J.J. Sullinger, who simply types, “You’re welcome.”

headline: Taliban Challenge U.S. in Eastern Afghanistan
text: JUMAH KALA, Afghanistan  The villagers gathered on mounds of dirt to watch as the American armored vehicles rolled in. The streets were narrow and banked by high mud walls; the bulky vehicles could barely squeeze through. The villagers had not seen a coalition patrol here in at least two years, they told the American commander as he stepped out to greet them.

headline: Junior Hockey Tournament a Major Happening in Buffalo
text: BUFFALO  It often feels extremely Canadian in this border city, where the Maple Leaf flies alongside the Stars and Stripes in front of City Hall, the average attendance for box lacrosse is 18,000, and the Sabres dominate the wintertime sports news.

headline: Teaching Young Players a Safer Way to Tackle
text: CARSON, Calif.  They walked through dawn’s thick fog to the practice turf  two dozen boys as old as 17 and as young as 9, giving up a Saturday morning to the coach in the Panama hat.

headline: Knicks Savor Joys of Defense
text: The home team wore green and the visitors red, and for one festive afternoon, the Madison Square Garden floor looked like a whirling tornado of Christmas wrap.

headline: After a Diagnosis of Parkinson’s, a Sister Devoted
text: Agneta Welber has lost track of how many home health aides have come and gone over the past five years. Some lasted long enough to “cash a check and not come back.” Others, she said, “took one look and walked out.”

headline: Schools of Hard Knocks
text: HEADLINES on the sports pages in recent years paint a picture of scandal and violence in football: college students playing for pay; recruiters doling out money under the table; professional agents trolling campuses from North Carolina to Southern California. And in both the N.C.A.A. and the N.F.L., crippling tackles cause head injuries bad enough to lead to dementia and suicide.

headline: Ensconced in the Presidency, With No Budging in Ivory Coast
text: ABIDJAN, Ivory Coast  The lush green drive to the president’s residence offers a glimpse of why its current occupant, Laurent Gbagbo, is fighting so hard to stay put. The privilege of this hushed spot is a planet away from the dusty squalor of nearby neighborhoods, where his security forces make nightly raids on his opponents, witnesses and human rights groups say.

headline: Cables Portray Expanded Reach of Drug Agency
text: WASHINGTON  The Drug Enforcement Administration has been transformed into a global intelligence organization with a reach that extends far beyond narcotics, and an eavesdropping operation so expansive it has to fend off foreign politicians who want to use it against their political enemies, according to secret diplomatic cables.

headline: Crossing Over
text: It’s just getting dark here in New Jersey, which means that at just about this time, 234 years ago, George Washington’s men began crossing the ice-filled Delaware, on their way to the battle of Trenton — the battle that saved the American Revolution.

headline: What’s Outside Counts, Too: British Law Spurs Scrutiny of Excess Packaging
text: The citizens of Lincolnshire, England, were so fed up with the layers of plastic and cardboard and Styrofoam that encased their store purchases this fall that they took a high-priced, highly wrapped piece of meat to court.

headline: Cut Here. Invest There.
text: Atlanta

headline: Obama Returns to End-of-Life Plan That Caused Stir
text: WASHINGTON  When a proposal to encourage end-of-life planning touched off a political storm over “death panels,” Democrats dropped it from legislation to overhaul the health care system. But the Obama administration will achieve the same goal by regulation, starting Jan. 1.

headline: In Budget Crunch, Science Fairs Struggle to Survive
text: DARIEN, Ill.  When one team’s model helicopter broke before a recent science competition here, the students made a replacement at the last minute using a pizza box and a rubber band.

headline: Because the Night Belongs to Her
text: I met Patti Smith briefly at the opening of the Metropolitan Opera’s “Ring” cycle last fall.

headline: Dealing in Death, and Trying to Make a Living
text: LOS ANGELES  Body bags go for $20. Yellow crime scene tape is $6. Toe tags are normally $5, but they were sold out this month. The merchandise comes in a white plastic shopping bag that says “Los Angeles County Department of Coroner.”

headline: Californians Are Smoking Less and Less
text: LOS ANGELES  Californians are smoking less than most other Americans.

headline: A Quest to Explain What Grades Really Mean
text: It could be a Zen koan: if everybody in the class gets an A, what does an A mean?

headline: The Big (Military) Taboo
text: We face wrenching budget cutting in the years ahead, but there’s one huge area of government spending that Democrats and Republicans alike have so far treated as sacrosanct.

headline: Morris L. Cohen, Leader Among Legal Librarians, Dies at 83
text: Morris L. Cohen, a book lover who shunned the practice of law because it was too contentious and became one of the nation’s most influential legal librarians, bringing both the Harvard and Yale law libraries into the digital age, died Dec. 18 at his home in New Haven. He was 83.

headline: The Looming Crisis in the States
text: For most of this year, the state of Illinois has lacked the money to pay its bills. Some of its employees have been evicted from their offices for nonpayment of rent, social service groups have laid off hundreds of workers while waiting for checks, pharmacies have closed for lack of Medicaid payments. Faced with $4.5 billion in overdue payments, Illinois has proposed a precarious plan to sell its delinquent bills to Wall Street investors in exchange for cash, calculating that the interest it must pay the investors will be less than the late fees it owes.

headline: Avastin
text: The Food and Drug Administration is preparing to withdraw its approval for using Avastin, a tumor-slowing drug, to treat advanced breast cancers that have spread to other parts of the body. It was a reasonable decision, based on scientific evidence. The drug has failed to extend lives in clinical trials, and it carries a small risk of devastating, sometimes fatal, side effects.

headline: Frank Bessac, Scholar and Adventurer, Dies at 88
text: In 1949, as the forces of Mao Zedong routed the nationalists of Chiang Kai-shek and the Communist revolution spread north and west across the vast Chinese frontier, Frank Bessac, a 28-year-old Fulbright scholar in anthropology, was living among the Mongols near what is now Alashan in the Gobi desert.

headline: The LeBron Effect, in Attendance Figures
text: As if there were a need for more evidence of the hole created by LeBron James’s departure from Cleveland beyond the team’s 8-21 record, there is the effect on dollars from ticket receipts — not for the Cavaliers but for their opponents.

headline: Bartender, I’d Like a Classic, or Maybe a Specialty Drink
text: With the craft-cocktail revolution well under way, skillfully made libations are edging closer to artisan status. Establishments like The Violet Hour and The Drawing Room have shined a national spotlight on Chicago’s mixology scene.

headline: Another Son of a Mayor Takes a Run at Office
text: Mayor Richard M. Daley isn’t running in the Feb. 22 municipal election, but the son of another former mayor is.

headline: Surprise Representative Plans Surprises of His Own in Washington
text: Joe Walsh’s anonymity is dissipating and, by the time it’s gone, we may have an answer to an intriguing political question.

headline: Jailed Soldier Has Support of Resisters
text: The small office of Courage to Resist, a nonprofit group in Oakland, is full of items featuring the smiling face of Pfc. Bradley Manning, the Army intelligence analyst accused of passing secret government documents to WikiLeaks. Bradley Manning T-shirts, buttons, bumper stickers  even whistles  are for sale.

headline: Sunday: Hey, Mister!
text: Note to commenters: This is my final puzzle but a personal farewell post followed this one. Let’s keep the comments here focused on the Sunday crossword.

headline: The Night Escape
text: Charleston Harbor, Dec. 26, 1860

headline: Holidays or Not, Veteran-Led Group Aids Neediest of Veterans
text: The sound of men’s voices echoed through the concrete columns of Lower Wacker Drive, desolate and frigid on a recent stormy Sunday night. Nearby, a homeless Army veteran stuck his head out of his foxhole of thin blankets and piles of tattered clothing, soiled and stained by life on the street.

headline: Hello, I Must Be Going
text: FAREWELL — I’ve been blogging about the Times crossword now for a little over three years and I’ve finally run out of things to say, so this is my 555th and final Wordplay post. All that’s left are some people to thank and, if you’ll allow some nostalgia, a few recollections of my journey.

headline: Bundle Up, It’s Global Warming
text: Lexington, Mass.

headline: State Poised to Sell Trophy Buildings to Unidentified Investors
text: As Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger prepares to decamp from Sacramento on Jan. 3, he has displayed zealous determination to complete what critics say will be among the worst deals the state has ever made: the sale of 11 premier state office complexes to a group of politically connected private investors.

headline: The Dump
text: San Francisco’s garbage dump, the Recology San Francisco Solid Waste Transfer and Recycling Center, does not throw out much trash. The majority of its rubbish gets productively recycled, at the transfer station at 501 Tunnel Avenue or the Pier 96 sorting facility. Recology, an employee-owned company, oversees the complex operation. HANK PELLISSIER

headline: Ending the War to End All Wars
text: NOT many people noticed at the time, but World War I ended this year. Well, in a sense it did: on Oct. 3, Germany finally paid off the interest on bonds that had been taken out by the shaky Weimar government in an effort to pay the war reparations imposed by the Treaty of Versailles.

headline: For Bay Area Economy in 2011, Some Glimmers Amid the Gloom
text: Jonathan Weber writes a regular column for The Bay Citizen.

headline: Banks and WikiLeaks
text: The whistle-blowing Web site WikiLeaks has not been convicted of a crime. The Justice Department has not even pressed charges over its disclosure of confidential State Department communications. Nonetheless, the financial industry is trying to shut it down.

headline: Who Killed the Disneyland Dream?
text: OF the many notable Americans we lost in 2010, three leap out as paragons of a certain optimistic American spirit that we also seemed to lose this year. Two you know: Theodore Sorensen, the speechwriter present at the creation of J.F.K.’s clarion call to “ask what you can do for your country,” and Richard Holbrooke, the diplomat who brought peace to the killing fields of Bosnia in the 1990s. Holbrooke, who was my friend, came of age in the Kennedy years and exemplified its can-do idealism. He gave his life to the proposition that there was nothing an American couldn’t accomplish if he marshaled his energy and talents. His premature death  while heroically bearing the crushing burdens of Afghanistan and Pakistan  is tragic in more ways than many Americans yet realize.

headline: That Over-Investment in Military Tools
text: My Sunday column argues that as we debate budget cuts in the coming year, we should remember that we have invested enormously in military power and far, far less in diplomacy, education and other fields. If we’re trying to figure out how to raise our standard of living, or at least preserve it, the evidence is pretty good that we’ll get a better return on investment in early childhood education than in, say, a military base in Germany.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu: Dec. 26
text: It’s the last Sunday before the new year brings in a new Congress (and with it, more Republicans).

text: NATIONAL

headline: Heat Steals Show in Los Angeles
text: LOS ANGELES  It was billed as the game of the season. The Los Angeles Lakers and the Miami Heat matching up for the first time, with the league’s brightest stars, Kobe Bryant and LeBron James, squaring off.

headline: Obamas Greet Marines at Christmas Dinner
text: HONOLULU — If twice makes tradition, President Obama has a new one for Christmas Day: greeting troops during dinner at the Marine Corps Base Hawaii.

headline: At Title Event, Asian Women Pursue World Domination
text: The Women’s World Chess Championship has provided more evidence of a shift in the balance of power in the women’s game to Asia from Eastern Europe.

headline: Elevator at Brooklyn Hospital Pins a Woman’s Leg
text: A 47-year-old woman was in critical condition after her leg became trapped in an elevator shaft at a Brooklyn hospital on Saturday because of an elevator malfunction, officials said.

headline: Bud Greenspan, 84, Dies; Filmed Olympics in Glory
text: Bud Greenspan, who disdained scandals to write, produce and direct uplifting documentaries about Olympic athletes facing triumph and tragedy, died Saturday at his home in Manhattan. He was 84.

headline: Vows: Katherine & Young
text: Katherine and Young quickly became best friends while attending Cornell. They were hesitant to act on their romantic feeling for one another until Katherine became severely ill.

headline: In an Old Berlin Post Office, a Gallery Flourishes
text: C/O Berlin winkingly acknowledges its location in the Postfuhramt — or (roughly) post office — in its name (“c/o” being postal lingo for “care of”). The space (Oranienburger Strasse 35/36; 49-30-28-09-19-25; www.co-berlin.info) has not been renovated since the days when it was filled with letter carriers. But today, it is filled with communiqués of a different sort: photographs, including, in a current exhibition titled “On Street,” up through Jan. 9, the work of the fashion photographer Peter Lindbergh.

headline: Americans Die in Egypt Crash
text: CAIRO  Eight Americans were killed Sunday when their tour bus collided with a parked truck full of sand on a dimly lighted desert road, passengers said.

headline: A Video Primer on a Safer Way to  Tackle
text: Alan Schwarz of The Times has written  another interesting article in his series on concussions and football safety:

headline: Holiday Travel in Disarray as Huge Blizzard Hits East Coast
text: A rare December blizzard unleashed its fury on the East Coast on Sunday, disrupting holiday travel by air, rail and road in the region and centering its force on the New York metropolitan area by early evening.

headline: What Should Be Done About the N.F.C. West?
text: It’s too late to do anything this season. A 7-9 team could win the N.F.C. West and host a playoff game. In fact, the 49ers, who were in utter disarray at 0-5 and who are now 5-9, are given a 35 percent chance to win the division by NFL-Forecast.com. They just need victories over St. Louis and Arizona and one loss by Seattle. San Francisco could wind up hosting a first-round game against the Saints, who are 10-4. The question is: Should the N.F.L. change its system in the off-season?

headline: Japanese Universities Draw Foreign Students With Manga
text: TOKYO — When Zack Wood produces his illustrated stories online, his Japanese classmates say they look like American comics while his American friends say they look decidedly like manga, the popular form of comics that originated in Japan.

headline: Saying ‘No’ to Excessive Packaging
text: In Sunday’s paper, I write about initiatives in Britain to cut down on excessive or unnecessary packaging on consumer goods. Regulations there now mandate that packaging be held to the minimum needed for “safety, hygiene and consumer acceptance.” Concerned government officials become so serious about tackling the problem that one county, Lincolnshire, began legal proceedings over an overpackaged piece of meat this year.

headline: New York Doesn’t Care to Remember the Civil War
text: It was anything but civil. On Jan. 7, 1861, Mayor Fernando Wood exhorted New York’s Board of Aldermen to declare the city’s independence from Albany and from Washington — a bold stroke of self-preservation that he maintained “would have the whole and united support of the Southern States.”

text: Thank you for your response to our call for snow photos! The submission period is now closed. Check out what we received.

text: Prime Minister Morgan Tsvangirai speaks with Celia Dugger about President Robert Mugabe, the elderly autocrat with whom he shares power.

headline: Despite Snow, Broadway Shows Will Go On
text: 6:44 p.m. | Updated Broadway producers rarely cancel performances because of snow, and Sunday’s storm seems no exception. So far all Broadway matinees will go on, according to the Broadway League, a trade group of theater producers and owners. Several productions added Sunday evening shows for this weekend to try to capture some holiday tourist dollars, and so far those performances are also a go, even though snowfall is expected to be quite heavy by Sunday night.

headline: Surprising Thrashers Find Some Certainty
text: The Atlanta Thrashers, who are battling Tampa Bay and Washington for the top spot in the Southeast Division despite having the lowest payroll in the league, have been a surprise team in the season’s first half.

headline: City of Dust
text: THE ONES LEFT behind, the survivors, remember it as a sound that had no context: the thunder of hoofbeats, thousands of them, or the strange, grinding gears of some monstrous runaway truck.

headline: Carlos Andrés Pérez, Former President of Venezuela, Dies at 88
text: CARACAS, Venezuela — Carlos Andrés Pérez, the former president who tried to make Venezuela a leader of the developing world during a 1970s oil boom only to have his legacy upended in a tumultuous 1989 return to the presidency marked by civil unrest, coup attempts, impeachment and exile, died Saturday in Miami. He was 88.

headline: ‘Spider-Man’ Actor Was Fortunate to Survive, Father Says
text: The injuries suffered by Christopher Tierney in “Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark” could have been far worse if he had not tucked his body and rolled sideways midair as he fell more than 20 feet at Monday’s performance, doctors have told his family. “My understanding is that Chris is fortunate to be alive,” Mr. Tierney’s father, Timothy Tierney, said in a telephone interview on Sunday.

text: The Ice Bowl. The Fog Bowl. The Tuck Rule game.

headline: Simultaneous Chess-Playing Record Set in India
text: India not only has the world champion — Viswanathan Anand — it now has the world record for games played simultaneously.

headline: Shovel Ready
text: Somehow, it’s not as pretty when it’s your own muscles on the line …

headline: Eagles-Vikings Postponed to Tuesday
text: Those of you in the Northeast hoping to hunker down on the couch for tonight’s Eagles-Vikings game better pick out a movie. With more than a foot of snow expected in Philadelphia, the N.F.L. rescheduled the game for Tuesday night.

headline: Jets Clinch Playoff Berth Despite Loss
text: Hold your heads high, Jets fans. As you ponder the split-second decision-making that turned an open Santonio Holmes touchdown into a game-killing interception, don’t forget that there was some good news in Sunday’s 38-34 loss to the Bears.

headline: Bounty Hunter Takes His Skills to the Met Stage
text: Carl Tanner is a truck driver turned bounty hunter turned opera singer making his Metropolitan Opera debut on Monday. Yes, it’s a long story  but that’s only the beginning. He’ll slip into the role of Dick Johnson, the pistol-packing, high-note-hitting romantic lead in “La Fanciulla del West” for one night, almost like a Wild West bounty hunter who rides into town for what’s called in that trade a quick collar.

headline: Proud Parents With Cameras, Clicking Away
text: You might think that Christmas Eve would not the best night to attract an audience to a classical music concert. Think again.

headline: Troubles That Ring True for Women of a Certain Age
text: “Men of a Certain Age,” TNT’s funny, elegant meditation on midlife, which resumed on Monday nights for a second season this month, was created by Ray Romano and Mike Royce (both of “Everybody Loves Raymond”), but it is easy to imagine that these are pseudonyms for two other people entirely  let’s call them Ramona and Michele.

headline: Scholars Say Chronicler of Black Life Passed for White
text: Renown came to Jean Toomer with his 1923 book “Cane,” which mingled fiction, drama and poetry in a formally audacious effort to portray the complexity of black lives. But the racially mixed Toomer’s confounding efforts to defy being stuck in conventional racial categories and his disaffiliation with black culture made him perhaps the most enigmatic writer associated with the Harlem Renaissance.

headline: News of Playoff Berth Thaws Glum Clubhouse
text: CHICAGO  The screams of joy came from the losing locker room, where emotions shifted sharply like momentum at Soldier Field, where smiles replaced frowns, where the defeated players dumped an ice bucket on their head coach in celebration.

headline: Kidnapped Reporter and His Wife, a World Apart, Enduring Their Test
An Overcall Not Made, and an Error That Was
text: Every Wednesday morning at 11 Eastern time two experts play for an hour or more at bridgebase.com with a variety of juniors from around the globe. It is fun to watch and can be as much fun to play.

headline: Readers’ Snow Day Pictures
text: Photographs of the snow on the East Coast.

headline: Winter and Spring Shows for 59E59 Theaters
text: Clifford Chase’s allegorical first novel, “Winkie,” about a teddy bear who comes to life, is arrested on 9,000 charges including terrorism and treason, and befriends a lesbian Muslim cleaning woman, will be presented as a stage play starting in March at Off Broadway’s 59E59 Theaters, the company announced Sunday. “Clifford Chase’s Winkie” is adapted by Matt Pelfrey and directed by Joe Tantalo, whose theatrical troupe, Godlight Theater Company, is producing. The production will run from March 5 to April 10. Among other shows in its winter and spring 2011 season, 59E59 Theaters will present “The Promise,” a thriller by Douglas Maxwell about a retired Glasgow school teacher who emerges as a protector of a 6-year-old Somali refugee who refuses to speak and who is eventually labeled a witch by town leaders. Directed by Johnny McKnight, the production by the Scottish theater company Random Accomplice is scheduled to run March 29 to April 17, to coincide with Tartan Day (April 6) and other celebrations of Scottish heritage in New York.

headline: Vineyard’s Next Plays
text: Next up at Off Broadway’s Vineyard Theater are the new play “Picked” by Christopher Shinn (“Dying City,” “Where Do We Live?”) and a work based on live interviews with audience members conducted by Zach Helm, perhaps best known as the screenwriter of “Stranger Than Fiction.” Mr. Helm’s show will begin preview performances on Feb. 3, open on Feb. 10 and run through Feb. 27. It will be followed by Mr. Shinn’s “Picked,” the story of a young actor dealing with life changes after a famous director casts him as the lead in a big-budget Hollywood movie. “Picked” is scheduled to begin performances in mid-March; members of the cast and creative team will be announced later.

headline: Hefner Is Engaged, Again
text: Merry Christmas, Hugh Hefner! The 84-year-old founder of Playboy gave an engagement ring on Saturday to Crystal Harris, his 24-year-old girlfriend and a Playboy Playmate (the couple, above), Mr. Hefner announced on Twitter. “When I gave Crystal the ring, she burst into tears,” Mr. Hefner wrote. “This is the happiest Christmas weekend in memory.” He later added, just for clarity, that the two were engaged. Mr. Hefner married his first wife in 1949, and they divorced a decade later; he married his second wife in 1989, and their divorce was finalized early this year.

headline: Strong Start for Coen Brothers’ ‘True Grit’
text: Holiday moviegoers were out for blood: Joel and Ethan Coen’s “True Grit” opened to stronger-than-expected results, while the Universal comedy “Little Fockers” underperformed. “Little Fockers,” which cost $100 million to make and generated negative reviews, was No. 1 with about $34 million for the weekend ($48 million total), a soft result that did not meet pre-release estimates. Paramount’s “True Grit,” starring Jeff Bridges as a cranky bounty hunter and made for $38 million, was second with $25.6 million  doubling pre-release projections  for a new total of $36.8 million. “Tron: Legacy” (Disney) fell to third place with about $20 million for a two-week total of $88.3 million, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles box office statistics. “Tron: Legacy,” which carried a $170 million budget and marketing costs of well over $100 million, is struggling to cross over to a broad audience, at least in North America, and must now rely on strong overseas sales for profitability. “The Chronicles of Narnia: The Voyage of the Dawn Treader” (Fox) was fourth with $10.8 million for a new total of about $64 million. “Yogi Bear” (Warner Brothers) was fifth with $8.8 million for a new total of $36.8 million. Also notable were Fox’s “Gulliver’s Travels,” an expensive Jack Black vehicle that bombed in its first weekend with $7.2 million, and “The King’s Speech,” an Oscar hopeful from the Weinstein Company that sold a solid $4.6 million in limited release.

headline: Sunday Church for the Obamas
text: HONOLULU — President Obama, whose Hawaiian vacation has included golfing, beach-going and visiting the troops on Christmas Day — as well as his regular economic and intelligence briefings — took time out Sunday morning to go to church with his family.

headline: On Forgiveness
text: In order to forgive others, victims must put aside revenge. But what are the other conditions of true forgiveness?

headline: Preserving Heritage, and the Fabric of Life, in Syria
text: ALEPPO, Syria — At first glance it seems an unremarkable scene: a quiet plaza shaded by date palms in the shadow of this city’s immense medieval Citadel, newly restored to its looming power. Foreign tourists sit side by side with people whose families have lived here for generations; women, both veiled and unveiled, walk arm in arm past a laborer hauling tools into an old government building being converted into a hotel.

headline: Ship in Israel Raid Returns to Turkey
text: ISTANBUL  Thousands of people gathered along the shores of Istanbul on Sunday afternoon to welcome home the Mavi Marmara, the ship that was raided by Israel as it led a flotilla aimed at breaking the blockade of Gaza.

headline: Iraq’s Wild Ones Are Mainly Looking to Impress
text: BAGHDAD  Just before dusk they begin to arrive, first the motor scooters, then the bigger bikes rolling up in a cloud of leather and noise. For an hour or two each Friday, on a wide boulevard beside the Tigris River, the complexities of Baghdad life give way to a few universal questions: Can I pop a wheelie when people are watching? Can I sneak out of the house without my family noticing? And wouldn’t it be cool if there were girls here?

headline: Monday: TV Intro
text: Did you know every Johnny in today’s theme? I knew the baseball player, country music legend and golfer but was a bit hazier on the singers Nash (I Can See Clearly Now) and Rivers (Secret Agent Man).

headline: The Uranium Conundrum
text: A proposal for a uranium mill in western Colorado is drawing objections from local environmentalists, but to many others in the area, it may be the only hope for economic survival.

headline: Brady Sets a Record, but Can’t Get Home to Celebrate
text: Nothing, it seems, can stop Tom Brady. But not even he can stop the snow.

headline: Necessity Pushes Pakistani Women Into Jobs and Peril
text: KARACHI, Pakistan  Dinner at Rabia Sultana’s house is now served over a cold silence. Her family has not spoken to her since May, when Ms. Sultana, 21, swapped her home life for a cashier’s job at McDonald’s.

headline: Preserving Tradition
text: More photos of the Aga Khan's preservation project in Syria.

headline: Protesting Ethnic Strife in Russia
text: MOSCOW  After weeks of rising tensions, a few thousand people gathered here on Sunday to protest ethnic violence and to call on the authorities to refrain from crackdowns that would curtail Moscow’s diversity.

headline: Women Who Work: Struggling to Provide
text: The Times's Adam B. Ellick examines the rise of lower-class women working service jobs in Pakistan -- despite backlash from male relatives. It's economic desperation vs. religious traditions.

headline: Visitors See North Korea Still Stunted by Its Isolation
text: PYONGYANG, North Korea  Girls’ soccer teams waged a fierce battle outside a huge gymnasium. Two young brides, one resplendent in a white gown and the other in deep pink, married sweethearts in a snowy square. Parents pulled toddlers on plastic sleds. Pedestrians lined up at kiosks to buy baked sweet potatoes and pancakes.

headline: Inside North Korea
text: Sharon LaFraniere on video shot while visiting Pyongyang, North Korea as part of a group traveling with New Mexico Governor Bill Richardson.

headline: On the Move, Despite the Storm
text: Blinding snow and surging winds in the New York metropolitan area and elsewhere on the East Coast left tens of thousands of airline passengers, and even Michael Vick of the Philadelphia Eagles, immobilized, but plenty of other people moved about.

headline: Talking Tech and Building an Empire From Podcasts
text: Balancing on a giant rubber ball in a broadcast studio and control room carved out of a cottage in Petaluma, Calif., Leo Laporte is an unlikely media mogul.

headline: Las Vegas Gets New City Hall, and a Mullet
text: LAS VEGAS  The imposing concrete building, a place now for the recorder of deeds and the seekers of zoning variances, will soon play unlikely host to a company that lists “a little weirdness” among its top 10 values and employs a greeter in the lobby offering free hugs to everyone. Need a nap? Grab a jail cell. And on the wish list of renovations are an indoor ski slope and a pet whale.

headline: For Paterson’s Parents, the Choice Was Independence Over Special Education
text: It is a quandary that parents of disabled children grapple with early and often: What is the right balance between teaching them self-sufficiency and making sure they have the special accommodations they need?

headline: Gadgets Bring New Opportunities for Hackers
text: Researchers at Mocana, a security technology company in San Francisco, recently discovered they could hack into a best-selling Internet-ready HDTV model with unsettling ease.

headline: U.S. Marshals Mishandled Forfeitures, Suit Says
text: An arm of the United States Marshals Service undervalued what could amount to untold millions of dollars in assets forfeited by white-collar criminals  including some from the family of Bernard L. Madoff  and sold them for far less than they were worth, according to a lawsuit filed in federal court in Manhattan.

headline: A Conspiracy Melts Down Into Washers and Dryers
text: GULFPORT, Miss.  The planned overthrow of the United States government ended rather prosaically this fall, with a giant pile of mashed-up trucks in a muddy scrap yard a mile or so off the Interstate.

headline: Irish in New York Look for the Forgotten Elderly
text: At the New York Irish Center’s free Wednesday luncheons for the elderly, the memory of Tony Gallagher  and his sad fate  is never far away.

headline: Taliban Fighters Appear Blunted in Afghanistan
text: WASHINGTON — The deadliest group of Taliban fighters in Afghanistan has not conducted a complex large-scale attack in the capital city of Kabul for seven months, its momentum stymied as elite American-led commandos have escalated raids against the militants’ bomb makers and logisticians.

headline: Eli Manning and the Giants’ Interception Problem
text: Eli Manning threw four more interceptions Sunday in a 45-17 loss to the Packers, extending his league-leading total to 24 and imperiling the playoff hopes of the Giants (9-6) even further.

headline: New Voters May Sway Fed Actions

headline: Conflict Over Squatters Divides Argentina

The residents of Villa Lugano, a scruffy neighborhood on the city’s south side, burn tires and beat drums, while a dozen police officers in fluorescent orange jerseys stand behind a metal barricade, protecting about 90 squatters from the neighbors’ wrath.

headline: The Finite World
text: Oil is back above $90 a barrel. Copper and cotton have hit record highs. Wheat and corn prices are way up. Over all, world commodity prices have risen by a quarter in the past six months.

headline: Women’s Basketball Charts Its Growth on Its Own Terms

Suddenly the frayed clippings were on the floor and she was again Donna Geils, starring for the Queens College women’s basketball powerhouse in the mid- to late 1970s.

headline: Cutler’s Best Quarter Proves Bad Timing for Jets

headline: Hollywood Moves Away From Middlebrow
text: LOS ANGELES — When negative Twitter commentary seemingly torpedoed the Sacha Baron Cohen film “Brüno” in July 2009, movie executives started talking in solemn tones about the ability of social networking to sway attendance. The era of using marketing to trick consumers into seeing bad movies was drawing to a close.

headline: How to Derail Financial Reform
text: Ever since the Dodd-Frank financial reform law was signed in July, the question has been whether it would actually lead to a stable financial system. If the Republicans who will control the House next year get their way, the answer will surely be “no.”

headline: Enlisting the Dying for Clues to Save Others
text: LOS ANGELES  They had told him on his last visit: the experimental drug that had so miraculously melted his tumors was no longer working. His legs were swollen, the melanoma erupting in angry black lumps. The patient, a computer consultant in his 40s, had little time left.

headline: After an Unsettled Adolescence in Foster Care, a Young Woman Finds a Home

headline: Huge Blizzard Halts Travelers on East Coast
text: A monster two-day blizzard barreled up the coast and invaded the New York region and the Northeast on Sunday with barrages of wind-driven snow that closed airports, disrupted rail and highway travel and transformed a dozen states into enchanted and borderless white dreamscapes.

headline: Hurdles Emerge in Rising Effort to Rate Teachers
text: For the past three years, Katie Ward and Melanie McIver have worked as a team at Public School 321 in Park Slope, Brooklyn, teaching a fourth-grade class. But on the reports that rank the city's teachers based on their students’ standardized test scores, Ms. Ward’s name is nowhere to be found.

headline: A Day of Postseason Clarity, for Better or Worse
text: The snow piled up in the Northeast on Sunday night, leaving the Giants and the Jets stranded in the Midwest to contemplate their rapidly clarifying playoff hopes. For the Jets, this was postseason redux, backing into a wild-card spot after losing to the Chicago Bears when the Jacksonville Jaguars lost to the Washington Redskins in overtime. The Jets will take it, of course  they needed plenty of help to get into the playoffs last year and then made it all the way to the A.F.C. Championship game.

headline: Giants’ Postseason Hopes in Jeopardy After Loss

headline: The Repeal Amendment
text: With public attention focused on taxes, the deficit, gays in the military and nuclear arms reduction, little attention has been paid, so far, to the Tea Party’s most far-reaching move to remake American governance. It is contained within a bill, called the repeal amendment, that was introduced in Congress after the election. The bill won the support of the incoming House majority leader, Eric Cantor, and is supported by legislative leaders in 12 states.

headline: California Stations Grapple With PBS Scheduling
text: On Saturday, when KCET-TV stops broadcasting PBS programming after four decades as the primary PBS outlet in Los Angeles, most programs will move to another quickly revamped public broadcasting station in Orange County, KOCE-TV, which has rebranded itself as “PBS SoCal” and scrambled to expand cable system carriage.

headline: Medicaid Bonuses to Reward States for Insuring More Children

headline: British Police Charge 9 Men, Arrested in Raids, With Preparing for Terrorist Acts

headline: Former Russian Tycoon Is Again Convicted
text: MOSCOW  Seven years ago, Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky, Russia’s richest man, was jailed after challenging the authority of Vladimir V. Putin, who wanted the country’s post-Soviet tycoons to stop meddling in politics. On Monday, Mr. Khodorkovsky, still behind bars, was convicted on new charges of embezzlement in a case that has been widely viewed as an indicator of whether Russia will take even modest steps toward establishing a real rule of law.

headline: Singletary Exits but Leaves Lasting Images

headline: The Temporary Vegetarian: Potato and Swiss Chard Gratin

On Monday, there was delicious (but time-consuming) braised red and green cabbage balls, which can be prepared a day in advance; on Wednesday, this golden, bubbling potato gratin with Gruyère and Swiss chard appeared in print, just in time for the holidays.

headline: Blatche and McGee Causing Problems for Wizards
text: The Washington Wizards aren’t exactly equipped to be a league powerhouse, but they were uniquely handicapped in Sunday’s game against the San Antonio Spurs. Going by Player Efficiency Rating (PER) – a one-number measure of player value and efficiency that while limited, is still quite useful – Washington had only one of its top five players at full strength, leaving it with only two healthy players within spitting distance of mediocrity.

headline: Wal-Mart to Invest in Chinese Online Retailer

headline: Mail Bomb Defused at Rome Embassy
text: ROME  Italian demolition experts defused a letter bomb at the Greek Embassy in Rome on Monday, just days after two people were seriously wounded when similar parcels exploded at two other embassies here.

headline: Early Word: Health Insurance, Jon Stewart and Election Battles
text: In The Times:— The Obama administration plans to reward more than $206 million to 15 states for signing up children who are eligible for public health insurance but had previously failed to enroll, Kevin Sack reports.— Sewell Chan anticipates the impact four regional bank presidents of the Federal Reserve might have on the central bank’s monetary policy decisions when they become voting members of the Federal Open Market Committee next year.— In Al Hunt’s Letter from Washington, two retiring Democratic Senators — David R. Obey and Christopher J. Dodd — lament the growing polarization of Congress.— Bill Carter and Brian Stelter liken the comedian Jon Stewart’s role in propelling the 9/11 health care bill to passage to heroic advocacy efforts by Edward Murrow and Walter Cronkite. — Piles of Soviet-era trucks that had indicated — to Gulf Coast conspiracy theorists — a plan by the United Nations to overthrow the United States government landed in a scrap yard this fall, where they will be melted down and reincarnated. Campbell Robertson dug up the story behind the Soviet vehicles and how they ended up in Gulfport, Miss.

headline: Out With the E-Waste, in With the …

But next month, the Lower East Side Ecology Center in New York City plans 10 e-waste recycling events throughout the boroughs at which any type of working or nonworking computers, televisions, DVD players, phones and other gadgets and audiovisual equipment will be accepted from both households and small businesses.

headline: In Massachusetts, Evacuations and Power Cuts
text: BOSTON — The powerful storm that whirled up the East Coast this weekend dropped as much as 20 inches of snow on eastern Massachusetts and caused flooding along the state’s coast, forcing several dozen residents to evacuate their homes, some in the dead of night, and leaving tens of thousands without heat or electricity.
