headline: Just Because One’s Vision Is Waning, Hope Doesn’t Have To
text: Jim Vlock is on a mission. Afflicted 15 years ago with macular degeneration, a retinal disorder that erodes central vision and thus the ability to drive, read, watch television and recognize faces, Mr. Vlock is determined to spread the word about the many devices that can help people like him live more fulfilling, independent and productive lives.

headline: Devices Help the Blind to Read
text: Specialized glasses and a talking watch are among the visual aid devices that have helped people like Jim Vlock, an 84-year-old veteran with macular degeneration, regain the ability to read and go about their daily lives, writes Jane Brody in this week’s Personal Health column.

headline: The Man Behind the Curtain: Lloyd Webber Plans Changes to ‘Wizard of Oz’
text: Having yielded some improved reviews for “Love Never Dies” with his recent changes to that “Phantom of the Opera” sequel, Andrew Lloyd Webber is now tinkering with an older chestnut of a musical that’s apparently in need of some updating: namely, “The Wizard of Oz.” In an interview with The Telegraph of London, Mr. Lloyd Webber said his production of “Wizard of Oz” at the London Palladium, which will star Michael Crawford as the Wizard and Danielle Hope, the winner of a BBC reality competition, as Dorothy, will also have four new songs when it begins previews in February.

headline: Car Bomb Kills 1 and Hurts 26 Near Afghan Police Station

text: The map of the quaint Ohio River town of Elgin Park indicates that, approaching  from the northeast, one could drive in via Koscs Way. The street bearing my surname parallels Boundary Boulevard, which separates Elgin Park from, well, the real world.

headline: Expedia Offers Free Room Upgrades for Top Customers
text: When members of Elite Plus (www.expediaeliteplus.com), Expedia’s frequent-guest rewards program, stay at selected properties, they are automatically upgraded on arrival, if a higher-grade suite is vacant.

headline: Wintry Weather and Global Warming
text: Dec. 28, 1:10 p.m. | Updated Here was the scene out our back door here in the highlands of the Hudson River Valley early Monday morning:

headline: Why Chapter 11 Cases Are Shrinking
text: As recently noted on Dealbook, the Chapter 11 world ended the year with more of a whimper than a bang. Most recently, the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company became the ninth-largest Chapter 11 case of 2010, in a year that had only 15 filings involving assets of more than $1 billion, compared with 45 similar filings in 2009.

headline: 14 Killed in Second Bombing at Iraqi Site
text: BAGHDAD  For the second time this month, suicide bombers on Monday struck a government compound in Anbar Province, after recent large-scale arrests of suspected members of Al Qaeda. At least 14 people were killed and 53 wounded in the attack, a police official said, making it one of the most deadly in nearly two months.

headline: TimesCast | December 27, 2010
text: The Northeast shovels out of the blizzard; the rise of Pakistani women working in the service sector; And an old American sport is gaining new popularity in Israel.

headline: Davis Says He Wants to Stay a Clipper
text: Embattled guard Baron Davis may not get what he wants from the Los Angeles Clippers. Davis, despite public criticism of his fitness and play by Coach Vinny Del Negro and owner Donald Stirling, wishes to stay with team.

headline: WikiLeaks Founder Signs Book Deal
text: Julian Assange, the founder of WikiLeaks, says he will reluctantly write an autobiography next year for Random House and Canongate Books to help pay his legal bills.

headline: Get Set to Do the Super Bowl Shovel
text: Of course, the N.F.L. was right in postponing the Eagles-Vikings game from Sunday until Tuesday evening because of the blizzard on the East Coast.

headline: Numberplay: Living to Eat or Eating to Live?
text: Greetings, folks! Are you enjoying the year-end holidays and eating twice the amount of food that you usually do? I certainly am. One of the things that enables us to do so is that we humans have catapulted ourselves to the top of the food chain. Well, here’s a puzzle that harks back to simpler times when no one species could take that position for granted. This puzzle, which can also be considered an ecological fable, has been suggested to Numberplay by Ravi Kumar Meduri, who also pointed us to the original puzzle on which Octopus Games was based. There is a tragic tale associated with these puzzles, and we relate it after the questions below.

headline: Being a Grandparent Is Better
text: Coming as it did right after Christmas, this latest blizzard means that more than one family is spending extra time together this holiday — what with slick roads and canceled flights.

headline: Third-Generation Kindle Is Top Seller
text: O.K., here goes: when it comes to the Amazon Kindle, I’ll admit it, I was wrong.

headline: Flashy Office Space, Advertising India’s Allure
text: SIRUSERI, India  A massive futuristic office complex is rising from a patch of spare, arid land here near the southern Indian city of Chennai. Six butterfly-shaped buildings dock like spacecraft to two long metal-latticed terminals.

headline: Aging: Paying the Physical Price for Longer Life
text: Americans are living longer, but those added years are more likely to be a time of disease and disability.

headline: Perceptions: Positive Spin Adds to a Placebo’s Impact
text: Can taking a placebo be effective even if the patient knows it is a placebo? A new report suggests the answer is yes.

headline: Nutrition: At Home, Influence Wanes on Child Diets
text: Parents may think they can set a good example for their children by eating a healthy diet themselves, but a new analysis finds that it may not work.

text: As the Giants began a fateful final week of the season, they remained unable to get away from their haunting 45-17 loss to Green Bay.

text: Q. A friend has hemochromatosis, a common genetic disorder that is treated by regular drawing of blood. Can that blood be donated?

headline: Julian Assange’s 1.3 Million Reasons to Write
text: While some banks and credit-card companies have gone to great lengths to cut off the flow of money to WikiLeaks, one company, Random House, has doubled down, paying both its founder and its former spokesman to write insider memoirs about the online publishing platform.

headline: A Diet Manifesto: Drop the Apple and Walk Away

headline: WikiLeaks Founder Signs Book Deal
text: LONDON  Julian Assange, the founder of WikiLeaks, will release an autobiography next year, having signed publishing deals that he told a British newspaper might be worth $1.7 million.

headline: Another Knock Against Google’s Deal-Making
text: Google’s $700 million acquisition of ITA Software, which powers many of the Web’s most popular travel search engines, has ruffled more than just a few feathers in the travel industry, The New York Times’ colleague Mickey Meece wrote on Monday.

headline: A Doctor in Iraq, Watching a Faith Healer at Work
text: IRBIL, Iraq  “Are you a Muslim, Dr. Amir?”

headline: A Writer Traces Illnesses Back to the Womb
text: NEW HAVEN  When the medical journalist Annie Murphy Paul’s first son was a toddler, she started wondering how personality traits are passed from one generation to the next. So she did what any reporter would do: she delved into the scientific literature and talked to investigators.

headline: Snowfall Totals
text: Snowfall totals in the metropolitan area as of 10 a.m. on Monday.

headline: The Top Political Moment of 2010? Nominations, Please
text: Have a thought on the key political moment of 2010? We would like to know what you think stood out amid the political background noise of the last 365 days.

headline: Anthony Howard, Political Commentator in Britain, Dies at 76
text: Anthony Howard, one of Britain’s most prominent and respected political commentators and the editor of The New Statesman in one of its most brilliant periods, died on Dec. 19 in London. He was 76 and lived in London and Ludlow, Shropshire.

headline: Ristretto | Rise of the Machines
text: Last week, Blue Bottle Coffee in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, inaugurated a restored Urania, a lever-operated Faema espresso machine. This one was built in 1958. If a machine can have karma, 52 years of making espresso should accrue some cosmic good will.

headline: Calling Your Bank Collect from Outside of the U.S.
text: If you’re traveling abroad this holiday season or in the coming cold-weather months, be sure to bring instructions for calling the United States collect.

headline: Expert Answers on Alopecia
text: In today’s Science Times, Claudia Dreifus interviews Angela Christiano, a researcher who began studying hair loss after a hairdresser discovered a bald spot at the back of her head. She has since discovered several genes that contribute to alopecia areata, a fairly common condition that causes hair loss, either in discrete patches or all over the body.

headline: That’s Jets Football, and Fans Are Along for the Ride
text: In New England, Patriots fans are celebrating consistency; in Kansas City, Chiefs fans are celebrating perseverance. In St. Louis, Rams fans are celebrating hope.

headline: Kale Salad With Apples, Cheddar and Toasted Almonds or Pine Nuts
text: For a kale salad to be successful, use the most tender kale you can find and cut it into very thin filaments or chop it very finely (or both). Curly kale and Russian kale are more tender than black leaf kale. This is inspired by a wonderful salad I tried recently at the New York restaurant Northern Spy.

headline: Partying Like It’s 1923: Or, The Weimar Temptation
text: There’s an observation I’ve tried to make in a number of columns and blog posts, but maybe haven’t gotten across as clearly as I should: namely, the extent to which current economic discourse is being warped by what we might call the Weimar Temptation, the desire to see everything in terms of the evils of deficits and the money printed to cover them.

headline: Tesla’s Stock Drops After Lock-Up Period Ends
text: It wasn’t a very merry Christmas for Tesla.

headline: Thursday Night Lights
text: In Israel, a full-padded American football league is gathering a small following and creating an alternative to soccer and basketball.

headline: Disney Tackles Major Theme Park Problem: Lines
text: ORLANDO, Fla.  Deep in the bowels of Walt Disney World, inside an underground bunker called the Disney Operational Command Center, technicians know that you are standing in line and that you are most likely annoyed about it. Their clandestine mission: to get you to the fun faster.

headline: The Penthouse Apartment Is Taken Down a Notch
text: Adrian Lupu never longs for more light in his 10th-floor apartment in Long Island City, which is known as “PH1001.” He has sweeping city views, hears no traffic noise from below and, as the sun sets, he can stare out at No. 7 trains snaking toward Manhattan that look tiny enough to scoop into his hands.

headline: Ryan Says Sanchez May Start Final Game
text: CHICAGO  The Jets are not strangers to strange seasons, even in years that culminate in postseason appearances.

headline: Malaria: A Disease Close to Eradication Grows, Aided by Political Tumult in Sri Lanka
text: Malaria cases jumped 25 percent in Sri Lanka from 2009 to 2010, the country’s ministry of health is reporting. And while this year’s total is still small, at 580, the trend is unsettling to experts.

headline: Durant, Thunder Gather Momentum at Right Time
text: Sift through any premature breakdown of this year’s race for most valuable player, and you find one name conspicuously absent. Kevin Durant, after a summer of Team USA competition, quiet humility, and public relations goodwill, started the season a bit slowly. By Durant’s standards, this means he’s averaged a gaudy 27.3 points per game, but in a slightly less efficient manner than we’ve all grown accustomed.

headline: Difference Is the Norm on These Dating Sites
text: Sherry Nevius, single and 52, is looking for a mate with all the important adjectives — caring, sincere, intelligent, funny. Oh, and one more thing: disabled.

headline: Online Dating With a Difference
text: No matter who you are, finding the perfect mate can be a challenge. If you are disabled or living with a chronic illness, dating can be especially distressing. Between the stigma of illness and the limitations posed by a disability, finding the right person to spend a life with can take on a whole new dimension.

headline: Pakistan Food Program Set to Resume
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  A food relief program was expected to resume soon in the northwestern tribal region of Bajaur, where a suicide bomber killed 46 people outside a World Food Program center on Saturday, according to officials.

headline: American Football Gains a Following in Israel
text: JERUSALEM  On a Thursday night early in December, Pinchas Zerbib took off his traditional cotton skullcap. In its place, he put on a polyester one.

headline: The Outsourcing Battle
text: In a country that produces 500,000 engineers each year, the latest construction spree by India’s top outsourcing companies aims to attract the best and the brightest software programmers.

headline: DealBook Portraits: Robert H. Benmosche
text: Robert H. Benmosche, the president and chief executive officer of American International Group, left retirement to take the helm of the troubled company. He reflects on his unlikely path to the top.

headline: In the Job-Starved West, a Debate Over Uranium’s Legacy
text: Is uranium dangerous? The question itself is probably enough to start a fight, depending on where it is asked.

headline: Producers Will Get Back Their Money, and Then Some, As ‘Rain’ Recoups
text: “Rain: A Tribute to the Beatles on Broadway” has recouped its initial investment of $2 million in seven weeks, the show’s producers announced on Monday. The biographical show, with four cast members impersonating the Beatles in a concert setting, opened on Oct. 26 at the Neil Simon Theater.

headline: Unearthing Prehistoric Tumors, and Debate
text: When they excavated a Scythian burial mound in the Russian region of Tuva about 10 years ago, archaeologists literally struck gold. Crouched on the floor of a dark inner chamber were two skeletons, a man and a woman, surrounded by royal garb from 27 centuries ago: headdresses and capes adorned with gold horses, panthers and other sacred beasts.

headline: DealBook Portraits: Robert H. Benmosche
text: Robert H. Benmosche, president and chief executive of the American International Group, reflects on his unlikely path to the top, his health and the insurer’s efforts to repay taxpayers in the first installment of DealBook Portraits, a new video series focusing on top deal makers and other Wall Street luminaries.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Afghanistan and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Afghanistan, New York and Russia.

headline: Turkey: Not Just for Thanksgiving
text: To often, cooks think about what to make with turkey only when faced with a deluge of Thanksgiving leftovers. Your refrigerator may still be stuffed with them even now, well after the holiday. But there are plenty of other reasons for cooks to get better acquainted with turkey. ﻿

headline: Traders Commuted Sunday to Keep Exchange Open
text: Trading volume may have been light on the New York Stock Exchange on Monday after the city was blanketed by 20 inches of snow — but at least there was trading.

headline: Snowstorm Takes its Toll on Broadway
text: The snowstorm could not have come at a worse time for Broadway.

headline: 36 Banks Provide A.I.G. With Credit
text: The struggling insurance giant American International Group said on Monday that it had signed credit lines worth $4.3 billion with 36 lenders  in yet another step by the company to get off government life support.

headline: Footnote
text: The tenor Matthew Polenzani, who was already scheduled to sing the role of Alfredo in the Metropolitan Opera’s production of “La Traviata” for five performances this season, will now sing the role in all nine, the Met said. He replaces Francesco Meli, who the Met said has withdrawn because of illness. The first performance will be Friday night; Mr. Polenzani will replace Mr. Meli in the performances scheduled for Jan. 19, 22, 26 and 29.

headline: Football Postponement Scrambles TV Results
text: With the blizzard forcing the rescheduling of NBC’s “Sunday Night Football,” below, in Philadelphia, CBS topped the ratings on Sunday night with repeats of “60 Minutes,” “Undercover Boss” and crime shows. According to Nielsen’s estimates “60 Minutes” (11.8 million viewers) delivered the night’s largest audience; it was followed by “Undercover Boss” (8.4 million), “CSI: Miami” (6.9 million) and “The Mentalist” (7.3 million). Fox finished close behind, benefiting from an overrun of its afternoon football coverage that meant that nearly 20 million viewers were tuned in to the network in the first half of the 7 p.m. hour. Fox drew more modest ratings the rest of the night for reruns of its animated comedies, including “The Simpsons” at 8 (6.4 million) and “Family Guy” at 9 (5.3 million). A new episode of Fox’s “Running Wilde” garnered only 3 million viewers at 9:30. ABC was third, attracting 6.2 million viewers for its holiday broadcast of “The Sound of Music.” NBC ranked fourth with reruns of “Minute to Win It” (4.4 million) and “Law & Order: SVU” (3.8 million) in lieu of football.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Afghanistan and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Afghanistan, New York and Russia.

headline: Critics' Picks: 'Waking Life'
text: A.O. Scott reviews Richard Linklater's unclassifiable 2001 cartoon philosophy seminar.

headline: Neo-Soul Setting for Old-School Soul Voice
text: KANDI

headline: Small Town, Big Word, Major Issue
text: LITTLE FALLS, N.Y.  This small city up the hill from the Erie Canal is known for manufacturing paper and tea, for rooting on its Mounties at high school football games, for deposits of quartz that glint like diamonds and for the Victorian mansion that houses its 100-year-old library.

headline: Teena Marie, 1980s R&B Hitmaker, Dies at 54
text: Teena Marie, a singer whose funky hits in the 1980s, like “Lovergirl” and “Square Biz,” made her one of the few white performers to consistently find success on the rhythm-and-blues charts, died on Sunday at her home in Pasadena, Calif. She was 54.

headline: ‘The Metropolis Case’
text: After Maria started kindergarten at St. Anne’s, it quickly became clear that she was anything but normal. Her fellow five-year-olds were less than charmed by her tendency to walk like a penitent and to murmur in Latin, and she could not fade into the background when she was the tallest in her class, with skim-milk blue skin and straight black hair that reminded the other children of spider legs. One of the girls told everyone that Maria’s green eyes were the same color as her cat’s, which confirmed a collective sense that Maria was not quite of them, particularly after she made the mistake of telling them she was adopted.

headline: To Wagner, With Love and Morbidity
text: A brooding seventh grader whose pallor and bad attitude have earned her the nickname Morticia, Maria knows that her love of music  which takes her “to mountains and lush islands and most of all great, teeming cities”  sets her apart from the other kids.

headline: Amid Inquiries, Experts Get a Cold Shoulder
text: Authorities arrested Don Chu, a Primary Global Research executive from Somerset, N.J., at 6:05 a.m. on Nov. 24. Within 24 hours, employees halfway around the world in the expert-network firm’s Manila office received a directive from their chief: stop recruiting outside consultants and do not return to work until Dec. 2.

headline: The Arts in 2010
text: With its costs and its casualties (including Christopher Tierney, standing above), “Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark” became the most scrutinized new show on Broadway this year, though it’s still in previews.

headline: A Cultural History of the Moon
text: Images from the book “Moon” depict the cultural history of the Earth’s natural satellite “through history, science and literature.”

headline: Exploring Our Relationship With the Lonely Moon
text: The Moon is Earth’s only satellite, a quarter of its size, moving around our home planet in cold and lifeless isolation, in an orbit that increases an inch and a half a year.

headline: Triplets, 7, Win a National Chess Title
text: Sometimes, Katerina Varsou needs to work or needs a break from playing with her sons, Andreas, Nicholas and Constantine Oskiper, 7-year-old fraternal triplets. So she tells them to amuse themselves.

headline: Mexico: Family of Dead Activist Flees to U.S.
text: The relatives of an activist who was shot dead outside the Chihuahua state government’s office have fled to the United States, state officials said Monday. Marisela Escobedo was killed on Dec. 16 as she mounted a vigil demanding the arrest of the man who confessed to killing her daughter Rubí. The suspect, Sergio Barraza, was freed by a court in April. The decision was later reversed by a higher court, but by then he had vanished. Graciela Ortiz González, the state secretary for government, said Monday that family members had crossed the international bridge to El Paso, Texas, despite state offers of protection.

headline: Here Are the Snows of Yesteryear
text: Though few blizzards have surpassed the one we’re digging out from now, several have rivaled it. And almost every season has a snowstorm or two that lodge in memory — at least, until the next one comes along. Paradoxically, they are at once photogenic and monotonous. It takes imagination and a sharp eye to find a moment that stands apart. This is a gallery of such moments culled from the work of Times photographers, beginning with the blizzard of 1996.

headline: Nuclear Builders Keep Their Options Open
text: The nuclear construction business looks highly uncertain at the moment, but companies that are interested in building are still keeping their options open, and spending money to do so.

headline: Critics’ Picks Video: ‘Waking Life’
text: This week A. O. Scott takes a look at Richard Linklater’s 2001 film “Waking Life,” which turned the streets of Austin into a surreal dreamscape.

headline: Crossing the Finish Line for Cacao’s Genetic Map
text: This year, a team of researchers financed by the candy maker Mars announced that they had, for the first time, completely sequenced the DNA of a cacao tree, which produces the main ingredient in chocolate.

headline: My Anxiety in Flight, After Free Fall in an Elevator
text: I’LL be the first one to admit that I’m not a great frequent flier. It’s not just the delays and cancellations; it’s actually the process of flying.

headline: Baghdad on Two Wheels
text: Just in case you missed it, our colleague John Leland had a piece in today’s Times on the return of bike culture in the Iraqi capital. The riders, both Sunni and Shiite, come to a wide boulevard beside the Tigris River on Friday nights. And tricks, not the complexities of Baghdad life, ruled the night.

headline: An Accuser Becomes the Accused
text: A year and a half after the killing of a prominent human rights advocate in Russia, no suspects have been arrested. But her outspoken colleague is being charged with criminal defamation.

headline: Retail Sales Rebound, Beating Forecasts
text: Americans are splurging as though it’s 2007 again.

headline: Living and Studying Alopecia
text: Angela Christiano, 45, an associate professor of dermatology and genetics at Columbia University Medical Center, studies hair. Last summer, she announced the discovery of the genes implicated in alopecia areata, the hair-loss disease that she herself suffers from. We spoke for two hours in her Washington Heights laboratory and then later on the telephone. An edited version of the two conversations follows.

headline: A Hair Loss Researcher With Purpose
text: Angela Christiano, an associate professor of dermatology and genetics at Columbia University Medical Center, studies the genetics of alopecia areata, a condition that causes sudden hair loss. Her work has led to the discovery of several genes implicated in the disease. What makes Dr. Christiano’s work unique, however, is that she has personally suffered from the hair loss of alopecia.

headline: Sotomayor Guides Court’s Liberal Wing
text: WASHINGTON

headline: Gaza Flotilla Activists Ejected From New York Gallery
text: Updated | Saturday | 12:17 p.m. Four activists from a group called U.S. Boat to Gaza were forced to leave an art gallery in New York this month for wearing T-shirts with the title of the show they were viewing, “Next Year in Jerusalem,” by the German artist Anselm Kiefer, written in English, Hebrew and Arabic.

headline: In Trenton, Emergency Puts Senator Back at Helm
text: Stephen M. Sweeney said he never expected to be running New Jersey again, but there he was on Sunday, with a severe snowstorm in progress, declaring a state of emergency.

headline: In Pursuit of a Mind Map, Slice by Slice
text: CAMBRIDGE, Mass  Dr. Jeff Lichtman likes his brains sliced thin  very, very thin.

headline: An Off-Kilter City, Marooned in Powdery Dunes
text: There were streets with snow piled tight and high against the chilly skyscrapers like mini-ski slopes. And then around the corner, barely anything at all. One street Vermont; the next Oklahoma.

headline: The Thinnest Cut: A Device for Discovery
text: As a graduate student, Kenneth J. Hayworth had a most unusual hobby: He built brain-slicing machines in his Los Angeles garage.

headline: Life in the Deep Field
text: Jeff Vervoort, left, an associate professor in radiogenic isotope geochemistry at Washington State University, and John Goodge, a professor of geological sciences at the University of Minnesota-Duluth, are writing from their research expedition in Antarctica.

headline: Economic Optimism? Yes, I’ll Take That Bet
text: Five years ago, Matthew R. Simmons and I bet $5,000. It was a wager about the future of energy supplies  a Malthusian pessimist versus a Cornucopian optimist  and now the day of reckoning is nigh: Jan. 1, 2011.

headline: A New Team Helps Steer Restaurateurs Through a Thicket of Red Tape
text: Opening a restaurant in New York City can be as frustrating as trying to brown a wet sirloin. Given worries over fire safety, food-borne illness and waste disposal, a new restaurant may have to contend with as many as 11 city agencies, often with conflicting requirements; secure 30 permits, registrations, licenses and certificates; and pass 23 inspections.

headline: Those Doorman Thank-You Notes Never Quite Said It Right
text: During the years I lived in a doorman building in Murray Hill, I remember devoting what seemed like a good part of a day to tipping the men who worked there, usually a day or two after Christmas, regrettably, but always before the New Year. There was the often snowy trek to the bank and back, the late shopping for Christmas cards, and then the writing of thank-yous, some of them more elaborate than others.

headline: Lawmakers Finance Pet Projects Without Earmarks
text: WASHINGTON — No one was more critical than Representative Mark Steven Kirk when President Obama and the Democratic majority in the Congress sought passage last year of a $787 billion spending bill intended to stimulate the economy. And during his campaign for the Illinois Senate seat once held by Mr. Obama, Mr. Kirk, a Republican, boasted of his vote against “Speaker Pelosi’s trillion-dollar stimulus plan.”

headline: Managing Scientific Inquiry in a Laboratory the Size of the Web
text: Hanny van Arkel had been using the Galaxy Zoo Web site less than a week when she noticed something odd about the photograph of IC 2497, a minor galaxy in the Leo Minor constellation. “It was this strange thing,” she recalled: an enormous gas cloud, floating like a ghost in front of the spiral galaxy.

headline: Republican Challenging Alaska Senate Result Shifts Course
text: Joe Miller said late Sunday that he would no longer try to prevent the certification of the Alaska Senate race, but he did not concede and he did not congratulate the unofficial winner, Senator Lisa Murkowski.

headline: After-School Arts Education Gives Lower East Side Students a Lift Academically
text: Ten-year-old Destiny Howard swaggers onstage, flinging her arms overhead in exaggerated disgust.

headline: A Venezuelan Oasis of Elitism Counts Its Days
text: CARACAS, Venezuela  The golfers still argue over handicaps. The waiters still serve flutes of Moët & Chandon. Sunlight still kisses the grounds laid out in the 1920s by Olmsted Brothers, the esteemed American landscape architects.

headline: Chasing Heat With Wrecking Ball
text: Before the Miami Heat could rise and despair could set in, N.B.A. executives and fans began reaching for coping mechanisms last summer.

headline: The Mysterious Predictions of a Governor’s Psychic
text: David A. Paterson, New York’s soon-to-be former governor, has given a bunch of farewell interviews in recent weeks, some of them reflective, some wistful and some, to be frank, a tad whiny about why things didn’t always go right for him.

headline: South Florida at Play: Sun, Sand and Chill
text: MIAMI  Floridians, who giddily track winter weather reports from the North, woke up Monday prepared to revel in their snow-free sidewalks and high-Fahrenheit fortunes. Another meteorological bullet dodged, chirped the snowbirds.

headline: 2 Senators Raise Questions on Use of Medtronic Device
text: Two senators are raising new questions about an experimental use of a Medtronic device in spinal surgery on veterans and soldiers at the Walter Reed Army Medical Center from 2002 to 2004.

headline: The Big Chill
text: Miami’s reputation for balmy winters has suffered an unexpected blow this month: waves of cold weather. With wind chills factored in, the temperature has repeatedly sunk to the mid-30s, far below average. Hats and scarves have replaced shorts and tank tops. And cold-induced crankiness has become common.

headline: Lottery Numbers
U.S. Entices Big Banks in Canada
text: OTTAWA — The Bank of Nova Scotia is sometimes praised for having a nearly perfect record with its investments in the United States. But it is the only one of Canada’s five large banks that has largely avoided the American market.

headline: Mets Acquire Backup Infielder
text: The Mets made another low-key move Monday, acquiring Chin-Ling Hu, a shortstop with little major league experience who team officials hope can be their backup middle infielder. Hu, 26, was acquired from the Los Angeles Dodgers for the minor league left-hander Michael Antonini.

headline: Decision on Transgender Player
text: More than two months after a transgender woman sued the Long Drivers of America claiming discrimination, the group said in a statement that it planned to follow a recent rule change by the L.P.G.A. and allow transgender women to compete. But the Long Drivers of America also said it had no plans to conduct any women’s long-drive events in the future but would allow women to compete in open or senior men’s events. It did not rule out future women’s events.

headline: Companies Promote Health and Brands, Making Playgrounds
text: MARKETERS like Kraft Foods, MetLife, CVS and Dr Pepper/Snapple Group are steering millions in charitable dollars to a new and somewhat unlikely project — building neighborhood playgrounds for children.

headline: Mets Acquire Backup Infielder
text: The Mets made another low-key move Monday, acquiring Chin-Lung Hu, a shortstop with little major league experience who team officials hope can be their backup middle infielder. Hu, 26, was acquired from the Los Angeles Dodgers for the minor league left-hander Michael Antonini.

headline: Photo Replay: Dec. 27
text: A view of the day in sports, from stormy seas to snowy practice sessions.

headline: Shoring Up Banks So None Fail
text: The “too big to fail” problem among banks will be partly fixed in 2011.

headline: Alcatel-Lucent Penalized by U.S.
text: Alcatel-Lucent agreed to pay $137 million to resolve federal criminal and civil investigations into accusations that it had paid bribes in Costa Rica, Taiwan and Kenya.

headline: Three Flags
text: Charleston, S.C. Dec. 28, 1860Dawn broke that morning to reveal three flags above Charleston Harbor: the palmetto, the star, and the Stars and Stripes. Each bore its own bellicose message.

headline: Narrative and the Grace of God: The New ‘True Grit’
text: Movie critic Dan Gagliasso doesn’t like the Coen brothers’ remake of the Henry Hathaway-John Wayne “True Grit.” He is especially upset because the moment he most treasures — when Wayne, on horseback, takes the reins in his teeth and yells to Lucky Ned Pepper (Robert Duvall), “Fill your hand you son-of-a-bitch” — is in the Coens’ hands just another scene. “The new film,” Gagliasso complains, “literally throws that great cinematic moment away.”

headline: Cheaters Find an Adversary in Technology
text: Mississippi had a problem born of the age of soaring student testing and digital technology. High school students taking the state’s end-of-year exams were using cellphones to text one another the answers.

headline: Choreographing a Snowplow Ballet, to Mixed Reviews (Again)
text: In the city’s plan, it is envisioned as something like a ballet of behemoths, with a fleet of more than 2,000 garbage trucks swooping through the streets, brushing aside tons of snow as quickly as possible. But like most things in New York, each snowstorm brings a flurry of disagreement over how well that production has come off.

headline: Somalia: Rebel Leader Threatens U.S.
text: A senior leader of the Shabab rebels threatened on Monday to attack the United States and urged President Obama to join Islam. The leader, Sheik Fuad Mohamed Khalaf, said he would send a message to America, which fought against God. “We are united to put you in misery, and anyone who fights against God will not get help,” Sheik Khalaf said. The Shabab, who seek to overthrow the weak transitional federal government here, are not known to have carried out attacks outside of Somalia except for a pair of bombings in Uganda in July that they claimed responsibility for. Sheik Khalaf also addressed Mr. Obama, saying: “Give in and join Islam. God will reward you twice, or you will go the way former leaders like those who fought against Islam went.”

headline: Blizzard, and Inflexibility, Knock Out Air Travel
text: ALWAYS look on the bright side of life, suggested G. Bruce Hedlund, who has been a pilot for a major domestic airline for over a quarter century. Actually, being an airline captain, Mr. Hedlund is of a breed that seldom looks on the bright side of anything, but at least he is trying, given the current travel havoc caused by the bad weather.

headline: Blizzards and Business Don’t Mix, but a Little Planning Can Help
text: In the Bronx, hundreds of thousands of pounds of meat came to a standstill. On Broadway, one of the busiest times of the year was anything but, and near Wall Street, traders were taking over downtown hotels to make sure they would be at work when the bell rang.

headline: East Digs Out After Blizzard Leaves a Trail of Disruption
text: Airports and railroads limped back to life, but thousands were still stranded. Roads remained glazed and city streets choked with snow. Subways and buses ran sporadically. Power was still out for thousands. Business was bad, and there were grim tales of people snowbound for hours in cars, buses and trains.

headline: Dolphins Know Where It All Went Wrong
text: Plenty of teams are wondering what might have been as they prepare for Week 17 — yeah, we’re looking at you, Dallas and Houston — but the Dolphins’ tumble from preseason contender to late-season punch line can almost certainly be traced to their 1-7 record at home.

headline: Stranded on the Subway, Some Through the Night
text: Around 9 p.m. on Sunday, Grigoriy Zilbergleyz, 64, bid farewell to a friend he was visiting on the Upper West Side of Manhattan and began his journey home to Bensonhurst, Brooklyn. He hopped on a C train, transferred to a D and was riding on an aboveground N when he called his wife around 10:55 to let her know that he was only three stations away.

headline: N.B.A. in India, in Search of Fans and Players
text: NEW DELHI  The success of N.B.A. Commissioner David Stern’s 25-year crusade to globalize basketball is often summed up in two words: Yao Ming. After Yao, a 7-foot-6 center from Shanghai, was drafted by the Houston Rockets in 2002, the league attracted hundreds of millions of new fans in China. And though Yao is out for the season with a stress fracture that could end his professional career, the N.B.A.’s international march continues.

headline: Optimism for Obama Should Come With Caution

headline: In Russia, an Advocate Is Killed, and an Accuser Tried
text: MOSCOW  In a small courtroom in Moscow, friends of Natalya K. Estemirova crowded onto wooden benches, clasping photographs of her. It was 16 months after the murder of Ms. Estemirova, a renowned human rights advocate in the tumultuous region of Chechnya, and now the legal system was taking action.

headline: The White Coast
text: Call it the Boxing Day storm, the blizzard that slithered up the East Coast on the night after Christmas and into the next morning. Like other historic blizzards  1978 and 1993 come to mind  this one carried a blunt message: stay indoors and stay put. Staying put was not hard to do on Monday. Nearly every mode of transportation in and around New York City, and much of the East Coast, had been suspended or was severely hampered. This was all the more troublesome because it caught so many holiday travelers in transit.

headline: A Step Toward Fairness
text: This country continues to pay a high price in both security and reputation for the Bush administration’s many violations of international law at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba. After more than a year of review, the Obama administration is preparing an executive order intended to resolve the situation of four dozen prisoners in the prison there who are caught in a legal limbo: they cannot be freed because they are considered a potentially serious terrorist threat, and they cannot be tried because the evidence against them is classified or was improperly obtained, often through torture.

headline: On Our Radar: Liquified Gas Imports Climb in Britain

headline: Letters: The Year in Ideas
text: The cover of the “The Year in Ideas” (Dec. 19) closed out the decade with a delightful conflation of change and continuity. Our two children pulled out their smartphones, scanned in the balloon Q.R. code and treated their parents to the animated primer on wind-power innovation. The science was succinctly educational, and the smiling birds, bats and bees were ecologically hopeful. Once we finished viewing all the animations, we were ready for the video unpacking the cover’s mandala-like code. Upon seeing the mindful construction of the artwork and its gleeful deconstruction, one of us exclaimed, “Hey, this is high-tech rangoli.” For centuries, Indian folk artists have used rice flour to meticulously create auspicious motifs that would be swept away by the evening breeze. Like modern-day innovators who are aware of the cycle of creative destruction, rangoli practitioners have internalized metaphors for impermanence and embraced the winds of change.MANGLA R. OZA AND RAJESH C. OZAPalo Alto, Calif.

headline: New York Struggles as Blizzard’s Impact Chastens Bloomberg

headline: Letter: In Pursuit of the Perfect Brainstorm
text: Regarding David Segal’s article about the ‘‘new breed of consultants’’ helping corporations come up with fresh ideas, governments also need help. We need such consultants in the public sector to help our governments transform to meet the budgetary and service challenges of the 21st century. In business, there is one bottom line to innovate to: profit. In government, there are many interests and dynamics that can undercut innovation. We need to develop specific techniques that address the unique situation of government. In my work to help governments innovate, I have found that separating stakeholders’ input from the design process is very useful. We need more ideas, more support and more commitment to innovation in government. I hope next year we see these ideas highlighted. Beverly SteinPresident, the Public Strategies GroupPortland, Ore.

headline: ‘The Nutcracker’ Chronicles: In Virginia, a Nutcracker for Every State
text: RICHMOND, Va. — If Patrick Henry said “Give me liberty or give me death” (there are doubts), he said it here in St. John’s Church. The State Capitol, dated 1788 and recently restored, is the second oldest in continuous use in America. The Virginia Museum of Fine Arts has the largest collection of Fabergé Imperial Easter Eggs outside Russia. I want to see these and other sights. At this stage of my “Nutcracker” tour and after a delayed flight, however, I confess I don’t have the energy. I love the view of a wide arc of the James River from my hotel room and go to bed before the performance.

headline: Box Office Remains Strong for ‘Spider-Man’ in Challenging Week
text: An accident at the Dec. 20 performance of “Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark” that injured the actor Christopher Tierney had no immediate effect on that Broadway musical at the box office. According to data released Tuesday by the Broadway League, “Spider-Man,” which canceled two of its planned performances for the week ending Dec. 26 while new safety protocols were put in place, grossed $944,138 for its four shows and played to 100 percent capacity. That figure, however, does not reflect any money that might be given back to audience members at the Dec. 20 show, which ended abruptly after the accident. They have been offered refunds or tickets to later “Spider-Man” performances.

headline: Injustice, British and Otherwise
text: Class consciousness has frequently played a role in Mike Leigh’s films, and not only because, as a storyteller whose native terrain is modern Britain, he can hardly hope to avoid it. And sure enough, the observant viewer of his splendidly rich and wise new feature, “Another Year,” will notice the shadows that an always-evolving system of social hierarchy casts over the passage of the seasons. (“We’re all graduates,” one character reminds another, with the prickly pride of belonging to the first generation to receive a university education in an era of expanded opportunity.)
