text: A view of the day in sports, with a winning streak on the snow and controversy on the water.

headline: Slowdown Seen in Money Flowing Into Hedge Funds
text: Is the recent expansion in the insider trading investigation — including raids at three hedge funds late last month — starting to rattle investors?

headline: 18-Game Season Remains Stumbling Block in Labor Negotiations
text: With the regular season nearly at an end, N.F.L. owners and players are expected to intensify negotiations for a new collective bargaining agreement. The existing agreement expires in March, and although Commissioner Roger Goodell said recently that he thought it was possible a deal could be reached by the Super Bowl in early February, two union leaders said on a conference call Tuesday that they had not seen progress on one of the key elements of a new deal: the move to an 18-game regular season.

headline: Providence Project Offers Health Care and Hope
text: PROVIDENCE, R.I.  For more than 40 years, Providence Community Health Centers has performed a vital role in this city by providing medical care to many of its poorest citizens.

headline: Suspicious Death Ignites Fury in China
text: BEIJING — The photograph is so graphic that it appears cartoonish at first glance.

headline: Fellow Writers To Help Charles Bock with ‘Most Literary Rent Party Ever’
text: The writer Charles Bock made a great many literary friendships during the years while he struggled to complete his first novel, “Beautiful Children.” When Mr. Bock’s wife, Diana Colbert, was discovered to have leukemia and underwent a bone marrow transplant in the fall of 2009, many of those friends pitched in to offer household help. In October, Ms. Colbert’s leukemia returned (she is scheduled for another transplant next month), and three of the Bocks’ friends, the novelists Fiona Maazel and Mary-Beth Hughes and the writer Leigh Newman, decided they needed to help even more. “We said everything that can be done, should be done,” Ms. Maazel recalled. So on Feb. 6th, at P.S. 122 in the East Village, the Bock friends are throwing what they’re calling “the most literary rent party ever.”

headline: Southern Writer With a Soft Spot for Wild Men Metes Out High-Octane Bonbons
text: Barry Hannah’s work is one of the great and wonderful train wrecks of American fiction.

headline: Rule by the Ridiculous
text: There must be a way to construct a word for this out of Greek roots; something like kleptocracy, but meaning rule by ridiculous people instead. But it’s all Greek to me. Anyway, a couple of stories today.

headline: Thais Look to the Supernatural
text: BANGKOK — Don’t be fooled by the skyscrapers, the roads clogged with the latest luxury cars or the high-tech gadgetry in pockets and purses. This country of 65 million people has embraced modernity, yes, but many Thais will tell you that ghosts and spirits still wander the streets and inhabit buildings. Important business decisions often require consultations with a fortune teller. Cabinet ministers and military officers are sometimes so concerned with numerology and advice from their shamans that politics in Thailand could be called the black art of the possible.

headline: Truth Lurks in Spoof of Singletary
text: One Mike Singletary is out of a job. With any luck at all, the other Mike Singletary will survive.

headline: Steven W. Fisher, New York State Justice, Dies at 64
text: Steven W. Fisher, a New York State justice who presided over the trial of two men who killed five employees of a Wendy’s fast food restaurant in Queens in 2000, died on Dec. 18 at his home in Queens. He was 64.

headline: Despite Snow, the Show Must Go On for Playbill Magazine, Too
text: 3:59 p.m. | Updated

headline: Now Baking | Provence Rises in Midtown
text: “I have a new bread we are doing, a breakfast bread,” Katzie Guy-Hamilton told me by e-mail from her new post as executive pastry chef at the Grand Hyatt Hotel’s barely opened restaurant New York Central. “Nobody makes it in New York, and I would like to think ours is amazingly delicious.” What was this bread? Its name sounds a lot like gibberish, literally. It’s gibassier, and Guy-Hamilton explained that hers is an enriched dough with anise seeds, orange blossom water and candied peel. “I shape it into rounds, cut little ‘claws’ and then it gets a showered with sugar before baking.”

headline: The Futuristic Insta-Family
text: How two women (and a husband) helped make twiblings — a son and a daughter of the same age from the same egg donor but two different surrogates.

headline: Chicago to Redevelop U.S. Steel Site on Lakefront
text: CHICAGO — A plan to redevelop the site of the long-closed U.S. Steel plant on the south lakefront here is ambitious even in a city whose attitude has long been Daniel Burnham’s maxim, “Make no little plans.”

headline: Unraveling the History Beneath the Ice
text: John Goodge, left, a professor of geological sciences at the University of Minnesota-Duluth, and Jeff Vervoort, an isotope geochemist from Washington State University, are writing from their research expedition in Antarctica.

headline: A Fake Danish Comedy Troupe Goes To North Korea, With Strange Results
text: In “The Red Chapel” a Danish journalist named Mads Brugger sets out to punk North Korea by arranging to visit it with a bogus comedy troupe. And yes, he succeeds in getting inside that closed country, under the guise of cultural exchange. But what he thinks he’s accomplished by doing so is never very clear, and the product — sloppy even by guerrilla filmmaking standards — has no revelations to offer that are worth the slog of watching it.

headline: Rangel Starts Legal Defense Fund
text: Representative Charles B. Rangel of New York has started a legal defense fund to raise money to pay for lawyers who defended him during his ethics investigation, he said in a statement Tuesday.

headline: Testing Medical Devices
text: To the Editor:

headline: Neutral on the Soda Tax
text: To the Editor:

headline: Pictures of the Day: India and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from India, China and New York.

headline: A Digital Tour of Paris
text: The next time you pack for a trip to Europe, leave those hefty guide books at home.

headline: Museum as Archaeologist
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Lower-Carbon Route to Replacing Oil
text: An emerging surfeit of natural gas has chemists and engineers studying how to turn it into pricier commodities, like diesel fuel or other oil substitutes.

headline: The Mob Work Is Tough; Then He Has to Go Home
text: Aging stage actors typically dream of playing King Lear, but many of their younger screen counterparts these days will settle for nothing less than Jesus. Not literally: the part of the actual New Testament Jesus tends to be a limited role best suited to actors of limited range, like Jim Caviezel (“The Passion of the Christ”) or Jeffrey Hunter (“King of Kings”). But there is something irresistible about modern men of sorrows who sacrifice themselves for the sins of others, and certain movie stars  Kevin Costner and Will Smith, most strikingly  have not hesitated to exercise the Messiah Clause in their contracts.

headline: No Shirtless Photos of Obama This Trip
text: HONOLULU — To all those Obama fans eager for another round of pictures of the presidential pectorals, forget it.

headline: Global Food Prices in 2011 Face Perilous Rise
text: Food prices globally are rising to dangerous levels. There is talk of a coming crisis, like the ones that produced riots around the world in 2008 and 1974. Many of the ingredients of a disaster are present, but governments can stop the problem before it causes too much damage.

headline: Stop Me if You’ve Heard This One ...Oh, You Have?
text: There may be no more bizarre holiday show in town than “Dollface,” a demented new musical having its premiere at Theater for the New City. While the year is 1956, and the show is set during Christmastime in suburban Queens, the anything-goes plotting and blithely artless performances made me think of early John Waters Baltimore instead.

headline: Neither Snow Nor Rain Nor …
text: The mail came late on Tuesday to a section of Sunset Park, Brooklyn. To watch George Joseph, the mail carrier, navigate the icy streetscape, it seemed a miracle it arrived at all.

headline: To Each His Own Museum, as Identity Goes on Display
text: Me! Me! Me! That is the cry, now often heard, as history is retold. Tell my story, in my way! Give me the attention I deserve! Haven’t you neglected me, blinded by your own perspectives? Now let history be told not by the victors but by people over whom it has trampled.

headline: Readers Recall Another Mayor, and Another Storm
text: Many of our readers are still waiting for the plows to reach their area (and will continue to wait). Feeling trapped and abandoned, at least a few recalled the time when the city was caught with its plows up on Sunday, Feb. 9, 1969. That’s when a mere 15 inches of snow froze the streets for days.

headline: The Senate’s Next Task: Ratifying the Nuclear Test Ban Treaty
text: Moscow

headline: Young Math Wizard Stumbles Upon Oz, Deep in the Heart of the Internet
text: The Oz in Mamoru Hosoda’s excellent anime feature “Summer Wars” isn’t somewhere over the rainbow but just a keystroke away. It’s a global virtual reality, and when things go wrong in Oz, watch out, real world: traffic tangles, and water mains burst. Worse, someone could launch a missile attack.

headline: In Remote Corner of Portugal, a Photographer Finds More Than He Expects
text: What is the opposite of precocious? If no suitable word exists, somebody should invent one — in English, French or, ideally, Portuguese — to describe the 102-year-old filmmaker Manoel de Oliveira. He has completed a dozen features and a handful of shorts since 1998, which is to say since his 90th birthday. His latest feature, a tale of supernatural romance called “The Strange Case of Angelica,” arrives in New York on Wednesday, and while it is evidently the work of an artist with great stores of wisdom and a long view of history, it also has a playful, wry quality that can only be described as youthful.

headline: Chronicling Love’s Fade to Black
text: There is a song about the thin line between love and hate, but most movies pick a side and stay on it. “Blue Valentine,” a long-gestating project directed by Derek Cianfrance, examines a young couple falling in and out of love, and makes of that thin line a vast and blurry no man’s land. Speaking of music, Leonard Cohen has a song about being danced to the end of love, but Mr. Cianfrance’s characters, Dean (Ryan Gosling) and Cindy (Michelle Williams), stumble and crawl in that direction, having forgotten the nimble, playful steps they once knew.

headline: New York, Unplowed
text: @import url("http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/css/multimedia/bundles/SlidingGallery.css");

headline: Wi-Fi Overload at High-Tech Meetings
text: SAN FRANCISCO  Internet entrepreneurs climb on stage at technology conferences and praise a world in which everyone is perpetually connected to the Web.

headline: Searching New Music For Keepers
text: “Most of the music we play,” a musician who specializes in contemporary works told me recently, “is not great. Some of it is very good, but it lacks something. It falls short. But we need to play it  not only because something great may turn up, and if we don’t play it, we won’t know it, but also because this is the music being composed now, and it ought to be heard.”

headline: Spider-Woman Is Leaving Troubled ‘Spider-Man’
text: One of the lead actresses in “Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark,” Natalie Mendoza, who is still recovering from a concussion sustained during the musical’s first preview performance, is leaving the production, according to two people who work on the show and who spoke on condition of anonymity.

headline: The Deal Makers Who Deserve Failing Grades
text: Year-end is a time for professors to grade. In a similar spirit, I end this year by highlighting the lowlights of the year’s deal making. These are, by category, the Deal Professor dropouts, the deal makers who deserve an F.

headline: Selling the World on Russia (Leaving Out the Spies)
text: MOSCOW

headline: New Year’s Dinners in Manhattan
text: RESTAURANTS everywhere offer New Year’s Eve dinners, often including a Champagne or sparkling wine toast. Many still have tables available. When making reservations, be sure to confirm the time. Restaurants frequently offer two seatings, with a less expensive dinner during the earlier slot. And for dinners before 9 p.m., it pays to find out what time you must leave.

headline: Making Choices for End-of-Life Care
text: To the Editor:

headline: Brees and Brady Keep Padding Touchdown Streaks
text: With 3 minutes 24 seconds left in the fourth quarter Monday night against the Atlanta Falcons, Drew Brees found the rookie tight end Jimmy Graham for a 6-yard touchdown pass. The throw gave New Orleans the lead and eventually a victory, and it clinched an N.F.C. playoff berth. But the pass also kept alive an impressive streak: Brees has thrown for a touchdown in 26 consecutive regular-season games (he also threw a touchdown pass in all three postseason games last season). Brees is still far from breaking the record, 47, set by Johnny Unitas 50 years ago.

headline: Betting on the Next ‘It’ Pig
text: ONCE upon a time, there were three little pigs — a Duroc hybrid, a Berkshire and an Ibérico — that merrily settled in the great American house of pork.

headline: Bare-Bones Approach Lets a City Embrace Winter
text: MEXICO CITY  Homero Aridjis, one of Mexico’s most revered poets, lives in a large home in the hills of this ancient city, with expensive paintings, imported rugs  and an array of items to help him keep warm, including door-stoppers shaped like snakes, thick wool sweaters, even microwaveable pillows.

headline: Derivatives Clearing Group Decides Against Registration
text: The world’s largest clearinghouse for credit-default swaps, ICE Trust, has had second thoughts about registering with regulators, citing concerns over new rules devised to bring transparency to the $600 trillion derivatives market.

headline: Time Warner and Sinclair in Fight Over Fees
text: The year cannot end, it seems, without a fight over the fees paid for television programming.

headline: ‘Women on the Verge’ of an Early Closing
text: Lincoln Center Theater’s production of “Women on the Verge of a Nervous Breakdown” will end its Broadway run at the Belasco Theater on Sunday, three weeks earlier than scheduled, the theater announced on Tuesday. The musical, based on the 1988 film by Pedro Almodóvar, with a book by Jeffrey Lane and music and lyrics by David Yazbek, was to have run through Jan. 23.

headline: Bloggingheads: American Jews and Muslims
text: Journalist Mona Eltahawy, left, and Imam Abdullah Antepli of Duke University discuss what America's Muslims and Jews can learn from each other's experiences.

headline: French Deal to Sell Ships to Russians Is Criticized
text: PARIS  Since a low-key Christmas Eve announcement of a French sale of assault ships to Russia, high-level government deal makers have boasted about the multimillion-euro deal like it was a soccer game triumph. “France wins,” declares the Web site for the Élysée Palace.

headline: N.H.L.’s Winter Classic Could Be Rained On
text: New Year’s Day in Pittsburgh is expected to be rainy with the temperature as high as 51 degrees, which is not good news for the N.H.L.’s fourth Winter Classic starting on time at 1 p.m. Eastern.

headline: Terrain Shifts in Challenges to the Health Care Law
text: The legal challenge to the Obama health care act has invigorated a dispute as old as the Constitution about the framers’ most nettlesome grant of power, which gives Congress treacherously broad authority to pass laws “necessary and proper” to carrying out its assigned responsibilities.

headline: Six-Week-Old Martinis, Anyone?
text: WITH the precision mixologists take these days in building their more ornate creations, customers have grown used to waiting a few minutes for a drink. For the latest innovation in elite libations, however, they’ll have to wait six weeks or so.

headline: Storm on East Coast Is Local News in West
text: KRTV News in Great Falls, Mont., has exactly one full-time reporter, Kay Rossi, on the Monday-to-Friday local news beat. So when Ms. Rossi called in stranded  snowbound with family in Connecticut, uncertain when she would be able to get back West  the tiny station’s managers were thrown into a staffing crisis. Then they improvised: They made her plight a news story.

headline: Thanks to Blizzard, More California Sun
text: LOS ANGELES  Even travelers in sunny California are feeling the blizzard that pummeled the East Coast.

headline: Travelers Improvise to Find a Way Home
text: ATLANTA  Elizabeth Elliott, 24, a travel administrator in New York, has a message for her fellow holiday travelers: “You have to be dedicated if you want to get anywhere.”

headline: Making It Clear That a Clear Parking Space Isn’t
text: BOSTON  By dawn on Tuesday, the space savers were out in abundance on East Seventh Street in South Boston. Someone had staked out a neatly shoveled parking spot with a potted plant, its dead fronds trembling in the wind. Someone else had reserved a space with a hot-pink beach chair.

headline: After a Blizzard, New York Struggles to Dig Out
text: As has happened in past snowstorms, many residents in Brooklyn, Queens, the Bronx and Staten Island complained that in contrast with Manhattan, snow had not been cleared on their streets quickly enough.

headline: In the Rearview, a Year That Fizzled
text: Washington

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,429 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans recently:

headline: Remarkable Run Ends for ‘Team North Dakota’
text: WASHINGTON  By now, Senator Byron L. Dorgan, Senator Kent Conrad and Representative Earl Pomeroy  best friends and Democrats who spent the last 18 years serving as North Dakota’s entire Congressional delegation  are the stuff of so much political lore in their home state, it can be hard to separate the tall tales from reality.

headline: Rarity in Region, Lebanese Paper Dares to Provoke
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Ibrahim al-Amine, the hawk-eyed editorial chairman of Al Akhbar, describes his newspaper’s founding ambitions this way: “We wanted the U.S. ambassador to wake up in the morning, read it and get upset.”

headline: Recession Creates Spike in Multifamily Households
text: Of the many ways the recession has altered the country’s social fabric, the surge in households like the Maggis, where relatives and friends have moved in together as a last resort, is one of the most concrete, yet under-explored, demographic shifts.

headline: ‘Doubling Up’ in Recession-Strained Quarters
text: FORT PIERCE, Fla.  For the three generations of the Maggi family crowded into a recession-beaten three-bedroom ranch house here, the tension from living on top of one another for the last 10 months sometimes erupts at unexpected moments.

headline: Groupon Fund-Raising Plan Spurs Debate on Its Valuation
text: Groupon, which earlier this month rebuffed a $6 billion takeover bid from Google, is preparing for a major round of fund-raising.

headline: From Mental Health Patient to Wellness Coach
text: Tyrone Garrett has been admitted to the hospital for manic depression more than a dozen times.

headline: Cup of Wrath and Fire
text: Few people in the North welcomed South Carolina’s secession in December 1860, but Frederick Douglass, America’s most prominent former slave and African-American abolitionist, was one of them. From his editorial desk in Rochester, N.Y., Douglass heaped scorn on the Palmetto State’s rash act, but he also relished it as an opportunity. He all but thanked the secessionists for “preferring to be a large piece of nothing, to being any longer a small piece of something.”

headline: Syracuse Punter Inspires His Teammates, Even if He Cannot Play
text: A half-dozen husky Syracuse football players in gray sweatsuits strolled into a ballroom at the Grand Hyatt late Tuesday afternoon for a news conference. The punter, the only man in the group with a jagged red scar on the back of his shaved head, drew the most attention.

headline: A Tight End Happy to Have Hands of Clay
text: LEESBURG, Va.  On the football field, Washington Redskins tight end Chris Cooley likes to throw his body at defenders, as he did on a go-ahead touchdown Sunday at Jacksonville. But in his suburban house, he prefers throwing pottery  that is, making bowls, mugs and vases.

headline: Brooklyn Immigrant Congregations Clash
text: The United Methodist church in Sunset Park, Brooklyn, is anything but united.

headline: Sam Sifton's Best Dishes of 2010
text: The restaurant critic for The New York Times describes the 15 best dishes he ate in the city this year.

headline: Buka
text: THE giant African land snail can grow up to a foot long and weigh more than a pound. But the three specimens ($10) on our plate at Buka, denuded of their shells and curled in tight black whorls, looked about as imposing as jumbo shrimp.

headline: Watercress With a Maroon Leaf to Accent Your Salads
text: Red watercress — although maroon is more like it — has even more peppery bite in its green-veined pointy leaves than regular watercress and, its growers say, more antioxidants. An employee of B & W Watercress in Florida, said to be the world’s biggest grower, discovered it growing wild, so the company began cultivating it. Use it raw in salads, because cooking turns the red to dark green.

headline: From Agnolotti to Ziti, a Book Pairs Pastas and Sauces
text: Distinctions among pasta are mostly about shape, and thus you have “The Geometry of Pasta,” an arresting book by Caz Hildebrand and Jacob Kenedy that covers pasta shapes alphabetically from agnolotti to ziti, more than 80 of them represented by strong black-and-white drawings. Fregola, gnocchi and couscous are included. A careful matching of sauce recipe to shape is the book’s mission, and there is considerable cross-referencing from one to another, and a useful index of sauces in the back. I loved the strozzapreti with calamari and broccoli that called for cooking the pasta and vegetable together in the same pot.

headline: Inexpensive Restaurants That Stood Out in 2010
text: THE best of the casual restaurants reviewed this year proved that delicious doesn’t have to mean expensive.

headline: A Brooklyn Market With Local Pride
text: Among the attractions at the fledgling Brooklyn Victory Garden market are fresh Bo Bo chickens, prized in Chinatown and sold with the head and feet — parts worth collecting for your restorative chicken soup this winter.

headline: A Critic’s Choice of Restaurant Newcomers
text: FOLLOWING is a list of my favorite new restaurants among those that I reviewed in 2010. They are presented in alphabetical order. But Torrisi was awesome.

headline: Sparkling Pear Cider, a Gentler Start to the New Year
text: To keep that New Year’s celebration on the light side, consider sprightly and subtly sparkling pear cider from Ireland. It’s delicately sweetened, delivers only 4.5 percent alcohol and behaves properly in a flute for toasting. Magners has been known for its more traditional apple cider for 75 years.

headline: Off the Menu
text: Opening

headline: Dishes That Earned Their Stars
text: I MADE a list of the 15 best things I ate in New York City in the past year of reviewing restaurants for The New York Times. It is an accounting that comprises restaurant dishes of uncommon excellence and flavor. Together they underscore New York’s place as one of the planet’s best cities in which to dine out.

headline: Dining Calendar
text: A Melodious Prix Fixe

headline: Whole Wheat Spaghetti With Spicy Chickpeas, Rosemary and Bonito Flakes
text: Adapted from Mark Ladner, Del Posto, Manhattan

headline: For a Snow-Crippled City, a Morsel of Humble Pie From the Mayor
text: On the third day, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg tried on empathy. Sort of.

headline: Share Rules Could Prompt an Offering by Facebook
text: Facebook likes big numbers — it now has more than 500 million users, each one of whom can have as many as 5,000 friends. Yet as a privately held company, its ownership base must remain small, or it will have to disclose publicly its financial results.

headline: To Governor, Postponing a Game Is for Losers
text: PHILADELPHIA  Whether rooting on the University of Pennsylvania basketball team or analyzing the Eagles on a weekly postgame television program, Gov. Edward G. Rendell has long been an outspoken Philadelphia sports fan.

headline: Bad Advice From Duke Ellington
text: Personally, I take the Airtrain to Jamaica, then the LIRR.

headline: In 2011, Let Coughlin Light a Fire
text: To the many thousands of Giants fans passing judgment on Tom Coughlin’s coaching future, give Coughlin a thumbs up. Let him live for another season.

headline: Accounts Diverge Sharply in Night Raid Gone Wrong
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  No one seems certain who fired the first shot in the early morning hours of Dec. 24 as commandos from the coalition forces here descended on a Kabul office building in search of two cars loaded with explosives.

headline: With Ambulances Stuck in Snow, City Resorted to Triage
text: A woman with stroke symptoms in Midwood, Brooklyn, waited for an ambulance for six hours, finally arriving at the hospital with telltale signs of advanced brain damage. In Forest Hills, Queens, bystanders waited for three hours next to a man lying unconscious in the snow before they were able to flag down help. And in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, a mother in labor who started calling 911 at 8:30 a.m. on Monday did not get an ambulance until 6 p.m., too late to save the baby.

headline: Answering Critics, Police Release Minor-Crime Data
text: The New York Police Department has begun providing broad access to data on misdemeanor crimes in the city, putting the information on its Web site.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Man Charged in Death of Woman Found in Suitcase
text: An East Harlem man was arrested on Monday and charged with the murder of a woman whose body was found stuffed in a suitcase left on East 114th Street in Manhattan, the police said.

headline: Russia: Inquiry on Airport Service in Storm
text: President Dmitri A. Medvedev on Tuesday ordered an inquiry into whether the authorities had mishandled the response to weather-related cancellations of hundreds of flights at Moscow’s two major airports. An ice storm over the weekend paralyzed service at the two airports, Domodedovo and Sheremetyevo, leading to widespread complaints from passengers that officials were unprepared and had no contingency plans. State television reported disturbances at both airports as passengers tried to force their way into departure areas. Some expressed anger over lack of information and over what they called price gouging at airport restaurants and shops.

headline: China: Apology for Farmer Locked in Mental Wards
text: A Chinese farmer who was imprisoned in mental hospitals for six and a half years as punishment for seeking government redress in a land dispute has been given the equivalent of $45,300 and an apology by officials of the Henan Province county that had engineered his confinement, Caijing Magazine reported. According to the magazine, which reported the settlement, the farmer, Xu Lindong, left, resisted accepting the award for seven months because it required him to abandon his right to sue the two mental hospitals that had confined him. Some human rights advocates say they believe that a growing number of agitators who seek government redress are confined in Chinese mental hospitals.

headline: E. Gene Smith, Who Helped to Save Tibetan Literary Canon, Dies at 74
text: E. Gene Smith, a Utah native who through persistence, ardor and benevolent guile amassed the largest collection of Tibetan books outside Tibet, saving them from isolation and destruction and making them accessible to scholars and Tibetan exiles around the world, died on Dec. 16 at his home in Manhattan. He was 74.

headline: Obama’s Traveling Team Stays Focused on Terror
text: KAILUA, Hawaii  President Obama was peeved. It was Christmas 2009 and a Nigerian had been accused of trying to blow up a plane bound for Detroit. Mr. Obama was supposed to have state-of-the-art secure telecommunications capabilities inside his luxury beachfront rental home here. Instead, he was stuck relying on operators to connect him to his top counterterrorism adviser, John O. Brennan. Once, as he was trying to reach Mr. Brennan, the call dropped.

headline: No. 14 Minnesota Men Lose
text: Jordan Taylor scored 22 points and Jon Leuer added 16 to lead Wisconsin (11-2) to a 68-60 upset of No. 14 Minnesota (11-2) in the Big Ten opener for both teams.

headline: Making It Clear That a Clear Parking Space Isn’t
text: Scenes from South Boston’s parking wars.

headline: Plowed? Yes. Salted? Sure. Cleared? That’s Murky.
text: It is the central question of this week’s snowstorm: How did the city’s efforts to plow and clear its more than 6,000 miles of streets rate against the jobs that it did in response to other powerful snowfalls?

headline: Wednesday: June
text: Today’s theme addresses the age-old crossword gripe that N and Ñ are two totally different letters. Both of those letters appear in the grid, but never crossing each other. No now-you-see-it-now-you-don’t TILDE … for a day anyway.

headline: Concrete Jumble: New Year New York
text: A short film by Gary Leib celebrating the new year.

headline: A New Jersey City Digs Out From 32 Inches
text: RAHWAY, N.J.  When John M. Rodger, the Rahway police chief, looked outside on Monday morning and could not see his wife’s Chevrolet Suburban in the driveway, he knew his vacation to South Carolina was a goner.

headline: For $10, $20, Clearing Cars and Walks, in a Flash
text: Some are just out of prison, others have Ivy League degrees. Many are day laborers who speak no English. A few are women. All are entrepreneurs, in an all-cash, tax-free enterprise that exploits desperation and deadlines.

headline: What Rule of Law?
text: President Dmitri Medvedev of Russia claims to champion the rule of law. He also claims that he, not Prime Minister Vladimir Putin, calls the shots in Moscow. Mr. Medvedev can prove both true by using his pardon power to ensure that Mikhail Khodorkovsky faces no additional prison time after being convicted on trumped-up embezzlement charges this week. Mr. Khodorkovsky, once Russia’s richest man, has already served seven years as a result of Mr. Putin’s judicial vendetta against him.

headline: A New Day for Wilderness
text: One of the sorrier blots on George W. Bush’s sorry environmental record was a midnight deal in 2003 between Gale Norton, then the secretary of the interior, and Michael Leavitt, then the governor of Utah, that withdrew 2.6 million acres of public land in Utah from consideration as protected wilderness.

headline: An Iraqi Government, Finally
text: Nine long months after parliamentary elections, Iraq has a new government. Its leaders can’t waste any more time on petty maneuvering.

headline: No-No Boy
text: Courage takes many forms. Frank Emi, who died in California on Dec. 1, age 94, had the steadfast kind, well suited for lonely struggles and ostracism.

headline: A Pinpoint Beam Strays Invisibly, Harming Instead of Healing
text: The initial accident report offered few details, except to say that an unidentified hospital had administered radiation overdoses to three patients during identical medical procedures.

headline: After Disruptions on Rails and at Airports, Halting Steps Toward Normal Service
text: New York’s many forms of mass transit stumbled back to life on Tuesday, a day after fierce snow and wind knocked out much of the city’s vast network of buses, trains and planes. But while some parts of the city moved toward regaining mobility, other areas barely budged.

headline: Corrections
text: BUSINESS DAY

headline: Knicks Get Another Hard Lesson From Heat
text: MIAMI  The foul was unnecessary, ultimately meaningless, but LeBron James gave it anyway, for emphasis, for the Knicks to remember in the months to come. The message: nothing will come easy against the Miami Heat, not even in the final seconds of a game in which the outcome is clear.

headline: A New York City Weekend for $100
text: HOW much spending money should you set aside for a weekend in New York City that includes taking in some theater, museums and experimental film, dining out at restaurants for every meal and having a few beers, too?

headline: Vacation Rentals Pile on Luxuries
text: A SELF-DESCRIBED hotel snob, Jennifer Treadwell prefers to stay at Four Seasons and similar upscale hotels when she goes on vacation, for the high level of service and luxurious amenities they provide. The idea of renting a vacation home, where she would presumably bring her own bed sheets and toilet paper, was never very appealing. Then she discovered the Cottages at Cape Kiwanda on the Oregon coast, where $500-a-night two-bedroom cottages offer flat-screen televisions, surround-sound systems, spa-style robes, iPod docks, in-room Internet access and whirlpool tubs. Guests have access to a fitness center nearby and a concierge who can book an oceanfront massage or surf lesson or recommend nearby hiking trails.

headline: My $100 Weekend in New York: Where the Money Went
text: What’s the lowest possible budget you need for a great weekend in New York? I figured $100 would do the trick, as long as you can find a free place to crash. (Recommendations: your college roommate’s couch, your ex-girlfriend’s futon, your rich distant cousin’s pied-a-terre, or Couchsurfing.)

headline: Making a Complex Machine Even More Complex
text: Linear accelerators create X-ray beams aimed at cancer or other problems. Some are retrofitted with a cylindrical assembly — called a cone — which concentrates the radiation for more precise treatments. Because the beams are so intense, a single error can cause serious injuries or death.

headline: John Warhola, Brother of Andy Warhol, Dies at 85
text: John Warhola, an older brother of the Pop artist Andy Warhol and one of the original three trustees of the Andy Warhol Foundation for the Visual Arts, died on Friday in Pittsburgh. He was 85 and lived in Freedom, Pa.

headline: Frances Ginsberg, American Soprano, Dies at 55
text: Frances Ginsberg, an American soprano heard regularly with the New York City Opera in the 1980s, died on Friday in the Bronx. She was 55 and had lived in Manhattan and Milan.

headline: China: Investigative Reporter Dies After Beating
text: Sun Hongjie, a journalist who was beaten into a coma this month in northwest China, died Tuesday morning, a colleague said. Mr. Sun was an investigative reporter for The Northern Xinjiang Morning Post. Colleagues declined to say whether he had been killed because of his reporting. Police officials said that Mr. Sun and a friend had argued, and that the friend had arranged the assault.

headline: Israeli Army Kills Militant in Gaza
text: The Israeli Army killed a 21-year-old member of a militant group loyal to the Hamas leaders of Gaza and wounded three others on Tuesday. The army said it had been aiming at militants planting explosives near the border, according to The Associated Press. But residents said the man had been watching the security fence separating Gaza and Israel; militants watch the fence so they can give warning if Israeli forces appear ready to attack.

headline: Phys Ed: If You Are Fit, You Can Take It Easy
text: New Year’s resolutions tend to war with wintertime malaise. Resolution urges you to work out. Malaise suggests that you linger in bed. But there’s good news for those of us torn between these impulses. A number of newly published studies offer compelling reasons to get out and exercise on the one hand, as well as new estimates of just how little we can do and still benefit on the other.

headline: Obama Back on the Links
text: KAILUA, Hawaii — President Obama is an avid golfer. But his friend Marty Nesbitt may have gotten the best of him on the links here Tuesday afternoon.

headline: Alaska: State to Declare Victory for Murkowski
text: A federal judge on Tuesday cleared the way for Alaska election officials to declare Senator Lisa Murkowski the winner of the state’s Senate race. Ms. Murkowski ran as a write-in candidate after losing to Joe Miller in the Republican primary. Unofficial results have showed her winning by more than 10,000 votes, but Mr. Miller has delayed certification through legal challenges, arguing that write-in votes must be spelled perfectly. The Alaska Supreme Court ruled against him last week. On Tuesday, Judge Ralph R. Beistline of United States District Court dismissed his federal case. Shortly after the ruling, the state announced it had certified the results. It later corrected the announcement to say it would certify the race on Thursday.

headline: Maine: 7 Hurt as Sugarloaf Ski Lift Derails
text: A chair lift derailed Tuesday at the Sugarloaf ski resort in Carrabassett Valley, injuring seven people after five chairs plunged about 30 feet into snow. Officials at the resort, about 120 miles north of Portland, could not immediately explain the accident, but said none of the injuries appeared to be life-threatening.

headline: Now Pouring | Some Like It Cold
text: One could imagine the likes of Rhett Butler raising a glass at the bar at Husk, the award-winning chef Sean Brock’s new restaurant in the historic center of Charleston, S.C. Husk offers hearty, somewhat masculine fare with a common theme: “If it ain’t Southern, it ain’t walkin’ in the door,” Brock says. This manifesto carries over to the bar, which is adjacent to the restaurant in a restored antebellum structure and boasts a killer bourbon list. Exquisite small-batch varieties are served in glasses made from recycled wine bottles, each with a “punt” in the bottom, which creates a kind of “moat” for the amber liquid. When a hand-molded sphere of clear ice is set on top (for cooling without dilution), the only real contact between one’s 23-year-old Pappy Van Winkle and its icy companion is while sipping. It’s a pretty neat experience.

headline: Pete Padilla of Calexico, My First Mentor
text: In the 20th century, Pete Padilla was the dean of professional photographers in Calexico, Calif., the border town in which I grew up. He was also the only professional photographer in Calexico.

headline: The Recovery That Was — and Then Wasn’t
text: We’ve talked before here about whether a fleeting economic recovery began early this year. Two pieces of data mentioned in my column this week offer more evidence that a recovery did in fact start, only to falter in the spring.

headline: Another Rex Ryan Moment: Making the Playoffs
text: Rex Ryan was conducting a grim news conference after the Jets lost to the Bears in Chicago on Sunday. A few minutes into it, he learned that the Jets had made the playoffs, thanks to Jacksonville’s loss to Washington. For those who missed it, his reaction (above) was priceless.The video at Jets.com gives a fuller picture, showing the somber run-up to that moment and a later question from a reporter about whether Ryan felt relieved. Ryan joked: “Not really, no relief at all! No relief at all!” (That video also showed a distraught Mark Sanchez not knowing how to react to the mixed news. He said he’d have to ask his teammate Mark Brunell how he was supposed to feel.)

headline: South Korean President Open to Talks With North
text: SEOUL, South Korea  In an unexpected diplomatic overture that could lead to the resumption of negotiations with North Korea, the president of South Korea said Wednesday that he would endorse restarting the six-nation talks aimed at dismantling the North’s nuclear weapons program.

headline: With New Show, Rare View of Rome’s Palazzo Farnese
text: Armored cars and gun-toting Italian police flank the entrance of the Palazzo Farnese, a hulking Renaissance palace that serves as the French Embassy in Rome. Though access to the imposing structure is generally limited for security reasons, the Palazzo will be open to visitors through April 27 for an extraordinary exhibition. The show, titled “From Renaissance Palace to French Embassy,” takes a look at the history, art and architecture of the palace.

headline: Vick Is King of Fantasy, but Reality Intrudes

headline: For Ford, a Green Roof That Springs Eternal
text: Ford’s Detroit-area River Rouge factory, celebrated in paintings by Charles Sheeler and other artists, stands with the Brooklyn Bridge and early skyscrapers among iconic American structures, able to accommodate more than 100,000 workers at its 1930s production peak. Growing in symbolism is the factory’s green roof, now celebrating its 10th anniversary.

headline: Are Small Businesses Going to Be Saviors or Victims?
text: Over the last two years, it has been widely reported that small businesses create more jobs than big businesses and thus are critical to the recovery. It has also been widely reported that small businesses are getting squeezed — by the credit freeze, by skyrocketing costs like health and unemployment insurance, and by cheap imports, to name a few examples.

headline: Meet the Twiblings
text: Midway on our life’s journey, I found myself in dark woods, the right road lost. I’ve actually never read “The Inferno,” but I found that line in my mind every morning when I woke to do my hormone injection and especially on the darkest mornings — the ones when I went into the clinic to have my unpregnant blood drawn to confirm another I.V.F. cycle’s failure. Of course, I had considered my life ruined many times before — other medical and romantic crises — but I was always wrong. This issue, though — childlessness — really did seem different. My two closest girlfriends chose not to have children and didn’t regret it, and I envied them, but I didn’t know how to feel as they did. No one gets everything they want in life, but to be childless felt like being deprived of something essential: the primal human experience. When I was 39 and single, I was in northern Uganda, and a woman there asked about my children. I said I didn’t have any, and she solemnly told me that she would pray to God to remove my curse. Instead of shrugging it off, I thanked her.

headline: Day 3: Have They Plowed Your Street Yet?
text: The math, at least from one angle, doesn’t really seem that unforgiving: 6,000-plus miles of roadway in the city; 1,700 plow trucks and 300 front-end loaders. That’s about 3 miles per snow-removal vehicle. You would think that 48 hours after the snow stopped, all the streets would be clear.

headline: The Year in Design | My Favorite Thing
text: I see a lot of innovative design; that’s why my job is so much fun. But it’s not often that I see something that offers a glimpse into the future. That’s how I felt when I walked into Sony’s exhibition in Milan during the 2010 furniture fair. The Japanese company had asked the British designers Edward Barber and Jay Osgerby, of the firm BarberOsgerby, to create an exhibition to showcase its Monolithic Design concept, in which its home entertainment products are seamlessly integrated into interior design. The exhibition itself was indeed interesting — BarberOsgerby designed an anechoic chamber, lined with foam blocks in the shape of triangular solids, in which to demonstrate projects like Sony’s pairing of a big-screen TV and near-field speakers to create a personal entertainment “space,” and a TV cabinet, made with a 3-D printer, that was porous enough to transmit sound from the speakers inside it. This was all very cool, but the part of the exhibition that was really thrilling was a group of objects that combined light and sound.

headline: Crude Oil Prices Stay Strong, Helping Indexes to Rally
text: The major stock indexes extended their rally on Wednesday, led by energy companies as crude oil remained above $90 for a fifth consecutive day.

headline: Police Arrest 5 in Danish Terror Plot
text: A group of men arrested in Denmark on Wednesday were about to mount a “Mumbai style” attack on the Danish newspaper that ignited Muslim fury around the world by publishing satirical cartoons of the Prophet Muhammad in 2005, the head of the Danish Security and Intelligence Service said.

headline: 2010: The Year in Mashed-Up Pop
text: Don’t pop those Champagne corks just yet: the year isn’t over until D.J. Earworm, the San Francisco song-spinner and mash-up creator, says farewell to the top pop hits of 2010 in one last video mix (which we were pointed to by the good folks at Billboard). Yes, you’ll have to bear witness one last time to Lady Gaga‘s prison dance and Katy Perry’s provocative pastries, and hear bits and pieces of Kesha’s “TiK ToK” in several dozen places, but when it’s all over, you might even shed a nostalgic tear for 2010 – or be very relieved that 2011 is almost upon us.

headline: Giant Icicle Terrorizes Cobble Hill
text: A giant icicle hung over Court Street in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn, on Tuesday, causing the police to cordon off part of the sidewalk. Eventually, a police officer whacked it with a shovel, bringing it down safely. The Pardon Me for Asking blog has the dramatic play-by-play.

headline: Recipe Redux: Chocolate-Rum Mousse, 1966
text: Chocolate-rum mousse, which ran in The Times in 1966, was a remarkably efficient recipe in two distinct ways. First, it invoked nearly every food trend of its moment: chocolate desserts were an exotic new fix; any respectable grown-up dessert contained rum; mousse suggested that you understood French cooking, or at least pretended to; two cups of cream was de rigueur; and the recipe assumed you owned one of the kitchen’s latest appliances, the home blender.

headline: Mayor Bilandic, Redux

I walked from the next line over last night and discovered the snowdrifts were still unshoveled at some intersections and on whole blocks of Church Avenue, which I walked along to get home.

headline: Who Benefits from Long-Term Unemployment?
text: The share of the labor force that has been out of work for at least six months remains near an all-time high. Long-term unemployment is clearly terrible for the millions of people who find themselves in that situation. But it does have a flip side for the rest of the labor force: unemployment in this downturn has been concentrated among a surprisingly small number of people.

headline: Cyborgs Onstage, Robots in the Wings
text: ON Friday a time machine will land on the stage of the Abrons Arts Center. The crew  an astronaut, a squishy space alien and a cyborg with a mustache  will try to transport audience members to the future, saving them from “an event so potent it turned this entire planet into a grave.” Unfortunately this future features endless copulation and meals salvaged from one’s own bodily waste. To get there, spectators will first have to survive goofy costumes, low-tech special effects, alien mucus sacs and at least one appalling dance number.

headline: A Little Good, a Little Evil, a Lot of Ritual
text: WHEN Rajiv Joseph was 13, he was voted Most Likely to Become a Priest by the other eighth graders at Gesu Catholic School in Cleveland. He wasn’t especially pious, he said  just quiet, private, observant. Little did his classmates know that their designation was apt. An altar boy, he had for years imagined becoming a priest. He loved the theatricality of Bible stories, like the big reveal of the risen Jesus on the road to Emmaus. He loved the rituals of the Roman Catholic Mass, like the blessing of the Eucharist as the body of Christ. Most of all, matters of morality and faith tumbled around in his mind. Eventually Mr. Joseph’s interest in girls made celibacy a nonstarter, but his interest in good and evil, in sin and redemption, found powerful expression in his calling as a playwright.

text: I love and admire nurses.

The event, at which Ms. Taymor was to be interviewed by Patrick Healy, a Times reporter who writes about theater, was scheduled for Jan. 8. A press representative for Ms. Taymor wrote in an e-mail that “with the changes in the ‘Spider-Man’ production schedule, Julie will be deep in rehearsals and will not be available to participate” in the interview. Ticketholders are being notified of the cancellation by mail and e-mail, and will be receiving refunds from OvationTix, the ticket service provider for the event. headline: Why Wait 200 Years? ‘Arcadia’ Revival, With Billy Crudup, Coming to Broadway Next Year
text: While just over 15 years have elapsed since Billy Crudup made his Broadway debut in Tom Stoppard‘s “Arcadia,” the actor is moving ahead two centuries to portray another character in a Broadway revival of that play slated for next year. In the original Broadway production of “Arcadia,” which shuttles in time between the 19th century and the present, Mr. Crudup played Septimus Hodge, a tutor and friend of Lord Byron. In the revival, which is headed for the Ethel Barrymore Theater, Mr. Crudup will play Bernard Nightingale, a modern-day professor investigating Byron’s life.

headline: The Ultimate Hostess Gift, in a Song
text: “I’VE sung at the White House and St. Patrick’s Cathedral,” the tenor Carl Tanner was saying  but, really, in this crowd, who hadn’t? Everyone was a star, or so it seemed, at the annual Christmas night dinner in the baronial Lincoln Center duplex of Sissy and Max Strauss. Each holiday, more than a hundred opera singers and other displaced performers and their entourages who find themselves in New York marooned far from home gather to wine, dine and, naturally, entertain one another.

headline: New Year’s Eve Events
text: RING in the New Year with style. Here is a sampling of the fashionable parties and cool scenes taking place in New York on Friday night.

headline: Europe Seems to Stick to Same Economic Strategy
text: PARIS  With much of Europe mired in a debt crisis and hamstrung by austerity budgets, one would think that European Union leaders are busy examining their economic models, looking for ways to promote growth amid tougher global competition.

headline: Learning the Tools of the Trader
text: Universities are building mock trading floors, with an eye on teaching students how to use the basic technologies needed for a career as a Wall Street trader.

headline: Keeping Closer Tabs on Designers
text: Thanks, everyone, for the comments on the last post, in whatever airport or train station the holidays found you. Pooks, referring to Moda Operandi, makes a good point about the difficulty of judging collections online (“those runway pieces can weigh a ton”), and I would add that the quality of fabrics may take a hit in the coming year or two as designers look for better-priced alternatives or cut corners. There has been a substantial increase in the cost of raw materials, especially cotton. And thanks to Kimb for information about getting the right fit online. Zachary: the folks at Google told me they want to do a boutiques.com for men but no timetable yet.

headline: The Actor as Architect of a Role
text: AS a boy, from the age of about 9 until well into his teens, the actor Javier Bardem would often help his mother, Pilar, an actress well known in Spain, learn her roles. At their home in Madrid she would hand him a script and then read her lines out loud while he read all the others.

headline: Aboard the Q Train, Finally
text: A long-lost letter appeared in the subway tunnel at the DeKalb Avenue station in Brooklyn Wednesday morning: the Q, emblazoned on the front of a train pulling into the station.

headline: More Flexible Workweek Takes Hold in Holland
text: In just a few years, a four-day week has become a powerful way of attracting and retaining talent in the competitive Dutch labor market.

headline: Batter Up: Eyelashes Enjoy a Spike
text: LIKE hemlines and cocktails, facial features go in and out of fashion, and right now, eyelashes are where it’s at.

headline: Groups Call Government’s Coal Ash Analysis Skewed
text: The Environmental Protection Agency is planning for the first time to regulate the disposal of coal ash, the potentially hazardous residue of the burning of coal in power plants and other large industrial facilities.

headline: Billy Taylor, Jazz Pianist, Dies at 89
text: Billy Taylor, a pianist and composer who was also an eloquent spokesman and advocate for jazz as well as a familiar presence for many years on television and radio, died on Tuesday in Manhattan. He was 89 and lived in the Riverdale section of the Bronx.

headline: Mavericks Offense Collapses Without Nowitzki
text: Not all teams are created equal, nor are they created equally. Though franchises look to emulate successful models or mimic particular elements of other teams’ strategies they find to be palatable, the construction of each and every roster in the N.B.A. is a unique process. So few team centerpieces fit into a convenient mold, which makes building around them a challenge specific to their strengths, weaknesses, and tendencies.

headline: At Dior, a New Look That’s More of a Sneer
text: MY visit to the reopened Dior boutique on 57th Street coincided with a couple of unrelated events that became inextricably relatable in my mind. (Bear with me, Gentle Reader. I promise these threads will form a rope in the end, if I don’t accidentally hang myself.)

headline: 10 Ways to Get the Most Out of Technology
text: Your gadgets and computers, your software and sites — they are not working as well as they should. You need to make some tweaks.

headline: Americans Split on Obama and Congressional Republicans, Poll Shows
text: As the 112th Congress convenes next week, Americans are divided in their assessment of both President Obama and Congressional Republicans, according to a new CNN /Opinion Research Corporation poll.

headline: Apps to Give the Novice Mixologist a Chance
text: My friends Cade and Sarah recently sandbagged me with a pink, frilly looking cocktail that sent my testosterone level plunging the minute I laid eyes on it.

headline: Weathering Survivalist TV, Like ‘Man vs. Wild’
text: The other day during my commute home, the New Jersey Transit train I was on had to pause mid-Meadowlands for some kind of storm-related delay. The conductor announced that we’d be moving again shortly, but I wasn’t taking any chances: I immediately constructed a double-sided lean-to from the laptop cases of my fellow passengers, caught three egrets by holding a Hopi bird snare out the emergency-exit window and built a makeshift stove to cook them on using soda cans and iPods.

headline: New Year’s Eve: A Night for Going Overboard
text: THE question most asked of fashion reporters at this time of year is a riddle for the ages: What, oh what, to wear on New Year’s Eve?

headline: Utilities Seek Fresh Talent for Smart Grids
text: GRANVILLE, Ohio  Speaking to a classroom of seventh and eighth graders at the middle school here, Lisa Magnuson shared a popular dictum from the power industry: if Alexander Graham Bell, the inventor of the telephone, could see how his technology had evolved over the last century, how would he react?

headline: Online Movies From … Sears?
text: When I think of Sears, or Kmart, a lot of products come to mind: discounted clothing, inexpensive tools, televisions, bicycles and apple pie. But one thing that doesn’t pop into my head is online movie rentals.

headline: How to Make MiFi Work With PCs and Smartphones
Survivalist TV
text: Pre- and post-apocalyptic survival series now comprise a popular reality television sub-genre.

headline: Stanford Poses a Challenge to UConn and Its Streak
text: PALO ALTO, Calif.  This date has long been circled on the women’s college basketball calendar. If the Connecticut express were to finally blow a tire, it would most likely happen Thursday at Stanford. Otherwise, the Huskies would continue racing toward the horizon of another season, unimpeded, victories rushing past like white lines on the highway.

headline: Storm Cost Retailers $1 Billion, Report Says
text: The snowstorm that swept through the Northeast kept shoppers home on Sunday and Monday and delayed about $1 billion in postholiday spending, according to a report released Wednesday. Still, retailers will probably reclaim much of that amount.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Pakistan and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Pakistan, China and Bolivia.

headline: A Bronx Bid for Dominoes to Be a Winter Olympic Sport
text: As the sun took some of the chill from the air in the South Bronx on Wednesday, residents there began to emerge onto streets that until recently had been little more than obstacle courses of ice, slush and snow.

headline: Well Received in Her Day
text: To the Editor:

headline: Jefferson’s Veiled World
text: To the Editor:

headline: Ramblings With Twain
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Great Unraveling
text: When Henry Louis Gates Jr. told Sgt. James Crowley of the Cambridge police, “You don’t know who you’re messing with,” he was speaking truth to power, albeit in a manner more akin to arrogance than erudition. The big shock here, according to the Pulitzer Prize-winning columnist Eugene Robinson, is not that a Harvard professor misused the subjective case (“who” for “whom”) and inelegantly ended a sentence with a preposition; it is, rather, that Gates belongs to an elite enclave beyond the sergeant’s experience or imagination. Gates’s life as an academic superstar places him among a select group of black Americans aptly labeled “Transcendent” by Robinson. Think of Oprah Winfrey, Beyoncé, Kobe Bryant, Vernon Jordan and Richard Parsons, the retired chief executive of Time Warner.

headline: Elegy for England
text: Impossible — and not even desirable — to disassociate this book from the circumstances of its composition. Tony Judt’s plight before his death last August was not as extreme as that of Jean-Dominique Bauby (who communicated “The Diving Bell and the Butterfly” a letter at a time, by blinking an eye), but by any reasonable standards, it was ­devastating.

headline: A Novelist Prepares
text: In 1966, an ambitious, depressed and unhappily married young woman came home to find her husband quietly enjoying a mug of coffee and a pile of her journals. As she later recalled, “I expressed moral outrage and he calmly replied that they were interesting to read and revealed things about me it was important for him to know.” This husband did not last long. But the journals endured, and now, with the second volume of “The Making of a Writer,” Gail Godwin is offering their revelations to a wider audience.

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: HERO: The Life and Legend of Lawrence of Arabia,  by Michael Korda (Harper/HarperCollins, $36.) For all its undisguised admiration for T. E. Lawrence, Korda’s biography leaves the impression that his heroism lay in a particularly stubborn brand of personal eccentricity.

headline: The Last Mitford
text: How do you even begin to write about two of the most storied people alive? One — the Anglo-Irish travel writer Sir Patrick Leigh Fermor, now 95 — infiltrated Crete during World War II, disguised as a shepherd, and captured a German general (an exploit that won him a Distinguished Service Order and inspired a film starring Dirk Bogarde). Fermor’s great friend Deborah Vivien Freeman-Mitford Cavendish, known as Debo, the Dowager Duchess of Devonshire, now 90, is the youngest (and last surviving) of the endlessly fascinating Mitford sisters, the six daughters of the eccentric Lord and Lady Redesdale. In 1956, in a letter Fermor wrote to friends after spending a holiday at Lismore, the Devonshires’ castle in Ireland, he tried to describe his hostess. She was “funny, touching, ravishing and enslaving,” he wrote, which made up for her “engagingly unashamed philistinism.” The duchess told Fermor she hated books — with the exception of Beatrix Potter’s “Ginger and Pickles,” the tale of a dog and cat who run a country grocery. Fermor was utterly charmed, and the visit spurred a correspondence that has spanned six decades.

headline: Nonfiction Chronicle
text: THE LOST PEACE  Leadership in a Time of Horror and Hope, 1945-1953.  By Robert Dallek.  Harper/HarperCollins, $28.99.

headline: The Nonconformist
text: Alice Neel has never commanded the household-name status of Georgia O’Keeffe or Frida Kahlo, art heroines who have been the subject of multiple biographies. But within the art world, she remains a beloved and influential figure. The pre-eminent painter-chronicler of New York bohemia, Neel specialized in frank, nervy portraits of artists and intellectuals and various other marginalized types, like black children, pregnant women and old men. More often that not, her subjects are shown in minimally decorated apartments, sitting by themselves or with a friend. They make you feel as if you have wandered into a room where they will continue sitting long after you have left. They are not classically attractive, with their shaggy hair and spindly, crooked German Expressionist fingers, but everyone — babies included — has a look of wide-eyed intelligence.

headline: Bookwoman
text: Sixteen years after the death of Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis from non-Hodgkins lymphoma, she remains indelible and yet unknowable, a glamorous, mysterious icon forever hidden behind oversize sunglasses. The subject of endless scrutiny, from schlocky best sellers to academically astute studies, her 64 years of life have seemingly been dissected hour by hour. Yet this season brings two new biographies that deal with the very same period: the 19 years she spent in publishing as an editor for Viking Press and then Doubleday. “Reading Jackie” by William Kuhn and “Jackie as Editor” by Greg Lawrence represent a rebranding of the legend, a strenuous effort to burnish her literary legacy.

headline: In Aphrodite’s Arms
text: My grandmother was born to Polish immigrants in Brooklyn, the fifth of six children and the first to be born in America. It’s safe to say that she struggled with the myth of the American dream. Some of her family succeeded, some did not. “Everyone needs mazel,” or luck, she’d say in Yiddish by way of explanation. “Even the dog.”

headline: Forbidden Planet
text: In August 2006, the International Astronomical Union voted to ax Pluto from our solar system’s pantheon of planets, rechristening it a “dwarf planet.” The ballot took place because Mike Brown, an astronomer at the California Institute of Technology, had detected a potential 10th planet, and the union had to decide how to categorize it. Admit the object to the roster and you pave the way for a solar system with over 100 planets. (Astronomers expect the Kuiper belt, the region beyond Neptune where the potential planet was found, to contain many similar objects.) Exclude it and you must also banish Pluto.

headline: Paperback Row
text: A BOMB IN EVERY ISSUE: How the Short, Unruly Life of Ramparts Magazine Changed America,  by Peter Richardson (The New Press, $17.95.) The San Francisco Bay Area magazine Ramparts didn’t live long — it started in 1962 as a quarterly and folded in 1975 — but this compact history credits the magazine with reviving the tradition of muckraking, exposing C.I.A. excesses and elevating the careers of notable journalists like Warren Hinckle, Robert Scheer, Adam Hochschild and Jann Wenner.

headline: ‘Decision Points’
text: To the Editor:

headline: In Europe, Mixing Union and Diversity
text: Politically, it is not at all difficult to conceive of Europe as a single entity, composed of the more than 800 million people extending far beyond the 27 countries that already belong to the European Union. But is there also something we can call “European literature,” and if so, what are the elements that make it distinctly European?

headline: Shopping With Ted Allen
text: The host of “Chopped” on the Food Network went shopping for items that would come in handy during kitchen cleanup.

headline: Bon Jovi Tops 2010 Tour Receipts
text: Bon Jovi was the top draw for concert audiences in 2010, a tumultuous year for the touring industry that experienced a drop in ticket grosses overall.

headline: The Many Faces of Stella
text: LEAVING the premier of “You Wont Miss Me,” in which Stella Schnabel plays an unstable actress recently released from a psychiatric hospital, a young woman was overheard to mutter to a friend, “Oh, Stella, she was just playing herself.”

headline: HIV Deaths Fall Below 1,000
text: Deaths from HIV in New York City fell below 1,000 in 2009 for the first time since the disease exploded in the 1980’s, the city health department announced today.

headline: Working (Part Time) in the 21st Century
text: In the Netherlands professional women have been able to work part-time for years. Now many men are doing the same, leaving them with more time for family.

headline: A Fossil Hunt in Ethiopia’s Mush Valley
text: Bonnie F. Jacobs, a paleobotanist at Southern Methodist University, writes from Ethiopia, where she is studying fossils of ancient plant and animal life. The current field season in the Mush Valley of Ethiopia is financed by a grant to Ellen Currano of Miami University, Ohio, from the National Geographic Society Committee on Research and Exploration.

headline: Big Apple Circus Goes Indie
text: On Jan. 3 and 4, an independently produced event modeled and named after the Rolling Stones’ 1968 Rock and Roll Circus hits Lincoln Center, with a lineup of indie music darlings like So So Glos, Amazing Baby, Japanther and Nick Zinner of the Yeah Yeah Yeahs. But it’s more than just a concert staged under the big top: food trucks from Mexicue, Van Leeuwen and Asia Dog will be present, and Tuesday’s show includes Big Apple Circus performances. The Moment caught up with Jessica Resler, founder of the brand development firm Muffincupcake, who engineered the project along with the event producers Adarsha Benjamin and Vance Garrett.

headline: On Our Radar: Fishing Nets Killed More Turtles Than BP Oil, Official Says
text: The impact of BP’s oil spill on threatened and endangered sea turtles in the Gulf of Mexico was serious but not catastrophic, the administrator of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, Jane Lubchenco, writes in an essay published Wednesday. Furthermore, the majority of the 600 dead turtles found during the spill appear to have been killed by fishing operations, not oil. “The heightened scrutiny of the Gulf of Mexico during the oil spill brought to light the need for stronger cooperation between N.O.A.A., the gulf states and the fishing industry to address the significant ongoing problem of sea turtles drowning in fishing operations,” Dr. Lubchenco says. [Miami Herald]

headline: Evil Spirit Alert: Keep Leaping for Your Life, Ya Big Ape
text: Is it possible that a secret colony of Mexican jumping beans has crossed the border and infected the video game designers of Austin, Tex.?

headline: The Tried and the True Step in After the Storm
text: The New York Philharmonic almost never cancels rehearsals. If the orchestra is in town, the players somehow manage to get to Avery Fisher Hall, no matter the weather or impediments to travel.

headline: Broadway Actors Who Are Bracing for Final Curtain
text: In the theater every closing night stirs up a bevy of feelings: sadness, elation, relief, anxiety. Those and many other emotions will be running high across Broadway soon, as 15 productions  almost half the shows currently playing  are scheduled to go dark by the end of January. (Reasons for the mass exodus vary; some shows are closing because of sagging ticket sales, others are finishing limited engagements.)

headline: There’s More Than One Way to Bring Home a Small Slam
text: The diagramed deal featured a very pretty play by Louk Verhees from the Netherlands. It is from Dec. 15, when he and I competed online with juniors from around the world.

headline: Working (Part-Time) in the 21st Century
text: UTRECHT, NETHERLANDS — Remco Vermaire is ambitious and, at 37, the youngest partner in his law firm. His banker clients expect him on call constantly — except on Fridays, when he looks after his two children.

headline: Students Meet the ‘Eroica’ Challenge With Gusto
text: Quantifying what a group of young musicians has learned during a 10-day program like the New York String Orchestra Seminar, currently in session at Mannes College the New School for Music, is probably impossible. And in any case the results of these intensive master classes, coaching sessions and performances may not be fully apparent until the participants have had time to let their experiences settle into their playing.

headline: Ireland = Nevada
text: As part of a project I’ve been working on, I’ve been doing some US-Europe comparisons, and have a curious parallel: by the numbers, Ireland looks a lot like Nevada. The populations are similar; the housing bubbles were comparable in their extremity; both currently have roughly 14 percent unemployment.

headline: Trailer: Donkey Kong Country Returns
text: The game is for the Nintendo Wii.

headline: N.C.A.A. Issues Rare Response to Critics
text: Is the N.C.A.A. working hard to seem more transparent in its enforcement decisions, or becoming defensive?

headline: Theater Talkback: Confessions of a Critic With No Fringe on Top
text: As someone who started losing hair before I hit 20, I made my peace with baldness long ago. Even so, a smooth pate is rarely a major social asset on a white guy. Except perhaps in a Broadway theater.

headline: History Moves in Tutus and Greasepaint
text: “AND a two and an up and a down, and eyes to the back of the room,” Charla Genn said from a perch at stage right at the Joyce Theater in Chelsea. “And a beep, and a ba-ba-ba and a tour jeté and you’re fabulous, you’re marvelous, relax.”

text: Les Ballets Trockadero de Monte Carlo is one of the few luminaries of the Off Off Broadway theater scene in the 1970s — a kind of gay artistic golden age in New York — to have survived the decades intact.

text: The war on Christmas is over, at least as far as the Lincoln Tunnel is concerned.

headline: Companies Exempt From Derivatives Rules May Yet Get Hit
text: The new financial regulations coming out of Washington are packed with exemptions – perhaps none greater than the promise to excuse Shell Energy, United Airlines and thousands of other nonfinancial companies that use derivatives from complying with proposed rules for the shadowy $600 trillion market.

text: Lauryn Hill addressed the audience hours after she was expected to perform.

headline: Worth the Wait? Just Ask Her
text: It was well past 11 on Tuesday night at the Music Hall of Williamsburg, and Ms. Lauryn Hill — maybe the most gifted female rapper in history, one of the most versatile pop talents in recent memory and also one of the great modern celebrity recluses — was nowhere in sight. By the time her D.J. played the third Nicki Minaj song of the night you had to wonder if it was a taunt.

headline: Whatever the Night, Football Wins for NBC
text: Tuesday’s “Sunday Night Football” game in Philadelphia  postponed two days because of snow  lifted NBC far above its competitors in the ratings in prime time. Although final audience figures were not immediately available, Nielsen’s preliminary overnight estimates for the broadcast were virtually identical to those for “Sunday Night Football” on Dec. 19, when 24.2 million viewers tuned in. CBS ranked a distant second on the night, as an average of 9.4 million watched the network’s broadcast of “The 33rd Annual Kennedy Center Honors” from 9 to 11. Fox was third, and ABC was fourth.

headline: Footnote
text: Lincoln Center Theater’s production of “Women on the Verge of a Nervous Breakdown” will end its Broadway run at the Belasco Theater on Sunday, three weeks earlier than scheduled, the theater announced. When it closes it will have played 30 previews and 69 performances.

headline: Perfecting Animation, via Science
text: Eitan Grinspun, the director of Columbia University’s Computer Graphics Group, doesn’t quite qualify as hairdresser to the stars. But if you want computer-generated hair (or fur) to look convincingly real when it is twisted, clumped, matted, coiled, soaked, dusty, wind swept, singed  or just about anything else a film director could possibly think to do to it  then Mr. Grinspun is the man to consult.

headline: John Hancock Tower Sells for $930 Million
text: The John Hancock Tower, a 62-story glass skyscraper in Boston’s Back Bay, was one of the first real estate trophies to run into trouble when the speculative property boom abruptly ended two years ago.

headline: A Bit More Vacation for the Obamas
text: President Obama apparently hasn’t had his fill of golfing, shave ice and swimming and snorkeling with his girls. He’s staying in Hawaii an extra day, the White House reports.

headline: Where Homework Is Managing a $200,000 Stock Portfolio
text: Bloomberg financial terminals hummed, stock prices raced across an electronic ticker, and CNBC blared in the background.

headline: Leaving Cockpit for Family
text: INDIANAPOLIS  At the office, she would speak of her desire to start a family, sometimes asking plaintively, “When I’m 80 years old, who am I going to tell I ran in the Indy 500?”

headline: A Reading Light With a Playful Hat Shade
text: The cheerful Cappello lamp, which mixes formal materials (a marble base) and informal ones (a molded paper shade), is designed for intimate tasks.

headline: Furniture Discounts at ABC Carpet, Conran and More
text: Select items at ABC Carpet & Home are discounted up to 75 percent through Jan. 30 (Tom Dixon’s Punch pendant was $820 and is now $574; Jim Denney’s Goodwood table, pictured, was $12,000, now $5,999; the Cobble Hill velvet sectional was $2,499, now $1,699); 888 Broadway (19th Street), (212) 473-3000; Bronx Warehouse Outlet, 1055 Bronx River Avenue (Westchester Avenue), (718) 842-8772 or abchome.com.
