headline: For Shoppers, a TV Guide
text: WHEN most people buy a television, they measure the wall where they want to put it and then pick the largest screen that will fit. That is exactly the right way to buy a big TV, but it misses the point if you want the right TV.

headline: Thom Filicia’s New Outpost in the Flatiron District
text: A new flag is fluttering over Broadway. It bears the image of Thom Filicia, and it flies outside the Safavieh Home Furnishings store in the Flatiron district.

headline: Yves Béhar of Fuseproject on Design With Grand Ambitions
text: Yves Béhar, the founder of the forward-thinking San Francisco firm Fuseproject, has helped create some of the most memorable designs of recent years, working with companies like Herman Miller, BMW and G. E. The Swiss-born designer has also been busy racking up honors — most recently, two Design of the Decade awards from the Industrial Designers Society of America: a gold for his Jawbone line of cellphone headsets, and a bronze for his One Laptop Per Child program.

headline: At Moss, Glass Bowls With Rope Handles
text: Industrial buckets with broken handles were the unlikely inspiration for the new Blow bowls by Alexis Georgacopoulos.

headline: After 66 Years, Her Love of Pink Hasn’t Faded
text: The allure of pink bathrooms is old news to Nora Alcaro, 90, of Philadelphia. The bathroom in the row house she shared with her husband, Peter, until he died last year, has been pink since 1944.

headline: Bathrooms: Pretty in Pink, Again
text: W HEN Nancy Burns and her husband, Thomas, moved into a 1959 split-level house in Fairfax, Va., three years ago, they tore up the cheesy shag carpeting and renovated the dark-paneled rumpus room but spared the pink-tiled bathroom with a matching pink tub and toilet that their real estate agent had thought would be a deal-breaker.

headline: Household Injuries, and How Kids Get Them
text: How do children hurt themselves at home? They act like children.

headline: With Kids and Coffee Tables, It’s Trip, Fall, Ouch
text: God does not punish Jewish children for celebrating Christmas. Uzi Rosha acknowledges that. But Mr. Rosha, a 42-year-old lawyer, cannot help but think that his son Uri’s accident  the one that opened a geyser of blood on his left cheek  would not have happened if the family had never gone to their first Christmas party.

headline: A Parlor in London That Enshrines the English Aesthetic Style
text: The ghosts of a more glamorous age stir in the home owned by Charlotte and Peter Fiell, the publishers behind the Fiell imprint.

headline: The Mathematical Carpet
text: If you are numerically inclined, this rug is for you: Hokanson Carpet’s C-84 features an abstract smattering of digits — some overlapping and some scribbled out, as on a chalkboard at the end of a three-hour math class. Each rug is custom made, and buyers can select from a variety of sizes, colors and materials, like spun or worsted cut-pile wool or wool-silk blends. The typical wait is five to eight weeks.

headline: A Recipe for Instant Snowmelt: Heat and Mash
text: Rising temperatures helped melt snow all over the city on Wednesday, but in a parking lot at Orchard Beach, the melting was helped along by a huge cooker run by the city’s Department of Sanitation, to eliminate snow carted in from nearby areas of the Bronx.

headline: Tech Talk Podcast: Greeting the New Year
text: Let’s face it — making those annual New Year’s resolutions is easy, but it’s the keeping of those resolutions that can be more of a challenge. With that in mind, Team Tech Talk takes a look at gear, apps and sites that can help sustain those good intentions a bit longer.

headline: The Mean Season
text: When I moved to New York City in August 2001, as an 18-year-old, olive-tan Floridian who had never seen snow, the closest I came to owning layers was the fake fur decorating the plastic thong on my flip flops. I had one long sleeve shirt to my name and an itchy hand-me-down sweater that my mother used on ski weekends in Colorado in the ’70s.

headline: What’s Your Worst Travel Experience of the Year?
text: This year will not be remembered as a good year in travel. There was at least one improvement for passengers traveling in America: the limitation on how long a plane could idle on the tarmac. But that came amid a slew of events that hampered air and rail travel, from the volcano in Iceland to the most recent blizzard in the Northeastern United States.

headline: H.P. Previews Intel’s New Chip
text: Intel’s Sandy Bridge processing chip will have its formal debut at next week’s Consumer Electronics Show when it arrives in a number of high-end, $1,000-plus, laptop computers.

headline: Some Northern Flair for a Pinstripe Affair
text: Doug Marrone always wanted to play in Yankee Stadium. It wasn’t that far from his home in the East Bronx, measured by nine miles or a lot of money for tickets, even back in the ’70’s.

headline: Brooklyn Fire Kills Boy, 8, in Bedroom
text: A young boy died and two people were injured on Wednesday morning in a house fire in the Mill Basin section of Brooklyn, a Fire Department official and a neighbor said.

headline: Civilian Deaths in Iraq Reported at Wartime Low
text: BAGHDAD  Fewer Iraqi civilians have been killed in violence in 2010 than during any other year since the American-led invasion of 2003, according to a Web site that monitors reports of such deaths.

headline: Ohio Court Limits Power of Localities on Gun Laws
text: CINCINNATI  The Ohio Supreme Court has upheld a 2006 law that prohibits cities and other local governments from enforcing ordinances that are more restrictive than state gun laws.

headline: Reshaping Mecca
text: Controversial new building projects are going up all over the city, including next to the Grand Mosque.

headline: Geraldine Doyle, Iconic Face of World War II, Dies at 86
text: Geraldine Hoff Doyle, who was believed to be the unwitting model for the “We Can Do It!” poster of a woman flexing her biceps in a factory during World War II  an image that later became a symbol for the American feminist movement  died on Sunday in Lansing, Mich. She was 86.

headline: Prosperity Starts With a Pea
text: AT year’s end, people around the world indulge in food rituals to ensure good luck in the days ahead. In Spain, grapes eaten as the clock turns midnight  one for each chime  foretell whether the year will be sweet or sour. In Austria, the New Year’s table is decorated with marzipan pigs to celebrate wealth, progress and prosperity. Germans savor carp and place a few fish scales in their wallets for luck. And for African-Americans and in the Southern United States, it’s all about black-eyed peas.

headline: Primero Hay Que Aprender Español. Ranhou Zai Xue Zhongwen.
text: A quiz: If a person who speaks three languages is trilingual, and one who speaks four languages is quadrilingual, what is someone called who speaks no foreign languages at all?

headline: Mother and Daughter Persevere Despite Health Problems
text: On the surface, Marie Troy, 51, and her daughter Nicole Abbate, 17, seem to have hit a rough patch  the product of bad luck, perhaps, or a bad year. But a short conversation with them reveals that the road their lives have taken has been bumpy all along, with so many detours that being sidetracked has become the norm.

headline: Policing of Clothes in Sudan’s South Reflects a Culture Clash
text: JUBA, Sudan  Joseph Lubega and his wife were strolling through a popular part of town, doing some shopping over the Christmas weekend, when a uniformed police officer approached and slapped his wife across the face, he said. The officer slapped her again. Then one more time.

headline: Reeling Giants Must Rediscover the Art of Intimidation
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.

headline: Rights Groups Tie Pakistan to Militants’ Disappearances
text: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration is expressing alarm over reports that thousands of political separatists and captured Taliban insurgents have disappeared into the hands of Pakistan’s police and security forces, and that some may have been tortured or killed.

headline: Navy Awards Two Contracts to Build New Combat Ships
text: The Navy on Wednesday awarded two companies contracts that could be worth a total of more than $7 billion to build 20 of its new littoral combat ships, splitting the purchase to obtain the vessels more quickly.

headline: Seventh Generation Highlights Its Chemical Free Detergent
text: LAUNDRY detergents have promised brighter colors and whiter whites for decades, but one brand of detergent is saying that approach should be hung out to dry.

headline: Judge Backs Appointment of New Chief for Schools
text: The appointment of Cathleen P. Black as the next New York City schools chancellor was upheld on Wednesday by a judge in Albany, clearing the way for her to start as scheduled next week.

headline: The General’s Dyspepsia
text: Washington, Dec. 30, 1860

headline: India Digs In Its Heels as China Flexes Its Muscles
text: NEW DELHI  It has been the season of geopolitical hugs in India  with one noticeable exception. One after the other, the leaders of the five permanent members of the United Nations Security Council have descended on India, accompanied by delegations of business leaders, seeking closer ties with this rising South Asian giant. The Indian media, basking in the high-level attention, have nicknamed them the “P-5.”

headline: Eugene Garfield, Founder of the Auto-Train Service, Dies at 74
text: Eugene K. Garfield, who originated the American Auto-Train, ferrying passengers and their cars between Virginia and Florida, saving people the effort of driving to their winter vacation homes and the expense of renting cars when they got there, died in Hollywood, Fla., on Sunday. He was 74.

headline: A Jeweler Who Calls Grandma His Muse
text: At age 21, Brady Legler has already achieved a measure of success that his classmates at Parsons the New School for Design might envy. A native of Kansas City, Mo., he started the Brady Legler Jewelry line there two years ago, before moving to New York. Now living in the East Village, he has also begun to sell paintings.

headline: Inaction and Delays by New York as Storm Bore Down
text: This article is by Russ Buettner, Michael M. Grynbaum and Serge F. Kovaleski.

headline: For Kodachrome Fans, Road Ends at Photo Lab in Kansas
text: PARSONS, Kan.  An unlikely pilgrimage is under way to Dwayne’s Photo, a small family business that has through luck and persistence become the last processor in the world of Kodachrome, the first successful color film and still the most beloved.

headline: A Color-Saturated Sun Sets on Kodachrome
text: The town of Parsons, Kan., is — for the moment — the worldwide epicenter of color film photography. That is where Dwayne’s Photo, a small family business, is processing the last rolls of Kodachrome. A. G. Sulzberger is there and has filed this report. Eastman Kodak stopped making the film in 2009 and gave the last roll to Steve McCurry. He shot the last three frames of that roll in Parsons before handing it in to Dwayne’s. They are displayed above.

headline: The Can’t-Do Nation
text: When does football become more than a sporting event? It’s not when the president comments on the redemption of a player who served prison time for a vicious felony. That’s a slow news week. Nor is it when a former Super Bowl quarterback crudely hits on a young woman not his wife or girlfriend. That’s an even slower news week.

headline: Massachusetts Sets Targets to Slash Carbon Emissions
text: Massachusetts officials on Wednesday announced a plan to curb heat-trapping gases emitted by homes, cars and businesses in the state by 25 percent below 1990 levels over the next decade.

headline: Giants Say the Season Is in Their Hands Alone
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Giants Coach Tom Coughlin did not look or sound Wednesday as if he was too worried about keeping his job, let alone extending the season beyond Sunday. He leaned on a lectern but did not clutch or pound it.

headline: For Some Travelers Stranded in Airports, Relief Is in 140 Characters
text: ATLANTA  Some travelers stranded by the great snowstorm of 2010 discovered a new lifeline for help. When all else fails, Twitter might be the best way to book a seat home.

headline: Deficit Hypocrisy
text: It was not long ago that Republicans succeeded in holding unemployment benefits hostage to a renewal of the high-end Bush-era income tax cuts and  as a little bonus  won deep estate tax cuts for America’s wealthiest heirs. Those cuts will add nearly $140 billion to the deficit in the near term, while doing far less to prod the economy than if the money had been spent more wisely.

headline: Germany’s Responsible Military Reform
text: Germany, like most European countries, is under pressure to cut military spending. But instead of slashing and burning, it has developed a sensible plan that links reduced spending with modernizing reforms that will let it contribute more troops to NATO operations.

headline: A Frozen City Boils Over
text: As of Wednesday afternoon, more than two days after the last flake had fallen in the huge post-Christmas blizzard, only a quarter of the residential streets in South Brooklyn had been plowed. Large sections of Queens and Staten Island remained paralyzed. With ambulance services taking hours to reach some people, Mayor Michael Bloomberg finally stopped being so casual about the city’s response to the 20-inch snowfall. He awoke to its seriousness and admitted that something had gone seriously wrong.

headline: The Messianic Schoolmaster
text: At 55 years old, William Lloyd Garrison — president of the American Anti-Slavery Society and arguably the nation’s most prominent abolitionist — was balding, square-faced and bespectacled. With his genteel manners and formal sartorial tastes, including black suits and severe black cravats, he could be mistaken for a conservative schoolmaster. But appearances masked a steely resolve capable of soaring to messianic heights.

headline: Speech, Cranky and Free
text: To the City Council in Santa Cruz, Calif., Robert Norse was a pest long before he sued it. An old-fashioned (and full-time) activist, he championed the city’s homeless and showed up regularly at meetings, making cranky comments and daring members to lose their cool.

headline: Main Victims of Mines Run by Gangsters Are Peasants
text: BAISHAZHEN, China  Peasants like Song Zuokai may be the main victims of the industrialized world’s hunger for rare earth minerals from southern China, which has helped feed a brisk illegal mining trade.

headline: Misaligned Cable Blamed for Sugarloaf Chairlift Accident
text: A chairlift accident that injured eight people Tuesday at a Maine resort occurred while workers were trying to free some 150 skiers who had become stuck on the lift after a cable went off its track, the resort said Wednesday.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,430 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American on Wednesday:

headline: Robert Macauley, Founder of Humanitarian Aid Group, Dies at 87
text: Robert C. Macauley, a paper manufacturer whose charity delivered more than $10 billion in medicine, food and humanitarian aid to alleviate crises in more than 140 countries, died on Sunday at his home in North Palm Beach, Fla. He was 87.

headline: Oil Bulls Should Take Closer Look at Supply
text: Oil bulls are once again kicking up dust. The intensifying struggle to lift output, they say, will collide with the insatiable thirst of an expanding Asia to push oil above $100 a barrel. In fact, the cost of crude may be held down as demand growth is cut by half as producers from Russia to Africa via Brazil ramp up supply.

headline: Mayor Is Criticized for Unplowed City Streets
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Cold Case, and Hope, Is Revived
text: The end of her life merited a 19-word sentence in a newspaper article about the first 10 killings on Jan. 1, 1987. She was the eighth killing recorded that day. There was no mention of her name or her age.

headline: Delaware: Complaint Made Against Senate Candidate
text: Federal authorities are reviewing an advocacy group’s complaint that accuses Christine O’Donnell, the losing Republican candidate for the United States Senate in Delaware, of misconduct, a Justice Department representative said. Kim Reeves, a spokeswoman for the United States attorney’s office in Wilmington, declined to detail the accusations made by the group, Citizens for Responsibility and Ethics, which is based in Washington. Ms. O’Donnell was dogged throughout the campaign by questions about her personal and campaign finances. Her campaign issued a statement on Wednesday denying that she misspent campaign money and saying that it had heard nothing from the authorities.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Rough Two Weeks for Giants? Rough Decade for Redskins
text: ASHBURN, Va.  If the Giants think their season has stumbled into chaos  with a coach whose job appears to be on the line, a blizzard hampering their preparation for Sunday’s game and their playoff chances slipping away  they should look to the Washington Redskins to put things into perspective.

headline: Avastin: Judging the Risks vs. Benefits
text: To the Editor:

headline: Six Recess Appointments to Be Made, Obama Says
text: HONOLULU  President Obama said Wednesday that he intended to install six appointees  including James Cole, his controversial pick for the No. 2 spot at the Justice Department  while Congress is in recess. The move will allow them to serve without confirmation by the Senate, where their prospects will only grow dimmer once Republicans gain strength in January.

headline: Religion, and the Freedom of the Open Mind
text: To the Editor:

headline: Frustration, Outrage and Neighborly Bonds on an Unplowed Block in Queens
text: The schoolteacher and her 84-year-old mother near the middle of the block were virtual shut-ins — by Wednesday, they had not ventured beyond the driveway since they returned from church early Sunday afternoon.

headline: Flights at J.F.K. Sit on Tarmac for Hours
text: At least 28 flights, carrying thousands of passengers, became stranded on the tarmac at John F. Kennedy International Airport, one for close to 11 grueling hours, in the aftermath of this week’s paralyzing blizzard, officials said. The flights had one thing in common: they all began outside the United States.

headline: Is Obama’s Plan for Guantánamo Safe and Just?
text: To the Editor:

headline: With Sanchez, Jets Weigh Momentum and Rest
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  Mark Sanchez considered the question  to play, or not to play  with a puzzled look. A reporter had asked Sanchez what he would decide if he coached the Jets, instead of being their second-year quarterback.

headline: Judge Rejects City Law on Antismoking Posters
text: A federal judge on Wednesday struck down a New York City law that would have forced all bodegas and convenience stores to post gruesome images of diseased lungs, brains and teeth in the shops to discourage people from buying cigarettes.

headline: Thursday: Clueless
text: Note: Although the Across Lite version of today’s puzzle works fine, downloading this PDF is recommended since it displays the theme more elegantly. Numbering for the print and Across Lite versions is different.*

headline: Schedules for New Year’s Eve in New York Region

headline: Shanghai Schools’ Approach Pushes Students to Top of Tests
text: SHANGHAI  In Li Zhen’s ninth-grade mathematics class here last week, the morning drill was geometry. Students at the middle school affiliated with Jing’An Teachers’ College were asked to explain the relative size of geometric shapes by using Euclid’s theorem of parallelograms.

headline: Stoudemire a Star Center Who Isn’t Really a Center
text: ORLANDO, Fla.  Amar’e Stoudemire is not a center, but he plays one on television. Often, and mostly quite well, despite his own protestations.

headline: Bloomberg v. Blizzard: How Strong Is the Mayor’s Defense?
text: It goes without saying that New Yorkers are unhappy with the way their city — and their mayor, Michael R. Bloomberg — handled the winter storm that hit the city on Sunday and Monday. Given the number of unplowed streets and unheeded 911 calls, they have ample reason to be annoyed.

headline: A Final Game for a Local Hero
text: Jake Locker, the quarterback for the University of Washington, has been defined not just by his performance or potential but also by the simple fact that he repeatedly chose to stay close to home.

headline: A High-Tech City’s Down-Home Hero
text: SEATTLE  They say Jake Locker was carved to athletic perfection between the Cascade Range and the Salish Sea. Big, strong and strikingly fast, he was a statewide myth by the time he was a teenager, a high school football force scorching through Friday nights in the farthest reaches of the Pacific Northwest.

headline: African Unity Faces a Test in Ivory Coast
text: On a continent where coups and stolen elections are far from uncommon, one thing makes the standoff over Ivory Coast exceptional: all the major powers in Africa and overseas agree that Laurent Gbagbo, the strongman leader, must go.

headline: Grounded Travelers Turn to Buses in Droves
text: Reuben Burgos, who works for Def Jam records, had to get to New York City from Los Angeles to help out at the big New Year’s Eve party in Times Square.

headline: After Years of Reaching Playoffs, Devils Reach the Bottom
text: NEWARK  Jacques Lemaire was asked why he was smiling so widely Wednesday afternoon, two hours before the Devils played the Rangers at the Prudential Center.

headline: An Election Gone Wrong Fuels Tension in Kabul
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  The inauguration of a new Parliament in just weeks threatens to worsen ethnic tensions and instability and to drive an important part of President Hamid Karzai’s political base into the arms of the insurgency, Afghans and foreign officials warn.

headline: Cuomo Picks New Location for State of the State Speech
text: Next Wednesday, four days after he is sworn in as governor, Andrew M. Cuomo will deliver the annual speech known as the State of the State address, outlining the condition of New York and his plans for the legislative session.

headline: Putin Assails Transit Officials for Response to Ice Storm at Airports
text: MOSCOW  Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putin of Russia chastised senior transportation officials on Wednesday for failing to respond adequately to widespread cancellations and delays at Moscow’s two major airports in the wake of an ice storm last weekend. He ordered the officials to call off their plans for the traditional 10-day New Year’s holiday  Russia’s most important  to prevent similar problems in the coming weeks.

headline: Corrections
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: New Look for Mecca: Gargantuan and Gaudy
text: JIDDA, Saudi Arabia  It is an architectural absurdity. Just south of the Grand Mosque in Mecca, the Muslim world’s holiest site, a kitsch rendition of London’s Big Ben is nearing completion. Called the Royal Mecca Clock Tower, it will be one of the tallest buildings in the world, the centerpiece of a complex that is housing a gargantuan shopping mall, an 800-room hotel and a prayer hall for several thousand people. Its muscular form, an unabashed knockoff of the original, blown up to a grotesque scale, will be decorated with Arabic inscriptions and topped by a crescent-shape spire in what feels like a cynical nod to Islam’s architectural past. To make room for it, the Saudi government bulldozed an 18th-century Ottoman fortress and the hill it stood on.

headline: Photo Replay: Dec. 29
text: A look at the day in sports, from eagle eyes in Switzerland to milestone coaching victories in college basketball.

headline: Bloggingheads: Tea Party Primary
text: Ben Smith, left, of Politico and David Weigel of Slate discuss the Tea Party's role in the G.O.P. presidential primaries.

headline: For G.O.P., End of the Preordained Candidate
text: WASHINGTON  A year ago, Republicans here were shut out of governing but could console themselves with having retained their hold on the party apparatus. This week, they will celebrate the new year having come roaring back to regain the House, and yet they have no semblance of control over the direction of their party and the conservative activists who seem to be steering it.

headline: Lobbyist Quits Job With Ivory Coast Leader
text: WASHINGTON  Lanny J. Davis, a well-connected Washington lobbyist who had recently come under fire for his work on behalf of President Laurent Gbagbo of Ivory Coast, announced Wednesday that he would resign from the assignment.

headline: New York Police Commissioner Unharmed After Accident
text: A sport utility vehicle in which Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly was a passenger was involved in a three-car accident on a slick Brooklyn highway on Wednesday night, though no injuries were reported, the police said.

headline: Skype Adds Video Calling to iPhone App
text: If you happen to see people making strange faces at their iPhones in the next few days, blame Skype.

headline: Groupon Draws New Investors and Works on an I.P.O.
text: Groupon, the social buying site that spurned a $6 billion takeover bid from Google earlier this month, has attracted several big institutional investors, people briefed on the matter told DealBook on Wednesday.

headline: Bomb Blast Damages Athens Court Building
text: ATHENS  A powerful bomb detonated outside a court building near central Athens on Thursday morning, but warning calls allowed the area to be cleared, the police said. There were no injuries, though the building and nearby cars were damaged.

headline: Former President of Israel Is Convicted of Rape
text: JERUSALEM  An Israeli court convicted the country’s former president, Moshe Katsav, of two counts of forcible rape on Thursday, a verdict that many Israelis described as a low point in the nation’s history, but also redemptive, in that it upheld the value of equality before the law.

headline: Fresh Crises Loom in Europe and the U.S.
text: Simon Johnson, the former chief economist at the International Monetary Fund, is the co-author of “13 Bankers.”

headline: Terror Suspects Appear in Danish Court
text: STOCKHOLM  Three men arrested in Denmark on Wednesday on suspicion of planning an imminent attack on a newspaper that published satirical cartoons of the Prophet Muhammad five years ago appeared in court on terrorism and weapons charges in Copenhagen on Thursday, and a fourth appeared in Sweden.

headline: N. Korea Boosts Tanks and Special Forces, South Says
text: SEOUL, South Korea  The North Korean military, the world’s fourth-largest, has bolstered its special-forces units during the past two years and has deployed a new battle tank, called the Storm, while expanding its tank brigades, the South Korean Defense Ministry said on Thursday in its biennial white paper.

text: From Today’s Times:

headline: A Major in Engineering, With a Minor in ‘Keeping an Open Mind’
text: In France, students are expected to choose their career paths at the end of middle school, when they are only about 14 years old. They enter specialized high schools and start learning about their future professions.

headline: Joining the Crowds for a Parisian Stroll
text: After indulging in delicious French holiday fare, you might want to burn off the calories with the Rallye Tour Eiffel, or Eiffel Tower Walk, which takes place on Jan. 8 and 9 between 3 p.m. and 1 a.m. (departure from Halle Georges Carpentier, 81 Boulevard Massena; www.godillot-familial.com).

headline: The Flowering of the Mobile Phone
text: I can’t tell you whether my cellphone will eventually replace perfume. I can, though, attest that the device comes in handier than I would have expected when the electricity fails in the house.

headline: N.F.L. Week 17 Game Probabilities: Inexplicable Chargers and Falcons
text: Brian Burke, a former Navy pilot who has taken up the less dangerous hobby of N.F.L. statistical analysis, operates Advanced NFL Stats, a blog about football, math and human behavior.

headline: Junk
text: I’ll soon be headed to Pittsburgh for the annual meeting of the American Dialect Society, where my colleagues and I will engage in discussions about the country’s diverse linguistic forms. We’ll take a break from these serious-­minded colloquies, however, for a lighthearted diversion: the selection of the Word of the Year, the lexical item that best captures the zeitgeist. In a year that brought us vuvuzelas (the dronelike plastic horns at the World Cup in South Africa) and mama grizzlies (Sarah Palin’s cadre of fierce women in the midterm elections), there’s no obvious front-runner in the sweepstakes for WOTY (pronounced “WOE-tee”). But for my money, the one word that sums up the scrapheap of the past year is junk.

headline: It’s 7 A.M. Is Your Street Plowed?
text: Updated, 10:12 a.m. | During a press conference on Wednesday, John J. Doherty, the city’s sanitation commissioner, said that he expected that every street in the five boroughs would be plowed by 7 a.m. on Thursday.

headline: Roadside Bomb Kills 14 on Afghan Minibus
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  A minibus packed with civilians, including women and children, was blown apart by a roadside bomb in southern Afghanistan’s Helmand Province on Thursday, and officials said 14 passengers were killed and at least four wounded.

headline: Shares Slip Back From 2-Year Highs
text: Stocks declined on Thursday despite reports showing a drop in jobless claims, the fastest business expansion in two decades and a gain in pending home sales.

headline: Coughlin or Cowher?
text: If the Giants lose Sunday at Washington, the pressure will build for the Giants to dismiss Coach Tom Coughlin. That may be understating it. The pressure has already been building, and she’s about to blow.

headline: Bloomberg’s Katrina
text: Michael Bloomberg has long been an object of affection from Very Serious People: he’s supposedly non-ideological, competent, able to transcend partisan divisions with a single bound. There’s a recurrent fantasy about a Bloomberg third-party candidacy that will Save America.

headline: Russian Judge Extends Term for Tycoon by 6 Years
text: MOSCOW  A judge on Thursday sentenced Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky, the Russian tycoon who was imprisoned in 2003 after defying Vladimir V. Putin, to an additional six years. It was a politically tinged decision that undermined President Dmitri A. Medvedev, who has vowed to revitalize the country’s deeply troubled legal system.

headline: London Underground | Designers to Watch
text: Who will be making it big in 2011? I asked five movers and shakers in London’s cultural world to anoint their chosen young designers. From embroidered photography to furniture fashioned from flowers, here are next year’s best and brightest.

text: “I know where we’re going. I just don’t know where the hell we’re parking.”

headline: ‘Refudiate’ Was a Typo — Political Revisionism 2010
text: Politicians love to talk about the future. They make grand promises about what they plan to do. They call on their adversaries to look forward, not back.

headline: Anadarko Shares Surge on Deal Talk
text: Speculation that BHP Billiton may make a play for Anadarko Petroleum of Houston is quickly moving shares in the company.

headline: A Last-Minute Choice by Texas and Vermont
text: Vermont and Texas, the odd couple of nuclear waste disposal, are proceeding with a plan to allow 36 other states to use a dump site under development in west Texas, despite the misgivings of Vermont’s incoming governor, Peter Shumlin, about the move.

headline: A Flurry of Finger-Pointing After the Blizzard
text: The snow piles are high and turning gray. Our advice: don’t eat the yellow snow.

headline: High I.P.O. Fees Weigh on U.S. Firms, Study Finds
text: American companies could save more than $1 billion a year if banks charged the same fees for initial public offerings as banks do in Europe, according to a new study by three British academics.

headline: O’Donnell Denies Misuse of Campaign Funds
text: Christine O’Donnell, the losing Republican candidate for Senate in Delaware,  defended herself on Thursday against accusations that she misused campaign money for personal use and said that a possible criminal investigation of her activity was a politically motivated attack by Democrats.

text: FarmVille, Zynga’s online game.

headline: A View Into New York Fed Chief’s Days
text: The Federal Reserve Bank of New York has released the daily schedule for its president, William C. Dudley, dating from January 2009 through September 2010.

headline: A New Chinese Venture for Josh Eden
text: Josh Eden, who was the chef de cuisine at Jean-Georges Vongerichten’s unsuccessful Chinese adventure, Sixty-Six, and worked with Mr. Vongerichten for 12 years, has opened Ten Ten, in Gramercy, for inventive Chinese fusion. His partner is Sally Wu, a native of Shanghai.

headline: N.H.L.’s John Collins Talks About the Winter Classic
text: The 2011 N.H.L. Winter Classic on Jan. 1 between the Washington Capitals and the Penguins is projected to bring in $9 million in ticket revenue at Heinz Field in Pittsburgh.

headline: Off the Menu: Mahjong Dumpling House

headline: Christian Bale Summons a Fallen Man’s Delusions
text: THE first time you see Christian Bale in “The Fighter,” you might gasp. He’s playing a true-life broken-down ex-boxer, Dicky Eklund, and he’s sitting on an ugly sofa wearing acid-washed jeans, a half-buttoned shirt, a glaze of oily sweat and not an ounce of fat. With his hunched shoulders and sunken eyes he looks caved in, almost collapsed. The life starts to seep back in when he begins talking, but when he loosely swats the air, his fingers remain splayed as if they had forgotten how to curl into fists. As the words keep coming, so does the life, and soon those hands are coiled hard, jabbing the air and knocking down ghosts.

headline: When Moving Seems Impossible
text: Patricia Wendler had been trying to sell her Southport, N.C., home for four years. Just before Thanksgiving, she finally got an offer, with one major contingency: Mrs. Wendler, 80, had less than three weeks to move, or no deal.

headline: Natalie Portman Embraces Monster and Victim
text: THE subject of “Black Swan”  a leading candidate for the most misunderstood film of 2010  is the relationship, in art, between technique and emotion. Ballet, the specific art form in question, is shown to require endless practice and grueling physical discipline. Bodies, in particular the bodies of young women, are stretched and twisted into unnatural postures, and the cost of the fleeting, breathtaking grace they attain is reckoned in close-ups of battered, bloody feet and tendons pulled almost to the snapping point. The toe shoes that are among the principal tools of this torment also seem to be surrogates and scapegoats; they are scraped, mutilated and disfigured by the dancers in a symbolic re-enactment of the violence they perform upon themselves in their ruthless pursuit of perfection.

headline: Outrage at Unplowed Streets? It’s a New York Tradition (and Sometimes Merited)
text: It is as much a part of a New York City blizzard as slush and cold and the color white itself: postblizzard outrage over the municipal response to said blizzard. One can imagine the very earliest settlers of New Amsterdam railed at their Dutch leaders after blizzards. The path to my farm is not plowed! It’s been three days! Het sneeuwt!

headline: Could the Next Move Be to January?
text: LOS ANGELES

headline: Iraq: A Look Back at 2010
text: As part of a TimesCast series on the major stories in 2010, Steven Lee Myers, Baghdad bureau chief, takes a look back at the major developments in the country.

headline: The Doctor vs. the Computer
text: Electronic medical records promise efficiency, safety and productivity in the switch from paper to computer. But there are glitches, as a patient of mine recently brought to light.

headline: Straddling Worlds of Performance
text: APAP: for many a New York choreographer, there’s no more frightening sequence of letters in the English language. Pronounced A-pap and used as shorthand for the Association of Performing Arts Presenters’ annual winter conference starting Friday, it’s a chaotic gantlet of showcases and networking, spread over a very long weekend. The goal is to get your performance booked outside New York. The more typical result is exhaustion, resentment and ruined nerves  especially for those artists whose boundary-pushing work doesn’t mesh with artistic directors’ looking for easy box office sells.

headline: A Maestro’s Four-Decade Evolution
text: AS if to make up for his reduced presence there, the Metropolitan Opera has favored us with two giant boxed sets, of 32 CDs and 21 DVDs, in celebration of James Levine’s 40 years with the company. They are quite wonderful, confirming all sorts of happy memories  which in my case date back to a performance in Los Angeles of “Tosca” in 1971, three weeks after he made his Met debut in the same opera. They restore one’s faith in all that Mr. Levine has been, and in what he may one day again become.

headline: Thursday Reading: A Television Buying Guide
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: Godard as Oscar Provocateur
text: WHEN the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences gathered on Nov. 13 to give out the honorary Oscars known as the Governors Awards, one of the evening’s honorees, Jean-Luc Godard, was not present. Not even in spirit. Mr. Godard, then just three weeks shy of his 80th birthday, kept his customary distance from his American admirers, several of whom stepped up to the microphone that night to toast him in terms that, in their amiable vagueness, betrayed the general bafflement that was, and is, the most characteristic effect of his stubborn art.

headline: Nocturnalist | Dipping With the Debs
A Leaner Goldman Sachs Is Seen
text: Credit Suisse analysts on Thursday lowered their earnings estimates for both Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley, citing “choppier than expected” market conditions in the fourth quarter.

headline: Year-End Investor Letter: A Wall St. Parody
text: It’s the season for the most introspective of Wall Street types, the hedge fund manager, to channel his inner Jack Handey and reflect on the flurry of numbers that dance across his Bloomberg terminal.

headline: Hedda Gabler to Medea to Frazzled Mom
text: ANNETTE BENING has portrayed many women in her life. On the big screen she has embodied a conniving widow (in “Valmont”), a giggly con artist (“The Grifters”), a sexy mob moll (“Bugsy”), a feisty environmental activist (“The American President”), an adulterous suburban wife (“American Beauty”) and a fading British actress (“Being Julia”). Off the big screen her portrayals have included a private school headmistress turned convicted murderer (“Mrs. Harris” on HBO) and straight woman to the Cookie Monster on video.

headline: Many Bus Lines Are Still Detoured by Snow
text: Updated, 11:19 a.m. | Despite municipal promises that all streets would be cleared by 7 a.m. — and the mayor’s assertion at 11:15 a.m. that every block in the city had been plowed at least once except for ones that were blocked by stuck cars — many of the city’s roadways are not yet clear enough for buses to get through.

headline: Move to Curb Transactions for Iranian Oil Leaves Indian Companies Scrambling
text: NEW DELHI  Officials in India and Iran scrambled Thursday to keep the $11 billion in oil and gas trade between them going after India’s central bank declared last week that a regional clearinghouse could no longer be used to settle such transactions.

headline: The Prince and the Uncommon Commoner
text: “THE KING’S SPEECH,” in which Colin Firth and Geoffrey Rush play a future English king and the eccentric therapist he hires to help him overcome his stammer, might qualify as a buddy movie if their relationship weren’t so prickly. Prince Albert, or “Bertie,” as his cheeky, would-be miracle worker, Lionel Logue, insists on calling him, is a stickler for formality and protocol. Lionel, an Australian brewer’s son, with a wife and two children, is an impudent free spirit and true believer in equality.

headline: Iraq in Review: The Great Game and a New Dawn
text: Baghdad Bureau Chief Steven Lee Myers takes a look back at the major developments in the country over the last year.

headline: Start-Stop Technology: Not Just for Hybrids Anymore
text: 12:11 p.m. | Updated

headline: A Big Payday for Groupon’s Directors
text: Groupon has already locked in $500 million in new cash in a funding round that could reach as high as $950 million, according to a Securities and Exchange Commission filing submitted on Thursday.

headline: Hold That Obit; MoMA’s Not Dead
text: WHEN I walk through the Museum of Modern Art these days, it sometimes feels as if the place has come back from the dead — even if I’m not always so crazy about the life it happens to be leading. There’s often a confusing, disjunctive quality to it, especially where contemporary art is concerned, as the museum’s programming lurches from crowd-drawing, performance-art spectacles in the atrium to relatively dry and didactic exhibitions in its galleries. But at least there’s a pulse.

headline: Looking Back on a Year of Parenting
text: Cash Van Rowe just celebrated his first birthday last week. The story of his birth appeared on Motherlode on Jan. 6, 2010, when, in one of the first of the 408 posts here this past year, his mother, Heather, wrote about how her partner, Britt, delivered their baby at home in (another) epic snowstorm. There was noise, and drama as the emergency workers fought their way through the drifts. Later, in the hospital, there was silence, as the pediatrician brought the news that Cash had Down Syndrome.

headline: Global Entertainment
text: Maps have always had admirers: people collect them, display them, linger over them in museum exhibitions. Yet it is only in recent years that geography, organized not on paper but online, has really arrived as popular entertainment — as diverting as the latest stupid video your Facebook friends are linking to yet somehow more virtuous or, at times, titillating. Or both.

headline: The Caste Buster
text: I came to Umred to write about a riot. A few months earlier, power blackouts that rural Indians always suffered silently triggered a violent reaction. Why? Umred was just another small town in the middle of nowhere, dusty and underwhelming. But Umred had begun to dream, townspeople told me, because of television, because of cousins with tales of call-center jobs and freedom in the city. Once Umred contracted ambition, blackouts became intolerable. A psychological revolution, a revolution in expectations, had taken place.

headline: Splitting the Costs
text: My mother and her sister bought a diamond ring, splitting the cost and agreeing to share the profit when my mother could resell it at her small antiques shop. Unfortunately, the ring was stolen, apparently pocketed by a customer. My mother has no insurance but offered to reimburse her sister for her share of the ring, and my aunt accepted. They’re fine with this, but it gnaws at me that my aunt took advantage of my mother. Didn’t she? NAME WITHHELD, MASSACHUSETTS﻿Your mother did right by offering to reimburse your aunt; your aunt did no wrong by accepting, as both of them apparently understand. The only one flustered is you. You should defer to their judgment and undergo some sort of deflustering.

headline: My Cart, My Self
text: I bought a lot of things online over the holiday season, and now I’m facing the New Year hangover — not credit-card debt but the blitz of recommendations for books and movies and other products that were generated by the secret software that Amazon and other companies use to analyze and predict my tastes. I’m not sure what I think of the selections, though. I’m not sure how well these computer programs know me. Some of their choices seem simplistic or patronizing, while others strike me as random, even crazy. And some are dead on, of course, which I find troubling. The only thing worse than being misperceived by a machine is being expertly perceived by one.

headline: Starter Buddha
text: Autumn in Beijing, where we had gone to live, and my husband and I were surrounded by Chinese “antiques” at the biggest flea market in town — detritus of a country embracing free-market enterprise. There were rows of vintage Mao wristwatches, red and black feng-shui meters, brightly embroidered Tibetan booties and slim, early-Communist-era cigarette cases. We could buy tea-stained calligraphy scrolls and vintage Cultural Revolution posters. We could bargain over the earliest Chinese radios and glass mirrors with etchings of the Imperial family. We could bargain over just about anything.

headline: Life of the Party
text: When the 112th U.S. Congress is officially sworn in on Jan. 5, two black Republicans will be among the new majority in the House of Representatives. Do you think the G.O.P. has made progress in attracting African-Americans to the party? One thing that you guys aren’t talking about is the fact that there were 42 African-Americans that ran on the Republican ticket in this election cycle; 14 made it to the general election, and 2 of us were elected to the House.

headline: Rewired
text: Fiber optics have finally arrived in my neighborhood! One frigid day, workmen from FiOS, the Verizon service renowned for providing home Internet service at the speed of light, showed up with ear protectors and jackhammers. Then, as workmen have done regularly for more than a century in Brooklyn, they tore up the road. Like miners in reverse, they laid down pure telecommunications ore, threading strands of silver-black fiber-optic cable under Hicks Street, a lopsided, part-cobblestone thoroughfare down which chugged the Hicks Street Line, a railroad that ran at the turn of the 20th century.

headline: North Korea Gets a Special Kick Out of ‘Bend It Like Beckham’
text: While you’re trying to decide whether you should spend your New Year’s Day watching a Three Stooges marathon on AMC, a “Doctor Who” marathon on BBC America or a “Twilight Zone” marathon on Syfy, think of the people of North Korea, whose television options consist of state-run “news” programs. But on Sunday, The Associated Press reported, North Korean television audiences were given a rare break from this routine when the British comedy “Bend It Like Beckham” was shown there. The film, which stars Parminder Nagra as a young woman from a Sikh family with dreams of soccer stardom; Keira Knightley as her best friend; and Jonathan Rhys Meyers as the dreamy coach they both have eyes on, was shown over the weekend by the arrangement of the British Embassy. According to the BBC, a message was shown during the film saying that the broadcast was done to mark the 10th anniversary of diplomatic ties between North Korea and Britain.

Opened late last spring, the space stocks under-the-radar brands including Snowberry, Uslu Airlines, Less is More and Scandalous, and offers a well-edited selection of indie fragrances, including options from Six Scents, Le Labo and Byredo. Go to colette.fr.

headline: A Weekend in Santa Cruz
text: Forget what you heard about Santa Cruz being the city that sleeps. This sunny coastal town still has its countercultural wackiness. But Santa Cruz has been stirred by the tech boom in nearby Silicon Valley.

headline: 36 Hours in Santa Cruz, Calif.
text: FORGET what you heard about Santa Cruz being the city that sleeps. Yes, this sunny coastal town still has its countercultural wackiness. You can still watch surfers shred waves, ride a seaside roller coaster on the Santa Cruz Beach Boardwalk and hear a street musician sing Pink Floyd’s “Goodbye Cruel World.” But Santa Cruz has been stirred by the tech boom in nearby Silicon Valley. In the past, “rabid localism” meant getting a black eye at the Stockton Avenue surf break. Now, the term refers to the restaurant that uses eggs from its own chicken coop, and the woman who churns organic ice cream with fennel foraged from a nearby field. And sleek lounges offer reasons to stay up until 2 a.m., an eternity by old Santa Cruz standards.

headline: My Plate Is Full. Yours Is Borrowed.

headline: Weak-Kneed Willpower Faces Temptation’s Lure
text: If you want a little insurance to help keep those New Year’s resolutions, you might consider turning to StickK.com. Started by two Yale professors and a graduate student in 2008, the Web site provides a binding contract to help you meet a particular goal, whether it is shedding pounds, quitting smoking or finishing Proust. Fail to live up to your end of the deal, and you have to pay a person or charity that you have designated in advance. You can even increase the incentive by choosing an anti-charity, a cause that you would normally oppose. Gun-control advocates, for example, could decide to forfeit their money to the National Rifle Association if they falter, while anti-abortion advocates might choose NARAL Pro-Choice America.

headline: Polenta Made Creamy With Celeriac

Then we face the question of consistency (soft or firm), and finally there are all the possible mix-ins and garnishes. You see a lot of butter and cheese, for instance, and milk, cream or mascarpone are not unknown. That said, the best polenta I’ve ever eaten was in Venice, and it was just white corn meal and water — served with spectacular, sweet tiny gray shrimp from local waters.

headline: CBS Wins a Slow Night
text: CBS was the most-watched network in prime time on Wednesday, a night of low-rated repeats. According to Nielsen’s estimates, CBS’s rerun of “Criminal Minds” earned the largest audience, with 9.3 million viewers at 9, while the network won the 8 o’clock hour too, with a repeat of “NCIS: Los Angeles” (6.9 million). NBC’s rerun of “Law & Order: SVU” (6.8 million) edged ahead of “The Defenders” on CBS (6.5 million) in the 10 p.m. time slot, although an earlier repeat of “SVU” drew just 4.5 million viewers at 9. NBC ranked second for the night over all. ABC finished close behind with repeats of its comedy lineup, including two “Modern Family” episodes in the 9 p.m. hour (6.1 million) and back-to-back reruns of “Cougar Town” in the 10 p.m. hour (3.3 million). Fox was fourth.
