headline: Perfect Poise, Pulled From Jaws of Distortion
text: ‘COMTESSE D’HAUSSONVILLE,’ BY INGRES, THE FRICK COLLECTION If not always for the same reasons, people of both genders love to feast their eyes on beautiful women. So it is no coincidence that some of the world’s most compelling works of art are weddings of female and painterly beauty. One is at the Frick Collection: “Comtesse d’Haussonville” (1845), a near life-size portrait of a lovely young woman standing before a mirror in a blue satin dress. Rendered by Ingres in a cool, neo-Classical style, she tilts her head, holds an index finger to her chin and gazes back with lowered eyelids and a quizzical, enigmatic expression.

headline: Keeping Score: Hall of Fame, by the Numbers
text: The reasons for voting for one player for Hall of Fame induction over another are as varied as the 500-plus writers, statisticians and bloggers who vote for the Hall of Fame. Generally, a player’s candidacy comes down to how a voter views the player’s career record and contribution to the teams he played for. These are, not coincidentally, the areas that sabermetrics (the analytical study of baseball) is most focused on.

headline: Extravagant or Modest, Inaugurations Vary With the Star of the Show
text: As far as political theater is concerned, an inauguration is a classic of the genre: an opportunity for a politician to bask in the trappings of a new office, to set forth a new political order and to revel once again in the triumph of an election.

headline: U.S. Unveils Plan to Sell Stake in Ally, Once GMAC
text: 7:50 p.m. | Updated The federal government said on Thursday that it was planning a complex transaction that would temporarily increase its ownership position in the former lending arm of General Motors to nearly three-fourths of the company while also paving the way to cash out its stake.

headline: Four Spas in New York
text: Russian & Turkish Baths, Body by Brooklyn, Spa Castle and Juvenex Spa.

headline: Take a Plunge, Soak Up Heat, Try a Scrub, Stay Off Your Feet
text: IT’S a typical weekend afternoon at Body by Brooklyn, a spa in the borough’s Clinton Hill neighborhood. In the “wet room” men and women in bathing suits step in and out of the Turkish steam room, two saunas and a cold plunge pool, or sip iced drinks as they rest on reclining chairs near the Jacuzzi.

headline: The Case Against Katsav
text: JERUSALEM 

headline: Landscapes and Still Lifes of New Territories
text: FAVORITE paintings in New York museums? You don’t have to be an art critic to have a few, or a few dozen. Winnowing these treasures down to five — the assignment here for three critics for The New York Times — is a pleasant, invigorating yet implicitly arbitrary endeavor. The resulting lists can only be characterized conditionally, as personal, partial or provisional.

headline: An Evangelical Backlash Against Environmentalism
text: Over the last decade, many evangelical Christians have embraced the doctrine called creation care, which uses a scriptural basis to promote good stewardship of the earth and its resources. For these believers, problems like climate change threaten to greatly intensify third-world poverty, making actions to reduce global warming emissions an urgent Christian issue.

headline: John Simon Steps Into the Blogosphere With a Few Words About ‘Spider-Man’
text: After 50 years writing criticism for newspapers, magazines and literary journals, John Simon has become a blogger. His first post is on “Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark.” And — surprise, surprise — he’s got a contrary take.

headline: Overlooked Works That Deserve Another Glance
text: ‘MANUEL OSORIO MANRIQUE DE ZUÑIGA,’ BY GOYA, METROPOLITAN MUSEUM OF ART There’s a reason that this painting is one of the first you see when you walk up the Met’s main staircase, pass through the heavy glass doors into European Paintings, and turn right (as museumgoers invariably do). It isn’t just the color — an arresting tomato red against green-gray — or the adorably precocious subject, the third son of the count of Altamira. It’s the unsettling way in which Goya complicates 18th-century ideas about childhood.

headline: Dance Listings for Dec. 31- Jan. 7
text: Dance

headline: Deciding Whether to Buy or Rent
text: IN today’s market, with uncertainty the sole certainty up ahead, the age-old question  rent or buy?  becomes increasingly perplexing.

headline: Time to Turn the Cultural Page
text: IT wasn’t easy for critics to choose the best cultural offerings of 2010. But whatever moments onstage still linger in our memory, Jay Gatsby himself would advise against dwelling too long on the year that was. Now is the time to look forward: what performances in 2011 will inspire, shock, cheer us, maybe even change our world?

headline: Reader Photos: Extreme Holiday Sweaters
text: Readers have sent photographs of their boldest, most garish sweaters.

headline: Christians Are Casualties of 10 Baghdad Attacks
text: BAGHDAD  One week after an Islamic extremist group vowed to kill Christians in Iraq, a cluster of 10 bomb attacks rattled Baghdad on Thursday night and sent additional tremors of fear through the country’s already shaken Christian minority.

headline: Q & A
text: An Error in Calculating Maintenance Charges

headline: The Vatican Creates a Financial Watchdog
text: VATICAN CITY — Amid a judicial investigation into its famously secretive bank, the Vatican created its own financial watchdog on Thursday and issued sweeping and tough new laws aimed at meeting international standards against money laundering and terrorist financing.

headline: Courbet, Bellini, Guston
text: A look at some of Karen Rosenberg’s favorite works in New York museums.

headline: Admiring Miró
text: Roberta Smith picks some of her favorite works in museums in New York City.

headline: A Home That Is Sometimes a Salon
text: RODNEY TERICH LEONARD, a gregarious jack-of-many-trades, adores a crowd. His annual birthday tributes to the singer Nina Simone, held in his exquisitely restored duplex in a West Harlem brownstone, are the talk of the neighborhood. So are what he calls his “salons,” lively events celebrating the Harlem arts scene. He can entertain 80 for cocktails without breaking a sweat.

headline: N.F.L.’s Statement on Punishment of Jets
text: The N.F.L. fined the Jets $100,000 on Thursday for the sideline wall and trip orchestrated by the strength coach Sal Alosi against  a Dolphins punt gunner  earlier this month.

headline: TimesCast Year in Review: Haiti
text: As part of a TimesCast series on the major stories in 2010, a look at Haiti.

headline: At Vero, Small Plates for an Italian Sampler
text: TWO of the hottest restaurant trends on Long Island are wine bars and small-plate dining. Vero, in Amityville, combines them, along with two other attributes that give it an edge over the competition: an experienced owner and a talented chef.

headline: The Sunday Roast Sandwich
text: The Belgian fries at Press 195, a two-month-old restaurant in Rockville Centre, are the stuff that cravings are made of. Burnished and crunchy outside, soft and creamy inside, they come with a selection of dipping sauces like chipotle mayo (fries, $6.50 for a large cone; sauces, 75 cents apiece).

headline: Long on Space, Water and Industry
text: ON the first Sunday in December, the St. Stanislaus Kostka School held its annual Christmas bazaar. Attendees sampled Polish specialties and bought chances to win prizes that included a 40-inch plasma television. Afterward, people filed outside to watch Sayreville’s annual holiday parade, cheering on the bands and floats as they marched up Main Street and catching candy tossed by volunteer firefighters from their lighted-up trucks.

headline: Sandwich Twins
text: About two and a half centuries have passed since the hungry Fourth Earl of Sandwich, unwilling to pause during a card game, called for his now famous snack — a handy little meal that has grown in popularity and complexity ever since.

headline: A Merger of Cuisines, With Sushi in the Fore
text: LIKE many other Asian restaurants that strain their resources in an attempt to satisfy the tastes of all potential customers, Oishii Asian Fusion succeeds only some of the time. Although a couple of dishes that I tried recently — like the tasty tuna tortilla, similar to a small pizza of tuna slices drizzled with a tangy Japanese mayonnaise — merged or fused elements from non-Asian cuisines, this restaurant’s menu is more pan-Asian than fusion, with specific offerings culled from the Far East and Southeast Asia.

headline: A Slice of Virtue
text: Chris and Kate Saville set out to create a pizza that would be as nutritious as it was tasty. They came up with the Flatz Company, a sleek shop they opened in Wyckoff a year ago. There, they serve crispy, thin-crust whole wheat “flat” pies with at least 45 grams of protein and 8 grams of fiber each; a small slice — there are eight slices in a 12-inch pie — has 5 grams of fat.

headline: A Chinese Take on Sushi and Sashimi
text: THERE’S an easy camaraderie behind the sushi bar at Taka Sushi in Summit, where the three or four chefs smile and murmur among themselves as if sharing an inside joke. Maybe the joke is that nearly all of them are Chinese, not Japanese, recruited from New York City and trained by the restaurant’s head chef, Bid Chen, who regularly works alongside them and also happens to be Chinese. Or perhaps it’s just the secret delight that comes with cranking out some of the best fish in the area.

headline: An Alternative to Beef: Bison
text: If eating healthier food is your New Year’s resolution, you might want to visit Creamery Brook farm, where the principal product is bison meat, significantly lower in fat (and higher in iron and protein) than beef, pork and chicken.

headline: South Indian Flavors, Served Cafeteria-Style
text: AT the turn of the new year, with post-holiday wallets slim and bellies amply filled, Udupi Bhavan, a very inexpensive South Indian restaurant in Middletown, holds special appeal.

headline: Ex-Candidate Says Inquiry Into Finances Is Political
text: WASHINGTON  Christine O’Donnell, the losing Republican candidate for Senate in Delaware, defended herself on Thursday against accusations that she misused campaign money for personal expenses and said a reported criminal investigation of her activity was a politically motivated attack by Democrats.

headline: Events in Connecticut
text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in Connecticut this week. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com, or by mail to the Connecticut Calendar, Metropolitan, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

headline: Events in New Jersey
text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405; or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: Events on Long Island
text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around Nassau and Suffolk Counties this week. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com, or by mail to Long Island Weekly, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

headline: Events in Westchester
text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around the Hudson Valley. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com, or by mail to Westchester Calendar, Metropolitan, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

headline: Parliament Takes on Contractors in Somalia
text: MOGADISHU, Somalia  Somalia’s Parliament demanded Thursday that the government immediately suspend the operations of several foreign security contractors because the lawmakers said they had no idea what the contractors were actually doing.

headline: Peace Hovers in Sudan, but Most Soldiers Stay Armed
text: JUBA, Sudan  Nearly six years ago, northern and southern Sudan signed a peace agreement after decades of civil war, hoping to finally bring the suffering to an end. Hundreds of thousands of soldiers had fought one another, some growing up on the battlefield. In the south, millions of people lost their lives, villages disappearing beneath plumes of smoke.

headline: Practice Those Pliés
text: THE notion that film inspires fashion is one of the style world’s hoariest clichés. But in the case of “Black Swan,” in which Natalie Portman plays an ambition-maddened dancer, that chestnut bears some truth. Darren Aronofsky’s Grand Guignol of a film both reflects — and anticipates — a trend in the making, its multilayered tutus, feathers and cobwebby knits attesting to a shift in the fashion wind.

headline: In Mel Gibson Case, A.C.L.U. Fights Move to Bar Ex-Lover’s Lawyer
text: LOS ANGELES  Larry King’s long-running interview program on CNN may be gone. But it is not forgotten  at least, not in the courts here.

headline: Judge Dismisses Hedge Funds’ Case Against Porsche
text: A federal judge in Manhattan on Thursday dismissed a $2 billion lawsuit brought against Porsche by 10 hedge fund managers, stating that the New York court had no jurisdiction over lawsuits related to foreign securities — an outcome predicted in an October Deal Professor column.

headline: On the Runway: Ballerina Chic
text: Kate and Laura Mulleavy of Rodarte are not the only designers with ballet on their minds.

headline: ‘Spider-Man’ Confirms Departure of Actress Natalie Mendoza
text: Michael Cohl, the lead producer of the Broadway musical “Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark,” formally announced in a statement on Thursday that the actress Natalie Mendoza was leaving the show. Ms. Mendoza, who portrayed the mythical spider-woman Arachne in the musical, suffered a concussion in the show’s first preview performance in November and had not appeared in it since Dec. 20, when a co-star, Christopher Tierney, was injured in a mid-performance accident. Word of Ms. Mendoza’s exit surfaced earlier this week, but neither she nor Mr. Cohl nor the “Spider-Man” director, Julie Taymor, had commented on it at the time.

headline: And Then, in a Grimy Squish, Came the Slush
text: Snow is fun for children and happy people. But what of the misanthrope, the bitter, the left-behind and burned-out? For them, the big moment arrived Thursday, finally, with the highest temperature in days turning beautiful, white snow into frigid, quasi-liquid gray and providing free entertainment for those who revel in the misfortune of others.

headline: Nonprofit News May Thrive in Comcast Takeover
text: Included in Comcast’s promises regarding its acquisition of NBC is a little-noticed plan that may stimulate the growth of nonprofit news organizations.

headline: Twins’ Facebook Fight Rages On
text: SAN DIEGO  Some people go to court hoping to win millions of dollars. Tyler and Cameron Winklevoss have already won tens of millions. But six years into a legal feud with Facebook, they want to give it back  for a chance to get more.

headline: Lobbying Law Keeps Conflicts Out of Public Eye
text: When Texas lawmakers begin grappling with the state’s huge budget shortfall next month, they will not be working alone: cities, counties and other public entities  and, of course, corporations and special interest groups  will send hundreds of lobbyists to the Capitol to defend their interests.

headline: Bears Have Look of a Champion With Cutler
text: Brian Urlacher, one of a handful of relics remaining from the Bears’ 2006 Super Bowl team, is of the opinion that the current squad is better than that one, largely because Jay Cutler’s big-armed presence at quarterback provides a home-run capability the ’06 Bears lacked with little Rex Grossman doing the throwing.

headline: Shaping a Network With Oprah’s View
text: For decades cable channels have been built around specific interests like news, sports or classic movies. Beginning this weekend, there will be something altogether different: a cable channel shaped around a person, Oprah Winfrey.

headline: A Federal Lifeline for Hard-Pressed School Districts
text: When Farmington Central School District 265 learned it was eligible for an infusion of $417,000 in federal aid to save jobs this school year, the district had the option to spend it on anything from new hires to raises for teachers, or even to meet benefits liabilities.

headline: Clicking ‘Like’ on Palin’s Use of Facebook
text: It seems that Facebook users understand what many a political journalist has come to know: Sarah Palin is quite adept at employing social media.

headline: Emanuel-Clinton Linkage Began Early and Goes Deep
text: James Warren writes a column for the Chicago News Cooperative.

headline: N.F.L. Reduces Three Big Fines for Hits to the Head
text: The N.F.L.’s crackdown on hits to the head has generated plenty of controversy this season, in part because of the big fines levied against players who make the hits. But a person with knowledge of the league’s system on fines said the fines on Atlanta cornerback Dunta Robinson, New England safety Brandon Meriweather and Pittsburgh linebacker James Harrison for flagrant hits on defenseless receivers had been reduced.

headline: ‘Red Tourism’ Thrives in Yan’an, China
text: Local officials and businesspeople in Yan’an, China, are profiting from a boom in “red tourism,” in which Chinese, many of them young professionals, journey to famous revolutionary sites.

headline: Tricky Call for New Governors: Price of Inaugurals
text: MIAMI — To warm up the Florida crowds for his inauguration as governor, Rick Scott has been flying around the state this week on a seven-city “appreciation” tour. For the main event on Tuesday, he will lead a parade featuring 26 marching bands, followed by a black-tie dinner for 2,100 people, with oysters Rockefeller and fried calamari served in mini-martini glasses. “Real classy,” said Christy Noftz, who is overseeing the catering.

headline: Revolution Isn’t a Party, but It Draws Tourists
text: YAN’AN, China  The explosives had been set, the watchtower manned and the dirt battlefield cleared of rubble. Communist soldiers armed with rifles took up positions at the foot of the barren hills. Their foes, the Kuomintang, loomed in the distance, advancing on the garrison town of Yan’an.

headline: Clock Ticks for a Jet, and a Record Approaches
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  As if fullback Tony Richardson needed a reminder, the faux street sign hangs inside his locker at the Jets’ facility, depicting a hobbled old man, bent over, leaning on a cane. “Geezer crossing,” the sign reads.

headline: As for Empathy, the Haves Have Not
text: THE GIST The rich don’t get how the other half lives.

headline: E.P.A. Limit on Gases to Pose Risk to Obama and Congress
text: WASHINGTON — With the federal government set to regulate climate-altering gases from factories and power plants for the first time, the Obama administration and the new Congress are headed for a clash that carries substantial risks for both sides.

headline: No Traditional First-Lady Role for Busy Sandra Lee
text: She will spend the night in Albany with him on New Year’s Eve, stand by his side as he is sworn in to office and might even greet guests who come to congratulate him at the governor’s mansion.

headline: America Is Waiting for the Economic Ripple Effect
text: What does the American economy need to get back on its feet? What would help tremendously is fewer roommates.

headline: Sisters’ Prison Release Is Tied to Donation of Kidney
text: Two Mississippi sisters serving double life sentences for their roles in an $11 armed robbery will be released, but only on the condition that the younger sibling donate her kidney to her sister, whose organs are failing, state officials said Thursday.

headline: New Capital for Groupon Sets Stage for an Offering
text: The 30-year-old founder and chief executive of Groupon, Andrew Mason, could raise as much as $950 million from investors in the next few weeks, laying the groundwork for a multibillion-dollar initial public offering in 2011.

headline: Rethinking the Old Public Functionary
text: By late December 1860, President James Buchanan was easily the most despised man in America, and particularly in the North. “The President,” one supporter observed glumly, “seems to be execrated now by four fifths of the people of all parties” – and this in New York City, the center of the cotton trade and the most pro-Southern city in the free states.

headline: Academic Economists to Consider Ethics Code
text: WASHINGTON  When the Stanford business professor Darrell Duffie co-wrote a book on how to overhaul Wall Street regulations, he did not mention that he sits on the board of Moody’s, the credit rating agency.

headline: Governor Cuomo
text: Andrew Cuomo’s inauguration ceremony on Saturday will be comparatively modest  a long way from former Gov. George Pataki’s black-tie gala and marching bands. That is appropriate at a time when New York State is mired in both a fiscal and political crisis.

headline: Haiti’s Vote
text: An agreement reached this week between the government of Haiti and the Organization of American States points the way out of the country’s paralyzing presidential election crisis. The deal will allow experts from the O.A.S. to re-examine the results of the Nov. 28 vote to try to clear up the uncertainty over who won second place and will go on to a January runoff.

headline: Still Cruel, Less Usual
text: The tide continued ebbing on the death penalty this year. States are putting fewer people to death, and juries continue to favor the punishment of life without parole over execution when given the choice. A report released this month by the Death Penalty Information Center counted 46 executions in 2010. That is nearly 12 percent fewer than a year ago, and down sharply from the 85 executions of 2000.

headline: Anchor Is Sidelined
text: Will Selva, an ESPNews anchor, has been sidelined after apparently plagiarizing several sentences of an Orange County Register newspaper column on Tuesday night. Selva said in a statement that he had made a “horrible mistake” by copy-and-pasting the text of the story and forgetting to then write a script in his own words. The words were originally written by Kevin Ding, who covers the Los Angeles Lakers for The Register.

headline: When Election Police Go Easy
text: You would not lose a bet at the Caucus Room, the watering hole for power lobbyists, by wagering that the most dysfunctional agency in Washington is the Federal Election Commission. For years, far too many commission members have put their partisan loyalties far above that of the public interest.

headline: Weathering the Storms of Voter Discontent
text: WASHINGTON — Long is the list of elected officials who, unbowed by terrorist threats, sex scandals, mobsters, pandemics, school system meltdowns, transit strikes or random acts of corruption, found themselves doomed by precipitation.

headline: Kansas St. Is Undone by Syracuse and Penalty
text: Kansas State wide receiver Adrian Hilburn polished off the final touchdown of the inaugural Pinstripe Bowl at Yankee Stadium on Thursday by stopping outside the back of the end zone, not far from the visitors’ dugout and a 3-foot-high bank of snow, then saluting the Wildcats’ fans.

headline: The New Voodoo
text: Hypocrisy never goes out of style, but, even so, 2010 was something special. For it was the year of budget doubletalk  the year of arsonists posing as firemen, of people railing against deficits while doing everything they could to make those deficits bigger.

headline: Lottery Numbers
The Arena Culture
text: Academic life encourages specialization and technical thinking, and, oddly, there are few fields in which this is more true than philosophy. The discipline that should be of interest to everybody is often the most impenetrable.

headline: Lobbyist’s Client List Puts Him on the Defensive
text: WASHINGTON  After decades of work for some of this country’s most powerful lobbying firms, Lanny J. Davis, the lawyer who once helped defend President Bill Clinton from impeachment, is suddenly scrambling to defend himself.

headline: Real Life Among the Old Old
text: I RECENTLY turned 65, just ahead of the millions in the baby boom generation who will begin to cross the same symbolically fraught threshold in the new year to a chorus of well-intended assurances that “age is just a number.” But my family album tells a different story. I am descended from a long line of women who lived into their 90s, and their last years suggest that my generation’s vision of an ageless old age bears about as much resemblance to real old age as our earlier idealization of painless childbirth without drugs did to real labor.

headline: Paterson and Federal Officials Reach Pact on Immigration
text: Gov. David A. Paterson, seeking to assuage critics of a new government program to strengthen immigration enforcement, said Thursday that he had negotiated a pact with federal officials to help protect illegal immigrants in New York without criminal records.

headline: A New Ambassador to Syria, but Little Hope of Change
text: WASHINGTON  When Robert S. Ford, a career diplomat with deep experience in the Middle East, presents his credentials as ambassador to Syria, he will be the first person to hold the job since 2005, and the public face of the Obama administration’s belief in engagement over isolation.

headline: The War on Child Poverty: A Mandate for Cuomo
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Virtue of Earmarks, and the Fear of Alternatives
text: To the Editor:

headline: Solving the States’ Deficit Problems
text: To the Editor:

headline: As Collapse at New Jersey Towers Is Repaired, Tenants Trickle Back In
text: HACKENSACK, N.J.  It sounds like a small thing, but for Debi and Gary Presslaff, it was quite a milestone: last week, they and their two dogs woke up in their own home.

headline: Report Shows North Korea Has Upgraded Its Military
text: The North Korean military, the world’s fourth largest, has bolstered its special forces units since 2008 and has deployed a new battle tank, called the Storm, the South Korean Defense Ministry said Thursday in a policy report. The report, based on a review conducted every two years, said the North’s overall troop strength remained the same, at an estimated 1.1 million. Only China, the United States and India have larger militaries. The South Korean military has 688,000 troops, making it the sixth largest, according to GlobalSecurity.org, a public policy organization. About 28,500 American troops are based in South Korea. Defense officials in Seoul said Thursday that the North had steadily upgraded its capacity and was better able to strike the South in unconventional and unpredictable ways.

headline: Sponsor and Baseball End Their Dispute
text: Major League Baseball and Anheuser-Busch said they had reached a multiple-year marketing agreement, ending an unusual public dispute between baseball and one of its most prominent sponsors.

headline: Denmark: Suspects in Plot Against Paper Face Charges
text: Three men arrested Wednesday in Denmark on suspicion of planning an imminent attack on a newspaper that published satirical cartoons of the Prophet Muhammad five years ago appeared in court on terrorism and weapons charges in Copenhagen on Thursday, and a fourth appeared in Sweden. A fifth man was released, but is still considered a suspect. The men in Denmark were accused of being in possession of a machine pistol, a 9-millimeter pistol and a silencer. The three men will be held in custody for four weeks, according to the Danish security police.

headline: Reducing Packaging Waste
text: To the Editor:

headline: Greece: Bomb Explodes in Athens; No One Is Injured
text: A powerful bomb detonated outside a court building near central Athens on Thursday morning, but warning calls allowed the area to be cleared, the police said. There were no injuries, though the building and nearby cars were damaged. It was unclear who was responsible. Anarchists in Italy and Greece have been active in recent weeks; in early November, a number of parcel bombs were sent to foreign embassies in Athens and beyond.

headline: Goodbye to Steve Boros, Bonus Baby, Computer Guy and Prescient Scout
text: Steve Boros, who died Wednesday at 74, spent half a century in baseball. He was a bonus baby, a major league infielder, a minor league M.V.P., a manager, a coach, a scout and a quiet pioneer, rarely with a high profile and sometimes at odds with what baseball expected.

headline: A Cooking Star’s New Challenge
text: Sandra Lee, the girlfriend of Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, has her cooking empire to keep her busy, usually in New York City, so she does not plan to spend much time at the governor’s mansion.

headline: Abortion Takes Flight
text: Irish law prohibits all abortions except those necessary to save a woman’s life, and as a practical matter it imposes daunting obstacles to terminating life-threatening pregnancies as well. In a secularized Europe, Ireland is noticeably out of step. Of the 47 countries covered by the European Convention on Human Rights, only in the fairytale countries of Andorra, Malta and San Marino, where all abortions are illegal, is the law any stricter.

headline: Putting Sobriety and Work Above Drugs and Crime
text: Larry Waldo’s family is so large that annual reunions involve a printed program 50 pages thick, with updates on family members and a four-day itinerary. Though Mr. Waldo, 59, has spent most of his adult life in prison, he said he was treated no differently from the lawyers, military personnel and politicians in his family, which is from South Carolina.

headline: Bloomberg Is Criticized on Storm Response as He Tours City Beyond Manhattan
text: On Thursday, the fourth day after the blizzard that inundated New York, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg toured the city and took his lumps.

headline: Renovated L Platforms Require Costly Repairs as Wood Planks Deteriorate After 2 Years
text: Wooden L platforms that were rebuilt over the past few years as part of the $530 million Brown Line renovation are already deteriorating at some stations.

headline: Plowing Complaints to Public Advocate Accumulated Like, Well ...
text: New Yorkers, it has been said, like to complain, and the city offers them several means to do so. Perhaps the best known  and by far the most used  is 311.

headline: Nonprofit Says City Took Revenge for Airing Views
text: Saul Bloom is preparing to pack up roomfuls of overstuffed binders in the offices of the small nonprofit environmental organization that he helped form almost 30 years ago. Arc Ecology, whose headquarters in a faded white storefront are protected by metal bars in the Bayview neighborhood’s crime-ridden Third Street commercial district, must move to a more affordable location after losing a key contract with the San Francisco Redevelopment Agency.

headline: Corrections
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Death of Jazz Club Underscores a Changing Scene
text: As another holiday season under a stagnating economy draws to a close, it is hardly surprising that San Francisco would lose that rarely profitable of ventures, a jazz room.

headline: Friday: Be Revolting
text: There’s the start of a mini-theme in today’s puzzle, with J.J. ABRAMS at 1 Down and P.T. BARNUM in the lower left. But that’s it. I guess we could call it an entertainment world BROMANCE instead.

headline: At Hotel for Capitol Crowd, Location but Limited Rooms
text: Albany is, in some ways, a part-time destination. When the Legislature is not in session, government, the city’s most vibrant industry, clears out.

headline: When 0.45% of Total Voters Can Translate to Victory
text: Scott James writes a column for The Bay Citizen.

headline: In Rose Bowl, a Chance to Study Size vs. Speed
text: LOS ANGELES  The Wisconsin offensive coordinator Paul Chryst not only calls plays, he writes story lines. When he sized up the Badgers’ battle with Texas Christian in the Rose Bowl on Saturday, Chryst predicted it would be easy to write about how the Badgers’ overwhelming offensive size would match up against T.C.U.’s defensive speed.

headline: 2010 Politics Brought New Faces, and Some Surprises for the Old
text: Ross Ramsey, the managing editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column.

headline: New Year’s Eve Schedules in New York Region
text: NEW YORK

headline: Texas Stands Against Tide in Retaining Biennial Legislature
text: Come January, as Texas lawmakers begin work to pass bills and tackle the yawning budget gap, they will go up against a simple but implacable barrier: time.

headline: ‘It Was Hell’: Dispatchers Tell of Flood of 911 Calls During Storm
text: As the snow deepened Sunday and Monday, roughly 100 front-line 911 operators in Downtown Brooklyn fielded tens of thousands of calls, struggling to sort the true emergencies from an ocean of concerns about stranded cars, twisted ankles and people simply stuck in their homes.

headline: At the Curb, Wheels for Free Expression
text: If the residents of the Haight, the Castro, the Mission and other San Francisco neighborhoods were given a giant public chalkboard, what would they write?

headline: Giants’ Offensive Line Is Intact, Good News or Not

headline: Big Boys Don’t Cry, Do They?
text: IN the next few days, Representative John Boehner will officially become the new speaker of the House of Representatives. While the Ohio Republican is not a universally recognized figure, people tend to know two things about him. The first is that his skin has an oddly orange-ish tinge, which some have attributed to quality time with tanning products. Mr. Boehner denies artificially enhancing his hue, and on “60 Minutes” recently, responding to the orangeness issue even brought him to tears.

headline: Worn-Out Fashion Terms
text: LEAVE it to fashionistas to try on new buzzwords like they’re going out of style. Whether it was our bromance with heritage brands, or the shellacking that some collaborations took, 2010 saw no shortage of P.R.-driven catchphrases and trendy terms. As with all fads, it’s time to put some to rest.

headline: Daphne Guinness, Fashion’s Wild Child
text: NO organ is more promiscuous than the eye, and no appetite more insatiable than the hunger to look. These truths go a long way toward explaining the preoccupations of a culture whose interest in imagery is defining. They also help one understand the ever-creeping appeal of fashion, a sphere that, like sport, is largely populated by arresting-looking people doing stuff that is legible without the help of words.

headline: Eric Wilson’s Key Fashion Moments of 2010
text: 1. Looking back at what truly resonated with audiences outside of the fashion elite, it is tough to think of anything more substantial than the hullabaloo that took place this summer over a single dress  one that hardly anyone had a chance to get a good look at. That, of course, was the white strapless beaded wedding gown worn by Chelsea Clinton at a top-secret ceremony in Rhinebeck, N.Y., on July 31. As it happened, it was a dress by Vera Wang, seen by the public in only a handful of official portraits released by the Clinton family. The dress had some silvery belt thing at the waist and a very tight fitted bodice, and what looked like a rushing waterfall of tulle below the waist. To no small degree of dissatisfaction among the fashion press, Ms. Clinton’s gown was not destined to be hugely influential in the tradition of bridal gowns worn by glamorous members of prominent political or royal families (i.e., Carolyn Bessette-Kennedy, Princess Diana, Ivanka Trump). But frankly, she could have worn burlap and remained at the top of this list, since half the fun was in all the anticipation and speculation. You can only imagine what 2011 has in store for Kate Middleton.

headline: Cathy Horyn’s Key Fashion Moments of 2010
text: 1. I wouldn’t have picked Dior’s January couture collection as a major fashion moment (John Galliano punched an out-of-date ticket for the Gibson Girl), but the scene illustrated the tension between the weird and the wonderful that exists in fashion. Dior held the show in the house, so everything was creamy with intimacy — just what editors love as they plop down next to friends — but it soon registered that Tavi Gevinson, the 13-year-old blogger, was in the front row. Some of the editors really hit her with looks. At the Armani show that night, the stares were openly hostile. It was obvious the older Italian ladies didn’t care to see a child in their midst. And Tavi wore a big bow-shaped hat that pointedly emphasized her juvenile stature. The fact is half the people were still in the dark about what was happening. Blogs? Strange ruminations from a girl’s bedroom in Chicago? They were still politely applauding satin ball gowns that Charles James would have whipped up in his sleep at the Chelsea Hotel.

headline: Excerpt: ‘Rabbit Hole’
text: Becca (Nicole Kidman) has been numb with grief since Danny, her 4-year-old, was killed by a car. Now, eight months later, her mother, Nat (Dianne Wiest)  whose son, Becca’s brother, died at 30  is helping Becca to put away, finally, the little boy’s things.

headline: Excerpt: ‘The King’s Speech’
text: In the first encounter between the duke of York (Colin Firth), known by family members as Bertie, and the unorthodox Australian speech therapist Lionel Logue (Geoffrey Rush) we see how Logue, who is impervious to royalty, begins to break down the barriers of class and position that have walled in the future King George VI, who has an acute stammer. The two men have been brought together through the persistence of the duke’s wife, the Duchess of York (Helena Bonham Carter), after conventional doctors have failed to help him.

headline: Excerpt: ‘The Social Network’
text: In the opening scene, Mark Zuckerberg, who would soon go on to become a creator of Facebook, discusses the importance of getting into one of Harvard’s exclusive final clubs with a young woman who’s slowly losing her patience.

headline: Excerpt: ‘True Grit’
text: On the frontier in the 1870s, 14-year-old Mattie Ross (Hailee Steinfeld) has set out to track down the man who murdered her father. She is aided by rival lawmen: Rooster Cogburn (Jeff Bridges), an ornery, hard-drinking United States marshal, and LaBoeuf (Matt Damon), a supercilious Texas ranger. As they gather around a campfire for the night, LaBoeuf’s speech is still impaired from a tongue injury he incurred during a nasty run-in with a band of outlaws earlier that evening.

headline: James G. Cobb’s Top 10 Cars of 2010
text: 1. VOLKSWAGEN GTI I had seat time in 2010 with some six-figure fantasies, including a gullwing Mercedes SLS and a blistering Corvette ZR-1. Yet my driving daydreams kept returning to this simple, fairly priced ($25,000), always entertaining hatchback. A four-door version adds more versatility, and a new direct-shift gearbox mates brilliantly with the turbo 4, making the GTI the most fun you can have at 30 m.p.g. For the price of a Porsche Panamera you can decorate your driveway with three or more GTIs — and it will look all the better for it.

headline: Unemployment Claims and Employment Growth
text: This is mainly an excuse to play with some of the features of FRED, the wonderful data site of the St. Louis Fed. On the horizontal axis are quarterly averages of weekly new claims for unemployment insurance over the past decade. On the vertical axis are quarterly changes in nonfarm payrolls. If I had been more careful, I would have taken out the Census jobs somehow, or just done private payrolls. Anyway, yes there is a strong relationship. The recent fall in unemployment claims bodes well for positive job growth; however, we’d really want to see numbers in the low 300s or below; only then would we be seeing the kind of job growth needed to climb out of our deep jobs hole in any reasonable length of time.

headline: Winklevosses Carry On Crusade Against Facebook
text: On Thursday, Tyler and Cameron Winklevoss, the cinematic identical twins who claim to have come up with the original idea for Facebook, almost gave up their quest to undo their settlement with the company, as I reported in Friday’s paper. It’s not hard to understand their indecision. They are sitting on a deal whose value has soared along with the steep rise in Facebook shares. By some estimates, the settlement is now worth more than $140 million, so risking that amount for a chance to get more seems, well, risky.

headline: Graphic Books Best Sellers: Another New Look at Superman
text: “Superman: Secret Origin,” published by DC Comics, enters our hardcover list at No. 3 this week. The six-part story, written by Geoff Johns and illustrated by Gary Frank, is a retelling of the formative days of the Man of Steel – from his childhood in Smallville to his move to Metropolis. This recipe for this retelling of the super-saga contains a smidgen of the television series “Smallville” (like the brief friendship between Clark Kent and Lex Luthor) and a pinch from the 1978 “Superman” film – Mr. Frank’s depiction of Superman is obviously based on the actor Christopher Reeve.

headline: Global Stock Markets Fight to Return From Recession
text: The global recession that began three years ago lives on in many ways. While most economies are now growing, few developed countries have recovered all the ground they lost. headline: Up Front: Why Criticism Matters
text: We live in the age of opinion­ — offered instantly, effusively and in increasingly strident tones. Much of it goes by the name of criticism, and in the most superficial sense this is accurate. We do not lack for contentious assertion — of “love it” or “hate it,” of “wet kisses” and “takedowns,” of flattery versus snark, and assorted other verbal equivalents of the thumb held up or pointed down. This “conversation” is often lively. Sometimes it is fun. Occasionally it is informed by genuine understanding as opposed to ideological presumption.

headline: Australia Floods Show No Signs of Retreating
text: Rising waters have knocked out roads and several highways in northeastern Australia, trapping motorists, marooning entire towns and driving thousands from their homes as flooding stretched into its second week on Saturday. More than 200,000 people have been affected so far by the floods, local news media reported.

headline: The Will Not to Power, but to Self-Understanding
text: Three years ago, Cynthia Ozick published an essay in Harper’s Magazine lamenting the decline of criticism, which she argued was impoverishing literature itself. Without the “consciousness that only a critical infrastructure can supply,” Ozick wrote, readers and writers are doomed to talk at cross-purposes, or at random; it takes a corps of influential critics to unite individual reactions into a common discussion. Indeed, this excellent novelist and excellent critic concluded, “Superior criticism not only unifies and interprets a literary culture but has the power to imagine it into being.” To see what we are missing, all we have to do is contrast our own moment with the postwar decades “when Lionel Trilling prevailed at Columbia,” and “Edmund Wilson, Irving Howe and Alfred Kazin enlivened the magazines.”

headline: Beyond the Critic as Cultural Arbiter
text: Fifty years is a long time in any national literature, but in the extreme environment of American culture, fiction seems to find an incubator for unusually rapid growth. A half-century takes us from the era of formulaic romances and Gothic novels to the metaphysical theater of “Moby-Dick”; from Mark Twain working on his autobiography to John Barth’s first novel. Yet across the 50 years since Alfred Kazin lectured about the function of the critic, academic literary criticism in America has arguably changed more than the modern novel, while the kind of critic that preoccupied Kazin — one who writes for the public, “lives in literature” and tries to create standards — now finds her function revised by technological changes that have reconfigured an audience that was once atomized by America’s urban sprawl.

headline: Inside the List
text: GUTENBERG MEN: The cover of the Jan. 9 Book Review contains a rare convergence of best sellers. The New York Times reporter David Carr (who spent three weeks on the nonfiction list with his 2008 memoir, “The Night of the Gun”) reviews a biography by Douglas Coupland (whose novel “Microserfs” was a business best seller in 1995) about the media-studies pioneer Marshall McLuhan (who had simultaneous paperback best sellers in 1967 with “The Medium Is the Massage” and “Understanding Media”).

headline: Masters of the Form
text: The inspiration for the six essays anchoring the Book Review this week was Alfred Kazin’s polemic “The Function of Criticism Today,” written in 1960 (and published in Commentary). But Kazin belongs to a long tradition of critics who have cast a keen eye over their vocation. In fact, Kazin’s essay echoes T. S. Eliot’s “Function of Criticism,” published in 1923, which itself echoed Matthew Arnold’s celebrated “Function of Criticism at the Present Time,” written in 1864.

headline: From the Critical Impulse, the Growth of Literature
text: “Your judgment . . . is true, but not all of it,” Tolstoy once wrote to the critic N. N. Strakhov, who had shared with the writer some comments on “Anna Karenina.”  “That is, it is all true, but what you have expressed does not express all that I meant. . . . It is one of the true things that can be said. If I wanted to express in words all that I meant to express by the novel, then I should have to write the same novel as I have written all over again.”

headline: The Intellectual at Play in the Wider World
text: I don’t think of myself as a literary critic. I write about novels and short stories. But I am reluctant to describe what I do as “literary criticism,” as I like to move quickly beyond the literariness of a text — whether narrative techniques or quality of prose — and its aesthetic pleasures, to engage with the author’s worldview, implied or otherwise, and his or her location in history (of nation-states and empires, as well as of literary forms).

headline: With Clarity and Beauty, the Weight of Authority
text: Is it time to write about the Death of the Critic, the proliferation of the app, the rise of the screen, the end of the discerning reader who curls up on a sun-dappled couch and devotes herself to serious books and their interpreters? Has the critic become a quaint and touching figure engaged in an irrelevant, positively medieval pursuit, like monks illuminating manuscripts?

headline: Translating the Code Into Everyday Language
text: I tend to shy away from big, sweeping, era-defining statements. It’s the fastest possible way to be wrong about the world, and usually just an excuse for various forms of sloppy thinking: cherry-picking, scapegoating, doomsaying, fear-mongering, sandbagging, arm-twisting, wool-gathering, leg-pulling. And yet it would be hard to dispute that over the last 5 or 10 years, the culture’s relationship to time has changed pretty drastically. The shift is so obvious that it’s boring, by now, even to name the culprits: Google, blogs, texting, tweets, iPhones, Facebook — a little army of tools that have given rise to (and grown out of) radically new habits of attention. Many of us are now addicted, on the dopamine-receptor level, to a moment-by-moment experience of life that’s defined by a behavior sometimes referred to as “time slicing”: jumping every few seconds between devices or windows or tabs, constantly swiveling the periscope of our attention around and around the horizon to see where the latest relevant data-burst might come from.

headline: Oprah’s List: The Finalists for ‘Your OWN Show’
text: Oprah Winfrey’s new cable network, scheduled to begin broadcasting Saturday, has announced the 10 finalists who will compete on “Your OWN Show: Oprah’s Search for the Next TV Star” for the right to become hosts of a program on the network. They include Zach Anner, a travel guide who uses a wheelchair, who was involved in an online-voting controversy related to the selection of the contestants over the summer; a minister from Texas who dropped out of high school and lived on the streets; and three aspirants who want to be hosts of cooking shows.

headline: Hedo Turkoglu: Same as He Ever Was
text: Hedo Turkoglu is back in a Magic uniform, and all is supposedly well again. On Thursday night Turkoglu had 17 points and 9 rebounds against the Knicks, and he scored a season-high 20 points in New Jersey only three days before. On first glance, a disappointing two-year stretch of Turkoglu’s career seems to have come to a close thanks to a midseason return to Orlando; he is scoring more, handling the ball more, and has again assumed the role of a late-game shotmaker.

headline: The Year in Review
text: The year 2010 was a fascinating one in the hockey world. And since it’s almost over, everyone who writes about hockey is required by law to do a “year in review” piece.

headline: Removing the Incentive to Skirt the Rules
text: The N.C.A.A.’s finding that Cam Newton’s father, Cecil, sought payment for his son’s enrollment at Mississippi State is only the latest in a long history of “pay to play” schemes in college sports. It has caused plenty of discussion, not only over whether Cam Newton shuold be allowed to play for Auburn in the B.C.S. championship game against Oregon on Jan. 10, but also over whether players like him should be paid.

headline: Jamie Dimon’s Year-End Bear Hug
text: As the clock to 2011 winds down, JPMorgan Chase’s chief, Jamie Dimon, took a moment to send the firm’s 222,000 employees some warm thoughts for the new year.

headline: Here They Go Again? ABBA Members Raise Idea of a Reunion
text: My, my, how can we resist them? Speculation about a possible reunion of the Swedish pop group ABBA, perhaps the most popular band in the world during the 1970s, is bubbling up again, following remarks by two members of the quartet. In an interview published in the British magazine M, the singer Agnetha Faltskog ruled out reuniting for a full-fledged tour “like the Rolling Stones and other old bands do now,” but said, “I could see us doing something together in the future,” perhaps in connection with a charity event.

headline: Stanford’s Harbaugh Remains Coy About His Future
text: MIAMI SHORES, Fla.  Emblazoned on the sides of the buses ferrying the Stanford football team to its Orange Bowl activities this week is the oversize image of its coach, Jim Harbaugh. He is depicted on the run, charging ahead of his players. But where is he going?

headline: The Sad State of European Deal-Making
text: It’s been bad a year for European mergers and acquisitions.

headline: Strong Finish Gives Paulson Fund Winning Year
text: John A. Paulson, that Midas of the subprime era, has done it again.

text: This week: Sam Anderson, Adam Kirsch and Katie Roiphe discuss the art and importance of literary criticism; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host. (Podcast Archive) //

headline: Critics on Criticism
text: In the Book Review this weekend, we asked six essayists to consider the question: What is the role of the critic today? In an accompanying feature, “Masters of the Form,” we briefly surveyed, through a series of quotations, the pantheon of critics who have puzzled over this same question — Alfred Kazin in 1960, T.S. Eliot in 1923, Matthew Arnold in 1864, as well as several in between.

text: In the Book Review this weekend, we asked six essayists to consider the question: What is the role of the critic today? headline: Classic Ad: Blizzard of 2010 Edition
text: Yes, plenty of New Yorkers have suffered the city’s snow-snarled streets with something less than equanimity. But here at the Wheels blog, we like to keep things in perspective. Case in point: our final classic ad of the year, which proves that with snow, as in life, everything is relative.

headline: A Cauliflower Bouquet for Winter
text: IN the icy, slushy cold of January, a light, leafy, scantily dressed salad seems as out of place as a tank top. That’s why I like to dress mine up in warming layers of cheese, meat, nuts, olives, capers, roasted vegetables and assertive, bitter greens.

headline: Chop, Fry, Boil: Eating for One, or 6 Billion
text: “Revolutionary” diet books flood the market this time of year, promising a life changed permanently and for the better — yes, in just 10 to 30 days! — but, as everyone knows, the key to eating better begins with a diet of real food.

headline: East Is East, and West Is West, but the Twain Are Now Meeting in Opera
text: BEIJING  On the frosty first Saturday of December, crowds packed the opera house of the National Center for the Performing Arts here to see “Xi Shi,” an original center production that tells the tragic tale of a legendary beauty from ancient China.

headline: ‘The Nutcracker’ Chronicles: In ABT Version, A Master Shows His Hand
text: Throughout Act One of Alexei Ratmansky’s new production of “The Nutcracker” for American Ballet Theater, you’re in the hands of a master. I can question perhaps 10 moments in it (the fight between soldiers and mice is relatively weak, for instance, while the concluding pose for the Snowflakes, lying back onto the floor as if exhausted, is a puzzle), and those incidental problems hardly matter. His version of the story is completely original in feeling, the whole tone of the drama frequently changes as you watch, and I have seen no work by this choreographer that better shows his powers.

headline: The Happy Marriage Is the ‘Me’ Marriage
text: A lasting marriage does not always signal a happy marriage. Plenty of miserable couples have stayed together for children, religion or other practical reasons.

headline: Getting Over Our Two-Year Itch
text: Every year, we buy zillions of music players, digital cameras and cellphones — and then, a couple of years later, send them to the nearest trash bin. “New every two” isn’t just Verizon’s offer to sell you a new, discounted phone every 24 months; it also describes the average person’s consumption habits for cameras, phones and other gadgets.

headline: Why a Budget Is Like a Diet — Ineffective
text: What would you do if your wallet became harder to open as your spending approached or exceeded your budget? Would you think twice about where your money was going?

headline: Favorite Political Moments Our Readers Left Out
text: Readers of The Caucus offered up more than 100 ideas for their top political moments of 2010. But the year was so chock-full of excitement that they forgot a few. So before the year ends, here are a few of our favorites.

headline: Want a Hit? Keep It Simple
text: LATELY I’ve been having a recurring sinking sensation. A hit on the radio gets my attention and doesn’t repay it; it adds up to little more than a dull thumping Eurodisco beat and a robo-tuned voice repeating an inane hook, something like the “Ay-oh, gotta let go,” in Taio Cruz’s “Dynamite,” or Justin Bieber piping, “Baby, baby, baby, oh” or the Black Eyed Peas chanting “Imma Be” more than 100 times (though at least that song goes through some rhythm changes).

headline: Michael Jackson Special Postponed
text: Following a barrage of complaints by some heirs and fans of Michael Jackson, the Discovery television network on Friday “postponed indefinitely” its plans to broadcast a re-enactment of the singer’s 2009 autopsy. “Michael Jackson’s Autopsy: What Really Killed Michael Jackson” was scheduled to be shown in several countries in Europe, though not the United States, on Jan. 13.

headline: A Diet for an Invaded Planet: Invasive Species
text: There’s a new shift in the politics of food, not quite a movement yet, more of an eco-culinary frisson. But it may have staying power; the signs and portents are there. Vegans, freegans, locavores — meet the invasivores.

headline: Comic Counterculture in the Northwest
text: IN the music video that kicks off “Portlandia,” a new comedy series making its debut Jan. 21 on IFC, Fred Armisen walks the streets of Portland, Ore., singing to a flat, synthesized soundtrack and praising the city as a flannel-clad slacker’s paradise where “young people go to retire.” As Mr. Armisen marches along the Willamette River waterfront, he is joined by stylish women wearing vintage eyeglasses, bearded men in leather jackets, circus clowns and finally by his co-star, Carrie Brownstein, who arrives with several facial piercings.

headline: The Family That Frays Together
text: Burbank, Calif.

headline: Screams That Charmed, and Other Overlooked Highlights
text: Every year arrives with abundance and leaves spilling overflow. Here are some of the things that didn’t fit into any of last year’s many critical boxes but should have.

headline: London’s Incubators of Idiosyncracy
text: House museums — the private realms and whims of inspired aesthetes put on public display — are something of a fetish in London.

headline: Paradise With a Past
text: Sydney, home of the good life in Australia, began as a gulag for British convicts. Amid its carefree beaches and bars, finding the remains of its brutal beginnings.

headline: Damascus
text: To the Editor: Regarding, “36 Hours in Damascus” (Dec. 5): Although the article suggests that a hotel in the New City would be “central,” nearly all sights of interest are in the Old City, within easy walking distance of any hotel there. The traffic elsewhere is ghastly, and taxis, though cheap and plentiful, may be as baffled as you are as to where you are trying to go. Carry a map. Finally, the Naranji restaurant, at the corner of Straight Street by the Roman Arch, is the place to see and be seen, with a lovely roof terrace, friendly service, and decent food to boot.

headline: Crested Butte
text: To the Editor: I am always delighted to see Crested Butte Mountain Resort, in Colorado, get attention in your ski guide about resorts (Dec. 12). However, although the steeps are amazing at the Butte, the terrain is actually wonderfully varied. This experienced but 62-year-old lady had no problem taking run after run on multiple trails with her snowboarding 20-something son. I love to tell people I ski Crested Butte because it has such a reputation for challenging terrain, but truth be told it is highly manageable and great fun for the average skier. And, if you’d rather not be with the super chic but with the super cool, this is the place for you.

headline: Books in San Francisco
text: To the Editor: Gregory Dicum’s lively tour of  “A Book Lover’s San Francisco” (Dec. 5) gives us many more reasons to visit everyone’s favorite city. But how could you miss William Stout Architectural Books (stoutbooks.com) at 804 Montgomery Street — one of the best in the world of its kind?

headline: In London, Private Homes on Display
text: AS the last tinges of lavender faded from the fall sky, a group of people lingered for a moment beneath a flickering gas lamp on the threshold of an 18th-century London town house. Were it not for the cars on the street, it might have been a scene from a century ago.

headline: Store Review: Andreas Murkudis in Berlin
text: Wandering through Andreas Murkudis’s cluster of sleek boutiques, hidden in a courtyard in Berlin’s Mitte neighborhood, one gets the feeling that Mr. Murkudis thinks of his shops more as intimate museums rather than retail spaces.

text: SHIRLEY TEMPLE once appeared in print ads for the Brentwood Country Mart, a beloved western Los Angeles retail village that opened in 1948. Ronald Reagan was a regular at the mart’s barbershop.

headline: Prime Number
text: 20: The percentage increase in the sales of armored vehicles last year in Mexico, according to the Mexican Armored Car Association. About 1,900 were sold in 2010, the bloodiest in the government’s four-year fight against the drug cartels, which has killed more than 33,000 people. A couple of years ago, armored cars “were for wealthy businessmen or the powerful families of Mexico,” said Fernando Echeverri, who runs a business that retrofits cars into armored vehicles. “Today the range of people has grown because ordinary people now feel the same risks.”

headline: Back Then: 1978
text: The economist Alfred E. Kahn died last week. As head of the Civil Aeronautics Board in the 1970s, Mr. Kahn was the force behind deregulating the airline industry. The Times’s Ernest Holsendolph was with Mr. Kahn in 1978 when he bumped into Frank Borman, president of Eastern Airlines, at what is now Reagan Washington National Airport.

headline: Fighting Words
text: A wave of criticism followed the conviction last week of Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky, once Russia’s richest man, on new charges of embezzlement. He has been jailed for seven years after challenging the authority of Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putin.

headline: Cuba’s Soap Subsidy Goes Down the Drain
text: It’s becoming more expensive to live — and keep clean — in Cuba, where the average wage hovers around $20 a month. Soap, toothpaste and detergent were set to be cut from monthly ration books as of Saturday, joining other items the government recently concluded were nonessential, including cigarettes, salt, peas and potatoes, The Associated Press reports. The government says the cuts are necessary to continue free or heavily subsidized education, health care, housing and transportation programs. “It’s already hard to make ends meet as it is, and this is only going to make it harder,” said Elias Conde, a 38-year-old father of two. “But we’re used to them taking things away. Today it’s soap, and tomorrow it’ll be something else.”

headline: Pakistanis Rally in Support of Blasphemy Law
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  A crippling strike by Islamist parties brought Pakistan to a standstill on Friday as thousands of people took to the streets, and forced businesses to close, to head off any change in the country’s blasphemy law, which rights groups say has been used to persecute minorities, especially Christians.

headline: Reminder for 2011: No Such Thing as Routine Chores
text: I often use my last column of the year (or, in this case, the first one of the new year) to air readers’ comments about the previous 12 months of columns. This year, I decided to add some of my own thoughts about what I have learned from readers.

text: There are plenty of marquee matchups besides the B.C.S. title game. Paul Myerberg tells Connor Ennis who he thinks will come out on top in this week’s edition of the Pregame Huddle.

text: KABUL, Afghanistan  Coalition forces killed the top-ranking Taliban official in restive Kunduz Province during an overnight raid, according to the Afghan police and a local governor.

headline: Room for Men to Work and for Astro to Play
text: FOR eight years, Brendan Mason had a great apartment in Clinton Hill, Brooklyn. His one-bedroom rental was in an owner-occupied brownstone with endless prewar charm. On the stoop one flight down, he would drink coffee, socialize with neighbors, have a smoke. His rent was less than $1,500 a month.

text: Here’s to a happy and healthy 2011!

headline: Congratulations to Estonia — or Maybe Condolences?
text: If I’ve got this right, Estonia will join the euro in about 40 minutes. It is an impressive achievement, a symbol of the country’s transformation from Soviet province to good European citizen.

headline: ‘The Nutcracker’ Chronicles: Listening to the Score
text: Whenever anyone tells you they want never to hear the “Nutcracker” music again, you know they haven’t been listening to it anyway. Tchaikovsky’s score is more diverse than any choreography set to it.

text: MOSCOW  Under extremely tight security, Ukraine has sent 110 pounds of highly enriched uranium, a significant portion of its Soviet-era stock, to Russia for disposal or storage, officials announced Friday.

headline: On the Stage, Old Words Are Reborn
text: “Wahuhrah, wahuhrah.” Exasperated pause. “Words.” That, more or less, is how Rory Kinnear pronounces the immortal redundancy “Words, words, words” in Nicholas Hytner’s new production of “Hamlet” for the National Theater in London. Those words (words, words) have of course been uttered more times than any calculator could compute.

headline: Council Grants Often Shortchange Needy New York Districts

headline: To See a Universe in the Tiny Details of Chinese Artifacts, Boxes to Birds
text: In 1969 the Conceptual artist Douglas Huebler produced his best-known artwork, a verbal statement announcing, “The world is full of objects, more or less interesting; I do not wish to add any more.” This made sense in the heyday of the countercultural revolution; manufactured objects were a major source of environmental and spiritual pollution. That is just as true today, and suspicion of the expensive, well-made object persists in circles of the contemporary-art world where neo-Marxist thinking lingers.

headline: The Hammond B-3 Lion Roars, Backed by His Pride
text: The organist Dr. Lonnie Smith played with his new big band for the first time on Tuesday night at Jazz Standard, and you know what they say about a big band on its first night: don’t go. Hear it after it’s settled a little, when its sound untangles, and the arrangements become refined. Give the soloists time to figure out what roles they will play, how to control themselves within the whole. Let a scene develop too: big bands sound best encircled by returning customers.

headline: Museum Wants to Return Objects, but There’s a Hitch
text: The Brooklyn Museum is preparing to return about 4,500 pre-Columbian artifacts taken from Costa Rica roughly a century ago.

headline: CBS Leads With Reruns
text: CBS dominated another night of repeats in the ratings on Thursday as its sitcoms and crime shows easily led during every time slot of the night. According to Nielsen’s estimates “The Mentalist” delivered the largest audience with 9.9 million viewers at 10 p.m. CBS’s rerun of “CSI” was close behind at 9 with 9.2 million viewers, about as many as tuned in to “The Big Bang Theory” on that network at 8 (9.1 million). CBS’s rerun of “$#*! My Dad Says” earned the network’s lowest ratings for the night with 7.3 million viewers at 8:30. Fox was a distant second place with back-to-back repeats of “Bones” at 8 (5.2 million) and 9 (4.5 million). ABC finished third with its holiday special “Happy New Year, Charlie Brown” at 8 (4.9 million), followed up by low-rated reruns of “Grey’s Anatomy” (3 million) and “Private Practice” (2.7 million). NBC ranked fourth with reruns of its Thursday-night sitcoms.

headline: Sarah Palin’s Nomination Chances: A Reassessment
text: In November 2009, I wrote an article entitled “10 Reasons That Sarah Palin Could Win the Republican Nomination.” The article wasn’t necessarily arguing that she was the favorite to take the nomination, but it did suggest she had a credible chance at it.

headline: Brazil’s New Leader Begins in Shadow of Predecessor
text: SÃO PAULO, Brazil  When Dilma Rousseff assumes the presidency of Brazil on Saturday, she will do so at a time when her country is thriving economically and full of swagger, eager to flex more of its newfound wealth and influence at home and abroad.

headline: Harrowing Cheshire Case Still Haunts Jurors
text: THEY check and recheck the locks on their doors and windows. Tears can come from nowhere. Images of one of the dead girls pop into their heads. Some have nightmares about children who need their help.
